nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And this one to record, so we have two things recording right now. Great. I'm going to step right into the process, do the script and everything. First of all, I want to welcome you all here. Thank you for volunteering your time to join the Real Talk conversation. As you know, Real Talk For Change is really set up to make sure that we are getting the voices of people who are often unheard from in the political process, to get their voice actually considered and part of what's going on with these current elections.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The way we're going to do it, we're inviting you to this conversation to do two things. One is we can help you think about what are the most pressing questions you might have about the future of the city of Boston and your place in it, and our goal is to kind of get those questions and elaborate on those questions, and toward that end, again, I just want to say thank you for all being here. I want to record these conversations, as I've told you before, and I want to share three things about what we do with the conversations. Okay? The first is in this room, we record the conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: These conversations, they will be uploaded into our system, but we will do a full transcript of the conversation, okay? If you decide, after we've had this conversation, there's something you don't want to be on there, you can let us know and we can, if it's a simple thing, we can redact it. If you want your whole part of the participation taken out, then what we have to do is take out everyone's, so we don't have any way to take one person out of the narrative structure, but if there's a particular thing and you say, "Hey, I need to have that removed, I didn't mean to use that person's name," we can go in and do that. Also, when we're talking, you can use any name you want. We only use one name, so you can use just your first name or your last name or you can make up a name, if that works for you. That's all fine and dandy for this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The next piece I want to go through kind of real quick here is also another thing that will happen to these conversations. Not only are they uploaded on the system, but we are giving ownership of these particular conversations to community groups. Usually the way we would do it is that whoever's hosting it, so like we're hosting here at the Neighborhood Center, right, we would give them the right of ownership of those conversations, so that if you wanted to change something, you would contact them and they would be the ones who would actually make sure that things got taken off and everything like that, but there's a default agreement that our system, which we call the Living Voice in this network, that these conversations will reside on that system, and right now, what that means is that the conversations will be public, okay? Anyone can come and see them and be part of them if they need be.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. I'm going to just keep going. I'm not going to stop, even though I'm changing batteries so I can add yet a third device to our conversation piece here. Actually, as participants to this conversation, what you actually need to do is give consent for Real Talk For Change to actually record this conversation. I need to have each of you go around and just say quickly, because we usually have this on Zoom, if you could just say your first name and say, "I give consent to be recorded," that would be helpful. Starting with you, [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you all so very, very much. Now I can start the third recorder, so this is actually really amazing. Okay. With that, I'm just going to jump right into the conversation. First thing we want to do is introduce everyone, all right, and see who's sitting at the table, but the way we're going to do it is through a very particular process. Something we call pies, right? Everyone's going to go around, and you can pick one or all of these to check in on, but what we'll ask you to do is say your name, say what part of Boston you're from, and then check in on one of the following four characteristics, either how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's pies. Physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. You can check in one of those, two of those, all of those if you're actually feeling, okay? Then after you finish checking in with your name, where you're from, and one of those, then just say, "And with that, I'm here." Okay? I'm going to do this in a circle format. I'm going to start with one person and just kind of move around to the right, okay? Zakiya, would you start us off, please?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: All right. I'm Zakiya. All my pies are in good shape today. I pass. Oh, was there one more thing? What was it?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Yeah, I'm Jamal. I live in Dorchester. Right now, I'm feeling a little tired, got off of work, but I'll be good.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: I'm Tara. I live in Roxbury. I will take... Let's see, pies. Spiritually, I feel strong, and with that, I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's good. I'm Ceasar. I live in Brockton. I think I'm going to check in, yeah, physically and emotionally. Physically, I'm kind of wiped because I'm supposed to be going on vacation tomorrow, and so you know what that's like. You pack a week of stuff into two days. Emotionally, I'm a little stressed because we're going down to Charleston and Savannah, and the Delta virus is creeping up more and more, and so there's just stress with the idea of going.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I'm Joe [Meldon]. I am from Jamaica Plain. I am... I think physically, I've been better than I have in years, and I am emotionally and spiritually... You know, been working on that. Working on that junk right now, but I'm here. With that, I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My name is Ron. I'm from Milton. Actually, I live in Milton, but I'm from Mission Hill. Spiritually, I'm fine. Emotionally is a lot of anxiety around this project, around what's going on in our community, but I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thanks. Good to have all of you here. Thank you for sharing. In this process, the way we're going to do things is we'll have the same basic conversation rules, which is we speak one at a time, and we speak for our own experience. There's no judgment to be offered here at all. The way we're going to start out is with a little task. I'm going to give you a little time to reflect on that, so if you need something to write on or write with, let me know, but the first thing I want you to do is think about this. If you got one question for yourself that you could state, that you could say, "This is my question about Boston and my place in it," okay, I want you to think what that question would be, okay? I'm going to give you a minute or two to think about that. What's your question about Boston?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: It's your question. You just take it and say, "I've got space, I've got time. I'm coming up with one question that for me is central about Boston." About knowing, if you want more context, the only other context I'll give you, about the future of Boston and my place in it. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. It's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it, and you've got to state it as a question. I'm going to give you about a minute or two just to think about that, so you can close your eyes, you can do whatever you need to do. Anybody need anything to write down?

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: For the record, so you can realize, Ian is actually my son's name, and I thought it would be nice to have him here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah, we're going to lose a lot of time. Here's what I want to do. What I want you to do, now that you've thought about your question and you know what your question is, I want you to think back, and I want you to think about what's the experience in your life that has led you to that question, okay? What have you experienced in your life that led you to that question? Because when we report out, what I'm going to ask you to do is say your question and tell the story of that experience, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The important thing about when I say experience, this is not about something you heard, something you read. It's not about statistics. It's not about that. It's about what you, in your own body, have actually experienced, okay? I'm going to give you a minute or so just to think about that.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I'm glad you're asking something that I've been thinking about a lot. I don't have to practice. I have to write it down. [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Especially I grew up at an age... You're probably the youngest. I'm assuming you're the youngest in the group here that we have [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Oh, you're writing down your thoughts. Okay. Fair enough. I have to remember that. Two of you might be Gen Z, you know?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. This is a problem facilitating with a group of people you kind of know, you know? Let's play it. Let's get into the facilitation. Would you like to start us off?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Let me just tell you what others have been doing. Everybody has their question, but the next stage is to think about what's the experience in your life that actually got you to that question, right?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay? Then what we're going to ask you to do when we get around to you is say your question and then also tell the story of that experience. The point is it has to be your own experience, and it has to be something you've experienced in your own body and time. Okay? Are you ready to start us off? We're going to go around again just in the same circle.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: My question, I'm trying to word it right, because in my head, it sounds right, so I've got to make sure I'm saying it right out loud, but when I think about... My question is, have you really thought about... I'm trying to say this right. How... [inaudible]. Have you really thought about how what you're doing is affecting the people of Boston, or what your choices are? So if I think about... This is coming from as recently as last night. I was on a community meeting for my neighborhood. I live in the Nubian Square area, and a developer is coming in and is trying to build two apartment buildings directly across from my house. Actually, I sat in my backyard on the Zoom and was looking at the property that they were talking about building on.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: I live on a one-way street, a one-way street from Blue Hill [inaudible], right? One-way street, and then a one-way street that hits here. They want to build a building here that has 41 units on two small side streets. The man that came in, the guy who's developing it and wants to come in, the residents on that Zoom gave it to him. I mean, gave it to him like, "You are disrespectful to think that you're going to come in here and build... The lots that you bought, the zoning is only 11 units that you can put there, but you're trying to capitalize on this space and put 41 units with 15 parking spaces."

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: I kept listening to this meeting and listening to him saying, "Well, I mean, I don't know what you're talking about. What do you mean? What?" Everybody was like, "You're being disrespectful to think that we don't understand this process." One girl had to say, "Let me tell you where I work. Google me. I work in real estate. I work with the city. I know what you're doing. Stop talking to us like we're stupid, and that you can just bulldoze in here and just tell us what..." He lived in Newton, and he'd been in different areas, so he's got a track record of doing this in other areas in Roxbury and not being honest.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: They were just very upset, and all I could think of was, "Did you even think about the other residents that live here and how what you're doing is going to impact us? Did you even think about that? Where are we going to park?" Now, we don't have... Now, I can see the sky and the trees from where I sit. Now, I'm going to have a big, red building in front of me. No green space around this apartment building. We barely... We part back-to-back on our street and when there's street cleaning, everybody's scrambling to find somewhere to park, so you've got 41 units, which technically could mean, if it's couples, 81 people, and then kids, and then cars, on two side streets that are very tiny. Have you thought about the impact to other people that are living here?

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: No, you just wanted to capitalize and make money off of that. That's my question. Have you thought? So as in, I'm thinking about what you're doing here, and the people who are now running for city council or the mayor, are you truly thinking about what you're going to do and how it's going to impact the residents of this city?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. Good [inaudible]. Good question, and a narrative story that was yours that went along with it. Great.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: My question is, why, in Boston, individuals are not as aware about all of their abilities to grow, and the ability to make change from within.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Oh, I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I thought we were going back [crosstalk]. Since I've come back to Boston, including the COVID year, which was about three years now, from the Washington D.C. area, where it's a predominantly Black culture, individuals there have a greater entrepreneurial spirit at a level of proficiency that you need to be in order to grow. I've had a challenge finding a group and multiple groups in Boston as a network, as a backdrop to entrepreneurial spirit, which I know everyone has, but for some reason, it's being suppressed.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to ask you just to elaborate on this story a little bit, because what I'd like to hear a little more about, you're speaking to something that you've witnessed.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: What I've witnessed in terms of that is... The first part, I live in the Codman Square area, and there is a young man that sleeps in his car, but he has a one-bedroom apartment. Not apartment, he stays in one bedroom within the house, but he doesn't feel secure within that one bedroom at certain times, and then there's things that he would like to do in that one room that he can't do, so he goes and do it in his car, like smoke a cigarette or something. That, I found, was appalling and degrading, and I felt like I had to help people like him. With my background being a builder, an architect by training, and a resident, long-term resident of the same neighborhood in Boston, I've seen that transition come firstly in the D.C., Maryland area.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: I've watched similar situations where housing was scarce and gentrification happened, but the city and the individuals in the city, I witness rallied around those who didn't have. This is observational. This is my observation from the data that I've seen. It seems like the politicians in the D.C., Maryland area really care about the residents, more so than I see here in Boston. On Boston, I'm witnessing a scarcity mindset versus an abundant mindset, and that's what's leading me to really come to the conclusions in some of the analysis that I've done, from being here just the short period of time, and as a caveat, I would like to see that change.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. I do want to just interject so we can first, I always think of these kind of narratives and stories as gifts that people are offering up to us. Something really precious and we should treat them as that, but listen deeply, because I'm going to come back and ask you about some of the things you're hearing, also. Joe?

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: My question is, I'm a graduate of... I guess I'm prefacing it as graduated from elementary school, middle school, and high school in Boston, then when I had the opportunity to go to law school, I wasn't really accepted here, but I was accepted to New York State and made a professional career there. The livelihood as a Latino, Puerto Rican kid, in New York City, in the Bronx, it was alive. I felt alive. I felt professional connection with other Latino professionals. There was a network of Black and Brown, and I felt good and excited.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Boston, what are you going to do to make this city a place not just for work, but for play and for fun, for our kids, my kids, and for my professional colleagues who are Black and Brown to enjoy Boston? Because you know what, Boston? I'm not going to stay here long. I may go somewhere else because Boston, to me, is a boring place. It's not exciting for me as a Latino. So what are you going to do, Boston, to make this an exciting place, not just for my colleagues of my age who are professional, Black and Latino, but for our kids, my kids, to make this a place they can stay, not just to work?

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Because Boston, you have all the smart people, you have all the great schools, but is it exciting to live? Is it a place that we can go out and have a fun time in a lounge with Black and Latino professionals? Is there a network that we can feel a connection to? I think that is up to you, Boston, to make it an environment, so that's my question, and my experience as someone having lived and grew up in Boston and then moved to New York City, is the background to this question.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I just felt a different self-worth and livelihood when I was in the city of New York, and I've been to other cities, and D.C., too. It's a different vibage. When I come to Boston, right, that parochial's still... After so many years, I come back to Boston, it still sticks. It's still there. The parochial is that idea that this is just a white city, and while I can pass in a lot of different ways, that wasn't for me. The connection was my cultural identity, connection from me being a Puerto Rican Latino in New York City, and being able to be with Black men, Black and Brown professional colleagues and friends that gave me a sense of connection like we're doing. That's my connection for that question. What, Boston, are you going to do to make this city a place for someone like me to want to stay?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Okay. Yeah. My question is, why are Black men and Black boys ignored and mistreated in the city of Boston? I speak not only from observation, I speak from experience, from my childhood. When I say I speak from my childhood, I think about white boys spitting on me, and I can still smell the spit and the liquor. I think about the Stuart case, when I was a young director, watching Black men being strip-searched in front of the cinema. I think about being called a nigger by a teacher at one of the most prominent high schools in the country, Boston Latin School. That's my experience, and the numbers don't lie. When the net worth of a Black family, African American, it's $8 compared to $247,000 compared to their white counterparts. [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: How can we ensure no one pays more than 30% of their net income for rent or housing costs unless they choose to? How did I get to that? Struggling to maintain quality affordable housing in Boston for myself and others, which is very different than my experience in D.C. in the 70s.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I mean, again, from your own... Because part of what we're trying to do is, "Okay. What has this person gone through in your life that makes that the question?"

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: There was more affordable housing based on housing policy, economy, being that even the federal government said no one should pay more than 30%, which is arbitrary in itself. Some of us would say no one should pay more than 25%, because otherwise, it becomes such a burden.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, in Boston, just yesterday, I was talking to somebody about it, or Sunday, I was talking to you about a two-bedroom somebody told me about. It's $2,500 a month. In my neighborhood of choice, Hyde Park, where my family owned an apartment when I was a little girl. Anyway. It's appalling to me that we are losing residents every day because of the high price of housing, and the lack of political will to do anything about it. It's a lack of political will to do anything about it. I can't believe how many of my friends in Boston's kids are moving out to where I was born and raised, in Bernardston, Massachusetts, and Fitchburg, and all those places that I couldn't wait to grow up and run the hell away from because there were so few Blacks, I couldn't have a social life. I was related to everybody, you know? Who am I dancing with at the dance? My first cousins. Way too [crosstalk]. And where did I go? D.C.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: His wife recruited me. She met me somewhere. She was just out talking to people in public about her husband. Effi was her name.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Okay. My question for the future of Boston is, how can we create a culture based on all children, parents, and professionals?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: What led me to that question was just doing the work that I do. Like the young man said over here, our children get lost by the wayside, you know? Schools are still overcrowded. The proper ratio is one to seven, and year after year after year, policymakers, they know this. That's why they don't send their children to public schools in Boston. They send them to private schools, because then they have smaller classrooms, and it's a thing that... A parent, and she said, she was a teacher, she said some of the classrooms, the ratio was one teacher to 30 children, and then they wonder why children in the suburbs bring guns to school, shoot up schools, shoot up malls, things like that.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Then in the inner city, there is so much gang violence. I went to a certain neighborhood, I don't want to call out a neighborhood, but there's a lot of neighborhoods like this, it had so much candlelight vigils for people who were getting murdered, killed. What about that environment? Not enough plant life in the city. Not enough flowers, trees, gardens growing, tomatoes. People, children are scared of their environment. Seeing the dogs, little dogs that are friendly, they're scared of little animals. They don't even know about nature, you know?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: I see all this with the work that I've been doing, and the policymakers, they know this and they don't even talk about it. When they write their policies, they don't think about any of them before they write the policy. My toddler, my preschool child, think about none of this. Go to DCF, a lot of issues over there. They live in an adult-orientated world. Should be a child-orientated world first. Our needs come second. I grew up in foster care so I seen this, I lived this over and over again. That's what I've got. That's my experience. I'm doing my part to help families out to make the future better where I live and Boston itself. That's all I've got.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I just want to kind of edit one thing you said, Jamal. Yeah, it's not all you've got. It's what you've got. All sounds too limiting, and it's your experiences, so I just want to say...

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What I'd like you to do now is kind of based on what you've heard. If you heard a question from someone that resonated with you, right, or experience that someone said, that, "Oh, yeah, I've got something like that, too," what I'd like you to do is just turn to that person and say their name and say, "You know that question you raised? This is my experience with it," or, "That experience you raised, here's how I relate to that." Okay? We're going to do this popcorn style. Whoever feels like starting out, turn to whoever you want to, and go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Tara. Tara, to your experience that you mentioned, I'll let you know, I'm an architect and a builder by trade, and a budding developer by choice. I hear you, and I know that a lot of developers out there do not care. The problems that I'm seeing is affordability of housing, where a one-bedroom studio is approaching $2,200, and the income that the average Black family, we already know is way below those needs. My question to myself and to the rest of Boston, how can we help? How can we help change that narrative where there's no Black developers of substance that will step up to that challenge? How can I step up to that challenge as a Black developer? And know that if the numbers are higher than a project, it's due to feasibility, to keep the rent lower, and that's the difficulty and challenge that any responsible developer needs to face, and I hear you.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: There's no need to respond. It's just whoever wants to go next can go. Again, connect a question you heard that you want to offer your experience to that question, or experience you heard that you want to elaborate on with yourself.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I want to speak to what Corey had mentioned about D.C. and what resonated with me about that. I've actually lived in D.C. for a while, I moved there for college, and the environment is just so different. It's like a family and people look out for each other, like our community used to be in Boston, in Mission Hill, but that's changed. I've mentioned this last night and I'm going to bring up the conversations that we've had about it lately. The silos that we operate in Boston, everyone's doing their own thing but not knowing what each other are doing, and that trickles down to even families. Families don't talk to each other. They don't eat dinner with each other. I think the pandemic has caused us to kind of stop and look and see that we do need each other. We do need to kind of look out for each other, but when you said that, I thought about how when I went to Philly/D.C. and I came back here, it was just like, "Ugh," you know? That kind of brought me back to that.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: I can relate to your story. One time, I used to play a lot of basketball growing up. One time, I was coming home from high school. It was like ninth grade. I used to live in the projects, and the jump out boys came out. I'm coming home from school, minor practice, tired, got my book bag and my Walkman. Cops get out of the car, just start searching me.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Shouldn't have to say this, but fast forward to this year, now, whenever I go by police officers, they're arresting people, all you've got to do is pull out your hand. They get spooked. You know what I'm saying? I walk by... Last month, these cops, it was the end of the month, and they pulled over a girl. First, it was a dude that come up. "Man, what's going on?" "They're pulling up everyone this time." All right. Went to go play some basketball, came back, then they pulled this girl.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: I stepped in the middle of the street, put up my hand, everyone came out. This white guy, he was talking to the girl, Black girl. He's turned around and seen me, got spooked, moved to the back of the car. A Black police officer who was sitting in the back of the car, he got out and he took over this scenario, and then they let her go. It was just like that. A whole crowd of people just came around. They just stopped, so... It's hot for the police right now, so all that dirty stuff that they did, karma comes. Karma comes and catches up with you, you know what I'm saying?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: That made you feel a little bit better, you know? They know they've got all that bullshit, you know what I'm saying? I can relate to your story. I haven't had... Actually, I chased a police officer one time.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: One time, I'm not going to say where it was at, this cop came out. They was clubbing at a certain club. I knew he was a cop. He came out. I knew he was drinking, too. Hit a girl.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: This cop, he called the station. His buddy came real fast. "Oh, we've got to [inaudible]." I knew he was something. Something was off, so I ran across the street and all his buddies came out. They cleaned it out. The ambulance came. That came fast. Everything fast. Then the girl, she was crying. She got a huge settlement and they fixed the light and stuff like that, but I knew he was drunk and he was scared. Cussed him out. "What the fuck is that in there?" It was a big thing. You can't get off the book for all the devious things that you do[crosstalk] your position in life, you know what I'm saying? So I [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: One part, too, I think the reason why I saw, oh, well, not saw, but thanks for vividly explaining that, I saw the cops run away, it's because of the cell phone, and that's been one of the equalizing devices I've seen, other than the fax machine. The fax machine was the first to speed up documentation and the cell phone is the light to shine on injustice, so thanks for sharing your story, really.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: But they still don't believe us. That's the thing. You can tape it, you can videotape it, and they still, they meaning the department of justice, they meaning white folks, they meaning many folks, they don't believe us.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to skip one of the sections because of the time restraints, so what I would like to do, and-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I probably shouldn't have added myself to this conversation, but I was just trying to, in response to you, Ron, saying, "I did know there was a time when we didn't get to live our trauma."

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: But what I'd like to do right now is just kind of go around to each person and just for you to say a closing word about anything you're taking away from this or gained from this, and then after we do that, Michael's going to ask you a few questions, okay? I'm going to start with Zakiya.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: I'm going to continue to be a participatory journalist. I'm fortunate to have DigBoston as a platform, and I can write about anything I want, or to write about what are we doing, just regular folks, generally speaking. Folks that don't necessarily have name-brand recognition, but sometimes. What do folks see as the problems and challenges, and what do they want to do about it? This just reconfirmed for me that that's the role that I'm supposed to be playing right now.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Catching those voices from the margins and lifting them up for folks to see, and making sure that folks have access to elected officials so that they can be heard. At least, that's my goal.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Oh. Oh. I am hopeful about the future of Boston. I used to live in Mississippi and the economy in Boston is way booming. Way more booming than Mississippi. At the time I lived there, I used to go about 45 minutes from [inaudible] murder capital, so if you haven't lived outside of Boston, you've got a good state that you live in. You've got some issues. Housing costs are extremely high. Need to get that down, work around a few other issues. It can get better, hopefully.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: I've got a lot of stuff going on in my head. I'll say one of the things that kept repeating in my mind as everyone was talking is, out of Dorchester CARES, I started a mom support group called Mothers Raising Black and Brown Boys, and it came about when George Floyd was murdered. I had some moms come to me and they said, "I feel like I need to do something because I have a Black son. What can we do?" This was something that had been sitting with me, and I just didn't know when to put it together. The timing wasn't there, and then when that happened, that's when I knew it was time. We just got some moms together, and we just talk about a lot of different things and support one another, but it's exactly what you're saying, Zakiya, too. I really believe that in the city of Boston, there is just a set of people in our communities who are not on Facebook, they don't watch the news, they're not reading the paper, they're not on Twitter, so they don't know how to get help.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: They don't know really what's going on, and one of the things that I really want to push and have been trying to push with the moms who do meet with us with Mothers Raising is I tell them, "We need to learn policy, and we need to learn legislation that affects but and protects our boys-

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: ... and you need to know that we are in a time in Boston where the political scene is shifting majorly, and you need to understand who's talking and who's sitting at what table and how you can get your voice heard, and speaking to silos." I tell them, "Boston is bunch of silos and we're not a silo. What we are is just a group of moms who will go to another group and get so their voice can be mattered," right? So it's not just us talking, but we're all talking, and then maybe that needs some more people to get [inaudible], and that's what you need to do, but it's those moms that I want to reach because you need to know what's going on in your city.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: You need to know that there's some things that are laws and legislation that's in place that are affecting your boys, and you need to be able to... We just did a community service announcement where our moms, we talked about, we made a one-pager and we said, and the title is What We Want Our Children To Know When They Encounter the Police, because we're worried about our children.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: But we don't talk about this with our children, so my thing was, "Let's do this one pager so we can get it on every refrigerator in the house." Maybe moms don't want to talk about it, don't know how, but that piece of paper will start the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: Right? Just, yep, Black and Brown men and boys, you know? And the moms who are raising them, they need support. I'm a single mom of a 14-year-old boy, and I need support, but they don't think that they have help and they're just surviving day to day. I don't want you to survive day to day. I want you to live abundantly, because you've got the opportunity to do that.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: So how can we help you do that? That's the kind of stuff that's just been building up listening. I've been saying that, like, "How can we get this information to these communities that need it? How?" I started at Mothers Raising, but there is other opportunities that I have in my job to speak to other parents, because I feel like everything that happens in our community starts small.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: How could... There's got to be... I want more ways to get to you, and doing this trauma work, that's some of it, right? Healing and recovery.

nodes.speaker: Tara
nodes.words: That's what I'm working on, and it's sad that I have to connect to you in trauma, but if I can connect to you in that trauma, I want to help build you up and build you up stronger.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: First, thank you all for sharing because you're in my head all the time, and a little bit of what I've heard from everyone truly motivates me to do what I'm doing. I've seen, and this is coming up, Ron mentioned silos. Coming back to Boston, that was the most glaring thing that I saw, that everyone was operating on this silo and had the same issues or concerns, and they weren't speaking and communicating to each other, and within seeing that, I've seen the flip side. I've watched D.C. go from the murder capital of the nation in 1989 to one of the best cities in the country and the areas to live in by the time I left.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: When I came back to Boston and I observed how things have evolved for some and stagnated for others. That's what's really motivating me these days because I get to see two worlds, one people, different outcomes. How I can make a difference is all I care about right now, because I truly believe a rising tide raises all boats. We've got to fight the cost of housing, but not at the point of lowering the cost for everybody. Making it a subsidy for those who don't have yet, and then also increasing the pocket, increasing earnings, where you can afford... Get life up to at least a living wage and beyond in the state and in the city that has some of the most universities per capita in that small area.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: [inaudible]. No, this is very good for me, being in the area that I'm in. I mean,[inaudible] politics and as a political consultant that's worked on my campaigns and focused a lot on narrative, and as a communication strategist, and for me now, it was everything. The story, who are you, what drives you, what hurt you, how did you survive that hurt? There's always something that is your core, and I always am interested in that. [inaudible] when I was doing journalism, kind of journalism myself, because I always like to get to the story and I think that's part.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: For me, I'm still trying to get an understanding of the city of Boston and what's it's core, and I only realized that the core is the people that live in there. I know that there is a change of, well, exactly with people from other parts of the world liking Boston because of its, as Corey mentioned, universities, and health, the health industries, the hospitals, ut there is still a Boston that's still been here for many years, and the generation of resident Bostoners, and a lot of them are Black and Latino that still live here. While I like to feel hopeful that this city is going to find those leaders that are going to make those connections and where everybody has the information but everybody also feels that this is, as I mentioned earlier, this is a city for them, for all of us. It's affordable. It relies on its influencers and leaders to make those connections to those people who don't have the connections to information, and then as... What is your name again? I'm sorry.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Jamal mentioned, and very importantly because I always think back about my childhood and my kids, when kids walk in this city and they walk around, that they see the parks. That they smell the flowers. That they can walk in a city that really feels like this is their own, this is home, that they're not scared of the dogs, that they want a dog because they're excited about who they are as a person. I want to feel hopeful, and I think the challenge for me is I'd like to see that leader and whoever and those leaders that are in our city and city government really take that into account when they say, "I have an opportunity," because we have the opportunity to elect a man that is a person of color, a women, possibly, likely, but that's just that.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: You would have to be a person who has a vision of the city as a city that's really going to make a difference, that's going to say, "I get to write a whole new chapter. I'm going to change. I'm not going to be like the old Boston, even though I may have come from that journey." So I am hopeful and would hope that the leaders, starting with the executive city, the mayor, is going to really be thoughtful about those things. How do I write the new chapter of Boston so that it is welcoming for all of our children and all of our residents?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I always get lost when I start listening to folk, and I forgot the question, but I was really paying attention. No, one of the things that I realized is that we do have to go back to the kitchen table. I had started out by saying we operate in silos, but we also operate in a microwave society. We're always going, going, going, and we don't get a chance to reflect on our experiences. For me to hear other stories that are similar to my story, that's important, and to know that you're not alone. Actually, you had mentioned the training and the civic engagement piece. That's why we've gone back to the old-fashioned way of doing things, right? Fill out the card, put it in [inaudible], lick the envelope, the stamp, the basic for those who think[inaudible], too. The basic stuff to reach folks that are not in the know, on TV, internet, social media.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I was doing you twice around. Okay. Let me say this. I want to thank you all for this. Before you run off and everything, Michael has a few questions he wants to ask you, because we want to just kind of get your sense of the whole process and how it was working-

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Okay. First of all, I want to welcome you and thank you for participating in the Real Talk for Boston campaign. I'm the campaign manager. I've been just hired by MIT Center for Constructive Communication. I'm also the founder of Dunk The Vote, and I'm really excited to be here with this exciting project because especially with the pandemic that we don't know what way it's going to go, but we still need to talk. We need to relate.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: This is an opportunity for us to reconnect, rebuild. I know both of you have went through either the Quarter Code or the demo conversation. But today, it was exciting. We had 14 people in the room without masks. We had our food. It was really exciting to be able to reconnect as we've been connecting. We're building up a community at Dunk The Vote with the Civic Engagement Leadership Lab, which is synonymous with what we're doing with the Real Talk for Change for Boston campaign.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: This is an opportunity for us to build trust, relationships and to build our community so that we can help ourselves, our family and our community as a whole. So I'm excited about this. As I mentioned, we've been in a hybrid mode and as campaigns go, you go all out for our people, for ourselves, to deal with experiences that we have. One of the things I want to make sure we reiterate is the fact that let's talk from our experiences because so often, we talk from issues.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: But let's talk from our personal experiences, how it relates to the future of Boston. So Ceasar's going to facilitate this discussion and we're going to be going in until 7:30. There's other folks who said, "Joe, we'll figure out how to weave them in," but again, I just want to thank you all because I know everyone's busy. Time is of the essence and I'm going to turn it over to Ceasar.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. So I want to talk about a couple of things. One, just to do a general overview of what this is about. I know Rob has talked to you before about this. So as he said, we're trying to get 100 conversations going on with people who often aren't listened to or heard as part of the public conversation that elected officials listen to them. We're trying to get those in by the end of August.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I think both of you have seen, when we do these conversations, we have this technology that allows us to both transcribe those, have the audios online to actually index that around things that have come up and from all of that, what we'll be able to actually bring all those conversations together and do something, what we call sense-making, which is really what's going on in these conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And then use that to both inform the debates that are going on, people who are interviewing candidates [inaudible] to really be able to let them hear the voices of people from Boston and also to give folks from Boston insight of what other folks are thinking about and the candidates too. We are going to keep this going.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We want to get to 100 by the end of August to impact the primary, but then we're going to keep doing conversations after that because we want them to create that opportunity for as many people as possible to have their voice. Our strategy for doing that is twofold. One is about having what we call lead facilitators. These are people who will get trained in our technology.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: They'll know how it works and everything, then they will actually help recruit two or three, what we're calling facilitators or hosts that each will conduct two or three conversations themselves. So that's our strategy. The lead facilitator identifies three facilitators. Each facilitator does two to three conversations. That's how we're going to get to 100 by having enough lead facilitators who feel they have a deep enough network to do that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're pooling our lead facilitators from across the sea, from different communities, from East Boston, from Mattapan, from Dorchester, from Roxbury, from Codman Square, from ... We're pulling them from all over. So today, what we wanted to do is make sure for those who were thinking about becoming lead facilitators, it is to actually take you through what one of the conversations looks like, how you participate in that conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So that way, you're familiar with the thing that we're asking you to take leadership around. Then after that, after you go through that, we will put you in a process to familiarize you with the script, give you recorders for recording conversations. If you want to do them online, we'll help you figure out how to set up the online spaces and so on and so forth. Then next week, I think we're planning to try to do something to get all the lead facilitators and facilitators together.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So we are all on this fast track. Then the week after that, we're going to have a big press conference, a launch of the event. So we are fast-tracking, moving fast. So that's one part of this. The other part of this is around the ownership of the data and information.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So what we are doing is finding community-based organizations that different people have trust in like Freedom House, Dunk The Vote, South End Technology Center, the Family Nurturing Center, [inaudible] who say, "We agree to be the onus of part of this conversations." So that when we do conversations, then even though these things, the data itself will be on this local voices network, it will be a local community organization who will actually own that data.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So they will be the ones you would interact with if you want to take something off, if you wanted to make it public or restrict it to only the people who are in your conversations. You will have the authority to do that by just going to one of the organizations that are actually serving as the data owners for this. Did I miss anything on that so far, Ron? Good. So if you're game for it, I'd like to take you through one of the conversations and Ron's going to participate this time.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: [Tarif], I know you've had a little bit of this, but we're going to go through the whole thing ourselves right now. The first thing I'm going to ask you to do is ... You can use whatever name you want. You don't have to identify yourself by your real name if you don't want to.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So I'm going to ask you to go to your settings and actually put in whatever name you want to be referred by. Right? So you can do that on Zoom. Does everybody know how to do that on Zoom on your phone?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah. Go into your settings and so ... I forgot how you do it on this phone. It looks different on the phone, but it does have the-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I hear. That's fine. That's okay. So let me ask you, what name do you want to go by? I'll just change it on here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Let me go back. I have to do this all over. Monique, how do you want to spell that? We have 1,000 spellings.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. How's that? We all have the right names or the names we were to go by for this conversation. Is that [crosstalk]?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's going to be good. So what I'm going to ask is because we may have background noise and stuff, keep yourself on mute until you're ready to have something to say, then we'll go with that. So let me off by saying thank you for agreeing to participate in this conversation for Real Talk for Change. As I mentioned before, part of these conversations are really our effort to create a new civic dialogue space inside of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're going to record these conversations and in a few minutes, I'm going to take you through three items that I want to talk to you about why we are recording, what's going to happen with the recording, and then get your permission to keep the recording going. Okay? So the first thing I want you to understand this, is that as I said, we're trying to create this new space across the state to facilitate more conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Part of doing that is actually being able to record these conversations and have them in a central place where people can look at them and we can share them. We can call them and actually begin to listen to what people are trying to say. So what this means is that we are actually recording all of these conversations as we go forward.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So what's going to happen with this conversation, with the recording is after this call, I will actually delete the video and the only thing we're going to be using is the audio portion of this, okay? That audio portion will get uploaded to our partner, Local Voices Network, to their site. That's where we will transcribe it. That's where we will also do the work of actually doing the coding and looking for the things that highlight better in the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Your conversation will be owned by one of the community organizations and we'll let you know which one that will be, but also, you'll have access to your conversations once it's uploaded there to see what's going on. Okay? Now, I just need to read this thing for you because this is one of those legal things you have to go through, so it's important for me to say this.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: It's that as a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent for ... excuse me ... Real Talk for Change and Cortico to use these recordings in accordance with our mission. You understand that the conversations will be part of the collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Cortico will connect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. All right. So if you understand this and are in agreement with this, can I have each of you go around and say, "I agree"? Monique, can you just say it again? You were-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Okay. So I want to set two little ground rules as we go forward. What is a good practice? All of you know this already. It's about speaking from your own experiences. That's a really important part of our conversation today. We're not talking about what you heard someone else experience, it's really about what you yourself have gone through. That's the grounding for everything we talk about today.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We want to make sure that people can speak for themselves, make sure that you're allowing time for others to speak. You can pause. You can take time for reflection. We'll have that there. Listen generously to each other. And if you need to take a moment, just let us know. Drop it in the chat and say, "Hey, I got to step out for a minute for something."

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That would be great. And if you have other applications or programs going, it'd be great if you can cut them down on your cell phone. So I don't have to tell you to mute them because you can do that anyway. Those guidelines okay with everyone?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. And if you can be on camera, be on camera. Ron's usually the one who says this the most, and there he is. So Jamal, we want to see your beautiful face too, brother, so we can all be here with each other. Great. So the first thing we're going to do is around the introductions. The way we do the introductions is we use this process we call [Pynes], right? I'm going to put this in the chat so you can see it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: But the idea is ... excuse me. I'm going to ask you to check in on one of four things, right? Either how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. You can take whichever one you want. So what you're going to do, what we want you to say is your name. Give us the community that you're connected with. And if you know the zip code for it, the zip code for that one, that will help us identify this later for geospatially. And then take one of these four elements and check in on it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You can check on anyone you want. Then after you've done that, just say, "And with that, I'm here." That's the way it's basically said when you're showing up. So I'm going to model for you. So I'm Ceasar McDowell. I'm actually calling in from Brockton, Massachusetts, 02301 and I'm going to check in physically actually, right?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Earlier today, I was doing really good, but then I think I just spent too much time in the car today and now, my body is really tired. My back is aching and I need to do some stretching. But I think after I do that, I'll feel a lot better, and probably after I eat dinner too. With that, I'm in. Who would like to go next?

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: I'm Monique. Hi, I'm Monique. I hail from Hyde Park. Today's spiritually just a little down but I think it's mostly due to, I need to regroup, rewind and exercise and get myself back on track again. And I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My name is Ron Bell. I am working in Boston. I live in Milton, grew up in Mission Hill, 02120, 02115, 021... you know..., Roxbury, Dorchester, Mattapan. I'm going to check in spiritual and emotionally because on the emotional front, it's been a rollercoaster coming out of the pandemic, not sure if we're still in it, but yet we're still in it, but not sure we're in it spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Also mostly, I lost a good friend and I have a chance to speak at their funeral tomorrow, which is hard. And to lose a lot of folks, family members and people in our community due to the pandemic and other reasons, spiritually, [inaudible] was helping me deal with emotion. So I'm glad to be here and I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. Thank you, everyone. It's good to have everyone here. So as I said, we know we're at the historic point in the city of Boston with the election now, this mayoral race and these [inaudible] candidates who are in that and the city council. But we also know that as we shift the restrictions of the pandemic, it can be easy for us to lose sight of what we've learned about inequality in America and in Boston and how our lived experience did shape that journey.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So part of what we're doing today is actually going to really get to the core of that. We want to start out with a proper round of questions. So we're going to do this in two rounds. The first one is, I want you to think about this and respond to it. What's your question about the future of Boston, right, in your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Just think about it for a minute and let's hear what you have to say. It's one question. The way I'm going to do this, instead of pop up, what I'm going to do is put a little order in the chat of how we're going to talk. So it's going to be Jamal first, then Monique then Ron. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: My question about the future of Boston? I'll go about what I said previously. The future of Boston needs to be more child-orientated and more focused on the children instead of more being more adult-oriented. We need to focus on the policymakers to focus on, before they write their policies, what about the children? Think about the children before you sign.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Any deal, any policy, any legislature, anything, all the schools, they focus on what the adults needs are instead of what the children's needs are. And I don't understand this ... huh?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: No, go ahead. So I'm going to push you a little bit. This is my job. I want you to actually take that because it's really powerful and see, how can you express that in a question?

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: Hi, I guess my concern is that I'm concerned about the poverty and the homelessness that I see. It's very depressing and it's sad to see that. My question is what are we really doing about this, especially through this pandemic? And a lot of homeless teenagers also.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Sure. My question for the future of Boston is, how do we not continue to ignore black men and black boys in the city of Boston? From my experience, growing-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: But I appreciate the question. So we have these three questions with us right now. We have a question about how we can become a child-centered city. There's a question about what do we do about homelessness in our society.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And the third question that came up was really about ... Oh, it went away again. I want to make sure we have it exactly the way you would like. That question about black men was ... How did you say it again? Can you just say it one more time?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Why do we continue to ignore and mistreat black men and black boys in the city of Boston? Great. So now, here's the second part of what I want you to do. Ron almost jumped right into it, so I had cut him off. Only he knows what the next part is going to be but I want you all to catch up. So the next part of this is giving you a question. What I want you to do is tell us a story, an experience you had in your life that really, that question comes from, all right?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So our notion is that if you have this question, it must be something you've experienced that actually has gotten you to that question. So what we want you to do is think about ... I mean, you may have many things you've experienced. We've gotten into that question. We'll take one of those experiences and telling it as a storybook. Okay? So not as a summary, not as a critique, but as a story, what was happening to you.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Make it, in some sense, in the physicality of you being in a place at a certain time or a certain set of events happened that for you are really what's connected to that question. Does that make sense to each of you? Sound like something you can do? I'll give you a minute to think about it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Jamal, I think if you can just turn on the video, that probably would be your story, huh? It's right there living with us. I love it. Okay. So we're going to do this in a different order. We're going to start with Monique, then we're going to go to the Jamal and then Ron. Monique, do you think you're ready with your story?

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: Well, my story is short and simple. Basically, coming home one night after being out with some friends, spending money, having a good time and coming across some teenagers or just sitting out on the sidewalk, no home, nowhere to turn to, no shelter and they needed food. And I thought to myself, "I've spent all this money to have myself a good time," and a couple of my friends were basically saying, "They're just trying to hustle you.

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: They're just ..." This, that and the other. It touched my heart because I ended up ... One girl started crying because she wasn't from Massachusetts. She had been brought here by someone else. I really didn't know what to do except to actually go and get them some food and sit there on the sidewalk with them and just listen to them. And basically, at that point, that's what they needed, just somebody to listen and really believe.

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: They needed some help. Eventually, I had to leave them because at that point, at that time, I didn't know who to get in touch with to help them. And that broke my heart, that I couldn't do anything for them. But I was able to feed them and sit and have a conversation for a couple of hours and left my friends and let them go on. So that saddens me. The homelessness has gotten worse. I don't see it better in any way at all. Yeah, that's my story.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you for sharing that. Thank you so much. When we hear these stories from people, we have to ... I always like to say these are really gifts that people are giving us and they're precious. We have to hold them and respect them as such and thinking ... Jamal, do you want to tell us a story for you that's really connected to the question you have?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Sure. I'm just thinking, growing up, I'd be really [inaudible] but just growing up and seeing all my friends as an adult and looking back and seeing all my friends growing up in single-parent homes or in foster care, or being raised in some other environment other than their biological family members.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Oh, one sec. Hold on. [inaudible]. Yeah. Just growing up and seeing all my friends being raised in an environment other than their biological parents and single-parent homes, foster care, just not a male figure around at all. Just seeing them as adults and seeing their whole life, it sparked the question, what about the child? All their childhood experiences, it's a lot of traumatic stories and trauma related to their first five years of life.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: So that's where it prompted me to have the question of, why can't we make it a child-orientated world instead of an adult-orientated world? So that's where I started to ponder on that question. So that's what made me think. The first five years of a child's life is so important. Those experiences are almost even more important than the whole education, 12 years or 14 years or whatever of their education. So that's my story.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My story is so many stories as a black boy, black man being in Boston, growing up in Boston. At the age of nine, I remember vividly going to Cub Scout every Wednesday, being spit on by white boys, drunken white boys who were bigger than me ... I was nine years old ... teenage white boys. And they would spit on me, drunk, and I would have to go into Cub Scout smelling of liquor and spit. I can still smell the liquor.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: One of the opening songs we were saying is my country ... Or recite, "My country, 'tis of thee, Sweet land of liberty," but I didn't feel very free. Fast forward, as the executive director of the community center I used to go to as a child, as the assistant director going into the director, I was initiated with the child steward tragedy in 1989 in October. I can remember the date and time, seeing black men being strip-searched, civil rights savagely violated.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I'm being the director and I had to turn around because I didn't want to be subjected to it. These were my friends. These were my participants in the community center, people that grew up with me, family members. Actually, my cousin, who was a former city councilor, was one of the kids. I skipped over something very important because I know that education is pointing ... And this has been in the news.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: One of the most prominent high schools in the city of Boston throughout the country, the first public school ... In the seventh grade, I was accepted in Boston Latin. I did not want to go there, but my mother made me go there. But during my tenure there in the seventh grade, I was called the N-word by a teacher. So I continued to fight for the freedom, the liberation of black boys and black men. I have a 21-year-old son.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Every time I look at the news, I'm afraid of the young people I've helped, the brothers I see. When I opened up, I said I'm emotionally, spiritually in that zone, trying to deal with life. I lost a friend, I'm speaking at his funeral tomorrow, who happens to be connected to an elected official, our mayor. I fought to help black men with an effort to form a commission that was denied. That's my story.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Stories, yes. Very well. Thank you so much. So I just want you to [inaudible] on what you've heard and what I'm going to ask you next is in the questions that people raised or the stories they told. If you too have an experience that connects to either someone else's question or someone else's experience that you'd like to share, something that really connected and resonated for you, what I would love for you to do is turn to that person, address them directly.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Just tell them what part of their question you would like to contribute an experience to, or whether that experience resonated for you and why, and what experience you had that connects with that. So this is going to be pop-up style. Whoever feels like going first can go. This is a time to talk with each other about what you're hearing and what is coming up.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Yeah. My story connects to both Monique and Ron. It goes back to child honoring. You need to honor each professional, each child, each parent. Meet them where they're at, grab their hand and just go from there. There should be no poverty. There should be no hunger in the most richest country on earth in America. With Ron, that being the racism, I'm blacker than Ron, I think. I don't know how ... You aren't going to compete shades.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: You know what I'm saying? But I've experienced racism in a lot of things of that nature. But if you honor each person, whether they're Chinese, they're black, they're Asian, white, whatever, you start teaching this in school, child honoring. It's called child honoring. You teach it in school. As they grow up, they'll learn, regardless of their parents' ideology about different races, they'll respect and honor that human being and work with that human being.

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Diversity is our strength. So my story does connect with all of them. Right now, we're in a culture of just extreme anger, entitlement, violence, anger violence, gun violence, drug, pandemic. All these pandemics and this culture, it's crazy. So let me just focus on the children, making the best for the children, what's right for the children and keeping them happy and giving them the best childhood that they could possibly have imagined. That's all I got, bro.

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: Hi. First of all, Ron, I'm sorry that that happened to you because I grew up in the busing era, forced busing and that was every day for me, every day. There was also ... My family was one of the third black families that moved to Hyde Park. I can remember vividly with my dad having to go out and scrape his car off from eggs, being egged overnight, nigga being written on the fence, being called that all the time, in school, constant riots all the time.

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: It's like every day, which way do you go home? Do I take this route today? Can't get on this bus. Or you get on the school bus and they're trying to tip the school bus over. "Go home, nigga." I'm sorry you had to experience that, Ron, too. It's not a good thing to experience and you remember that from a kid and it sticks with you in a matter of ... You lose trust but you can't lose hope. That's my story.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Yeah. I resonate with both Monique and Jamal and even more so now when you mentioned that, Monique, that during that time I was called the N-word was during busing. It was in 1976 when I started at Latin and I remember how during busing, the Boston Latin and Boston English, Boston Latin where I was a student, predominantly white Boston English, where all my friends were mostly at, predominantly black.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: There were times that folks, whoever would pull the fire alarm and the white kids and the black kids, 1976, I would come out and it would be a riot. I would have to go back into a school full of white kids that fought my friends. So the busing ever ... We've talked about racism, we've talked about our experiences and our story, but that just brought me back and it was a trigger for me because you can't put a bandaid on racism because it's like putting salt in the wound.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: It festers. I'm feeling this now. Jamal, my mother was a foster parent and she probably had about 30 young children that called her mother. I had a whole bunch of mothers, bro, [inaudible]. She made the best fried chicken in the world and I got a recipe now. But to see you as a father, with the stereotype of black men, I see it right here. You have two beautiful daughters. I see that. Right?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: And when they say black men left their families, there were no father figures for you, but there, you're doing something special. You're doing something that a lot of black men do. So not only do I hear you, I see you on this Zoom call, on this conversation Real Talk. So I resonate not only to what you say, but what I see [inaudible] each other. And we're the same color, bro.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Well, we're near the end but what I want to do is offer each of you an opportunity to say anything you want to say in closing as we start to shift down from this conversation. We could go more, but I think we're at the time, given what we settled on during the day.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So again, I'm going to just go around and we're going to start with Jamal then go to Monique, end with Ron. Just anything you want to say in closing. Jamal, do you want to start us off?

nodes.speaker: Jamal
nodes.words: Sure. Yeah. I'm just glad to be a part of these conversations because I think there's something special that's going to happen or that's going to come from it. I don't know what it is, but I know in the future, we'll figure it out. When you start talking about problems, you start talking about solutions. That's all I got, bro.

nodes.speaker: Monique
nodes.words: Well, I'd like to say thank you to all of you. This is very enlightening. I released some things. It made me think about some things that I really want to get into, do more, volunteer more and really try to make a difference. Jamal, keep up the good work, keep up the good fight. You're a wonderful dad. Ron, as always, keep up the good fight and, Ceasar, thank you for your time and for explaining and for listening to us. I appreciate that. That's all I have.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Thank you. I just want to say thank you to all for being courageous enough to tell your story. Sometimes, particularly in the black community, we don't tell our story because it's too painful and it hurts. It really hurts to relive our trauma. I just want to thank all of us for doing this, but at the same time, I want to say this, that we have an opportunity to do something different to build relationships, not only with each other but with ourselves.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: One of the things with Dunk The Vote we've done is to get to know ourselves because we've been in this pandemic. We are starting to realize and to feel. We so often try to quantify, qualify the numbers and this and that, whatever, but we don't talk about how we feel.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I think that's important, telling our story because it is therapeutic. It hurts, but it is therapeutic. So I'm ready to not only take this journey with you all, but I'm ready to make Real Talk for Change a reality in Boston. That's my goal. I just thank you for doing that with us.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you, again, to each of you for taking the time for not only being here, being present. Being here and sharing your story to each other and for listening, all right, with an open heart to each other. We have a lot of work to do, but I think our ability to listen and to bring our stories forward as part of getting our work done [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Something we were going to end with a more [inaudible] outcome is if our solutions are grounded and trying to address the way we are experiencing the issues and the problems in the world. So with that, I'm going to stop the recording but we're still going to stay online. We were trying to [inaudible] for the quarter. Let's see.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. I'll put the recorder in the middle of the table and I'm going to tell you a little bit about why I have this here and we're going to ask your permission to record, but I'm going to turn it on right now so that I can actually make sure I can record me telling you why we're recording this and getting your permission. Okay? So that's where we're going to start. So, first of all, I want to thank you all for giving up your valuable time and participating in the real talk for Boston conversations. These are a set of conversations we're trying to support people around the city of Boston to have that we believe can actually have an influence, not only on the upcoming elections, but really provide a way for people to make sure that their lived experiences are being considered, not just for the election, but also to build a network of conversations that actually can be used monitor what's going on in society within the city.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: There are a couple of things we're going to ask you to do in this process, but before we do that, I want to talk to you a little bit about why we're recording these conversations. One of this is... And I need to start with the purpose, I guess. The purpose is we're trying to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across communities and within communities. So we're inviting you to this conversation, which we think is going to be a little bit different than what you have normally have experienced. Then the second part is, let me say a little bit about the recordings. Okay. So following this meeting today, actually don't worry about that. I have a scratch because usually we do this on Zoom now and we tell you that we're going to throw in the video and only use the audio. So all we're using today is the audio. Okay? And... Is Eldin joining us? Are you going to join us?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Come on, sit down and get rolling where we are at. Okay. So anyway, as I said, normally we do this on Zoom and I realize this script has all the Zoom cues in it, as opposed to just we're in person. But so normally what we do in these conversations is what we're going to do is we record these conversations. They go into something, what we call the Living Voices Network. It's an online forum that we are actually able to lift the recordings into, get a transcript of those and then that transcript in and of itself will be visible online. And our technology then goes through and looks for the things that are in the conversation. And you can actually search through the conversations by the things that are in there.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And so this will allow us to connect. What we're trying to do is honor the importance of small conversation, and then at the same time, be able to connect across small conversations to really make something much bigger. So what we're asking really right now is that as a participant in this conversation, that you are going to provide consent for Real Talk Boston to use and retain this recording in accordance with our mission. And that you understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Living Voices Network whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. So we will collect, retain and analyze those conversations in keeping with that mission. However, the ownership of those conversations, who owns them will actually be a selection of community-based organizations throughout Boston.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're working on the final agreements, but we know since they will actually do one, the Southern Technology Center we'll do one, there'll be one of the hosts and owners and we have Inductive is going to be another one. And the Family Nurturing Center is going to be another one. So we have a couple of community-based organizations who will actually serve as the owner of the data. So MIT's not going to own it. Cortico is not going to own it. Community-based organizations are going to own it. And if you decide at any time you want to not be on the system anymore or something like that, you can turn to a community-based organization who can help make that happen. So that's the way that we're going to move in with that. So with that understanding, what I need to do is have each of you go around and say, if you are in agreement with this and you're willing to be recorded, and this is the last of the formality. So can we start with right there?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: As a facilitator. Okay. Yeah. So I'm cool. I am here. I agree. I'm sorry. I fucked it up. I'm here and I don't work fully at the little kids table. I haven't been out much lately, so yes, I understood that I'm being recorded and I consent to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: All right. Good. Kind of sitting back there. Yeah, I know. [crosstalk]. Okay. Okay. So we're in this now. We're in this and we're starting to work and it's recording. So with that, just a couple of ground rules. This is a very structured conversation. So I'm going to give you some prompts. I'm going to ask you to respond to those prompts only and at one point we'll have a much more fluid and open flow. One of the things that's really important about this conversation is, we ask you to speak only for yourself. Everything in this conversation is about grounding in your own experience. So it's not about analysis from other things. It's not about what you heard from somebody else. Everything that you speak about should be grounded in your own experience. Okay?
