nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So that's the framework that we have for going forward. Great. Next, I think we can get started. Now we're going to check in. We didn't check in before a little bit to see who's here at the table. And we have this little exercise we call PIES. Has anybody done pies before? People like PIES, right?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Good. So this is checking in on how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. That's PIES. Right? Okay. So I'll say that again. Check in how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. You don't have to do all of it. Only one of them. Okay? And so here's the deal. Go around and you say your name, say where part of Austin you're from, and then check in on any one of those items. And then once you finished checking in on that item, what you say is, "And with that, I'm in." Meaning, I'm here and present. And I'm going to model for me. My name is Ceasar McDowell, unfortunately, I'm not from living in Boston. I live in Brockton right now. I'm going to check in emotionally right now. Mostly I'm in a really fragile space, lost a really good friend last week. And then my second mother who just took off the life support yesterday. So this is a lot like emotional fragility. But with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm Francesca Bell Sandra also known as Franc Smith, and intellectually I'm super overstimulated and really excited about my brain still functioning so well. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: Hi, my name is James, Mattapan.. And basically, a physical thing here. I'm overweight. I got to lose weight and blood pressure is up. So, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Good afternoon, I'm Marilyn Foreman. I am from Dorchester and I'm spiritual. And I'm giving thanks that I was able to wake up this morning and I could see, I think of in my right line. And I just feel good about being here and having the opportunity to give up myself to the Almighty. And with that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Dawn Duncan and I live in Lynn, and I would say emotionally I dissent feeling. It's great to be like in a physical space with other people, for having such a long period of time where we didn't have that and being around like real people. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Quanda Burrell. I'm from South End / Lower Roxbury.. I love to check in emotionally, I am excited and hopeful. And for that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: miguelkingone
nodes.words: I'm miguelkingone from the South End and I want to check in, I think intellectually. I go through stages. I feel like I know what's up and sometimes I feel like I don't. So right now I'm at that introspective stage where I'm trying to absorb. And I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. It's good to have everyone here in this conversation. So we're going to get started with the first part of this. So this may seem a little odd, but I'm going to ask you to... If you have something right on, if you need something to write with we can get it to you for sure. If you have a piece of paper and pencil. But for this first thing, I want you to think about this. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? Right? So I want you to think about how you're imagining the future of Boston. All right? Again, it's hard. I'm going to say it again. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? Would you think about it for awhile? And we'll give you a couple of minutes and try to formulate the question.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: [inaudible]. Get in. Doesn't have to be an essay. Doesn't have to be an essay. Okay. Can I go to the second part? The people who were ready to go to the second part? People who they got a question? The second part is, I want you to think about acting your life and I want you to think of a story that is an experience in your life that actually got you to that question. What experience in your life actually gotten into that question? Because the sense there is that these questions don't just come out of our heads, they come out of our lived experience, what we've seen in the world, what we've experienced ourselves. So I want you to think back to your life and connect, explain one of your experiences that really are about that question.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And I will say this as you think about that, we're going to share the questions and the experience. And when you share the experience, I want you to share it as a story. Okay? All right. So I can give an example of that instead of saying, "My question is, will it ever be safe to walk down the streets of Boston?" I just put that up. Then my experience is, "I got scared one day walking down the street." That's not a story. All right? We want a real full story that really explains and gets at what really you were experiencing at a particular time that really is connected to the question that you have.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You don't even have to write the whole story. Once you know it, you can just say it. Just you might write down a little note to yourself. "Oh yeah. This is the story I'm going to tell." That's all you have to do. You don't have to write the story. Okay. So who would like to start us off?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. So first, what I want you to do is tell us the question that you had, and then tell us the experience that you had.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. I would say the experience for me is equality. I grew up in Allston Brighton. And one thing I remember is coming home from the basketball game, my myself, my cousin and my brother, and we was getting ready to get run down because of the [inaudible]. And I hate to call them nuts, different ritual name. So walking out and then I came to this side of town, which was Dorchester and it was totally different the way blacks and whites treated each other, more so the way blacks treat each other. That was a different story for me. So I would say equality. I would love to see equality, more no to politics from all ethnicities. I would say that. That really sticks out for me.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. I want to remind everyone else, if you're listening, people who are really in these experiences and stuff, they're offering us little gifts and so we share armaments, their stories and stuff, and we're going to come back to it. So listen very carefully to what people have been through given an opportunity to exchange. We're going to do this in a circle format, so we're just going to go around and we go next.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Sure. So my question for the future of Boston is how to deal with so many types of privilege and being deliberate and addressing those same things I think of institutional privilege, white privilege, those other kinds. So in terms of the experience that I thought of, it's kind of a personal experience, but it's also a work experience because of the work that I do with nonprofits. So the experience I'm thinking of is a small community based nonprofit that I work with that was given a legislative earmark from a state agency. So we went to meet with the person to get it. It's like 50,000 bucks. It was like really good for the small organization. So we went to meet with the people to get the paperwork rolling and the person running the state program said, "Oh, okay, well, this is a cost reimbursement contract. So you can keep track of your receipts and we'll reimburse you." And we were like, "Well, we don't have $50,000." So we kind of [inaudible] giving them back.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And I just see this so many times where there's this huge gap where certain organizations just can't even get over this hurdle. So it's this huge issue and I've seen it a million times. So that was the thing that was triggered to me. Like how do you literally deal with like that level of these gaps and disconnects to privilege?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: My question is, has Boston designed a new infrastructure to keep us up? It's like fighting to be able to position myself and my children to stay. And then my experiences is, growing up, graduating high school and doing job search, I was unfortunate, become a single mom, but blessed at the age of 19. So like throughout my job search, job hunt, people always assumed I didn't have like my degree or assumed that I had a GED instead of a high school diploma or assumed that I didn't have the means or I guess I can say knowhow when it came to certain things. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: Yeah. So my question about Boston in whether the education system will ever so really become student centered and really get beyond some of the issues that seem to keep impede them from progress. These issues of skills with teachers and certain restrictions that happen. And so yeah, how do we move sort of beyond that is the question. And my experience is, in high school, I was in a Mass experimental school system and we had this system called the model high. And it was part of, like they had a lower school, middle and upper. And one of the things about it was that a lot of the young people that went, they went because they were either kicked out or had difficulty either learn differently or whatever in the traditional school system.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: And so as an experiment, I thought that this is a skewed experiment because what you're doing is that you're loading the experimental school. If you're really trying to understand what could be a more advantageous school system or whatever, and you put it with folks who, in a lot of way anybody whose kid was doing well in the traditional system wouldn't take them out and put them in an experiment. So we was filled with kids who had behavioral issues, or had some difficulty in a lot of ways in dealing with the typical system. And so that was one reason why I think that it never got on track because of the results. When I see that happening again, I see the same ideas about trying to open up the classroom and trying to not have grades and trying to design schools that try to meet the students where they are and just going through the same cycle. That's my question and experience or issue.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: My question is, will working class and ethnic neighborhoods sustain diversification and displacement in Boston? And I've moved 28 times and I don't know... I live in Dorchester now and I feel like in the last six years, I've understood housing insecurity. I've always been housing insecure because I'm not a homeowner. But I never thought that the city and the state and the federal government, because I think I grew up during a time when there was safety-ness would abandon working-class people. And that we would have to work two and three jobs and give 50 to 60% of our rent to stay in the communities that we fight, like y'all to meet better. So, yeah, that's my question. And I don't understand housing policy, but I really appreciate that system that's been sleeping on the steps of the Capitol because she put her money where her mouth is, and I'm grateful for that.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: I see myself in the future homeowners years ago and I started off as a young staff and an event planner. And I found out it brought a lot of people together, all colors. So my future will probably be in the campaign aspect of the city politicians that I feel that are the right ones for the job. I have a knack of bringing up people from an international concert to a local concert. So I have a knack of bringing a lot of people together and I find that most people that come together, they come together for the same cause. And my future, again, I feel that we don't have many people of color in a position to sway or to bring up bigger crowds for the candidates. We usually have folks dictating who is going to be in their position worlds. So with my knowledge of a brand people, I feel it would be a big asset to the community. And that's where I see my future at Boston.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So get at that question about the future of Boston is, I would love to see everything be accessible for every one. And that really comes out of an experience. For me watching, I'm going to cry, watching this guy who, he wanted to go to a party, but he couldn't get into the party because they were stints. And so it was really difficult for him. But I also watched even through the city of Boston, in Codman Square, people that were in wheelchairs and before they started looking at the ADA compliance sidewalks, it was difficult. They were looking for like her cuts to get onto the sidewalk. So I almost watched them get hit by cars because they're in the street trying to navigate getting around.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And even to go to the playground to watch little kids and to see their hurdles, like trying to be a kid, get on some play structure. And it's just difficult without someone having to pick them up and all of it. My future, or what I would like to see happen is that accessibility is just without a question. Like when you build, when you create, that you have all of these people in mind, that you have the children, that you have the help. I'm going to be old one, eight and four. I am, right? And maybe I might have some type of issue. I have a friend who is living in an apartment, who's in a wheelchair and had to eye people way up here. She's in a wheelchair, how she's supposed to see through the door? So I'm always fighting for this access for people that just don't have it. And then there's no consideration when they're creating, when they're building, even as simple as getting around on a public street. They're doing a little bit better, but it still can be better.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you, everyone, both for the questions and the experiences that you're sharing. I'm going to just give you a couple of minutes to think about what you've heard. And then I'm going to ask you, from the questions that you heard on the table, is there one that really resonates with you that you also have experienced you want to connect with? So from what other people said, or did you hear in someone else's experience something that connected to you and you said, "Oh I have something like that or just the opposite of that," whatever it may be. All right? So I want you to think about that for a little bit. And then when you're ready, this is going to be like popcorn style. Whoever feels like talking first, talk to that person whose question and/or experience, you felt a connection to them.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Mike and Frans. For education purposes, I have the budgeted, I say the both directions. So I'm a parent of a black son and a parent of a black daughter. So I get to see how they treat them differently. And I'm also a parent in the school system. So I can see firsthand of how home culture can get confused with school culture and the school culture is totally different and teachers are doing the best that they can, but there will never be a connection without that home culture. So that's where they misunderstand and misinterpret our children's signs. Somebody might see my son as aggressive, but it's probably passionate or a cry for, "I don't understand." When you have teaching tools or you're trying to say, "Okay, well, this kid needs to learn social, emotional growth and tools to voice what the issue is that all school year, you say, "It's okay, you can be mad. It's okay, you can be mad, but just tell us what you need."

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And then when you see that student actually voice what he needs and is not being listened to by the same people who drill the venom, "We're here to listen," it's like, "What?" But then it's a lot of the policies to that have crippled some of these teachers and crippled the children that's trying to keep the children and the parents safe and also the teachers safe. So it's to be able to see that and to go through some experiences as a mom of a black child with another teacher and see like whole, it's like, yeah, educational system use my languages like that because of the world spent, the teachers not talking to the parents and the parents are afraid of the teachers and the teachers are afraid of parents, but nobody is willing to tell them that. And the kid is in the middle, you can see his book. And the kid becomes smarter than both of the teachers and learn how to play, both of them by using the same policies that they implemented for the teachers and the parents to keep them safe.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. So now my job as my son's because I know my son's first teacher is to be able to pull apart these things that I know he's willing to go through, see them firsthand with having him be considered as aggressive or have an attitude problem or anything. You just knows because he's already witnessed it firsthand. Like, "I know you're going to get treated differently than me if I do what you just did. I know that for a fact. I've seen it." And he's 10 and I've raised him to always voice how he feels. And so that might come off as smart remark or disrespectful, but no big deal at that point. It may come on to you. So it's just, how do you navigate that? Plus knowing the system, plus raising a child and keeping his morals and his self-esteem and confidence and tech without letting their skins play that.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: It's like Francesca's, housing. I lived in the same housing complex. My daughter will be 16. So for 16 years in the South End and I've witnessed a lot of... Let me see. It's a lot of the infrastructure I believe. I don't know how to like put it. So it's like, might've been these policies, like who makes these policies? Because I don't live in public housing. So public housing is a lot easier to pick up the phone and say, "Hey, I think I have been racially discriminated," and they'll do something about it quicker, the private low-income housing. So that infrastructure too was just like, it's like, "What?" So they can take... If the property manager don't like you for whatever reason, it doesn't mean necessarily have to be something you did. Just by the color of your skin. They do little things. They'll take a lot longer to fix something or forget you completely.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: And it's like if you go in reports at 1010, yeah, they'll get a spank on at risk or whatever, whatever, but then it's like, they use the other system like when it comes time for your certification and hard and use certain words to make you feel inadequate, like non-compliance and all this other stuff where this can go the record. So the policy piece is really strong for me because it's like a lot of these people that make these policies and put them in place are not actually the people that live in through them. So it's just like, they don't know how that makes a person feel. And then again, you're raising family, you have to disregard all of that. And the push is like all of that and make sure you still raise your kids the right way so that when they go up, they don't make the same mistake or they don't have a certain type of hate just because somebody is Hispanic or white or whatever or is black.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Dawn. So what resonated with as you were speaking, what came to mind was just equity. And so that's what I was feeling as you were talking about, "We don't have that." Maybe somebody else does, but we don't have that. So for me, what stood out was equity.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And if I could with Dawn, because I've been in the nonprofit sector, raising money for so long, what I flashed to was when I was at a meet and greet with funders and I was scared to death because in the past there was small community based nonprofits that had like budgets of 300,000 to the urban league. But there were universities and hospitals. Their fundraising staff in the same community-based fundraisers, I don't know, maybe 15 years ago might've been longer. I was at the Boston Foundation and I was just like, "We're in deep do-do if the funding dollars that somebody would that our budgets and our capacity to raise money." So not only do they... Yeah. So like, how do you compete with when you have a part-time grant writer with Berkeley School of Music's development staff, so talking about inequity? And then nonprofits.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And then like biggest pet peeve of a big nonprofits in Boston is they don't pay taxes. They don't pay taxes. So homeowners in Boston... These homeowners in my opinion, subsidize big institutions. And that's another policy whack thing that I don't understand. Because look at what CEOs of some of these hospitals make. They could fund that whole neighborhood just this hour. So yeah, inequity is like-

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: I know the thing that stood out to me was, Francesca, when you were speaking about the gentrification and displacement, that resonated to me. Also growing up, I grew up very poor and Southern Illinois grew up in like a mobile home and stuff. And it's this weird disconnect because I can remember I went to the Harvard School of Public Health and I can remember being there and feeling so out of place with my background and being like, I was walking around and be like, "Oh God." I was like fixing the thing there would be my dad. Like he would be the mechanic guy doing that. And then also, financially I had so little money. I had a student loan, but there were barriers to like getting the money. And there was a period of time where I had like a week where I couldn't buy groceries. So I was like hungry. It was such this weird feeling because I'm like, "I'm freaking at Harvard." And I can't eat.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: And the person in the financial aid department was really nasty, like the way he talked to people. And I can remember he would say to me, "I don't know when your loan's coming in." And I'm like, "Well, I'm hungry." And it's like, "Okay." And then several months later, the next semester, when I was waiting for my loan again, I felt more empowered in and somebody said, "You need to write a letter to the Dean." So I did. And of course, because it's Harvard and they're off privilege and they don't want to look bad, he called me in and he was horrified that I went through that. So he fired the financial aid lady, but see, that's still not really solving problems because it's like, "Look just who you were talking about to."

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: So there's just these layers of layers of things. It's like, "Well, that's hard." So he could just fire him. And then he's like, "I'm really sorry. And I got through it and I'm fine." But it made me think about just how complex all these kinds of issues and situations are.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I just wanted to add when miguelkingone was talking about the school thing, I was thinking about how we don't put enough emphasis on what students think about their own learning. And I feel like if nothing, I've learned that the people that are closest to the issue have the tools, they just need some support and maybe some access to some technology to problem solve it. Because just listening to each other's stories, it's clear that we have the answers, we just maybe need to get the resources to. Yeah. And so thank you, miguelkingone.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Got it. I resonate with James on the home ownership this far to try and break the generational curse. So that when I pass I know that my son and my daughter will always have a place to stay and be able to express who they are and be able to do much when they want to.

nodes.speaker: miguelkingone
nodes.words: Well, I think the thing when James was talking about that, that resonated with me about that is just that when I was coming up, I had an opportunity to go to college and stuff. They were saying, "Oh, we got this financial aid." They want to give at my area colleges and stuff like that. So jump on it. So I'm jumping on it. And then there's people I work with that I had a partner from, they talked to me about, "Well, we're doing this low cost housing program. And they want to take some of the deposit and they were trying to cover it and we'll help you get into this brownstone." This was 1970. So for $20,000, we're talking about four-story brownstone. And I had a choice. So it's like, "Do you take this here or do you go to school or whatever? But I guess the thinking at that time was, "Oh, you can always get a house, but you'll always have your education." I thought about that. I went to school and sometimes that's one of those things you think about maybe I might be in a different spot if I'd-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. We're coming to the end of our conversation, but what I'd like to do is as we come to the end of this is actually just go around for each of you to say something that again, just where'd you like to lead, what'd you like to leave everyone else in this room with? And I would say, because it's being recorded in shame makes you want to leave basically to people in Boston in general, this is from this conversations were heard, and this is what this is making me think about for us going forward. And again, we do it the same way. Whoever wants to start first can start and then we just clockwise roll on.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: Okay. I would say I've learned a lot. I didn't realize all these different opinions would resonate with me. I could catch him and text him and catch him. So I'm in my prompt.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Yeah. I feel like that this just makes it feel like how everything's so interconnected, like all these issues and life experiences, like we've all had different experiences, but then there are similarities of the barriers of things. And like Marilyn said, equity seems to be an underlying theme. So I feel really privileged to be able to be part of this and thank everyone for their also openness and vulnerability and sharing stories and experiences.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: I feel good about the situation because you said we'll be dealing with people with voices that haven't been heard, and that's very important. I'm an educator, a teacher, franchise owner, and a pass, did those things. But I think what I'm doing today, I'm a very positive, because you can just hear the unheard voices. So definitely-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I feel this hopeful with auto conversations, they'll be a solution to come out for all of us. I hear equity, and I think that should be like the main focus because equity pulls out everybody's stories. How is the big question.

nodes.speaker: James
nodes.words: Yeah. I like that. I like that you said there about being hopeful. I think that just in general, in the context of people being able to share, there's no pretense I think that. And so I think this perhaps can unify us by eliminating all those things that are common in the marriage, so separation. To me, the separation's what keeps us divided.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: I feel really honored to have been part of this circle. And like everybody is, I think it was you that said a little bit from everybody resonated with me. And often times when I walk into a room and there's a lot of people that I don't know, I get a little anxiety about, especially in these charged political times, will we be able to find the common ground? So it was refreshing to be in this space. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I feel honored, blessed and privileged in a way to be able to offer, but also to be able to receive. And one of my favorite quotes from the Bible is like, we do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit, right, that we should have like the heart of praise when we're thinking and doing. And so what I picked up from everybody just speaks to that. So nothing we do should be just self-centered. It really should be about the hood of our brothers and sisters. So I feel, again, I'm honored and somehow privileged to be able to receive and feel like there's something that I can give. And if it's my ear, but we all should help each other to move forward. And I think that once we do that, what a world! What a place this would be! Yeah. Thank you all for what you've given me today.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I want to thank all of you for participating in the call today. I just want to let you know that, we will be putting this up on the website, and when it's up, we will let you know. We will let you know how you can actually go see and listen to the conversation further. And with that, I'm going to close out this conversation, but we have a couple of things we want to do with you. But that does [inaudible] my instructions.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I said from the beginning before Robert Yancy, I thought he was going to join us. I was asking all of the people that are here, which is India, Marilyn, myself, and Akeya to agree to be recorded. And like I was telling you ladies, I was asking you to say your name and say, "Yes, I agree." That way we can move on and you are agreeing to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: Okay. So again, I wanted to welcome you ladies to the real talk. This is a conversation that helps people in the city across Boston, and we're trying to give voices to the voiceless, most voiceless people. So, what we're trying to do is get [inaudible] that we would prefer to see in the community. So, what we'll do is speaking, I would prefer someone to give me their aspects of life, opposed to going down a valley to where we can't stop. So, what I was saying is give me an experience that happened to you, think of a question and then you give me an experience that is chained to what happened to you, so it would not happen to another individual during your time. India, Akeya, Marilyn?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, I think for this forum we have to stay on the script. So, I think the first question, really Shanette, should be about the future of Boston and what is your place in it? So, let me see because I just totally got lost in the script.

nodes.speaker: Lorena
nodes.words: Though I should mention that the script will be shortened. We understand that it's kind of long to sort of reference back during the conversation. So, we will have a final, more concise version of the script. And I just want to, before we continue also, I want to make sure that would you like me to stay on the call? Would you like me to just be a listener in case you need any assistance with the script? My plan was to leave to let you have your real talk for change conversation. I'm from MIT. We are working with Ron on this project, et cetera, and this is the very first conversation we have. So, I just wanted to make sure that you are all set, ready to go, but I'm also more than happy to stay if you think that would be helpful. So, just let me know. [crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, you know what? Let me do the first one, the first question and then we'll go from there and then I'm going to hand it back to Shanette to finish. Okay? So, I'm just actually going to read what this says here on the script, okay? As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston and how our life experience has shaped that learning. So keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think about, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? So, that's the question. What is your question? What is the question that you would want to know about the future of Boston and then what your place is in that future? So, now you're just going to take a couple of minutes to reflect on what I just said and write it down somewhere, and then you're going to think about that experience in your life and then how you got to that question. So, is that clear for everyone?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So we're going to give a couple minutes for you to think about that question, write it down somewhere and then we'll circle back and have some conversation about it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: You're all set. Okay, so now we're just going to ask you to share both your question and your experience, and keep in mind that this experience has to be personal, not something somebody else experienced, but something that you experienced directly. So, who wants to go first and share their question about Boston and then your future in it? [crosstalk]. India?

nodes.speaker: India
nodes.words: Okay. So, my question for the city of Boston is where does the MBTA or, where does the MBTA stand in 2025? So, four years. Where does the MBTA stand in 2025? That's my question for the city of Boston and then a personal experience is, the reason why I asked that question is because I always used to write to MBTA and it was always broken down. And I always used to be late for particular things that I had important to me. So therefore, that's why I brought that up. But I was in Dudley one day and the 20, the 28 or something, it was super delayed and this was my last time getting, I mean, getting late at my job that I currently had in the past.

nodes.speaker: India
nodes.words: So, I want to change that and make sure that other people don't have to experience that. Even though it still happened towards this day, everyone's always late, but good to set time or I don't know, to leave five or 10 minutes in advance. I did that but I still wasn't on time and right then and there, my job was on the line all because of the MBTA. So yes, that's a personal experience.

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: My personal question for the city of Boston is what are they doing to really take the guns and stuff off the street? Because of all the teens and putting them into some type of programs and make programs readily available, not just for small children but also for teenagers and young adults. And sorry, I don't have a personal, very personal experience with that because my child wasn't out there at that time, but they need to have something to do with that.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, I guess my question would be what is the plan in Boston to make housing more affordable so that when my granddaughter graduates from college, which will be next year, how is she going to be able to live in the city that she was born and that she loves with the rents being so high? So, that would be my question for the future of Boston. And then I want to just say that my experience is that growing up, I think maybe I was fortunate in that my parents were always home owners. So, when I was able to get my first place and I did, I lived with someone but I couldn't live on my own because I wouldn't have been able to afford it, even though the rents were lower then. But once that relationship dissolved and I needed to have my own place, I couldn't afford one.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I did not want to live in my parents' house, but I really had no choice because I couldn't afford rent though it was a lot lower than it is now, but now it would have totally been out of the question for me. So, my experience is rent has always been a challenge, but even more so where it seems to be gentrifying. Developers are coming in and they're putting more high-end in the city that we grew up and we love so it's unaffordable, unless you're making almost a triple digit salary.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: So, I'll go and I'll say, I think coming from different... My question is coming up in a different part of town, [inaudible] has always been the bottom of the barrel. So, why is that? Then it's like okay, so Boston needs to do a reparative justice. It needs to be economically feasible for everyone depending on who's in office, who's not in office, that's when it becomes a thing. It's like okay, so now that we're trying to get a different mayor in, now everybody wants to get [inaudible]. I think without the proper economics, the financial literacy and certain communities that have never had people only come out when it's an election year. When are we going to see reparative justice, which is called reparation for black humanity?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. All right. So, Shanette do you want to go and take it from here or you want me to continue?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So, let me just do it just for the sake of time, so that we can just keep moving. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: No, not quite. Not with them but I mean, we're learning together. That's why I wanted to be here with you. So, what I want to do next is think back to each of the questions and experiences that were shared in our group, then find someone whose question or whose experience resonates with your own life. Then just speak to the person and tell them why their question or experience resonates with you and share a story from your life that connects you with their experience. So, you got that folks? [crosstalk] Good. So, who wants to share first?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: [crosstalk] We can take a minute or so to reflect just so you think about what we all said and then, connect that to.

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: Oh, I have a personal experience with this one. So, I connected to the question that you have as far as affordability of housing. My experience is that when my house became no longer affordable, then I had to move all the way down to New [inaudible] where it's affordable rent. It's on market. And my family is in Boston, so.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I want to ask a question to India. I used to work for the MBTA and that was something that I resonated and I always made sure that I was on time, but everybody didn't have that drive. They were more so for the dollar. I was for the public, so I was always on time.

nodes.speaker: India
nodes.words: Yes, I was thinking. I resonated with Akeya or antikea. Why? Because it's getting ridiculous, it's been out of control. We need some type of reparation. We need some type of rehabilitation for our young black males out here that's just trying to make a living and they're just, all they can do is I don't know, sell marijuana or protect their family with guns. That's not always the right answer, but that's all they know unless we have community centers. Unless we have some type of resources for our young black men or men in general, it's not going to get done. So I really resonated with Akeya.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yes, I'm sorry. Because I agree, I want to know also your question was, what are they going to do about all these guns and the gun violence and what have you. And I want to know too, because everybody is totally aware that there's an issue. That is really a pandemic itself, right? And they keep saying we need to get the guns off the street, we need to get the guns off the street, but I have yet to hear a plan to get the guns off the streets. So, I don't know how they can ever stop the pandemic or the epidemic of the gun violence if there's really no plan. I don't know. You want to get it off the street, but what's the plan? What's the plan to do it? So, yes, I definitely resonate with that question and then even take it further to think about the process to see how we eliminate the problem.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And then also with the MBTA, it's been a long time since I've taken the MBTA, but I know that it has always been an issue for us in our community. And I don't know if it's because people just didn't care or if it wasn't important to them, that it was important to us to get to where we needed to get to on time so that we can keep our jobs or that we don't have to experience detention in school. Because that was my issue back then when I did have an issue with the MBTA is that, if the bus was late and then crowded on top of that, it would just pass us by. And so, I would always get to school late and I don't care what time I got up to try to make it early if all the students trying to get to school early too. So, the buses were crowded, so they just keep going, you know? So, yes, I can resonate with both question and experience with the buses.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I like that. So, do you think that by gentrifying communities, do you think they automatically get the guns out of? In my opinion, I think they have communities where once it's gentrified the guns and the crime rate goes down.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: Do you think that's just by chance? They literally want this community, for instance, when they were doing that to let's say Mattapan, making them look pretty. Once they were gentrifying it, the guns and the violence started ceasing because they wanted to buy the property cheaper. You don't think that's by chance? Or do you think that's by design or how do people feel about that?

nodes.speaker: India
nodes.words: I think that's by chance and design, both aspects. Why? Because like you were saying about how they came at pamperting it did absolutely go down I think 15% if I'm not mistaken, all because they wanted to build these high end expensive apartments condo. So, when the legislators or the higher officials, white folks, came to actually look at Mattapan to actually see, okay, is this a good place to build or to start building all these condos and apartments? It was like, oh yeah. So.

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: I feel like they have a solution, they have a plan, but their plan doesn't include the people that's already in the community. That's all. [crosstalk] I feel like if they wanted to make a plan to do that and help the people that's already in the community with that, I feel like they should be training these people to get these kids off the streets and offering them several programs that's cost effective to the person that's trying to do it, so that they can make more money and be able to afford to live there.

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: That's what I'm saying, they need to train them. By training them in different trades, train them and going into the medical field till where they get a good entry level position that's paying them decent amount of money and where they go into, they pay for their schooling or pay a percentage for their schooling and they have a higher degree or whatever. They can do that with these children because if you don't teach them early, right? It's going to be very hard for them to absorb all this information if they're used to being out there. They have to have a way to take care of them and their family and still pay their bills and still eat.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: Exactly. That's all I think. Do you feel like this is by design or do you think this by chance? Because I've noticed, for instance, different places, they want the value of the homes and the property so they can buy the land cheaply, thirty it up. Then they come along and gentrify like they're trying to do with this community. Gorgeous but if you use this end of the spectrum, you will be able to have rent. You can probably rent a place here, two bedrooms for 750. Don't even think about it today. You have to have a roommate. I mean, literally. Grow up like you're saying, Marilyn, you're talking about wanting one of your people that's graduating this year and she's like, wow, will I be able to afford to live in Boston? The answer is no, the answer is no.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Oh, I'm sorry. I said, is there a common thread with what we hear, what we've been hearing in our conversations with each other, our experiences? Does there seem to be some type of commonality in our stories in question of what we want?

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: Yes, and not only that. I feel like one question we get to another question. And it's like a domino effect because if you're going into a neighborhood or community and you're trying to get the guns off the street, then you got to get them good jobs. And I've worked for the T, so I know that they taken me off of routes that's longer that we have all African-Americans in it. They put me on a route that's going to Watertown just for say. So, I know what they do. They cater to communities and they'll take me off the 23 or the 45 to go do something that's in Newton.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: All communities experience this. But when they gentrify it, they literally make sure you have no experience, you have no money. So you figure, wait a minute, I don't want to be kicked out of my community. So, how am I going to take care of my family? I think we need economic financial literacy. We as African-Americans or black people need financial literacy. We need solutions, and the solutions are give us trade before we leave high school. Stop forcing everybody into college. Yes, they put it on hold till 2022, but come on, everybody got their hands in the kiddy pool. You can't do that. You have to give them real solutions. Real solutions to me is trade and economic financial literacy. We need to learn economic financial literacy. We don't learn that because we don't have reparation. Reparative justice.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Right. I think that for the most part, we are coming to the end of our conversation and we were able to kind of listen to everyone and their voices and their concerns. We were able to pick out some common threads within the city. And the goal of what we're trying to do is to collect more voices, to hear how people respond to what they think about the future of Boston and where it's going. And hopefully that can spark some change to change the whatever outcome that we're looking for is. So with that, we can just kind of take the next couple of minutes, just to share something that we will be taking away with us from this conversation today. So, is there anything that kind of sticks out in your mind that you think that you'll be taking with you? Okay, let's share.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yes. For me I think that as big as Boston or as small as Boston is, and the way that people look about it, I think that we genuinely have very much the same concerns about our transportation system, about our living system and about safety, crime and safety. So, I think I will walk away thinking about, wow, we come from different places, we're all different individuals yet we still have the same issues that kind of change what could be the outcome of our destiny in the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: Do you ladies think that while we're coming to the end, do you think this was helpful? Do you feel like your voices were heard? How do you feel in closing?

nodes.speaker: Akeya
nodes.words: I feel like our voices are heard every time I speak up on it and I feel like if we can get people involved and this whole situation with the voices and then people actually go and be proactive, then I think it's great.

nodes.speaker: India
nodes.words: Absolutely. Absolutely. I just want to piggyback on what Akeya said. Yes, more people's voices need to be heard or we need to get more people involved. So, I don't know, I'm thinking, because I don't know if this is our last meeting or just our first meeting, but probably little flyers or little things so people know it's happening. People know that we are talking about this because this is not a subject that should be swept under the rug. No, no, no. This a subject that should be brought into the light and need to be done by. So.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well I think that everyone's right and I just agree. I think that real talk, which is the organization real talk for Boston is the group that Shanette and I are affiliated with and the whole goal is to sort of network and hear from voices across the city of Boston that are usually silent. That you don't hear these voices for one reason or another. But as someone alluded to earlier, everyone's voice matters and their concerns are legitimate. They're your concerns, right? And so the conversation does need to continue. And what will happen with what we did today is no one will see your faces or anything like that, but they will use the audio and there will look across the city and see the common threads.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And that's what is going to spark a larger discussion about the things that we all care about and the things that we need people to know about. So, I'm happy to have been a part of this today and to hear that, yes, we have some very real concerns and they are similar, we all kind of have the same thing. Our experiences may have been different, but yes, the question is for Boston and how what we see is the same. We have that same question about all of the topics we talked about. So, thank you for sharing.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I know this will not be the last time that we'll have this discussion. Like Marilyn said, they're actually going to be quite a few meetings done and all of the audio will be heard by the real talk, which is the real talk conversation. So, that was great. I loved that. It was done properly. It was harder than I thought but it was definitely... Thank goodness for Marilyn.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: No, I think the first one is always a little, you're trying to find your footing but after that it's going to be smooth sail. You did great. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I appreciate you ladies for bearing with me. And I appreciate Marilyn definitely, because she jumped right in. I was like wait a minute, where is it?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: That's okay. [crosstalk] I said I was coming. I was coming because I would've did the same thing. I wouldn't want to go by myself the first time. I mean, and then until you feel comfortable, I will, I will be there.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, I think this concludes our conversation for today. This could last anywhere from 60 to 90 minutes, but we didn't have a lot of folks, so it was a little bit less. So, again, thank you ladies for your time, your attention, and most importantly, your input. So, I was just reading a piece that said that all of this information is going to be gathered and transcribed and then indexed. And then when the voice, when they put the compilation together, then they'll send out an email where you can click into a link and kind of hear the voices across the city.

nodes.speaker: Lorena
nodes.words: Hi everyone. I'm Lorena. I'm with MIT's Center for Constructive Communication. We are actually developing the campaign that Michael is helping us facilitate, and recruit for. That's me. I just have a quick question. I just want to make sure that Michael has everybody's emails, because once this gets into the LVN site, we're going to have to match. We want to make sure that we have names, and just look back, and it will not be shared with anybody, so you don't have to worry about that. I just want to make sure Michael has them.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I'm just going to go around as I see people. Again, my name is Michael Jacobi Brown. I'm one of the facilitators of the Real Talk for Change campaign. Don Nanstad, do you want to introduce yourself just briefly?

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: Yeah. I'm Don Nanstad, I'm a pastor in East Boston. I live in Maverick Square, East Boston. I've been here 41 years this fall. [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Eviva, I am a community organizer at the Boston Center for Independent Living. I'm here today with Shaya to observe and train for a conversation that we're planning to have with the disability community.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Hi. My name is Jo-Ann, and I currently reside in the South End of Boston. I'm a long term resident of the Boston area, I guess three, four generations. I worked in the human service field for two decades. I recently started in nonprofit on honor of my mom. Right now I just want to be a part of the conversation to see what we can do to make Boston a better place for all.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Geanier. I currently reside in Dorchester, Massachusetts. The house has been in the family for 40 years. I'm in school. I'm actually getting my bachelor's in psychology, but I've been in the healthcare for probably 20 years.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: I'm Shaya. I go by they/them pronouns. And I work as a community organizer at the Boston Center for Independent Living with Eviva. I live in JP, and have lived in Boston for the last six years, and worked as a community organizer in the disability community for the almost five years now. I'm really excited to be part of this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Well, thanks a lot. This conversation is being recorded, this little thing up there. It will be used as part of the Real Talk campaign for Boston to help people whose voices often who are not heard to be amplified and heard better. Welcome to the conversation, I want to thank you.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I want to invite you to think that one of the most pressing questions, this is what I'm really going to be asking you about. One of the most pressing questions you have about the future of Boston. Our goal today is to share those questions, and have a conversation with each other. Thanks a lot for adding your experience to those people in Boston who want to speak and be listened to, rather than be talked at.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We're going to begin recording our conversation. There are at least three things that I want you to do before we do these introductions. We're going to do a little more. First, the purpose of the conversation is, we're trying in Real Talk for Boston to create a space across the city to have more real constructive listening across the divides of neighbors, politics, culture, race, and provide more visibility and accountability between the candidates, and the future mayor, and the neighborhoods, and people who live in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: To this end we're inviting different types of people into this conversation. The conversations are going to focus not on statistics, or analysis, but on personal stories, that's your personal stories, rather than entering the conversation about specific candidates. We're not supporting any candidate.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We're doing this to build connections, and foster conversations across the city, and to build a better understanding from each other. People in East Boston like Don, may not talk to people in Jamaica Plain, or Dorchester, or the South End. Just getting through the tunnel sometimes is an operation, or getting on the T. Particularly in the winter getting through the buses.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Secondly, I want to address what's going to happen to the recording of this conversation. The video recording is discarded. So your faces aren't going to be there. Just the audio becomes part of a collection of other conversations. Along with the other conversations that are taking place across the city they'll be shared with the Real Talk for Change team, and others who participate in the conversation across the network.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Local Voices Network, you can learn more about it if you go to cortico.org, or lvn.org. Is a web based tool for accessing ... Hi Zakiya. We're introducing in little while. It's a tool for recording conversations, and it will upload both the transcript, and the audio, just the voice recording, to this tool.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: The system highlights keywords, and phrases that emerge from different conversations, and allows users to search the conversation, and listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns. What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a tapestry of conversations across the city.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Now, as a participant, in this conversation you're providing consent to Real Talk for Change Boston to use and retain the recording in accordance with our mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities, and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. So, if you understand and agree to this, I want you to say verbally, "I agree." I'm just going to ask Don. I'll just go around as I see you. Just say I agree verbally.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you very much. Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone, and we've got quite a few people here, share and learn from one another in this conversation. To support this I want to introduce a few guidelines. Probably one, the most important is, speak for yourself, and your own experience. That helps by starting a sentence with I, instead of you, or we. And allow others to speak for themselves, and share the time.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Allow others to finish speaking. Let's take turns. Stay curious, ask honest questions. We'll have a time later to go back and forth. This is something I got to impose, take time for reflection. I'm going to ask you to take a couple of minutes either just to reflect, or write down perhaps.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Listen generously, people may say things you disagree with, or have a different view, but assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible close unnecessary programs. I'm shutting off the thing on my phone so it won't blink, or do anything, and notifications, so your phones are silent. If you do need a moment just put in the chat, nature calls, or something happens. Just let us know, real life happens.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We're going to use a modified circle for this. So we're going to ask each person to take turns. I'm just going to probably go around as I see people. It's a little easier for me, but to begin with, I want to just do a quick round of introductions. Here I just want in this case, just say your first name, where you're located right now on the planet, and one value that is important to you.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Also, I want you to check in using, there is something we call PIES. PIES stands for physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. You can choose one, or more of those four. Again, just share your name, where you are, one value that's important to you. And just to check in how you are, either physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. Anyone have any questions about that? I'm just going to go around as I see people. It's not necessarily important. Don, can you check in?

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: Okay. I'm getting all these instructions down. Let's see. I'm Don, I'm on East Boston. A value? For me, being honest, straightforward, really important. Where am I at? Well, I guess I'll pick emotionally I'm fairly interested in this project, because most projects that go on in East Boston, I don't speak Spanish, and that leaves me sitting on the sidelines, and that's no for me from many years prior. I'm curious, and I guess I want to have a little more clarity to stir that emotional response.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I didn't know until yesterday that the conversation was going to happen today. So, I had went through with the grandchildren. A value to me is family, and emotionally right now I am a little drained, because I just recently helped put together ... Hold on one second. I need go to into another room. I just helped facilitate a repast, because I have a nephew that took his life.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Just the other night we lost another family member who was gunned down outside of his mom's house in [inaudible] Mattapan. I'm just a little drained emotionally. I'm feeling blessed and grateful that I'm here with my grandchildren, and they're safe, and that I'm available today.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you for sharing that Jo-Ann. I'm Shaya, I go by they/them pronouns. I am currently in Jamaica Plain, Boston. I'm going to go with kindness for my value. I'm going to go with emotionally tired, because my roommates, and I have been interviewing housemates, and we talked to nine people in three days, it's just been a lot.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Yeah. My name is Geanier, I am in Dorchester at my home. Something that I value is just mindfulness, being mindful of things, people around you to basically make sure that you're just being mindful, whether you live with somebody, whether you're helping somebody, whether you're working, just being mindful of everybody's situation. Everybody has things that they're going through. I'm really sorry Jo-Ann for your losses.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Also, emotionally I'm tired, it's been so much death a lot in the past year, especially these last few months, emotionally drained, and tired. So, yes.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Nice to see you. Just for facilitators to keep in mind. You see when Jo-Ann had to drop something that was really painful, Michael took a couple of minutes, maybe a minute, a full minute though. He paused. That's real important.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Just so you know, I had recruited another facilitator, and the reason I was late to this meeting is, it was her cousin who was murdered, that Jo-Ann was speaking of. In a community like Boston, where there is 140,000 black people, particularly, and we happen to be talking about a black person who was murdered, oftentimes there is like a hundred of us right off the hip that know who the person was, or have some connection.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: My name is Zakiya. My value is integrity. I try to bring my highest best self. I try to tell you what I'm going to do and follow up with it. Checking in, physically I was able to walk about 2,000 feet today with minimal back pain, so it's a good day. With that I'm in. Thank you, Michael.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Glad to hear it. I can check in. My name is Michael. A value I think is important is kindness. Thank you, Shaya. I'm here in Arlington, Mass, my home, where I live with my wife Jessica Goldhash, sometimes my daughter, who's sometimes here, sometimes not, who's 21. Right now I'm feeling sad hearing the news, and I've heard this from other people. I'm feeling sad right now hearing this, because it's hard.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I appreciate your coming on in spite of the sadness. This is Real Talk not fake talk. I appreciate that. Are we ready to move on, or did someone have something they want to share before we move on to the core of the conversation?

nodes.speaker: Lorena
nodes.words: Thank you everybody for being here, and for sharing in with your stories, and for being part of this project. It's really uplifting. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I just want to appreciate Lorena, not only for who she is, but for what she does sending me the link when I got all farblunget with the Local Voices Network. I think you made it a lot simpler. I could never have done this without Lorena. Thank you. I really appreciate that.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. She's very responsive too. It's something I love. She answered like that, quick, quick, quick. Otherwise, I thought we were going to be not able to have this conversation. Thanks to Lorena's quickness and abilities we're on Zoom together, and hopefully we'll be with COVID going away, hopefully at some point in real communication, and have a meal together.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. We're going to get into the core of the conversation now, which is really to think about, during the pandemic, we've just seen how the inequality in America has been really worsened. The inequality in Boston is certainly something that all of us have lived through. So, keeping this in mind, I'd like you to think about, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in the future?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: What I'd like you to do is take a couple of minutes to reflect on this. What's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in the future? Reflect on it, and if it's helpful write it down, the question. What's your question? What is? How is? When is?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Then I'm also going to ask you, and we're going to go around, to share a personal experience in your life that led you to ask that question, and again just keep the experience personal. Something that you experienced directly. I'm just going to give us just a minute to reflect on that. Then I'll ask everyone, and given the limit on time we'll just try to limit it to a couple of minutes if you can. We'll do the best we can recognizing it's already 4:47. If you think you have a question, or ready to go, just raise your hand, or if you want some more time, just say time, or something like that. Anybody wants more time? You want to go first Don?

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: My question is, how are most people going to ever afford to live in this city? My personal experience with that is that I'm a pastor. I live in a [inaudible], it's not my house. I owned a house in Wisconsin and sold it for a ridiculous price in comparison to here. East Boston was always cheap, and poor, and even though I didn't have any money I could have easily bought a house anywhere around me.

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: Now when I retire, which, who knows when that's going to be? Well, I'll be stretching myself, with a pension with two people who worked their whole life to get about 900 square foot, maybe 800 square foot condo for about $650,000. This is absurd. No yard. That's the bottom line for a two bedroom condo in East Boston.

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: If I could to other city neighborhood, which I'm not interested in, I'm going to be in the same boat. West Roxbury believe it or not is way cheaper, a nice big condo, but that's a long ways to go. My grandchildren are all there, my daughter is there. As far as I'm concerned it takes me out of the city. It must be happening to thousands of families who are in this situation.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. Who is ready to go next? I'll just let you do that. How is that? Just raise your hand, I can see everybody. Go ahead Jo-Ann.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Hi, Jo-Ann. I just had a concern that the last gentleman raised. Most people that I encounter on a daily basis don't even have that option to even say, "I don't want to move from East Boston to West Roxbury." Most people haven't even ventured outside of where they are to even go as far as West Roxbury, to even consider the option.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: They're just trying to figure out how the cheap, the place they have, where they're at. That's my thing. A lot of folks are like, "How can folks afford to live?" Many folks that I'm encountering are trying to figure out how they can just stay where they're at.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: A lot of the folks that I'm encountering are living in places that are known to many folks as what we call projects today. Housing developments that were never for people to actually live in for long periods of time. The projects are made for military families that were going to get the G.I. Bill that's going to elevate them to housing.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: What happened was, it was not distributed people. So a lot of families were families of color were not provided with the G.I. Bills, and they were left behind in the projects. For three or four generations you had people that have been in these little small spaces. I myself now I'm a resident of a small space that I'm speaking of.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: That happened due to the gore circumstances of life. I'm not complaining, trust me, grateful. I'm getting to see a struggle that I did not know. I grew up in [inaudible] home. If anyone ever knows, or heard of the fact that when people plant certain things, you have to give the things you plant room to grow.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Well, I was wondering why sometimes people can come out of the house in the morning very upset, and they haven't walked out into the world? It's like the people that I'm speaking of that are just trying to figure out how to keep where they live. They're living in places, and spaces that were not meant to be inhabited, and folks are trying to make it hard for them to even stay there.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: That's the question is like, how do we make it a better place for people to not just live where they're at? Expand, where they are in a city that's trying to make it hard for them to even keep what they already have. How do we provide housing for those who can't even see past where they're at? Because they've been there in this position for generations.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Who wants to go next? Anybody feel ready? A question you have? Geanier, go ahead. You're muted. There you go.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Yeah. I am. That really touched a cord with me, what Jo-Ann said, because it's like, is there going to be a place for my daughter that's nine? Or my older daughter that's 21? Where are they going to stay at? I was fortunate enough that my mom bought a house in Dorchester, but it doesn't look like it did when I grew up.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I saw this little old lady earlier today mowing her lawn, and we're all supposed to be human, or neighborly, but then nobody was helping her. Then neighborhood doesn't look the same, it doesn't feel the same. Everybody is being pushed out for big developments, and 500, 600,000 townhouse condos, and the taxes are so high. How are you supposed to afford to even keep where you stay at? And you're trying to keep the house in the family, but how are you supposed to do that? I don't know how you're supposed to do that. Is there going to be a space, or a place for future generations to even be able to live in Boston? There isn't going to be a space for them to live.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: There is barely a park that I can bring her to in Boston. I have to go out to Lexington, Wakefield, Stoneham, just to bring her to a park that I'm comfortable letting her play in, because of the needles that I found at one park, the condoms that I found at one park. There is not a space for us to be in right now. There is just not a space. Not even COVID, just in general.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I used to be able to walk from my house to Carson Beach, or to Castle Island, or to Tufts Medical Center, and just have a great walk. I would never walk anywhere right now in Boston, from fear of the danger of what's going on right now. People are hungry, they're not working, and it's just ... I don't even know what's going to happen, not even two years from now. I'm scared that there is not going to be a place for the next generation to even be in, you can't afford to stay here no matter how hard you try to stay here. I don't know how it's going to happen. I'm done. Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: No need to be sorry. You haven't done anything wrong. I appreciate you sharing that. Anybody else want to share? Just raise your hand, or unmute.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: This is Shaya. Independently from everyone else I also came up with the question of who will be able to live here in 10 years? I've had six friends move away in the last year or two. When I first moved to Boston, there is a Facebook group for low income people. It's a place where ... When I first moved here most of the apartments were under 900 for splitting a four bedroom with three other roommates. Now less than 25% of them are.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: I used to think that I would live here for a long time, and now I don't. It gets even harder as someone who has a disability and need to find a flexile apartment. I also think about, I work with a lot of disabled people in the Boston area, and for so many of them, when people ask me, "How do I find an accessible apartment?" I'm having trouble. And I expect so little to offer them.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: I think about one of our members when I first started, who is an amazing advocate. She almost single handedly got the T station near her house to be completely renovated, and prioritized, and made accessible. I was visiting her, and she offered me a cup of tea in her apartment. I took her up on it, and she was like, "Great, and you're going to have to make the tea, because I can't get into my kitchen, because it's not wide enough for my wheelchair."

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: When halfway through our visit I asked if I could use the bathroom, and she was like, "Yeah, I'll stay over here, because they had to take the door off, because I couldn't get my wheelchair into the bathroom with the door on."

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: This is an apartment that she found after looking for at least a year, and this is the best she could get. It just feels so hard, I think the sense of it being so temporary living here, and if you can get in the door in the first place.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: Yeah. This is Eviva. Thank you. I don't have a super fully formed question. Yeah Real Talk, I am concerned about the wealth inequality in Boston, and about like I see people in my community and network who are just so outrageously committed to the idea that Boston is a good place to live.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: I'm from Houston, not as racist, not whatever, just this idea of a liberal city. It's really that people will hold onto that until they die, that white rich people. I don't know how people in leadership beyond political dialogues on race or whiteness are actually going to be able to do something on a culture shift to make people shift their understanding of Boston, like what Boston is to the people who live here.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: My dad grew up in Lexington, and I grew up in Houston. I moved here after college, and I just had been so deeply instilled with some narrative about Massachusetts and Boston of like ... I mean, I just see it everywhere, I just feel like it just creates so much of a gap between the narrative of absent, and the reality. I want to know how ... I guess I want there to be less of a gap between this perception of what Boston is, and of this great place, and I wish people would hold onto it so tightly. I'm done.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, I did come to just shadow in a way, so that I could be here if the two people I recruited for this had any questions, or whatever. Like Geanier, and Jo-Ann, housing is uppermost in my mind in the fact that the communities that I've lived in, worked in, and played in, since 1979, are changing rapidly. In fact, the U.S census tells me that we've lost about 10,000 black people since the last census. You said put it in a question, Michael?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, the question is, will anybody who makes less than $75 an hour afford to live here? That would be with a fixed amount of hours, a full-time job, that would be my question. Will anybody who makes less than $75 an hour on salary for a full-time period be able to afford to live here? With that I'm done.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Well, thanks a lot. The next part of this conversation is think back to the questions, and the experiences, the stories that we were just honored to hear. I appreciate your sharing those, and find someone across the computer screen, or hopefully at some point across the table, because this Zoom stuff frankly, I'd much rather be in person, so we could actually eat something, have some food, and share. Be bigger than a quarter of an inch, or however big you are on the Zoom screen. That's just me. I'm so tired, but this is what we got with COVID, and everything else.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: What I'd like you to do is think to someone who just shared, and find someone whose question, or whose experience resonated for you. I want you to speak to that person, and tell them why their question, why their experience resonated with you. And share a story from your life that resonates with what you just heard. You understand what I want you to do? Go ahead Jo-Ann.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I mean, the statement you made was so impactful, because I had no intention of sharing this story today, but when you spoke of what folks hold dear about Boston, and I am a true Bostonian through and through. What I will say is is that there is something that is engraved in the fabric of Boston from the hallowed halls of Faneuil Hall, where they did the trading years ago, where we all sit and have a meal together now that folks don't really speak about.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I was at a job that I loved for almost five years, and because I don't go to places to change things, I went there to be a good fit. I was a counselor in the human services field. I'll speed this up, but I wrote an email, because they offered the COVID vaccine to the families of the employees except for two persons of color, myself and someone else.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I spoke up about that, and in the email I wrote that the company was no stranger to systemic racism, and because I used those two words, they found two reasons to get rid of me. They said, my paperwork wasn't at the par, and that I was late a few times. After I sent the email they responded eight days later to my email. People didn't speak to me around the office. They were afraid to have conversations with me after I used those two words. And I had just been given a raise, a $3 raise by the way. And I had just been given that raise retroactively a whole year back for my performance, but yet I was fired for not having good performance.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: That's why when you made that statement about what people hold so dear about Boston, I spent every day working for that organization, helping other people to try to get their lives on track. And in a moment after sending that email off, my whole life was turned upside down, and I lost a lot.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I just had my credit on track, I was thinking of purchasing a home, so I can move out of the punch that that I live in. And because of the loss of a job the credit score went down, everything just in one moment. The racism piece, trying to cover it up caused me to lose a whole lot. Thank you for sharing what you said. Better to know this than that it is not seen. So, thank you.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
