nodes.words: I'm going to try to make my preface short, which is that I mostly just talk all the time, and I don't even know what to say, but I still want to say something, which is that it's not unbelievable, it drives me nuts when people are like, "Unbelievable this." Or, "Unbelievable that." That's not unbelievable to me at all. That's what I'll say. I really I'm speechless that that resonates. So, thank you.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: I feel like what I have experienced in my own life, what feels like to me disregard of black people's livelihood. I've had personal experience with this, I couldn't believe that when I was trying to advocate for my coworker to be given a chance to show how brilliant they were, and how much they could contribute to the org, that essentially they were told to leave.

nodes.speaker: Eviva
nodes.words: I was just like, "But all the implications of firing this person are fucking insane. Why will you even just create capacity for them to show how much of an ass that they are to this organization?" Then I got in trouble. Again, it's not unbelievable, but it made me so angry of what felt like just the disregard.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Eviva, I am so glad you stuck up for your coworker, because as Jo-Ann said, it happened to me, but it happened to me in 2013. I was thankful that I did have coworkers that wrote letters for me, but I was fired. I had a boss that literally would harass me. I would be on the phone, and she would come ... You can tell now, but I have a lot of hair. She would come, and touch my shoulder, and turn me around, and was like, "Did you hear what I said?" I'm like, "I'm on the phone with a provider. Give me a second." She would scream at me, and yell at me, and berate me.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I did end up suing the company. I can't disclose anything, but I ended up having to, because they fired me. I couldn't believe it, because I was there for three years, and I was really good at my job, but she didn't have any training. A lot of times, instead of hiring another person of color within the company that was really, really good, because there was somebody that was just as good, they hired outside, and the person wasn't even ... She wasn't trained to be a director, because we had to report directly to the director.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: It was a very horrible experience to the point where I left corporate completely. I had to go to therapy for a while, because I never experienced that. I went to a predominantly white school system. I didn't experience it there. I never experienced it until I got into the workspace, and I haven't been back.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: So, I am trying to get back in now, but with kid gloves, because I guess I'm stronger now to deal with it. I wasn't mentally strong at the time. My mother had passed away a few years before that, so I just wasn't prepared to deal with her, and it was a bad experience. So, I completely commend you, because I did have coworkers that did stick up for me, and write letters, and stuff. But they weren't strong enough to say something to her face, but they were willing to write letters when I had to go to court, and stuff. I'm glad you did. So thank you for that.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I also thank you Eviva. Thank you for all the people that don't have anyone to speak up for them. I thank you for all those that don't have anyone to champion for them, Eviva.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We appreciate that. I also appreciate everything everyone said also. I also want to honor our time commitment. I assume everyone needs to leave at 5:30. I'm making that assumption. Just go like that if that's your assumption, and we're going to end at 5:30. I want to honor that. If anyone wants to stay I can stay later, but we'll end at 5:30. Because we were taking some of our time because of the technical difficulties, which I apologize for. Like the bumper sticker stays, that happens sometimes.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I just wanted to go around, and see if anyone has any final thoughts, or appreciations, or regrets from what you've heard, so we can close with some, if there are any things you heard that you would like to make sure we get down, that would be a good time to say them now, or any appreciations you have, or like I said, appreciations, or regrets.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, I'll say, I regret that the technology didn't work perfectly. I'll just get that out of the way. I just wanted to hear from you. Some people haven't spoken up much.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: I appreciate how real and everyone got. I feel like I learned a lot on this conversation. And also I feel a lot of the emotional impact of what everyone shared, and is going through, and those people who are going through.

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: I had a couple of things. One, I would have responded to Jo-Ann, and Geanier because my housing situation after I got done I thought, "Oh my goodness, I'm talking dollar numbers that are going to sound like something is sticking in your throat." On the other hand I've never made more than half a salary. My wife, she was a headstart teacher. I realized that there are people who are just literally hanging on to what they got. City life meets here in East Boston at my church. The times when I sit and listen to translations of the horrid situations people are in, it's just awful. I shake my head, and I say, "That's happening here in this time? People wouldn't believe it."

nodes.speaker: Don
nodes.words: Even though I know this it's still a wake up call to hear it again. Thank you. This is a better group than I ever could imagine. Thank you. I got to go. Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Thanks Don. Don's been the pastor of our Saviors Lutheran Church, and the leader of the Maverick Square Neighborhood Association. I met him 25, 30 years ago. I appreciate all you've done Don, and continue to do.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: I regret that Don is gone, so when you please speak to him again, please let him know that that was not in any way, I don't want him to feel like he should feel bad, because he'll have the opportunity to maybe be comfortable in his retirement, because being a pastor is a chore. My mom sent me to divinity school when I was a young girl, and I did not want to take on that responsibility. So, he needs to retire comfortably. Please let Don know I said that. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Being a pastor, it's a lot, we need people to have to be responsible for it. So, he needs to retire comfortably, absolutely. All right.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, I'm glad that I was able to [inaudible] facilitator. I feel confident that they're going to do a good job, and be of great support to the people who participate in Real Talk for Change conversations. With that, I'm done.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: No, there is no regrets. I appreciate this group, the transparency and the honesty that everyone has shown, being able to just be free to speak your mind, or your truth as they say. Being able to speak your truth, and not be afraid to speak your truth.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: This talk, you were able to actually be honest and open about your feelings, your experiences, and where you want to go, how you want things to go going forward. So I appreciate that. So thank you.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I just want to appreciate Shaya's story about ... I remember saying, "Oh, I'll make you some team, but you're going to have to go into the kitchen, because the wheelchair won't go there. And I had to take the door off the bedroom, and it took a year to find even that apartment." That story really stuck with me. You want some tea, you're going to have to make it yourself, because I could imagine, I at some could be in a wheelchair, I couldn't go into my own kitchen, how does that feel? I can't somebody a cup of tea." Thank you. I appreciate your telling that story. It was so real and immediate, and visual.

nodes.speaker: Jo-Ann
nodes.words: Absolutely. This month is my anniversary for having my knee replacement, and just last year I had to learn to walk again. So trust, absolutely that resonated with me. The ability to not be able to be mobile and get around. Thank you definitely for sharing that story, Shaya.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: Yeah. I think I was really struck by Geanier's experience about needing to drive so far away for your daughter to be able to play in a park. I think it just really ruffled a lot to me like what feels safe? For example, for your neighborhood, to actually feel like part of your home, and community?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: You said you had to go to Lexington, or someplace, because nearby the parks had condoms, and needles, and that is Real Talk.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Yeah. She's in the METCO Program, so she goes to school in Lexington anyway, but during COVID obviously then we weren't able to be outside. So I tried to take her to the park on Norfolk Street, by Mass Ave, and I'm like, "Kids actually play here?" Because it's right across the street from a school. And the school kids actually go into the park and play there every day. I couldn't believe it. I think I emailed the governor, and the mayor, and somebody else, because my kid doesn't even go to school here, but we live here, and it's not too far.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I'm like, it looked like it was a decent park, so I brought her there. And I'm like, "Let's go right now." I put her in the car, and I'm like, "No, we're just not." That's not how I grew up.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I hear you. We just have a few minutes. I just want to appreciate all of you for coming on, especially all of you, and Zakiya for your leadership in this. Now, you will be facilitators. In terms of the role there is a script, and I had to condense it, because of the long gap we had in our hour and a half.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I definitely condensed the part about what resonated with you, and learnings. I tried to do that. All of you, if you want can be facilitators. The point of having this practice session is to feel what it's like to be one of the people you'll be facilitating.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I just wanted to see if you had any questions about, or any comments, good, bad, or ugly, about any of the things that I did as a facilitator, because you'll be doing this. Our job at Real Talk to change, and Zakiya's job is to support you in that role. I just wanted to see if you had any questions before we end, or comments like, why did you do that? Or whatever.

nodes.speaker: Shaya
nodes.words: The last thing I have is if, is the most important thing to be telling stories? Because I know that we didn't all ask a question for that team to go find. But when we are improvising, are there a list of one, two, or three things we want to make sure that people are really hitting, or doing?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Telling a personal story is important. I mean, what I did, some people didn't start with a particular question, but eventually what I heard was a question came out of it. There were questions embedded in after they said a couple of paragraphs I heard the questions. Often, how are we ever going to do this? How am I going to live here?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: The important thing yes is to tell the personal stories. I mean, if you remember like I remember the kitchen, going to make the tea. I remember the condoms, and the needles, and I had to take my daughter to a park in Lexington. That's really powerful. I heard your story. I mean, I don't want to go to every story about saying systemic racism, and being fired for saying what is obviously true.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: The stories are really important. The reason for that is, the power that we will have as people, and as people communicating not only to the mayoral candidates, but also to each other, I think we recognize comes from those stories. Not from statistics, not from making speeches, not from complaining.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, sometimes it's good complain, there is plenty to complain about. Not from saying there ought to be a lot, but telling stories. The power that we have both to communicate to candidates, elected officials, and to each other comes from those stories. As facilitators your job is to draw out those stories. Is that a helpful answer? Okay.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Good question. I emailed Lorena, and she said, "Wait." She's working with Kelley from Cortico, the parent organization, to get it back. She emailed me, and then I tried to email you. She said, "Stay put." So, exactly what she did I don't know, but she and Kelley came up with a new Zoom link. I didn't do anything. I just asked Lorena, or she emailed. Said, she's going to try to fix it, and stay put. Then I tried to email all of you, I don't know if you got that email-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Saying that she's trying to fix it, and stay put. This could happen. Hopefully we learned something, so it won't happen again, but you never know.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: What was cool about it was you kept your confidence. You explained that something was going on. You didn't give up on it, and that's what we have to do. I think tomorrow Michael when we go into that meeting at 11:00 am I think it is, we can say that we probably need [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: You're breaking up a little, Zakiya. I heard you say at 11:00 when we go into a meeting, something. You're muted Zakiya.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Well, thank you. Okay. It is 5:30, I do want to respect everyone's time. I appreciate you. I'll try to send you all everyone's email so you can be in touch with each other.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: First is the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across the divide, such as neighborhood political and cultural, et cetera, and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates, and the future mayor, and the neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we're inviting you to have a different type of conversation.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your positions on the upcoming election or specific candidates. We're doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another. Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recoding of this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Following our meeting today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of the collection of conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are set aside throughout the city will be shared with members of the Real Talk For Change team and others who participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network or LVN. LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: LVN system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads, both the transcript and audio recording to the Explorer tool. The system highlights key words that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns. What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change, Boston, to use and retain this recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of the collection of cortico Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Cortico will [inaudible] retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say out loud, I agree.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you, everyone said it. Great. Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in the conversation and to support those goals, I'd like to introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. First of all, please speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. Third, share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Four, stay curious, ask honest questions.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Five, Pause, take time for reflection. Six, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words do have an impact. Seven, when possible close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phone on silent. Eight, if you need to take a moment or take a break, let me know in the chat. Is everybody good with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: All right. Great. Already. So, the first thing we're going to do is a brief centering activity, for the ease of this virtual conversation we're going to use a modified circle called a circle process where each person will take a turn and I'll help transition us from one person to the next. And you can always pass or pass and ask for us to come back to you if you're not comfortable when I call on you.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: So, this is going to be a quick round of introductions and we're going to use something called the PIES, P-I-E-S.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Dawn, I'm sorry to interrupt you. Someone's phone isn't muted and I'm hearing a lot of wind or something. I don't know, and I can see Florella. I don't know if her video is possible to work, but someone's phone is not muted and it's this annoying whish sound. Sorry to interrupt.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Sorry, but it's my air conditioner and I need it on. It's very hot in here. So, what should I do?

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Okay. Thanks Florella. Thank you, Michael. That's better. Yes. So, we're going to do something called the PIES where we check in and you can pick one, or you could do more than one up to four. What it means is, PIES, P is physically, I is intellectually, E is emotionally, S is spiritually. And like I said, you can choose any one of the four. So this is going to be a quick round of introductions and we're going to have you share your first name, where you're located right now, one value that is important to you and let us know how you are using the PIES method, and I will start.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: My name is Dawn, I'm located in Lynn, Mass, of value that's important to me is equity, and how I'm feeling right now, I'll say physically and I'm feeling sleepy. So, how about we go to Paul? You're on mute, we can't hear you if you're trying to speak.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: My name is Paul Simmons, I'm currently in Monongahela, Pennsylvania. I would say my value is accountability in the context of this conversation. And that's essentially it.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: I live in Boston. Just kidding. And my primary interest is in quality of lives, not only for myself, but that's a big part of it. And I'm tired today too.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: My name's Michael and I'm coming to you from my home in Arlington, of value that's important to me is at risk of repeating, although flak... What did they say? Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery. Accountability is a value that's important to me. Doing what you say and following up and not flaking out and showing up on time is a value that I value. And in terms of my check-in, I'm actually feeling full because I just ate two hotdogs for lunch. Probably should have stopped at one, but they're really good.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Ron Bell. I live in... I'm actually in Milton, but I grew up in Mission Hill, of value to me, one of my values is economic empowerment, economic justice, how am I doing today? I'm a little caught between the physical, the emotional, spiritual side. I just got a call today from a friend of mine to go pray for a person that grew up with me that was murdered last night.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: So, pardon me if I see a little off or whatever, or I seem a little off, but this person was shot in Mattapan in the head and killed. So I'm making sure that I don't overdo it as far as going to see him.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: All right. Well, now that we know who's here, let's get to the core of our conversation. This part should take about 15 to 20 minutes. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we've learned about inequality in America and Boston and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'm going to give everyone two minutes to reflect on this question, and write it down somewhere if that's helpful, you don't have to, but if that's helpful for you to write it down, feel free. Then I want you to think about what experience in your life got you to this question? Because I'm going to then ask you to share both your question and your experience, and it's really important to keep your experience personal.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: It has to be something that you experienced directly. So, after a couple minutes, we start. We'll go around in a circle and each person will share their question and then tell the story of an experience that led them to their question. So, I'll give everybody a couple minutes, okay? (silence)

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: And again, it's what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? (silence) Are people ready? Okay. Is there someone who would like to volunteer to go first? (silence)

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Here's my question. My question is, how are young people, young people in their 20s, 30s, even 40s, are going to be able to live and buy a home in Boston? That's my question. You want me to tell the story now?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And the story is probably, I don't know, over 35 years ago, I was living in Brookline and taking in a border, in an apartment I rented so my daughter could go to the Brookline schools, which I thought was really good. She was like, she's 48 and she was in elementary school so it was a long time ago. And my landlady who had bought the house for... It was a three family house we were living in, raised my rent from 700 to 1100 in one year and I had to move.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And so, we moved to Jamaica Plain. And then several years later... I mean, I was real mad and angry, even though I was a leader of the Brookline Tenant Union, coordinated the entire towns' election and all the 20 precincts, and I just felt powerless and just left and contested. Anyway, a couple of years later, in '95 or '96, I was renting in Jamaica Plain, and a friend of mine [Chrissolio] who had become a realtor, who I knew from years ago, told me about this first-time home buyers program that the city ran.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: That if you went to this class downtown you could get a $2,000 grant or loan that would turn into a grant from the city to buy a home if you were a first-time home buyer. And it was for low-income people, which I wasn't making a lot of money at the time so I qualified. And so, I went through this, got the thing, and I found an apartment, 94 Forest Hills Street, in Jamaica Plain, for $72,000 and was able to buy it through this first-time home buyers thing.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I got a grant, I got a special, soft second mortgage through the Mass Affordable Housing Alliance and bought this place. And I lived there for several years. Later, Jessica and I got married, we moved to Arlington, I still own it. That apartment, it's your basic triple decker, tens of thousands of other triple deckers, not the whole building, just one floor, a thousand square feet, two bedrooms and a front room is now assessed by the city at about $500,000.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, that's crazy to me. So, how can anyone... I mean, I could never buy that house now, even though I make good money. And my daughter who moved to Phil... She's 48, bought a house in Philadelphia for 200 and something thousand dollars, could never, even though she makes a lot of money with her partner. So, that's my question. And that's my story.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, I was able to do it because I'm old, I'm 74, in '95/'96 I could buy this place with 72,000 and maybe by inflation, it might be 150 if normal inflation would take place, but it's 500. So, that's my question, how has anyone who's not a gazillionaire going to be able to live and stay in Boston. That's my story. And I'm sticking with it. And I'm done.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: All right. I guess I'll go around in circle, how I see it on my screen. So Paul, you want to go next? Your question and your lived experience relating to your question.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Over the years I had a tendency to be a constituent service person. Not that I was in elected office or part of city government, but people would ask me if I could help them on this or of the other and I generally know what agency to go to, just to shepherd their concerns. And obviously, I can't do this because for the moment I'm out of town, but I am getting the same type of requests and getting the same type of complaints that both individual residents of the city and organized neighborhood associations are getting no real redress from their elected officials or public employees on issues they're concerned about.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: I don't mean like the cosmic stuff, I'm talking about things like speed bumps, crosswalks, traffic signs, it's just basic nuts and bolts stuff. And I'm concerned about the lack of any real sense of accountability on the part of a lot of elected officials to the people they purport to represent. And so, in that sense, my lived experience is leading to a sense of anger fed by the utility of not being able to handle stuff because of physical distance between where I am in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Can you help me just a little bit by framing what you just said into a question? I'm not totally clear on what your actual question about Boston, the above is.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Meaning, somebody that's just be a resident of the city, somebody that I might've helped in the past will call me up down here and say, "Paul, we have a rat problem, who should I contact? I've tried to contact," we'll keep the name of the elected official, "And gotten no redress." So I then have to deal with, give them the address of the people over [10/10 00:19:03] Mass AB they're supposed to handle rodent infections.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: They make a follow-up phone call, but it's been my experience, I get better results when I physically go to see these people in their offices. And that is something I can't do as a result, maybe two or three weeks later, again, I get another phone call from the same person, "Paul, we haven't gotten any follow-up on the rat problem." And that feeds back into my earlier statement about accountability.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Thank you, Paul. All right. Florella, you can tell us about what your question is and the story of an experience that led you to your question.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Yeah, sure. Okay. Let me turn off the air conditioner and hope I won't sweat too much. Hold on. Well, my issue is pretty large, and I don't know if I can condense it into this amount of time, but the question would be, how can we make the City of Boston less dysfunctional? We have gotten ourselves into a real mess here, like many cities in the US and maybe around the world where we perceived locally through the Walsh administration that we were critically short on housing and that providing housing was important.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Now, the problem is that Walsh, because of his ties to construction industry let developers take over this initiative and the developers, they're not so interested in quality of life issues or even in costs. Now they came up with this term called affordable housing, which is actually a developers term and what it amounts to is a slight reduction of rent for a year.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Now, that's not really going to help a lot of people in the long run, but it provided the developers with an excuse who I erect here in my part of towns, literally hundreds of high rises, which is going to have a completely disastrous effect in terms of climate change issues in the near future, and the delivery of city services, including water and sewer, electric service is going to be deteriorated because every source has already said they don't want to provide more equipment.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: So we're facing a crisis of infrastructure mainly, and also a surging population that we can't possibly handle, because I mean, the rat situation here in this part of town is already out of control, as you know rats bring disease and cause other problems. So we're looking at, between one issue and the other, we're looking at it very large deficit in terms of quality of life in the near future.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: What can be done about it? Well I do have a solution, but nobody wants to hear it. Somebody, an entity or a group, needs to file a class action suit against the BPDA. Nobody wants to do that because they're a very powerful organization, but I don't see another solution. I spent all day with these groups online, discussing these issues, so I'm pretty well-informed, but we'll end up saying the same thing, "We feel powerless to do anything about it."

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: And this ties into what Michael was talking about also, and what Paul was talking about, and I think we're all talking around the same kinds of issues that Boston, it's not Paris, it's not London, it's not LA, we don't have that physical space here, which was an issue with the Olympics. We don't have the physical space to do these things, but we have grandiose delusions.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Do you consider your personal experience that brings you to this question? The things you were saying about trying to work on this with other people? I just want to get a little more information that your [crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Oh, well, yeah. Okay. Sure. Fine. So, given the experiences I've had in working with these individuals and groups over the past two or three years, I've the conclusion that I have to leave. Boston doesn't work for me anymore. That's just the bottom line. It's not only the money that I'm wasting on an apartment. I mean, it's thousands of dollars for no security. That's another issue, and I've no security, landlord could throw me out tomorrow. No reason he should, I mean, I always pay the rent, but that's not the point.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: I have no security, so I'm looking to move out of town and I'm looking for security so I'm thinking of buying a house. So, that's my story. And that's why. Because of the changes that I've mentioned a few minutes ago, that's why I come to that conclusion.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My question to Boston's, when will Boston stop ignoring and mistreating black men and black boys? And from my experience, just what I'd mentioned earlier about a friend of mine being shot in the head and killed, two weeks ago I had to speak at a funeral of a friend who had my name, which was weird, Ronnie, after 30 years experience working with, in particularly, communities that had been ignored, in particularly, black men, being [inaudible] and we needed every disparity, whether it's in Mass incarceration, health disparities, income disparities, and I can go on, that's my story.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you. All right. Well, that was really interesting. We got a lot of good experience and some really amazing questions. So, now for the next 15 minutes or so, we're going to engage in something called connecting our experiences. So what I want you to do next is to think back to each of the questions and experiences that were just shared in our group and find someone in the group whose question and/or experience resonates with your own life.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Then I want you to speak to that person directly and tell them why their question and/or experience resonated with you and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. So, I'll give everyone a minute or two to reflect, and then, it's just open, so whoever's ready can start us off and we'll go from there.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Okay. So my question, because of our somewhat connected experiences would be, and I'm not sure it's a question, but to Michael, he's coming to the housing issue from one perspective, I'm coming to it, that tension internally, it's the same, but I'm still in the position that he was in when he was younger, I'm still a tenant. But the problem with the housing issue that both of us faced is really the same that Boston does not have a lot of housing stock and the housing stock they're building is not going to help, because it doesn't serve families, and children, especially, these high rises are very dangerous for children.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: There's nowhere for them to play and so forth, so the housing issue still is critical to many groups of people whether they're homeowners or tenants, whether they're young, or old, or retired, or students, we all are vying for the same piece of the pie here. And the pie is very small to begin with, because this is a small town and this is the problem. Boston has always been a small town and we've always been somewhat in denial about it.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: And the problem now is, is because the other issue involving construction has reduced the amount of green space. I didn't bring that up, which also is going to contribute to the adverse effects of climate change, because we have fewer trees here, we have a heat sink here in Allston because of the amount of concrete it's going to raise the temperature, that's going to use more electricity, more energy.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: So, we're making it worse, and at the same time, we're looking at thousands of students pouring back into the city in another few weeks and they're going to be looking for housing. And I think, I personally believe that the rents should come down, and I know their arguments against that. I had a rent controlled apartment, it worked fine for many years. I don't think people understood the law actually, which is why they voted it out.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: But I think that someone's got to give, it's one of those things where everybody's pulling in the same direction, somebody's got to give a little bit up here in this equation. And well, Michael, I mean, you solved your problem personally, you're not in a housing crisis yourself, but the issue continues. So, that would be my response.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Well, it probably is, but no, that's not the only reason, I have the business to consider. There are many issues, security issues surrounding the business that I have to deal with. And also my commercial.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: My inventory's worth a great deal of money. And this building has security, but it's not the greatest, and increasingly we're a bit... But also the crime has increased, we are, according to the police report, there were 12 break-ins in the Brighton Center area just last weekend. This is another concern. So, it's a whole bunch of issues really, but they all point in the same direction, frankly, that I need to leave.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Well, actually, somebody suggested Lowell, because of the art scene. I don't know, I do know someone who has property there, but it's not a single-family house, so I don't know. But that area, North of Boston. North. I don't want to go south. North.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Story about wanting to leave. And I just wanted to clarify, she said, I think in part, was it also because of the, you said security of the inventory you have because of the break-ins and I think you said this, but I'm not sure also, because of the cost of buying a single-family home in Boston is much more than it would be in Lowell or some other place.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: It's because... Here's the problem that we're facing. This gets into politics, and voting, that's another issue I wanted to talk about, but the problem here is that I walked through Brighton every day on my way to work and home after home is no longer a single-owner home. They're all apartments, they're all, not that many condos, they're all rentals. And so, as a result of this, there is no voter base in this part of town. And that's a serious issue, because these people are running for office who's going to vote for them? Nobody around here, that's a problem. That's a serious problem. So, that's another issue.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Going back to the question in reference, what resonated with me, it actually what everyone said, in particularly, I would pause to around accountability. As we approached this upcoming election, the preliminary election, on September 14th and the general on November 2nd, oftentimes our elected officials or candidates will promise us the world and when they get in office they forget, and particularly with the black community.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: And I'll be very specific African-Americans. They are often overlooked, they're often disrespected in the City of Boston, and I'll go back to what I originally said, in particularly, black men. And we have an opportunity with the upcoming election and with the upcoming vote on a commission for black men and black boys to stop to help change the city's, response to my question, ignoring and mistreating, and for them to even ponder over it would be a problem.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: So with Paul's accountability, one, the housing with Florella, my housing stability is not good as a leader in our community. So, that's what resonated with me as we discussed this con... Continued this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you, Ron. And I'm glad you said more than one issue too, because I should have said at the beginning of this part of the conversation that it's fine if you connect with more than one persons what they answered. So it's fine. Sure. To talk about that. So, Paul, did you want to say something that did [crosstalk] resonate with you?

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Well, it resonates for me because every issue or every issue that's been brought up so far, black folks in general, African-Americans in particular, and African-American men, even more particularly, are at the pointed end of the spear. You see all this self-congratulation, for example, about the burst, even the census released his first batch of numbers, which ignores the fact that Boston's black population has decreased.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: And so, what happens is we get all kinds of rhetorical play, but when it comes to matters of substance, be it broad policy, or be it something as basic as rat control, we will essentially considered to be expendable, and I stress it, even when these requests come from organized groups, the city feels that there's no downsize to ignoring it. Even when the complaints come to district elected officials, be they on the council, or be they in the State House about events in their district, I get the feeling that everything is performative.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: And as I mentioned before, because for certain things I can generally resolve in person, but we can't because I can't be in person. I find this thing more frustrating than usual. And it's always frustrating.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you, Paul. Did anyone else want to add anything about connecting our experiences? Since that's the topic we're talking about now, is actually connecting our experiences with the questions everyone had. Did anyone else want to add anything about that or do people feel like we're good on that?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I think we did good on that, but you changes this when you talked briefly about something you wanted to talk about, which was voting in Allston-Brighton, and there's no baits. So, I've never resonated with me as well, because it just sparked my attention. Did you want to elaborate or say something about that and we can move on if that's okay with the group?

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Yes. That's okay. And/or we could move into the next piece, which is drawing connections. So maybe, I don't know if this fits better into the draw connections or the experience.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: I think that's a good lead into the next. So, if everybody talked about their first lived experiences, I think that's a good lead into the next section of our conversation, which is called drawing connections. And in this part of our conversation, we can take 10 to 15 minutes. Let's talk a little bit about what we're hearing. What are you hearing in people's experiences and drawing connections between topics. So, maybe Florella, you want to start based on the question that Ron just asked about voting.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Well, in general, yes. I think, generally speaking, what I'm hearing from other people is really what I started out to say that the city is dysfunctional, and in many ways. And for good reasons, we don't have good leadership, and we don't have good leadership because a lot of people don't vote, and they don't vote because they're transient. And I'm not sure what to do about that. I don't have an answer right off hand, because the way we've structured the housing situation, it's going to be even more transients and even fewer permanent residents. So, I don't know where we go with that.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Well, I'm hearing a lot. People are talking about Boston not being safe, I'm hearing, that was a call from Leonard, the guy was telling you about, I'm hearing about people not feeling secured in their housing, and I'm hearing as it relates to voting that they're not really pleased with some of the candidates. That's what I'm hearing. I'm hearing they're pleased with some of the, I mean, the mayoral candidates, I'm hearing that they're pleased with a lot of the other candidates, but this is what I'm hearing. And that's why I want to make sure that we provide a way that folks can really ask the tough questions and get a response and get some action.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you, Ron. Paul or Michael, do you want to talk about what you're seeing in terms of drawing connections with people's experiences?

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Well, speaking for myself, I'm seeing a lot of Middleton disengagement in populations that are not transient. In particular, there are a lot of people that put a lot of sweat equity into getting property. Some instances we're talking 40/50 years ago for elderly folks. But all of a sudden they're finding that their property is assessed at a rate beyond their ability to pay. They're seeing, again, all the basic quality of lifestyle that everybody here is discussed to some degree or another, and the justified feeling that their concerns are being dismissed to the Hall or at the State House, again depending on the issue.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Speaking for myself, what I see are a lot of people that are well-meaning on the policy side, but what they offer are abstractions, having little or nothing to do with the actual issues they think they're dealing with. So again, broadly speaking, everybody else has actually expressed the issues better than I can, but that's also why I said accountability at the beginning of this session.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Yes. These are people that have made a rational decision, based on their lived experience that they get nothing back from government at any level. And as a result of that, they come to the conclusion that public participation, maybe beyond the neighborhood association level, is a fool's errand. And because their premise that government in their experience does not care about them as citizens, as residents, as people, that decision not to vote is rational.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: I can deal with trying to make a counter argument, but it's difficult to do so successfully, again, because their premise is correct, that they, however you want to define them, don't care about us.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). So, what I hear you saying, it's a combination of elected officials not being accountable, that unless you, someone who's obviously very articulate, shows up in person about a rat problem or something like that. You mentioned speed bumps, nothing gets done. And I also heard from Florella, that because of the lack of security, break-ins, cost of housing, it's rational to leave and go to a city or town where it's a lot cheaper and you could have a single-family house, in Lowell perhaps, for $300,000, I'm guessing or something, instead of $800,000 in Boston and Oak Square that, I'm making up numbers here slightly, so it seems rational to leave unless something changes. Like you said, you used to have a rent control department that's not possible anymore.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: No. And it was a good law, if I may break in, I don't know if anyone remembers the law, do you Michael?

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: The issue was, because maybe not everybody knows, when you moved into apartment the owner could raise rent in only a certain percentage a year until you moved out. And then they could charge whatever they wanted, and then it started all over again. So, it wasn't, at least in my case, it wasn't keeping an apartment at a certain level forever, it was only the length of a tenancy.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: But it did tend to encourage longer-term tenancies, which was good thing, and also people tended, I think, to do their own, I certainly did, their own repairs and their own take care... They had more sense of responsibility in terms of the unit. And now, there's no sense of responsibility. It's like a hotel room, essentially. That's what I see from the transients and younger tenants, they have no investment whatsoever. It's like a hotel room to them, a nine month hotel room.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: And they couldn't care less about the property, they couldn't care less about the town or they certainly don't care about who's running for office, locally, or even maybe a wider spectrum. But these are some of the issues that are tied in. It's, the point I was trying to make, it's a complex problem with many facets. So, that's why it's a good issue in a sense.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I would guess, but this could help me out here and correct me if I'm wrong, I'm assuming in Allston-Brighton, there are a lot more students than there are say in Hyde Park or Roslindale.

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Yes. That's true. Absolutely. And that's why, like Hyde Park is a good example or Roslindale, they have a better voter base and they have managed to resist some of the bad effects of the development, because they have neighborhood groups and they're better organized, but in Allston-Brighton, there is nothing. There really aren't enough groups that have any power at all, or there aren't enough people to join them who are experienced residents. That's how I would put it. So, this is becoming a transient city, is what I'm saying.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Thank you, Florella. Thank you, Michael. Did anyone else want to add any more about drawing connections or do we feel that part of the conversation is good? Okay. All right. Well, we're actually making very good time. So, we're actually ready for the wrap up section of the conversation, and basically, in the wrap up, we're just going to go quickly around the circle and share something that you will be taking away with you. Do you have any closing thoughts that you would like to share or other general reflections on the conversation? And also, do you have any questions for us? That's it.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: So, let's go around and share something you'll be taking away with you and any closing thoughts you'd like to share, other general reflections on the conversation or questions, and whoever wants to start can start. [inaudible]

nodes.speaker: Florella
nodes.words: Oh yeah. Okay. All right. Sorry. Okay. I was a little surprised that some of us had similar experiences, I guess that was what I take away from it. That we were pretty much focusing on the same kinds of issues, if you look at it structurally, we really were. So, that's my takeaway.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My takeaway just to piggyback of what Florella just mentioned about our similar experiences, I know Paul is in Pennsylvania but he lives in Boston, has a rich history in Boston. Michael works with a lot of folks in Boston, and then Florella lives in Allston, I'm from Mission Hill, and I'm living in Milton, that when we talk about voices of those unheard, even in our robes, as we are, leaders, and entrepreneurs, and so forth, we're unheard. We are unheard.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: We talk about those that maybe on the bottom of the barrel, but we're not too far from that. And so, hopefully, my take away is that, continue to do the work I've been doing, but working smarter and to surround myself with people that are like-minded to really take on the powers that be. So, that's my takeaway.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, I think one thing was different and I want to direct this to Ron. Ron, you talked mostly about the lack of attention to black men and boys, so one question I have in terms of the wrap up, you didn't go into a lot of detail or your personal story, although obviously I know some of them and I'm asking this in terms of what it's like to be a black man to participate in this, or what might be likely for other black men participating in these discussions, a leading question, I know you've talked about reliving trauma and paining people to do that, how much of that is... So what would it, I don't know how to even phrase the question, is part of not going into the personal story because it's too painful to talk about it again, and part of the reason I asked that is, the whole theory behind this is hearing personal stories, as opposed to general statements is what's going to hopefully motivate people and connect people.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So I'm wondering, what was behind, I mean, I've heard some of these stories and all of us have from you personally, not going into a lot of that in this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Right. One of the reasons why, and thank you, Michael, for the question, I didn't go into my personal story because it is too painful, at the outset I'd said I had lost a friend who was shot in the head and murdered and Mattapan, so that's painful. When I talk about my story, it's painful, it's like reliving trauma. I talk about the times being spit on by drunken white boys and go on to Cub Scout when I was nine years old.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: That's painful to talk about, because I could still smell the liquor in the spit, which has a bad smell. I mean, I talk about being a young kid growing up in Mission Hill running a major community center and was initiated with Charles Stuart murder when a pregnant white woman was alleged killed by a black man, and those are all a hunt for every black men, civil rights savagely violated, pants pulled down in front of the center, I was going to become the director, couldn't happen to me.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: That's painful, so I can go on and on. One of the officials in that year, when we started dunk the boat doing a couple of years later in 1992, one of the officials was my brother who was murdered on Christmas Day in 1992. So, when you talk about stories, and then you're asking people to come tell this story, that brings knowledge to those who are collecting it and look at us as being experiments.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: So, I think it's important that we compensate when we talk about equity, when we talk about reaching people that have been overlooked, mistreated, literally written off, and then you're asking them to relive that experience, it's painful. So, that's why I was hesitant. And you're going to hear many stories like that, and it is traumatic to go through this.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I'm sitting here with people that I love, I'm sitting here with people that I trust, but it's still painful to even talk about what I'm experiencing. So, that's why I was hesitant in telling that story. So, as I continue with this project, and as I talked to my staff and those that are part of this campaign, take into consideration that people are dealing with a lot of stuff, whether it's health, whether it's poverty, and whether they feel comfortable being able to tell this story.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: The people that don't look like them, that they don't trust, that they don't want to tell their business, that they don't want to hear from them how to be black, and what we need. So, it's hard being a black man in America, is hard being a black man in Boston. That's my story.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. That's why I think it would be important for the facilitators of black men to be other black men. That makes sense to you, Paul? Paul's head is [inaudible]. Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: One point, which is, I'm not all that happy with the term microaggression, but I've been fairly privileged, both before and when I went to Boston, nevertheless, I find it interesting that you're more day-to-day irritations, I mean [inaudible] irritations that, pardon gender reference, but the ratio of Karen's general population tends to be much higher, in my experience, with rest of neighborhoods. As a result-

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Are much higher in progressive neighborhoods like Jamaica Plain, was just a day-to-day thing of at least five to 10 aggravations per day, if I lived there. Cambridge is even worse. And to get on Rons' point, it's not just a matter of trusting non-black folks is also a matter of trusting black folks that are employed by non-black folks. I mean, I won't go into specifics, but Ron, rolling off I can tell about anyone of a number of people that might share, like the same goes, they have the complexion but not the connection.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: And in a lot of progressive organizations, there's a high rate of people. So, the racial identity of the people doing saltation is secondary to their ability to establish mutual respect at their audience.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I just wanted to pursue that and ask Ron, but do you think you said the racial composition of the facilitator is less important than their ability to show respect?

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: No. No. What I'm saying is, I agree with Ron that you have to have black people doing these types of interviews, but the black people that you bring in have to have the ability to relate to the folks that are part of the group, rather than regurgitate.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Yeah. Because what you see are a lot of people that will come in with an externally generated model, a model that they should know, based on their own lived experiences, black people doesn't work with black folks, but nevertheless, that's 90% of my encounter is with, shall we say, professional progressive black folks. They regurgitate outside bottoms. I find that intensely irritating.

nodes.speaker: Paul
nodes.words: Respect for the community, respect for the individuals in the group, the ability to not patronize folks for a non-black audience.

nodes.speaker: Dawn
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Well, I just wanted to let folks know a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts you shared. These recordings will be transcribed, indexed, and shared with the team. You'll receive an email from us when all the conversations are ready to review on the LVN platform. And I want to thank you so much for joining us and sharing your thoughts, and it was terrific. And I'm going to stop recording now and thank you. Thank you very much.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah, I can hear you. Okay. All right. I don't know why I can hear you, because you're supposed to be muted, but that's okay. All right, so let me just get started with you guys so that we're not on the phone all night. But I truly, truly value your time and attention.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Welcome to one of the Real Talk Boston conversations. Thank you for responding to the invite and joining this network of voice conversations that will happen all across the City of Boston. We invited you to the gathering by asking you to think of one most pressing question you have about the future of the City of Boston. Our goal today is to share and celebrate one of those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want speak and be listened to knowing it will matter.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I will now begin recording our conversation, and I need to share three important items of information with you before we do the instructions. Okay? Okay. First is the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across divides, which include the neighborhoods, political, and cultural, etc., and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates who are running for public office and neighborhoods through the city.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience rather than entering conversation with your position on the upcoming election or specific candidates. So, whatever we talk about, this has to come from you, your lived experience. I don't want to know about what somebody else did. It's really about what you did, okay? We are doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that will improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording of this conversation following our meeting today. The video recording will be discarded, and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. These conversations, long with all the other conversations that are taking place across the city, will be shared with members of the Real Talk for Change members, sorry, participating in the conversations of the Local Voices Network, which is what LVN stands for.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations. LVN system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation, and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to the explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change Boston to use and retain recording in accordance with its mission. You all understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with its mission.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: If you understand and agree to this, please say your name and, "I agree." So, you all can unmute, and then say your name and you agree.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Michael, unmute yourself and say, "I agree." Okay. All right. Well, we're going to move on. So, Michael, at some point, just tell me that you agree before we end, right?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: so, lastly, I want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversations, and to support their goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. First, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Allow others to finish speaking by taking turns. Stay curious. Ask honest questions. Pause. Take time for reflection. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, notifications, and put your phone on silent so that we have no interruptions.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: If you need to take a moment, take a break, let me know in the chat, if you can. If not, just let me know, because I know some of you are on the phone. Is this okay with everybody? Everybody on board with those guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. For the ease of this virtual conversation, we are going to use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn. I'm posting the order... I'm not posting anything. I will help us to transition from one person to the next. And you can always pass, or pass and ask to come back to you, right? So, we're going to do a check-in in a new way. Does anybody have any questions so far?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So, the questions that we are going to do, we're going to use a process called PIES, P-I-E-S, which is acronym for physically checking in, intellectually checking in, emotionally checking in, and spiritually in. What you're going to do is you're going to share your name, and where you are located right now, and a value that's important to you, and then you're going to check in using one of those four that I just named, physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, I will go first just to model how this should be done, okay? My name is Marilyn, and I am in Dorchester, sitting in my front room right now, or actually on the beach. I want to say that a value that is important to me is fairness. I just... fairness. And I want to check in emotionally, because I feel like this process, trying to get this done, because it's really important stuff, is kind of making me tense. So, yeah, that's where I am and how I'm checking in. With that, I'm going to hand it off to Marinella.

nodes.speaker: Marinella
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Marinella. I'm in Dorchester. I am actually sitting on the front porch of my building. Checking in, I feel... I'm checking in-

nodes.speaker: Keyna
nodes.words: Am I supposed to... Dealing with families is stressful, is very stressful. So, trying to balance that with everything else brings a lot of emotion into everything that's being done.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: My name is Shanette. I'm in Dorchester. Physically, I feel... I would say I feel alert. Physically, emotionally, spiritually, I'm very alert in learning something new.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Wonderful. Thank you so much. And with that, I'm going to pass it off to Carol. So, Carol, could you unmute yourself?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: An old home. Spiritually, I'm trying to keep the faith and understand the situations that people put on you when you haven't exactly done anything to them, and trying to understand and... Let's see. What else? Emotionally, sometimes I get tearful. Intellectually, my brain is still working even though I'm a senior. I'm a pretty old lady, and I've been blessed a lot, because I still do the things that I've often done, artistically, and musically, and all that stuff. I guess that's that, I guess.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Michael. I live in Dorchester. I'm sitting in my living room at the present moment, looking out the window. I value topics like for senior citizens and the homeless. I'm very big about that. And as far spiritually, it's only by the grace of God that I'm able to sit here and conversate with you guys on the phone. Basically, that's it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you so very much. So, we're going to move right along, and thank you all so much for that. Now that we know who's here, let's get to the core of our conversation. So, as we-

nodes.speaker: Lorena
nodes.words: [crosstalk]. Sorry, Marilyn. I'm just going to jump in. It seems like everybody's all set, so I'm going to let you guys have your Real Talk for Change conversation.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, bye-bye. Okay, so, as we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think what your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future. Take a couple of minutes to reflect on what I just said, and if you need to, you can write it down, if that's going to be helpful, but think about what experiences in your life got you to this question. Again, the question is: What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay, I'm Michael, and my perception of the future of Boston is looking pretty bright. For me, things look pretty bright too. If you hear some noise, that's because I live by the commuter rail, and the train comes through a lot, so it might drown me out until they go past. But as I was saying, I think the future for Boston is pretty bright. I'm not really excited about one of the mayoral candidates of yet, because I'm feeling all of them out. I'm looking forward to seeing that I can vote somebody that's going to change some of the outlook on Boston as far as crime. I'm very big about that.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And as far as the pandemic, I have a problem with some of the rules that they're setting, because I don't know whether to wear masks or not wear masks. I'm fully vaccinated, but I still need the protection of a mask. So, it's like I'm in a confused state right now. So, my thing is to just stay in the house and don't partake in any events until they sure about where this pandemic is headed. So, I believe in staying safe and keeping my friends safe.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, you really answered what your place is in that future, but your question, if you were to pose a question about the future of Boston, what would that question be?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Because I think senior citizens are treated unfairly, and the homeless are treated unfairly, and I hear a lot of talk with the candidates, and even the current politicians say that, "We look out for our seniors." I have a lot of questions about that statement as far as looking out for the seniors, because, one, I am a senior citizen. So, anything involving a senior citizen interests me.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And homelessness, I was once upon a time homeless. They need help in those shelters, and I understand why homeless people rather sleep on the streets than in the shelters, because they're treated unfairly in these shelters. That's one of them hidden agendas that society doesn't know about. So, I'd like to pursue both of those topics in the near future.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Awesome. Great. Thank you so much for sharing. Michael. Who would like to go next? And remember, we're framing our responses out of our own lived experience, right? So, again, I'll repeat the question. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Marinella
nodes.words: My question would be what are we going to do about gentrification? Because of my experiences and what I've gone through in life, I feel like I am being pushed out of this metropolis, that is becoming a metropolis, Boston, and getting squeezed out. So, that's my question. What are we going to do about gentrification for individuals who have gone through some stuff and trying to live in this city, but it's getting too much to even be able to basically try to live here, on top of the everyday struggles of trying to just exist on a daily basis of daily things, from work, to housing, to whatever. That's my concern, that's my question, and that's what my question would be in the future as to here, because at this rate, I'm like, "Do I got to leave here to be comfortable, to have a nest egg?" You know, things of those things.

nodes.speaker: Keyna
nodes.words: Similar to what Marinella just said, the question about [inaudible] of Boston has to do with affordability and housing, which is also what Michael spoke about. Looking at what's going on in the city now, I don't see Boston being a place that I have a future in, because, given what's going on, I will not be able to afford to live in Boston. That's an issue for a lot of people. It also deals with the gentrification, and the homelessness, and affordability.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). Okay. All right. Good. Thank you so much. Who would like to go next? We have Miss Carol and we have Shanette?

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I was going to... Okay, so what I... My question is: What am I expecting of these mayors? Who's going to hold these mayors accountable for, these candidates accountable [inaudible] they run on? And where do I see myself as?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Carol, why don't you go ahead? So, the question again: What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah, like what do you see... What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in the future?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Well, I guess where I look at the future of Boston, I think a lot of things need to be done for Boston. I think it has to do with teaching and learning, and don't forget the histories that once were. I know we all want to run to the future because we want to forget the past of a lot of things that have happened, but if you've got young people coming up and they're not learning, what is their future going to be like? [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, is there anything out of your lived experience that you can speak to about what you want for the future for Boston and where you, Carol, fit into it?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Well, I'm upset, you know? It has to do with family, because they're the next generation and everything else like that. I don't know where it's going to go. I don't know who's going to listen, who will listen, because I remember trying to speak, and say what I had to say, and ask questions, and then being criticized [inaudible] "Oh, what, are you making fun of me, or what are you saying this thing for? You trying to make trouble?" We all listening to different lies and everything else like that.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: There's got to be a way of understanding, and appreciating, and caring about all people who are in this Boston, and there's got to be a way that we can understand each other. There's got to be a way. If a new mayor comes in, a new whomever, all these people who are qualified to be in that position have to like at all that. It can't just be favoritism or, "Oh, no. Well, don't deal with that over there, or leave that." No, it's got to be as one, because this is United States. It isn't separated states, or country, or America. It's United.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: I remember having my hand over my heart and saying pledge allegiance to the flag. What was wrong with that? Why was it taken out? We need to look through a lot of things. That's why say a lot of things should be taught, retaught. What was wrong with it? It was us. It was America. Is was us, united, people of the United States.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: No, what I was saying is a question that I have is for mayoral candidates, how we're going to hold them accountable for their actions, like how, what she's saying, United States of America. How are we [inaudible] hold the mayoral candidates accountable for their actions? They run on a whole different plateau, but then they veer off and no one hold them accountable.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, now I want to... I just want to move us into the next part, which is connecting these experiences about what was just shared. What I want to do next is think back to each of the questions and experiences that were shared in our group. Find someone whose question or experience resonated with your own life, then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you, and share the story from your life that connects with their experience.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Shanette? I resonate with her. Bringing it back to Boston, what we need to understand, Boston is the gateway to all other towns in the state of Massachusetts, because everything begins with Boston. If you notice, when they have championships or whatever, they always have the parades in Boston. And if you notice, people that work in the suburbs, they come to Boston to work. I mean, they live in the suburbs. They come to Boston to work. So, Boston is the gateway to all the other towns in Massachusetts.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Boston is always going to be around, may the future look dim or bright. What these candidates need to understand, they need to be accounted, like she said, for the things that go on in Boston. Boston is not a forgotten town. Boston is [inaudible]. Everyone all across the world know about Boston for sports, or for its history, and whatever. These candidates should continue to follow that trend to make Boston as popular as it is today.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So, I see Boston as being very bright from my experience, because I've been in Boston since the '60s. As each year comes and go, things do get better, but not a lot better, but they are getting better, as long as we, as Bostonians, learn how to deal with the racial injustice, the criminal system, and all that type of... housing for the homeless, things for the seniors. That's the only way we can make Boston a promising community, and that's totally just my opinion.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: We're going to continue to move along and ask someone else, listening to the responses from everyone with regard to their questions or their experiences, what and who had something that they shared that resonates with you, that you can identify with. Who would like to go next?

nodes.speaker: Marinella
nodes.words: I identify with Michael when he was talking about being homeless. I was homeless at one point, and that resonated with me because... And being in Boston, I took a long time just to find a home again because of being homeless and the situation that is going on with the homeless population here. Now, even though I had a job and I was commuting from another city to get to this city, Boston, to work in a daily basis, it was a struggle. So, homelessness is a big part of my story too. You know what I'm saying?

nodes.speaker: Marinella
nodes.words: Those are some of the questions that I'm like, "Okay, what are we doing here? How do we help each other? How do we help the people who want to stay here and live here, grow old here?" because we see, in a couple more years, and, I mean, less than a couple more years, so what about me? How do I fit in? What role am I going to play? Will you all even listen to me? Will people even listen to me?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Don't they have some programs where if you come from a different place, or wherever you come from, and you come to Boston [inaudible]. Shouldn't we have some kind of programs here that people can be involved with, that they can learn something new. Shouldn't there be new program?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, I don't know. Maybe, but right now, who said something that resonated with you for you to even give that response? What was said that made you feel like that needs to happen?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Because the last lady that just spoke, she said she came to Boston through... I think she said she was homeless, and until she found something, I don't know if she's from Boston or someplace else, but [inaudible] if you go to another place, and you're walking around, and you're trying to find work or something like that, [inaudible] there be some kind of way that you can get involved with something and learn something [inaudible] to make a paycheck?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yeah, I think there should be a [inaudible] or something where you can go and learn something [inaudible] maybe a few weeks or something so you can get onto something to make a paycheck.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you. Keyna, how about you? I see you cooking. I'm coming over for dinner. So, was there something that was shared in someone's question or lived experience that resonates with you?

nodes.speaker: Keyna
nodes.words: Actually, I think just about everyone, because my issue is really the affordability of being able to be in Boston, and leads to gentrification leads to homelessness. So, being able to figure out how to not let that be what we're heading into, and how to stop it from happening is the big issue. How do we fix it?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Let's talk a little bit about what we're hearing and what we're hearing in people's experiences, which I think we probably just did. So, we are definitely reaching the end of our conversation, and we want to be able to just kind of connect with each other and these lived experiences, and want you to know that all of what you say is important. There are people who have concerns about their future, who never get an opportunity, really, to voice their opinion, or whose opinions they feel don't matter.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
