nodes.words: So, in what we're doing today, these collective voices and conversations, which are going to be compiled, are going to be used with other people's conversations, and they're going to be able to sort of link all of the commonalities together to raise those questions to those people who are thinking about leaving the city. You know what I mean? So, if gentrification, if homelessness, if elder care, if jobs and all of that is what you're saying is important, then there a whole lot of other people, pretty, who feel the same way. So, we want to collect all of that information and make sure that those people even seeking to be in office are hearing those voices, because oftentimes, it's just the people who everybody knows who gets heard. Ordinary people like us, they don't... They just pass us over.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: The hope is that in doing these conversations and hearing everyone's voices, we find the commonality. We see the intersections of where people... You're not so different in what you believe, and in your values, and what you see for the future of Boston, and what you feel or where you feel you will be placed in that future. So, all of this information is definitely very, very valuable, but we are going to wrap up unless someone has a burning question or something that they would like to talk about.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah, again, I'm Michael. Well, I shouldn't say that, because I'm the only guy on here, but my question is, with these candidates, it's surprising to me that I never see these people that's running for office in my neighborhood until it's time to vote. Only time that I see them in my neighborhood is when it's time to vote and they want my vote, but other than that, I don't see them in any other community at all. And I'm still kind of like messed up about that, you know? And I'm not the only one that feel like that, so I need to ask these candidates, if they have a forum, "Why is it the only time you come into my community is when you're trying to solicit votes? Other than that, we don't even see you at all."

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah, exactly. So, I sort of jumped the gun a little bit. I wanted to also ask, while we're wrapping up, for us to just go quickly through with everyone and ask: What is it from this particular conversation do you feel like you're taking away? What did you get from this conversation, and what will you walk away with? So, Keyna, tell me first.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Well, my name's Michael again. I just found the conversation from everyone very interesting that I can identify with each one of the persons on this call, and I'm walking away with a little bit more knowledge and a little be more understanding about certain things that goes on in the community.

nodes.speaker: Keyna
nodes.words: What I'm walking away with is that the issues are the same for everyone, no matter how old you think you are. It's some... Oh, I lost my train of thought. But it's a start to get the conversation started, and hopefully to be able to get it out to the people who can do something about it, and hopefully they do something about it.

nodes.speaker: Shanette
nodes.words: I would say [inaudible] knowledge, I would say, because now I can see different people's point of view. And I will say [inaudible] knowledge from every single person that's been on this call.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Well, it's good to hear everybody talk. It just feels that I belong more and more in this community with all these people that I've listened to today and someday hope to see in person, and just shake hands, or bump a fist or something, or maybe hug or something, and, "Hey, we're all in this together. We're working together," and that's the way it should be.

nodes.speaker: Marinella
nodes.words: I walk away with the fact that we have a lot in common, and I agree with Miss Carol and Michael that candidates should just not solicitate us only when it comes time for voting, and that we do have a lot in common, from housing, to senior's issues, to gentrification. So, it was great to know and be in the first time in this discussion to hear that I'm not alone, and that we all have some things in common.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Wonderful. Well, unless anyone else has any other questions or something that they'd like to share, we're just about to close our session. Any thoughts, questions, reflections, anything? No?

nodes.speaker: Keyna
nodes.words: I think it was good to hear different points of view on that. We're all kind of thinking the same thing-

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, we got that it was good to hear that folks are all thinking along the same lines, that the concerns are the same.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. That was good. So, again, Michael, only because when we were agreeing to this being recorded, we did not hear you agree that it was okay. So, can you just confirm that it is okay and you agree?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah, so again, appreciate all of you for your time and your attention, and I'm going to be reaching out to you again so I can tell you about how much we appreciated this conversation with each of you. Yeah, so I think that's it. Again, these conversations are going to connect with other people across the City of Boston to see, just as we discovered in our little group, the intersections and how much we're different but we're the same; we have the same concerns. So, we're going to just compare this with all of the other conversations that took place across the city.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, again, thank you again for your time, attention, and I'm wishing you all a good night. We will talk soon.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Hi everyone. My name is Reverend Dr. Norma. I am the founder and the Chief Financial officer of Amron international organization. I was raised in Boston, Massachusetts Dorchester, and I'm very happy to be a part of this project. So I have a lot of questions. So I'm here willing to learn on this conversation. Thank you all. Oh, pie. Pie.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Thank you. Hi everyone. My name is Corey Thompson. I'm the vice-president of West of Washington (WOW) and I'm also the founder and principal of Mobius Community Builders. It's a affordable housing development company. And how am I feeling today? Well, I'm grateful. I'm feeling very grateful this morning, a little sore and excited. We're having a barbecue at West of Washington, Norwell Park in Dorchester. Come and have some free food and some good music and free music. Anyway.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: It's from 12 to, sorry, from one to four, 12 to four, 12 to four, sorry. So I have a hard stop because I'm going to help prepare.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I am Cindy Diggs and I grew up in Mission Hill, Roxbury, and have been in the same home for probably 40 years. And I am the founder of Peace Boston, which is not very active now, but it was a very active hip hop peace movement. And for work, I am the community and cultural engagement manager at Mass General. And I've been an activist for over 40 years in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I'd say probably emotional because I'm working in the medical field and having this Delta back around and having all these mandates put back in place, it's kind of very emotional and frustrated.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Hello, good morning everyone. I am Priestess Ziona and my pronouns are she/her/hers and I was born and raised all over Boston, Massachusetts. One of my pies is physical. I'm not doing physically well. Lately, I'm prepping for surgery for later on this year, but I am a lot better than I was a couple of days ago. And yeah, I work in the community as a peer support for emotional and crisis support. And we talk about mental health recovery and do some public speaking and I'm also a published author. Thanks.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks for your pie. So you checked in physically, your pie was physical? Okay, great. Thank you all so much. I really appreciate you being here. So I'm going to read this and if you agree, oh, I was supposed to do this first. I'm sorry. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Real Change Boston to use and retain the recording in accordance with our mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree. Could you unmute one at a time and go with Norma first?

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I agree, but the only thing that I asked is that I come under my personal life and not Mass General.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And I Francesca agree as well. My understanding, Cindy, and I can clarify this and get back to you is that none of your personal data will be shared or used unless you yourself would access your conversation and want to hear it, or I would, and then it would just be from Cindy. It wouldn't be an affiliation. And I actually appreciate that all of you are bringing your full selves in including your personal and professional aspects of who you are. So we already did a quick round of introductions. I recorded, I asked for your consent-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yes. You can access it. Yep. As a matter of fact, that's why Cortico wants all of the participants to register. But because we were moving really quickly, I didn't have each of you to do that, but I will make sure that all of your data is inserted into it. And then you can go in and I'll clarify this too, you can go and click on a link to this conversation. That's my understanding, is through Cortico's website, you can access the recordings. And I'll get more information about that as well.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. So we're going to be given with, again, if you have a piece of paper, I'm going to give you a minute or two to think about this, to formulate a question. What's your question about the future of Boston in your place in that future? And then I want you to think about what experiences in your life got you to this question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Sure. And I'll also put it in the chat in a second. What's your question about the future of Boston in your place in the future and what experience in your life got you to this question?

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Yes. My question about the future of Boston is, what will happen to our mentally ill residents who are homeless? Will there be more housing for this population? And the reason I got to ask this question is because that's me, I have mental health issues and I was homeless before, and I like to stop stigma. And I'm very passionate about that community.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: My question is, how long will inequity in housing continue to hurt people of color in Boston? And what made me come up with that is that there's a young man, I tell his story to bring his story and others like it to light. Let's say his name is Terry and Terry was living out of his vehicle and he has a full-time job in the medical profession as a technician for where they do colonoscopies. And he still can't afford to live in proper housing. So that's my concern.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I have so many, but the one that stands out to me right now is how long will we allow the drug addiction to go unattended on Mass and Cass, and how many more hospitals need to get involved to make something happen? And I say that because I used to be a substance abuse counselor in that area, and that was probably about 10 years ago and we didn't see that state of emergency that exists there now, and it's just horrifying to watch what's happening.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yes. I was thinking about, there's been a lot of improvements going on in our community as far as housing renovations and development. There's been some educational opportunities, more ways to get educated as far as GED programs and small trades and a lot of it's free. There's been a variety of cultures living together now, agriculture's going on where people are doing local farming and stuff. My concern is about the prices going up for the cost of living in Boston. And the reason why I care about this issue is because I lived in Boston independently as a renter for about a year. And living there as a renter, to be as a single person with no children, I found it to be a little bit costly. And I didn't know if that was because of the renovations and the developments that's new, or if maybe it's always been like that, I never noticed.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: But the cost of living in Boston has gone up tremendously, especially in the last two years alone. And it is becoming more difficult for single mid adult age and young adult age youth to become more independent and have more opportunities for getting an apartment they can afford. A lot of my peers are in the bracket where they make too much to be on housing or have a subsidy, but they don't make enough to pay market rent. So a lot of my peers, they unfortunately live with family and they don't have a stable, independent source of living because of this problem.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So Priestess, I want you to just stop for a second and just state your question about all of that because I thought I heard a question, but I want it to be specific, especially if part of what we're trying to do is have the audio tape lift up our questions and so just ....

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So the question would be, how can we keep the cost of living down and even fair for the upcoming generation and moving forward as a community, even though we still want these property developments, we do want nicer living quarters and stuff like that, but how can we keep the cost of living as low as possible so that more people would have an opportunity to live in Boston and stay living in Boston?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you so much. My question that I came that I came up with was the same, will people like me be able to stay in Boston? People like me being a senior because my ... yeah, will Boston be affordable to working class people is my question. In my experience, I've moved 28 times. I am not a homeowner. I've worked in the nonprofit sector and I've been mission-driven in terms of my desire to leave the planet a better place when I leave. And I'm not sure that I can.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm going to retire in six to eight years, hopefully, but right now, if I don't get to stay where I am, in a friend's apartment who rents it below market and it's substandard, I have a leak in my roof for two years, but she didn't have the money to fix it. There's mold, but it's a thousand dollars for two bedroom next to the train. I have cataracts. I'm not going to be able to drive forever. You know what I mean, I want to have an active life in my retirement and I want to be in the community that I walk down the street and I see people. And so that's my question, will there be a future for working class people in Boston?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So the next part of the conversation is to think about what you heard from people and talk about what resonated with you and why.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: What resonated with me was it seemed like everyone was concerned at some point or the other with housing in the Boston area.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Likewise, yeah. And thank you all for sharing and that's my sentiment as well. And if I wasn't fortunate to be living in the house that I grew up in, it would be a challenge to find similar type of housing. And that's why I chose to do some of the things that I'm doing in terms of a builder. So it's really reassuring to hear real voices. And I think this is exactly what this conversation will be uplifting through Cortico courses. And everyone here, I will put my number into the chat. If you just want to share more about your story offline with me, because I really would like to see how I can help.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I agree. It all seem to talk about housing and my comment about substance abuse that leads to homelessness and homelessness can be the cause for their substance abuse. So I think that that's a major issue that we're seeing in big cities like San Francisco and them being ridiculously out priced and people having to move. And it's happening here in Boston and where will our neighbors be? Well, we won't have that sense of community when we can't afford to live here.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I resonate with everyone, but I resonate a lot with Cindy and Reverend Dr. Norm about working in the recovery field and having lived experience with recovery and being homeless and such things. It is hard for people to get out of a program and find affordable housing to stay in that community where all their resources or their clinicians and their support and where we have a lot of recovery places for detox and stuff like that in the Boston area. How can and also the working class I agree with, I resonate with Fran on that, the working class, all of that comes into place because we're all, I notice a common theme in my work is everyone's looking for stable place to rent or own or even sublet even. Sometimes it's hard for landlords to find tenants. So that's a whole nother thing, but I resonate with everyone.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you all so much. Now, Shareef, since Shareef has just joined us, I'd like to ask us since we're moving really kind of quickly, so if you all wouldn't mind doing another round. And Shareef, if can unmute yourself, I'm so glad that you were able to join us.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So what we just did was we asked everybody to introduce themselves and say their name and where they came from. And then we asked everybody to think of a question and I'm asking everyone if we can do another round of thinking of a question. Cindy mentioned that she had several questions as do I. And so since all of us, except Cindy, I don't know if you want to be a facilitator or a lead facilitator. We can talk about that. It would be good for us because all of us so far, except for Cindy, our lead facilitators and it'll give us another opportunity to practice the script as well as hear from you, Shareef, who you are, where you live and your question and why, and then we'll reverse order and go with Priestess, Cindy, Corey, and Norma. And if everyone agrees it, we can continue with another round. Yep. Okay,. Go ahead, Shareef. You're on.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Oh, Shareef, you have to give consent to be recorded. Thank you, Cindy. Will you consent to be recorded? You know that this is going to go to cyberspace and I just need you to say that you agree to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: I got a lot of action over here this morning, so I'm not going to be on video. But who I am, I'm Shareef. I'm from Boston. I grew up in Boston and went to school in Boston as well. Lived in Mississippi for a while. Really not too much for my story. I I'm kind of caught off guard a little bit because I just woke up too.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. I guess I'm going to ask you directly and give you a minute. What is your question about the future of Boston and how do you fit into it?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: The question about the future of Boston is, [inaudible] what's in it for the future for the children and where do we stand as a community to help make a better future for the children?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Because I grew up in foster care and a lot of my friends did as well. So I saw the family and the inner city getting destroyed. So that's what made me think about that question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you so much Shareef. Okay. So now we're going to ask Priestess, if she's ready with another question and Shareef, we'll come back to you afterwards when we ask about resonance. And so you can listen for now. Thank you so much for joining us despite the early morning.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Oh, that's beautiful. All right. Beautiful girls. Daddy's going to hang out with you now and come off the mic so you can be as loud and crazy as you want while he probably fixes your breakfast. Thanks Shareef. All right, Priestess.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I'm still thinking of a way to phrase my question. My next question that we kind of started off on that theme of recovery supports and community recovery based supports, I feel like there's been a lot of improvement in that area as well. We have a lot of more walk in day programs and community centers for people living with addiction or mental health crises and we have the best team. So there's a lot of stuff out there. The question is though, how do we get more people to partake in these resources and events and this awareness of mental health and addiction stigma and things like that? How can we fight the stigma in Boston and this pertains to my place in it because I live with mental health, I work in the mental health field, I do a lot of volunteer and activism work there.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: And I find it very rewarding and I find it very useful for us to also not just focus on our financial life or focus on our spiritual life as a community, but to also focus on our mental health and trying to break these vicious cycles of what comes with trauma.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: So my question is, when will we ever put real funding behind gun violence prevention and alternatives to violence so that we are not burying our children at a faster rate than we are for some adults? And my involvement in it is that I have been a youth program manager for many years in the past, a peace activist for 16 years. And I say that I've probably attended more funerals for young people than I have for any adults in this lifetime.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you. My question is it has to do with workforce development and workforce. And how will we address the workforce inequity that's in the city and get individuals into programs that can attack the $8 to 256K inequity that sits in the city right now? And that's the question and yeah, sorry. And what brought me to that is the study and generally concern about if you can't get a steady job, it makes it even harder to get at market rate or even below market rate housing. So it's like a double-edge to that sword of inequity that sits in the city. So that's where the generation of that question comes from.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Yes. We all know about global warming and I believe that global warming is real. And I wanted to know what will Boston's plan be for emergency preparedness as far as the things that are going to happen? Scientists has done studies which prove that the water of Boston is sinking underwater more rapidly than they previously thought. So that in approximately 30 years they said, we'll be underwater a little bit. And I want to know what's Boston plans for emergency preparedness for this buildings will be sinking. The weather is extremely hot or extremely cold. All these things that have to do with global warming. And we can't sit here and not do anything. So I want to know what is Boston planning to do for emergency preparedness when it comes down to our environment and global warming?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My question is when will elected officials center structural racism as yeah, when will they center structural racism and the repercussions of that and attack it and really do it. The reason I ask that is because my journey into racial justice organizing started when I was a teenager in the Boston public schools, and I was from Weymouth, but I was part of a regional group. And 19 of the 30 kids were from Boston public high schools. And it was in 1975, 76, 77. So it was right after school desegregation and the city was going coocoo. And I did not understand why everybody was so mad that people that look like all of you on the call wanted what I already had when we all pay taxes and public education is supposed to be free for everybody?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So anyway, I spent the next 15 years trying to understand that and study it. And I have come to understand that most people who are leaders in our nation don't know the history of structural racism. So my question is probably, what are you going to understand the history of structural racism and how it impacts us today and what you're going to do about it? Drop the mic.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So now I'm going to read to you what we were supposed to do the last time, because this is only my first time doing the conversation. The resonance is supposed to be with an individual. What I want you to do next is think back to each of the questions. We did two, so it could be either one and their experiences that were just shared in the group. And then find someone whose question or experiences resonates with your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you and share a story from your life that connects with their experience. So I'm going to give everybody a minute to do that.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And actually the last conversation we had so much in common that we didn't say specifically. So this is an upgrade, especially for those who will be doing conversations because we're assuming there'll be people that have different questions and come from different walks of life. And we really want the opportunity for people in these conversations to share directly with somebody else and make that personal connection. So who would like to go first? Take a minute to think, and then you can just put your hand up or unmute yourself. And I'm going to stop for a minute.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I was unclear with, I know you said we're going to go back and revisit another question. It could be either or of any of the questions we already did. I was unclear.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. So each of you stated two questions. And so I'm saying that I want you to think about what you heard and what resonated from a specific person, either of those two questions because we did two. So what resonated? So I'll model it. So when Cindy talked about gun violence, that has always been a concern of mine. I've buried more young people, not now because now I'm older, but 35 to fifties, there was so many people dying all the time. And I actually did an experiment with a friend of mine. We tried to score a bag of reefer or a gun on a Saturday night in the nineties, he was a Black man, I was a white woman. We couldn't find pot, but we found guns easily. And I was like, if I can find a gun, then why can the Popo find a gun?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So Cindy, I've always really appreciated the work that you've done with Peace Boston and your story about burying more young people than elders really resonated with me because that was my experience as well. And I haven't shared this with too many people, but my daughter, a few years ago, somebody shot at her, somebody around the corner shot at her and then the gun didn't go off and pistol whipped her, messed up her nose, broke her nose and it was pretty traumatic. So that was traUMatic. But what was even worse was making the decision because I lived around the corner in a house with my four girls, young girls who had to go by that house every week, every day, not to do anything about it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And then a couple of my male friends said, "Let's get [Tarida] in the car. She can point them out and we'll take care of them old school way." And Tarida said, "Mommy, that man is crazy. If so-and-so and so-and-so want to kill him ..." otherwise. And then what we did was we started walking a different route. And then about a year later, the brother was arrested for gun possession.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So I've lost young people. Like I said, my hands during the time and then for it to be so close and to feel powerless because there wasn't a good option, Cindy, to restorative justice. If we had restorative justice practices where people could name the harm and take action to repair, a lot of people would be alive and a lot of our brothers and sisters would not be in prison. So thank you for reminding me that gun violence is such an epidemic in our society and nobody in my opinion has figured out systemically how to address that. Sorry, I took so long. I don't even know who's next. Go ahead Cindy

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: I'll go next. What I wanted to say the question that resonated with me is ironically yours, Fran, because I grew up in Mission Hill during the busing era. I moved here after living in Grove Hall and I came to shell shock because over there I had Black neighbors like myself and then I came here and it was primarily white. My first experience was going up to the playground in Mission Hill and having a white kid punched me in the face, no reason at all. And then our first encounter was my sister having to beat him up. And then in the fall, turns out that he's in my class. And so this is the beginning of my life as a middle schooler, listening to the stories of the high school and them having race wars and us fighting with our friends who were friends in school but as soon as we crossed the street from the Catholic middle school that we went to, then it was all hell that broke out.

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: And so I became an activist when I was 14, very young. And probably at that time subconsciously leading to my adult life as an activist, I never did anything in Mission Hill. I never wanted to have anything to do with this area, but sleeping. And so I think that probably about three or four years ago, I joined the board of our neighborhood bus but before that, I still had a lot of that animosity. So the systemic racism that exists now as the community and cultural engagement manager at Mass General hospital, I'm doing my best to break down a lot of those walls and having to fight with white people to get them to see why this is not a handout or a hand up, but it's just telling them that they as a system need to give back to a community that they've turned their back on for so many years.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Okay. What resonated most with me was Priestess'. I can relate to the mental health epidemic and advocating for mental health. The business, Amron International, my business is we deal with people in mental health recovery. And so that resonated the most with me.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: I like to say that it all really touched home with me what everyone's saying, especially the last three. And I could pull from my history something applicable. So I think I might honor all three and say a little bit about all. In terms of Cindy's experience with racism, growing up, I remember walking home from Boston Bowl and this is on the east side of Washington. And it was four of us. We were all Black from the west side of Washington and the only way to get to Boston Bowl was walk. And we got jumped on our way coming back from bowling and car of young white men, young white boys jumped out and started to swing at us with golf clubs. I remember getting hit at my chest and the club breaking off. And ironically, how we got out of that, a vehicle stopped with an interracial couple. And then the neighbors who saw who were all white, came down to help us because they didn't feel what was happening was right which is true.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: And so that really tainted my view on some of the race issues, because at around the same time we were being bused as well, from Dorchester to, I was bused from Dorchester to West Roxbury- the Joyce Kilmer. So that touched my life.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: And then something else that really resonated with me too that's worthy of calling out is the issues that this country, the world is facing with climate change. And it's a real thing. And Boston, like this storm coming the T-stop in the South Bay has to be four to five, so that the station wouldn't get a flood with the anticipated storm coming. So it is real. There'll be more storms like this. And I'm working to get the word around about climate change.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: And then the third aspect is the mental health issues and challenges that we as a community face. They really overlap with a lot of the different things that we are concerned about at this table right now. And if we can see the connection, you can see how important it is to act today. With mental health, we don't really see it as a job issue, but it really is because when lives are stable and incomes are comparable to the national average, lives are better and the stress is less and you don't look for self-medication and you treat your kids better. So the quality of life all the way around where all of these things seem seemingly not connected are very interwoven like a sweater. So we have to really take a mindset of all the challenges that we have. So I think one thing that's coming to me now is that it's not a silo, it's all related and we all can help each other.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks so much, Corey. I stated the conversation with between 75 and 90 minutes. So we're getting to the 9:29. I'd like to hear from Priestess and then Shareef, and then we'll wind down and I want to, again, thank you all so much. This has been really moving for me. It's really great. Priestess and then Shareef.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yeah. I resonated like Corey with a little bit of what everyone is saying, but I'm going to talk a little bit about what Cindy's point was about gun violence, more advocacy towards gun violence prevention and protection and just violence in the community in general. Sometimes it's not just about weapons. I'm going to get a little bit intimate here and share something that happened to me recently. Last winter, I was in crisis and I had lost my phone. Well, actually my phone had broke and then I had lost it. It was raining really bad that day. And I went into crisis and I was looking for a phone to use. I was near a friend's house. So I said, let me walk to this friend's house because usually they are at home, maybe I can use their phone and get a ride back to my house or whatever I got to do.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So I was on my way to the friend's house and I saw the friend in that area. So I didn't even make it to their house. And I was asking them, "Oh hey, my phone got wet in the rain. I don't have a bus pass. I need to call a ride. Can I use your phone?" And they was like, "Oh, my phone's off. I'm going to go pay my bill now." So I was going to go with them to pay their bill. So I asked, "Can I just walk with you or whatever?" And they act like they didn't know me. So that led me to go to wait for them at their house. They said, I could wait for them at their house because they didn't know how long it was going to take.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So I got a little antsy. So I knocked on a neighbor's door and they opened the door and I asked them, I said, "Hey, I need some help. I just need to use a phone. I'm a friend of your neighbors." And I've seen them before and they've seen me before and they just started attacking. So you can imagine how strange that was. It was a very serious altercation. It was more than one person attacking me. Someone called the ambulance because I was obviously beaten up and I had to go to Boston Medical and mind you, I still had no phone. And my family started worrying about me. They had to put a missing persons report because remember I had no phone, I wasn't home. And I was never able to use someone else's phone. And it bothered me that when somebody could be needing help or something and they knock on your door and the first thing you do is attack them, you don't try to give, you know what I mean, help them out and see if there's anything, if they need to use a phone or if you could show them where the ... just help out instead of ... like, the first instinct was for these people to attack me. Why? I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: And so that never made sense to me, but the police did come to the hospital and stuff, but they didn't really do a good job of asking me what was going on. And on top of that, I was really injured. I had to have MRIs and brain scans and stuff like that because I was disoriented at that point because of the blows to the head. And so I feel like a lot of this violence that does happen goes back into mental health. A lot of people have mental health issues and they're not dealing with them.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: A lot of people have been traumatized. Maybe that person has an old trauma about someone coming to their door and that's why they responded that way. Or even just being trauma informed can ... even people who don't want to admit they've been traumatized or anything, or if they actually weren't, but being trauma informed will allow us to be more considerate of the people around us and to be more gentle and be more kind and understand that everyone goes through different periods of their life where you might lose someone and that can put you in grief and there's trauma support for that. So I think the violence, like Corey was saying, all of it is interwoven like a sweater. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks so much. I'm really sorry that that happened to you and community violence, you're right, comes in many different kinds of ways. Shareef, do you want to share with what resonated with you?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yeah. I could really identify with every one of you all stories, but structural racism stuck out with me. In law enforcement, as you could see with George Floyd situation, a cop, if you can call him a cop put a knee on a man's neck for nine minutes, what is that all about? And then you see all the violence that happened within the police force and you can see how racism has infiltrated law enforcement. It's a susceptible racist, you can't even call him a police officer. So that stuck out with me. What Corey was talking about business resources or something like that, business development, I'm sorry about that.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Good jobs and good business loans to start up businesses, especially in a lack community. A lot of this violence would end simply by that, and then having better educational systems for the smaller classrooms so you can really reach a child and you're not stuck in a classroom with 10, 20, 30 kids to one teacher. It won't work like that. That's not learning. That's just having them in classrooms so that these schools can get profit from corporate, more money from corporate America. So that's what really stuck out with me. Just concerned with how to end all this stuff. So it's so many different layers when we've got racism within prison, overcrowded prisons, the Black person gets convicted for whatever reason- say marijuana or something, versus a white person. [The] Black person's sentence is always a little bit healthier, why is that? So a lot of that stuff stuck out with me.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: And I'm sorry for anyone of you guys who got beat up by a white person and hit in the face. So that's why we're having these conversations. So hopefully end that so that another woman or man doesn't get beat up or mistreated because of racism. That's all I got.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks so much, Shareef. Thank you all so much. We're going to be winding down. It's clear that there was a lot of resonance with each of us, for each of us' point. And so as we wind down, I'm wondering if you can think for a second about closing thoughts, one thought that you're leaving with and then I'll stop the recording and I'll field any questions that you might have about the project. So Cindy, why don't you go first because you're to my left?

nodes.speaker: Cindy
nodes.words: Well, my thoughts on that, I'm extremely grateful for being involved in this conversation and to see that there's other people that this is the first time that I'm meeting you with, but our stories are similar and our concerns are similar. And I hope that we can get these questions to the candidates and not have them answer them because they're running for office, but if they get into office, to have them address these issues on a real level.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: So first thank you all for sharing your stories because it, they, all of them were a little bit a part of me as well. What I wanted to end on is similar to what Cindy was touching on. Hopefully these conversations can get back to elected officials and uplift all of us here where we are supported by the voices that we share. And those voices are very important voices and your voice is similar to my neighbor's voice and my voice. So we all are valued citizens of this city. And I want to thank you. And I want those officials to really truly get the point. So thank you for sharing and may God bless you guys. And Shareef, I love the hear to babies and I'm going to give you a big old high five for a brother that's doing the right thing. So all of you, thank you and have a blessed weekend. Thanks. Bye-bye.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yes Fran, my closing thoughts, well, thank you again for inviting me. It's a pleasure having this conversation with all of you individuals that are participating. And my closing thoughts is I feel like I understand a little bit more about what we're doing here and I'm grateful for this happening because I believe this is a pilot for something that we might want to do again in the future, as far as getting voices of the community involved with what the mayor and what the political powers that be in our community can help us with or support us with or try to make some change. So I feel like this seems like a very good idea. I feel included. This is really an easy lighthearted conversation. I feel like it's very, how can I put it, the way the conversation is going is very fluid. It's very fluid and I think this is a good idea.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: All right. Well thank you for inviting me, Ms. Fran. We have family day. When was it, last Thursday? Last Thursday. And we had Mr. Brian Warren, he's running for Boston city council district four. So I told him that we got to have a whole bunch of conversations about what needs to change and we're going to be talking about him in these meetings. So I just wanted to bring that back to you guys. And he didn't really turn into a politician after that, but he was cool guy. Shot some basketball in the community, and it was good to see him out. Him and one other lady was out there. I can't think of her name right now. But they was out there and we had a lot of people out there. So I like that if we continue to have these conversations, that action will start happening and accountability and all that other stuff, it will be changing.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: He wanted more people to get involved in politics. I'm like, "Man, let's get everyone involved in the politics at a young age as early as possible. Let them know about civics." There's a lot of these young men and women out here don't know, even know who the city council is. They don't know. That's all I got.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Yes. It was very good to be here. This was a great conversation. It's opened my mind more to think more about these issues. I like to see these conversations continue to happen. They're very important. A lot of times, the marginalized communities don't have a voice and I feel like these conversations give us a voice. And when I say us, I mean people in the mental health community. So I'm grateful to have been here. And this is a very, very important project. And I just hope that it continues on. And I hope that our politicians listen to us and hear us and support us in the things that we elected them to do. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Put into the cloud. Good morning. I'm Francesca, also known as Fran Smith. I've been a community organizer and activist for as long as I can remember. I'm really excited that you're all here. Thank you so much for joining us. This is an initiative by Dunk The Vote and the MIT and I will pull up the correct title and Local Voices Network. And the objective is to bring people together from across the city to hear and learn about issues that matter to them based on their lived experiences. And to also provide us an opportunity to work across difference.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I need to read this. It's also in the chat. If you're like me, and you like to see text, you can open it up. George, you might not see it because you joined afterwards. But it says, I'll read it aloud, "As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk, for change Boston to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of [inaudible] Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: [inaudible] who's partnered with MIT will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission." If you understand and agree to this, please say, "I agree." And let me just say we're going to ask you to do that. We're going to ask you to stay muted. And I'm going to drop in the chat. We're going to almost do a circle process. So I'd like to begin with Jacqueline, then go to Beverly, then George, then Norma and then Ziona. And I'm going to drop that in the chat. And if you forget-

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: I do agree. I did get it in the chat. I typed it in the chat. I don't know who... Yes I agree-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Beverly is it possible you can have Kevin calling on his cell phone? So that way he has his own platform to speak and stuff so you don't have to worry about going back and forth with the device. Maybe he can call in on the phone?

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: Okay so what do I do? How do I do? Oh, he can call in on the phone. Okay. What's the phone number? To speak. Oh, no. Okay. Your microphone is muted. It's unmuted. Can you hear me now?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay, so we have a couple of... While we're together for this hour, so we are going to ask for some agreements amongst each other. I like to talk about... some people call them rules, some people call them guidelines, but I talked about ways of being so while we're together for the next 75 minutes or so, we'd really like people to enter the conversation with best intentions and I mean, I'm sorry. I have to pull up my long script. Actually Ziona, Norma, do you have the long script in front of you? Would you mind reading the shared agreements?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay, here are the shared agreements, "Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking take time. Stay curious. Ask honest questions. Pause. Take time for reflection. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications and notifications and put your phone on silent. If you need to take a moment, take a break. Let the facilitators know in the chat." Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Those ways of being for the next 75 minutes or do we have any clarifying questions about them? If you are in agreement, can I get a thumbs up? All right, perfect. Thank you so much. And now I think I'm going to turn it over to Sister Norma to have us do some intros and check-ins.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Yeah we are. This is the center in activity. For the ease of this virtual compensation. We are going to use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn, a post in the order in which people will be invited to respond in the chat. I'll help transition us from one person to the next. I'm not going to post it in the chat. We'll go to Jackie, Beverly, George, Ziona, Fran and me. Can anyone have any questions about this process?

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: To begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions. So please share your first name, where you are located right now, one value that is important to you. And then let us know how you are using the PIES check-in. The PIES check-in is physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually. But you could choose one or any all four of those. I'll go first. My name is Norma, I live in Brockton. I was raised in Boston, Massachusetts, where I lived for many years. Physically, I'm feeling well and intellectually appealing stimulated. Thank you. So we'll go over to Jack.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Good morning. My name is Jacqueline and I right now I am my home in Revere, Massachusetts. I am born and raised in Boston. Physically, I'm struggling today. Emotionally, I'm doing pretty okay. Everybody's home and everybody's safe, that's what matters to me. In intellectually, I'm very stimulated going on a new venture with this group right here. Did I miss anything?

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: Yes, my name is Beverly Little. I live in Cambridge Harvard Square. And I am a recovery coach. And I'm physically What? Physically I'm feeling really good. Intellectually, I'm stimulated. And emotionally I guess I would say I am ecstatic.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Yes, good morning. My name is George. I'm from Cambridge, Boston and grew up there and I live in Dorchester now and I am feeling physically well, intellectually I'm excited, I guess if you can feel that at the idea of being able to do something like this. I'm really excited about this work. And emotionally I'm feeling safe. So, yeah, so I feel good this morning, happy Sunday everyone.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Good morning, everyone. I'm Ziona my pronouns are she, her, hers. I was born and raised in Boston all over. I recently moved to Brockton, for my PIE check-in everything else as well except for my physical. I'm having some more back spasms. But I'm going to stick it through this meeting, at least, and then do some self care afterwards. But I'm glad to be a part of this project and process and this conversation. And I want to thank everyone for joining.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Francesca, also known as Fran. I'm doing great intellectually because this project has been wonderful and I'm so pleased to have you all here. And spiritually, I've been doing a lot of power prayer. So I'm doing great. Great to be here.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: All right, Norma. Right. Hi, my name is Kevin. I was born and raised in Boston, Massachusetts. Intellectually, physically rather I feel really good most of the time. Today, I feel excellent. Intellectually, I'm someone who always wants to find a means or ways to utilize the gifts that I've been given. So intellectually, I'm always stimulated, as you stated. Emotionally, I'm an individual who just loves this share what's in his heart. But so realistically, what you hear from me will always be something that's true and sincere. Spiritually, that's what [inaudible]. That's it? You don't want to hear about my spirituality?

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: No, I'm sorry. No I didn't mean to [crosstalk]. You go boy. You are the only one that did all of them. But go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: But spiritually, that is the foundation of all of what I actually find to be the most important aspect right now, pulling all the pieces together. So hopefully, that slice of PIE will help us all to understand each other even better than those that we should. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Wonderful. Thank you, everyone. Thank you. So we're going to pass the mic over to Ziona where she'll do the sharing questions and lived experience. Peace.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: No, thank you, because that's going to be too much back and forth. But I got it digitally, It's right here. So Sharing questions and lived experience. I'm going to read from the scripts so I don't miss anything. Now that we know who's here. Let's get to the core of our conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston, how our lived experience have shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I like to invite you to think what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? We're going to take two minutes to reflect on this and write it down if you want, if that helps. So we'll have two minutes for everyone to reflect on what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Then think about what experience in your life got you to this question. I'm going to ask you to share both your question and your experience. It's key to keep your experience personal. It has to be something that you experienced directly, then we will go around in a circle. Each person will share their question and then tell their story of their experience that led them to this question. I'm posting the order in which you will be invited to respond in the chat, which I believe is already there. I'll help transition us from one person to the next. You can always pass or pass and ask for us to come back to you later. So let me get this. So it's 10:41, so maybe till 10:43, we will reflect on a question about the future of Boston and our place in that future.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: I don't think none of us need a whole two minutes to reflect on that question. Given that we started so late.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Everybody can get their questions together and have it organized, go by the script. We have 15-20 minutes for this section alone. So let's follow the script. Please and thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: All you have to [inaudible] with a question? And for the future Boston, in your place in the future of Boston. And your experience. So just reflect on it for two minutes, some people want to write it down. In that way, you'll have more organized thoughts when you share.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay, so the two minutes just happened. And for the sake of staying organized, I'll model the question. So I'll like go first. And then we'll go into our order with Jackie, Beverly, George, Kevin, and Reverend Dr. Norma and I think Mrs. Francesca is going to sit out on this particular part. So for my question about the future of Boston would be what will... My concern really is, what will it look like with all these new developments and all these different, these new things that are coming up, these new ways of living in Boston. Like these new ways of telling the bus sizes, directions to each library locally, there's bike paths, there's limited parking, there's a lot of construction going on, it's a lot of buildings going up, there's a lot of stuff going down and being remodeled.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So my question is really what is that going to look for us when the cost of living is going up for all these developments? And the reason why I say this question is not just for me, but also I have peers, that they make too much money to be on housing, but they don't make enough to afford market rent. Also, for myself when I lived in Boston, I had to move every two years and I had trouble finding single apartment living for myself as an individual, whereas living in a studio was about the same amount of market rent for someone who had a three bedroom. So when I was paying 1200 for a studio, someone could pay 1200 and get a three bedroom. So stuff like that and the cost of living did go up and it was all over the news in the media about the cost of living in Boston going up. So that's my question and my story. And what how it affects me. So next would be Jackie.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Oh my God, Ziona you hit it right on the spot. So I was born and raised on Dudley Street. [inaudible] start off with that one. So my question is, what is fair and equal housing and the structure of the infrastructure of our community? So for those low income families. So I grew up right there Corner of Dudley and Blue Hill Avenue. And back then there was rent control. I remember I had a studio... I had a one bedroom apartment for $600. This is back in 1990, 1991 in that state and that was market rent. It was over at 420 Mass Avenue right next to the train station. And right now that same unit is $2200. That's a little bit out of the score. That's almost 80%. Right? So yeah, almost 80% more than... And I did not pay utilities, the person living there, or the people living there right now do pay utilities.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: So what's fair and what's not fair? Because all these developments coming up in the community, but there's no real opportunity for people that are of low to moderate income to be able to succeed or be able to afford purchasing a home or a place a business, whatever, in the community. So that's it for me.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: Thank you Jacqueline for sharing that. The next person on the list is Miss Beverly Little. If you would like to share your question for the future pertaining the future of Boston and your place in it. Your mute Miss Beverly Little, you're muted, you must unmute.

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: [inaudible] muted me. Fran muted me. Okay. Yeah. My question is, why is it so many people homeless and living on the streets? Because from my experience been... Past tense is that there's a lot of resources, but I don't understand why the people that really need the resources on the streets without any shelter. And any advocacy to help them get fortunate because I have been a part of the community and been active in the community all my life. So that yes, it was very disturbing me when I became homeless, but it didn't take maybe three to four months for me to obtain another apartment.

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: And I just said it wasn't really easy. But I've known people and seen people out there on the streets, homeless in Boston for many years and have not obtained a place to live. And I don't understand that question. That is a part of what the question that I asked, why is so many people homeless in the city of Boston when there's so many resources that they're not able to access? And being a Recovery coach, I've been able to help some people but it's some people don't even have a clue about having a recovery coach. So that's it. Hello? Anyone there?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Miss Beverly, that sounded like everything it's seems we have residents already. But we're going to go on to the next person for the sake of time. And the next question is George, what about your question for the future of Boston in your place and in your experience?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Yes, my question for the future of Boston are how we want to treat our citizens that had the least amount of opportunities. My experience, I'm a Certified Peer Specialist. I have conservation as part of my story and coming home and starting over. It was really challenging, and it remains a challenge for a lot of folks and my place in it hopefully will be to advocate for myself and for others in a similar space. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay, so sharing your question with pertaining to the future of Boston and your place in it and a little bit about your experience.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Well, as I just heard, many of us say, I have a reality of my life as well as with incarceration and homelessness but one of the questions that stood out to me always in working in St. Louis and other parts of this country was why are the resources so far or seem so disconnected from the population [inaudible] in the case of better-

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: And in St. Louis, Missouri at that time, but in Boston, it was merit but when I started working at St. Francis House, that's when I realized that here are the resources from one floor to the 10th floor and then in some cases, permanent housing for the rest of their lives but people out front been sitting out there and in fact, dying out there for being 10 and 15 years. So my question was, why is that disconnect so strong? And in particular not only in the city of Boston but they seem to be throughout this country but seeing that my life in Boston has been full of the issues that are related to re-entry, homelessness, dysfunctionalism and all these other big challenges that the majority of the people who are homeless are facing, I want to make sure that somehow in Boston, we're able to create a stronger bond, a stronger connection and a deeper commitment to the people who have the greatest challenges that mirror the challenges that we also have had. Okay.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you for that Kevin, that's a good resonation with Kevin and George about re-entry and things like that. I think that's a good angle. That's something we could focus on as well as the community. So Reverend Dr. Norma here next.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: My question for the future of Boston is what about the mental health community? What about them being homeless? At least the mental health community should be more involved with the resources out there as far as housing. There shouldn't be any mental health people homeless on the streets of Boston. So what are we going to do about the mental health community? And my experience is I have mental health issues and also I've been homeless. So I know a lot of people that was in my shoes with mental health issues and homeless, no one came by and gave us any resources. We had to go up there on our own and figure out how to apply for housing and things like that. So we need more of that in Boston. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thanks for sharing that [inaudible]. I'm sorry. It's taking my mouse sometime to get to the unmute button. I wish there was a button I could click instead of having to mouse pad that. But thank you all for sharing that. I think that was everyone, right? We got everyone? Okay. So we're going to move to the next part of the conversation. And I believe Fran is going to take this one away and lead us home. You're muted.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yes. Thank you so much. Same thing, my mouse, I have to click it a few times. So now for the next 15 minutes or so I'm going to ask you to reflect on what you just heard. And I want you to think about what story that somebody shared, a question that somebody shared that really resonated with you. And then unmute yourself or raise your hand and say, we're not going to go in order this time, we're just going to ask you to say what resonated. And so I'll model. Jacqueline, when you were talking about you grew up in this area and you were given the examples of the different prices and you mentioned that you spent most of your life in Boston and now you live in Revere. And so, what resonated with me was, I'm holding on by a thread in Boston because I live in an apartment owned by somebody I've known since 1997.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So she's renting below market. But it's only a matter of time before her children grow up and it's an investment. And I know... And I just... So I don't want to live in Revere in my 60s and 70s. I want to live in the community that I've given and grown so much of my heart and soul in. So, that really resonated with me. And I wondered... You don't need to respond to this, but I wanted if you got priced out of Boston and that's how you ended up in Revere. And just a little... They just said that in terms of the population in Boston, we lost 3% of Black Americans or people that identify black in the census. And they didn't necessarily leave the state. They're in Revere, Everett, Randolph, Brockton.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And so I just wonder, what's our community going to look like? And am I going to get thrown out? And it makes me feel like I'm being discarded. So anyway that's an example of resonance and I'm going to stay on. I'm going to keep my mic on so that I can call on people. You can either raise your hand or just unmute yourself. Okay, Jackie. Thanks. I'm sorry I'm calling you Jackie.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: No, it doesn't matter. Just don't call me Maria. Jacqueline, Jackie, I'm good. But reflecting on that the reason, and not that I'm answering, but yes I was priced out of Boston. The school system in Revere it's greater and also the services that I received. And George and... I'm sorry, the other guy, I can't see his name.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Kevin, sorry. They talked about re-entry, so I am somewhere where they lived the experience of substance misuse and mental health and in the correctional system. And I guess I just felt that I just needed somewhere where I felt safe. And at that time that was 15, almost 16 years ago I just didn't feel safe in the community that I grew up in and I wasn't able to get the services I needed. And I work in the homeless... I worked for a department of mental health in the two biggest shelters. When I see all of this stuff going on with mental health services and lack of connection and so many people dying and suffering out there, so for me that's why I came over here because I feel safer. I'm close enough to the city. But for my own peace of mind and to raise my family that's why we're over here.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: I resonated a lot with Beverly as far as where are the resources for the people in the mental health community because that's where my heart and soul is. And that's one of the reasons we started our business in the first place to help all people just like us. So everybody resonated but if I was to choose one, Beverly's story really resonated with me about where are these resources that we so desperately need.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you [inaudible]. Anyone else? Beverly, Kevin, George, Ziona, any specifically whose story resonated and let them know why. Go ahead George.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Yeah. I can resonate with almost everyone's story and there's a common thread that seems to be running through the group. And I know that for me having mental health challenges, growing up feeling like I was very much discarded since I was a kid. You know what I mean? And I lived in Boston or the Boston area my whole life and I love the city, but I don't feel like the city loved me back. You know what I mean? When I ended up homeless and was told, okay, you're out of jail but you're on probation. You don't have any resources at all. We're going to drop you off at this shelter and you better figure it out. That was challenging. And I see people dying and not being able to manage that challenge every day. And so I really feel connected to the work on a personal level. But, again, I have so much love for the city and I see so much potential in it. I really want to find ways to connect those resources for the folks that really need them. Thank you

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I'll share briefly on the resonance. I really appreciate George and Kevin bringing up the topic of the correlation between mental health, imprisonment, resources and homelessness. I feel like all of these things do play a big part in how the future of Boston can strive for change in these areas where people are not falling through the gaps. I definitely try to look for... I try to do some research on re-entry in prison and see what's out there and there's places that do stuff but, like George was saying, it's half ended. They have all these good intentions. They give us all these hopeful resources, but access to these resources and the practice of these resources once we have access to there's disconnect. And I think a lot of that plays a part on for me through my personal experience, through social workers and community engages how a lot of them are not hands-on only because everything is so paperwork. Paperwork pushing instead of actually being hands-on, one-on-one with individuals who walk them through these processes to re-entry them back into the community, whether it be from incarceration or mental health or homelessness or any of these things.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you so much Ziona. Anyone else have any other resonance? Address that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you. Beverly is frozen I think. I don't know if Beverly or Kevin want to say anything. Beverly you're on mute.

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: Yeah. I resonate with all the questions because for me I am willing and able to help someone to access a lot of the resources that are there, but it's a pick and choose thing. You could be number one in line and wind up being number 10 to get the application. So it's an unfair practice going on. And a lot of people are not aware of what's really going on because they're following directions and they're taking advice from social workers and from people like myself. But the people that are actually doing the work are not really doing the work. I'll send a client somewhere or I'll refer a client somewhere and then they're backed into a wall. They run into a brick wall. And it's like what? I don't understand that. So that's why I said what I said. And I believe Kevin has something to say about too about the resonance about what everybody was saying. [inaudible] Yeah. You can go on in [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: It seems like the congregate thoughts of all of us that resonated with the challenges that we've all seen, hopefully some of us have been able to help others overcome, it is definitely something that comprehensively and exponentially will build Boston and all those individuals and families that face these challenges we see every day. I know that what I've listened to and heard thus far is a lot of compassion, a lot of passionate commitment and what's really important and it's backed by certifications and experience, real life experience. And that's what I found most people will listen to. And most people will adhere to and acknowledge you and willing to listen to some of the challenges that you've had and then willing to give back. And you can allow them that moment where they can really share what their challenges are. And I think that's what we have. We have such a diverse group here that has so many very challenges that are consistent with what's going on in Boston and Massachusetts in general.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Although the challenges are throughout the world, at least we have something where this is a beacon, a strong beacon. It's great to hear us talk about it. And also the things that we have done as a group recently to try to just build that sense of strengthened togetherness so that we do come with the power of a strong hammer force to bust loose some of these challenges and at least give people the chance to voice them. And hopefully we can then turn around and disseminate that to those that need to hear it and marry those victories in our own lives so that we offer people with (Inaudible) examples that they can use to begin to face some of the biggest steps that they know they have to go forward with. But listening is our biggest thing. And I see that that's something that in our early talks we talked about being generous in our listening. Listening and giving people a chance to really unload and give us a way to really pick out which is the best challenge that we can share with them. If that's the issue, a reflection will be one of the biggest things I see we all realize we have to do

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you so much Kevin. We went into the next two sections of the conversation, drawing connections. What are you hearing in people's experiences? And we certainly have during our resonance section of the conversation named that, but I guess I want you to just take a minute and think about any other connections that you were hearing that haven't been named yet. Go ahead, Jacqueline.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: I think that connections to culture and language. Culture and language as the community grows into intensively diverse beautiful [inaudible]... Inclusiveness has not been talked about here. We all share, the people on this call right now, we all share a common goal.[crosstalk]. But given changing times, I started off the conversation with I was born and raised in Roxbury and Dorchester, right? The community has changed so much and there is so much beauty in everything and everyone that is to be found and to try to have some connections and have all voices being heard. I think that that is very important. And if a voice can all speak English, let's find a way to understand.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: I guess somethings that haven't been mentioned here today is the environment, global warming and climate change. And those are important issues as well. And I liked that Jacqueline touched on violence. So, that was good as well to hear. But we didn't talk about the environment.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. And so we wanted to focus on anything, so that was something that you maybe would like to have heard about in this conversation, but we're winding down. So I just want to give everybody an opportunity to share any takeaways or closing thoughts as we wrap up. I want to remind you that I... Yeah. So closing thoughts and takeaways. And then I have some housekeeping to do. So Beverly and George since you guys are unmuted and you're both in the picture, why don't we ask each of you for a closing thought or takeaway?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You know what? I'm sorry, I called Kevin George. Beverly and Kevin, since you guys are both on the same thing, why don't you go first? Because we're having trouble hearing you. So you might actually just take yourself off video if you can and just use the mic because you've been breaking up and I don't want to lose your brilliant voice.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Thank you so very much. Now that was nice. Something I'm going to have as one of my take off and take away is that wonderful statement you made that my heart is being received well. That's one of the things that I felt really strong about the takeaway. One of the things I'd like to leave as a thought that maybe we can all hold onto is that this gift of us giving people an opportunity to really have some ways to take from us is one of the most important and most visible ways today that I have seen that's going to help to assist them. And also give me a great way to just feel good about knowing that the work that I have envisioned and work I've done all my life is something and the stuff we've all done is something we should all be very grateful for and thankful for. And that power pairing that you've been doing I'm going to take that away too. So I want to be grateful and I acknowledge that. Thank you earlier for that statement.

nodes.speaker: Beverly
nodes.words: Okay. I'm Beverly. What I take away, what that leaves me wondering is that... Let me see, how can I put it? I feel as though that we are reaching out and we are touching a lot of people's lives that didn't know that we had so much patched in [inaudible] and listening skills to hear a person's issue it makes [inaudible] takeaway from this meeting is that there are people that are out there that are very attentive into listening to whatever it is that we're experiencing. And I'm really grateful that I am a part of this. And I am so grateful to be available today. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: All right. Thank you. I guess my biggest takeaway from this is that, like I said before, this seems to be a common thread that runs through us. And when I can remember coming up where I needed some help and there was no cultural competence, so there were no doctors or therapists that looked like me that I was dealing with. So there was a disconnect. And now all these years later where that's been addressed in some ways there aren't a lot of people doing the work that lived like me. And what I'm hearing from this group is that there are some common themes. And that gives me hope because where it was cultural competence before it's lived experience today that I feel like could really make the difference. So I'm happy to be a part of this as well. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Norma
nodes.words: I've taken away, I'd just like to thank everybody for coming in. At the end Fran is going to ask some questions about us doing to facilitate the questions that we have about that [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Sure. So first of all, I would like to thank everybody for being here and Ziona for asking me to be part of this conversation. It's a really good feeling to be part of community change as change agents. That is very important to me. But I do have, I don't know if it's a concern. How would I know... My question is, how would I know where these conversations take us? Looking at it from a researcher's point of view, rarely do we find out the results of any research project or any type of community project till years later. So what should I expect after this project is over?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And I can... Okay. So I can respond to that. And we can do that once we end the recording. I will say that the initial goal is to engage people who are not heard and not necessarily engaged in local elections within the city of Boston. It's really important that if you guys end up being facilitated since most of you no longer live here, that everybody that participates is a resident of Boston. That's really important. And I need to clarify with my supervisors about your roles beyond participants and facilitators. So I just need to clarify that. However, the goal is for like Norma's organization can be an institutional partner and everybody that participates in these will have the link to go and listen to your conversation. So you mentioned Jacqueline that you're a change agent. So if you are and you work in two of the biggest shelters.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
