nodes.words: If we glean electronically from the university and the people that do the electronic stuff testimony that most people that are experiencing homelessness, substance misuse and are coming back to the community after being incarcerated and there's these parallels and patterns, that's really powerful for you to go to even your supervisors and say, "You know what? Maybe we're not doing this right. Maybe we're not delivering the services right."

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I heard many of you mentioned things about connections to the resources and how you get connected. And so, we have this technology to further our individual and collective roles towards building power, especially among those that are the most impacted like yourselves. You guys have remarkable lived experiences. And I think George mentioned or somebody mentioned that as a result of your experiences, you're [inaudible]. What I heard was as a result of your lived experiences, some people that are in your circumstances currently will hear you better than those that haven't walked in your moccasins. So what we do as Dunk the Vote and the voices project is to further the mission of building power among the people that are the least invested in and lifting those voices individually then collectively. And how powerful it will be at the end of this project for all of us to be able to listen immediately.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You can hit a link and go listen to it as soon as it's uploaded, not this [inaudible] decision because we had a glitch with it. But once we work out the technology, any conversation that you either lead or a part of, moving forward you can access directly. And I'm glad that this is on tape because, as I may have mentioned, we are engaging in this really ambitious agenda quickly before the September 14th and then the November 2nd election so that we can hold electives accountable. And one of the things that we're doing is a launch on Tuesday with the 52 people that are running for office in the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And I would say we're blessed because we have a lot of people of color and a lot of women and a lot of people that are immigrants. And that's very exciting. The question is, how do we hold them accountable once they're in? And [inaudible] difference is the way to do that. So anyway, I went off way too long. Does anyone else have a closing comment so that I can end the recording and then answer any further questions about the project itself? Thoughts, closing statements.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm kind of long-winded and it's cultural. So I hope that... And you know what [inaudible] myself? I've come to learn that I'm not linear. I'm circular. My brain does not think from the bottom up or the top down. I go in circles. And so. I make these connections. My daughter says I'm poo poo, but maybe I am. Bipolar and schizophrenia runs in the family. So maybe I need to go see a mental health professional soon. Anyway, thank you all so much for sharing your stories and trusting myself and MIT and [inaudible] with very personal, intimate information that will only be used to further the progress as we unite as humans to make things better. So, that's my closing comment about that. The other thing that I really need is I need you to send me, especially if you didn't register, you can either drop it in the chat or if you can give Norma, the permission, I need your names and emails so that you can get your gift card for this participation and that I can stay connected to you directly around next steps. And then if you did register on that link [inaudible] confused, this conversation will be uploaded to that, and then eventually we can send you a link so you can listen to it if you want.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: With that, I am going to stop the recording unless you have any other clarifying questions or comments that you want included in the transcript. Okay, I am going to stop.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: ... recording. First of all, I want to think you all for coming to participate in this Real Talk for Change conversation. As you know, we are holding these conversations throughout Boston. Our goal is to really create a venue in small settings for people to come together in the city and really both talk about their sense of the future, but mostly to talk about their experience and what it means to be in the city for them.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're particularly focused on voices that aren't often heard. I want to say the thing about voice that aren't often heard. Just because someone's voice ... I should say voices that are not often heard and listened to because a lot of times you can hear people speak but not listen to them. And so, what we do in this effort, between this small conversation and all of it we're trying to have in this timeframe, is really make it possible for those voices to be listened to. We bring together old technology, which is sitting around and talking with food. That's old technology. It's ancient. It works. We combine it with some modern technology that allows us to record and hold onto these conversations and actually put them into a format so that they both are preserved but they actually can be analyzed and used for making meaning that can have an impact on policy, and how candidates themselves are thinking about what's on the public's mind.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, that's what we're about and I want to thank you for that. Now I want to say a few things about the audio recording. The audio will be transcribed. We take the transcription and we put it up on our system, which is called LVN, Local Voices Network. You will all have access to that, to be able to see it. We are working with a series of community-based organizations to serve as owners of these conversations, so they won't be owned by MIT, they won't be owned by Cortico which runs Local Voices Network. They will be the stewards of it. They will make sure it stays up to date and on the system. But the ownership is going to be around these sets of community-based organizations who are working through that agreement process and how it's going to work.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, I need to read something, which is a consent text. This is the only thing I'm going to read out of this whole thing. And then I'm going to ask each of you to go around and say if that's okay. It goes like this. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to retain the recording in accordance with this mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. So if you understand and agree with this, could I have each of you say yes?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. I can say yes, too. Okay. Thank you so much. I think we can do the introductions. I have this recorder here in the middle of the table that seems to have turned off. No, it's going. It's going just fine. I have this recorder in the middle of the table. I'm not sure how well it's going to pick up. So what I'm going to do is use it like a talking stick. What I'm going to do is, I'm going to hand it to one person, and the person to their right is the one who's going to talk. Okay? Then we'll just pass it around. Okay? Clear? So when you have it, your duty is just to hold it slightly in front of the other person, gently, so we can make sure to pick them up. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So in this first round of check-ins, what I want you to do is each of you, pretty straightforward, I want you to say who you are, what part of Boston you're from. Then, we have this thing we call PIES, and you get to check-in on PIES, but any one of the PIES you want. PIES stands for physical, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually. All right? You get to check in on any one of those you want to do. Maybe they're so connected you may have to do two of them, depending on what state you're in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So the motto is, and I'll show you, I'll demonstrate it myself. My name is Ceasar McDowell. Unfortunately I'm not from Boston. I actually live in Brockton right now. I want to check in physically, because Friday I had two implants done. Friday was good. Saturday was good. Sunday was not so good, neither was today. And so, the dentist says it'll be better in a couple more days and I'm really looking forward to that. But right now, I'm struggling with a little bit of pain. We're just going to go around.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: My name is [Geanier] Moore. I am from Dorchester. I will say emotionally and spiritually. Emotionally, I'm tired. I'm drained. I don't really know how to really completely tell you how I'm feeling right now. But spiritually, I meditate. That's the only way that I'm able to actually be okay right now. And being a psychology person, it's a lot for me right now to even explain how I feel. So, I'm okay because I meditate. That's just my thing.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Can I back up for a minute because I forgot one really crucial point. I didn't model it, so there's no reason you would know it. But at the end of it, what we say is, "And with that, I'm in."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you. I'm Zakiya Alake, and I'm going to check in consciousness, spirituality. I feel really good about this project and the possibilities of what it can bring to our communities. The idea that we are developing a process where everyday ordinary people, as Sly and the Family Stone would say, they can step up and talk their piece. And it can be shared with each other and with potential elected officials, is just so exciting to me. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Thank you. My name's Quanda Burrell. I live in South End. They call it South End- Lower Roxbury. Check in I'd say physically. I just drank coffee and I haven't had coffee in maybe two years. So, I'm in and also controlling the whatever it is that I'm actually feeling going through my body right now. So, yeah. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Jimmy L. Thompson, Junior. I'm from Dorchester, Massachusetts. I'm physically here and present, you're hearing my voice. Intellectually, I'm going to remain on point to the best of my ability. So, it's the emotional and the spiritual part that I'm going to be dealing with real briefly. Mostly, I'm on a rollercoaster ride. I had an awesome ... I just came back off an awesome vacation where I was in Las Vegas surprising one of my sons for his birthday. But during that time, I was able to be with my father, who we just recently reconciled. I'm watching him age, and I really understand the aging process even more. So, I'm just going through that emotional rollercoaster ride. And spiritually, spiritual foundation or the soul has been my foundation I should say. Just being able to be centered with the Creator in the creation. With that, I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: My name is Corey Adrian Thompson, and I'm from the Dorchester, Codman Square area. I'm feeling achy all over, but glad about it. Over the weekend, on Saturday, our neighborhood association which I'm part of, West of Washington, we had our annual barbecue and it went phenomenal. We had tons of support from the community, and we had some elected and candidates for mayor and D-4 present showing the strength of the community. And with that, I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: My name's Tony Brewer. I'm a resident of Roxbury. Spiritually, every moment I open my eyes I feel great. I'm just grateful that the Lord opens my eyes and gives me an opportunity to make a difference in my neighborhood, my community, and my family, and anywhere that I need to make a difference in. Physically, I feel pretty good. I changed my diet, which makes me more and more healthier, eating more healthier. I'm getting aging, so I want to make sure that I get a little bit more time on the clock. So, part of that is changing your diet. I'm just grateful. So, I have no gripes. I have no gripes with anything or anybody or anything. Just my foundation spiritually is solid as a rock. I'm grateful for the good Lord above because he's what keeps me going, and I'm grateful. And for that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. One of the reasons we do that check-in that way is because sometimes when we come together in meetings we just get focused on the task at hand and don't realize we're all carrying other parts of ourselves in that space. So, it's just an opportunity to let that be and to recognize the complexity of who we are and honor that, and let that be okay.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, we're going to move into really the first part of this. This is actually great because there's actually paper and pencil on your table, so you might want to use it for this. There's two things I want you to do. First we're going to model the first one. The first one is, we have a prompt we want you to answer. The prompt is like this. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That may seem like a hard thing to do. We often don't think that way about questions. Often we're not even allowed the space to have questions about things. I'm going to ask someone, just to make sure we all get it. Anybody got an idea of the question? Just give me an idea. It doesn't have to be the one you have to set on. Anything come to mind automatically?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Now, what I'm going to say to you is, what I want you to do is put that into a question. What is that question for you about voter suppression? And remember the prompt is, what's the future of Boston and where do you see yourself in that future?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Just think about that. Just think about how you would do a question that way. I'm going to come back to you.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, okay. To me, I see the future of Boston as pretty bleak for low income people. I don't even know if there's such a thing as moderate income people anymore. I think we delude ourselves here in Boston and speak as though there is, but there's a Boston Globe study from a couple years ago that says you need to earn about $50 an hour to live here. But yet, I'm a member of the Roxbury Neighborhood Council and most-

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: There goes my job as a trainer. My question is will people that make less than $50 an hour be able to live in Boston moving forward?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. That's a really great model. So everybody, that's what I wanted her to model. That's what we're looking for in a question. So again, give everybody a few minutes to think about what their question is and write it down.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I see nods. We look like it. We all good? Okay. So here's the second part of it. Now that you have a question, our questions don't just come out of thin air. They exist because there's something that we witness, experience, accumulation of things. So what I want you to also do is think of what's an experience in your life that has actually led to that question for you. Something's made you put that question and say this is what's important for me. There's been some experience in your life that's gotten you there. There could be many. It doesn't have to be one. But what we want you to do is think of what one of those experiences were, and then we're going to ask you to tell the story of that experience. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, think about that for a minute, what that experience is going to be that you're going bring forth. And then what we're going to have each of you do is go around and say what your question was, and then tell us the story of the experience that got you there. Okay? okay. We're going to do the same thing again, where we just gently hold this. Corey, you're going to go first for us. Just put it right there. So first, tell us your question and then tell us the experience that got you to that question.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: My question about the future for Boston is, will there be adequate housing for Black men and their families in Boston? And what got me to that question was I'm part of several men's groups that have men of color and they share their issues and concerns in these meetings privately. Without disclosing anyone's name ...

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: I have interacted with several men of color, Black and Brown, in these groups that express housing insecurity. And when they were looking for housing with their child, one particular father, he has a 14 year old child and he was turned down housing because he was a man. It's easier for other families that are led by women or don't have a complete nuclear family, it's easier to get housing. But when you come with two, a husband and a wife, or a male and a female, father and a mother with a child, it becomes difficult.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: So, that really is one of the things that I hold dear. And it's disheartening to know that it's a way that the Black family's being split intentionally or non-intentionally. But an effect is, if you come together, you can't stay together. You've got to come together separated in order to get housing, and that should not be the case.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: I got three questions, but I'm going to try to go with one. One of them was getting to the polls, but we're going to skip that because what really concerns me is brothers coming home and brothers in the community not having an opportunity to have gainful employment. That is even from the Latino brothers to the African American brothers to any other kind of brother. Even my brother, that's the case. One of the things I'm finding that's the biggest-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Go on. Go on. I hate to interrupt. I'm going to interrupt. I'm going to push because this is hard for us. I'm want to take what you just said ... Can you silence?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Men and women of color. The second thing I'm going to ask you, and this is going to be the harder piece, what I want you to do next is tell us a story from your own experience that got you there. And I'm pushing on this, because what we often tend to do is we'll go to facts and figures and stuff, and we'll leave out our experience. I want you to just talk-

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: Specific story. For me, I have a lot of friends who I receive calls from on a daily basis, who are either now coming home from incarceration, and very close friends of mine that I've grown up with in my neighborhood and around my neighborhood who not have an opportunity and will tell me, "I don't have an opportunity." My goal is to tell them that there's no such thing as can't in my book. There's no such thing as you can't have an opportunity if you don't want an opportunity. You just have to start somewhere.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So, it bothers me that I have to beat down our ... Because I'm a Ward Committee Member, that gives me access to my elected official a little faster than it would take a normal community member. I have to beat down our elected official's door to say, "Hey, listen. What are you going to do about helping this woman or this young man get gainful employment? Now they can't live. They can't even live in the City of Boston." That's one of Zakiya's statements. Folks can't afford to live here unless you're making ... not $50 an hour ain't even going to make it to be honest with you.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So, I get those experiences on the daily basis. I just got two of them actually this morning, and then I got one Saturday, a phone call Saturday. A friend of mine's just home. And what bothers me is I see the guys coming out of federal prisons and women coming out of federal prisons and they're going right into the unions. And I'm asking myself, why isn't it that this can't happen for city? Why is it that they can't get a city job? They can't a leg up or get on their feet? And what are we not doing as a community of people to not organize to make sure that they're eating because it's public safety issue as well if you really realistically think about it. So, I'm going to leave it right there, and I'm going to pass the mic.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Again, this is Geanier Moore. My question is, what will happen to the African American or minority homeowners after the pandemic? A lot of people own houses. A lot of us, especially me for instance, I rent rooms. I was renting rooms prior to the pandemic, during the pandemic. And a lot of people, once they said, "Hey, you guys don't have to pay your rent anymore," and he's like, "Okay. Cool." Not that they couldn't work, it was just that they didn't want to work.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: That left me with you can't evict them, and I've never been one to actually just want to evict somebody. It was always like you have to do something really bad. But when I have my kid at home and I have active drug users living with me and I didn't know that at the time, what am I supposed to, what do you do? So, it's not even necessarily the money. Let's just take the money out of it. But what am I supposed to do now that I have active drug users at the house that are coming in all hours of the night. Didn't matter that I have an alarm system. Doesn't matter. Anything doesn't matter. The street is quiet. It's just there's no help for me because I have to wait and until everybody else that was getting evicted, what, 2019, 2020, to get evicted.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: What happens to homeowners like myself that decided to try to do the right thing, to help people out? Like you said, people that come out of jail. I've had all that with no problem up until the pandemic hit. And now, it's people that actually really did lose their jobs, but then there's some that just was like, "The government said you can't evict me. The government said this, that, and the third." What happens to me as a minority, single woman owning a house in Dorchester, Magnolia Street line? I don't know. What happens to me? Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Will people who make less than $50 an hour be able to live in Boston in the near future? And that's based on my experience. Now I can go into that, right? My experience is I've helped over 100 individuals and families move out of Boston since 2007 as they could no longer afford to live here. I have been room-mating with family and or friends since 2008, although I'd prefer an affordable place of my own.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Hi. Quanda Burrell. My question is, like we wrote it in different ways like five times, when will there be more affordable, bigger, not bigger but ... I have it here but it doesn't ... When will there be more three-bedrooms for affordable housing? I've gone to a lot of meetings where they say, "Oh, two bedrooms, two bedrooms, two bedrooms." Right now, based on my experience is, I have a 16 year old daughter, soon to be 16 year old daughter, and a soon to be 11 year old son. We've been living in that space now for, he's 11 years. I have to make my daughter share a room with my son. And so, that brings into play a lot of back and forth, because the age difference there plus the gender. He's a male and she's a female, and she's now into teenager and he's still a young adolescent.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So, it's a lot of tit for tat going on. It's always a rush in the morning. "I can't find this," or, "He has that," duh, duh, duh. So all of that is like you wake up and you have to ... All right. This person's going to fight because of that person. This person's going to fight. So, there's certain things you have to do to be prepared to wake your kids up that share that space so that they won't have to fight anymore so you can have your mental with one bathroom.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Also it's just there's only so much that you can do as a single mom. I'm building on my credit. If I move out, I want to get into a house. But at the same time, you see all of these buildings going up and all these condos going up, and every meeting you go to they're like, "Oh, no. The new thing is two-bedroom, working space. It's working space. We're going to make it smaller, make the rooms smaller." And I'm sitting up here like, "Who are these people that are making these rules for us?" It's just crazy. It's not functional to have a smaller space when you have kids. All right. That's it.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Jimmy Thompson, Jr. My question is, when will Black men in Boston rise up other and become real leaders, other than entertainers, politicians, athletes, and pastors, to sit at the table and really be a part of the decision making process? I believe it starts and ends with the man along with the Creator and the wife, and the woman. And what brings me to that is, despite the fact that today I'm 58 years old and I'm a CEO of a security company, I work in the music industry as a bodyguard, and I'm a founder of Second Chance Against the Odds, where I give adults an opportunity to share their life experience in churches, group homes and such, it's not always been that way.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: So, my personal experiences growing up in a dysfunctional society, in a family, I'm a survivor of molestation. I'm a survivor of the school to prison pipeline, which equal the fact that I was in the streets and I was gang involved which led me to stay in federal penitentiary beds. I'm a victim of an unjust criminal justice system, also. Today, I have close to a decade of sobriety, which includes a spiritual walk and foundation that I was talking about. With that, man, I'm a father of 10 and a grandfather of 10. And so, I don't put my trust in the government or politicians. I have to be concerned with those that I'm able to influence with my testimony and my children and my grandchildren.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, I want to say to everyone, this has been really good. I hope you hear what people said and offered up is really a gift, people sharing these gifts with you. What I want to do now is, based on what you heard, I don't care who it is, you will figure it out, but if there's someone's question that you really connect to and have an experience related to that question you want to share with them, then I want you to talk to that person and just say, "Hey, your question really connected with me. Let me tell you my experience with that."

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Or, if there's something somebody said in their experience that you said, "You know, I had a very similar situation, but my experience was actually different. It wasn't the same as yours. Let me tell you about that." And so, you do it with whoever you want to do it with. There's no order. It's free fall. Whoever wants to start, can start. I think somebody wants to start.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I actually resonated ... well, I resonated with everybody especially these two. I'm sorry. But you, because I'm 47. I'm 47. So, my mom, I was blessed to have my mom. My mom, God rest her soul, she passed away 11 years ago. But, my family was always a firm believer in making sure that your family had some place to go. So, my mom passed. She passed the house on to me and my brother, and I was able to have that. So, don't ever say, "I need to get my credit." Listen, you're going to get there. I hear you.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: A lot of my friends have had to move to Middleborough and Taunton and Fall River, and just Braintree. They were in shelters and they have the kids, the same, but they had to move out to get a three bedroom. They can't get stay in Boston. None of my friends that I grew up with are here. They're all out in East wherever, and I'm like, "I can't visit y'all." I'm just here because my mom left me a house. That's why. And I'm thankful for that, it's a lot, but that's why. It's not because ... well, I worked on my credit, but that's not why.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Yeah, it is sad that we can't stay here and we can't raise our kids here. This is where we grew up at. I grew up here. I don't know what's going to happen when she gets old enough to take over if something happens to me, my older daughter or something like that. I don't know what's going to happen, because I don't know if anybody can afford to live here. The taxes are ridiculous here. So, people are moving out.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: I've questioned whether should I still stay here. I used to walk from my house to Tufts Medical Center when my mother got sick. I cannot walk from my house to Tufts Medical Center anymore because I'm scared to. And remember, I'm 47, so I grew up in the '90s and I wasn't scared of anything. I could walk up and down Washington Street and walk everywhere and walk downtown. But I'm scared now, because of Mass and Cass. I can't walk through the side streets anymore. I would not dare do that.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: So if there was something that we could do to find out if we could get those three bedrooms, but everything that they're building right now doesn't even have a three bedroom attached to it. It's always a loft or they're building $500,000 condos or lofts. They're splitting that. They're buying houses up around the neighborhood because now it's for cash, and a lot of the families have moved out. So, they're selling them, unfortunately, and they're splitting the houses. Put them in two or three family houses. They're splitting them into $500,000 condos or lofts now.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: ... to pay for a three bedroom, so they go to Northeastern or MIT, and have three college kids rent out a room in each of the house. That's how the landlords are now making it.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: When I was growing up, you lived on 1st, 2nd, and 3rd floor, you was a family. It wasn't all these strange people in a house just to make the rent because the banks say you have to charge three grand because of the property or whatever for taxes or whatever.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: That's why I prefaced my personal experience with growing up in an unjust society or a dysfunctional society, which made my family dysfunctional. To me, with all this data and information, we hear words gentrification, we hear all these types, we see the cycles over and over again. It's rigged from the start.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: You know what I'm saying? So, I'm pretty sure if we would go to the annals of time, not maybe 10 or 15 years ago, someone was mimicking or saying the same issues and concerns that you're talking about right now, that I'm talking about, all of us that are talking about. But however, it gets recycled and the powers to be just puts out a new game plan. And today in 2021, we have to learn how to play the game by their rules.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: You know what I'm saying? I'm saying there it's not a White or Black thing, it's just it's a game and we have to learn how to play it.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: So, it's just deep, man. The game is rigged and this delusion and hypnosis is real, and cognitive dissonance as well.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: Yeah. I had two things for you and I relate very much to Jim Thompson. I'm Tony Brewer. Sister, I think that there's accountability piece when you're renting out your rooms.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: To the point where you have to have accountability when someone comes through your threshold because you have a child. So when you have a tenant that wants to rent out that room, if they come in your door they have to know from the jump, from day one when they step their first left foot or the right foot through that threshold, "I have a child here. This is what I'm looking for. This is what I'm not looking for. Other than that, I'm sorry. I can't help you."

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So when it comes you having to get rid of them, well sometimes you have to do what you have to do, and you have to do it in a manner to where it's understandable because you have a child there and she comes first.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: It's very difficult to stand up sometimes to druggies or whatever, but then there's people in the community. There are community folks around you. There are people around you that will help you if you just ask, that will come and sit down and help you get people to exit stage left that are doing the wrong thing.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: I was chalked up as lost. I was done. I was left in a hallway for dead. My life was unmanageable. I was in prison for over 18 years. The reason why I say I get a lot of calls from people who are getting out of incarcerated because these are people who were in prison with me. We were family. We were all we had. My life was dysfunctional. A lot of fighting, a lot of dope in my family, dope shooters from the '60s. You know what I'm saying? They shot dope. They were Black Panthers. They were Mau Maus. They were gangs. They were street people, but they were my family.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: My mother passed away when I was four years old. I was a very bitter young man and I didn't understand myself until I learned how to get some help for myself. One of the most important things that helped me was getting on my knees and asking God to help me help myself. Until I learned how to do that, I was unmanageable and I didn't understand myself. But I had one friend, and I hate doing that because I ain't blowing his head up.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: I had one friend that never allowed me, in spite of if I would keep him out of harm's way, but he would never allow me to give up and he didn't give up on me. That's my boy right there. He didn't give up on me. We did a campaign. I was working for the City of Boston, and my so-called friends in the city, because I was campaigning for an African American person, the mayor had O'Reilly and we had Patrick. Let me just be frank with you. I didn't have that city job no more. And my friends who worked for the mayor, who was in his administration, wouldn't pick up their phones no more. I didn't cry about it. I trusted in God, and I kept volunteering. I kept working. I didn't ask nobody for nothing.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: But then when we won, my boy got there, I said, "Man, just crack the door just a tad bit and let me get my foot in and I'll do the rest." "All right, Tone." He did that. Cracked the door. I stuck my foot in it, pulled my arm in, and I refused to be denied. Because of God's grace and his mercy, you have to understand where this is coming from. If you don't understand where it's coming from, when you take some time this evening, you go home and just be grateful for God's grace and mercy for waking you up this morning.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: The director of security, the director of operations called me and said, "Tony, let's have lunch." I went over to the statehouse, I was on the fourth floor over the governor's office. He said, "What do you want to do, Tony? I know you don't have this city job no more." I said, "Ho. Ron, we called Ron. He called me, 'What's going on? What do you want to do?'" I didn't know what I wanted to do. You know what I'm saying? I was like, "Okay. What do I do?" He said, "Don't worry about the CORI." I went over the one in Ashburnham and filled out a piece of paper. That was done.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: But it just told me that God had his hand on me from the time that began walking, and when I surrendered. What I mean by surrendering, I don't mean just by surrendering to the alcohol and the drugs. I mean surrendering to God and saying, asking my Lord and Savior to lift me up. And He said, "I got you." And He brought them in the from of my boy, who is my friend since we were kids. Now, I'm not going to mention what we used to do, because I don't want y'all to know. You know what I'm saying? But I'm saying that to say that for all the time I sat behind the wall and all the opportunities I had, I went to school, I got a two-year degree. I went straight out of high school into jail. I was the pipeline. I sat DDU, DSU, 10 block, everything you can think of. Came out, was still unmanageable.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: But out of all the things that I did, was I went to a program. And I keep this program up front. I went to a program up in Shattuck, and it was a 30-day program. I went home. I wasn't stipulated by no courts or nothing. I went home and I sat at my kitchen table with my children and my wife, and I said, "I need to go to further treatment." And they're like, "You're home. You're all right." "No, I'm not. I need to figure out why I keep getting on this treadmill."

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So, I checked myself into a program that, what I called FUBU, For Us By Us, that held me accountable for my actions and gave me some tools to understand oneself. And I had went and got some help. I went and sat down with the psychologist, which most Black men don't do, and got to learn me and took the mask off. And understood that I represent somebody. When I walk out my door, I represent my wife, my children. I represent a family, so I have to conduct myself as though I represent somebody, and how do I want to do that.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So to wrap this up, I am grateful, and I never, ever, ever not hold myself accountable for anything that I do on a daily basis. It's all about the struggle but it's about lifting and continuing to lift, lift, lift. You got that girl right there, so I'm going to pass it on.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Corey, where you from? I just want you to know that we are at this place where people are just connecting.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: First, I want to say how grateful I am to be part of this conversation. Grateful for the stories that everyone has shared. I first started off wanted to talk about the three bedrooms and the inability for a family to be able to be housed adequately. But as the stories went on, it hit closer to home. Mental health, and particularly for a man of color in this country, in this city.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: I lost my son 11 years ago, and had only started to truly grieve three years ago as I joined an all-Black, all-male group. And within that group, we share our pain, our struggle to be equal, and I found a certain level of peace from losing my son. When I lost my son, I had vowed to give back to the community because they gave to me. And we were very fortunate in that respect. When my son passed, when he was sick in the hospital, he fell sick on Valentine's Day of an enlarged heart. Dilated cardiomyopathy.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: My daughter, on the other hand, had that issue. We knew about it, and she had treatment along the way. He was a complete surprise. He passed away subsequently after hospitalization on Mother's Day. My relationship with my ex did not last. My relationship with myself was suppressed. And until I came home, and I call Boston home now, and got involved with the community, with a men's group that allowed me to share my story, and give back because of the gratitude I live with today. All that to say is, a little bit of everyone's story touched me profoundly, and I say thank you.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: I am but a small part just like everybody else, but I believe I can pick up on what I heard. I'm just so grateful for this process because I've been dreaming about a recovery corps for Mass and Cass, which I'm starting to call Marty's Mile.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: But the God of my understanding tells me that's mean-spirited and I need to let that go. But can you imagine if we were properly prepared and came with the giving spirits I heard in this room today, and went down to Mass and Cass every day and said, "I love you and I see something in you, because I was you." Or, "I have a family member that was you." Or, "I have a tenant that is you right now. And if I could just give you a little spark of hope, I would help you. And by the way, here's a sandwich and a cup of coffee. How do you say, no strings attached. There's no strings attached. We just love you and want to see you do better." Now, sometimes we have to come with the stick a little bit.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: And that's what I'm hearing in this room, and that's also the value of this bigger process. There are going to be people in these conversations who have met some of the challenges we're talking about within their neighborhood, and they can share about it. And we, not just the elected officials, we'll be able to go into the Local Voice Network, the Real Talk for Change.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: And I can hear, "Hey, in Holborn, Gannett, Gaston ... I forgot the ... Gannett Neighborhood Association, HGGOBA, they solved that problem. Why don't we try it?" It won't be just the elected officials and candidates. It's being able to say, "Listen, did you hear that somebody said they had a problem with a tenant and it had nothing to do with paying rent. It had everything to do with their behavior. This is how these people came together and solved it. Why don't we try that?" That's the genius that I couldn't see in the beginning of this, Ceasar. And I'm seeing it over the weekend and today. This is why we're sitting together at these tables like this. With that, I'm just-

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Okay. Jim Thompson. For those that are going to hear this, we're sitting around a table of melanated people, from light skin to dark black. The primary question was, what does Boston look like. That was the primary question. And then, what was our experience. We heard how everyone addressed it. But when dig down, when we look into the core of it, like Zakiya just said, sometimes it's about behavior. And sometimes, like Corey talked about, he talked about trauma, and Tony talked about getting help, seeking out.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: So when we talk about overall, a lot of this stuff, a lot of our solutions and a lot of our problems go beyond ... it goes to we're living in an unjust society. We have some dysfunctional pain and unmet trauma, post-traumatic stuff. And we have some epigenetic stuff that was given to us from our grandmother's grandmother's grandmother due to how we were brought up.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: So, the future has to start with oneself and how you self-heal. How you address whatever you went through, reaching out to the agencies and organizations or the men or the women that you know that's a heart to heart, a soul to soul connection because sometimes it doesn't have to be from your local clinic or your hospital. It could be that basketball coach or that gymnastic coach, or that pastor or that minister that the Creator has placed in your life.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: So for me, listen, it starts with healing. And that's what it was with all my barriers that I was able to overcome to have a testimony like Tony talked about, was truly what allowed me to really dig deep and say, "Listen, I can't really focus on Boston. I have to focus on me and my circle. But I have to be a part of Boston by planting the seed." I have seven children. They're not doctors and lawyers, but they're all great human beings. You know what I'm saying? None of them, they're not CORI affected, SORI affected, no gang affiliation. I guess I took the whole weight of all of that. So, I did a wonderful job, me and the Creator and his mother and the community. So, I'd say it comes to the healing, the internal healing, spiritual healing first, which touches all of our topics.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: I just wanted to go, too, because I see this as an opportunity as a Black mom and as also part of being Mothers Raising Black and Brown Boys Coalition. My biggest fear that I have is my son. Raising my son. He's 10, he's going to be 11. So, I have five beautiful Black men here. I don't want my son to go through that. I don't want to get a phone call, the same way my sister got her phone call the day my nephew turned 18 because he was just standing up for somebody and got stabbed in the heart. I don't want my son to go through that. My daughter, she's fine. She's all right. I can take her out of my mind a little bit, because again, she's a little bit more like me. I understand her female to female.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: But my son is just like ... I'm not a man. I don't know how to raise him to be a man. I can just give him certain things and certain things to understand like you're going to get treated a different way because you're a man, you're a Black man, you're a Black boy. It's guaranteed to happen.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: It's already happened. It happened that day, June 7th, when they had a Martin Luther King history about racism. And then he's like, "Okay, well this is what that is. This is what is happening to me right now. So, she's racist." He's so verbal, where he ... yes, he asks questions and he'll call out. "But you just sat here and taught me the difference between equality and inequality. When I call you on it, you're telling me that I'm bad. That I'm a bad kid. Nobody wants me. Nobody loves me because of what you just taught me. And I'm telling you, I understand that this is what it is."

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So, I'm afraid for him. But at the same time, I don't want to change how he's able to question certain authority figures, because that's a good trait that I see he can have to read a person. "All right. I see the way you move this way. Let me just back off here."

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: But at the same time, I want to be able to teach him the skill of how to control that, because it comes out with passion. I know it's passion, but other teachers or other people will see it and label it as aggression.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And he's like, "But Ma, right is right and wrong is wrong. This is Black fear, because Tommy ..." So, that's my biggest fear, is how can I continue to raise my son in this type of world where he'll be able to stand up for himself but not be labeled as an aggressor.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Thank God he's short, because I know a friend, he's Black and he's tall and he's big. The sweetest teddy bear in the world. 38 years old. Construction, got a good job, everything. Sweetest man in the world. But because he's big, if he walks by a certain type of crowd, everybody clinching. Everybody clinching. Tell you the truth, he got more money in his bank account than the person he's walking by. That's the other thing, when I have these conversations, I don't know. I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: Thank you, Sister. One thing we got to learn to teach our Black boys is to be able to show all of their emotions. Controlled emotions, but show it. As a Black man, and I don't think I was able to truly show all my pain and stand up strong and don't cry, even when I lost my son. Don't cry, even when I lost my aunt. Don't cry when you're shot at. That's not easy. Because if half those people that walk the street that don't look like us had to step in our shoes, they would not last. So, I go to bed knowing that I'm stronger because of the people I'm with. Because what I've become after 51 and change years, I learned a little bit.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: All right. I just got feeling when he was talking about he goes to a men's group. Maybe afterwards we talk about we get your son active in a group in an organization of young brothers or older brothers trying to make a difference or trying to move forward.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: Zakiya, to your question about the Melnea Cass. I do this three times a month, me and my church. We go down and we give clothes away and we feed them. One of the things I found that 85% of those people that are down there aren't even from Boston.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: I feel terrible because they're taking beds away from the people from Boston so they can't get beds. But what I wanted to say was that I heard a lot of stuff in this meeting this evening, and I think this requires us to open more dialog and continue to come back to the table, and continue to talk about how can we collectively come together to help solve some of these issues that we're having so that this way we can move forward and move Boston forward ourselves. You don't really need a politician to do that. It really is the people power. The power of the people is what moves everything, believe it or not.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: So, if we collectively continue to come together and count on one another to hold each other accountable for what we're talking about right here at this table. Because, I'm a man of my word. I'm a man of my word. I didn't used to be. I ain't going to lie to you. I didn't used to be a man of my word. I used to be the sly, the slick, the wicked. You know what I mean? But today I'm a man of my word because I believe that all I got is my word, and I ain't going to say the other thing, but that's all I got. You know what I mean? It's important that I hold myself accountable if I'm sitting in front of someone to be the very best that I can be and give them the best that I can give, so that this way we can all get stronger together. I'm not one to not share. I love sharing. I like to share, but I'd like for everybody else to grow with me. If we're all growing, we're all eating, then we're all happy.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I do want to honor where we're at and that you've given each other the time to be here tonight. Why don't we just sit for a minute and just sit with what we've heard. Kind of center ourselves. Take a few really deep breaths.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: It's hard for me to sit and look at that picture. I ain't going to lie to you. I'm looking at 13, 14 [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're going to calm you down. We're all just going to sit here and take some breaths. Ron's going to start. What we can do is, I don't have to pass this around, we can just talk out, talk loudly. Whoever wants to start first, just give us a closing comment about things you want to leave everybody with.

nodes.speaker: Corey
nodes.words: It'll be real quick. I've been through therapy as a family and by myself. But sessions like this hit deeper and heals stronger. I feel stronger now, even though I'm letting it all out. So, thank you for helping me to be stronger.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: This was a wonderful process. It has deeper and more far-reaching results than I saw in the beginning when I first heard about it. And it's one of those that the more you do this process, the more we learn all the different results that we can get from it. This is an each one teach one. This is a, "Jeez, I get to find out that my issues are very similar to what everybody else's are," even if I didn't think that when I first came through. So again, I'm grateful, thankful, and appreciative of this process.

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: This is a wonderful process. The wonderful thing about this is, I love dialog, for one. But I also love to be able to solve a problem and work collectively because we're in a group. This has to be serious for me. I can't just come here and wait for her, the Globe lady, or wait for anybody. Don't get me wrong, Sister, or waiting for anybody and not think about the people that are around me that are having these conversations. Because each one, I've took something from each and every one of you and I digested it. And now, my goal is to see how can I help. That's just me. How can I help somebody help their self? You see what I'm saying?

nodes.speaker: Tony
nodes.words: I got a whole bunch of things, man, going in my head right now. I'm going crazy. But I do know that it's important that we have these discussions, because these discussions are also a part of healing. It's a healing process. And it's an information session, and information that we've gotten from one another. Now, we can't just take this as we're having a table talk. We've got to come back and we've got to see how can we help one another and not keep our resources to ourself. So, we take our resources and we share our resources and say, "I know Such and Such a person. Call this person. This person can help you." I have no problem with that. That's what it's all about. Community. Right? It's a community.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Well for me, I'm grateful. This is the second one I've been to, and I'm always crying. I'm a crier. I'm sorry. I always cry. By the middle of it, I'm done. That's because a lot of it, being in a room with others that look like you, you're able to ... a lot of past traumas, even though you feel like you've healed from all the traumas. A lot of my childhood came up in that I try to ... I'm fine with it. It's okay. But it's really not okay.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: And as far as you, I have a brother who is seven and half years younger than me. He's dealing with a lot of trauma that he refuses, refuses to get help for. It's hard for me, because I'm his sister. I'm a psychiatrist. I can't do anything for him. He doesn't listen to me because I'm his sister. But if he had a group of brothers that could talk to him-

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: They could talk to him. It might help. He never dealt with my mother's passing. He never dealt with his divorce. Nothing. So, I think now it's at a place where he doesn't even talk to his kids. So, I would love to come back and dialog because I think our boys do need other men that have dealt with trauma to help.

nodes.speaker: Geanier
nodes.words: Yeah. It's a lot. So, I'm grateful for this group, because the last time I didn't ... you don't have a lot of ... I have a very strong uncle that's like my dad around me. You've got to be strong. But it's different when it's not family.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: I'm grateful for this group, too. Making connections. I'm just noticing, again, as a mom, as a woman, in everyday life sometimes we tend to put certain things, push it to the side and prioritize. That's not a priority right now. This is. That's not a priority right now. This is. And then you sometimes forget about the stuff that's still knocking at your head, "Hey, this is going to come up soon." You can see. Yeah, they call it preventative measures.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Oh, Jim Thompson, Jr. In 2014, with only three or four years in my sojourn of finding myself, I was able to graduate a seminary theology school. It was during that process for me, I'm just speaking for myself, that the veil of ignorance was peeled back as I was doing my research under the seminary and theology and Christian thing. So, it's just for me. What I came to the conclusion was, before the heart, mind, and hand of man created what we know as doctrine, whether it was written or pictures, I know that there's the Creator and the creation.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Because my soul is so valuable that I don't want to be tricked or fooled with the many different denominations, but I know I have a heart to love God and the Messiah, whoever He may be. So, I say that to say this, that I give thanks to the Creator. And I give thanks to the ancestors that their blood runs through us right now. And I give thanks to our departed elders, some of our brothers, some of those recently that just was taken from us. We say too soon, but there was a purpose for why they left. And I give thanks to the heavenly host.

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: And I give thanks, man, I have the same buddy as Tony has. He's the reason why I'm here today, and he never gave up. I'm not going to put him on blast, but he knows who he is. He's in this room. He's shown me love when the pastors and politicians and entertainers and athletes that know me really well didn't give me a chance. But he did. So, I'm thankful for Real Talk for Change, and is it LVN?

nodes.speaker: Jimmy
nodes.words: Yeah, LVN for allowing us to plant a seed that maybe 30 or 40 years from now, something that we said when they hear this will resonate in somebody else, and that can be the catalyst for them in their life. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I can get it from you. I don't have to have people fill anything out. That'll be good. Thank you so much for the opportunity.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: To be here and sit with you and listen with you. I think there's some connections that are going to be made. I'm going to turn off the recorder so you can do that.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Here we go! All right. [inaudible] We all know each other in here, so this is going to be a real stress-free zone, real stress-free meeting real quick. We're going to go over what we're here for about Real Talk for Change, so we're just going to have a conversation. Thank you for responding to our invite and joining this network of voices and conversations that are happening across the City of Boston. If you can't hear me, let me know. Just feel free to say, "Hey, Shareef, I can't hear you." If you want to make a comment or something, just throw it in the chat room.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: But you are being recorded. We are being recorded, with your permission. This is for the mayoral race for the upcoming election starting September 14th, and it's going to be ongoing after that, so just we wanted to hear your conversation about the future of Boston, where you see yourself in it. That's why we're inviting you to this gathering by asking you to think of one most pressing question you have about the future of the city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions, and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing course of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to, knowing it will matter. I will now ... You're already being recorded, so I don't have to read that.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Four important items of information with you before we do the instructions. First, the purpose of this conversation, we want to create this new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across divides ... neighborhood, political and cultural, et cetera, et cetera ... and improve visibility and accountability between the candidates for mayor and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your own lived experience rather than entering the conversation with your position on the upcoming election of specific candidates. We are doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording of this conversation for our meeting today. The video recording will be discarded, and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. The conversations, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with members of Real Talk for Change team members and others who have participated in conversations throughout the Local Voices Network, LVN. LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by the nonprofit organization Cortico. LVN systems creates a transcript for each recorded conversation, and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to the Explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns. What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Networks, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you agree, please say, "I agree." I agree.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Thirdly, we will wrap up, we will share with you a form to fill in your name and your email so that we can send you your gift card. We have also included a selection with demographic information, which is optional. The reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect on and uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable answering. If you're not comfortable answering no question, you don't have to answer any questions.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in the conversation, and to support the goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Number one, speak for yourself, and out of your own experience. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. Number three, share the time. Allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Number four, state curious and honest questions. Number five, pause. Take time for reflection. Number six, listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Number seven, when possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications and put your phone on silent, so if your phone's on ... Some of you guys are on your iPhone, so, I see. If you need to take a moment to take a breath, please let me or Francesca know, and ... Or, you don't have to let no one know. Just go and stretch and do whatever you've got to do to get comfortable.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: For ease of this virtual conversation, we are going to use a modified circle ... but we're on Zoom, so we're not in person, so ... process where each person will take a turn. I'm posting the order in which people will be invited to respond to chat. I will help transition us from one person to the next. You can always pass and ask for us to come back to you.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: To begin, we want to take a quick round of introductions and check-ins. Please share your first name and where you are located right now, then let us know you are using the PIES check-in. This means you are saying how you are choosing to check in using one of the following: physical, intellectual, emotional, and spiritual. I'll go first. Physically, I'm okay. I'm a little tired. I've been up since 4:00 this morning. I had to work early this morning, but I'm happy to see all y'all come into this place and participate in this little political dialogue. I had a good time in it last time, but this is my first go-around, so I'm a little nervous, you know what I'm saying? But, it's all good. That's my friend Elliott who just entered the building. What's up, Elliot?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Good, we're just doing the little check-ins, so as soon as you're done, you can pass it on to the next person. Does anyone have any questions about the process? Feel free to let me know. No? So, I don't like to call on no one, so I'll let you guys come off mute, and whoever wants to go first, just let us know how you're doing, either physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: Okay, hi. My name is Arlene. I'm from Franklin Hill development. Emotionally, I am drained. I just came back from a business trip, and I did not accomplish everything that I had to do, so that's a little bit emotional for me. And physically I'm exhausted, because from my business trip, I came right into an activity here in my development and I have a lot of catching up to do.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Thank you. That's awesome. Arlene just came back in the country. She escaped this for a little while, but she's back to lay down the law. Shoot.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: My name is Azalea Castillo. I'm from the Franklin Hill community too, development. I'm getting ready to go back to work and work for the City of Boston for the social service department. The time for summer vacation is almost over, so I'm just preparing to go back to another year of excitement and running around with the kids. I try to do day-by-day. So far, we're healthy, my kids are healthy, and I'm very grateful for that.

nodes.speaker: Sandy
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Sandra. I'm from the Franklin Hill development. Physically, I'm tired. I've had a long day. I've had a busy work so far, and it's just Tuesday. And emotionally, I'm just going through a few things right now. My grandson had some tests done yesterday, so we're just waiting on the test results for that, but other than that, I'm okay.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yeah. Margaret and Elliott, you guys are up next. Elliott, I'll explain it to you, so whenever you're ready, just let me know. I'll explain to you the short version.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: Hi. My name is Elliott. I'm not in Boston. I'm tying in all the way in Connecticut. I'm a microbiologist and an epidemiologist for one of Yale New Haven hospitals in Connecticut. Physically, I'm a little tired. It's been a very busy week. Clinically, I work in the lab in microbiology, so I'm very involved with the COVID testing and monitoring and all that, so it's a little overwhelming. Some days are very busy and stressful, like today, and so physically I'm a little tired and all worn out, but other than that, I think I'm okay, generally speaking.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yep. Elliott's the doctor, so if you got any medical questions, feel free to throw it at him, you know what I'm saying? Miss Margaret, you're up next.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: Okay. Good evening, or good afternoon. My name is Margaret Davis. I'm a mother of three. How I'm feeling? I'm good. I'm good. I'm also a tenant of Franklin Hill apartments. I think that was it, right?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm just going to introduce myself very quick. I'm Francesca, and spiritually, I'm struggling because I lost a good friend of mine, and although I have a lot of faith, I wonder sometimes why God snatches people that are so wonderful. And he was at the Yale Hospital in New Haven, and I'm going to his services on Thursday in New Haven, so it's just ironic, Elliott, that you're with us. Thank you so much. Okay, Shareef, take it away.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you, Francesca. Now that we know who's here, let's get to the core of the conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inadequate in America ... inequality, I'm sorry ... in America, in Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keep this in mind. I would like to invite you to think, what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? Take two minutes to reflect on this and write it down somewhere if that feels helpful. We'll reflect two minutes, and I'll go first to kind of model how the question is.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: One second, Shareef. Elliott. Excuse me, we have to ask Elliott to state that he consents to be recorded. I'm sure when he joined there was something that said, "This session is being recorded," Elliott, but we just need you to unmic and state that it's all right for us to record you.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Thanks. My question about the future of Boston is about education, since I've got two four-year-old daughters. What is the educational system going to look like five years from now? 10 years from now? 20 years from now? Because I want them to have the best education possible, so that's my question about the future of Boston. Where I see myself in it, I do work within the school system a little bit, so that's where I'm at. I want to have them thrive and do the best that they can do. So, whenever the next person's ready, feel free to state your question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Actually, I dropped the order in the chat so that we can just keep it moving. We'd like Sandy to go first, then Arlene, then Margaret, and then Azella, Azalla? I'm not sure if I'm saying that right. And then Elliott. So, if you can just ... And then Sandy, you go. And if you're not ready to speak, you can say, "Pass," and then the next person go so that we can really listen deeply to your questions and your stories. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Sandy
nodes.words: My question is, what would our community look like in the future? And how are we going to handle all the violence that's going on in our community? What goals are we going to set to curb the violence in our communities?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No, Shareef was. Shareef was muted, and I'm sure he was getting ready to ask you to share the story about why you came up with that question. But Shareef, you should probably stay unmuted so that [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Sandy
nodes.words: The reason why I came up with this question is because my son was injured in 2017 in gun violence, coming from a basketball game. He was innocent. He was coming from the game. He was at the bus stop. There was a bunch of kids fighting and they started shooting at each other, and a bullet hit my son, so he was just an innocent person that was injured in violence that had nothing to do with him. So, that's the reason I ask the question. Because we have a lot of people, innocent people, that's been getting hurt because of this gun violence. We have grandmothers, mothers, children. I can even go far back as the Tiffany Moore story, when she got shot and killed, so that's the reason I ask that question.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: And my question was the same. It was along the same line, the quality of life for everyone living in Boston. My reason for asking is because of all the violence that's going on, all the gun violence, all the innocent people getting killed. I would really like to see some change. I know I was speaking to someone else about the violence that started years ago with the OG people, and those people are still around, and what they started, they should try and end it. Because I have two young guys growing up, 21 and 22, and whenever I hear a siren, I'm just checking to make sure my kids are okay. Today there was some sort of an incident over on American Legion highway, and I told my son to call a friend of his who lived on American Legion highway to make sure he was okay. So, as a parent, I'm always worried about my kids and other young men living here in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: And with us living here in Franklin Hill, there is always a beef with Franklin Field for whatever reasons from way back when, but the youngsters are now taking up the same fight when it's not their fight at all. So, I would like to see something happen to make the quality of life better for the young guys. Not young guys only, but for all the youngsters growing up here in Massachusetts and Boston.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yes indeed. And that fight's been going on ever since I was an infant, so I don't know why it continues to go on. They don't even know why they're fighting. It's just embedded in the culture.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: Yes. It's just keeping it up, just keeping up appearance for whatever reason, and it's not really working for the parents and the grandparents who have to raise all their grandkids and great-grandkids because of the choices that some people make.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: My question and concern for the wellbeing and safety of all the children that are going back to school in person. In that example, previous school one of my daughters attended, there's ... Actually, both of the schools, there was poor ventilation and there weren't any windows. They did send out a email to the parents making them aware of the situation, and to, I guess, dress accordingly, but me personally, I feel like that's not enough. Just the wellbeing and safety for all the children that are going to school in person, knowing that COVID's around.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: And my children have asthma, too, so the ventilation and the air conditioning and windows are essential, I think, to ... [inaudible] trigger an asthma attack for some kids. All right, so that's my question.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: Okay, now it's my turn; Azalea. So, I'm thinking everybody's talking a little bit of education, violence, and other areas. I think one of the other points that we have to work more is affordable housing for the middle class. Now, it's true, they make a lot of construction, but it's more like luxury apartments or private apartments for people who can afford living in private houses or things like that. Middle class is more affordable houses for low-income families. They have to stay in some kind of situations because they don't have another option to move to more available or flexible places to live.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: Also, it's very important the school system, to pay a little bit more attention to the buildings, the condition of some buildings; air circulation or their situation in the bathrooms, things like that. I think it's very important to touch base in the health programs too, more affordable health insurance, or again, like the low-income, middle-class family. Those don't have a lot of programs in a lot of different, flexible ... We can say programs, but at the same time, we need more. But I think the impact that would help a lot is more development for low-income or middle-class families.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yes indeed. Yes indeed. I'm involved in a group called GenUnity, and we've been talking about inequity in housing, and how the cost of housing is almost a million dollars just to buy a home. That's where a policy should come in the room, so if you want to talk offline after the conversation about that, and if you want to join the meeting one time, feel free to let me know, Azalea. Elliott?

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: Yeah, I think Azalea, Miss Castillo, just talked a little bit about what I had in mind, or my concern. It's about affordable care. I work in the health field. I know there's a lot of disparity in terms of how care is being sourced and how care is being given. I've seen a lot of people suffer just because they can't afford care, healthcare, and I've seen just the simple kind of care they need, so my concern is, what's the way forward? What's the plan in the future on how to correct that, and how can everybody access quality care being affordable to everyone? And especially during this time, with the COVID situation. So many people died, not because of the virus in itself, but also because they weren't able to get care.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: There's so many disparities when it comes to healthcare delivery and other systems, and I'm concerned about that. It bothers me to see that some people can afford care and some others can't, and there's no provision set up to be able to accommodate those who cannot afford that kind of care. I want to see a situation whereby in our environment we make provisions so that everyone can have quality care, it's affordable, and it's accessible to everyone.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yes indeed. Arlene, [crosstalk], can you say your question again, just to state it? Not your whole experience, just your question.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Now, what I want you to do next is think back to each of the questions and experiences that we were just sharing in our group. Find someone whose question or experience resonates with you in your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonates with you, and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. Let's give everyone a minute or two to reflect. Whoever is ready can start us off. If you guys want me to go first, I'll go first.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Okay. Well, I definitely identify with everyone, especially with the gun violence. As a young child, I didn't think that I'd live past 21 years old, but I managed to do that. I remember going to the festival and all the violence around the whole city. I remember every gang, every group, every crew, and I just had my friends growing up, going in and out of jail, killing, some got killed, all that other stuff. Then when I moved down to Mississippi, it was the same thing.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Things are changing now little by little, because people are becoming more socially aware of issues. Just thinking back to that, I'm like, "Man, my God, I was lucky. I played basketball, so I stayed away." Well, actually, a lot of the gang members protected me, because I was winning them championships, so it was like, "Rif, go home. Stay out of trouble. You need to win the championship."

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: And someone said something about the environment, just going outside. I went to a local neighborhood ... I don't want to say the project, but it was like candlelight vigils all around the neighborhood for people getting shot. I'm like, "My goodness! This is tragic!" You've got kids running around, and there's candles almost on a whole section of the project, of the neighborhood, where people got shot. That was tragic. You've got kids looking at that. What are they going to grow up and see? What is their future going to hold? What are they going to do about life, their quality of life? Are they going to continue to repeat the cycle about the Franklin Field and Franklin Hill beef that they don't even know why they're beefing with each other? It's just embedded in the culture.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: So, that's what I'm thinking about. And the quality of housing. It's almost a million dollars for a house. This is crazy. Gentrification, the red lines and the racial situation. So, that's where I identify with all you guys stories, and now affordable healthcare. Now, some state are implying that if you don't get vaccinated, they're going to raise your premium $200.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: I identify with all the concern that was raised today. And I know we supposedly have free healthcare, and recently a family member of mine had to go in to get services. Everything was covered while she was in the hospital, but now that she's out, she has to financially take care of all her medication and stuff like that.
