So, they're saying free healthcare, but it's not always free. Some people say they don't want to go into ... Like what your friend just said. People don't want to go in for health services because they don't have insurance to cover it, and that's a concern because people wait until it's irreversible, to go in and it's too late.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: So, that's a big concern that I see happening in all over, and I hear about it, and now I am actually ... It's a little affecting me because of a family member. And the housing, it's the same thing. You have all those people who are homeless. My mother is on the mayor's committee, the monetary committee that speaks about all this affordable housing, and when [Marty Walsh] was here, he wanted all the new companies that are building houses to have 20% for affordable housing or low-income. I'm not sure if that's being done, but there are so many buildings going up now and they're telling us it's market rent, and affordable housing is affordable to whom? Because someone who's working for $10 or $12 an hour, that's not considered affordable housing, because they can't afford to pay the $1600 rent for a one-bedroom.

nodes.speaker: Arlene
nodes.words: So, these are all good points that need to be raised, and we need to have it to voice openly for everyone, because there's a lot of people who is in these situations and they have no idea what to do about it. Just like school safety and the fire plans that is going on all over. I don't know who could fix it, but we have to try to make all these concerns we have be raised in our community and try to fix it somehow. If it's truly the mayor's office or the local politicians that ... I mean, this is, I would say about 70%, 80% concerns for the residents living here in Massachusetts, because it's not only Boston. It's all over. That's my take.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: Well, I think we share the same sympathy about safety musts. I'm single mother of three kids ... Well, four, but one is married and is not under my care anymore, but I have three; 18, 15, and 12 years, my kids. For me, the safety and the education and a place to live, for me, priority.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: Going through some situation, I ended up in a shelter, and I think that system has to be arranged a little bit, too. They destroy you. Immoral. They destroy, like you feel like you are nobody and you don't have any option. That is the way that I was feeling, so I almost gave up and I tried to get better conditions for me and my kids. I've always been working. It's not that I've been expecting some help from just the government, but I've always been working and paying my taxes and all that. Being in a situation like that make you feel like you lose hope sometimes. Like I said before, my dream is to have a place where I can feel safe and my kids can be safe playing outside, going to the park and not seeing bad people around the area where he lives, and doing some bad business.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: I cannot complain where we live now, but it can be better. I think some people try to work hard in that. It's true it's difficult and it will take more than a couple of months, but I think if you were together, we can make it better, the situation, but I think everyone shared a little bit of the fear that we have, and I think it's valid. Everybody feels the same. Safety, help, have access to education. Now, going back to the school ... and it was a little difficult for me to get into school again, but I feel I can do it, and I want to do it, and I hope that'll help me for my future, to get a better work, have a better situation for me and my family to move, a better place.

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: Like I said before, every day I say, "Thank you for all the help that Jehovah give to me and my family, and I hope that everybody one day reach the dreams. And we have to continue doing every day. Don't lost hope, because we can do it. That is true, we're fighting every day, but I think it has to work together as a community and help others to build a different view. But, we need more work from the big heads, the community leaders, to put a little bit more effort to help the middle and the poor people in this community.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: Oh, no, I was just going to say that my number one concern would be health and safety. It seems like everybody have the similar concerns, because they're not promised tomorrow. Safety and heath risks is crazy. It's like you feel like you're safe, and then something could suddenly happen with the COVID, and then those other viruses, and reasons of safety or people that otherwise ... It's like, we've got to really focus on this. I feel like people are more thinking of it now, but the fact that COVID is here in ... Whereas before, it probably wouldn't have been a main concern. And that's sad, but at least before thinking about it now, and it's like a number one agenda versus before, where it was just day-to-day living. Live like it's, I guess your last, because you don't know.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: It's just super scary for, even the little kids who cannot get vaccinated, so the elderly, the seniors, everybody. And then going back to the school and the masks, it's just ... Seems like it's out of control. I'm even afraid to send my youngest one to school because she's not very good with the masks, and I don't blame her, but I don't know, I just think they need to have something in place for extra precautions.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: I'm going too deep into ... It's just so huge right now with the safety of other people, and small children, it's just like people to the seniors who are very vulnerable.

nodes.speaker: Margaret
nodes.words: I have to stop myself before I get going. Yeah, it's mostly health and safety. But, the other concerns as well are equally essential, like with the housing and the skyrocketing out of the rent, and making it unaffordable to people to live. That's sad, because the whole goal, I would think, would be trying to eliminate people from living outside in homelessness. It's sort of like you're pushing people or just getting by to homelessness. That's not where we should be going. And I'm going to give somebody an opportunity to speak, so I'm going to mute myself on that point.

nodes.speaker: Sandy
nodes.words: I can identify with everyone with the gang violence, the affordable housing, the school. Even though my two are grown and done with school, I still have a grandchild in school. And also, the mental health in the community. Mental health as well. We have a lot of homeless people that have mental health issues, and what are our politicians doing about it? What are they doing about these people getting the care that they need? What about our veterans getting the care that they need? So, I can identify with what everyone else was saying ... you know, the healthcare, the housing, the violence ... because I've experienced it myself. I've had on-hand experience with the violence, and I also have friends that have lost children due to gun violence, so I can identify, but I'm just going to get off this subject because it's really touchy for me and I get really emotional sometimes when I talk about stuff like that. So, I'm just going to give someone else a chance to speak. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: Yeah, I would like to say something briefly about that. I think I kind of relate to what she brought up about mental health. I think I had mentioned about there's a lot of disparities in healthcare delivery. Some folks, in terms of mental health, some folks get the healthcare attention that they get, but when other folks act out because of mental health, they say they're violent. These ones don't actually get the opportunities to get the care or the evaluation that is required. And because the mental health condition makes them to become violent or commit a crime, they are being sent to jail. We see that all the time.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: But some other folks do the same thing, just, "Oh, he's sick." That's on the one side. On the other side, I also relate about schools, the school system, the safety, and how we can ensure that our kids are well-taught in a very good and safe environment. I have a five-year-old and a one-year-old. My daughter, my five-year-old just started kindergarten yesterday. Yesterday was her first day in school. It was mixed feelings, where we were happy she was going to school, but at the same time we was kind of scared.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: We hope she's safe, we hope she's well, we hope she can get the best out of that arrangement, but at the same time, we know what's going around besides the COVID, the violence in schools, and so on and so forth. So, our hearts are actually in our mouths while we send our kids to school, when back in the day, 10, 20 years ago, we never had school violence and all that. So, I can relate with those comments that folks have made about education, security in their environment, and especially also, she just talked about mental health. I think mental health is a very serious issue in all our communities, and I don't think it's been given the needed attention. Even if they do, like I mentioned, there's disparities in how the delivery network give attention to mental health illness, and how folks who have mental health illness have been cared for.

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: I think I would love to see, down the road, how this is taken seriously, and how folks on the streets should be evaluated if, for any reason, they show any signs or factors to classify them to have mental illness, they should get the necessary care. They should be able to access care and not wait until they become very sick and they start to act out and throw them in jail. I think the system somehow have failed us in that regard. We'll continue to hope and look forward to a situation where all those are corrected, and we'll continue to give needed attention, support, everything that's needed to make mental health issues, give awareness to people about mental health issues, and give care and concern to it so that we can save those who have mental health, and save our communities too. [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Now, let's draw a few connections with each other. Let's freestyle a little bit. Let's talk about what we're hearing and what are you hearing in people's experiences. I'll start off first. This is kind of like a freestyle part of the session the last 15, 20 minutes.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: The mental health, I work back in Back Bay, so I see a lot of drug addiction as well. With the meth, and I don't even know what other kind of drugs these guys and girls are taking. Every morning though, down Back Bay when I go to work, it's like a Michael Jackson Thriller video. You see the people literally laying down in tents, and they're just sobering up throughout the night, out there just ... Oh my God, it's bad. Just high as a kite, and it's throughout the whole city.

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Down by Boston Medical Center as well, it's the same thing. They have a whole little fence just packed with a whole bunch of people, and they're legally allowed to shoot up and take drugs. That's crazy. So, with the mental health issues, I'm seeing a lot of people just fighting, being angry. Anger's at an all-time high. Stress. It's just crazy. So, that connection is what I'm also hearing for everyone else. Anyone else want to share anything? Feel free. About what connection you've made with one another. Francesca, you want to jump in? Feel free.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm not sure I made it clear what my role was. I'm helping with Shareef. Shareef is one of the facilitators for this project, and I just want to ... Excuse me. I think I might need to have a little water. I just want to appreciate everything that I heard, and I wish I could participate, but I'm not allowed to. I'm a participant observer supporting Shareef's facilitation, and it sounds like he did a good job because you each were able to ask a question, share a story, and then find connections with each other. So, what I really want to do is appreciate each of what you said, and know that the technology will be able to get all of our stories and experiences connected with ...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Our goal is to do 150 of these conversations with a minimum of four and a maximum of eight, and to try and get people that know each other, but also that may not know each other, in the same room or on the same Zoom call. But the power of hearing each other's stories and resonating and connecting and knowing that people all over the 22 ZIP codes in 22 neighborhood will be able to bring to the leaders, to Azalea's point, Miss Castillo's point, your voices through a link. So, instead of trying to get 100 people in a room during a debate or something, we can get 100 voices in the room with a link.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, as an old-school organizer ... I'm in my 60s ... been trying to make our city a better place for everybody, and a little intimidated by technology. I'm really grateful to be a part of this project, and to be learning new things in my 60s that are really powerful, and I want to thank Shareef for reaching out to you and inviting you. Any closing comments before I do a little housekeeping and have a request so that you can get your gift card and consider inviting other people? But before I do that, any other thoughts or concerns or questions that you want to raise?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Yeah, I want to thank everyone for coming, showing up. Our first go-around, so it's good to see you guys. We don't get to see each other as often as we should, but thanks for this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay, so you know what I did? You all got the email from Shareef. Well, let me come off of this so you can see me, my beautiful self. Hi. The email that Shareef sent with the link, I sent you a Google Doc. Let me show you what this is. How many of you have used a Google Doc? I have somebody under 30 that can help you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay, this is, it's the demographic information. We want to collect this information so that we can demonstrate that we're building power across difference and including a lot of people's voices in this project, so we're asking you to click on this link and make sure you give us your name and email address, but we'd also like you to fill out the rest of it. This is how you will get your gift card. We ask you a little bit about your race and ethnicity, we ask you about how you identify as a man, woman, or other, your age, and what neighborhood do you live in, but you only have to fill out what you want to share with us. It's all anonymous. The most important thing is that you fill out your name and email so that you can get your gift card, because we really want to honor that you took time away from your very, very, very full and wonderful lives, and hope that you can enjoy the time together, and also we appreciate you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Oh! My most important thing; Ron Bell from Dunk The Vote. We're asking everybody to consider voting on September 14th in the preliminary, and then voting again November 2nd. If you're not registered, please register. We are trying to get 20,000 people to make a commitment in our community to vote this electoral season. Most people vote at governor and president elections; a lot of people don't vote at the local election, and the local election who are the people that have the power to determine our budget.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, that's my Dunk The Vote plea. Please make sure you vote. And I'd like to just give a round of applause to all of you for your being with me and joining us today. Thanks so much. And Shareef, is there anything you'd like to add, end with?

nodes.speaker: Azalea
nodes.words: So, I think ... One question. Are you going to send the link? Because you can just copy the link from your email and put it in the chat right now and we can do it. [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You know why? Because Lenora, she did it with me before you all got on it, so let me put it right here into ... Oops! Wait. No. Let me see. Let me see. Let me try it. Hold on one second. Here we go. Now, see. Is it in there now?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I sent it via the ... So, the link is there and you can do it right now if you want. I'll stay on the call. And I also emailed it to you. But once you have it on your phone, you don't [crosstalk] right?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: All right, so, Shareef, I emailed it to everybody. Shareef is available. You have his phone number, right? You can text him if you have any problems—

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. As long as we have your name and email, you'll be all separate. We really appreciate you sharing as much as you want in that form, and it'll all be uploaded in a spreadsheet without your names and emails attached to it. It's just [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Because I'm pretty sure the way they give gift cards through the email is they just send it to you and you have to click on something. All right, so, [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Elliott
nodes.words: For me though, seeing as I'm out of Boston, I'm from Connecticut, do I ... Because one of the questions is what territory or what neighborhood of Boston do you identify with.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. I mean, Shareef mentioned that he thought you had some origins here and you'd been here for a while, or at some aspect of your life, so wherever you connected. We get that you're not there anymore, but we really appreciate your time, and I know Shareef really appreciated the support, so we're glad you joined us. And everybody else, Shareef is going to be doing these conversations and we would love to hear from other people that you are connected with; people that are like you, but also people that aren't like you. People that you might work with or you cross paths with and you're like, "I'd love to see what they have to say," and maybe you wouldn't be in the same room with them, but maybe they'd join us. So, we're really trying to promote as many ...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We want to do 150 of these conversations by the end of October, so if you had fun and you want more, tell your friends about us. And don't forget to vote. And I know somebody was working on dinner, so I'm going to say ciao for now unless there's anything else. We good?

nodes.speaker: Shareef
nodes.words: Thank you. And feel free to send anyone who wants to participate in this conversation, give me their information and we'll do it again.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. We are now recording. So, as part of these Real Talk for conversations what we do is we actually are recording the conversations. Oh, great. Okay, just hold on. Let Elvis get in. Hey, Elvis. How're you doing? Welcome.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, I'm doing fine. You just came in right at the right time. I was just getting ready to tell people about why we record these conversations. So-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah, that's where you are. So we record these conversations and what we end up doing on the Zoom calls is after the conversations we actually throw away the video and we only use the audio, okay? And then these actually end up on the system and I want to... because some of you may not have seen this before. I just really quickly want to show you what this might look like. Can all of you see this? I can't see you, but can you see this?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: It ends up on a system like this where we have the full transcript of the conversation. We have who is in the conversation, and then themes that came up in the conversation, and when they were spoken, and by whom. And so with this system we could, like for example in this one, actually go in and see that Marilyn had something to say about the pandemic. If we click on it, you should be able to hear it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, bye-bye. Okay, so as we shared the restrictions of the pandemic. It will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequit...

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Now I'm not going to go on and play it, but I just wanted to give you a demonstration that this is the system that this conversation is going to be part of. And, for those of you who after this conversation will [inaudible], we'll set up a totally different meeting with you to take you through the whole process where you really can understand how the system works and the technology and everything. But right now we're just going to delve into this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, a couple of things. One, these conversations, as I said before, are going to be up on this site. Our organization partners with a non-profit called Cortico. The site that I just showed you called the Local Voices Network is actually hosted by them for the public use and for community-based non-profit organizations. We're starting to build a network of organizations in Boston who are community-based organizations who actually have the management and the ownership and responsibility for these conversations. So it won't be MIT. Cortico will actually be the host and truly keeping up with the control of those are going to be left up to this community consortium we're building. So that's one thing.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Two, some people don't like to use their real names and you don't have to. So if you want to use a different name, you can do that in the conversations. And we'll just ask you, to make it easy for everyone to know, it will be really good for you to change your name now, so that when other people are referring to you, they don't refer to you by the name that's on screen but they refer to you by the name that'll be called on this conversation if you want to be somewhat anonymous, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And then the last piece that I want to say to you is I have to read something. And this is really the only script piece that I have to read exactly as is because it's all this stuff about the permission to record. And so basically I'll start with that. It says, as you participate in this conversation you are providing consent for Real Talk for Change to retain the recording in accordance with this mission. You also understand that the conversations would be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect and retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. And so, if that's okay with you can I have you each say, I'm okay, I agree, and I'm okay with being recorded. You can do it unanimously all at once if you want.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Anyone who doesn't agree? Good. We're good to go. So with that we're going to keep the recording going. I think we are all on and ready to go. But also if you want to step off you can. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, at the end of this, when we close the conversation at the very end, I'm going to ask you to stay on for one more minute because what I'm going to ask you to do is fill out a little online form. It has seven questions and it's about helping us capture some demographic information that will help in being able to report this back out, and it's all pretty broad, and you can choose to answer the ones you want to or not. So, with that, let's get started, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So one of the things we're going to do is we're going to use this and what I like to call a modified circle process. And the way that works is I'm going to basically have all of you here and I'm just going to put a couple of names here so I have them right. And, it's Joe. Okay, thank you, Joe. Did anybody else change their name because I don't want to mess that up?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And change hers to Lina. Okay. I will call you by these. So, for my reference who I have on the call today is Lina, Doug, Jasmine B, Elvis, Somala, Davo, and Joe. Is that correct? Okay, so we're all good to go.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So it's all good to go. Okay. So why don't we start out. First thing I want to do is a little round of introductions, but here's how I want to do it. We're going to go around. I'm going to put the order in the chat so you see which order you speak in. And this is how I want you to introduce yourself, your name, what neighborhood you associate with in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And then, we do what we call a P.I.E.S. check-in. So what is P.I.E.S.? I'm going to fill this in the chat real quick. P.I.E.S. is basically checking in on one of four things, how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. And you can check-in on one of those, or two of those if you want to. So when you go around just say your name, say what neighborhood you associate with, and then take one of those four things and actually check-in on it, okay? And, once you check-in and finish, I always like to have people say, and with that I'm in, which means just I'm acknowledging that I'm here. So, I will model and then we'll go around and I'll put the order in the chat after I model. I'll just put it in the chat now.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So my name is Ceasar McDowell. I don't live in Boston. I live in Brampton. But, if people ask me what I identify with is really with Roxbury because of years of doing work there. And I want to check-in actually today emotionally. Some of you may have heard this before but this has been a really rocky year for me and I've still been sitting on the emotions because we've lost so many people in our family in the last two years period, not only to COVID, some of it to other things. But just sitting in the space where you feel you never get to just calm down and say, okay, I'm free of that for a little bit. It just feels like it's continuing. And with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: I am Lina. I live in... I am Lina [Rohas]. Sorry, I got big dogs running behind me. I live in Dorchester, Codman Square, and I am emotionally tired due to COVID and all the irrational behavior with COVID, and with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: Right. My name is Doug and I live in the Hyde Park area of Boston, and I am emotionally a bit frustrated with a lot of the... it's campaign season and just frustrated with a lot of the current campaigns that are going on and frustrated with a lot of the candidates. I wish I could be more satisfied with some of the candidates.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Jasmine B for the purposes of today. I am going to go with intellectually exhausted today with views on leadership development and how to manage and build teams. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: I'm Elvis Rodriguez. I live in South Boston. I think that I have been tired emotionally, physically, and mentally with all the changes, not only COVID, but certain things that because of COVID were triggered. So, with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: Hi everybody. My name is Somala. I am living in Dorchester near Savin Hill, and I am also feeling physically, emotionally, spiritually, intellectually exhausted. At a period of transition in my life and so that's exhausting and then just general COVIDness, never ending. And today I don't feel I move my body enough. So, I'm feeling a little static. But with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: I'm Davo Jefferson. I live in Hyde Park, but I'm more of a Dorchester kind of a dude. So, want to just put that out there. I am feeling intellectually curious about what's going to happen here tonight, and I'm feeling physically great. And with that, I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Hi everybody. My name is Joe. I am a Dorchester resident. I am physically and emotionally tired. And with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: All right. Thank you all so very, very much. I always think it's important to start out by being real with where people are and what they're holding in their lives, and sometimes we do this check-in and people would do all four of them. But, because of our size and our time we only want to do one today. But I appreciate you bringing that honesty and fully bringing yourself here and being here with us.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, move us into the conversation. So the conversation is actually pretty structured. It has two big parts to it and the first part is really guided and I'm going to guide you through it by asking you to do two things. And I'm going to give them to you one at a time, but you don't report out on them until after you've done both. So it might be helpful for you if have a little piece of paper, if you're one of those kinds of people, some people do it on their phone, some people do it on their computer, to help you think. But I'm going to give you a prompt and what I want you to do is actually think through this prompt a little bit for yourself, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So the first prompt I want to give you is, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it, okay? So, what I'm asking you to do is come up, for yourself, not for anyone else, but just giving you, your own life, your goals, and what you give in your life? What's your question about the future of the city and your place in that future, okay? And so at some point we're going to come around and ask each of you to actually share that question. But first I want to make sure you get it down for yourself. Everybody got that? So I'm going to give you a minute or two to think through that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: How are people doing? Everybody got a question? I need some recognition. Give you another 10 seconds, 15 seconds. Two, three. You're ready, Elvis?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Davo, you're ready? Joe, you're okay? Okay. So, looking at your question, and this is [inaudible] interesting for me is that when we think about questions in our lives in which we're centered in, our questions are actually informed by things in our lives that have happened to us, that we've seen, that we've come in contact with. So what I want you to do is, look at your question and then I want you to think about the experience in your life that has actually led you to that question, because this question doesn't come out of nowhere. Now you can say it came, oh, I read this book and... but I want you to ground it in your own personal experience. Your own lived experience. An experience in your life that you think is part of what's led you to that question. And then, once you know what that is I want you to write it down and remind yourself of it because you're going to tell us the story of that experience when we go around, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So I want to give you a few minutes to think about this because you probably have lots of experiences that have connected you to that. So you have to decide which one do you think is most [inaudible] is best in really connecting with that question in a powerful way, okay? And remember, it's going to be your experience.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Everybody feel [inaudible]. People ready,[inaudible] experience? Okay, so here's how we're going to do it. I'm going to put the order in the chat. So, whoever goes first... Oh, hold on a second. I'm going to let Tibi in before we start and then I'm going to just let her know where we are.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're right in the middle of something right now and so what I'd like to suggest is you will see what people are doing and then you can try to pull it together for yourself also, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's okay. That's okay. So what you might want to do is just watch and see what people are doing and... but, before we do that I'm going to ask you to tell people who you are, what part of Boston you're connected with, and then I want you to say something about... check-in on one of these four things, how you're doing physically, emotionally, intellectually, or spiritually. Anyone, doesn't matter which one. Go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Okay. So my name is Tibisay Zea, and I live in East Boston. I've been living in Boston for the past eight years. And I feel good physically.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Good. And then what we always say at the end when we check-in is, with that I'm in. So you can repeat, with that, I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). With that, meaning, that's what you reported out. Now that you've shared how you're feeling you just say, with that I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Got you. Okay. And, we're going to start and then you will catch and you'll see what people are doing. They're actually responding to a prompt. I'll put it in the chat what people started to talk so you'll see what the prompt is and you can think about it while they are going through it, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. So anyway, as I said, I'm going to put the order in the chat. Here's what I like you to do. The first question is going to go, they're going to say what their question is, and then they're going to tell us a story about the experience that got them to that question. Before the next person goes, let's just take five seconds, 10 seconds of silence, take it in, and then the next person go, okay? I'm not going to manage that. You can manage it yourself as you go through it, okay? So here we go. Joe, you're first.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I figured out that was going to be the case. So, my question is, why is it so easy to not have a true community investment? And what brought me to that question is really thinking about how I grew up. And most of my neighborhood, the people who are renting supermarkets and everything, it was a lot of community stuff involved where I guess the economics were a little different that I see now. It's very hard to afford living in the city that I have grown up and grew fond of and everything. And I was just wondering why is it so hard for that same community investment to be put in a plan.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And I'm just going to ask you, can you say a little bit more about that, about what was that experience? What that experience was for you?

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Well, my experiences are more along the line where you can actually as a young person you can afford to live outside the parents house in the neighborhood and the neighborhood is just a lot of the communities that you guys mentioned just now and it's affordable and it was a practical thing that I believe that kept... I'm thinking about my community in particular and it kept it real tight and people were a lot more resourceful about helping each other in the community. I think that had a lot to do with the affordability and everyone really having the same goal which is to help each other navigate through a tough city. Like, Boston, even back then, and I'm talking about 80s, the 90s, it was a lot more affordable and the community was a little bit more involved with each other because there was an... and I'm talking about from the neighborhood stores to the neighborhood restaurants, everything was a little bit more invested in the community.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: So, Jasmine B. My question is, as a woman of color, how do I lead effectively to create access and opportunities for people who look like me within a community and folks who are from low income or underserved communities, is my question. And then, I guess the why-

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: The experience. Thank you. Thank you. The experience is because I'm a first generation child of immigrants who has lived the Latinx experience through the lens of the black communities' struggles here in Boston. And my own-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Can you say a little bit more about that because I think I might know what that actually meant for you as an experience, not here, but an example of how that actually played out in your life.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: Yeah, so I think for me being Latina in Massachusetts, this is my own perception and my own reality is that when I first got here there weren't a lot of Latina representation in Boston in terms of elected officials, in terms of leadership roles. So, I think for me I gravitated towards what I identify as a black Latina and the black community and the struggle here. So I've had to have my own identity but then also cross from my identity and my own struggles to a similar community which is a black community here in Boston and join forces, for lack of better words, in the struggle as two voices, a Latina and also a child of immigrants but also as a person who's been looked at as Latino black or white, right? So looked at within that perspective as a female of color, if that make sense.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: And that's why my question is so important to me because, as a woman of color, how do I create that access and that opportunity for others that are within that spectrum light of Latina, black, afro, light skin, dark skin, a whole lot of it?

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: Okay. So, my question is, how will I be heard and considered relevant in city decisions that impact my neighborhood? And I came to that question because I have been in community meetings, and this is my experience, where what is being said in the meeting on behalf of developers or for developers is that our voice actually doesn't count. They're going to do what they want to do anyway in the neighborhood. And so how do I change that in my little corner of the world in Dorchester?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Right. I always try to get people to elaborate a little bit more. Can you actually bring to life one of those experiences?

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: Sure. So I was in a community meeting and as a community leader I let the neighbors speak first and then the answer everybody danced around, which I already knew what the answer was, but I asked the developer outright, "So you don't really care what we really think or feel or want for our neighborhood. You're going to do what you want to do." And he blatantly said in front of city officials, O&S, "Yes, we already made this deal. We're going to go forward anyway." As blatant as that. I said, "So why bother coming to our meeting? What was the purpose?" So how do I make sure that our voices are being heard or my voice? I didn't like the development either so it didn't really matter. It was a monstrosity of a building that didn't even match the neighborhood. So yeah. That was about two months ago.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: My question is. How do I, right, because I consider myself a leader and an advocate for youth in general, how do I in able to lead and bring more youth to the table where major decisions that are being made that impact their day to day lives are being made, but unfortunately they're not present? So adults that are not in their position or have most likely not walked through their path of life are making these decisions for them.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: The reason why I arrive at this question is because from an early stage in life I have always been involved in the education space, right? Working for the superintendent or working for the mayor's office or just doing work that surrounded me with, let's consider them the big shots. People who are making these decisions each and every single day, but, they don't hear from the youth, right, and the youth just know when the decisions are made and they are already implemented? They don't get a, hey, we're working on this. Hey, what is your opinion?

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: So, in a little bit of detail from me more in an example to elaborate is, I was appointed by the mayor to serve on the search committee for the superintendent of Boston Public Schools. That was something that a lot of people within our governmental stand were not proud of. They didn't want to talk and they didn't want to see it happen. But I find this so fundamentally important and I think I made a stand and I left a mark that a lot of people now think of it as something that we need, right? So now it's a staple. Now we want to make it a staple that each time we made these certain decisions we have students there, because adults were finally able to see the importance of having a youth voice in these major decision meetings at these hiring places, because at the end of the day we're hiring those people to serve the youth and we're hiring them to buy them either a better education or a better lifestyle, because at the end of the day they are the ones who are getting affected by these decisions. So yeah.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: So I had several questions and in the end I morphed it into one and it's a simple question. Is there a place in Boston for me in the near future and people like me, black and brown folks? And it's a twofold question. One, can I afford to live here? Somebody alluded to it. I think Joe. I am originally from New York City. So the why, for the question is, can I afford to live here? I'm originally from New York City. I left New York for other reasons, for work reasons. But New York, is the most expensive city in the country to rent. I can't afford there anymore. Now Boston is the third most expensive place to rent in the country. I'm not even talking about owning. Can I even afford to rent here?

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: I started a small business and it seems to me for black and brown businesses in Boston it's hard to just get off the ground, let alone succeed. And I live in Hyde Park now I mentioned for the last year and a half, but I used to live in East Boston and I loved East Boston. But why did I leave East Boston? Because a developer bought my unit and they kicked us all out. So I couldn't afford to stay in East Boston. Hyde Park is one of the few neighborhoods that I can still somewhat... most black and brown people can afford, but I'm not sure that's going to last that much longer.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: So, how can I afford to stay in Boston? I don't know. It's not just owning, forget about owning, but renting. And, can I have a successful business here, because it seems to be, at least in my field, it seems to me that people treat black and brown businesses different than the white businesses. They quickly know they have to pay a white business or a white person in that business, but for a black and brown, they wonder is it really cheap or a free service. And it's a challenge and it's very frustrating, because I have probably developed a strong network in my time in Boston and a lot of people want to tap into that network, but they don't want to pay. So it's been a... especially in my field, which is sometimes political when it comes to candidates. So that's why I mentioned earlier why I was frustrated with a lot of the candidates in the beginning. So yeah, is there a place for me and for black and brown folks like me for just people want to live here or small business owners who want to succeed here?

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: Okay. I guess I'll go next. I think my question is similar to Doug's, and it's also a compound question, but I think it's from the perspective of the city which is, is it truly possible for Boston to make space for everyone that wants to be here? If not, what's the best that we should expect from a city like Boston to try to make space for everybody to be here, and how should a city take care of people that are going to be excluded, because we're seeing that happen?

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: I think this question is rooted in... So I'm not from Boston as you all can maybe tell from my accent. I'm from the D.C. area. And so I'm a transplant. And like many others in the city, the city has a lot of transplants, and I think it's been a weird experience to just be viewed as a black [juge fier] after coming from a place where I belonged, where I had community and into a city where I don't really have that outside of other transplant circles. And I think it's just recognizing there's going to be a gap between people like me and people that have been here and that are fighting to stay here, and this motivates a lot of what I want to eventually do in my career as well, which is focusing on community development.

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: So yeah, I think the main experience is coming to a city as a transplant, recognizing there's a lot of shared struggle and oppression that I do have with people that look like me, but there's also a really big gap in the experiences between transplants like me and people who have been here and want to stay here and just no longer can afford to.

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: So, I want to know, what's actually possible. Not aspirational, equity language, and campaign promises, but what is actually possible, and how should people set their expectations given what's possible and what's not possible? So that's me.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: All right. My question is... First, everybody, you guys had great questions. I appreciate you guys sharing. My question is, what is the city going to do intentionally and strategically do to address the racist reputation that it has?

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: And, where I get that from is there are few folks on the phone that mentioned that they're transplants, that came from somewhere else and now they're living here. I feel the city would have a whole lot more folks that will be transplants if the reputation of the city wasn't what it is. We have comedians that are internationally known making racist Boston jokes, and the audience gets it. They get it. And it's like, and for me I live here. I won't say I've never had a racist experience in my entire life here, I definitely have, but I haven't had it for the degree that I feel the reputation Boston has. I haven't had racist experiences to that degree, and I'm not saying they haven't happened for other people who may live here, but I haven't had those experience. And so I do make space for folks who may have though.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: But I travel a lot and I hear it often like, "Oh, you from Boston." I actually had some people ask me, "Are there black people in Boston?" This was many years ago, but it was like, wow! And in fact it was a person from, it was either South Dakota or North Dakota. And I'm like, "How are you going to ask me a question like that when you're from North Dakota or South Dakota. Aren't there black people there?" So, as ignorant as that may sound, but my point being is, I travel a lot and I often hear folks who have issue with Boston and some [inaudible] that question around me once we get past the sports is usually going to be around some form of the racist question that they're going to ask me, like my experience with racism in living in Boston, and makes me feel like Massachusetts is the furthest northern confederate state of some sort. So, that's my question. What are we going to do as a city to address that racist reputation that we have nationally?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you, Davo. Tibi, I don't know if you feel you have a question and an experience you want to contribute or if you just want to listen in for the rest?

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: I can relate to many of the questions I've heard here. But I'll ask one specifically related to immigrants because I'm an immigrant myself. I'm the first person in my family that immigrated from Venezuela eight years ago. And people talk about Latinos, but it's very-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, Tibi, I'm going to interrupt you for a minute. And I'm really rude, I'm sorry, because what you're saying is really important. But I want to hear that question first.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: And I'm a journalist and I've struggled for so many years to get a job in the broadcast industry, which I love, because I have an accent. So, [A Taurus] producers they have told me, "Hey, you are a great reporter, you are a great journalist, but you have a thick accent. So you made it better off as a producer or as writer." So I was so frustrated, I signed up for accent correction lessons and I practice radio scripts in front of the mirror, and finally I was able to record my first radio piece last year when I started collaborating with a radio station in Boston. But, in trying to find a full-time job as a journalist in English media, it has been a real struggle for me. And I know journalism is a very competitive job. But I wonder, how many people who are great professionals who come here expecting to have a better chance because their countries are so bad that they can't live there anymore and they come here and they just can't get a chance because they have an accent. So that's my question.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you all for those questions and for really letting us know what really motivate those in your own experience.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So I want to move to the second part of this and the second part is a little more free flowing. And you've heard everybody's questions. You heard their experience and what I want you to do is just find someone whose question you really resonated with... And it can resonate in two different ways. It can resonate like, I got that, I hear, and let me tell you about my experiences with that, or it can resonate in that, I struggle with that, but I don't see it the same way. But there's a connection. There's something you have in relationship to either the question or the experience that someone shared.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And so I'm not going to put an order in, but what I'm going to ask you to do, whoever feels the spirit and the connection to someone, to just start, and be mindful also of there's seven other people here who want to talk too. But, again, we're always trying to stay connected in the experiences and what our experiences are that actually make our connection to another person actually there. So, with that I'm just going to be quiet.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: I guess I'll start. I would say that what Elvis said really resonated with me. I work with 18 and 24 year olds and I think there's a serious misstep to develop any kind of programming at all without having that youth voice at the table. It's a serious misstep.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: As an example, this group on the phone seems very, very intelligent. I'm sure we can develop a program hypothetically for elderly Haitian women. I think that the brainpower's there at this table right now on this call. But I think if we were developing programming for elderly Haitian women I think we should probably invite some elderly Haitian women to be a part of the conversation. And I'm sure everybody would agree with that and it's the same thing with youth. And, in fact, for any kind of programming we should definitely have the population that you're going to be serving be a part of the program. So, Elvis, I think you put that very, very well. You spoke eloquently and I'm glad that they do have your voice at that table in regards to who the new superintendent might be.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: I'll go next. I guess technically I don't have an accent although some people will disagree with me and say I do have an accent. But, mine is more of a region, I guess, New York original native accent. But I've resonated with what Tebi said because, not only does my mother who's from Columbia have an accent and I know for many years she was looked down upon or not treated equally because, even though she was good at her job, she had a thick accent.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: But why I related it to you is because I have a really good friend here in Boston who is a lawyer who's worked at the State House, who's one of the smartest people I know, but has had a tough time advancing his career, because his from Puerto Rico, and he has a thick accent. And it's been frustrating just to see that because I know how much he has to offer. But because all these years he's been frustrated and probably will move one day from Boston just because he feels he doesn't get a fair shake in Boston. So, even though I personally may have an accent, obviously it's not the same thing, Tibi, so I'm not trying to... but, I can relate it just based on from what my mother went through and what my really good friend who lives in Boston is currently going through whose an attorney and really smart guy. So, thank you.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: I guess I'll go since we're talking about accents. I guess I have an accent. And Spanish is my first language, and I grew up down south. And, Somala, when you said, "I may have an accent from D.C.," I didn't hear that accent. So it's interesting that you perceived it, but I didn't hear it. I was like, oh, she's from Boston. And then [Zintze], I understand[foreign] your feeling, because when I first got here to Boston people would correct my English. I would say, "It's in the table." [foreign], right? But it's on the table. So I'm like, "What do you mean it's on the table? No, it's in the table." And, because I think in Spanish and I translate so everybody would help me speak proper English, whatever, right? But to me I'm like, that is proper English. That's how we translate our English. And that resonates with me.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: And I think also, Elvis, I'm a huge youth advocate, and I think what I've seen in the City of Boston the last 25 years that I've been here is that there's a generational mentoring gap, and for me my question was about creating access and opportunities, and if we don't move from our seats and bring in the next generation, and how do we continue to multiply or create spaces for other people to lead. So I definitely appreciate the youth voice and I'm glad that you're here and I love what you said, "The adults," right? It's interesting that you even call those adults because you're an adult, right, but it's like it was... I appreciate you in that sense of bringing that to the space, so...

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I think no one else mind so I think I have to say, Doug, I definitely connect with Doug's question. I not too long ago came from a community where it was natural for the network to be supportive to one another's... economically, socially you can really flow. And I definitely am familiar with how things run in Boston because, I don't know if this has changed, but I read some stuff where there's maybe one to 2% of the business opportunities given from the government, the same place that we all pay the same taxes to, is for black and brown people. And I'm like, wow, that's interesting. So, I'm not familiar with that. I am familiar with that especially from Boston, but, I have seen other examples of it being a little different and I feel there's definitely some space for that.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Davo, I also can identify with what you were talking about as far as Boston having that rep. It's like to me I think a lot of it's done out of really convenience. Boston can be labeled as a racist place, but, travel a little through U.S. and you'll see a lot of similarities. And just look at the neighborhoods and how they're made up in a lot of the cities in the U.S. Not to say that I'm in any way trying to defend any of the folk that's in Boston as far as racist reputation goes, but I definitely feel there's a lot of similarities in a lot of the cities that are not too far from here in how things are operated. So, I definitely identify with both you all on that.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: Out of curiosity, by a show of I guess hands, how many people are transplants to Boston? Okay. So Joe and Davo are the only real Bostonians.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: I guess I'll go. I want to piggyback on what Jasmine mentioned that she said. It's hard coming from a third world country to the United States. You see all these lavish things, oh my God. And then eventually you start going to school and you start meeting new people and then you notice that a lot of those people don't speak the same language that you speak. So you find yourself in these places that at the beginning middle school was tough because, you were that kid who got bullied on because you didn't speak the language. But, because they don't know that in the Hispanic culture bullying people is a norm. So I already came with a tough skin. It didn't affect me at all. But, at the end of the day, it was very hard to make friends, to speak to other people because there was that language barrier, right? And even to this day I feel that in a lot of places I code-switch my English, right? The same way that I'm speaking to everyone in this meeting is not the same way that I'm going to speak to friends outside, right?

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: But I feel that also I am very proud from where I came from. I'm very proud to be Dominican. And I'm very proud that I'm bilingual, right? It's very funny to me how a lot of people see it as, "Hey, I wish this could be my first language." And I'm like, "No, I love that I can speak Spanish." And having that two language in the back pocket it's ideal because then when people think that you're from Cape Verde, which I get that I'm Cape Verding a lot. I don't see it, but, other people do. And they start talking behind you in Spanish, then you're like, neh, I know everything that you're saying, but it's okay. So, that resonated with me just a little bit. So, yeah.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Okay. Yes, I'll go. I related to what Jasmine said, as a woman of color how can we access leadership opportunities to advance our careers? We have so many things that play against us, but at the same time we are important, so...

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: And also, I'm very concerned about the housing issue that Doug mentioned. I think that's the number issue in the city. People are moving away, so who's going to stay in Boston? We talk about diversity, but how diverse is Boston going to be in the future if people are forced to move out?

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: I'll go really quick. All right, Lina, do you want to go? All right. Well actually I wanted to lift up what you said about the dynamics that I think make housing such a problem here, which is that, I mean, there's population change. Lots of people coming in. People making more money, et cetera. But there's also this dynamic between... I think that you called out in your story, Lina, just about how a lot of decisions are made before people are even brought to the table. And I think that's a big challenge and a big problem. And especially when you do have a city where the former mayor proclaimed to build 70,000 new units of housing by 2030. A lot of it supposed to be affordable and yet you still have instances like what Lina just described, right, that still happens where developers can do their thing without really having to reckon with the community? So yeah, I just wanted to lift that up. But that's a problem that I also see that I'm interested in understanding more deeply and interested in learning about how we might change that. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: And I think also, Joe, what you said at the very beginning just about... you said, "Why is it so hard for a community investment to take place in the communities that maybe need it most?" And that's just a question that I myself still have. How is it possible to do that in a way that ensures that people can stay where they are? Yeah, I just wanted to lift those two things up and say that I relate to them and that I'm also interested in figuring out how to solve them.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: I was just going to say that I resonate maybe with pretty much everything everybody said. As I was listening to everybody, I always asked the question of whoever's coming into my neighborhood, whether it's my neighborhood or my neighboring neighborhood, "What are you going to do for us in our neighborhood? How are you going to treat our neighborhood if I decide to let you in to my network of people to talk to them to figure out what they want? What is the end result? How are you going to represent us statistically? How are you going to talk about us in a way that highlights and celebrates all of our diversity?" Which you were talking about Somala, which is something that I always talk about.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: And then, the other thing that we, well, I always think about is that the leadership comes in different forms and this is something that Jasmine said, and why is it that people are always looking for leadership to look a certain way? Leadership looks so different with so many different people in our neighborhoods. I often wonder about the youth in our neighborhood, everybody's looking for the shiny, bright youth in our neighborhood. What about the youth that are struggling? They could be shiny and bright too. Invest in them, which is something somebody else said. I'm sorry my memory's a little [inaudible]. But, why do we have to pick and choose who we speak to, and why do we need gatekeepers to protect our neighborhood and our neighbors? Why do we need to protect them? So, all this is all about the way City and institutions have treated our neighborhoods and the people that live here.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: I know that I raised two Afro-Latinas and they struggle so hard in the paths that they've chosen. One in trauma, following my footsteps, and the other one decided, she's at school, "Everybody I'm just going into the Military." So it was a little shock. But she went into the Military where you don't see too many Latinas in the field that she's in. She's in chemicals. So, I struggle and fight with different institutions and different people for them to understand that our neighborhoods are worth fighting for and that we need to fight, not with each other, but to empower each other, which is something that you all have said in different ways.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: So I'm just all over the place because I agree with everything everybody said. And I have an accent but you only hear it when I'm angry and you only hear the southern part. You don't really hear the Puerto Rican side until I'm really, really upset. So [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I want to thank you all for actually jumping in here. Everybody's talking about how tired and disillusioned it is [inaudible] but people really brought their energy into the conversation [inaudible] and I really appreciate that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I want to do three things before we sign out. One is I'm going to go around and ask you with any last thoughts you have about this conversation about what you've heard that you want to share with everyone. Then I'm going to drop a link in the chat and I would like for you to just take three minutes to go to that link and answer the questions that are there. Four of them are things we really need from you. The other four are optional, up to you. And then after you've done that I want to just give you one more piece of information and then we will call it a night, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, as usual my wife has put the order in the chat for closing comments before we step into the administrative piece.

nodes.speaker: Davo
nodes.words: Closing comments. I want to thank everybody for sharing. Really interesting to hear those perspectives and give me opportunity to think about how you're spilling and why you're spilling that way and try and walk in your shoes a little bit. So again, thank you everybody for sharing. It was an interesting experience. You don't always get to have these kinds of conversations or get a moment to reflect on some of these things. So I appreciate the opportunity. And with that, I'm all out.

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: I want to echo Davo and say thank you all for just sharing your experiences. It's just nice to interact with a different set of people who are all navigating the City differently. And although we have these questions and it sounds like a lot of frustration, it also sounds like there's just a lot of people just within this room that are committed to building a better city themselves. And so, I'm going to walk away just thinking a little bit more about what every day empowerment looks like. Not just the traditional gatekeepers and not just the shiny flashy people, empower, but what it looks like just amongst normal people like us. So thank you all.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Well, I came into this meeting a little bit tired just like Susan mentioned. And I'm going to leave this meeting very excited and very pleased with the fact that there are still people fighting for a better Boston. Because sometimes you go into these meetings, right, and yeah people do speak and people do say, hey, we're going to do this, we want to do that, but nothing happens. So you start thinking, it's just not going to work. But, we are all passionate about it. We all want to see a better Boston and we're all willing to do the groundwork that nobody else wants to do to get it there. So, I'm very happy to be part of a group of people that are actually eager to do the work and are willing to do it.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: And I just want to appreciate everyone for sharing their thoughts, sharing your experiences. It's like when you go to Hawaii and you get a smell of different air, right, it's not the same overwhelming, same thing each and every single day? So I just want to appreciate everyone for letting me into the space and sharing their personal ideas and opinions. So thank you.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: And that's on me. I had a very enjoyable conversation with you all. I think the most important part is hearing that there is a theme that we all are connected to and I'm wanting to make sure that if I'm wrong about that theme that I get straighten out and that. But if I'm correct with that theme that I get some support. But I'm thinking, we all have agreed that we will be here and we've decided that we're going to try and make an imprint somehow in a productive way to combat some of the things that will make Boston a better place.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: One of the things that I want to definitely say because I don't want anyone who's... only me and David has been here, but I don't want anyone who hasn't, as far as being an original Bostonian, don't ever think that racism isn't rampant here. We're just saying that... It made me think about maybe we've learned how to navigate it in a certain way and I'm going to put a little bit more thought into that because it is and it's present. But I also want to just say that in my travels I've seen it present in a lot of other places as well. No one is the champion of it. We're just champions of sports. We have some of the other stuff taken care of too. But I definitely feel all the people who have moved here, don't get it twisted, it's really... and you'll see it too, it's a very sterile, very clean form of racism, but I feel maybe-

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Very subtle here. Very clean. Yeah, very sterile way to do it. But I also feel the theme that we've all mentioned in this conversation will help at least pushback on that in a very deliberate and intentional way. And I'm out.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: This is definitely a, thank you. I don't know who invited you all or how you guys got here, but thank you. It's an easy, confidential, comfortable conversation when you don't know each other, and we all come from different places, and it feels good to just be able to talk, and be real, and have real talk for a better Boston. And I think, I'm a transplant, I got an accent, I'm a child of immigrants, and I love Boston, and I want to continue to create access and opportunities for more people to just be at the table.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: And, Lina, I love what you said in the beginning about you giving space at community meetings for the neighbors to talk, and I love that you said, oh, we may not hear your Puerto Rican accent. I felt it through the screen early, right? So it's, continue to bring that boricua in you to those meetings again for developers and speak your piece. So, I just want to say thank you. It's been great and this is for Doug because he's from New York says, go Red Sox. Well, with that I'm out.

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: Oh, sorry. This has been good. It's nice to be in a room with different people who want the same thing, who hope for the same thing regardless of being transplants or not. And while I don't know most of you, I do know you Jasmine. Years and years ago. Years and years ago. We have someone in common. So this has been really good. It's nice to hear everybody's perspective and know that you're not alone in doing the work that we're doing. And with that I'm out.

nodes.speaker: Jasmine
nodes.words: I'll just say, Lina, yes, absolutely. It's okay, we can scratch that off from the thing. But, I know you've been fighting for years and it's really good to see.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: Yeah, it was great to hear everyone's perspective and where they're coming from, although sadly none of it surprises me. Everything that I've heard here I've heard before. Elvis, keep doing your thing. It wasn't that long ago that I was a youth leader trying to push new voices and before you know it, you'll be my age. So, time flies. But keep doing your thing. We definitely need youth voices at the table.

nodes.speaker: Doug
nodes.words: And as far as Boston being a racist city, I guess, every city is racist. New York definitely has its racism, without a doubt, [inaudible]. I think because Boston is almost like a big town and some people who grew up here get defensive about it and I think that pushes the narrative especially when some players are free to come here and experience racism and people get defensive. But, no doubt what Joe said, racism is everywhere. Even though I'm a transplant, I first came to Boston when I was really young, and one of my first experience of Boston was the whole Charles Stuart case, and I think that's another reason why, in addition to Boston, the Charles Stuart case, it created this whole I guess stereotype of Boston being a racist city. But, don't get too defensive, Joe and Davo. But, with that, I'm out. Go Yankees.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Well, thank you very much for admitting me into the group even though I was late. I'm very sorry about that. But thanks for sharing your thoughts on how to make Boston a better place. It's amazing how a group of people that you don't know or you barely know get inspired to talk about our frustrations. And after listening to a few of you I instantly felt the confidence to talk about what I consider is very intimate to me. So, that was therapeutic I believe. Yeah. So, with that, I'm out.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you all so much. So before you really go out, I'm going to drop this link in. Can you just take a few minutes right now and, on second, click on that and fill it out. It won't take you more than two minutes, if that, and then when you're done just throw up your phone, let me know, and then I will say one more thing.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Or in other words, want to use your real name we'll connect it to your other ones. And this is so we can actually get access to these conversations afterwards.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Well, you need to add that for sure. Do me a favor, put it under, you know where it says phone number?

nodes.speaker: Somala
nodes.words: Oh yeah, Hyde Park, it looks like it's combined with Fenway-Kenmore, Hyde Park. I guess that got to be a typo-

nodes.speaker: Lina
nodes.words: Please refer, where it says race, it says, "please check all that apply," but you can only check one. What race to identify with, please check all that apply, but you can only check one.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yes, please. For this one. Just so we can get the connection back to the conversation. Do me a favor, where it says name and facilitator, if you want to put in your neighborhood, just put Ceasar and then, in parenthesis, put your neighborhood and then I can grab it from there and put it in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Everybody done? One done, two done, three done, four done, five done, six done. Joe, are you done? Seven done. Okay. Everyone, I want to say thank you so much for participating in this. I'm going to get you out of here in the next two minutes.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Just a couple of things about what happens next. We've got 20 that's going to get uploaded into that LVN site and I will send you an email when it's there so that you can go look at the conversation if you want to.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Second thing is, we'll keep you up to date about what we're doing with this because we're actually going to build a public view into our org that's going on. And, if you got invited here by someone or if you want to know more reach out to them.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: If you're interested in actually just doing one more session and you're learning this facilitation process and then want to do it with two people in the community or friends, let us know and we will set you up and make that happen. And if you say you want to be a facilitator we do... pay a couple of 100 bucks to take you through an hour and a half training and then a 100 bucks for every conversation you actually do. So, thank you all so much for participating and being part of this. It was really great for me to [inaudible] to have sat in and heard you and your conversations. And take care.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: ... growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to, knowing it will matter. I'm going to begin recording our conversation, and I need to share four important items of information with you before we do introductions. First is the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate, which to me means just to get it going, more constructive listening across divides. Neighborhood, political, and cultural. And provide improved visibility and [inaudible] in neighborhoods throughout the city. So for example, I like to use this example.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: If you guys are doing something up here, like the Homework Club I saw on the wall that's working, we want to be able to talk about that either today or another time when we come back. And then, this is my prayer that somebody else who's looking to do a Homework Club or some after-school program, they could look on the website and type in after-school programs, and your program would pop up. That's my focus, that's why I got involved with this. To this end, we're inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your questions or positions on the upcoming election or specific candidate.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So we're not here to talk about whether this one will make a good Mayor. We're here to talk about what's your lived experience? What are you going through that you want whoever is the next Mayor to deal with? And we're doing this to help build connections and build conversations that improve our understanding of one another. Like I said, somebody in Brighton might hear a conversation in Franklin Field that makes them think, "You know what? We need to reopen our after-school program too." Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording of this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Following our meeting today, the audio recording will become part of a collection of conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with members of the Real Talk for Change Team and others who have participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network, LVN. "LVN..." I'm sorry to read you all this stuff, but it's the only way through it. "It's a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by the non-profit organization, Cortico."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: This is important because later on, in a couple of days, I'll come back to Joe and say, "Oh, we got to get them a username and a password. They can go on the website and hear what [inaudible]. So this system creates both the audio as well as a written transcript, like a court case, of what we say tonight. And when I say we, I really mean you, because my job and Joe's job is just to guide this. This is all about you as residents. But tonight, Joe's going to talk too, if he wants too.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Let's see. "What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and keep the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that will improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: I can tell you that in my training, I was with a group of people from Madison, Wisconsin. I don't know anybody who lives in Madison. But now, I feel a little bit more connected because of what they were talking about. "If you understand and agree to this, please say I agree."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: "Thirdly, before we wrap up, we will share with you a handout to fill in your name and email address so that we can..." We aren't sending you. We are giving you a gift card. We have also included a section with just some information, like what neighborhood do you come from, and how you identify age group wise. I know we're all teenagers, but if you just check off the little box that says what range you're in. That's just so that we make sure... If they say to me in two weeks from now, "Hold on a second, you and Joe, you're only talking to 30-year olds. Go find some..." So that's the only reason. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable with. "Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation. And to support these goals, we will introduce a few guidelines to the conversation."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
