nodes.words: You know what would be good moving forward is if I had this stuff written out where I could point to it. I just thought of that. You know when you were in the training [crosstalk]?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Okay. I'll work on that over the weekend. I'll get Ron Bill. He's got the money, not me. Yes, I said it. Provide the newsprint, and we'll put it up because we're going to be doing this. Joe's got an ambitious plan to do this several times.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So, here is what we would put on the newsprint or the computer screen if I knew what I was doing. "Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking, and take turns. Stay curious, and ask honest questions. Pause, take time for reflection." In other words, you know how sometimes somebody drops something like it's hot, and the group just moves on? We promise not to do that. We are going to give a moment for that to sink in, if somebody talks about some heavy topic.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: "When possible, on your phone or..." Well this is actually if we were doing Zoom, we ask people to close unnecessary programs. They should have taken this out of here because we are in person. "If you need to take a moment or a break, would you let me or Joe know, if you got to leave the room for a minute? Everybody okay with this?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Three hours. Ah, joking. We say 75 minutes, an hour and 15 minutes. All right. From the time it starts tho.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: We are going to start in a minute. Now, to begin with... we're starting right now. "We want to do a quick round of introductions and check-in. Please share your first name and where you live. And then, let us know how you are using... we call it the PIES, P-I-E-S check-in. This means, saying how you feel to check-in using one of these. Physically, in your body, how do you feel? Intellectually, what are you thinking about? Or emotionally, how you feeling? Or spiritually, which is however you choose to define it. We used to say you could do all four of them, but this lady already asked how long we going to be here.

nodes.speaker: Residents
nodes.words: [crosstalk] No, she called me and told me if I could [inaudible], and I said, "sure, no problem" but I came from the hospital. I was supposed to bring my brother some medicine, that's why I was asking but...

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So, I'm going to give you an example... or I might ask Joe, cause we did this the other day. If you were to check-in physically, emotionally, or spiritually, Joe, what would you say?

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I would say, "physically, I feel fantastic today. It's been a really easy day today, Friday, camp just ended, and delivery just ended. So, me and Karine actually had a day off yesterday. So physically, also, I'd say great."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: All right. And then, what we do when we finish? We have a special way of passing it on. We say, " and with that, I'm in."

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: And would you like to check-in physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually? Excuse me. I'm not sick, it's the water going down.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: Well, I'm fine like I said. Physical, I'm fine. I work with kids, so I'm out of the [inaudible]. So, I started my weekend too, so we're doing good. Just doing the enrollment and doing everything else, like checking for orientation. So I feel just fine, because it's Friday.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: You had a nice day. Are you feeling good in your heart? Is it emotionally, you're doing good, feeling-wise or physically?

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: My name is Gladys Tavaski. I lived here for more than 15 years. Happy to be here, I came from plane. [inaudible], and now I live here. But physically, I'm great, I feel very good. Emotionally everybody has problems, if it's not one thing it's another, but with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: My name is Carmen and I'm from Dorchester. Physically, I'm fine and sad at the same time, because I love coming to work in the morning, and now I'm going to miss it. I'm going to miss my people, giving them food in the morning. It was fun on the site, working with the people and I'm going to miss them.I feel sad.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Just for a minute I wanted to sit with that because that was one of those moments that said, "Sometimes we're going to say something that is a little heavy and Carmen is one of those people. I only met her one time before. Her heart was so into it. I could see it. And I went home and I told people that work in the food pantry... you need somebody like that in every community where their heart is really in it, you could see it.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: She knew, her and Sheilah, they could tell you where... you already know. Oh, this house to six people, they have this age and this... and I put extra because the visits on this dam home. How do you remember all that? It's like the [crosstalk] remembering all the numbers without no paper, no pen.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So now that we know who is here. Of course you guys have a wonderful relationship. I can tell from a distance, right? Lets get to the core of the conversation. This usually takes about 15-20 minutes. I think it's important to share that part, but thank god it's right there, 15-20 minutes. Guys, we get through this pandemic... although now it seems like it's tightening up again. It will be easy for us from what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston. Like you Carmen with the food, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I invite you to think, what is your question, family, not a comment. The first thing is a question about the future of Boston and your place in that future. And I'm going to wait a minute, cause again, it's hard for me. I started off with a comment and the person training me said, "no Zakiya, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?" And we don't have to go in any order. If you feel like you're ready just...

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I'll go. My name is Joseph. I think the future of Boston is in trouble. I say that because we keep having elections for Mayor, Governor, City Officials, Senates, State House, whatever. And as we go along, nothing was ever done about the guns in the streets.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Yeah. I want to know what the next Mayor... cause we've had four that I've just been with, and I want to know what the next Mayor is going to do, to stop the gun violence in the city of Roxbury, Dorchester, Hyde Park, Mattapan and... I think that's it.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Yeah. I go with Joe. I want to know what the Mayor is going to do for us? What is he going to do about the housing situation? There's a lot of homeless. A lot of people ain't sheltered. And not only for people who ain't sheltered, for us too, we want to get out of this development. We want to go live good too, but affordable, [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So the question is, what is the next Mayor going to do about the housing situation? We're going to come back around, but everybody ask their question first and then we're going to talk about what in your experience lead you to ask that question. Are you ready Gladys?

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: Violence. The killing. What is he going to do about that? There's a lot of stuff going around everywhere, but you hear from here more than... somebody got shot, somebody got this, somebody got that. You talk about it, but there's nothing really done about it. So, I would like to know what he's going to do about it?

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Yeah true. Just like Gladys said about the violence, not only just in the community here, because it happens everywhere and a lot of them are young kids. And I would say that with all the young kids that are getting in there, I would think that it would be good if they get something for them to keep themselves a little occupied and all the violence out, because not only just Teen Centers, but events and activities, and stuff that they could do for the kids. That would be something good. So that maybe there won't be that much violence out there.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: I go with Carmen and Joe too. There's too much violence in here. Every time you look around, you see the news. BOP, someone got shot. BOP, someone got killed. So, what's the next Mayor going to do, cause all the Mayors promised but they don't do nothing.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: When they sit up in that chair. The only one that really did something was Thomas Menino. It's a Menino pass, nobody has come just like him.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: All right. Now, thank you. So, now lets go around in a circle one more time and each one I want you to share a story of the experience that lead to that question. What made you come up with a question around the guns?

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I've been working here for 10 years at the Community Center, and the reason why that question is so important to me is because one day I was taking the kids out. We were getting ready to get into the van. We were going to the movies, and two kids from Franklin Hill came around the corner and started shooting at two kids that were with me. And bullets went around my head, into the van. There were bullets all in the van, everywhere. For some reason, god wasn't ready for me, cause I didn't even get touched. Both those kids ran up the street. The kid that was shooting at me, he could have stopped and shot me, but he just knew I was an older person and I had nothing to do with it. And he just kept chasing them right up the street. And the police came that day and stayed to like 12 o'clock. The next day, nobody was out there. They didn't even go... the van that I was driving, I drove that van for another three years, with bullets in it. They never even took the bullets. Yeah, they never even took the bullets out of the van. So that's the reason why that question is important.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: My question was, what would they do with young kids due to all these violences? If they were to keep them, have activities or something for them to stay out of the streets. I think that there won't be that much violence.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Now what lead you to that, in your personal experience makes you think that activities for kids cuts down on the violence?

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: Due to the fact I have young kids myself. Well, now they're older, but when they were young there wasn't a lot of places. I mean the Teen Center was here. It took me awhile for them to come in. Offers that they had, and then I had to look for other places, where to get them. And there was still a lot of violence going on. Sometimes they had funding, sometimes they don't, certain things happen and they would close. And what were you going to do with your kids? Trying to get them now, I see all these kids, all riding, jumping, doing all these things. Maybe if they had something, any activity or safety place for them, you won't see like you said, the guns or any kind of violence out there. And some parents cannot really afford... something affordable for parents because some parents work but they can't afford an afterschool program.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: From a program, I wasn't able to afford it even tho I was working. To afford for a family of two or three, you would need a vulture, they would give you a vulture but it wasn't enough and it was less hours. So I had to look for places, for people, my family members, to stay with them if they were closed or something like that. That's what I say.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: Yes, Franklin Field. And the first guy I saw shot really close... There was this guy on a motorcycle and they were chasing him and in the back where I live, they shot him. My daughter she was screaming, "Mom, somebody was killed." I said, "Well call the cops." She said, "No, not me." But there's a lot of street... you can't even go outside, unless you got a look by your shoulder and stuff like that. I mean, I'd be scared of coming out of my house sometimes. But life goes on anyways. But if they could get them off the streets with all those guns and have these kids go places where they could entertain themselves.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: That's what's going on now, every time you look around there's a shooting in the air [inaudible]. It's not good. It's everywhere. It's not only here. It goes everywhere, Puerto Rico, everywhere. I got grandkids too. My girls, I use to through my girls out when they were small, but I used to tell them, right there, don't you move from there. But nowadays, parents like to through their kids outside, but they don't really be watching them.[crosstalk] And they don't know what the other kids are doing behind the mothers back.

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: Yes. My question was about the violence, the killing and all the stuff that's going on around here. What got me to the question was... I have a lot of family members. Well, the ones on the corner of Westview. Their son got killed and shot right in front of the house. To this day, nothing was done about it. The same thing that Merexane was talking about. About that guy that was on a motorcycle and drove by, and somebody shot him in front of the dumpster and he lay there for, I don't know how long, I wasn't there. I probably was, but I was sleeping. My daughter was living with me at that time because she had to live in places [inaudible] she had to stay with me for a little bit. But she said, "Mom, somebody just got shot. Somebody's on the [inaudible] just got shot." And then my brother was [inaudible] so I told her, "Call the police." And then she said, "Well, we don't live here, really? [inaudible] so what are we going to say." I said, " Well hell, you saw what happened, just tell them that somebody got shot." But I don't know, they'll probably say, "What Merexane's daughter said, not me."

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: The thing was... good that somebody called, but my daughter moved out because she said, "She's still in shock for seeing somebody get killed in front of her and my granddad." So they moved to Milton. They bought a house in Milton, but she was not happy. She got really scared and then she said, "Ma, I can't even sleep because I never saw that, somebody got shot in front of my eyes." But that's why something has to be done. And we say we both want to see action but nothing is ever done.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: My name is Carmen. I said housing. The reason why? I've been here 21 years. The same apartment and I say, "The management is not fair because I asked for cabinets." All right, they went three times to [inaudible]. No cabinets. But what do they tell you? There's no funding. But the sad part is, that you see with your own eyes when an apartment is empty, everything is installed. New refrigerator, new cabinets, new floor. So how about the people that pay their rent on time, keep their place nice and clean, and order, and you don't do much for us. I'd say[inaudible] because I would like to leave out of here and I would like to get a house. I love my community, but I have to do for myself too. I cannot stick with the community all my life. But I still give my love out to the community, but I would like to get out of here. Cause you go to my house, my floors are yellow, they're not white. You clean, it doesn't look clean cause its still stained those floors. It's so old.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: It does not [inaudible] fair to live. Especially for me, I help out the community a lot and every time you tell me something, I won't mention no names, there're no funds, there's no money. At the apartment, there's money right away. And that's not right. The thought of it, they've been living here for so long, they haven't missed a day of their rent and I don't think that's correct. And I say for the housing and those new buildings they're doing, we want to live in one of them, but, what? We can't afford it. Look at the rent. That's for high-class people, that's not for low-class people like us. Come on that's for high-class people, we don't need that. So, I want to see what the Mayor is going to do... about that situation of housing.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Now, I want us to think back to each of what you just heard, and pick one person that you want to connect what they said to how you're feeling or what you said. Because this is also about making connections. You guys are a cohesive group that meets together, but the people that's listening to us, they don't know that. So...

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: So with what Carmen was saying, I work and I've been here for two years and I want to get a house myself. And I am looking around and it's not affordable. Not even, I call them those lego house. I call them the lego house due to the fact that I go to work and they're pieces there and they're just connected. I wouldn't mind a lego house but when I look at that corner house right there [inaudible], that house was going for $598,000. Tell me who could afford that? Even tho it's Worcester area. I don't care where we're going. The only thing is, how are we going to be able to afford it? No matter whether you work, even tho they say, that they have programs for people that work, people that don't work, people with any kind of disabilities that can't afford it, but where are you going to move?

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: Not even into one of those lego houses, you're not even able too. You're not able to afford that. I don't care about living in a lego house, I might fall down, but I'll get back up and fix it your own way [crosstalk] and you could add what you want to add to it. And you could live comfortable. I mean not saying that the violence stuff is not going to happen. That's everywhere. Security, they're paying all these cops overtime and doing all this, and some of them aren't even... I called them a few times due to noise and violence, whatever. They would never come, they would never show up. I called them one time from the park over here, that we were and kids were online and I had to go to work and get up in the morning. Until 5:30 in the morning people gambling, yelling and playing, doing all this stuff. I call them four times, they never showed up. So, who's going to want to live and pay the amount of money to just live here and not get what you want.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: So, at least you want to live somewhere and could say, "Well this is my house, I don't want to do this." Maybe they'll show up because it's not the projects. That's one thing, I bet if it was somewhere where there was money, all these rich people, [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: And when you call the cops for some little minor things, here they are. I think the whole station comes, but then you can't call them on the back and they can't show up. The first thing they ask you is, "Where is it?" I said, "My [inaudible], where I'm at." And they said, "Oh, okay." Then I go to the night manager over here and tell them and he goes, "Well keep on calling the cops."[crosstalk] He told me to keep on calling the cops, but nobody wants to be calling the cops, the police, whatever they want to be called, nobody wants to call them because when you call, even tho they say its anonymous, something happens. Your name is [crosstalk]. I had to call them for the kids, they were doing the sidewalks and everything, because the kids were breaking the truck and getting in there. And for the safety of those little young ones, I called them and the first thing he goes, "Oh, okay, well thank you." And that was it. You call me, you call, and my name better not come in there because I'm not going to the police. That's for your own safety, you have all these cameras there. What good is it?

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: Yeah. Just for show. But, for the safety of the others, that's why I say for housing I would rather just go and get a place of my own, even tho it's those lego houses.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I would follow up on what Merexane said, because to see somebody get shot outside of your house like that, and I would say for anybody that's running up for office. There's not a gunshot anywhere in the city of Boston that I know about. We got guns that kids have every day, and I'm not talking about little twenty-two's, we're talking about guns that kill people. And I don't understand how you could run for office, make a video and all of them did it, Janey, the other one too, I can't think of her name right now...

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Campbell, now you can make a video on TV that you're running for office with kids every day about... Nothing in your video says nothing about all these kids that have died this year or in the last 10 years. The only thing you're going to get up there and talk about... housing is important, but a kid's life is way more important than ours. And they talk about how they're going to do all these other things and not once in any video did I see anything about violence and getting guns off the streets that would save these kids lives. Cause these kids, they're not making the guns, these guns ain't in Newton, these guns ain't in Brookline. So why so many guns in Dorchester, Roxbury, Mattapan. That's what I would say to them, what are you going to do to fix that?

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Put these guns off the street so people like me, like her, like her, like her, like her, and like her, we can walk down the street after eight o'clock at night. Once it gets dark, we all go in the house, we don't even come outside. I'm a man, and I'm not afraid but still, I have to watch every place I go. The only time I feel safe is when I'm in my backyard and I don't live in the province, I live on the street, but in my backyard, nobody sees me, they don't know what I'm doing back there. That's the only place I really feel safe, other than in the house. So its just sad that we have to go through that as... poor people, that's what I'll say, as poor people. That we don't get the consideration that everyone else gets, that shooting is natural. It's nothing.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: Yeah. I saw one day, 4:45 in the afternoon. In front of my house, I said, "I'm going to take out the dog, but something tells me, hold on." I saw a group of people. They're moving. They're trying to move somebody fresh out. And the guys pull up in the back, what do you see? A car stopped, opened four doors, POW, POW, POW, POW, POW, POW, POW. They kill one guy in front of me. I just had to close my door real quick, jump in my house and cuddle my son. I can't take this, I can't live like this. It took me a month to go to my kitchen. At the seminar club, I didn't want to go to my kitchen, because I felt that fear. And I saw the body and everything. So it was scary.

nodes.speaker: Janet
nodes.words: But its tough because they don't do nothing about it. Like I said, [inaudible]. The police shows up. They'll try to cover their selves, stay another day when the thing happened today. They'll come tomorrow. They'll sit for another while the next day, then the... you won't see them no more. So, it's not safe. When we're walking around here, we have to have four eyes, cause you don't know when a bullets coming. A bullet that don't have their names. So, its scary. We have our[inaudible] in the front of our house. We got a big back hill. No, no, no, we prefer having it in the front, on our stairs, we put our chairs and we see something funny, [inaudible], time to go in and we go in. That's the way we have to live here, with fear, and its not fair.

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: With the thing with Merexane, the shooting out there, my daughter, my granddaughter, they moved out of here because of that. My daughter saw that... they could not believe that. They just saw somebody get shot and just left there. Anyway, she moved out, but nothing is being done with the violence. Not too long ago, I think it was last year was it Carmen that they killed the guy, what was it Puerto?

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: How many other people did they kill right there? They're just dead. They just came in, just shot at him. I'm not gonna say that he was innocent because I don't know what he was dealing with. We might say, "That people are innocent, but we don't know what's really behind them." But it's still murder. Somebody still got killed, some people got shot, and this is our neighborhood. We supposed to be not scared of being around here. Our kids live here. My kids were like... When I moved her, it was 15 years ago, my kids they weren't little, but they were enough. And they never come outside. We go outside, we sit right in the stair. Don't go nowhere, don't move from there, because even walking, some other kids are bully's to them. Other kids are coming in and will hit them or whatever. So you don't want your kids to be hurt. You don't want to be living in fear. Your parent come and said, "They don't do nothing for you." I've been here for 15 years, asking for a gate in my backyard. There's no...

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: They told me that I'm going to get it if I move in. So I said, "Okay, I'll take that if you're going to fix it later." I'm still waiting for him and they still didn't put no gate on. So if their not doing anything about comments about the apartment, what do you think they're going to do about the people?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: She talked about activities that would... I want to say distract, but engage the kids so they wouldn't get into violence. But it seemed like your kids weren't going to get into violence because of the way that you were raising them anyways. Joe's story... its random violence, right?

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: Because I remember, I'm not married, I was divorced. I've been divorced for the longest you could remember. But my ex-husband lived on Jay Creek in [inaudible] plane in the [inaudible] history. He said that one day he came out, just to come out and a guy came with a gun and shot him right on his head. He said five times the gun went off, POW POW POW, he didn't kill him, because that guy thought he was going to steal his car, right? And then when he go to put the gun to the car, he went POW and it went off on the car, but he could have killed my ex-husband, five years... he was telling me the story yesterday while he took me shopping. And he said you know what I'm so grateful that guy saved my life because that gun went off five times he shotted at Mike's forehead and that gun did not go off into the guy, then it went into the car and blew off the car windows. So, this is crazy.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: When I say random, I may not use that word, my grandkids use it so much. It's not directed at me, Zakiya, it's I walk outside and there's the violence. Joe went to take the kids to the movies or whatever you said, and you were just going to be caught up in something that had nothing to do with you.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: You guys talk about going outside. You can't have a cook out in your back. Now Franklin Field is full of empty space for park and you can't use it?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: When I came in the back, the men out there stopped talking and looked at me. And not at the age, where they start looking at me because I look like Beyonce. [crosstalk]. So my goal was to make them know that I wasn't here to get into their behavior, I'm looking for Carmen now.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So, really its time for use to wrap up. I want to thank you all for sharing your questions and experiences. We're getting finished a little earlier than these people thought, that they put this together. So I'm trying to make sure that I didn't forget anything. Do you have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share or any other general reflections on this conversation or what you hope would happen?

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I do. And they all say they're going to do this, but I doubt that they do it, is get the people from different neighborhoods together. People who run neighborhoods, people like myself and Carmen from here and someone else from Brahmin and someone else from there and there, and ask them at a round table with the Mayor, the Governor and whoever else, what's going on and how to fix it? Because when I first started working here, this place used to be packed with kids. Now people don't even let their kids come out, unless we're going to go get them, walk them back home or whatever. And I don't blame them. When I lived in Bromley, we'd go out. When we grew up in Bromley, we had our own police, it was called Bromley Patrol and there was never shooting. Never, no one was doing violence. And we had a Team Center in every house [inaudible] around the city.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Everybody did stuff together. We would bring all the developments together, that way there was never any conflict, but now they got everybody spaced out, no one likes each other, they fired all the workers. The only place that has a Senate that's open is Franklin Field and Bromley Heath and... Franklin Field and Bromley Heath that has an active running Task Force and Community Center and doing things for the people and the community. And we need that everywhere. We need the Mayor to come out here, talk to the residents and so the residents can tell them... because I don't think kids are really bad, they grow onto us. Because we got some kids in here, and they were good kids, but they started smoking dope, and now they come running across the field, they getting shot at. Those are the kids that were in here with us, and they were little kids. And now they grow up to be 14 and 15, they're only 14 and 15, they're still little kids. They have to cross the field and somebody is shooting at them. And this happened this summer.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: So I mean, it's a non-ending thing, it just keeps going and going and going and everything that we try to do is for nothing because the police used to come in here, every day. Shoot pools with the kids, they just got a new captain, he just got fired. They got a new captain, he took the police out of here. We had three officers who used to come here every day, shoot pools with the kids. Now, if you notice three police officers in here, everybody is going to send their kids in here because they know its safe. And they don't even have to stay in here. They would take their car from here, go out and come back. They were always here, that type of thing. Its things like that, is what the Mayor and the Governor need to know, that needs to be in community so that we could feel safe. Or just to have a car parked there. And take his car from there, they're riding around the city doing nothing. I'm serious. I see cop cars all over the place, they're not doing anything to me, they're on their cellphones, they're out there on detail making triple money. Why do they need the detail?

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: If we are not safe, why should they be safe to be parking on the street. I'm talking about the people that are working tho.[crosstalk 00:46:29] in our neighborhood but they're not guarding us. That's just ridiculous. How could you be someone of power and you have a brain and you think, and you can't see that that's not right. You're letting the people suffer but you have a detail where an officer will make $300 to guard eight or nine guys out there doing something, half the time they aren't even guarding, they're just standing there. [crosstalk] But you can't have a cop sit out here. Come on you can't have a cop sit out here, right there in that corner, sit right there. All that drug dealing [inaudible] will be gone. Its too easy. When I first started helping there was no heroin around here, now heroin is really bad. It was nothing awhile ago.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: They transfer people [crosstalk] See its not even that, they're transferring here, they're transferring to Bromley, they transfer them everywhere. And they don't care, cause they're not doing anything. They got three housing police officers for 10,12,14 developments. One's decided, he's staying in the office all day. He goes in there at 8:00 in the morning, I see him there every day and he leaves at 4 o'clock and he takes off, every day in Bromley. And the other two, ones a white lady and a black guy, and that's it. That's the police force for housing.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: You know for us, I hope the kids come when we open the Teen Center. I hope we have plenty of kids come in. We're going to have to do good stuff with them, we're going to have to keep them off the street. See how that works Joseph, right? We're going to do our best, we got plans to do with them on break with them, got the cookies, got a new plan set to do with one of my kids.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: I mean come on [crosstalk] So we got to sell sodas and chips, that's bad for our kids and we know it, but that's the only way we want to get money, to try to get a pool table over here and that's just not right.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: The guy that just left didn't do anything. He played his game until he got that next step and now he's in Washington D.C. and he's getting big money and he didn't do nothing but build up the sea ports and build up houses everywhere.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: And you know something, its so sad. My job is calling people, making sure they're going to vote. When you ask the last question, honey, are you going to vote this year, there's an election this fall? They say, "No". I say, "Oh wow, what makes you feel that way." Cause I have to ask these questions. They say, "No, none of those that are running are showing anything good for ourselves." I see my family still in the same position since they came back. No Mayor has done nothing. And that's sad to hear from the community and resident, its very sad, that's the way they're feeling and I don't blame them. But then I have to go and say please think about it, try to vote because each vote counts. Its important, if you don't vote, nobody's going to hear your voices. So make sure you think about [inaudible] and read about each one of them, then you got question number one. Okay and there's another one people say, "What is it?" Look into it, this is going to come in the ballot, so you need to know about that question number one.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Yes I have to tell them about what the [inaudible] is all about. It's about the power to keep the budget into the hands of the community, not to take the budget to somewhere else. They want to keep it into the hands of the community and the people that vote number one on that, the budget is going to go to somewhere else. Okay, so that's question number one, please all of y'all make sure question number one is yes.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: And tell the politicians stop giving all our money to these creatures, because the creatures are not giving anything to the community. [crosstalk] They're riding nice cars, they're getting [crosstalk], they're getting 10% every Sunday and they're giving back nothing to the community. I've not seen one priest or creature out here during this whole pandemic doing anything.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: We've been out here everyday giving our food for two years and not once that one of them come up and say, "Oh, can we bring something, we could give you all some fruit, anything, just to give to the community."

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: He brought [inaudible], doughnuts and a couple of sweets. Okay, then when we kept on asking, "Oh, are you going to bring..." he says, "don't ask me, if you ask me I ain't bringing you no more." So we stopped asking him.[crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: But you know something, I don't work anymore in the morning but I still got the spirit of food we're going to try multiple pantries, see if we're able to pick it up and give it out to the community. We'll see what works out, we got a lot of plans, in my mind. We'll see how, me and Joe are simple, we'll make it work. We want to do good stuff for the kids. We want to keep the kids out of the street, we want to keep them busy. We can have our movie night, we have a popcorn machine, we can make popcorn, I got cotton candy, we can keep them all busy.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: And I'm glad you guys are working well together. It's a blessing to the community, that Joseph and Carmen are working. [crosstalk] We appreciate that.[crosstalk 00:53:19]

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Those are all brand new. We just got those. They're all hooked up and they're all working. And they're spread out, six feet apart.

nodes.speaker: Maritza
nodes.words: Just the Mayor to come down here, and do what he's supposed to do. If he ain't going to do what he's supposed to do, give up the job to somebody that could do it.

nodes.speaker: Gladys
nodes.words: Yeah. If you're going to sit out there and expedite someone to vote for you, then you're going to sit in your office and just wait, and do nothing about it. What do we need you for? We need somebody who is really going to act upon what he has said. We're going to work on it, whatever he said he's going to work on, he never does it. So what's the meaning of telling us what's he going to do, if he not going to accomplish his job.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: And not just get your vote in and not doing anything about it is exactly what... At least do something and do what you say you're going to do.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: If the [crosstalk] is smart, we would gather together and vote for somebody that we know. Internet with everyone in the city and then we could put who we want in office. But we are the vote, we have the most votes, [crosstalk] has the most votes in the city. So we can do what we want to do. We just have to get together and do it. [crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Is there anybody else that has a final comment? Did we get everybody? My name is Zakiya Alakay and I was the facilitator for this conversation at Franklin Field and with that we're going to end the recording.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And I'm just going to publicly and just welcome all of you to this conversation, very important conversation and I'm so happy that you were able to join and accept my humble invitation because I think all of you know how passionate I am about community and making change and stuff and I know that that is not something that we do by ourselves but we do collectively so thank you so much because we can move mountains when we work together. So welcome to the call. I just want to say to you thank you again for responding on behalf of real talk for change. We invited you to this gathering by asking you to think of one of the most pressing questions you have for the future of the city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonian who want to speak and be listened to and know that it will matter. So I will begin recording this conversation and I need to share a few of some important information to you but for particular pieces of information before we do our introductions so I didn't forget about the introductions. So first, the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across divides, across the neighborhoods, across the political sections and across cultural sections and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates for the future mayor position and the neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience rather than from entering a conversation with your position on an upcoming election or a specific candidates.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: We are doing this to build connections and foster conversations that will improve our understanding of one another. Secondly, I want to address what happens to this recording of this conversation following this meeting today. This recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. The conversations along with all other conversations that will be taking place throughout the city will be shared with members of the real talk for change team and others who've participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network, the LVN. The LVN is a web based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by a nonprofit organization called Cortico. LVN system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to an Explorer tool. The system highlights key words that emerge across different conversations and allow users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, we are providing consent to real talk for change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voice Network whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: When the conversation is shared to whomever, I understand that it's a part of a tapestry. Whatever is shared, is the conversation the person speaking ever identified?

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: So actually, I'm just going to jump in here for just a minute. There'll be a name associated with the transcript, the conversation, however you can choose to use, it will be one name, a first name, and you can choose to use your real name or you can choose to use a pseudonym. And so at the end of the conversation, there'll be a form where you can put a pseudonym in and that it would never be connected back to you specifically. So you could choose to use the name Kathleen, you could choose to use a different name and so it doesn't actually need to be a real name.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Wonderful. Thank you so much. Okay. So third, before we wrap up, we will share with you a form to fill in your name and email address so that we can send you your gift card. We have included a section with demographic information which is optional. The reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect it on an uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable answering. And lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from each other in this conversation, and to support these goals we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So number one, speak for yourself out of your own experiences. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. Number three, share the time. Allow others to finish speaking by taking turns. Number four, stay courteous, ask honest questions. Number five, pause and take time for reflection. Number six, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Number seven when possible close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications and put your phone on silent, please. If you need to take a moment, take a break, let me know just by putting it in the chat. And if everyone's comfortable with these guidelines just respond to yes, I am.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Quick question. With regard to request in my email address, I'm a very private person and I resent when people begin after being given my email address that they feel that they can send me all kinds of information. I do not want to hear. I would like for you to repeat again why you need my email address because I do not want a whole lot of information requests, solicitations and so on to my email address from this organization. As a matter of fact right now I am irritated with all the politicians in Boston sending me unsolicited, getting on my phone and sending me messages. I'm so angry. I am so angry about that. So I do not want a whole lot. I'm very private. I only give my email address to a select few. So if there is any question that I'm going to be getting a whole lot of unwanted information in the future, please keep your gift card.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: No, and in it when you put your email, just make that clear. It's a Google form that I will put in the chat later so you can put that on right on there. But this is just for the purpose of I believe that the gift card is going to be an electronic transmission of a card.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Any other questions? Okay. For the ease of this virtual conversation, we are going to use a modified circle, a process where each person will take a turn. I'm not posting anything but it says I'm posting the order in which people are invited to respond to the chat. I'll transition from one person to the next. You can always pass or pass an ask that we come back to you. To begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check-ins. Please share your first name and where you are located right now and then let us know how you are using the PIES check-in. So PIES, is anybody familiar with that particular check-in?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So PIES is acronyms that mean we're going to be checking in either physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. So as soon as you say your name, where you are right now and you check-in in one of those four categories, in the PIES categories, then when you're done, please say, and with that I am in. Does everybody understand that process?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So we're just going to share our name, where we are located right now and then you're going to use a check-in using the PIES method. The PIES method is you're going to check in physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. So I'll model the first one so that you get it. So my name is Marilyn and I am sitting right now in Dorchester in my front room in front of my computer. I am checking in emotionally I think because I'm excited about this space and feeling both nervous but confident if that makes any sense. And with that I am in. So someone else can... Go ahead. Anybody can go next.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Carol. I am participating. I'm located in Hyde Park. I am currently on my phone just standing by my door. I would sit by my computer but I'm not sure. I keep having problems with the volume so I can hear myself speaking now. So I may try and go sit back over there. And what else am I supposed to add Marilyn?

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Oh, I'm feeling like I would like to share some comments and this real talk for things that are going on in the community. I'd to share my opinions, my thoughts and hopefully it will be shared with a broad, with further for changes.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I am Kathy, please don't call me Kathleen. And I am sitting in my computer room although I don't have a working computer in Hyde Park. And I am checking in spiritually, I'm not sure, I thought spiritually would be a broad term because right now I'm in a spiritual mode only because there was so much illness in and around me, in my family with loved ones so much and I don't know how that relates to what we're doing today. I'm not sure if when I state that I'm checking in spiritually if it should relate to what we're doing today. I don't see how we can but that's where I am presently and with that I am checking in.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Mish. I am laying in my bed because I fell asleep and just woke up before this so sorry if I'm sounding kind of distant. I am checking in physically for the reason I just said, and with that I am in.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: I guess I'll go. I am Kenya. I am checking in from Dorchester. I am checking in from my bedroom. I am checking in emotionally because I am angry. I am very angry because I recently lost my 17 year old son to gun violence in the city. I guess and with that I am in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, perfect. Thank you all so very much. Okay, now that we know who's here, let us begin the core of our conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite us to think, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'll repeat that. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? So just take a couple of minutes to reflect on that question. And if you need to, you can write down your feelings about that, and then, when everyone is finished then we'll share.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Marilyn, can you read that whole question again? I understand the second part of the question, but I just need to catch it from the beginning again.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Oh, okay. I'm so sorry. All right. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we've learned about inequality in America and Boston and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. So then the question is, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: It really is. That's why I gave you a couple of minutes for reflection. Because as stated initially, it's very easy for us to lose sight of what came out of that hope at the things that we learned about inequality and what have you. And then thinking in terms of, given what you already learned from that, and it's going away or it's supposed to be, the pandemic, but things did rise to the top for many people, for many reasons. So for the future, what is your question about the future of Boston giving all that you've experienced and what's your place in that future moving forward?

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: I'm going to pass on that one because I know I don't have a future in Boston so I don't have any questions for myself, but if I were able to answer for someone else, then that would be different.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Well then my question would be, what is going to happen to all the green space since every time you turn around, they're building something. Where will I be able to go and sit and relax and just taking the calm if every time I look around there's a new high rise and new this and new that. Are they taking into consideration the piece that we want and get from just being in nature.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Right. So this is out of a lived experience of yours that has brought that to the forefront for you.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Absolutely. Every time I turn around, the street behind mine, they want to put up 30 condo units. I was just over by Ashmont yesterday, I mean [inaudible], excuse me, yesterday and there was this spot where there was nothing for as long as I can remember when I drove by yesterday, I saw what must have been a six unit apartment spot and it took my breath away.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: So my question is, what has been done to provide city residents with a sense of safety in regards to the increase in gun violence? We are plagued. This is a daily issue. This is not just a black issue or a white issue. This is an everybody issue. What has been done to help in stopping gun violence? Where do we go? How do we get people, younger people involved and turn them away from the streets? Because if these young people are supposed to be future leaders then how are they going to lead us with violence? So I want to know what has been done.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: In the future I could definitely be an advocate. Why? Because my son was murdered. I could also be an advocate from a professional standpoint because I am a nurse and I could talk about what I have to experience as a nurse. I could talk about what I experience as a mom. I could talk about what I experience just having to live in fear.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: My question is about the mental health of young people in Boston. In many of the private schools, independent schools, whenever there is any traumatic incident taking place, either in the school or an area, very often some kind of mental health group committee is provided for those [inaudible]. I don't know, perhaps I'm mistaken. My son did not attend Boston public schools. And I'm wondering, is there enough attention paid to the mental health of young people in Boston with regard to the violence that Kenya just mentioned, with regard to this COVID because there are a number of people in the Boston, well nationwide but of course this has affected a whole lot of people in young people in general. Very often they don't have anyone anywhere to go to express their concern, their worry, their frustration and so on.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Now, will mental health become a priority in the Boston school system in the future? Is my question. Because I think that's very, very important. And I guess now I'm thinking about the black community that mental health has always been put on the back burner, has never been seen of any importance. And I feel as though the time is now for us to prioritize that and make it across the board, make it in a way that it's accessible to all. So what's going to be done in the future to ensure that our young people have access to mental health facilities and mental health individuals that would help them to grow? Because I think in the black community, we've always been taught to to man up, to be strong, to get over it. And I don't know if enough attention has been paid, I repeat again, to that aspect of our health.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: And as far as being, excuse me, playing a part in the future with regard to that, I would be willing to be trained to facilitate something like that, whether it has to do with developing questionnaires or being on a panel discussion, whatever is required, whatever is needed, I would be willing to be called upon in order to help in any way, shape or form based on my background, my professional background.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: You know it was me, sorry. I was at the computer again. Well, my concern is with the housing. They're building all these new developments, all these condos or townhouses but they're not affordable, not affordable for the young adults that are growing up, for the millennials that are trying to get jobs and trying to start a family. The housing is just way, way, way too expensive. It's not affordable. I find that a lot of the millennials they have to move out in order to live, in order to decide, in order to have something to live someplace decent. Even the housing, just the housing in general, the rents are skyrocket, they're high. They're not affordable.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: What is going to happen about that? Pretty soon, everybody's going to be living in shelters. It's very tough, Dorchester, Mattapan, Roxbury at one time, you could afford a rent. There is nothing less than a 17, 18, $2,000. If someone's starting out, graduated from college or has a child, they can afford that. Not on a single income, sometimes maybe not even on two people's income.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Okay. All right. Great. Thank you. Thank you for sharing. So now I'm going to invite you to think about what experiences in your life got you to that question? So the question that you posed, and what experience in your life got you there. So I know for Kenya, you kind of touched on it some but did you want to, I'm just going to say you first because you gave us a whole package, but if you want to elaborate a little bit more on what experience got you to that question.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: Well, the experience that got me to that question was losing my son on January 15th of this year. Prior to losing my son, if anyone had asked me if Dorchester was a safe place, I probably would have said I felt safe because I wasn't aware of what was going on. But after losing my son, I was exposed to so many younger people and they would share with me what their world is like and I didn't know we lived in two different worlds. Their worlds are way different than our worlds and they do collide because as an adult, you could be walking down the street or simply driving your car and you could get killed and that's scary to think that you could sit on your porch and get killed on your porch like that woman that was up in Upham's Corner, she was an elderly person, I think in her 80s or something, just minding her business on her porch and she was taken, she was stolen.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: And so was my son, my son was stolen. And it's aggravating to think that we have to keep losing. We have to keep having these losses. And it seems like nobody is doing anything to help. Where are the guns coming from? Who's making them? Who's putting them on the streets? And those are the things I need to know like, where are they coming from? Because I'm pretty sure we don't have a gun manufacturer in Dorchester. We do not.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you. Anybody else want to share what experience in your life has got you to the question that you asked?

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: I'm going to say the increase in noise and rhetoric in the area. Years ago, I felt like the streets were quieter. People were considerate of their neighbors. They didn't feel the need to blast the music 1:00, 2:00 AM disturbing their neighbors. There weren't fireworks, gunshots, whatever going off all the times of the day and night. There was a certain peace about where you lived. I know this is about our own personal experience but I'm going to share mine and my neighbors because it happened at the same time. So there was a shooting on our street a couple of weeks ago and it disturbed the neighbors and so much so that my elderly neighbors are like, if anything else... Well between that shooting a sober house in the pot shop, they want to put at the top of the street.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: They're like, if anything else happens, they may have to leave. They're losing their sense of peace and serenity. So for me, it's like, well, how do you get that back? How do you maintain that so that people aren't looking to leave? Even for myself, I am so over all of the noise and everything I would like to leave. And the green space that I spoke of, it's a good park to go to where you can sit and rest or free your mind. And even if you hear kids laughing because they're being kids, it puts you at peace.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I guess I'll go next. Mental health is of great concern to me because my son he has battled it from several years following the death of his father. And if individuals aren't aware that mental health is important, they tend to overlook it and they tend to misinterpret another person's actions. And someone said to me recently that they have discovered that a whole lot of young people seem to be suffering from some aspect of mental illness, that there's a lot of depression, a lot of anxiety, a lot of young people experiencing panic attacks and so on. It has become, and these are not my words, but someone said to me recently, it has become almost epidemic now. So I believe that it's something that needs attention. And I think that even though it is right there, we're aware of it, we continue to overlook it. And of course, if you're not healthy mentally, nothing in your life works well. You aren't able to be successful in any of your goals.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: And even when you make the attempt, you fall short because if you aren't being cared for in that capacity then it's going to affect you in a number of ways. So I feel as though, I repeat again, as though in the white community, mental health is taken seriously and I don't feel as such in the black community. I don't know if... That's just my impression. That's my sense. So I feel as though it is something of great importance. Not only personally but for the success of the city because you want healthy individuals running the city. If someone isn't given the treatment and given the care that they need in their youth, they may grow up, may get through whatever they need to get through, whether it's school, whatever they need to get to a certain goal. But always there is that problem there in the background, and it is going to affect the decisions they make later on, decisions that may affect people in Boston, depending on the role they're playing.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: If they're in politics, if they're in some capacity where they're dealing with people, dealing with the masses, it's going to affect negatively adversely. So I believe mental health is something that needs, when I say attention, not just a conversation because I think we're beyond just a conversation. I think we need to get going on working on mental health as a problem, as a public health problem, especially with young people today in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Any other comments? Well, I wanted to also mention, yeah, the gun control is a concern as well. Someone had talked about it earlier. It's scary. It's scary. I'm concerned. I work-

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Perfect. Okay. So what I want to do next is think back to each of the questions and the experiences that were shared in our group and find someone's question or experience that resonates with your own life. Someone else's experience that spoke up earlier in our group that resonates with your own life. So now Carol you can go.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Yeah. I was, as I mentioned before, the guns, I work a later shift and I get home sometimes after nine o'clock and when I get home after nine o'clock, I'm concerned with nothing other than coming down from the T station. I'm glad the commuter rail is just right up the street from where I live because I take the commuter rail. I no longer take the red line or the buses. I'll get on the commuter rail, go into work, go into the office. I'm so concerned when I get out of the office because I work at the C point area which is very safe. There's always tons of people walking around. There's the long wharf and then there's the international, Intercontinental, I'm sorry, Hotel so there's always a bunch of tourists around.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: There's always transit police and police because it's the downtown area so I'm not concerned so much walking from my office when it's dark at night, ask the eight o'clock to south station. But sometimes when I arrived Blue Hill Labs Station where I get off, there's a big old long platform and a big old long ramp. So what I did was I was, because sometimes people are just sitting there. I don't know, maybe, watching trains but it's late at night, they're just sitting there guys. So what I did was I asked the engineer, I said, "Look, when you get to Blue Hill Avenue, could you possibly pull closest possible to that ramp?" And he said, "You ain't going towards the rebuilt area?" And I said, "Yes." He said, "Yeah." He said, "That's a long platform." I said, "Yes it is." And he said, "That's a long ramp." And I said, "I'm glad you know that." He said, "I never know where to stop because some people do when they exit the train, they go towards the Blue Hill Lab but I go towards Cummins Highway because I live on that side."

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: And most people it's maybe one or two people they will get off. Me and another woman or me and another guy but there's never more than two or three people that will get off at that stop. So he started pulling close as possible, going towards [inaudible] so I don't have to walk up the long platform to get to the ramp and then walk up the ramp. The ramp is so long, I don't know if anyone has ever taken the commuter rail or has entered that station, but they have benches that you could rest because it's so long.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: So lately there's been some crazy guys sitting on those benches with their mask on and stuff like and it's kind of scary too. You never know if someone's waiting there, they going to knock you upside your head or when you exit out of the station on Cummins Highway, they're doing construction up there so it's always kind of dark. The trucks and stuff are everywhere. When I'm crossing the street I'm always feeling nervous because those bike racks are in the way and then it's so dark that if you're walking across, the cars may not be able to see you and you don't know who may be they're waiting with a gun or whatever. I always think about the guys that were shot a few years ago at that barbecue. They're sitting in a car or outside of our car and then the grandmother that was just sitting on her porch and some random shooting or something like that. Where do these... I could be coming out the station and somebody may be chasing someone else out of matter Penn square and I may get shot by a stray bullet or something. I'm nervous too.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: So it's scary. I try to walk as fast as possible when I cross that street, cross over, get to my car and get home and no one should be scared that afraid.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Right. So yeah, that was Kenya's thing, the public safety and she made mention of that too with the woman sitting on the porch and being hit by a stray bullet, not the intended target but just because of the guns that are out on the street and you don't know who people are and it is a public safety issue.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Yeah. And lately they have been, I think a few, maybe last week or the week before, someone was shot in the Mattapan area and it wasn't daylight, it wasn't the early evening hours. This stuff is not happening two and three o'clock in the morning. This is stuff that's happening early enough, in between the hours of 5:00 and 9:00, 10:00, 11 o'clock and people get off work at 11 o'clock. Nurses and nurses that work double shifts or whatever. Yeah, that's a concern.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I think it was Mish that mentioned about green space. I love trees and grass. I love trees and grass. And like her, I'm very sensitive to the increase noise that we're hearing in Boston and specifically those lanes that were recently created for the bicycles, they have decreased the number of lanes that were previously there in a number of major routes. And because of that, people are much more irritated and frustrated and the honk and the phones and so on. And also too because it cuts down on the efficiency of getting from point A to point B in Boston because you're backed up now. So I think the noise level has increased due to the, I don't know who made the decision about where to decrease those lanes, but it's an annoyance and it's an irritant and it's causing a lot of noise pollution.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: So when, Mish I think you even talked about serenity and peace and whatever, it brought me to that, that we have increased the amount of noise due to people's irritation and frustration with those lanes. So I don't know if I'm doing a disservice to the people who are bicyclists. But I think that whoever made the decision could have done a better job in finding the routes that they needed to to amend with these bicycles. Some of those roads weren't built for that, and some of the residents in those areas have been complaining. One woman told me in order to get around the corner to a store that she frequented in the past, now it takes two times, three times as long to get there because now there's only one lane versus two that were available in the past. So the noise pollution for me is something. I love my trees and grass and peace so I'm speaking with regard to peace.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: In this form, can we question another person about something that they said or is it only we can only answer your questions?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: No. In fact the next piece is a combination of what you're doing right now, it says you want to speak to the person and tell them why their question or experience resonates with you and share a story from your life that connects with their experience. So sometimes yeah, that might have to be that you do ask a question. It could be a clarifying question or whatever in order to make a connection so sure.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Okay. Well I have two; one is to Ms. Kathy. I wanted to know, are you referring to American Legion Highway? Because that is blowing my mind how they decided that those-

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I'm sorry, I was on mute. I was responding to you but I was on mute. Yes. Specifically American Legion and Cummins. Those two are ridiculous.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Yes. And I'm like, who decided that and why didn't they talk to the people who actually traveled through there because they make no sense what they did and what can we do besides cutting them poles down and making them back our own self the way we want it.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: And then the other one was for Ms. Carol. I was going to say, are you comfortable carrying a flashlight with you home in the night so that you can make light for your own self so that you can see your surrounding or carry some pepper spray or something, or even a whistle. I had some class and they were saying to carry a whistle so that if we feel uncomfortable, at least the noise will startle the person who startling you.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Oh yeah, that's a good idea. I never thought to carry your whistle and that's a good idea. I have many years ago when I was given one of those spray things, I guess it's against the law that the post office man carry. So if a dog comes to attack you, you can spray it in their eyes but I think that's illegal. I don't think you're supposed to carry those things, but I will definitely get a whistle. That's a good idea. The flashlight you mean as far as crossing the street because it was dark over there.

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: Because it's dark, just a flashlight period. Wherever you feel you need that extra light you turn it on. And as far as that spray being illegal, I don't care. Your safety comes first. You fight the law second after you protect yourself.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: That's right. I got that spray. And I always say, the postman had given it to me and he said we carry these as postmen if there's a wild dog or anything coming, we can spray it. It doesn't kill anybody but it I guess blinds you or whatever that you can't see.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Yeah, disabled. Yeah, I'll carry my spray. I was always nervous because I would be in some trouble if something happens but you're right. If someone attacks me, I have to protect myself.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: I want to say that you 100% correct in that nothing much has been done to address the issue of mental health with young people. I will take it back to me losing my son. I do have another 16 year old son and I could honestly say nothing was done. There was no services provided by his school. Yeah, they did have grief counselors on hand for the students but that only lasted one week. And for example, my son had a girlfriend who was in the same grade as him and she was struggling and nobody seemed to care and they're trying to say that she's pretty much making excuses and I have to jump in and say, "No, she's not making excuses. This is losing her best friend." And they pretty much take it for a joke. There's nothing that's been done. Absolutely nothing. They just talk and talk and they don't do anything. They just overlook the needs of the kids in their care and then once the kids that are acting out then it's a problem but nothing has been done to address the issue.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Everything you just said resonates with me because I've been through the ringer with my child, been through the ringer. His behavior went off the charts. At one time he was hospitalized and it continues. What people don't understand is that grief doesn't have a deadline. The way one person deals with grief is different from the way another. Some people are just thrown off and they never recover. That's difficult to believe but they never do. They never do. And the start of my son's issues and problems was because he lost his father. He was very close to his father. I used to say to my brother that he loved his father more than he loved me. I didn't regret that I didn't have a problem with it but just to give you a sense of the relationship.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: And so from the time, the way my son responds to his father's passing, I always describe it as though a hole in the world opened up and he fell in because nothing was the same after that. I can give you, oh my gosh, a book of the things that went wrong. So when it comes to grief and mental health and needing help, it is not a week long thing. It cannot be. It has to be ongoing and there has to be experts who recognize the severity, the gravity of the situation. They have to have a safe space which many young people don't. I could go on and on and I don't want to but thank you so much for responding to that. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: I wanted to know, how does that work? When they do the grief counseling at the schools after that week, do they not allow the students to continue to see someone or once that week is done, it's done. It's up to your parents to figure it out.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: It's pretty much up to your parents to figure it out. They just walk away and act like nothing happened. Let's just sweep it under the rug. Nothing happened. To this day, we're about what? Eight, nine months in and no one's ever called me to address the needs of my 16 year old son. I am smart enough to have my own services from outside but you would think that this would be a priority to them because I have students from that school who still come here every day and tell me, on the first day of school, this kid came into my home and said to me, "I don't want to go to school." And I was confused. And I said, "Well, why don't you want to go to school?" And he said, "Because I don't want to." And I said, "But why?" I said, "You have to finish for our team."

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: And he said, "It's just not the same. I can't go there. I don't want to be there." I have another kid who just came up from Alabama and she came over and she said, "I can't be in the school. No one will help me." I have his girlfriend who cries every day. They're not helping us. And it's like they just want to, okay, the person passed and they just want to erase all the memories like this person was never ever there. Let's just not talk about him. Let's not recognize him. He was never there. And that's wrong. That's foul.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: The people left behind are always there and so much pain which is why we need experts. People who are trained to deal with grief. It is very, very difficult to understand what it, adults don't understand it. You're unable to explain it to young people. If you don't understand it, you can't explain it to them and so they struggle as you are struggling. And so everybody is walking around blind and struggling and nobody's getting help and it's a very difficult, complicated situation and it's ongoing. It goes on for months and years which is what folks fail to realize.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I've had someone say to my son, oh, you're still... I'm paraphrasing. I can't remember the exact words, but it was still painful. You're still grieving your father or something like that, years later. For some people, it never ends. It never ends. They learn to live with it but there's always a problem. There's always a part of their lives that just doesn't seem to fit and it's very difficult and I am so sorry Keemysvoice for your loss. I'm so, so sorry for you, your son because the road that you will travel, it resonates with me when you speak. I am just so sorry. I'm so sorry.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you. So we're going to move along and it says that let's talk a little bit about all of what we're hearing and what hearing in people's experiences for one another like, what exactly, what are you hearing? You heard everyone and their questions and where they fit in this and the future of Boston or the future of our lives here. And so that whole cross sectionality, I guess of what's happening. What exactly are you hearing in people's experiences? Is there something, sorry.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: I hear sadness, sorrow, confusion, anger. Just a whole lot of different emotions. I only have emotional words to describe what I hear unfortunately. I wish that there were happier experiences that we could share and speak on and look forward to, but unfortunately just the way that things are going and because the world is just at a place where you don't see as much happiness as you would like to, you just don't know what to think and feel or where to go to find that sense of peace and gratitude.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I said spirituality. That has been the only thing for me that has brought me some solace, because trying to explain to another human being what you've lived through, I personally feel own only God. Those are the two words, only God for me, only God. If it weren't for God and God in my life, oh my gosh. I don't know what I could say because now I'm becoming so emotional just saying those words. Many times it had to be on bended me trying to figure it out spirituality.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: I definitely hear a lot of frustration. And from my personal experience, I know I'm definitely in a place of pain and a lot of anger. And I do hear a lot of frustration because people's needs are not being met. It's like we have needs in our community and nobody cares enough.
