They will come out and they will socialize with you and they will talk and say, "Oh, I live on this street or I've been here for 104 years." But then as soon as they walk away they go back to that street where they're safe and where they've lived for 104 years, and they forget the people that actually put them in the position to serve. If you're here to serve, you should serve in full capacity. I can't go to work as a nurse and choose not to serve a man because of the color of his skin. That would be wrong. If I'm going to serve as a nurse, I'm going to serve everyone in the same capacity. And if you can't do that then you should move on.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Well, I have no comments here. I just agree with everyone. If you're born and raised or you've been living in a certain area for 10 years, 15 years, 20 years and then all of a sudden things start happening, you get confused, you're like, you don't know what you should do. I don't know. My niece sometimes might ask me, "Well, I don't know if I should live around here. The area's not good or it's safer. I don't want to raise my child in this area because I'm not sure if it's going to be safe." They shouldn't feel like that.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: They feel like they're being discriminated against. Because you live in Dorchester or because you live in Roxbury or because you live in Mattapan or Hyde Park, would you be treated the same? They feel like if I said I live in Newton, probably not.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Okay. Well, this was all really good and it's time for us to start wrapping up. So I just want to thank you again for sharing your questions and your experiences. And we're just going to go around again and just share something that you're going to take away from this whole discussion piece. So we could just start by, I don't know, whoever, backwards, Carol. So just talk about something that you're going to take away from the discussion and all that you've heard today. And if you can share any closing thoughts as well.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: Yeah. Well first of all, I'm going to take some of the advice that was provided regarding that whistle and the flashlight.

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: That was definitely on point. About that mace spray, I still feel uncomfortable with that, but the flashlight and the whistle, yeah, you can pull that whistle out by the time I take the mace out and try to spray it somewhere, probably knock me on my head or something. And the mental health issue, the concerns that were brought up, I never thought about them but I do think about them because I think the mental health issues affects the millennial generation. I think when I was growing up, things were not the same things. I think I am a millennial axial but I'm not at that millennial in the 70s or whatever. But there's a lot of things that are affecting these millennials that cause mental illness or cause depression or cause them the housing concerns, the gun concerns, all this stuff that's going on now. When I was growing up, I didn't experience a lot of this because it wasn't that way even with the housing concerns, that's a real, real big issue. Wherever I go around, there is a new development being put up, but why isn't it affordable?

nodes.speaker: Participant
nodes.words: The whistle and the flashlight piece and the mental, a little more thought about the mental health thoughts and why the millennials think the way they do because I can say sometimes why they do act out is because of the way life is.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: I just wanted to share one more thing with Ms. Carol. I just want to also tell you, if anyone were to attack you yell fire instead of help. I can't remember who told me this but they said that people are more likely to look and respond if you yell fire that help these days because they don't want to get involved in someone else's problems.

nodes.speaker: Keemy
nodes.words: I would say that from this meeting, I could take away that we all have issues. It doesn't matter which neighborhood, we all have our own issues that we deal with. Even though we have our own issues, we can also be each other's keeper, even for the young people. If you see for example, one young person pointing a gun at the other one, don't just go into your house and close the door and say, "Well, it has nothing to do with me. They're just these bad 17 year old boys." Because if you do that, that 17 year old boy could lose his life. So be each other's keeper and do the right thing. If you see something and you have to hide to do something, do it. And I don't hide. I do it. I'll talk to the police right there. I don't care. So if you see something, do something.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I don't even know what to say. I feel as though that there is so much more pain among our community more than I'm aware of.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: A lot of it is silent pain, and I don't know how each and every day when I pray, I ask God to show me how I can make a difference in my little corner. You asked to identify, I'm in a little room in my house. I don't know what I can do, how I can make a difference where I can go and that is a constant ongoing question that I ask all the time. I am aware that there are concerns. There are similarities in the pain that we share, but as you said Marilyn earlier, when we get together, when we come together, we can do something but often it's, do what?

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I can sympathize and empathize very easily but you feel stagnant and paralyzed and you just don't know what to do. But hearing about each other's concerns makes me... For me, my life is all about spirituality at my age and then this time in my life. When I feel as though I can't do anything then I pray. I don't know if others see that as doing something, but very often I don't know what to do. So that's just what I'm left with. I don't know if I'm answering the question. I don't even remember what the question is but there is quite a bit of pain and concern and questions amongst the people of Boston and knowing where to go to have these questions answered, knowing where to go where you can get help is the start, the beginning of changes. And I guess that's why we're here.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. It's the voices that are in the background that don't get heard. So this particular network will allow for these voices and the concerns that are real to be heard across the city, across the State, across the nation. And that's what Cortico does. It provides that. So rest assured that yes, people are going to hear the concerns and the cries of the people. Is there anything else that anybody wants to add to this or talk about a takeaway from this session?

nodes.speaker: Mish
nodes.words: I feel like we, because we don't see enough other people helping or supporting our needs per se, that maybe we should within ourselves and our own groups find support or make a support group to talk about and deal with the things. And for me, myself, I know me and a couple of my friends. I feel like when we talk, we talk about the same things but it makes us feel better. So to find that listening ear or whoever who doesn't mind listening to you say whatever over and over because it makes you feel good and it doesn't take anything from them to be there for you. Unfortunately I don't know how that would work or how to go about doing that but it was just something that I thought about as I was listening to folks talk about not having enough listening ear or people doing things. I don't know if that was helpful. It sounded good in my head but as I'm saying, I feel like it didn't come out the way that I intended.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Support groups of very beneficial. So over the years support groups, which you're suggesting, what you're recommending, support groups in any way, shape or form, however you can create them. Support groups, they serve a purpose. So stating that and recommending that, that's a big help. That can be a big help to a lot of people because some people feel as though others don't hear them even when they speak. So when they're in a situation where others are willing to listen, and not just listen, but hear them, that is very helpful for people who are hurting.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: That's nice. You know, what I will do is I'm going to send a link around, I don't know if you're familiar with Can We Talk Dorchester, and it's a group again, that you can share your emotions and different things and it came out of a family's pain where their son, who everybody also loved and was very fond of just like Keemysvoice's son, he was murdered and it shocked a community. And they created, I can't remember the name of it, it's something like Jonathan's story, that's not it but it's something like that but it came out of first I think, what's the name of that church where Liz Walker is? They started this group out of there, but now they have a Can We Talk group that is out of second church in Codman Square.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And Emmanuel Temples outreach actually facilitates it. It's every Tuesday. So I will send that information out and if you want to join in that group, even if you don't say anything but listen to fill it out, to see if that might be a space for you, because sometimes there is things or there are things that are on your chest that you want to get off and there are a number of things because not only the death of someone can cause a depression but also that housing situation, also the loss of feeling like you have this open space that the serenity and all of these quality of life issues are going away can cause deep depression and which are also part of the mental health piece. So I think that having a space where you can talk about the things that are causing you these instabilities in your mental health would be good. And if that doesn't work, then yeah, Michelle will get something started and she will let us know that time and place to be there. So any last thoughts before I just close us off?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: All right. Okay. So just remember what will happen with the thoughts that you share. These recordings will be transcribed, indexed and shared with the real talk for change team. You will receive an email from us with all of the conversations that are ready to view on the LVN platform. They'll pull the snippets from some of our conversations and then some of the others where you'll be able to hear and understand what's going on and how people's frustrations and conversations intersect. So before we leave the call, please stay for a couple of minutes and fill in the Google form. I just put it in the chat.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay? So welcome to one of the Real Talk For Change conversations. Thank you for responding to our invite and joining the network of voices and conversations that are happening across the City of Boston. Oh, let me show my face at least. We invited you to this gathering by asking you to think of one most pressing question you have about the future of the City of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to, knowing that it'll matter.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I will now begin recording, but I know when you came on it, it kind of let you know that this call was being recorded, right?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And I'll tell you a little bit more about that. So first, the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across the divides. Which are the neighborhoods, the political set, and cultural settings. And provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates for the future mayor and the neighborhoods throughout the city.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing your personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your position on upcoming election or specific candidates. We are doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So these conversations are really about your experience, not what you heard somebody else say or your guess been about everything else. Just what you've experienced, okay?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording of this conversation. So following our meeting today, the video recording will be discarded. So if you show your face, that's not what they're interested in having at all, okay? The only part that they want is the audio which will be part of a collection of conversations. These conversations, along with other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with members of Real Talk For Change Team and others who have participated in conversations through a local network which is LVN.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So the LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by a nonprofit organization, Cortico. LVN system creates a transcript of each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to an explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that this conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. So if you understand and agree with this, just say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Perfect, perfect. Wonderful, thank you so much. Okay, third, before we wrap up with this, I will share a form for you to fill out your name and your address so that we can send you your gift card. So the gift card is coming electronically. If you're going to have any issues with that then just let me know and we can probably work it out another way.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: We have also included a section with demographic information, which is optional. The reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect on an uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable answering that's in that form at the end of this conversation. So lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And to support these goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. So there's eight guidelines. So number one, speak for yourself and out of your own experience. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. Number three, share the time. Allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Number four, stay courteous and ask honest questions. Number five, pause. Take time for reflection. Number six, listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Seven, when possible, close unnecessary programs, applications and notifications, and put your phones on silent. If you need to take a moment, take a break, let the facilitator, let me know in the chat. If not, just let me know, okay? Is everyone clear with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, all right. So for the ease of this virtual conversation, we are going to use a method circle process where each of us will take a turn. So this is where we're going to be doing an introduction. I'll transition us from one person to the next. You can always pass and ask us to come back to you.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: To begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check-in. Please share your first name and where you are located right now, and then let us know how you are using the PIES check-in. So if you're not familiar with the PIES check-in, it's one of these following that you're going to check in with. You're going to check in physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: As soon as you are done please say, "And with that, I am in." And then we'll go to the next person. So are we clear on that?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So we're going to introduce ourselves by saying our name first and where we are right now. And then we're going to check in using one of the following of the PIES technique, which is the acronyms physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. So my name is Marilyn and right now I am in Dorchester and sitting in my living room at my computer, and I am checking in intellectually because I have really been putting a lot of thought in analyzing a lot that's been going on in the course of this day. So I think that I figured out a few things, so this is why I am checking in intellectually. And with that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I am going to pass it on now too [Kashawnii]. And Kashawnii, you could just say it. Well, you I said your name. But say your name and where you are right now, and then how you're checking in

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: Okay. Well, I'm a little confused about the checking-in part, but... So my name's Kashawnii, I am in Quincy, in my kitchen, and... So I think I'm confused about the next part.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So you can check-in... And it's really about how you're feeling at this moment. It could be physically you're feeling a certain type of way, intellectually your feelings... It's just...

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: Okay, so I'm checking-in a little tired. I had a busy day today and I have a busy week coming, busy day tomorrow, but I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: My name is Isabel and I am in Dorchester, in Darlington Street, sitting in my living room, in my little rocking chair next to my phone. And I am going to check in spiritually and emotionally because today has been rough. It was a rough day, I got some bad news. But God is good and with that I'm checking in.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yes. Hi everybody, my name is Carol and I'm in Dorchester. I'm standing in my bedroom and checking in physically because I'm feeling okay. I had a good day today and... What else? And basically just had a nice day. And with that, I'm checking in.

nodes.speaker: Lawanda
nodes.words: My name is Lawanda, I'm in Dorchester and I'm checking in mentally. Looking forward to hear what everybody has to say today. So with that, I'm checking in.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: Hi everyone, my name's Gina. I'm in Mattapan, in my bedroom. I'm feeling a little anxious about this whole thing, but I'm in. And I had a great day. I was at church this morning and got a good word so I guess that's the spiritual piece. And the other one... I don't know. Anyway, with that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Perfect, perfect. Okay, so now that we know who is here, let us get into the core of our conversation. So as we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and in Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? Again, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So we just came out of this pandemic, and through that, there were lots of things that rose to the surface about whatever in the city of Boston. I don't know if it was services. I don't know. Whatever it was that rose to the surface for you. So keeping that in mind, again, the question is, "What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?"

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: That's a hard one there. Future of Boston, oh boy. That's a hard one because how can we even plan about the future of Boston. Anybody going to say anything, because every time we think about something and we try to practice it, it doesn't happen. So right now, I'm stuck. I don't even know what to act or what to say, to tell you the truth.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, no. Well, I think that that was like a good lead in for you Isabel because you just said, when you think of something you get stuck. So why is that?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And like I said... So imagine this, through the pandemic, there was a whole lot of things. We were all in the house and people had their issues around a whole lot of things. Now we're coming out of that, does anything change or was there some experience you had during that time that makes you wonder about what changes need to happen in Boston? And how is it going to impact your life in the future?

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: For me, about the pandemic you personally know that I've been through it. I went through it, you know. It's still happening inside my family, so it's a hard thing. But you know what? The thing is it's not going to stop until people start listening because a lot of people think because they vaccinated, they're not supposed to wear mask, they're not supposed to do certain things, and it's not like that.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: And This is why it's increasing everywhere and it's sad because what we was supposed to be expecting? Now, the kids are back in school, not remotely. So they are exposed to anything that we don't even know and they could just bring it to us home and we would not know. So it's a [inaudible] panic to me.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Because I don't see not results. The government should have been ready for this malady. So there's nothing to say about it. It's just scary to me, I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. I like that, that good. That's really good. Thank you for sharing. And who is that that was trying to go next?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yeah, I was just going to say it is scary. People in my family have had it. A couple of people, my brother, my sister. Two of my sisters had it, and my brother. And yes, it's scary and a lot of people don't want to get the shot. So it's when is it... I don't think it's going to end and it's going to be a long time before it ends 'cause... So that's the scary part about it. If everybody don't get vaccinate, then when is it going to end? It's like it's never going to end. There's never going to be an end to it. Things are just getting worse. That's about it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So is there a question other than 'When is it going to end?' that you have about the future of Boston?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, that's a good question. So hold that. That is your question. So that's perfect. That is your question. Who wants to go next? I'm sorry, go ahead, Carol, you finish.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Well, can my question be what can they do to stop it? To make sure everybody gets vaccinated? To make it mandatory or something?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Your question about the future of Boston can be anything you want it to be. So if that is your question...

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Come on people, I know you have a lot of questions. If we have an answer, we'll help you with it. But if we don't, we just put it on pause.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: Alright. I love you all. See you later. So, I have a bunch of issues on what I think Boston should look like or what I'd like to see. For instance, I'm going to go into a couple of things and then decide which way I'm going to go. Because I'm a product of South Boston High in the years of the segregation. And all of this stuff that's been going on about Black versus White and Latino and, Chinese Americans, and all of this is really a problem for me. But I don't know how it's going to be resolved because hate is in peoples hearts and you can't... People have to want to change. I don't know how you can enforce that.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: The other thing that really strikes a chord with me, because I am a recovered addict of 28 years. And I see all these people down Methadone Mile, I see them up here on Blue Hill Ave and Morton St, and they're begging constantly. What do we do? They've closed down all of the facilities that help these people get clean, and they have no place to live. And so they're in the street, they're killing and they're being killed. You know, because... And then there's mental illness that goes with that.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: So there's just an array of things that seriously concerns me about our communities. And as I will put it, being overlooked. Because a lot of these people are coming from the outskirts, from the suburbs into our city, and we are being affected negatively. Not to mention what we're doing to our own selves, but that just adds to it. Thank you. So that's all I'm going to say for now. I think that's quite enough.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, so is there a question that sort of gets at the future, what your place in the future of Boston?

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: Well, I probably have the same question most people have about like... We already went through one lockdown and now we have a new thing called the Delta and I want to know if the government has a better plan for people that are employed and just everyone, for if we have to go into a lockdown again. That's what I want to know. That's my question.

nodes.speaker: Lawanda
nodes.words: Basically that nothing has gotten better with the COVID going on. So I really didn't understand why things had got opened back up. Like for school and people going back to work and stuff like that.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: In the future. Right. So I think I wanted to share a little bit too. And I think my question that I have about the future of Boston, and my place in that future is... So although I am a home owner, I am concerned about just the rising costs associated with living. And with even... You know, I'm not a renter, but I rent to people. And because of the rising cost of taxes and everything else, I worry because of people that aren't able to afford where they live.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And for a landlord who tries to do the right thing and keeps the rent down low, but then because of all of the building and all of that that's happening, it's rising, it's causing property taxes and insurance and everything to raise. And it makes it difficult for me to really want to keep rent low and affordable when the cost is growing for me myself. And so what I'm concerned about for the future is how much more will things go up? And will people be able to keep up?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: The rate of inflation is going up, yet the salaries are not in line with it. And it makes it difficult when people that need to rent because either they don't own and it's a choice... They can't or they just prefer to rent, can't afford to rent. So what happens to my space? What happens to my place? Do I rent under market? Do I try to keep in line and then know that someone's not going to be able to keep up with the rent? And then they're in my place and not paying me rent and then I'm at risk of losing my house 'cause I can't pay my mortgage?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I want to know when is this whole housing situation and the cost of living going to stabilize? Because if it doesn't then I don't think anybody wins. So I want to know what's going to happen. How is this going to play out? So that's kind of sort of where I am in this whole question for Boston, and what my future might look like, as someone living in the City of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I just want to like move us along a little bit again and thank you all so much for sharing those questions. But I also want to emphasize that it is key to keep the experience personal like what's happened to you, what you've experienced directly as a result of what has come out of your living experience in the city of Boston. I mean, COVID was just an experience and multiple things happened. But what happened to you during this time that was able to impact your life one way or another?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So we can go around again in a circle, and each person can share a question, then tell a story of an experience that led them to the question that you asked.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Not real- Okay, let me just throw this one in there. So I told you... All right, so COVID was about a lockdown thing. But in that, because I had all this time to sit still. It kind of made me think about many, many things. I had more time to process on top of being worried about this pandemic thing. But losing a tenant not to COVID but like my tenant moved, and thinking about having to rent the place again and knowing that there's this moratorium, right?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And worrying about all of the scams that are out there, that people know that because of this moratorium, that they can move into a space, they can give you the money for their first month, their last month or whatever. But then once they get in, they stop paying rent simply because the city says, "Well, the courts will not evict you." So people are staying in your house and not paying rent because of the moratorium. So the apartment stays vacant because do you really want to risk putting someone in that you don't know? And that could be your problem.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So that's part of it for me, but I also heard in I think it was Isabel and Carol who talked about pandemic and worrying about it, it's coming back. And [Shani] actually talked about it, too, it coming back. And what does this mean? Will there be another shutdown? And what does... Not just the government, the city of Boston. What plans are in place to address the inevitable? What is in place?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So there are these experiences, my experience. And then I listen to your experience and kind of wonder. And then we have this election coming up and how is our new mayor going to take what we say to heart and figure out the plan?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So again, I want you to respond to each person who shared their question and tell a story about an experience that led to that question.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Well, my question was about COVID. In my experience with this COVID, it was not easy, it wasn't bad because I was able to get over it but it was tough. It was hard because remember I have my grandkids at home so I have to quarantine myself upstairs. And I spent a whole week eating peanut butter and jelly and drinking water until I've come down from my house.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: So that was a bad experience to tell. It was bad enough that we have to be on lockdown and then I couldn't even move around in my house. That was a bad experience. This is the reason why I've vaccinated myself and I don't leave my meds and I don't go nowhere and I don't accept visitors in my house that I don't know that they safe.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: It's been a bad experience to me. I suffered it, I had it, and it was bad. And it's still in my household. Not inside my house, but you know. You know because you know, Marilyn.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: So it's bad. It's bad. It's bad. And to me it's a bad experience. This year, cannot get over it soon enough.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Somebody else want to share an experience that can help you understand how you got to the question that you shared?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Well, mine was about the COVID too. This is Carol. Well, I haven't really had it or anything but I experienced my family having it and how it's affected them, how it's affected my family, and other people but I haven't had it. But just having to wear a mask all the time and not being able to go to places. I'm not... Mostly staying in the house, not going around, not going places I normally go and stuff like that.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: So it's just kind of been a bad experience because of that, because of my family members catching it and worrying about them. And if they... Because my sister's in the hospital now. I'm just worrying about her. Is she going to come out of it all the way and stuff like that. So it's just been kind of bad like that because of my family members worrying if they're going to make it.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: I didn't have a question and I'm thinking a little different than most because the pandemic, for me, didn't really hit me as hard as I'm hearing from others. Both of my daughters and their families had it but they all came out fine. My husband and I did not have it and we were blessed enough that we continued to work. My job, though, deals with issues that people have had because of the loss of jobs because of the pandemic and the things that I hear are horrible. But that's neither here nor there for here. So I really don't have an answer for this one. I just don't. I don't. I'm somewhere else.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: I, too, am a homeowner but I chose not to be a landlord because of the very things that you spoke of, Marilyn, before the pandemic, because I don't have enough sense and I'd hurt somebody if they didn't give me my money. So I knew that I couldn't do that.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: But of the experience that you had, the question that led to your response... How you shared that, how do you... What am I trying to say? Help us understand how you arrived at that question that you shared with us, that's what I want to say. So you talked about your question being, what they plan to do about the people that are homeless that are down at [mass cast] and you had a concern because of where you've been in your life, where you sort of came out of that but you had a real concern about what that's going to look like in the future. That was pretty much your question, right? And so I guess the experience is what I'm asking you to help us understand, what even got you to that question?

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: It is something that's always been on my heart. Seeing these people out here doing whatever they have to do to get their next fix, not having any place to go, bathing in the streets if they bathe at all, stealing from people, hurting one another. It's part of the crime that's in our communities. And what are they... Are they going to open up... They closed all the facilities.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: Back when I was using, there were facilities that you could go in and you could get some help, some direction. When I went in for the first time, I didn't know that they even existed until on my job that this woman cared enough and she asked me and I said, "I have a problem with drugs and I need help." And she sent me to a facility.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: They have shut everything down. They don't even have these things anymore. And so we're left with the crime. The demand for drugs keeps the drug dealers going and they're killing each other to get the money. And if they don't get their money or they get the other big time drug dealers money, and they don't care. They're killing our babies, our men, our women, our elderly, everybody. Doesn't matter. And we are all impacted by that one way or another.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: And so, I mean, COVID is a big deal, I'm not downplaying it at all but this has been going on. COVID has only been here for, what, a year and a half, two? But this other epidemic has been here forever and nobody's doing anything about it.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: And all these new drugs that are killing these people. One hit and they're dropping dead. We have children and children can be so easily misdirected. And people are losing their children every day. I'm sure you saw it on the news about the needles down at the football field, where these kids have to go up and down the field to pick up the used needles before they can practice or play football in our community.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Mm-hmm (affirmative). Thank you. Thank you so much for sharing. Who would like to go next? [Otto]. Some experience that you've had, help us understand the question that you shared with us[crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: So excuse the noise because I'm picking up something in Walmart but pretty much during this pandemic, I've experienced... So I was living on campus. I experienced campus shutting down and school going fully remote. I'm sure the whole Zoom thing and online thing for anyone who preceded work or school during this pandemic was really hard and new for everyone because we're all so used to doing everything in person.

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: And so that was a really interesting experience. And also during this pandemic, I had a baby. And though it was my first baby, I know that people don't usually go have babies alone and can't have any visitors besides one person. And then you have to put family or your significant other in a position where it's like, "Well, who am I going to pick?" You know what I mean?

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: So it was just I experienced that too. And even while I was in the hospital, my partner couldn't even come into the room for hours until it was closer to the time that I was going to go into labor. So it was such a sad experience going through such a difficult and new thing alone. So that's kind of what I want to say.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So what I want to do next is think back to each of the questions and experiences that we'd just shared in our group, not... Especially the one you... But the questions that were raised from all of us, right? And find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life. And then let's just talk about that.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: That affected me because I've been suffering that same concern that she suffered. Because when you see these young kids in the street begging to get their next fix, that's something really, really sad and very depressing. And it hurts because they have mothers, they have daddies, they have families.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: So these mothers are hurting them [inaudible] and we don't have nothing to do with that. It might in the family. That is something real sad you know what I mean? And I've been there with family, the girls luckily, the ones that didn't die with it, they're out of it so that's a good thing. But it's hard because they don't have nowhere to go and nobody to help them. And if they don't do anything from going, they're not going to get fixed. Nothing is going to get resolved because it's been going this way forever.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Now, the COVID has started [inaudible] it's fine but all this has been going on forever. Now they're making everything legal. But, come on, [inaudible] marijuana, now what's going to come next? And there are all these drugs that they're making new now, it's different with everybody. It's something to be concerned about. And what did they do about it?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). Mm-hmm (affirmative). Yeah. So let's speak about the question or experience that resonates with us and share a story from your life that connects with that experience.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I know if Shani talked about my connection or how I resonate is not really about having a baby, but the isolation piece of it is what I can really resonate with because the of pandemic. It was difficult to... In all my years of living, I've never had to sort of separate, stay in the house. I remember when the city was first locked down, it was like a ghost town out in the streets. No cars, no nothing. But, no one can come to your house. Family had to stay away because you didn't... It just was a scary notion to have to isolate.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And so that definitely resonated with me. And that was an experience that I think that we have in common. The whole isolation and what that feels like, what that can do to you emotionally, what it can do to you physically, to have to... I am definitely a people person and I enjoy being around people all the time. So to have to kind of just reset my life and live a different lifestyle other than what I know and I'm used to was a little hard for me. Thank God, I tried to insert a spiritual notion in there so that I can keep my sanity. And that's what it was really all about.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And thank God, my husband... At least I didn't have to stay in the house by myself but my son who's away, he couldn't come home. So it was tough, that whole isolation piece. So this is where I definitely can resonate with Shani and her experience. Does somebody else want to go?

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: I, too, can... This is Gina. I, too, felt Shani as she came through. I felt her passion and how she felt. I too had a grandson, a granddaughter that was born seven months ago during the pandemic, and my son could not go in with the mother. And he couldn't go in until after the baby was born and all of that. And that was very disappointing for him and I felt his pain. But then, the same son just had a surgery last week and I asked him if he needed me to take him and he said, no, that the mother of his child, they're still together, was going to go. But he had to call and ask if she could stay and they told him no.

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: Now, it wasn't a major surgery but anytime you're going under anesthesia, that's serious stuff because people die going under anesthesia. And all I could do all day was pray that my son was going to be okay and nobody was going to be there with him if something had happened. So that's where Shani's experience touched me personally.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Tell you what, give me a second. [inaudible] can you all give me a second? My phone should be okay and I'll come back on. Can you give me a second?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: So what I was saying was I had COVID in June and I was [inaudible] by myself a little better because [inaudible] I also experienced that also. Yeah, having to be alone and having nobody with [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). And so it kind of makes you wonder but because of the pandemic, all of this has occurred. And I don't know if the City of Boston, if there is anything that can be done so that it doesn't have to be like that. But I think the answer is in dealing with the real issue which was the pandemic that caused all of this, right? So, I don't know. I guess it's something to think about and how that whole pandemic situation has changed our lives in so many different ways. And how, even though we have different experiences, they're really all connected.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: They're all connected. There's crime, there's housing, there's sickness, there's so much. There's unemployment, all of it. It's all connected, right? And we want to know how and what's going to be done to sort of like alleviate the issues for all of us, right?

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Crime is going to rise because Biden stopped unemployment, it's all loans. So now with the crime, and the [deeds], and the hold up, all of this has gone rising. And all the scammers in the internet, too. So we're in trouble right now. It's going to get crazy and it's still getting bad. I don't see nothing getting better. We're going backwards. Everything is backwards right now. And it's kind of scary because I'm scared already.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So it's just about time for us to wrap up. So again, I want to thank everyone for your questions and for your experiences, and we can just quickly just go around just one last time and just share one thing that you will take away from this experience in this conversation. One thing. Gina?

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: That we're all in this together. And that we're all connected one way or another. I heard everybody and I think everybody is on point with what they're experiencing and I think we're all sharing all of the same things in one way or another. But again, the question is, how do we overcome?

nodes.speaker: Gina
nodes.words: Faith is big for me. And sometimes we have to do some footwork but I think here, there's not a whole lot of footwork we do. We have to put the metal to the pedal or however the heck you say that. And these people who we're voting in, they have to hear us and we have to make them hear us.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Absolutely. Absolutely. Thank you, Gina. One thing that anyone else may want to share what you're taking away and maybe a reflection from the evening? A general...

nodes.speaker: Kashawnii
nodes.words: Yeah, I can go. I agree with the first person that went there. We're pretty much all at the same place. We're all worrying, we're all just wondering what's next and no one's alone in this. That's the big thing.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: Can I just say, [inaudible] when I hear all the conversation, I basically feel relaxed because I see my family last night in Vegas. I think when you hear other people having the same experiences, you cool off. You laugh at and you think about and you just go, "How can I be so ungrateful when I'm alive and somebody else is having more problems than me and is grateful for being alive?"

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: So that made me realize that I shouldn't be complaining so much and praise God every day, which I do, but we're all brothers and sisters one way or the other. We are connected, period. It's not even about the pandemic. We should all be connected regardless if we in the same community, we should work together.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: If anything that's binding us, we could do it like a group, as a community, and try to fix it because that's the only way they hear the person. They don't hear one voice, they like to hear more than one person because everybody else has a different opinion and different way to say the things that wants to get fixed.

nodes.speaker: Isabel
nodes.words: And if we plan a different kind of way for them to do it, they cannot refuse because we're giving them different ways to fix it. It's all there but they don't want to do it. So we're the ones paying the price because there's nothing else that we can do.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: You know, I'm feeling really bad because I know that you're saying something so important and I want to hear it and I can't.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: That's okay. I can feel it in your heart. Take away everything from this evening because I think the conversation that everyone contributed truly was valuable and I think all of what was said is resonating with everyone. So thank you. Thank you again, everyone, for joining tonight.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And just remember, what happened with the thoughts you shared, these recordings are going to be transcribed, indexed, and shared with the Real Talk For Change Team. You will receive an email from us when all of the conversations are ready to review on the platform.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So your conversations along with everybody across the city is going to be sort of categorized. So you'll hear little snippets and hear the common themes of what people had to say across the city. But hopefully... Not hopefully. It will be heard by those seeking office and they need to know what the constituency here needs and wants done.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: We have a huge plethora of issues that need to be addressed and not everybody's out there rallying in the street. But for those voices that can be heard, this is the mode or the venue that they will hear from everyone.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So before you leave, I don't know if you all can... Well, actually I will send you the Google form on the text message. You can fill it out. It's a Google form and send it right back. And that's the way they'll know how to get you your gift card and also be able to pick up some of the demographic information that they would need for this. That stuff is important when it comes to funding and so forth.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So again, thank you all for joining tonight and I am going to let you back to your Sunday evening and wish you well and hopefully we will talk and see each other soon. And when we do, just know that you're going to get a big old hug for me.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right, thank you. All right, so before we get started, we have sort of like a check-in kind of thing that we like to do here. It's a P.I.E.S. check-in. Is anybody familiar with this, what that means? Basically, what we want to do is that you want to check in based on how you're feeling in either physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. If you... Let's see. Well, let's see. Well, I think I'm pretty much doing a lot of reading right before coming on here, so I'm going to check in intellectually today. Stuff like that. So, basically, however you're feeling, just go around and check in based on that. We'll go this way on this one. So, that's physically, intellectually, emotionally, on spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: I think, since it's been a day of multitasking, I would say all of the above. Try to do many things, do them well, keep all the balls in the air, and keep moving forward in a positive manner.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: I feel grounded, especially spiritually. On the intellect level, I also am working on a lot of books, so I feel great. [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right, thank you. So, I want to... Just to give people a chance to reflect, I'm going to pass out... They're just scrap papers, but I want... We try to recycle paper around here. But, basically, what I want you to do is... Has everybody got a paper and pen? So, the idea is to come up with a question. Think in terms of your future or the future of Boston, since this initiative... Basically, that's because the focus there is... In terms of the future of Boston and your place in that future. Come up with a question that you would like to have resolved in terms of the future of Boston and your place in it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: You know, like I would like to see the Boston schools get their act together and final be able to come up with a plan is able to meet all the children where they're at, or something like that. You know? Saying in terms of that, and provide for all children in the city, something like that. That's like a question that I would ask, that I actually asked in my... But whatever the issue is that is close to your experience.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And what we're going to do... And after that... You don't have to write this down, because I think it will be here, I think, a long time. But what experience in your life got you to this question? What was the catalyst that you brought you to that question? We're going to have you talk about what that was in a few minutes.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. Yeah, one other thing, just as some sort of... As a general ground rule, what we're doing is that we want to make sure that, in this process, that you only speak from your own experience. You only speak from your own personal experience about what your question is, and what is it in your experience that brought you to that question.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Well, yeah, I mean, if that's your experience with the community, then sure. We just want them to be from each person, generally from each person. In other words, this is something that you experienced that brought you to wanting to see this question resolved however.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Right, what experiences or experience brought you to the point where this was a significant question for you, that made the answering of that question, the resolution of that question important to you? What experience in your life or experiences made this an important question for you to want to have answered?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So, what we're going to do is we're going to read... Who reads the questions? They read the questions? Okay, so each of you are going to read your question, and then you're going to talk about the experience. All right, and we're going to go one-by-one around. You don't have to write your experience down. What I was saying is write the question down, and then we're going to go around in the circle and have you talk about your experience. You're going to say your question, and then you're going to talk about the reason for that question. All right?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Not I, no. Not me, mm-mm (negative). No, we have a little bit of interaction on the questions. I'll go into that in a second. I guess, right? Okay. Okay, everybody done with the question? How you doing, Gilberto? You ready?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Almost done? Okay. All right, as a matter of fact... What are you doing now [inaudible]? There's some food if you want some food.[inaudible]. We got some food for you all. Steak, or chicken, or... I think, is there chicken left?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So, whenever you're ready. There's a drink in there too, and I have some extra iced tea, probably, if somebody wants some.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. So, let's see. Well, why don't we start the other way this time? So, that means to start with you. Tell us your question. So, they do both, right?

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: As a lifelong resident of the South End, I feel that mental health is a significant part of the success of our residents here in Boston. It's inadequate, and it's imperative to find a solution to real healthcare. Why is this question important to me? Because I encounter people every day.

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: It's a travesty. You can't wall down the street without encountering somebody, and if you're not like you, you feel bad for them. They should be getting proper healthcare. Every drug addict that catches hepatitis C or is homeless has proper healthcare, but they don't.

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: Just every day. Every day you see it. And just of myself being in the Marathon bombing, other situations that have happened. I don't feel I received proper care. So, that's personal. I know people that are undiagnosed, wreak havoc upon other people's lives.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: I had several questions in mind, but I'm going to raise this one. Has to do with police profiling of Blacks in the city. A case that came to my mind... Well, I should raise a question. Why Black people are being profiled? That would be the question. Background is I've lived in the city for the last 30 years or more, and I know that Black people are not getting a fair shake in the criminal justice system. I just sat on the grand jury for the last three months, and those cases have exacerbated in my mind the imbalance, if you will, in the criminal justice. That's why I raise that question.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. So, I want to... Before you go on, I don't know if I can do this, but I want to focus back on what is the-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: The question is: What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? How has this personally affected you? I don't get any sense that...

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: Well, there's a philosopher who said that the death of one man is the death of all man. Being a witness... Not a witness, but having been exposed to so many cases... We've seen over 90 cases at the grand jury, and I can see how the criminal justice works against Black people. So, that's why I raised that question, and I hope, in the future, some measure of justice might be raised and something good might come out of it.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: [inaudible]. The question about Boston's future with the IT skill resources. My experience in this field is that I worked in the financial district, and I find that people working in the IT department are from other countries. I know that the US citizens, the United States, their tech resources are pretty low. US citizens are catching, going to catch up, but, yeah, you go to the financial district, these companies, and their best technicians are either from India or Pakistan, even China, Japan. What's Boston planning to do about that?

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: I mean, the way it affected me is that the difficulty I had with computer and the IT departments is that I didn't have really a computer network to work with, to mess around with, but apparently, people from other countries, they do for some reason. Maybe they were sponsored by their government, and they were well-trained. But I worked with them in computer schools, and a lot of them, they have a lot of skills.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: Yeah, I say to myself, thinking that if I can put together a computer network, physical computer network, and have a nonprofit organization, I might invite in US citizens that are striving to develop their skills in the IT department, and come in and work at it to try to gain those skills, because the knowledge they're getting in colleges, like the community college, I guess isn't enough. You're not allowed to take the computers apart, work with it, experiment. They only let you do a certain level of configuration, but that's it.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: When you go out into the real world, it's a lot different. It's a lot, lot different. You won't understand Excel. Okay, I've got two certificates from Excel at a really good IT school, and in Excel, they got us to do a couple of links to a couple of pages, do a couple of formulas, and that was about it, where you can go in and enter the information in this page, and the information will appear in the next page. You might type a form in MS Word, and then embed the information from Excel to that Word form, and that was it.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: I mean, it looked great. It was fantastic to learn it. But when I got into the work environment and I got handed a Excel document, it's a good thing I was strong with Excel, because that Excel document had about 500 different lines that I had to go through looking to do that entry and the make sure that there was no mistakes in the other part of the balance sheet, another page on the Excel. And if it did, I had to find where the mistake was. That was a big difference. In the community college, it was just two links to two pages, but in the real world, it was a huge [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: Okay. So, like that, the same way it is with IT. You look at a few computers, but the computers are... You cannot put them together or take them apart completely. They stare. You do a couple of things, and voila. You know, you're not...

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: Sorry. Thank you, Gilbert. My question is: In 30 years, or even in 10 years, will there be a thriving middle class in Boston?

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: And this involves jobs in housing. What kind of employment opportunities can we have that will pay the kind of wages that will let me, and others, live in South End, Back Bay, Fenway, Beacon Hill, Seaport, Financial District, even Jamaica Plain? What will happen to the middle class in Boston? Will there be... Because we are getting to be like third-world countries. There's the wealthy, and there are the servants. You cannot successfully hold together a society without a thriving middle class, and the middle class is shrinking, is disappearing in places like Boston, and New York, and San Francisco. Disappearing in places like London and Paris. Disappearing.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: So, that's my question. What kind of jobs are going to be around to pay more? This so-called living wage thing, $15 an hour, that's after-school money. You know? Okay, that's after-school money. If I compare the wage that I got in a factory job in the '70s at Uniroyal. The minimum wage was like $2.50 an hour. I was marketing like $5.50 an hour. I mean, if I had kept on that wage, I'd probably be making $85,000 a year now. But the unions are gone. I mean, unions are not typically... Well, socially, not middle class, but middle income. But the thing is, that's what I'm thinking about. The bread and butter, "How you going to make money? How you going to live?" That's my question. Who is advocating for that?

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: And I'm living in it, I mean, hanging on by my no-longer-manicured fingernails. They used to be manicured, okay? Every week. You know, that's over. It's been over for over 20 years. It's probably not coming back. I get a manicure, I do my own. So, that kind of stuff. I mean, just basically living.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: I mean, in the '70s, secretaries used to live on Beacon Street. Do you know that? Secretaries had their own... Yeah, you know, [inaudible]. Secretaries... Well, if you lived alone, you might've had a studio, but you might've had a nice two-bedroom. So, you and your roommate, and you're both secretaries, and you're doing okay. And if you went to Katie Gibbs, well, you were an executive secretary. You had your own two-bedroom apartment. I mean that kind of stuff.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: And that secretary, that's a non-college educated... But now, you can have a master's degree out here in Boston, you're making $52,000 a year, unless, of course, you're making $48,000 a year. That's with a master's degree. This place doesn't pay.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: I mean, this is like a high-cost, low-wage town, and the people who come here from places like India and China, and they're living in, or wherever, Latin America, you got the immigrants who are taking... They're getting college scholarships and various other kinds... Section 8 housing and all that kind of stuff, while the citizens are unable to get access to these resources, and are in debt for college. They got no degree; they got debt.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: Well, that's just it, my no-longer-manicured fingers, trying to hold on and at least pretend to live a middle class life in the city of Boston. I suppose you could say I could move somewhere else. Who knows? You know, Saugus, but it wouldn't be that much different. Wouldn't be that much different. I mean, for God's sakes, I heard about the rents they're charging in Chelsea. Chelsea! I mean, I used to think about Chelsea, "You'd have to pay me to live there." Well, I mean, they have a waterfront now, and things have gotten a little bit fancy, at least in parts of it.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: Revere has their waterfront apartments. I even been into a couple of them. They've been around for a while on Revere Beach. I mean, so, a view of the water. Planes coming in. They can charge more. I mean, I admit that my friend had a nice apartment. He worked for their Fed, by the way. Worked for the Fed, living in Revere. But, I mean, on the waterfront.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: But, I mean, but the thing is that the people... It's like people who come from another country with money coming in, people who come from another country illegally and without money getting resources, and the citizens going under, and the progressives telling you the that, "Well, you're xenophobic." Are you kidding me?

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: So, that's where I'm at. What happens to the middle class? What kind of policies will be in place? What kind of opportunities will exist in 10 years, 20 years, 30 years, or maybe on January 1. What'll it look like? You got the mayors talking, the mayoral candidates, talking about, well, affordable housing and rent control. All of that is nonsense. It can't be done. You got to make money. How are you going to make money? What kind of opportunities will survive that will allow you to just have a one-bedroom apartment, and not have two other roommates with you, or whatever. That's my story.

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Okay, simply put, how will city leaders plan to deal with the Mass and Cass crisis? You see people involved in that area who's actions affect the quality of everyone in the City of Boston as well as visitors to the City of Boston. You see people affected by that crisis in the subways. Frequently, they're on the seats. They've passed out. You see them in stolen wheelchairs, passed out. You see them in people's backyards, various states of activity. This question affects everybody. Again, going forward, what plans do the powers that be in the city have to come to terms with this, if not resolve it?

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: Well, I'm not a city resident, but I commuted to the city. I walk the sidewalks. I take the public transportation. And I see the people who are affected by the crisis, what they do. I'm not quite sure how I should proceed around this. Definitely, impacts everybody's quality of life. Those individuals need assistance. They need help. What's the answer to it?

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: There can be many answers. I believe there are commissions that are in place right now to develop different strategies to deal with it, but you don't need commissions. You need actions. Do you need a bridge to Long Island? Do you need ferries to Long Island? Is that the answer? Do you need to decentralize facilities in the suburbs? Does the state need to step in and help with that?

nodes.speaker: Kathy
nodes.words: But anyone who has to walk on the sidewalk and worry about somebody coming up, going in your face, maybe putting their hands on you, because I've had that experience more than once, what are you to think of this? What are you to think of this going forward? Do you want to ride in a subway car with somebody who's passed out with no mask on? Do you want to get off at a subway station, see a group of people. They're there because they have no place to go. What do we do? Are we our brother's keepers? What do we do here? But this is a quality of life and public health issue that affects all of us, both those who need help, as well as everyone who could provide help.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. So, I want to take a few minutes just to think about some of the things you just heard from people. Is there anybody's question here that connects with some experiences in your own life?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Is there anybody's experiences and questions that connect with your own... Anybody whose experience that they've described here connects with you [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: They killed a young Black man in the back of Tent City. He had no gun. He had no drugs. He begged for his life, and they shot him in front of me and my daughter. So, yeah, that affects me. His mother worked for the police force for over 20 years. Didn't even get the common courtesy of a phone call. So, yes, that affects me.

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: The IT stuff, I'm like... I'm sorry, I'm not too swifty with the IT. I definitely understand where she's coming, like where will we be, like what jobs are going to be available, how are we going to survive. Of course, I understand what she's talking about on Mass Ave. that's the first thing you see when you drive into the city. I mean, that's crazy.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: No, I was just reflecting on what you were saying about those kind of jobs that used to exist in the past, like being a secretary. Unfortunately, the reality is that, today, those jobs don't exist, and you can't expect to see them coming back in the future, because who needs a secretary today, so to speak? You do? Okay. But-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: And it's usually someone you know, like word of mouth. It's not like the people that put their resumes on do all that. They'll be lucky if they get that job, because usually it'll go to somebody that knew somebody that knew somebody and slipped them in.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: Those jobs, from my perspective, do not practically exist anymore. You you could have somebody working as a personnel, but not as secretary per see as we used to have that in the past. I think the world, not just the States, but the world in general is moving towards a new age of technology.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: The question would become for me: What those who would be elected envisage to produce or create in the realm of technology so that more people can be computer literate and can really get access to those jobs.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: Administrative. Yeah, they've changed the name, but it is true that, yes, technology... Thank you. That technology... In general, the world moves forward all the time. The jobs that existed in the 1700s don't really exist anymore, or at least not in the same way. But what kind of jobs will be available, and what will they pay? What kind of jobs will be available? How many of them will there be? How do you access them? Will they pay enough? Will they pay enough? I mean, and let's get realistic about living wage, because it's not $15 an hour, and it's not $30 an hour. It's more like $50 an hour in this neighborhood, and in many neighborhoods. And can you get enough hours to do it? And what will the benefits be like? Will there be benefits? There's all those kinds of things.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: If a society does not work to have a thriving middle class, the society is going to be destabilized. That has already been proven. In history and economics, it's already proven. But what we have here is greed stepped in, as it usually does, and it starts to erode your society. But the question was, "How do I link up with other people?" Well, Pam and Kathy, of course, as someone who walks around the city, I mean, I am afraid to go by Mass Cass. I'm afraid to go by Mass Cass.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: And yeah, there are solutions. It's just that the powers that be are not interested in funding them. People don't want to fund them. People don't want their tax money diverted to that kind of stuff. Myself, I think their biggest mistake was closing up the hospitals in Northampton. If it were up to me, they would've never left Northampton. They would've been there. They would've stayed there. You just repurpose it. And of course, make sure that people are not being abused, and over-medicated, and physically assaulted, and all that kind of stuff.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: I mean, the healthcare is bad or nonexistent, but then again, you got to remember, you can't make people... The way the laws are written, you can't make people take their meds. See, I would never go along with that. I mean, you can't say to someone whose mind isn't working, "Do you want to take your meds, or do you want to have M&Ms?" I mean, that's like asking a child. But people who... They feel that everyone has agency, and I agree with that, but... I agree with that, but if you don't have the capacity to make decisions, you can't make that decision. I mean, I'm not advocating for Nurse Ratched here, if you know who Ratched is, but... I'm not advocating for that.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: As for the whole thing about tech, and jobs, and skills, yeah, our education system is not good. It's not good globally. I read an article probably three days ago. It talked about a woman who came to New York City from Jamaica, and she said she didn't do well in the New York City schools at first, and she said, "The work that the schools that we had in Jamaica," she said, "I was at," she said, "It was harder," meaning more intellectually, academically challenging. She said it was more... I'll use the word academically challenging. She said she went, I don't know, somewhere in Queens. She said the school was nothing. They advanced her a grade, and then she went to a community college, and then she went to, I don't know, NYU or something like that. She got a master's degree, and now, in Bridgeport, Connecticut, she runs this big social service agency. It employees like 300 people. But the thing is, yeah, our educational system, I mean, unless you are in a private school, or Boston Latin, or something like that, it's, I guess, not so great.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: I had one about mental health. I had an experience where I was having difficulty trying to read and trying to keep up with college-level reading. I couldn't understand what it was. I got to a point where I had heard about to get some help. Get some help. [inaudible]. I went to this place. It's over here on Brookline Avenue. I think it was Mass State Health, I think they call it.

nodes.speaker: Gilbert
nodes.words: I went there, and... You know, I reported there. I spoke to the reception desk. She sends me over, says, "[inaudible 00:42:06]." They call me to go enter this office. I said, "No." This big white man walks in and says, "Hi, how are you?" I go, "Nah." And you know? Then he goes and puts a bottle of pills right there on the counter. He said, "Take this." Well, "Excuse me, you haven't even asked me anything. I haven't said anything to you," basically. "Aren't you supposed to take a blood test [inaudible] give me medicine?" "Oh, no, take them." That's the last time I went there. Never went there again.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. So, I mean, just as we try to wrap up, I think... Just trying to get an idea, is there any [inaudible] connections between a lot of this stuff here? I mean, is there-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: I feel like these are probably issues that if there was a group like this 10 years, 20 years, 30 years ago, I think that it would probably still be the same issues. Here's racial profiling, education, future security. You know what I mean? Meaning financially, like-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: Yeah. No, not even stable. Let me at least poke my nose somewhat out the water. Don't let me just drown. I just think that these are issues that residents in Boston have been standing on their soap boxes screaming at the top of their lungs for, and it just...

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: No, not at all. Maybe it's just me, but I just feel like I'm not in... I follow politics, but I'm not really, really deep into it, and I just feel like, once you get to a certain level in being a politician, it's like they all end up dirty, or whatever they said that they were going to do, they don't end up doing. And these are the people that we vote to speak on our behalf.

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: It's like... What was it? There was one lady. She was using our helicopters for private transportation. I don't know if she was the DA or something. She got fired, but she was using the helicopter to fly her kids here and personal-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: And like thousand-dollar dinners and just extravagant lifestyle. Meanwhile, she was supposed to do these things and never did. And then we vote somebody else, and it's just like a domino effect. So, I feel like all these questions have been brought up before. So, what's going to change with us bringing it up now?

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: It seems like we do not seem to have our priority right, our priority straight. As I was listening to her, I was reflecting on how much money we spent every day in Afghanistan, and yet, at home, people are suffering like crazy just to make ends meet. I heard that, if I'm correct, that the US spent like 300 million per-

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: No, in 1979, we sent our troops over there, and we told the CIA... When the Soviets went to Afghanistan and went outside their borders, we told CIA people, operatives to then Afghans, "and we'll give you a billion. If that's not enough, we'll give you more." So, it's way over a million.

nodes.speaker: Raphael
nodes.words: And at home, we have the opioid crisis, and we can't invest money into that to help the citizens of this country.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. Well, I'm going to let that be the last word. Well, thank you for taking your time. I'll be able to let you know at some point when this stuff gets put on the system [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Pamela
nodes.words: Where is this going, like to people at that statehouse or the mayor, or is this just like a demo and you guys want to see how it-

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Welcome to one of the Real Talk for Boston conversations. Thank you for responding to your invites and joining the network of voices and conversations that are happening across the city. We invited you to this gathering by asking you to think of one pressing question you have about the future of city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to knowing it will matter.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: I will now begin recording the conversation, and I need to share three important items of information with you before we do instructions. First, the purpose of this conversation, we want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across the device neighborhood, political, cultural, et cetera, and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates and future mayor and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations have focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience rather than entertaining or entering the conversation with your positions on the upcoming election or specific candidates.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: We are doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve the understanding of one another. Secondly, I want to address that what will happen to the recording of this conversation. Following our meeting today, the recording will be discarded, and the audio will become a part of the collection of conversations. This conversation... [inaudible].
