This conversation along with other conversations that are taking place throughout the city will be shared with members of the Real Talk For Change team, and others who have participated in conversations through the Local Voice Network, which is also LVN. LVN is a web based tool for accessing and exploring conversation. LVN system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads them both the transcript and the audio recorded into the Explorer[two]. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns. What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change, Boston to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Networks, whose mission is to foster conversations and communities and the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations and in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from one another's conversation and to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, allow others to speak for themselves, share the time, allow others to finish speaking, take turns, stay curious, ask honest questions, pause, take time for reflection, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, notifications and put your phone on silent. My apologies, doing that now.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: If you need to take a moment, take a break, let the facilitator know, it's just four of us so you can just get up and leave. All right, is everyone okay with the guidelines? All right, so now we're going to begin with a censoring activity. For the ease of the conversation, we're going to use a modified circle process, where each person will take a term. I'm posting... Sorry, I'll help transition us from the person to the next. So I'll go and then I will go in the circle. So we'll do a quick round of introductions. So we're going to do this thing a check in is called pies. So it's going to have your first name, where you are located right now, and one value that is important to you. And the values we'll use the pie chart, so we have physical, intellectual, emotionally and spiritual. If you feel like too, you can choose to and check in. I'll go as an example. So it's physical and intellectually, emotionally and spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So hi, my name is Quanda. I'm from the South End. And I grew up in Dorchester. And I would like to choose spiritually. I'm here spiritually, because I feel that God has brought us all together, and certain people at this time. And so with that, I check it.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Kenyetta Thurston. I was born and raised in Roxbury, but I live in Dorchester now. I'm going to say, spiritual and physical. Physical because I feel if your body's not right, you feel sluggish so you have that motivation. So it's your physical body has to be on point. Spiritual on what you Quanda, God has reasons and purposes, and He has us meeting people and seeing people you haven't yet seen in a long time.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: Hi, everyone, my name is [crosstalk] Jisca and I currently live in Grove Hall, Dorchester side. And I'm going to follow you ladies, I'm going to go with the spiritual. I do obviously, I believe that everything has a purpose. And there's already a design and so it's always my desire to follow the outline that's already been set and to be obedient to wherever it is that I am supposed to be, what I'm supposed to be.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: My name is Ben or Benedict. I'm originally from Hyde Park. But I'm living in Jamaica Plain. I'm from Boston. And I would say I'm definitely going to follow the spiritual side, I truly believe that as a person of color, as a Black man, as a gay man, I feel that it's strong when I can see women of color leading spaces. I've always been inspired by when Black woman specifically can lead. And I do think it's a calling from God when I see a connection that I can add from the social aspect. A parent of a student that I work with, easy I can have a nice conversation with her and we can have that [inaudible] connection feel like a friend is bringing me into the community where I can promote my role as well. So, it's a calling from God that youths got to have conversation, like Real Talk and not just focus on distractions.

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: Good evening. My name is Debra [inaudible]. And I'm also here spiritually as well as physically. Spiritually, I'm here because I believe that we all have a purpose. We all have a purpose here. And my purpose here is to be an advocate. So physically, I need to be here and touch on the things that are around me to make that change.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: All right. It's still going on. I just want to make sure it's still going. All right. So now with that, we know who is here, we can go to the core of our conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston, how our lived experience have shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I like to invite you to think what your question about a future of Boston is, and your place in that future. You can take two minutes and write it down.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So it'd be what your question is about the future of Boston, and your place in that future. We'll take two minutes to reflect on this and then write it down somewhere, if that feels helpful. If you want to think about what experience in your life got you to this question, you can. So I'm going to ask you to share both your question and your experience. It's very important that you keep your experience personal, it has to be something that you experience directly. So your experience, and then what question you would have about the future of Boston and your place. What would your place be in that future? So you come up with a question, for example, will I be able to afford to live in Boston?

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And what brought me to that question is, my kids now, my experiences is... Where I live, I see condos going up everywhere. And I don't see any opportunity for home ownership for single moms, or just people period of a certain bracket or certain color, minorities. We're always trying to get ahead, but we're trying to get ahead, but we're still... We're so focused on just maintaining a roof over our head. Because the cost of living has gone up, but not necessarily wages. And so, with that being said, it's just home ownership, where would that be for me? So that's mine. Alright, so we will go around in a circle. Each person will share their question, and then tell the story of an experience that led them to the question. So did I do a story?

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: My question for Boston in the future is, I want to know when will people of color be able to get loans from our banks in our community? It's been, and I'm over six years old, and born in Boston, and I've know that it's been very hard to get a loan from our banks in our community, why? Why can't we get loans? Why can't we get properties? So that is my question. When is that going to change? How is it going to change? Who is going to work with us as a community to make that change? We say affordable housing, yes, I agree that yes, we need affordable housing, but what about affordable homes? What about banks lending us money?

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: So that's my question. And I remember when I was younger, going to a bank to borrow money, it was ludicrous. Impossible. So now we're still in this fight of getting money from the banks. So, Who? When? I want to see my future. I have a son, who's in his... Will be 40. It's even hard for him right now. I have a 10 year old grandson. When? At what generation will I be able to see people of color in the community be able to get money to buy homes and property? That's my question.

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: My personal experience, it has been, in the past, it was a no brainer of me getting money from a bank. It was no. And I've worked, I worked, had money in the bank, but not able to get money from the bank, where I've been banking for years and years and years. But I can't get money. I can't borrow money. So I see that has to change. That has to change. And I want to hear some of our politicians that want the votes to step up to that. [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: I'm nearing my 30s. So it's interesting, because I think my take on it, I don't know much about housing. And I think this is why I actually have this question as in, when we prioritize education for our youth? Just because I know I stayed in college in the 1930s 1920s, the redlining process was very prevalent in many communities and the education system was pretty much it. It marginalized people of color, it marginalized women, marginalized LGBTQ, all that youth. And I think education is a source of all opportunity and all growth and all wealth. So I speak from my experience, because I had the opportunity to sit in a meeting with Arne Duncan, who is the former Secretary of Education.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: And this was a meeting where students from all across the country, we sat down, we talked with him. And we just got to talk, what is our education system looking like? And I'm from Boston, Harvard's down the sheet, Wentworth, MIT, all these schools. But in my mind, and I'm actually talking with the kids that I work with now, they're juniors and seniors [inaudible] O' Bryant School. And they're like, they read these books that like, "The next day, we don't remember what we read." And it's interesting because I think that when I actually talked with Arnie Duncan, I told him straight up, I was like, "You look like you're really outstanding man. So why is it that we don't have classes on financing? Why can't we teach cooking class? Why can we teach home economic classes? Why can we not teach our youth how to make a garden? How to cook for yourself? How to buy a car? How to do these things? Why does our family members have to do this on our own and teach and teach us when."

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: I feel it makes sense in education system, we should be learning that specific fact. I mean, the weather cycle is great and all, but teach the foundations of life first and then you can proceed to electives as in like, language and... I mean, language is of course important but teach stuff on first. And it's interesting because I think that that's something education is once we're going to do it, you have to be a public school, or a private school, or a charter school to start your own curriculum. But I think that it's important to start teaching, especially Black and Brown youth, we shouldn't wait until you're in your 20s to start learning about finance. And it's unfortunate that these kids we had to learn on our own, how to do all of it. It's just not right.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: So my question is centered around accountability, what accountability measures will be put in place for the different programmings that are being offered? And my personal experience is that, we know that in the city of Boston housing has become an increasing issue as time goes by, it's not new, it's always been present. And I feel we see a lot of buildings and affordable housing units and all these things being pop up, but the demand for is still not being met. So my personal experience is I entered the lottery for one of these new buildings, and the lotteries through the city, but then once you get accepted, it then gets pushed to the property management company.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: And the property management companies have tactics in place to deter folks from actually being placed within those units. So what accountability measures are being placed for a program that's being funded by the taxpayers, that's being built by the city, and all these different things, and it's just like the ball is passed to folks that are not managing it appropriately. And in a space where there's a lot of just disorganization, and they're not being honest about things. And they're saying, "Oh, this person's rejecting it, and not creating a full picture." We're never going to be able to meet the demand. If the folks that you were doing business with, you're not making it clear to them that this is your expectation. And if you don't meet the expectation, the result is you will no longer have a contract as a property management company. And I feel just all around, there's just no accountability period for anyone.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: Folks just get to do what they want to do, they put a really great picture on, they write eloquent words, they create this whole pie chart and graphs without actually implementing any other measures or showing all the progress that was made. And no one goes back and says, "Well, we know we want to be able to audit your paperwork, we want to be able to see what it is that you're doing. We want to have conversations with folks that you've had contact with to understand what customer service has been? What process has there been? Has it been transparent? What's happening? And so as we're working to build more spaces and build more housing for folks, I would really love to see this city or the next mayor really have a handle on what is actually happening. And I know that the mayor, she or he cannot do everything by themselves, but they also have to make sure that the folks that they're appointing around them has the capacity and the ability to really go forth and prioritize this.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: Flow. So my question has a little branches off of it. So it's basically where everybody's saying about affordable housing, where is affordable housing? And is that coming back? Because affordable housing-

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: ... yeah. So with affordable housing, what was I was going to say? Affordable housing, what does that mean? It mean something different for everybody. Affordable housing means to me, me now working two jobs to pay my rent, me spending time with my child instead of always at work. And then on Saturday, I'm cramming all this quality time with my child. So that's basically what I did. There was no community and what happened to the affordable community centers, right? So and then, growing up, I grew up with my son. And basically, I had to work two jobs, just to maintain, to make sure that he... I was a single mom, make sure he was able to go into programs and go to community centers and stuff like that. But I got to work in order for him to do that. You know what I mean? And the centers wasn't cheap. The program wasn't cheap.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: And me, because I couldn't afford education, [inaudible] had the money for it, my years and... So there's another question, education versus years and your position. If I got the experience, years of experience, but I don't have the education, when does that going to count again? Just because somebody was able to afford a education doesn't mean that they have knowledge and understanding or understand the population that they're dealing with. So I couldn't get those high paying jobs, because didn't had a education, but I had the experience, you know what I mean? So it goes all the way back to the affordable housing, I would be content, if I didn't have to raise my child and make sure he was equipped.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: If I didn't have to work two jobs, it's hard trying to juggle school work and your child, you know what I mean? So, I think we need to bring back affordable housing which is really affordable to middle class people, working people because when you are working, in my experience, you can't get certain benefits, you can't get TAFDC, you can't get food stamps, snap as you all call it benefits anymore, because you are overqualified. You have to qualify first before you can get this snap. And so stuff like that helps and it benefits your child. But the working class, if we make over a certain amount, we can get that affordable housing, quote, unquote, we can get the support that other families can get. And people that, basically, I'm not going to say we don't need it. But what I'm saying is, we all need it. We all need support. We all need a hand.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: So, don't look at my income and say that it's less than somebody else that has lower income. My needs is the same as that other person. So if my needs are not being met, right? How can I afford it? So their needs is not being met by this programming to help them meet those needs. But there's no programming for us middle class. So my question is, when are we going to have affordable housing? So women, single moms don't have to work two and three jobs just to make ends meet.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Thank you. So the next part is connecting our experiences. So what I want you to do next is think back to each of the questions that everybody asked and the experiences that was just shared in the group. Find someone whose question or experience resignates with your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resignated with you, and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. I'll start, so I want to check in with Ben. I connect with you and I can share my experience with yours because growing up, finances wasn't talked around the table. When we went to work, [inaudible], there was always something to eat. But there was always her yelling or, "Do you think money grows off trees?"

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So and it was, "[inaudible 00:28:50] woman's crazy, what's she talking about?" You know what I mean? You'd come in the house throw your sneakers down, and you have the bag on the floor or whatever and that type cover. So growing up, we didn't have a conversation about savings or what IRA was or 401k plan or even Medicare, MassHealth, or health insurance. So for me, I began to teach my daughter whatever it is that I learned. So I had a job since I was what? 14. But I didn't have a real, real job and didn't realize medical and health insurance was a thing because when you turn 18 you don't really care about all that stuff. Because nobody talks to you about it. You just know you got some money. And you got to go spend your money now. And go get everything that you couldn't get, you wasn't able to buy. Now you can do it on your own.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: So when I started working a real job like for security, what does that mean? What does claim 0 means on your W-2 form, you know what I mean? So those things that I've learned through my late adult life, one, I was unable to ask questions, because I'm like, "I don't want to ask that person that question because they might think I'm stupid. You know what I mean? Or dumb." And so when I began to ask questions to better myself, I'm like, "Okay, this is what my daughter is going to go through. I need to turn around and teach her this stuff now while I'm here, so that way, she'll be able to know a little bit of something." So I'm just connecting with you on that experience, how come financial literacy wasn't taught in the schools?

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: I mean, home-ec was and I think [inaudible] was, so how to build a [inaudible] and then cook. I develop a love of cooking out of going to Timothy Middle School, when home-ec was a thing. It's not anymore? So I agree. Basic stuff like financial literacy should be put into the curriculum. And as well as civic engagement, voting, why is it important to vote? The three, was it... Judicial systems. It's not just you vote for the president, no. This is broken up into so many groups, if you put one good president, and you got to go back and get the rest of his cabinet and two.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: And I'm still learning that as as I get older, like, "Oh, it's not just about that, is who his elected official is that's representing him. Who will we send into the State House that represent us? Who's that person?" Because that person might have some way off ideas, like, "Let's charge everybody 10 cents. Let's bring the bag." And we didn't know to think of it, but he's been in there for 10,15 years, might as well just continue to check off his name. But what is he actually doing for us? So that just connected with but... All right, and then that's mine [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: Ben, I most definitely related on what you were saying about finances because that's, I believe, the start from when I was talking about finances and banks lending money. Maybe if a lot of us had that knowledge. Maybe some of us would have owned homes and property. But we didn't have that knowledge. And like I was saying, I'm over 60 years old, and know that I have that knowledge of finances. No, as you were saying, Miss. [inaudible], you were saying that no one talked about it. It's so true.

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: They didn't even talk about checking or savings. I never know what checking account, savings account. I didn't know that until I was in my 20s. When I got out of high school, I got a job working at Fidelity Mutual Funds. And that's when I learned some of those things. But no, it wasn't taught to me in school. But there are schools and most of these schools are not in our inner city that teaches young people on finances. And that's where our officials have to have our school committees to implement these these courses into our school. Finances, which is so true. Because if we're not educated, then how do we know?

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: How do we know if we're not educated? Because education comes first. So you were right on point when you spoke on that and you were also [miss Burrell] and I can't... Can you tell me your name again?

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: Jisca, it's a pretty name, Jisca. And also you brought a lot to my memory when you talked about housing and having people stand accountable on who's making decisions and property managers. I'm going to some stuff like that right now where I live. And people need to be accountable. These property managers have to be accountable. I worked in a shelter, actually, I'm on leave right now. And I seen a whole lot of things going in this shelter, who got apartment first? People have to be accountable. We need to have people... In my model, because I call myself a whistle blower. I blow a whistle. If I see it, I'm blowing it. If I see it, I'm blowing it. And because people have to be... We have to make people accountable.

nodes.speaker: Debra
nodes.words: And I was very... When you said that, numbers like two is so right. Making people accountable. I apply for an apartment, I'm not going to say where it is, but they told me, "Oh Miss. [inaudible], you got the apartment. And someone in the management office told me a different story." So my belief was they put their friends, bump me off and put their friends in that unit where I was waiting for years for. So countability we need to start keeping people accountable. Yes, and since you were talking about-

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: I'm going to add to the idea. I think Debra and [inaudible 00:3 7:05]talked about the housing. I think that's the most important thing. And as a parent, when you talked about juggling work, school, and raising kids. That's something that not a lot of people that I know are... They don't have that knowledge of how to balance all of that together and also get a house. Usually, I mean, people in my generation, or at least or friends or my circle, they're just getting housing and trying to... If you scroll on Instagram, Facebook, it's like, "Okay, who has the latest job? Who has the latest features or car?" But our parents weren't worried about that, they were worried about is this the house I want? Is this is this rent good? I remember, my family was moving from... Obviously, when I was growing up, I didn't care where I lived, it was whatever it was good enough for me.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: But we moved from our apartment to a house. And that in and of itself, was the greatest thing for my family. It's now we have a house. And the idea of home ownership. I don't think people in the inner city understand that. You can literally, if you are a good parent, you can be looking at your children, and they won't see the suburbs or the rural areas and be like, "I want that." Though we see on TV, and understand that that's the life, but they won't look up to you and be like, "We need to have a house." But you are thinking, "We need a house. This is what I want. I want to create generational wealth." And that's something that I think people in my circle didn't grow up with that idea. It was just everything's here, we have an apartment, we have our household, we have education.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: But the idea of now getting affordable housing is something that is coming to the forefront of my mind. And how do you make sense of getting affordable housing? Where's the right place to do it? And thinking about not just getting a house but if you want to have a family, how do you now choose the right location for a school. How do you choose it, where you have good hospitals near you? And I think it's something that goes back to education, not just finances, though we need to understand how does housing happen? How do you make sure someone is held accountable if they're not hiring their friends to get this in the housing? How do you make sure everything connects and fits. And that's why I take it back to education, because if we're not just learning about 400 years of history, or the weather cyber, which is sometimes... It's important, but if we all are at the same understanding of what is going on our society, and I think you've talked about civic engagement.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: Voting, we don't talk about that in school at all. And it doesn't make any sense because there are so... You'll see signs of this mayor, this person for councilor, it's like, "Who is this person?" We're seeing these people every single day, but you don't understand your role. And I think it's also how to not only accountability for people who are in places in power, but how do we take accountability for ourselves, because we are citizens who have so much power. We have the power to vote, but not only that, we have the power to learn and make active change, to create community spaces, sit down and do it. But how do we understand our role? And it's because we're not taught at all. We're not taught that we have one. And we need to know that we do have one.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: Thank you for that. For me, Miss Debra, your story resonated with me when it comes to banking and loans and financing. So when I was growing up, when we first came to America from Haiti, my parents, we lived in Everett. And so I went to the Everett school systems. And once you get to high school, there was actually... Everett Cooperative Bank is within the high school. And that was a class that you take. And I took the class for two years. And so you go through the class, they teach you everything about banking, you actually do banking within the schools, kids have accounts and all that, once you graduate, they then position you into the actual branch outside, where you now have a job as you graduate, and you're going through the whole banking system. And so that's something that since in Boston, I've been trying to figure out every corner you turn around, there's a bank, somewhere, but I don't see that being implemented at all.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: And a big question for me is that we've been talking about entrepreneurs and businesses and loans, but there hasn't been any discussions on personal. You're building these homes, you're building these spaces, we can't afford them because we can't get loans. So where's the disconnect? Where are the conversations that are being had to know that everything is interconnected? So if you want us to be able to access the generational wealth, typically, in order for us to access it, we need to get a loan in order for us to make that purchase. And we know that through the banking system, it's very predatory practices, it's just absolute. Structural racism within the banking system is just out of this world. And I think that that's one of the ways that we need to make sure that we can start to attack some of the challenges and issues that we're having in our communities, you see more check cashing places than you actually see banks.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: And then the banks that are opened, there's no sense of community, you can't go in there, there's no one that really knows your name, no one's actually sitting there to try to figure out what they can screen you for, what products they have that would work for you. It's just taking your money and then not investing into any of the programming around you. And investing in anything that's beneficial for you. But meanwhile, you're giving them your hard earned funds constantly. And that's something that I would really love to see an elected, at least try to acknowledge or convene the banking systems in all the different places that we have, to start to have conversations on how do they better approach people of color, and making sure that the products that they have available work for us, and if our credit scores are not good enough, or we're not meeting the requirements, what programs do you have in place to help us get there?

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: How can you usher us into a new space where we can walk into your space, and be able to say, "I'd like a loan, please." Actually, we don't even need to be able to ask for a loan, you should be coming to us because you go everywhere else, and you send fliers to X, Y and Z and you say, "You're pre approved for this amount of money." But how do we improve that line of communication and the ability for us to feel we can go to banks and be able to access the funds like we know a lot of other people can.

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: So I connect with everybody as well. And what keeps coming to my mind is, who is it for? Who is all this for? We do have banks, we do have these ideas in place, right? But who is it for? Because connecting with Ben, you're not educating us at a young age, you're not educating us to be able to get a loan, you know what I mean? And to know that something isn't right within these systems, you know what I mean? So, who is this all for? Because it's not for us. If this is our community that we live in, tailor it to our community. So that's what just comes into my mind. We don't get educated... We have these things implemented, but we don't get the knowledge to how to handle it. How do we walk in it? How do we deal with it? How are we able to... Okay If we do get that house, how do we maintain it? If we do get that a loan, how do we maintain it? We do not get taught how to maintain what we do have, you know what I mean?

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: And it's because we're so busy trying to obtain some things that we can't be taught. Because we're trying to hold on to the little bit we have, but if we were taught as a young age, so that goes to back to me relating with Ben, we're taught at a young age about finances, the basic life skills of learning how to cook, learning how to saw, learning how to change tires. And I learned these things in school. We had these things in school, but as the years went by, what happened? They got cut. These things got cut from the system, what just go, what's you saying? We have Boston High who who did something like what you did. There's no more Boston High. Madison is the only school that I know, vocational school right now. But how many people can actually get into that? So it's, who is this stuff for? We cut a lot of things back, and then you expect us to have the same results.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: Thank you. All right, so now we're going to just continue to draw connection and talk about what we're hearing and people's experiences. And whoever is ready can start us off. So what are you hearing and people's experiences around the table?

nodes.speaker: Kenyetta
nodes.words: What I'm hearing from everybody's experiences, like Debra's experience, she's been overlooked. And a lot of times, we do feel like we're overlooked. So we're not going to go become that entrepreneur because we're afraid to go to that bank, because the bank is always telling minorities, "No." And so I just feel... What I'm hearing is, why are we overlooked? Why is it that same opportunity, that is for somebody else in a different community given, but the opportunity for us within our own community, Black and Brown people, it's not there, you know what I mean? We all talk about that door that is right there, that that an invisible door, we need that door to be gone. So that's what I'm hearing, that door that is stopping us from being able to live a quality life needs to be cut down.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: I would say, the idea of that disunity in the community, and that's not on our fault. Because within Black and Brown communities, you have people immigrating from Haiti, Cameroon, DR, Tanzania, wherever, and they're already doing that work to come from your home country to come from back home, and then enter and decide we have to learn a new language. And then you have to raise your child, you have to figure out what is society? What is community? And that's the idea of why is it feel everybody has to do it alone? Why is the community... I'm not saying that it's up to the community, because there should already be systems in place, because due to a [inaudible] racism, we're already marginalized by this.

nodes.speaker: Benedict
nodes.words: But why is it that a single mom has to feel she's doing everything on her own? And there's many single moms in that situation. And why is it feel they have to go and rescue themselves out of that situation and connect with other single moms and then [inaudible] altogether. So it's the idea of unity within the community is already there. Well, why is it feel we have to do so much, go extra mile all the time?

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: What I'm hearing, what I heard from these conversations, is there's a duality to it, where we know that they are oppressive systems in place that hinders us from having the quality of life and being able to thrive and not just survive and be able to just be who we are created to be without any hindrance like we know a lot of other folks that have different tones, skin tones have that opportunity, but I also am hearing the accountability piece relative to ourselves. At what point do we take our power and our choice back to ensure that the systems that we know are here actually start to work for us? We are living in a digital age now where we have access to YouTube and articles and all these other things. And so how much are we taking advantage of these critical information to help us to frame our understanding of what's happening in our communities?

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: And so we are under 400 years of oppression where it's a constant catch up, and we haven't had an opportunity to once just usher into a space where we can finally be, but at the same time, in reverence and honor to our ancestors and folks that came before us, the tireless work that they've put out before us and becoming the first and dismantling here, mantling that, when do we take that back and prioritize it and put it at the very forefront? Because when desegregation occurred, it wasn't for us, it was to access our money. Because they knew that within a Black community, we are one of the biggest spenders. So what we had is never going to be equal because it wasn't with the intention of creating this for us to thrive and be, it was created just to give us a glimpse and make us feel we're a part when we're not. Our money is a part, our money is counted.

nodes.speaker: Jisca
nodes.words: But when it comes to proper education, and housing, and healthcare and everything else that other folks have lighter skin tones have an opportunity and access to, we are denied that. And so it's just important for us to recognize what has been put up against us and figure out how do we call forth those same spirits and power that was bestowed upon us to continue to deconstruct and really abolish this nasty system that's built off of genocide, basically.

nodes.speaker: Quanda
nodes.words: All right. We're slowly reaching to the end of our conversation. But before we do that, I'd like us to listen to... This is on Zoom. I don't have this Zoom. So let's skip for that. So there was a video about people initiate conversations and just snippets of people, just how you're doing here now. So that's if you're on Zoom, I don't have that. So we're going to wrap up. We'll quickly go around and share something that you'll be taking with you. If you have any closing thoughts you'd like to share or other general reflections on the conversation, or if you had any questions in general, just a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts that you shared, these recordings will be transcribed, indexed and shared with the FP team. You will receive an email from us when all the conversations are ready to review on the LVN platform. There's everybody's emails written down on the cards. All right. And now,

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: They're saying, "Recording in progress now." Hi everyone. I'm Ceasar McDowell and I want to thank you so much for participating in one of the many conversations we're having around the city called Real Talk for Change. Our effort here is really to create these small scale conversations throughout Boston, to really allow people to talk about both the future they see for the city, and to really talk about the experiences they have, and what it means for them to be in this city.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: As I'm sure, either Fran or [Zakiya] has told you, we have the ability to connect all these conversations together, so while we're doing things in small intimate spaces, we have the technology and the support to connect them together. And our hope is through, by having these voices of your voices and other people's voices, we can shape not only the dialogue and debate that's going on around the election, but we can use these to help build a sense of accountability for what happens even after the election, and going forward. So that as people are talking about proposals, what they want to do, we can juxtapose those, of course, with what people are experiencing in this city.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What we're doing around election is really just, we're using the election as a launch pad for a longer term project, so this is not just about the election. It really is about building a new, what we call a civic infrastructure, in the City of Boston. One that enables people to have their experiences and their life cold, and controlled and owned by the community. For that last piece, we are building a collaboration among a number of community based organizations, so they are actually the owners of this information coming out of here, and we're just serving, right now, as a place to store it until that relationship is put in place. And we're actively working on that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: This is a facilitated conversation. It does have a script and a particular structure, so we're going to go through that structure and that script, for each of you. Zakiya's going to be my observer today, watching me, to make sure I do okay. We've been doing this for a while. But I want to just tell you a little bit about what happens here, in the technical sense.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So we have this conversation, it's recorded. The recording itself, once this conversation is over, we take the audio and we throw the video. We don't keep the video part at all, this is all an audio based experience. It's uploaded into a system we call [Levin], it's basically a technology stack. There's a transcription made of it, and then that transcription is reviewed by people on our team, to make sure everything is right, in terms of spelling, people's names. Sometimes the transcription gets things wrong, so it's corrected. And then the Levin technology itself, is able to go through, read the transcript, and really discern different things that are emerging in the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So now, you'll be able, in a couple of days, after this conversation, go to the site where we store this, and you can see this conversation. You can see the things that came up on it. You can click on a theme and listen to where that came up in a conversation, and who spoke it. So everyone who's actually participating in a conversation, can go view their own conversation. And all these conversations are in a protected site, so that everyone who participates in a conversation can see all their conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: But the second part of what we're doing is, going through all those conversations and highlighting the questions and the experiences. And then we have a team that includes some people from here at MIT, some community fellows, who are reading through those and looking for the themes, the tags and the issues that are emerged in that. Then we're taking all of that and building what we call a public dashboard. What we mean by a public dashboard, and outward facing thing that anybody can see. That really shows what neighborhoods people come from that participated in this, which topics did they talk about, and then the ability to actually listen to the transcript of that particular piece of the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: As a member and participating in this, one of the things you can do is you can decide not to use your real name in this conversation. You can use a pseudonym if you want to, and if you're going to do that, and I'll check with you in a minute about that, we'll have you change your name actually, in Zoom. That's so that anybody who's referring to you on this call, will be referring to you by your pseudonym, instead of your real name, so that is perfectly okay.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I want to read something to you, just around permissions and if that's okay, then we'll go forward. As a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent to Real Talk for Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission, which is what I just spoke about. You also understand that the conversations will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, that's what I mean by the private collection, that protected connection, whose mission is foster conversations in the communities and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another. We will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: In addition, you understand that while your whole transcript will not be made public, it will stay protected. Excerpts from your transcript, from your particular conversation, either a question you raise or a story you share, could be made public. If you keep your name in the conversation, then your name will travel with anything we excerpt from your conversation. If you choose to use a pseudonym, then it's your pseudonym that will go, and not your real name.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah. That's a great question. [inaudible], do you mind if I just get the rest of the approvals, and then I'll come back and answer that question?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Can you change your name on your Zoom thing to Jane Doe, or do you want me to do it?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you all for giving me permission. Before we get into the whole conversation thing, I wanted to go back to the question Jane asked. Jane asked, really, what's going to happen with all of this and what's the impact we're looking for. Is that correct?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We don't have a theme. It's interesting, we're not theme oriented. What we are is, experience oriented, so the themes will be really related to what it is that you bring up, to the structure of the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Cool. Let's get started. The first thing I want to say, like in all conversations like this, and all of you have had these experiences before, we have a set of rules about people speaking for themselves and allowing others to speak. Being mindful of the time and making sure others have the opportunity. So before we get started actually, in the conversation, what I want to do is ... We have a little exercise that we do, as a way of having you introduce yourselves to each other, because you need to know who you're in the room with. That would be a good thing. We call it PIES, P-I-E-S.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: This is the way it works, Zakiya is actually going to model it for you, so you see how it goes. In Pies, what happens is you check in, and the way you check in with everyone is you say ... And I'm going to put this in the chat. How you well you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually. And then after you check in on those four things, the last thing you say is, "With that, I'm in." So then basically, you tell us your name, what neighborhood you're from, and then how are you doing; physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually, and "With that, I'm in." So Zakiya's going to model for us.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Good evening. I'm Zakiya Alake. I live on the Dorchester-Roxbury line, right near Upham's Corner. Physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually, I am in a really good space right now. I got reconnected to the family nurturing center, one of our community partners for Real Talk for Change, and I was able to work with them on a proposal to address food and security, that the City of Boston had let requests for proposals out. Anyway, it's due tomorrow, and we're already finished with it, and that's the first time in a long time when my heart wasn't beating fast because I got a huge deadline, and I just feel really good about it. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Very good. Thank you so much, Zakiya. The only adjustment I'd make to what Zakiya did is to check in on each one of those individually.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What I'm going to do, and the way we're going to do this, and this is kind of the way we're going to run everything today, I'm going to put an order for you to speak in the chat, and that's how we will go forward. I forgot to put the privacy label for it. I'm so sorry. Okay. With that, since Warren's not here, Sedric, you're first.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: Hi, everyone. My name's Sedric. I currently live in Hyde Park. Physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually, I'm doing good. There's always something to complain about, but to me, I'm just still alive and I'm growing, so I'm blessed.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's good. Again, I'll just say to the rest of you, as you go forward, think about each one of those words and check on each one individually. You don't have to group them all together. We want to know really, how you are, in those different spaces. And I think you can see the order, in the chat, in which you speak. So it looks like Jane is next.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Hey, everyone. I identify as Jane. I would say, today I'm doing well. It's been a busy day. I kind of like the rain, so I'm a little relaxed. Physically, I haven't ate any dinner yet. I've only had breakfast, so I'm a little hungry. Intellectually, I'm doing well. I had class. I teach on Tuesdays and Thursdays, so it's been well there. Emotionally, I'm excited. I got a show coming up, about a book that I'm going to introduce to the world, so I'm excited about that, emotionally, and a little anxious. Spiritually, I'm blessed and I'm doing okay. I would say. I want to to pass this. With that, I am in. And I'll pass it on.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Hey, there. I'm Becky. Right now I'm living in Brighton. I think physically, I'm doing okay. I woke up pretty early with this staff retreat at my work, so that was exciting. That was good. Physically, emotionally. Is that next?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I would say, honestly, I'm on a down beat. To be honest, I'm not very happy about how the preliminary elections turned out, but I think, just moving forward. But otherwise, things have been okay. Spiritually, things have been good; spending time in the community, with my church, with some friends and just being touched by the Holy Spirit and all that. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. I see that Warren has joined us. Warren, we will ... I'm going to let Matthew go, and then I'll catch you up.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Okay. I got a Bluetooth in, so I don't know how it work. I literally just got it yesterday. Physically, I'm doing great. Every morning I wake up in the morning, I get at least 15, 20 minutes of exercise in, to make sure I get the energy pumping and all that good stuff. Intellectually, I'm doing superb. I just cracked open a new book that pretty much allows me to connect with myself mentally and spiritually, so emotionally, I am intact.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: That brings me to spiritually. I am superb, great, intact; head, shoulders, knees, all that good stuff. And I'm excited about being here. This gives me an opportunity to connect with the community, and most importantly, one of my clients today was happy with my service that I provided for them, so that is a one up. That's pretty much it, and with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: A couple things I need to repeat, that I went through with everyone else. The most important one is, the permission to record this conversation. We are recording it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And there are two things I want you to know about that. One is that, the transcription and the audio of this will be in a protected collection, on the Living Voices Network, that you'll have access to. And then the other is, the group is working on making meaning of all the conversations. They take excerpts of your conversation, the question that you ask or an experience that you share, and it could show up on the public dashboard. So we want you to know that, and make sure with that understanding, you're still okay with being recorded.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Last piece is, if you want to, you can actually have a pseudonym, if you don't want to use your real name. But if you're fine with using your real name, that's fine also.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. Now for the last one. Everyone was just going around, introducing themselves. The way we introduce ourselves is; say our name, where we're from, and then I'm going to put into the chat, we asked you to check in, what we call PIES. This is just checking in on how you're doing physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: I'm Warren. I'm from the Grove Hall area, Dorchester. Spiritually, I feel fine. I'm happy to be alive. I feel like when you see COVID deaths and you watch TV, you're just happy that you can take a breath and you feel sorry for the folks that isn't here. It's just stress between, I guess the violence of Boston, not just COVID, but other than that, spiritually, I feel fine. I think everything else is fine, so far. Just have to remain strong and stay connected.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: I think all those are good. Intellectually, I think I'm okay. You lose a step as you get older, but you learn more as you go along.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you everyone. And part of the reason that we do that is, we're sitting in the room with people we may or may not know and we're all coming to these spaces carrying a lot of stuff, and just to acknowledge that. That we're human beings and we're complex, and we have a lot going on. And even with all of that, knowing that we can be present, and that's really what the point of that is.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: As I said, this conversation has really three main parts. We're going to do the first one now, and then there is the second part. The first one is structure, the second part is interactions between you and the third part is really the close out. So I'm going to take you to the first part, which actually has two questions embedded in it. You might want to write something down from what I'm getting ready to say right now, there's a prompt to this. Some people find it very helpful to just kind of write it down, and some people like to kind of keep it in their head, just the way they work.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The first question, I'm going to drop it in the chat for you, is this; what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future. This is asking you to think about where you think the city's going, where you think you will be, how that future, where the city is going, how that's going to relate to you. But we want you to put it in the form of a question. Make sense?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to give you all a minute or two, just to think about what that question would be for you. One that really resonates for you, and is really true for you, about the future of this city, and your place in it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I certainly can. In one conversation, the question was raised ... I won't give it verbatim, I get it wrong a little bit. But the question was, "Will this city finally be a place that treats Black men and boys with dignity".

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Now, you've got this question. There's a second part to this. It never would be easy, with just one part. Couldn't do that. The second part is this, is that, questions don't come from nowhere. They become because of things you've wondered about, things you've read, or more importantly for us, of things you've experienced in your life.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So our second question for is, what's the experience in your life that's gotten you to that question. You have this question, but it's come from somewhere, so what we want you to be able to do is think about what's either A, a particular experience, a summary of a set of experiences you personally have had. Embodying an experience that you know, really, a part of why you have this question. And then, what we're going to do is, ask you to tell a story about that experience, when you come back around.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're going to give you a minute or so think about that. What experience, in your life, is really connected to that question. This is not a time to deal with things that are a little bit abstract, or "I read somewhere this ...," things like that. But it's about what you, and your own embodied self, have really experienced.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. I'm going to assume they're ready to go. Here's how I'm going to do this, I'm going to put the order for you to speak, in the chat. Here's what I want you to do, first person goes. They're going to tell us their question, and then they're going to tell us the story, the experience in their life, that got them to that question. When they finish, we'll just take two seconds, just calm space. Take it in, and then the next person is going to go automatically. I'm not going to call on you, you just go automatically. So you see the order in the chat, and with that, we can start.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The first is, what is question about the future of America, and the second one, what's your story that got you to that question.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: My main question is, who is going to live in all these new apartment buildings that are popping up around the city. I really think, particularly luxury apartment buildings. My other question's, will I be able to live where I live now, or would I have to worry about being displaced. Right now, I'm renting out of my aunt's, friend's house. So rent is good, it's cheap and they're ... I live right in the border of where Brighton meets Allston, so if you know anything about the geography, right along Western Avenue and Market Street, so right at the intersection of Cambridge and Watertown. A lot of luxury apartment buildings have just been popping up. Different, old bars or restaurants that have been there for 20 years or so, they've been closing down and then within like, six months, these buildings are coming up.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: What prompted me to ask that question is one, living here in the past few years, and have been. Two, reading books and hearing people's stories about being evicted, and because some law would be plighted or it might not be deemed as safe, in the area. I'm just thinking about the West End. I know that was a long time ago, but I know this has been a history in this city, and we're surrounded by ... Not slowly at all, but quite steadily, it seems like the geography is changing. There used to be a lot of old buildings, old houses built maybe 100 years ago or so, and some of them are being taken down, or nearby restaurants are being taken down, and then it's starting to look more and more, for lack of a better word, gentrified. I don't want this to be like a Mr. Fredricksen situation, if you saw the movie Up, where it's like this little old man's house in the middle of this huge city that just built up around it. That scares me.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I also work on Western Avenue, so at the intersection of right where Harvard is starting to spill into Boston. I think they already bought up most of the property, under a secret name. So it's hearing stories about the residents, by living there and just seeing again, all of these apartment complexes and then hearing that there will be research centers popping up. Like, "I can't afford this. I can't afford living here," if I would need to resort to that. And I know people in the Allston-Brighton, we can't do that either, so it's like, "Who's going to be there then". Is that good enough?

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Sedric. The two questions I have for the future of Boston and my place in that future is, will I be able to own a home, and will I be able to live in Boston any longer. One of those questions were because I'm a native of Boston my whole life, and I've been evicted three times, actually. Just because the landlords more like slum lords. They barely work on their house, but want top penny. Charge you like 2900 for a three bedroom apartment, but stuff wrong with it, so it's kind of sad that ...

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: I just know I have it far from the worst, because I started looking at apartments during COVID, they're terrible. People don't really work on their houses, but they're charging so much for a two bedroom or three bedroom, it's like, "Who's going to pay for that? It's 2700 for a two bedroom apartment that has problems or is molded, and people are just paying," although it kind of speaks to how we run. There's nobody checking the order of stuff. It's like a game of Monopoly, whoever has the most money is winning. As long as you can pay your way, you're pretty much set.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Yeah, I didn't know that he was done. Do you want to ask him if he was done, or if he has anything more to say or ...

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you for that, Sedric and Becky. My question would be, will Massachusetts be able to meet this new Green Deal Agreement that they made, and it kind of embodies what the previous two already mentioned. That we do have these old houses and if these old houses don't ... I believe that Massachusetts, around 100,000 houses have to be switched to this new electric grid, as opposed to burning fossil fuels and oil, the way that we are right now.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: And if they don't, then it's going to trickle down to the agriculture industry, and I do work close to the agriculture industry, and a lot of people don't think about the agriculture industry cause we live in comfortability at this point in time, where you just go to the grocery store, and you're just anticipating that fruit or that vegetable, or whatever that you eat, is going to be there. But you have to come to the realization that, if a lot of these houses that they promised or agreed upon with this new Green Deal doesn't happen, then the carbon footprint and carbon emission is going to trickle down to the agriculture industry and a lot of the individuals that I work around, are already squeezing their costs, because some do cut corners, but that is to feed themselves. If they can't feed themselves, or if what they're growing ... And a lot of them are switching from produce.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Not fully switching, but they're going to hemp and they're going to cannabis, because I guess by the graces of God and everybody here in Massachusetts, to give credit where credit's due, did vote for cannabis and hemp, so we do have cannabis and hemp, and that's a profitable ... It's a cash crop in the agriculture industry, so if they don't get the produce and the cash crop, and it's not profitable, they're not going to do it. And if they're not going to do it, I hope everybody in Massachusetts has a green thumb, or knows someone with a green thumb, that can pretty much grow themselves.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: The worry that I do have is, if we do not meet what we agree to, when it comes to this Green Deal, and making sure that the houses, the city most importantly, don't meet the agreement, then it's just going to end up affecting myself, my clients, and everybody here and everybody in Massachusetts, to where you're going to end up eating genetically modified GMO produce. And who knows if it's grown in a laboratory. If you can do an example, look how the vaccine kind of rolled out and it was kind of like, flip of a coin.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: That ends up happening and you don't do real tests on the produce, and if you actually take the time out of your day and look up how they actually do test your produce, all the way down to your meat, a lot of testing is done. Whether or not it is beneficial to your health, they don't say, they just say it doesn't affect you. And as long as it doesn't kill anybody, a certain number of individuals, then they really don't why say anything. It's on the shelf and everybody just go about they merry way.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Once again, this just something to think about, knowing that if we don't meet what we agree to, then it affects everybody here. That's all I have to say. Thank you for listening.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Matthew, I going to ask you something. We really appreciate everything you said. At the very beginning, as you were talking, you were really kind of grounding this in something you've kind of witnessed and seen yourself, and experience. Then you kind of moved out a little bit further away, to an analysis of that. I'm just wondering, can you ground us back in a story that you, yourself have experienced, that relates to what you were saying.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: I'll give an example. I work with a mother and daughter, they have their own produce farm and it's down in Rochester. When I mention Rochester, a lot of people think New York, but it's by New Bedford, so I'll just mention New Bedford, to dial it in. And they're doing produce, so they're doing a great job doing produce, but they're not making the amount of money that they need to make. Cause number one, they're not getting the capital that they deserve.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Minority people of color not receiving the capital, now if that's something you want to dial into, we can dial into that also. A lot of us don't even know the resources that we do have available, and those resources that we do have available, they're not willing to give us exactly what we need, as opposed to other races. With that being said, we have to cut a lot of our costs, and when we cut a lot of our costs, we really can't, because we have to hold on to every single penny that we do have. So we have to get into the cannabis industry.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: But like I said, that ended up being the good thing at this point in time. But that does affect the entirety of our way of living, our way of getting back and forth to work, and it's a good drive to go out there to the agriculture land, but once again, it affects not only ... Just our every day way of life.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Thank you, Matthew and everyone else before me. I think this is a really big question. I'm always thinking about solutions and ways that Boston matters to me, because I'm born and raised in Boston. My question is, how will the city's educational system help preserve the history and the historical landmarks of the people in the neighborhoods, also, their legacy be preserved and celebrated. How do we use this to educate people about our people and their values?

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: I think this leads to having more ownership and more say in what we do in our communities. I think there are important folks, important leaders, people who don't have enough voice, I would say, or enough ownership with what they're doing and how they're creating community and leading. So my question is really, how do we start to preserve the legacy and educate people in the educational system as well, but also start to educate people in the neighborhoods about the values and the landmarks, so that we could have more control over what we do. And more vision about what we want to see next, with the people who've built it for us.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Actually, I'm going to ask you to go back and tell us what did you experience in your life that made that question so important to you?

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: The question is important to me because I'm born and raised in Boston, and I went to a Catholic school, so we learned about our values. And when I was growing up in Boston, we just had a lot more of integrity about our space, and principal about who we were and where we came from. I always learned to respect my elders, and always look out for other people who come before me, so those are the people who I work with it or I try to learn from now. And I feel like that stuff is getting erased.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Not a lot of students that I teach now, they know nothing about their leaders. There's not enough of us out there becoming young leaders for the youth, so it's about really painting a bigger picture for the future. I know this because I'm in Upham's Corner community, and I feel like a lot of the people who I feel are leaders, are not represented enough to be able to carry through with their legacy, and with the moves that they want to make, because we don't have a place where the vision is held, like archived of all this stuff. Where we can say, "This is proven to be done and we need these people back again." I just think that there should be more say. A lot of people should have a better say, more voice around what they want to see in their community. But we have to preserve the legacy and also bring that back into the educational system, which will hopefully amplify the historical landmarks that we have, so they can't be erased. I want to advocate for that more.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: I think there's a lot of neighborhood legacy. I want to advocate for that, just try to make that something before it just disappears, and it's not the same anymore. Create a better community by educate with the youth too, about where they're at, because the community is special too. And I feel like a lot of us don't know, because we're not walking outside enough, or talking to our neighbors enough and stuff. Doing that just makes you feel like you belong in the community, and we need to keep that feeling, instead of having it feel like there's no community, or it doesn't feel like the same community.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: That would be my ... I would say I would pass it along because ... This is a really big question. There's a lot about education, about safe space, and about preserving the legacy of our people. I think all of that is important for Boston, to be as rich as it really is, in terms of the people, because they're people in roots. And also, they're people that are hidden. So those people will come out and celebrate their communities more if we can just educate more people about what's going on, because there are people out there.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: Thank you. That was beautiful. I think for me, my question would be, when did Boston start moving away from home ownership to home development, that was inclusive of everybody. What I think really led to home ownership being too expensive and not inclusive to everybody, is really when Chuck Turner and Dianne Wilkerson got indicted. I felt like they were the last two stopgaps, to really kind of say, "Everybody's not being included, especially Black folks." So when I see everything moving up, and you're seeing the new buildings and new development in the city, I see the conspiracy unfold where home ownership looks like the MCAT scores for schools, where certain folks, usually Chinese folks and White folks score way above Latinos and Blacks, and other folks. So I think that ties into home ownership, how much you make to survive in the city. That's usually not minority folks that are doing good on the MCAT scores, or will be inclusive into home buying in the city.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: So when I see the city changing a certain way, I feel like it's kind of, people's duties to make sure that minority ownership in the city is inclusive of all people. I feel like that's an issue that I have within myself, is helping other folks have home ownership one day, if I could help folks get there. And that's what I have.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Warren, I'm going ask you, just kind of like I did with this last one a little bit ... You started out this way, and I want to kind of get you to be a little bit more that way about, in your own personal life and what you've experienced ... What in your own experience kind of got you to that question?

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: I live in a condo. I'm off Boulder Street, it's on a dead end, and I realize how lucky I was to buy when I got it. It's kind of like a bit of luck, a bit of savvy, and everybody doesn't have that luck or that type of savvy, and it shouldn't be this hard to own something in Boston. Because my mother's a home owner and her parents are home owners, I saw how it goes, I saw how I could get there, but that map, I guess it wasn't inclusive of everybody.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: I had a friend and my friend was renting. He goes, "We had to move from this place that was $900 a month for three bedrooms, and now we're in Roxbury, paying 1700 for a two bedroom, and he wants to go up in two months to 1900." I had to kind of sit him down. He's older than me, and I had to say to him, "Dude, what you're paying for rent, I'm paying for mortgage. You and your people have enough money to have a mortgage."

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: It was kind of a hard conversation to have, because he's kind of looking at me and I just never realized, I never talked about mortgage and ... I guess we're friends, but I never had the conversation about, "You can do this too," and I probably could have had it 10 years ago, but I'm just thinking he knew what I knew, and he didn't know what I know. And he was looking at me and I'm like, "We're paying the same money." And then when he realized it, it took him a year, and his mother yelled at me because I was talking about, "If your mother has a job, she has a 401k, you make enough money, you can put it together." And then you see the mother now, happy in the house like ... I can see that home ownership, that good feeling, versus renting. That's what led me to the experience.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Thank you all so much for sharing both your questions, which are powerful, and your stories and your connection to those questions.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I hope, I know. I don't have to hope, you are all listening to each other and stuff, so what I want to offer up for the next 10, 15 minutes or so, is just time for you to connect with each other. What I'd like you to think about is, either whose question or story they raised, you felt a connection to. And then speak to that person and just say, "I felt a connection to what you just said in this story, and here's why." This is what has happened in my life, and this is why I felt a real connection to what you said, and that connection could be one in which you agree with the person or disagree with them, or you have another way of looking at it. That's all fine, but there's no ... I'm not going to put any order in the chat, cause this is for you to connect in a way that you, yourself, just felt a connection to another person. So I will open that space for you now.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: I think for me, it was Matthew, because we've talked about the GMO foods. I gave up meat, just for that reason. You don't know how long that animal's been dead, how long it sat, how long it took the process before it even sees your plate. As as I get older, I realize, meat's kind of hard to process through your body if you're eating it every day. It's not the same system that you had when you were younger. So it's kind of like treating your body more as a temple. So I connected to him.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: And I connected with Jane, on the leadership, the education and the vision side. To jump out, and I'm a jump back in. I grew up in Louisiana, and every day, being in high school, my father made me walk to high school. It was less than, maybe two miles. And every day that I walked to high school, there was a standing and operating plantation, and my father used to tell me ... Well, when I graduated high school, "What did you learn on your walks every day to school". Now as a man, I realize that we were operating those plantations. That plantation, that house, it's still there. It's still being used for prisoners. What do we call it? What's the word I'm looking for? It's free ... Somebody's got to help me here.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: It's free labor, and it's still standing, it's still operating. And every day I had to walk by, made me realize that being Black was something amazing, and if we don't keep in touch with our culture, we've failed to realize that, how impactful that is and just realize who we are in our place. Not only in Massachusetts, but just in this entire nation and the world, period. So I did feel real close to her story, knowing that we're going to need that leadership, and if we don't have individuals of color who stand for it and stand for an empowerment that we need, the voice that we need. That's why I love being a part of this, so thank you all for inviting me to be a part of this. That we're going to lose the vision, not only for ourselves, but for our communities. So yes, Jane and I did connect. And again, thank you for having me.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: I want to jump in and say, thank you for reflecting that, Matthew. I think, for me, I've connected with everyone here and their purpose, and what they want to see for housing and for, just the vision of Boston in a whole. Working together is always better, and I think our landmarks and the people, putting money in the people, not the places, is how we got to really move here, and really celebrating the people that came before us, to kind of have a place of ownership or a place where we can really see the legacy and actually see it be built before our eyes, instead of always on our papers or our PDFs. So that is important too, being a visionary, how can we create the safe space for that.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: But I connected with each and every one of us. Living in Boston, born and raised in Boston, so I really want to see people who like being here, be here and get money here, because there's a lot of money here for everyone. And I think education is important. Just being from Boston, a lot of people don't see it that way, but the creator is it right now too. So I think just learning about the greats, because there's so many creators and legacies that are in Boston, will us help us move forward with a plan. I'm going to thank you again for having us here.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I messaged Sedric in the chat, but I think I connect with you Sedric, and you, Warren, about housing here. I think of my landlady, she bought this house. It's a beautiful, old house, for like 30 grand. This is back in the '80s, now it's worth, on the market, like about a million. By her grace, she does not really care about the money. She knows that she could charge a lot more, but she just wants to have the house full of nice people, because that's just her.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: But hearing stories about eviction, I have not been evicted before. I grew up somewhere else. I lived in the suburbs, and my parents are blessed to have their own house, so it just wasn't an issue. But now, the longer that I live here and then the more stories I hear, and the more I see the city change around me, just in these three short years that I've been here, I just wonder, "Should I consider other options? Rent's really cheap now, should I consider home ownership," and so I resonate with you guys.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: And the reason why I asked Sedric, "Is this normal," because is it normal for slum lords and for those who rent out their spaces, for them to take advantage of the people who live there. I grew up in the suburbs, so I didn't see this. Living in the city, it's pretty new to me, so it's a different world in some ways.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
