nodes.words: To answer your question, I actually said it was extremely normal or almost necessary, simply because what I've noticed about having multiple landlords, they're beautiful people of course, but when it comes to fixing the property, they're just as cheap as us. So it's like, their fixing is really like patching it up. You know?

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: It's like, just trying to get it to work for the next two months, three months, pass the inspection maybe. It's not really about your well being, it's really about what's the cheapest option. I mean, my landlord does everything himself. I don't even know if he has certifications, but he doesn't mind doing everything himself, and sometimes he needs help, but he might be too proud to admit it. But I'm not one to be mad at somebody who hustles. They still got to earn it, but this care, like how your landlord cares about you as a person. But it just comes down to people's values, and in this city, it's really about the money. It's a business thing.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Yeah, I get it. Speaking to that, I said that my own floors. And right now, the solution to the shower door, is duct tape, and that has been the solution for the last two, three years. But otherwise, rent's great. But that's just one isolated case.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: It's really, I was very blessed. This year, the Attorney General sued my mortgage company and they took 66% off that mortgage.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: Yeah. Like I said, when I say I'm lucky, the mortgage Gods done looked down and sprinkled something on a Negro. That's all I can say.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: Oh, yeah. We really do. It's really changing before our eyes. Three hundred units is going up where I'm at, and I'm just looking at the traffic but, none of that's for us. None of it looks like it's for us. The bike lanes don't look like it's for us, the bike lanes, nothing in this city reflects that we're here. It looks like we're being eradicated, or almost like the Trail of Tears, where they talk about how they moved the Natives from one place to the other and they died along the way, with the smallpox blankets. It's happening now, I just feel like this is the modern day version of it. We'll just phase you out by raising your rent, so I think the city's are going to kind of look like what I hear Paris looks like, all the rich folks live in the city, all the poor folks live around the city. It's kind of looking like that.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: New York has their feel now. Every place feels like Manhattan when you go to New York, and then everybody else lives around New York, as services to people. So that's what it's looking like. You see train stations, you see apartment buildings go up around train stations. They don't want you driving anymore, the bike lanes. Who's all that for? Who's this new development for? Not people that look like us, because they know we don't make enough money, because the system's kind of rigged from day one, to only support a certain type of person, who may have a lot of money. And that's the problem.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: It's not taking into consideration all human beings, and that's the biggest issue I see. It's like it's treating people, if you don't have this, it's almost like, "Go over there, we don't want to see you. Go hide, because we're going to buy our lattes for $9 and you can't afford it, so go hide in the back somewhere." They say [inaudible] is bad, this is like [inaudible] for home ownership. We'll just phase you out by raising it and making everything high.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: I think the start of it, or how it's going to start, is with Amazon. I believe Amazon has a distribution center that they're going to start at the seashore. That's going to give them a reason to raise rent.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: That's going to be the start of it, because he pulled the same thing when I was in Washington state. I lived in Washington state for six years, before I moved here. I've been here for, going on three years now, and they did the exact same thing. He threw up distribution centers throughout the state, to the point that where it was certain political individuals had to put their foot down and say no. Like, "You're running people out of the state."

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: "People can't even afford to live in the city that they're supposed to be operating in," or pretty much, like you said, "Have some type of ownership in the city." The city ain't even yours anymore. It belongs to them, cause they have all the money. So that's something that we need to, all together we just need to either put a stop to, or put some type of plan in motion and not just a plan. Like Jane mentioned, an action plan. Like you have to do, that this is mandated.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: If everybody doesn't shop at Amazon for three weeks, I bet you it becomes more political. Same thing with Nike and the other type of consumerism. If everybody doesn't shop at Walmart for one week and they lose all that bread, they'll become political activists. We actually control the companies, we just don't. If we stop patronizing their businesses, that is the new revolution. You don't have to protest in the street, just spend your dollar differently.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: Yeah, but they beating us with conveniency, and they're beating a lot of small businesses also in that lane, because they really don't have to do anything, but just ... We're in the day of mobility and being comfortable, and doing everything from your couch, and a lot of small business owners don't have that money to switch to mobility and go straight to Android, or pay somebody to build you a app and all this and all that, that comes with it. Cause that's still a back and forth, so there's going to be a situation on our hands, but like you said, it's going to be-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you all for that exchange. I have one more question I want to ask, and this will actually start to lead us to the closing up conversation. But I'm going to go around, I'm going to put the order, and what I would like you to do is reflect a little bit about what you're hearing in this conversation and what it suggests to you, about a path forward.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's the thing, what are you hearing. And it may suggest many paths forward, because we've talked about many different things. But I'll give you a few minutes to think about that. The order is in the chat, so when you're ready. And when you think everybody else is ready Matthew, you can start.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: I think the path forward, like I mentioned, is actually having an action plan. I believe that if we actually put people before profit, I believe that base is going to be ... That's our transparency, is putting our people before profit. That's our action plan. As long as we stick to that, I don't believe that there's ... Nothing can fail.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I don't know what's a step forward. I think what you're doing here, having a facilitated like ... I think that might be a step forward, but it's kind of like, why hasn't ... How haven't these problems been properly addressed in the past, 60, 40 ... I don't know how many years. I'm just here to listen.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: I think you have to address these problems through politics, your elected officials. Kind of got to put money in the pot, to help everybody. I always thought, maybe there needs to be a different type of system where money's put in the community pot towards home ownership, maybe doing a development corp, where we develop our own buildings in the city, by buying the lands, buying the extra lots and really building affordable housing and home ownership opportunities. I think that has to come from grassroots. I think that's a way forward. Everything has to be done in the grassroots and unified fashion, and I think there's a lot of big egos in Boston, that kind of stop that from happening.

nodes.speaker: Warren
nodes.words: I guess a step forward would like I'm not changing in the Black community though. It's just funny how they tore down the Roxbury mural, but they'll keep Paul Revere's house and stuff, so that just speaks volumes to how they're quick to tear down whatever we build, but keep everything they got.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: I think a plan moving forward, we need to have a really tight, tight, tight, tight, tight, tight understanding. People need to really understand what's happening and what needs to be done. I think people are in different coalitions and different circles, trying to do the same thing, but we have to really, really form a force and that coalition, that will do the one thing that we all want. If we're all saying the same thing, then we've got to agree on that and try to really put our money where we can walk towards victory, or at least a mountaintop, where we can see something happen. Because I don't know if Boston has done that before, but we need to have that done again, a big pot of people who believe in something and want to see a change, and then have it towards something great. That's a start.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: I think with the politics and stuff, that's a different way, but sometimes we can have politicians as friends and stuff. So it's just about making sure that people are understanding our goals, and people in Boston really, really, really want to work together, to achieve what needs to happen. Like we're talking right now, if we all was to come together and do something, that would be a step forward. Like together, so it's kind of like really getting people on the same road or on the same mission, whether it's money wise or voice wise, and kind of pushing forward with that.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Money is going to make things move, but a pack of strong voices and strong people, can really do some damage too. But all we have to have are, a really secure ... A really, really powerful team. Teamwork needs to be the dream work there. I don't know if that's tough or hard, but it needs to be more easy. It needs to be easy, to be done here. If we all want the same thing, then we need to work as a team, and we need to fill like everybody can play their part in making that thing happen. So that's what I'm rooting for, for people to make outstanding in what they know they can do, and letting others do what they know how to do, and working together. Working together.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're getting close to the end. I have two more things that I want you to do. One is, I'm going to ask you to fill out a little form, but before we do that, I want to ask you this one last question. This question isn't in the script. I've been thinking about it for awhile, to put it into the script. I'm going to offer it up today. I'm going to offer up an order for you to say it in, but the question I have for you now, and it's a short one ... But you're all here, and because you're all here, you're here in some sense because you believe something is possible. My last question for you, say a little bit about what gives you hope, where do you find hope, what gives you hope. Becky, you're our starter.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I think what gives me hope in the broader sense are the individuals that are making the change. That are the community members that do stand up and that do organize. The organizers that do that. And seeing people from across neighborhoods, demographics, ages, whatever, standing up together and forming that tight network.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I think we're all different ages here, and I think we're all different professions and come, but we're all here and we're here for a reason. I think that speaks a lot. The fact that Real Talk for Change, that it exists, and that people are looking at it. And that it's gaining traction, that gives me hope.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: What gives me hope? After today, like someone already mentioned, it's everybody here. Of course us being here, listening, learning from each other, educating each other, and no matter whatever small way possible, it is going to, at the end of the day, I believe, invoke some type of change. Because I'd like to believe after this conversation ... I don't know how everybody's night, or tomorrow is going to be, but I'd like to believe that tomorrow someone, if not tonight, someone's going to have a conversation about what we're talking about here tonight. And that's going to pass on to someone else, who's going to pass on to someone else, and this is going to become something that is going to be much more than we could even anticipate, or even think of.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.words: So to me, hope is everybody here having a voice and listening to each other, and continuously passing this along, because this is just to start. Like you said, the election is coming up, and a lot of people have hope for the future for Massachusetts, and after the election, we gone see if all of these politicians or whoever wins, is going to really hold on to their promise. That's it for me.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Thank you. What gives me hope is believing in the people, believing in the future, and the impossible is nothing. So I'm definitely always believing in the people and knowing that impossible is nothing, and together, we can achieve anything. I'm a very optimistic person, so I believe in the future. That gives me hope.

nodes.speaker: Jane
nodes.words: Today, you all bring hope and joy too, knowing that we can do this together. The world is still ours, together.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: I think what brings me hope is that I see this fundamental change after the police shootings, people becoming more active, people having a voice and speaking up. I think people are starting to get a clear understanding of what we need to do to help and hold each other accountable. I think we have to get back to those community values that Jane's basically talking about, those old-school community values where we held each other up. I think it's going back to that, because people can see there's a disparity in the way people are living. Everybody wants what's best for their children, but what are the steps to get there. So you see the mindset changing.

nodes.speaker: Sedric
nodes.words: Through social media, I think we've become more connected and more revolutionary, through media and through understanding. I think it's slowly getting back to almost like a '60s feel, where there's like a mini-revolution going on inside of each other, and we can hold each other accountable because we can become more connected through social media.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Wow. Thank you all so very, very much. As we wrap up, there's one thing that I would like to ask of you to do. I'm going to drop this link in the chat. It's a form that we're asking you to fill out, and we'd like you to do it right now, right here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: There's a couple things in it. One, this is how we make sure who's in the room at the time. It asks for your email address, I know you've probably given it to whoever you met with first, but this is to get it in one place so we can get you access to where these conversations are going to be stored. If you use a pseudo name, it asks for it, so that we can make sure that we've gone through and not have your name show up anywhere else. That's a different set of people, so they just need to be able to cross check that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And then it has your information about what neighborhood you are associated with. We ask for that kind of piece, to submit that. And there's about three other questions after that, that we would love for you to fill out, but they're optional. They basically have to do with gender identity, age group, and racial identity. So I'm going to give you a couple minutes, and ask you all to open up the form and fill it in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Has everybody finished the form? Thank you all so much. Really appreciate you participating in this. A couple things I like to just say at the very end. One is, if any of you are interested in becoming a facilitator for these kinds of conversations, let us know. We do the facilitating trainings on every Tuesday evening at 6:00 PM, and you can either talk to Francesca or to Zakiya, to learn more about that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We are changing a little bit of our strategy right now, for facilitators. We're asking, in your training, after you get trained, you have to do a conversation with who you observed, and then you agree to do two more. We've been having people organize those other two conversations with people they know and stuff, but we're also going to have spots for people to just say, "I'm available at this time, to do a conversation," and we'll be recruiting some of the people to be in conversation. So there may be a little bit more flexibility, in some sense, going down the road.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Again, I want to thank you all. Any closing comments, anything you want to say? Zakiya, anything you want to offer up?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you, Ceasar. I know at least three of the people that participated tonight, want to be facilitators, and I'm interested in knowing, now that you've been through a conversation, do you still feel like you want to be a facilitator? After you-

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: To me, the hardest part was being quiet. I was the observer. And even though I nodded my head emphatically a little bit, my job was to be quiet. And if you notice, as a facilitator, Ceasar did not weigh in. He just guided the conversation, that's the hardest part of this, to me. So thank you all.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you all. Get some nourishment in your bodies for the evening. I can't even tell you how much I appreciate, having met each and every one of you. It looks like I'm going to get to meet you again, soon.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: The purpose of these conversation is to create a space across the city to facilitate deep listening across differences and divides, to focus on personal stories from lived experience. The audio recording will be kept and transcribed. The recordings will be uploaded to Local Voices Network, a nonprofit organization. I'm going to read the consent text.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing concent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with our mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, "I agree."

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm going to actually ask that we ... I'm going to drop the order in the chat, but I'm going to ... Kevin, Tina Maria, Erica, and then Vivian, so if you could do that order, and say, "I agree," beginning with Kevin.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Vivian, okay. Thank you. Now, we have a list of conversation agreements. You are all very familiar with conversation agreements, and I am dropping them in the chat.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Stay curious and honest. Ask honest questions. Pause. Take time for reflection. Listen generously. Assume good intentions, while recognizing that your words have an impact.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phones on silent. If you need to take a moment, take a break, just let me know in the chat. Is everyone on board with these agreements?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: All right, wonderful. The other aspect of this work this evening, and we will probably take about 75 minutes, no longer than 90, is for your full selves to be present. We're very complicated. Life is very complicated, so I just want you to take a minute to just breathe and center yourself.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I do this activity, and I love it, because I love pie. I particularly like blueberry and apple. Feel free to drop some by anytime.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Pies, in this instance, represents our full selves, right? Our physical aspect, intellectual, emotional, and spiritual, or social, and support. In this instance, I'd actually like you to just choose one pie, say your name, your affiliation with Boston, what neighborhood you are connected to, or if you're city-wide, whether you work or live here, and one of the pies, so, I'll model.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Francesca. I live in Dorchester. I'm working right now freelance, eagerly looking for full-time work, and I've lived in 28 different places in Boston in my life. I'm checking in physically. I took a nice walk around UMass, the back of UMass, before the call. I'll turn it over to Kevin. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Kevin, and the affiliation with Boston is through the Boston Public Schools, and so it's city-wide. Did I miss something, now?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No, Kevin. I want you to tell me, PIE is an acronym that represents how you're doing physically, intellectually, or emotionally, or spiritually. If you want to-

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Well, I can't talk about the lemon meringue pie that I would like to have, that I want, but, so, the physical is walking around the neighborhood. Does that work?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You just have to do one, just one check-in, how you're doing intellectually and physically, how you're doing physically, or intellectually, emotionally, or socially, I mean, spiritually. I apologize that I distracted folks by talking about real pie.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Okay, so, intellectually, I like to be well-read, and I particularly like economic history, particularly when it contains things dealing with the black experience in this country.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I'm Erica. I live in Dorchester. I currently work in Cambridge, although I work in community development, and I've done some of that work also in Boston. Checking in, I would say, spiritually, I'm coming off the Jewish High Holidays, which are a time of reflection, so I feel like I've gained some positive reflection on myself and how I want to move forward in a better way in the coming year, so I'm in that space these days. Is that it? Did I touch on everything?

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Vivian, and I live in Mattapan, and I work for the Safe Routes to School program, to encourage kids to walk and bike to school, so I am actually pretty happy that school has started, and kids are in the building, because then I'm able to get around and do what I need to do with them. I'm also going to mention on the physical, sprained my ankle this morning. I'm doing much better now, because I need to be able to move around, so I've been resting at home and just taking it easy for that, so I think that's it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you all so much. Now, as I said, and as you know, we just had our preliminary on Tuesday. Part of what we hope to do with these conversations is share this, our findings and people's voices, in the next month, during the runoff to the final election on November 2nd. We're not going to talk about issues, and we're not going to ask you to share, although I would at another time love to hear your feedback about the preliminary, but that's for another time.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: What I really want you to do right now is to think about the future of Boston and your place in that future. As you're thinking about that, I'd like you to form a question. I'd like you to think about what in your own personal experiences leads you to form that question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You might want to grab a piece of paper or your phone, if you like to make notes on your phone. Just take a second. We'll take a minute so you can think about a question about the future of Boston and your place in it. (silence)

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Does everyone have a question and a story that relates to your own experiences? If so, give me a thumbs up. Okay. Kevin, looks like you need a little more time. Excuse me, when you're ready, Kevin, and again, it's Kevin, Erica, Tina, TMJ, sorry, and Vivian.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Okay. I guess I'll go. I don't know that I have the story. We have to do it all together. This is for the future. How can I promote better economic education and financial literacy among multi generation in Boston?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Why is that a question about the future and your place in it? What, in your own experiences within Boston have led you to that question? A short story to help us understand why that is meaningful for you, economic development and teaching about that.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: I think largely due to what I have experienced when I've had the chance to travel abroad, and I see other cultures, and other society, in places that are as developed, and even those places that are not as well developed as the United States, at least in the way that we think of development stages, and how they seem to be better educated when it comes to financial literacy. So, how do we change that here, in this land of wealth that has enormous income inequality? And perhaps how people can learn more about how to equip themselves better as a defense against the growing inequality [inaudible] ...

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: A question I have is, how can I, as a citizen of Boston, have agency towards climate change? I guess my specific question is related to sea level rise, and what can I do to, as a citizen, to support our collective understanding of sea level rise in the city? It's just important because we need the city. We need a physical space to be, so, just thinking through physical space and preserving it I think is as crucial for everyone as a foundational level.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: That's what I mean. I just feel like land is everything for everyone, so specifically to me, and generally to everyone, we all need a place to be, so I want to know how I can help with that.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Is there any experiences specifically in Boston that really lead you to focus on that, in terms of land that you want to share?

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: Just my learning and education, getting older, and just trying to ... I don't know what's most important. It's just something I've developed over time, so that seems important.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I've been trying to think about how I can help connect people who are progressives, and care about a lot of things that I do, but seem to not quite see the major crisis, not just around housing and the need for more affordable housing, but around how development happens in the city. I feel like I'm involved with a lot of people really focused on how we have more equitable development, like, who decides? How are we allowing developers to do that?

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: My question is, how do I help connect these people that I know who are progressives and care about this, but who somehow, I feel like there's a gap in there, in how they think it needs to be addressed, and they don't quite see the gross inequity. How do I talk to them, educate them, involve them more in what I think is something they care about but maybe aren't seeing the whole picture? Hopefully, it's not just me thinking they should think the way I think, but, so, yeah, that's my question, because I see what seems like a disconnect, and a gap in advocacy and activism around inequitable land use.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Do you want to talk a little more about your own personal experiences? I know that you've mentioned that you do some development work professionally, but anything personally that you feel you would like to share now?

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: Yeah. Well, I think, moving to Dorchester, I moved here five years ago, so I'm a white, financially-stable newcomer. I'm part of this gentrifying world. Even if I wasn't, and I had lived here a long time, just like TMJ just said, land is everything. Who gets to live where and how is just everything. I feel that, personally, and I want to contribute to making my neighborhood better and not worse.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Mine is going to be a little bit different. I don't know if I have a future in Boston. I'm getting to that point now, I've been here 12 years, 13 years, and I just get really frustrated, because I don't see that we're progressing as much. I don't think that, at least in the space that I'm in, I tend to be the only one that's thinking about a lot of these things.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Similar to what Erica is saying, there is a divide. Then, I don't always see that there's an interest in a lot of these topics. That's coming from working closely with different organizations, and trying to ... I talk to people just randomly, and having conversations on a lot of different topics, and folks will be like, they're interested, and then I'll see if there's a way that I might be able to connect them with whatever it is, that topic that we're talking about, but I don't really think they are.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I think that folks are just living in their homes, and just surviving, day by day. I just need to be in a space where there's other folks that are thinking, and like-minded, and moving forward a little bit more. I don't know if Boston is the place for me to be able to do that. It gets lonely to be the only one. I have no family here. Also, just frustrating, so that's it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: ... in Boston. Okay. Thank you all so much. I really appreciate your willingness to share. Now, what I would like you to do is to think about what you heard and whether ... I want you to find someone whose question or experience resonated with you or your own life, and if so, unmute yourself. We can go in any order.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I would just say that for me, as far as resonance goes, I feel like I really resonated with the notion of whether Boston will be ... Anyway, I resonated with all of your questions, but I'm facilitating, so I'm not going to talk. I would just like someone else to unmute themselves and share with whosever story your question resonated or you felt connected to.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I'll go first. Both Erica and TMJ, the whole development issue, and just trying to get more folks to fill in that gap is something that I am not ... Development is not the area of interest that I can speak on the most, and the same thing about trying to get that information so that my neighbors have more of an interest in that. We do have a lot of development that's going on in Mattapan, and I think that we could do a better job as individuals to know more about what that means, and then, also bringing in folks to share that information.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Then, TMJ, with the Neponset River being right in my backyard and a space that I spend a lot of time in, again, my neighbors not necessarily being that ... I don't want it to seem like ... I'm being careful on how I word this. It just seems like they don't really care. Whenever the king tides happen, that's just the way it is, and what it is that they, as individuals, all of us can do to help us prepare for that, it's been a conversation, just as an individual, not a professional, that I've wanted to have with folks. I find myself just getting some of that resistance.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I don't own, and so I am one of those people in some of these spaces. So, I sometimes feel that I'm not seen as a person that has any knowledge or expertise in some of these topics. That can be really frustrating, so, always trying to find, who are those experts? And bringing those folks in, and asking that when they do have these conversations, please start from the really basic, because I sometimes think that people are just not interested because they don't understand it, and maybe don't want to have those individuals coming into spaces, because they're just like, I'm not going to understand what they're talking about. So, trying to bridge the language gap, even though we're all speaking the same language, to have better understanding on that.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Kevin, not so much on your economic development, even though I understand, but for me, the other two were the ones that resonated with me more.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: Well, Vivian, what you said resonated with me, too, and what you just said, because I do feel like it is frustrating when it feels like people might not be interested, but I also feel like there's a culture in Boston of people aren't supposed to be interested. I feel like there's a bigger culture.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I think maybe that's changing now, because who our elected officials are is shifting, and that's been shifting for many years, and there's just, I don't know. My history is so limited, because I've only been ... I lived Somerville for years, so I've only been actually in Boston for a much shorter time, so I don't have that context of living here, but I feel like there is, probably from decades back, just a culture of ... There's been an inner clique, and an inner circle in Boston, even though it's such a small city. Then, everyone else is not supposed to be part of that.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I feel like there's something culturally that's persisted around that, so even if people are invited in, there's a skepticism of, like, well, am I really going to be invited in? Do I even have a role? What am I supposed to be doing about it? I think there's a message that's gone to people, and it's so hard to overcome that.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Vivian, I think she asked an incredible, quite effective question. To what extent do I even have a future in Boston? I mean, I think that's fundamental before you do anything with any of this. Where will you be 10 years ago, 5 years from now, or 20 years? Will you remain here, and why would you choose to remain? That's interesting. I think that's deep. What would hold you here?

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I also have to share that I was a military child, so we moved around often. I came here because I went to school in New York, so I don't have those lifelong roots of living in one place. Some of it is just that, okay, I'm ready for change, but then, at the same time, I'm like, I'm 58 years old. When am I going to stop doing this moving around kind of stuff?

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I'm right now at a moment that I just don't feel that I'm in a community, in a community, right? I just am living here, but I'm not in a community. Like I said, it can be really lonely.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: People are coming and going all the time, and their choice is, for some people, it's a choice. Some people don't have a choice, and those that to, why do they choose to stay? Those who leave, why are they leaving? Who leaves I think is less important.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Erica said, "Well, I've made a decision to move into Dorchester," and it sounds like you have options. You didn't have to move to Dorchester. So, who moves?

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Then, you talk about equitable development, and Vivian, you said something about in Mattapan, there's a lot of development. I'm thinking, okay, if she's saying there's a lot of development, what's that based on? But even I think that, when I come back in the city after not being in the city as much the last year and a half, [inaudible] for a while and they're building something here, they're building something there, they're building something over here?

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: To what extent is that good? To what extent is it not so good? Who is the development for? Does it work for some, and why does it not? When you talk about equitable development, why is it not working for some? How do we change that? Who changes it? Who's being moved out as some are being moved in? Displacement's a long part of the history of America, so, that's interesting. A lot to think about.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: I think that the conversation of taking ownership, like for sea level rise, how do you take personal ownership over that in a city where people are coming, going to that point? What percentage of people are from Boston, aren't leaving Boston, versus the amount of people that just come and go? It may be hard to take ownership over issues in a collective fashion when, to folks' point, people don't see themselves as necessarily from here, or staying here, or ... Just curious about how much that plays a role into how we think about those things.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I think, for me, it all comes down to how organizations, or people in neighborhoods, are organizing groups of people together, which is the only way you can really change anything. To Vivian's point, it is really hard if you feel like ... I spent a few years living in Connecticut, where I felt like such a fish out of water, even though it was just one state away. I just felt like no one around me understood anything that was really important to me, like, I couldn't find a critical mass.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I feel like it's almost like that's how you feel. You're like, am I the only one who thinks this is important? Where is everybody?

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: One thing I didn't mention before is I became active with Dorchester Not For Sale, which grew up, it's mostly low-income tenants, but it's really for everybody to be advocating for development in Dorchester, anyway, to be driven by the actual needs of people who are going to be most negatively impacted by development, but it's hard. I mean, for all these issues, everything that we've talked about, you're going up against the status quo stuff of how stuff has been done. It's really hard to, even when you're organized, it's hard to make change, but I feel like that's the only way to answer any of this, is there has to be like-minded people working together, because none of us can do this stuff as individuals, really.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I can only speak about the area in which I live in, Mattapan. It is like there is no activism. It's just, we don't want it. We want everything to stay the way it is. This is the status quo it's always been. We don't want anybody new.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: When it comes to the development, Kevin, it's like there's an empty lot that a developer buys to build whatever, however many units it is, and they don't want it. So, let's have that empty lot, even though we hear that there's a housing shortage, but we don't wan that.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Then, when a church was building something, and it was on their property, and the conversations were with the abutters, but they didn't want that group of people. They had different choices of the different folks that were interested in buying that property. They didn't want any of them.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: It's like, how is it that these folks that have been here for the amount of time that they've been here have that kind of power just to say, "No, we don't want anyone here. We don't want anyone here."? What happens to the families? What happens to folks that are interested in becoming homeowners, and you can't ...

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: If I were to stay here, I love living in Mattapan, but it's just really, really frustrating to not see that folks are willing to say yes to something. So, I've stopped going to my neighborhood association meetings, because it was just not healthy for me, mentally, because I was usually the person that was saying, "No, I don't agree with that."

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Because I don't own a home, then it was almost like, well, we don't really care what you're saying anyway, because you're not one of us. I tend to be a little bit more civically engaged than a lot of them, and trying to not come across as that person that knows everything, but I love to share information once I hear it. I love to pay it forward, and like, this is something that I learned that this is a new program, and bringing that forward, okay, that's fine, but no, "Hey, why don't we look into that?"

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: It's just like folks are really just okay with the status quo. That's disappointing to me. By the way, none of their children are here. These are older folks. Their kids don't live in the community. So, Kevin, when you talked about displacement and gentrification, when they die, I don't know who's going to take care of their homes, because their kids left a long time ago, because they didn't go to school in Boston, because a lot of them are Medco kids, so their homes are being sold, because their kids don't necessarily want those properties.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: The development that is going on, who is it for? You said there's a lot of development that is ongoing, so [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Well, there's a lot of proposals. When I was going to the neighborhood association meeting, like 90% of the agenda was about development. I would, like, "Hey, I don't know you guys. Could we just have some social time? Can we talk about some other topic?" Like four developments would be on the agenda. Small things. Not major properties [inaudible] so ...

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Small units, like on a residential street. Then, I'd also get upset with the city, because I was like, I don't think that we have a great foundation of how development works, which is not to say that it's perfect, but just, what is the current process? As an outsider, I was longing for that, and I didn't feel that there was ... It would just get messy, because it was like, I don't think that, in general, people understand the process. They just go along with it.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I know I'm a person that asks a lot of questions. I would be like, "Why aren't we asking all these questions?" Because, well, whatever, but ... It was just difficult.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Would you call the people at this neighborhood association, would you refer to them as ... It sounds like you wouldn't call them progressive.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I think they're pretty conservative, in the sense that they like what they have on their street. Look, I ride a bicycle for transportation. That's the only way I get around if I'm not on the T. They think I am out of this world crazy for doing that, but they want those streets to be safer, and they don't want all this traffic, and they don't want all these ...

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I'm like, "I'm not telling you, 'Give up your car,' but we have a trolley that's around the block from where you life. Just try that every once in a while." "No, I got a car." Okay, well, then, the conditions are [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: Yeah. I mean, and the conditions are going to stay the way they are, because the city can't force you to get out of your car. So, those type of topics are the things that I'm just like, hey, let's go for a walk on this beautiful trail that we have. No, no. It's like, all right.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I think that's so common for neighborhood associations. I mean, they're not all that way, but that's who joins those groups, and those groups have a lot of voice with a lot of development issues. Those groups tend to be the older, more stable, financially stable homeowners who have been there for a long time, so they feel like they should have, their voices should be more important than other people's.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: They tend to be conservative in the way you say. Not necessarily political or not. I'm sure a lot of them are Democrats, but conservative as far as change, or just seeing a new way, or how something could be better.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I think that's a big problem, is that a lot of those neighborhood associations do have a lot of disproportionate power around keeping the status quo. Certainly in development, anyway, because those are the people who are, like you said, they're putting it on their agenda, and they're talking about it, and they're getting ready. They're like, they know how the system works, and they're paying attention, and they're showing up to public meetings, and voicing their opinions.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: Other people aren't as plugged in. They're coming with a certain ... Not all of them, but I feel like a lot of times, those neighborhood associations come with that kind of perspective. I mean, I literally have heard someone at a public meeting, when I was working in Hyde Park, say, at a meeting about a new proposed development, and granted, it was a pretty large one, but say, "I didn't move to this neighborhood for more neighbors," which I thought was ... I'll never forget that line, like, I didn't move here to have more people near me.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: Like, I didn't move here for more neighbors. I moved here to be alone. I don't know that he was necessarily part of an active neighborhood association, but I just think, in general, neighborhood associations just have a disproportionate amount of power. It's one voice, and it's one legitimate perspective of people who live here, but there's so many other voices that aren't being heard that are just as legitimate, or in my opinion, sometimes more so, because they could stand to be hurt by things more than someone who owns a home. To me, that's a big problem is like, right, whose voices are being heard at city hall or in other places?

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: [crosstalk] Right. They're calling up their city counselor, and their state rep, and they know that person, and that person will take their call, because they're the ones organizing the meetings, and always ... Yeah. [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: if they know them, if they know who they are, because sometimes I'm like, no. We're in between two. That is not our city counselor. This is the city counselor, and that person is not the city counselor. That person is a state rep. They're like, "Yeah, I know that," but ... Yeah, there's a lot of work to do, but it's just, you keep hitting the wall, and after a while, it's just like, I don't know. All right. I'm talking too much.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: But, I'm young, in comparison. I'm young in comparison, because we don't ... Then, of course, those 30 and 40-year-old folks aren't going to those meetings, because they already heard about them, and they have no interest in attending, so ...

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: It sounds like they're not fun, right? You're like, "Hey, let's get to know each other," and people are like ... I mean, it doesn't sound like the most fun, inviting meeting to go to, so ...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I want to check in with TMJ, and see if there's anything that you would like to add, and yeah, give you a second to see if anything is resonating, other than what you already commented. Then, I want to move to close us out, if that's okay.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: No. I think I hear what everyone's saying. I go to my neighborhood association meetings sometimes, but I think everyone is different. I think a layer of that conversation that I'd like to have is how many folks identify as immigrants versus non-immigrant? How does that shape how people think about what's going on in their neighborhood?

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: Those are questions I have in my neighborhood association meeting, but just where are people coming from culturally I think is important when they think about these things. Yeah. That's it.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: No. My mother is a homeowner, so I go to the meetings on her behalf. Yes, I would say there are folks who are immigrants. There are folks who their parents were immigrants. There are folks who are not immigrants.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: I think that that's where hiccups I've seen. It's been out of just difference of opinion, culturally, particularly related to driving and biking. That's all what I've witnessed, just a cultural understanding of how to use space that, yeah, I think it needs to be ...

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: To your point about, like, let's get together, let's get to know each other, I think that that part is super important. Yeah. You can only do what you can do, so ... Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Since, I think you mentioned sea level rising was of utmost importance to you, where do you see the others who are in these groups, these kinds of spaces that you attend, like your neighborhood association? What do you think some of their thinking is? Do you get into those kinds of conversations?

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: Not even mentioned. I think if it was brought up, folks would be concerned, but not enough to just talk about feeling concerned. I think that that's where it stops. That would be my guess, because I don't think people feel ... I don't think anyone feels like they have the agency to do anything about it, so they just have internalized that in how they understand issues.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: I think so much of how we are in America is we tend to be much more reactive than proactive. I suspect that there would be a different kind of conversation in a place like New York City, after this last storm that we just experienced two weeks ago. Who would have thought in New York City? I don't remember what the number was, I don't know, 10, 20, something, people died, because they're living in basement apartments that got flooded because of some type of weather-related changes that are going on. I mean, I don't know when they've had that many people die in New York City.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: Clearly, I'm certain there have been people who have been impacted by water damage and things like that, but to die? In a metropolitan area such as that, that's conceived of as being very modern, progressive? I would suspect, again, because we're so reactive as opposed to proactive, people, perhaps in Boston, sadly, there would have to be something perhaps tragic before people realize, yeah, this may touch me, too.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. As we're winding down, I'm just wondering if anybody wants to make a closing, any takeaways or closing thoughts about this conversation? Then, I have a little housekeeping, and then we'll sign off.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: The other part that I didn't mention was about that report that came out by the Federal Reserve a number of years ago, what four years ago, five years ago? The color of wealth in Boston, that shows the glaring disparity in wealth, what we call wealth, in the metropolitan Boston area. One of the worst in the country.

nodes.speaker: Kevin
nodes.words: How do we take that data and put something in place that's grossly needed to then make some huge correction to the results of that study? I mean, this is the thing that's fascinating, this is what's perceived around the country, is being this progressive place. This notion of this blue state, and this deep blue, and yet, you've got that going on. It's such a contradiction to me, the reality beneath the perception. It's so huge of a divide.

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I was just going to agree. I feel like I hear, especially on NPR, that that data repeated so often, the wealth gap, the assets owned by a black family is eight dollars, compared to the white family of whatever it is, 200. I don't remember the number, astronomically larger. It's repeated all the time, but you don't hear, here's a package of things that we are trying to ... Here's some policies we're trying to advance to address that. It's just, I hear [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Erica
nodes.words: I don't hear the ... I don't know. It feels like no one's saying, "This is ..." People are proposing Green New Deals for Boston. No one's proposing the Racial Wealth Gap New Deal. I don't know how people are thinking about that, but you hear people talking about the problem, and not talking about what should be done, which is interesting.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I see it as folks expect our government to everything, but then when our government does do something, then they get criticized for they didn't do it, and where did you get that data from? You must have come at a time when da, da, da, da, da. I'm just like, but, what are we doing as individuals? What are we doing as individuals to go to a space, and go into the library, and have a conversation with a kid?

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I know we live in this society that everyone's like, who are you? The [inaudible] an all of those things that have to, but what are you doing as an individual to look out for some other person? It's just such a me, me, me, me, me, me. I don't have time. I can't do it.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: It's like, you need to make the time to have a conversation, to say something to a child, to just ask how a person is doing. That happened during the pandemic, but I also saw that some of it, I got the impression was kind of like this, I'm doing it because I think it looks good. I saw that in my neighborhood, that people were knocking on doors and asking if people needed this and needed that. Then, they wanted us to help out financially with that.

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: I said, "Why are you doing that? The city has all of those resources available. I'm okay. I don't really need that. Let's just check on people to check on them and see how they're doing." Is that going to be a pattern that we're going to continue, or is that something only that happened because it was the pandemic, and now we're going back to our normal lives?

nodes.speaker: Vivian
nodes.words: It's just a different rush, rush, rush, rush, rush, that it's a cultural change that you have to make to just have a conversation with your neighbor. One thing, I'm not going to those meetings, but I have more conversations with the people that just live on my street that don't go to those meetings, because we're just out, and I'm saying hello, and things like that. I'm talking to folks and having some human interaction in a different way. I think we could benefit from doing a little bit of that, so getting away from, for me, the negativity, and just finding out, who are you? Tell me a little bit about yourself. I think that would be helpful. It has been for me.

nodes.speaker: TMJ
nodes.words: No. I'm just going to say, thank you all for sharing. I appreciate being a part of the conversation, and will continue to think about my own agency in getting things done, and working towards solution. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. I really want to appreciate the time that you all took to step into this space. I'm hoping that you will have found some value in it, and that you may want, like Vivian, the people that you're talking to in your neighborhood that don't go to neighborhood association meetings, maybe you could have them over, and we could come together in your neighborhood and have this conversation in this kind of way. The voices of folks that aren't going to neighborhood association meetings, they're not going to debates, and aren't making comments in the Boston Globe when there's articles written are the voices we're trying to reach to engage in dialogue around our future, our city's future, and our place in it. Then, to build relationships across difference.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, I actually just, I want to thank you. The project wants to thank you by providing you with a $40 gift card. I want to encourage you to think about other people that may want to engage in this conversation. Then, I just sent you, I mean, I just put in the chat a Google link.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We want to collect demographic data, as well as your name and email, although the demographic data won't be attached to you. It'll just go in a data file for the project. However, I need your email, and I need you to fill it out so you can get your gift card sent to you, and gift card sent to you, and then, also, when this conversation is uploaded, you'll get a link so that you can listen to the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Then, once all the conversations are uploaded, you will also get a link to hear the different conversations. I will keep you posted on that, because we're meeting on Tuesday to learn more about the back end. Again, I'm a novice with this 21st century technology. I think it's totally cool.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, please, did I hit the return button so it showed up in the chat, the link? Everyone can copy it and fill it out? Again, thank you so much. I'm going to be hosting these conversations on Tuesday nights, 6:30 to 8:00, Saturday after October 2nd from 4:00 to 5:30, and Sunday at this time, and Friday morning, early Friday morning for folks.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Again, if there's people within your life that you think might be interested, send them my way. Thanks again. Have a great week. Stay healthy, okay? Love you all. Bye for now. Ciao.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: So, welcome to the Real Talk Change conversation. And I will now begin recording our conversation, and I need to share four important items of the information that we're getting ready to go over. The first one is the purpose of the conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across the divided neighborhoods, political and cultural, and provide improved visibility, accountability between the candidates and the future mayor and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your positions on the upcoming elections or specific candidates. We are doing this to help build connections, understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Secondly, I want to address what will happen to the recording for the conversation. Following our meeting today, the audio recording will become a part of a collection of conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with members of Real Talk Change team and others who have participated in conversations throughout the Local Voices Network.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations, designed by the nonprofit organization Cortico. LVN system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and the audio recording to the explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with this mission. You also understand that the conversations will be part of the collection of Cortico Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with the mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, "I agree."

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Thirdly, before we wrap up, we will share with you a handout to fill in your name, email address, so when it's over, you can... And it says on here we'll send you your gift card, but because we're doing it in person, I get to give you your gift card. Most of the other people are doing it online.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Okay. [inaudible]. Thirdly, before we wrap up... Which is optional. The reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect on and uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable answering. Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation. And to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. One, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, allow others to speak for themselves. Three, share time, allow others to finish speaking, take turns, stay courteous, ask honest questions, pause, take time for reflection, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary program applications and notifications. That means you all's phones go on silent. If you need to take a moment to take a break, let the facilitator know. And chat is very onboard with these guidelines.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: So, to begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and a check-in. Please share your first name, where you live, then let us know how you are using the PIES. And the PIES is physical, intellectual, emotional, or spiritual on how you're feeling today. So, you can start to the right and go around. So, Dorothy, how are you feeling today?

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: I'm feeling very good today. My name is Dorothy Cotton. I live in the Dorchester area. My take on this is, well, it's going to better help our community.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: My name is Tameaka. I'm feeling optimistic today. I'm checking in, I guess, physically. I don't know if that was the option.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: My take on this is how these new electives will better our communities for the better and not just be words this time around, if possible.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: Hello. My name is Tarazer Funderburk, and I live in the Roslindale area. Oh, damn. I'm here physically. And I would say, as far as my intake on this, I think I'm in it in terms of what's best for the community, being sure that we're heard and we're being provided the information and...

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: ... just being here to be supportive and making sure that there's a voice from the community to have part in the say of our community.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: Okay. I'm Yolande Sealy, and I am from the Roxbury area, now living in Brooklyn. And I am here physically and emotionally, wanting to know what the future holds for the City of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: So, now that we know who is here, let's get to the core of the conversation. As we share the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about equality in America, and Boston ,and how our lived experience has shaped that learning. Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think what your questions about the future of Boston and your place in the future. So, you can take two minutes to reflect on this and write it down somewhere if it feels helpful.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: My question is that, honestly, are they really trying to move all the black folks out of Boston with these bike lanes and bus lanes? And I think it's a death trap. It's not safe on the road, the way these streets are weaving in and out, so I'm just wondering like what's going on. Are we getting pushed out? Because we aren't riding bikes.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: Us minorities aren't riding bikes to need the whole city to have bike lanes and bus lanes all around it. So, now we have bus lanes and the buses only come up the street every hour or so, so now traffic is congested for a bus that's going to come by every 40, 45 minutes. And now there's a whole lane that's restricted that cars can't commute down. I think it's stupid.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: So, for me, I would say: how does a future hold for minorities currently within the city, in terms of owning property? It's damn near... Not damn near, it is impossible for someone to buy in Boston. I would say the majority of the inner cities, they make minimum wage. You need probably more than two incomes to even be able to afford rent. So, that's concerning to me that it's not equal opportunity for us to even be here, in terms of buying property. If you don't own it now, it's like, "What happens?"

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: My question about the future of Boston tills on: what do our elective leaders and people in charge... Are they allow the dollar to determine how they take this pandemic approach? Because everybody's worried about the money that we make and our income, and not the safety of the people when there's people continuing to die, lifting mask mandates, sending kids to crowded schools. They're saying they want to make sure everybody's vaccinated, but are they making sure that they continue the same safety protocols that they did in the beginning of this pandemic? Because, as a Fauci said and the different people of the... What is it called?

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: The CDC, this is going to be with us. And people are forgetting to wash their hands, use sanitizer, to just stay with them common practices that keep this virus at bay a little bit. And I just say, my concern is my children, because I know Boston. What makes them, all of a sudden, go and do something better within these school systems that's going to make it safe for the kids? That's what I don't trust. And they don't have a smaller amount of children. I think even they should probably go back to the certain days of the week so that all the kids-

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: Yes. Yeah, because it's just too many kids in these schools. And when I was going to the schools, the schools were messed up. There was peeling paint, asbestos, no ventilation. What's the ventilation? These open windows? I just wonder, are they going to let money rule the decision and just kill off people?

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: What I look out for [inaudible] is that... Well, I'm an elderly person. I'm 64. How are we going to be able to afford rent these days? I mean, they build houses these days that the rent is so high that people have to pay double money, have two jobs. But when you get an apartment, you can hear somebody next door. And they build these houses up so high. I live in a senior citizen building, very nice, brand new. I live near the train tracks, but you can not tell me my windows are not open and I can not hear the trains. You can hear the people downstairs, on the fourth floor. I'm on the fourth floor. You can hear the people's conversation on the ground floor. I mean, they're doing a good job building these buildings but they're not putting a lot of work in them. Who's checking these buildings that... How can I have a kid in one room and they can hear me making love to my husband in another room? It's just not fair. And then they want to raise our rent up. You give us this faulty material.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: You have these houses they're building up, they called first-time housing. People are having problems with them, and nobody's helping them when they come to this issue that they cannot solve a problem that these builders build. And all of a sudden, it's your issue, but you won't help me with the situation that caused you guys to build. I mean, we would like to see people continue to show us... When you say you're going to do something for us, equal wage for women, as much as men, we want you to stand to your word.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: And we appreciate everything that Boston has done for us these days, your food. And as far as the fact that the food things comes with, you give people the walk food and then it's a lot of waste, too much waste. I mean, we're blessed to have food, but the thing about it is, sometimes, you give the people the things they don't want in bags and then they leave it on the streets. And then this is another issue that really hurts my spirit, it's what are they doing... What is it? 10 Mile?

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: Methadone Mile. I mean, okay, you give them a place or they took a place over there to live with tents, but the City does not go over there and clean it up, just like they're dogs. You wouldn't even treat a dog like that. I mean, where's the government? Where's the people that are cleaning our streets? You keep paying people to clean our streets in Dorchester, Roxbury, and we got to go looking around and see all this trash, masks and stuff all over the place. It's not right. If you're going to do something, stand up to your word.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: Thank you for sharing. So, I want everybody to know that we appreciate your questions. Now, what experience in your life got you to ask that question or to [inaudible] to that question? A personal experience in your own life. Tarazer.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: My personal experiences, all the things that I'm saying is a personal experience. I mean, I go to Target and look at all these people. Now they're doing drugs in front of Targets. I go over there and I gets the 8 bus to go to deli, there's a whole lane of people with trash just leaning all over the place. Nobody's cleaning. At least clean it up once a week. I mean, the housing they build is good, but like I said, keep your word.

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: Just basically the rush. I guess Boston has been one of the slower cities to start the schooling back, but they just want to be like every place else. I don't know if they're paying attention to what's happening in the other states, where the kids are coming down with all this extra variants and... It's not working. What is their plan to make it even better? I was in a meeting with the schools the other day, with parents asking, "If you aren't giving me a billion-percent security that my child is not going to get COVID going back to this school, then I don't want it. I would like to go back to the remote model." And they just keep saying that we need to come to our electorals and tell them what we want. And I'm pretty sure there's been enough parents that have expressed their disapproval of this move, but what do they want?

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: It's almost like those parents that want their kids in school, then go ahead and send your kids. But there should be an option for either remote or hybrid because, like you said, this pandemic isn't over. And now we have new variants and the virus changes and mutates, so it'd be best if parents had more of a say-so in these decisions.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: Sorry. [inaudible]. Oh. So, I would just like to add a different perspective in terms of the parents having their kids in school versus the hybrid schedule. I don't have children in school at this point, but I do manage staff and a lot of my staff have younger kids at home. So, the expectations from the employer is they can give 100% to their 40 hours, but it's really unrealistic to ask them that if kids are required to stay home and things like that, so it's like a double-edged sword. So, I think it's a huge issue that they're going to have to, overall, really deal with. Personally, I think the hybrid isn't a bad thing because it's a happy medium. And we do have to function and move forward, but there are requirements in place for safety measures. So, again, there's just a lot of different folds in terms of people's concerns around going to school, staying home. I would not be on that committee.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: So, as far as me, in terms of my future, my question I had in regards to minorities being able to purchase in the city, this, for me, really hits home because I was blessed to have the opportunity to purchase a home in Roslindale probably five years ago. And I have a lot of friends that have really bussed there to save their money. Now that they're in a position with a decent amount of down payment, they've worked 99 jobs, guess what? They can't afford to buy here in Boston. So, to be going out, commuting back in for work, I think it's just unfair and there should be something in place where people can still afford to buy housing here within the city.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: All right. So, what I want you to do next is to think back to each of the questions and experience that you just shared in our group, find someone whose question or experience resonates with you and your own life, then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you, and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. And then we can give everyone a minute or two to reflect. Whoever's ready can start us off.

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: Okay, I'll go first. Okay. Actually, everybody's question resonates somewhat with me. As a mom, it does concern me because topic about if the city is rushing things, as far as the pandemic. So, that is something that concerns me. I'm glad that they reinstated the mask mandate because, when going out to eat, I was not comfortable seeing servers and people in the kitchen staff handling food. I've witnessed someone sneeze while delivering food to a person, and it just wasn't a comfortable feeling. So, it's nice to see that at least the City of Boston has reintroduced the mandate for mask wearing, whether you're at the grocery store, doctor's office, things like that.

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: So, as far as the Methadone mile, I think it's heartbreaking and it's something that we are all sick of and want some resolution for. I had my own thoughts of what they should do, round them up and bring them back down to the South Shore where they're coming from, because the majority of these people aren't residents in the City of Boston. So, I think that our elective officials really need to meet with the officials and the mayors and things of these other communities because these people are taking resources from the City of Boston. They're coming here, and like you said, it looks like a third-world country over there. It's not safe. Every other week, one of them is stabbing one another. Just going to doctor's appointments, having to walk from one building at Boston Medical Center to the next, it's like, "Oh. What am I about to encounter today?" And, oh, I can't even get on the purchasing of a home in the City of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: I'm one of those that is just looking outside of Boston. No, I can talk on all the topics that I would like to. We have 75 minutes, okay?

nodes.speaker: Dorothy
nodes.words: And as far as buying a house in the City of Boston, I am priced out. And I have been looking on the South Shore and everywhere else, but I don't see myself buying. First of all, the violence in the city keeps me from wanting to buy a house. I have a young son and that was always one of the things that had us decide that Boston wasn't going to be the place for us. But... Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
nodes.words: So, I would like to piggyback off of Dorothy's in terms of housing for seniors. I think housing, period, in Boston... There's a huge, huge need. There's a lot of families and people out there but there's not enough housing for it. Again, we piggyback on people not being able to afford their rent. Thank God of the mandate for people not getting evicted. There's a lot of people out there that need for that. And I just think it's really scary that officials aren't looking into the housing situation here. I mean, you guys know, I mean, I work for an organization that we provide resources for the underserved and people that need housing, food. The resources are not out there. So, here you are working with someone and you can't give them what they deserve and they need. So, I have big issues and concerns around that and hoping that, that's being addressed and can be addressed more.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: A lot of these topics resonate with me. Firstly, I am a homeowner through one of Boston's programs that help to give affordable homeownership, but I believe like there are some loopholes that stifle our people. When you go through this process, it doesn't allow for advancement.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: It doesn't allow for advancement, they don't have any resources for the homeowners after the purchase, any guidance. And then, as Dorothy had said, they tend to... When you come up with an issue with the house and the quick build of that, money rules the factor of giving these contractors the job to do something, and then they use cheap materials and product. And I don't know if the inspection process part of it is skipped over just to get pushed along just to get the home sold. And then the City's not tentative to the homeowners when they get into a serious situation. And then the reason why you go through that is because of, like what Tarazer said, the pricing, the pay that you make. Half a million dollars for a property that's probably not equal to a half a million dollars' worth of property.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: And also to piggyback is: are they trying to do what they did in the '60s and move the colored people back onto the outskirts so it's comfortable for the upper class, so to speak, people to be able to access their jobs more easily and make things convenient? It's okay that we share, but be fair. So, don't just push us all out or whatever after we've built up the community and the livelihood of all the neighborhoods and brought that equity back, and now you slyly just push the minority population of the Dorchester Roxbury Mattapan communities out.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: And I hope that those fears don't come into the homeowners and they stay with their properties, because there's people that come out here like, "We'll buy your house for X, Y, Z." And the money sounds enticing to the homeowners that are minority and don't have much, but they need to stand their ground and stay in these properties and have something to pass on to their children or their family afterwards.

nodes.speaker: Tarazer
