nodes.words: And not only that, once they sell, if they sell the property, they're not going to be able to rebuy in Boston. So, it makes no sense.

nodes.speaker: Joseph
nodes.words: That's good. So, let's talk a little bit about what we're hearing. What are you hearing in people's experience? And whoever's ready can start us off. And you can take a-

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: I think what we're hearing is that we all experience a little of all of this assumption in some shape or form, and can relate to those topics as a whole group, whether it's happened to them or you've tried to help that other person with that issue or... We're all trying to move ahead, I think, because that's all, I think, as people, that we want, to have better things and accomplish things, homeownership, safety where you were born and raised, and not have such a struggle.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: Like in the beginning of the pandemic, the diversities of... Whether we were going to get care to minority people or they just told you, "Stay home," and then they died, or... Some people couldn't not go to work. And where did they see that happening? In these areas. The people that don't make money, we could not afford to stay home and not suffer through the pandemic or whatever if you weren't going to get no aid or relief from government or whatever. That's what I think.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: Well, my whole thing is that I understand the thing that the mothers are scared for their children to go to school, but then I look at it, a lot of mothers won't get their children vaccinated. That's what you go to help the kids. And another thing that I also worry about is that a lot of kids are scared to go outside, so if they don't go back to school and start meeting friends, they're going to start getting depression. So, then we're going to have to deal with that whole thing because what kind of life are they going to have if they just stay at home? We just got back out as grownups, enjoying ourselves, and then we get wild.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: I see a lot in my grandkids and stuff. We don't want to just continue to show our kids in. So, I think it's easy to get our kids vaccinated, instead of they're sticking that thing up in their nose every... What is it? You have to do it three times a week if you go to school without vaccination.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: Yes. So, I mean, it's hard to look at you. You said... I mean, nobody said. But I don't have kids but I have grandkids, and I really look at that depression that's going on in the world and the things the kids are not really involved in that we were involved in. So, I look at it like that.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: What I feel like I'm hearing is that we all have the same common sense issues and fears, what's going on in society, in the City of Boston. And I guess we have to hope and pray that things turn around.

nodes.speaker: Tameaka
nodes.words: And that's the whole thing when you're picking a mayor, a governor, a president. I mean, they give you a lot of good feedback, all the things they're going to do, but are they really going to do it when they get in?

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: Right. Right. One of the things, though, that I think we didn't... You touched on it a little bit, on the rent mortu... What do they call it? Mortuary or whatever. One of the things that I'm having a problem with is... I understand the pandemic and I understand that it has been tough on a lot of people, certain things that I think we'll put in place just, I feel like, coddles people and allows people to abuse the system, because people weren't allowed to be evicted.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: And yeah, you don't want to put people out in the streets in the middle of a pandemic, but honestly, you was already four months behind on your rent before the pandemic. So, I don't see how that was right, then these landlords had to continue to suffer. There still had to be a mortgage that had to be paid. The banks did not say, "Oh, it's okay. You don't owe us." No. They might've said, "You don't have to pay us this month," but they tacked that onto the back of somebody's mortgage. And I don't think that, that was fair. It's crazy to me that you can earn more money sitting at home on unemployment than if you got up and went to work.

nodes.speaker: Yolande
nodes.words: I mean, shoot, then everybody should just stay home if we can get more money staying home than actually going to work. So, I think that people have taken advantage and abused the system that was put in place to help folks, and I really think that it needs to come to an end becau...

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: All right. All right, so welcome to one of the Real Talks For Change conversations. Thank you for responding to our invitation and joining this network of voices and conversations that are happening across the city of Boston. We invited you to this gathering by asking you to think of one most pressing question you have about the future of the city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. So again, thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to, knowing that it will matter.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: I will now begin recording our conversation. We want to create a sense... we want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive and... Oh, sorry, I skipped something. I will now begin recording our conversation and I need to share four important items of information with you before we do introductions. First is the purpose of this conversation. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across divides, neighborhood, political, and cultural, et cetera. And provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates and the future mayor and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your positions on the upcoming election or specific candidates. We are doing this to help build connection and foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. Secondly, I want to address that what will happen to the recording of this conversation. Following our meeting today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city will be shared with members of the Real Talk For Change team and others who have participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network. LVN, or the Local Voices Network, is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by the nonprofit organization Cortico. LVN's system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to the Explorer tool. The system highlights key words that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in the conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change to use and retain an recording in accordance with this mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of the collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations and committees, and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. Oh, boy. Okay. Sorry, got lost here. Okay. If you understand and agree to this, please say I agree.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Okay. Because we have to make sure everyone agrees. So you could put your virtual hand up, thumbs up, or you could, if you're on camera, if you're not on camera-

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. All right. Okay. I think that's it except for my good friend, Francesca, and she gets a pass. All right, thirdly, before we wrap up, we will share with you a form to fill in your name, an email address so that we can send you a gift card. We have also included a section with demographic information, which is optional. The reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect on and uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics. Please only respond to questions you are comfortable answering.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from one another's conversation... from one another in this conversation. And to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. So the first one is to speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. The next one would be to allow others to speak for themselves. Then it's share the time and allow others to finish speaking and to take turns. The next is to stay curious and ask honest questions. Pause, take time for reflection, listen generously, and assume good intentions, while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phone on silent. Next one, if you need to listen generously... No, I'm sorry. When possible, close unnecessary... No, if you need to take as moment, take a break, let the facilitators know in the chat. Does everyone know how to use the chat? It's pretty straightforward. If you have any trouble, just put a hand up.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Is everyone on board with these guidelines or is there anything else, like to ask another question at the end of that, or is there anything that anyone would like to add that would make their experience more comfortable here today? Anyone? All right, then we can get started. Sorry, I'm having a hard time seeing.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: For the ease of this virtual conversation, we are going to use a circle process... we'll use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn. I will call on people in the order in which people will be invited to respond in the chat. I'll help transition us from one person to the next. You can always pass or you could pass and ask us to come back to you after. So to begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check in. Please share your first name and where you are located at right now, then let us know how you are using the P.I.E.S. check-in. This means saying you are choosing to check in using one of the following, either physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. So they call that the P.I.E.S. check-in. So you're going to pick from one of those and let us know how you are doing. As soon as you are done, you can pass it to the next person. Does anyone have any questions about this process?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Sure. So P.I.E.S. stands for physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. And so when you check in, you want to check in from one of those spaces. So you can say, "I'm going to check in emotionally by saying blah," or, "Physically, I'm feeling blah." So they just want you to use one of those as a guide.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: I'll go first. I'm Armand, I'm checking in... I'm going to say intellectually. Check in with an intellectual check-in. I'll pass it to Edee.

nodes.speaker: Zoe
nodes.words: Hey, I'm Zoe. I'm in Boston. And I work for most of these wonderful people who are on the Zoom right now. And I'm checking in, I think, spiritually. And I will pass it to Sydney.

nodes.speaker: Sydney
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Sydney and I'm in Boston right now. And I would say I'm also checking in spiritually. And I'm going to pass it to Eric.

nodes.speaker: Caroline
nodes.words: Hey, I'm Caroline. I'm from Boston and I'm checking in feeling spiritually as well. I'm not sure who I'm supposed to pass to, but I thought I was supposed to pass it to Eric.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: All right. Well, I am George. I am from Boston as well, born and raised. And I am spiritually. Yeah, I feel like I'm in that kind of space. Thank you. All right, so now that we know who is here, let's get to the core of our conversation. Excuse me. Sorry, hold on one second. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have heard and what we have learned about inequality in America, and Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keep in your mind, I'd like to invite you to think, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'd like for you to take two minutes to reflect on this and write it down somewhere, if that feels helpful for you. Thank you for sharing your question with us. And we're going to take two minutes for everybody to just sort of reflect on that question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My apologies. There is a error in the script that we discovered, and I didn't get a chance to check in with George before he began. So I just dropped in the chat for everybody to see... actually, I direct messaged it to Armand by accident. Let me drop it in the chat to everybody. It's my eyes. I thought I hit everybody. So we wanted you to take a minute to think about a question, to formulate a question, about the future of Boston and your place in it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And then the second part of that is, what in your own personal experiences in your life got you to this question? So we'd like you to take another minute or two to think about that. Armand, before you begin, and then say... I'll give you an example, my question is about affordable housing for elders on a fixed income in Boston. Will there be affordable housing for working class elders in the city of Boston? Why do I arrive at that question? Because I've moved about 18 times, I'm not a homeowner, and rents are beyond... So that's why my own personal experiences lead me to want to ask that question about the future. So that's sort of how we'd like it to go. And I apologize, George, that we discovered that schism in the script. So carry on.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Thank you, Fran. Thank you for correcting that. [inaudible] another minute and then we'll get to your answers... or to your questions rather.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: My question, right? My question about the future of Boston and my place in this future is... I mean, my question is centered around the results of the primary of the election. I voted in the election. I was happy to vote in the primary. I even took some first time voters to the polls. I was excited to see, what, two Black... three Black people in the race, people of color, and to see the results where none of them actually made it beyond the primaries. My question is like, well, will Boston ever have a Black mayor? Are they even ready for a Black mayor? I say that with the full understanding of they had their... Massachusetts had the first Black senator ever elected, the second Black governor ever elected.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: And during this time where the plight of people of color are elevated and they had three strong candidates on the ballot, none of them made it through. To me, that felt like... that was a blow. I was like, that was crazy to me. I couldn't even fathom that, especially when I looked at around, at one point in time, I think last year, maybe even this year, Boston had a Black district attorney, Black sheriff, Black chief... I mean commissioner, excuse me. But basically had Blacks in every level of law enforcement at the highest level. I don't know. And I'm thinking like, will Boston ever have a Black mayor? That's why I checked in like intellectual. Because to me, that's something... I think this was the best chance ever to have a Black man and it never happened. I know that I've been in Massachusetts a long time and I've known somebody become the mayor, they're there till they die, they leave, or they go somewhere else. This was a once in lifetime chance, I think. And I'm just kind of like, I don't know. For me, I think that plays into my experience as well. So that's my question, you know? And that's what got me to that question.

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: So I think for me, I partook in the primary and I was extremely surprised the next morning to see which candidates were no longer in the running. As a matter of fact, even talking about it now, my heart is really heavy. And so it takes me to a place where I say, as a woman of color, what could I have possibly done to maybe help to get some of those candidates over the top? I ask myself that question actually a lot. Because when I think of about it, it's somewhat hurtful. Do I think that we will ever be at a place where we could be so close now? I know that the two candidates that are in the running are considered women of color. I understand. From my perspective, as a Black woman, when I hear woman of color, I only hear Black. Black is women of color. I know that women of color can be... I'm pretty educated, I understand that. But so, yeah, I'm just a little confused a little bit. I'll get through it. But what do these folks have to offer to the community that I service? I didn't see any of them in my neighborhood of town. So it's interesting. And for someone who works for the state, it's even more interesting to me. So I guess I'll pass that on to, Zoe is it?

nodes.speaker: Zoe
nodes.words: Yes. I also thought about the election. I'm coming from a little bit of a different position being that I can't vote, I'm not a Massachusetts official resident. But I feel sort of naive or ignorant in a way, because I didn't know much about the election and I didn't know much about the candidates. And I think that's the problem. So my question is, will there ever be any future initiative directed at young people living in the city, on this topic especially? Because even though I can't necessarily vote right now, whatever the outcome is of this election, or regardless, everything that's going on is still affecting me. Being that I'm living here right now. So I think there's a lot of work to be done in that regard. And with that, I will pass it on to the next person.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Excuse me, can I just jump in for a second? So if you're not speaking, can I just have you put your microphone on mute? That'd be a big help. Thank you. Okay Sydney, sorry about that.

nodes.speaker: Sydney
nodes.words: No, no, no, you're all good. So I'm pretty new to Boston, but one of my questions has to do with the education system. So maybe how might the new changes in the education system that were major in the pandemic, reflect long-term education academics for students in Boston? Also students from various backgrounds? This means elementary school, high school, university, and being a new student in Boston at Boston University, coming as an international student, this is a question I definitely have thought of.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Sorry. I'm sorry, I said we can go to Caroline next. Thank you. I didn't know I was on mute. Sorry, and as amendment to the last question about muting, when you're not talking, please unmute when you are talking. Thank you. Caroline, it's all you. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Caroline
nodes.words: Thank you, sorry. My question is about the wealth inequality in Boston. I think that the pandemic really pushed the issue to a lot of people's minds about the wealth disparities. And because I'm a college student, I'm living in Boston and I understand that colleges are unfortunately, in a lot of cases, the cause of a lot of gentrification in areas. So my question is really what is Boston doing to protect lower income communities and how are they balancing... or how will they balance in the future the pros of having lots of people come to the city and the revenue that brings, while also staying true to the people who live in Boston? And sorry, I'll pass to Eric.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Did anyone not have an opportunity to speak for this round? Okay. Sorry. All right, we will go around again and each person will share their question and then tell the story of an experience that led them to their question. We'll go in the same order as before. Are there any questions right now?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Yeah, we're going to go in the same order as before, right? And I just said that we're going to go around... It's just the same thing, it's just the next part of it. So we're still going to be in the circle, we're still going to go around everyone's... we're going to keep the same process.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: We didn't get to the question yet. I was just letting y'all know we're getting to the second part of it. Again, I'm following a script. What I want you to do next is think back to the questions and experiences that were just shared in our group, find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. Did everyone understand that?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Okay. Nobody needs me read it again? Okay. So listen, just take a minute and reflect on that and whenever... Noble, whenever... I mean, good brother, whenever you're ready, you can start. Armand.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: Okay. First, I want to say a few people here resonated with me with their question and their experience, but I'm going to touch on what Zoe said. The fact that she's not able to vote even though she's here and she's active. I did a lot of time in prison where I was disenfranchised and I was unable to vote. And so just hearing that and seeing another person being a positive contribution to the world and not being able to contribute politically, to me, definitely resonates. And I also resonate with what Edee says, too. So I might be making the rules here, but I love what she said about is there ever going to be a time like this, that happens again. That's how I feel. This was the best time, everything was right, and I can't fathom why it went wrong. I can't, I can't, I can't, I can't. So it's like, I'm befuddled. I'm befuddled when it comes to that.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: And I will also say, I relate to what Caroline said about gentrification. That's because I'm in Roxbury, I'm in Boston, I'm in a place that's getting gentrified daily. When I left the city, it was all Black. I never even seen a white person walking around. And now white people buying up all the property. Everybody but Blacks seem like they buying up stuff around mean and it's... And I don't know how that process could be reversed. But I always looked at Roxbury as a Black mecca for Massachusetts or even the North East. So just to see that and be a part of it and happened to be jeopardized by it, because I could be homeless soon as a result of that. So a lot that was said resonated with me. And I would yield to Edee.

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: So for me, I'm pretty disheartened by... I mean, it takes a lot to get me disheartened. I've worked for the state for a very long period of time and I think that I have a little bit of shield kind of built around me. But I am just so disillusioned about politics and the prospect of, "You want my vote? Okay, you would like my vote? What are you going to do to work for my vote?" And I think that that's not something that we talk about or people talk about a lot and every vote is precious clearly, but you've got to work for it. I'm not going to just give it to you because you knocked on my door and you gave me a flyer and said, "Hey, I'm running for office." And it's not even the candidate that's coming by the house. It's somebody working on their team. So that's not being translated.

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: And I think the political system just becomes so politicized that it gets to a point where it's like, what about the people on the ground? What about these young men and women getting out of prison, who've been told all these years, "You can't vote," when the law really says you can't vote while you're in the institution. But people get out and say, "I can't do jury duty, I cannot vote. I can't do any of that," and it was like, who told you that? You couldn't do any of that stuff when you were behind the wall, but... So there's lots of stuff that needs to be out there and people need to be educated if those are the votes that they really want. But maybe that kind of work is too hard. I don't know. Maybe I'll call Jay-Z and see if he's got a organization that might be able to help with that. On that note, I'll pass it to Zoe.

nodes.speaker: Zoe
nodes.words: I think that's a good idea, Edee. If you speak to him, I want to be a part of that meeting.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: [crosstalk], Edee. I know you're powerful, but I didn't know it was like that. I didn't know you had a Jiggaman like that.

nodes.speaker: Zoe
nodes.words: Okay, I'll be there. I'm in two directions right now. Naturally, I relate to what Sydney said about the education system. Being someone who... education was significantly affected by COVID, my undergrad year ended with COVID and then my post-grad year started with COVID as well. So I do think a lot of great things have been done to sort of make up for the in-person. However, I do think nothing's going to go back to the way it was before, and I'm curious to see how we move forward from here. While I can't relate to this directly, I've had a lot of exposure to exactly what Edee was talking about in terms of people coming out of prison and jail, and thinking that some of the same limits that they experienced in these institutions are the same limits that they had in the outside world. And that's just something that we have all been working towards as a group, especially here, towards changing. And it just opened my eyes to the fact that we need to do it... or I need to do it, even more so beyond this scope. And that's something that I want to do moving forward. And with that, I will pass it to Sydney.

nodes.speaker: Sydney
nodes.words: Thank you, Zoe. I definitely relate to Zoe's question, as we both kind of came to Boston and we both aren't allowed to vote. And I also just, I didn't know a lot about the election and I felt like I've seen some things in the news and papers, but I didn't really know much about it until it was coming towards the end of the election. So just having resources and the ability for students, especially students who are not allowed, and aren't able to be part of this election, just resources to educate these students and other Bostonians, would be very helpful. And I'll pass it on to Noble.

nodes.speaker: Caroline
nodes.words: Thank you. Every question that was asked was so insightful, but I was really drawn to Edee's question. I think the idea of what more could I have done, which was something you said early on when you were speaking, really resonated with me. Especially being a young person who has only been able to vote in one presidential election, you're told a lot of stuff. And I live in Boston, but I'm from New Jersey, where should I vote? Where will my vote make the biggest impact?

nodes.speaker: Caroline
nodes.words: And I think that, unfortunately, something that has come up with a lot with people who are return citizens from incarceration, [inaudible], but then also just people my age in general, is that there's not that much information out there that's really accurate. All the information that you're getting is for certain political parties, or for certain people, and so it's biased. And I think that there really needs to be a, just general guide for people our age, or for people who are maybe voting for the first time, that just gives you an idea of how to do it, how the system works, in a way that isn't politicized. Because unfortunately when things are so politicized and the parties split, it just makes things so complicated for people who are really trying to get into it. And it make politics feel kind of like an exclusive party, as opposed to they're civil servants, they should be working for us. Thank you. Sorry, I don't know if that really made a lot of sense.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Give him a second. Eric, are you with us? Okay. So is there anything else that anybody who is here would like to... I mean, I think would like to add to this topic this difficult. It was for me as a facilitator to not be like, "Yeah, and this is how I feel about this, too." But yeah, does anyone else have anything they would like to add at this [inaudible]? Okay. So let's talk about what we are hearing. What are you hearing people's experiences? What are you hearing from each other and what people are saying? And whoever is ready can start us off.

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: What am I hearing in people's experiences? Are we talking about people's experiences in this group or what am I hearing around the city?

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: In a lot of ways. I mean, this is a pretty big city. I know that politicians usually stick to areas of where people are voters or people that will go to the polls, and they concentrate on those folks. And making sure that these folks reach out to them, but they don't reach out necessarily to the people who are registered voters, who really are expecting to hear something, to hear a word from them. So they just don't do enough politicking as far as I'm concerned in regards to selling themselves as the best candidate. That is a major problem.

nodes.speaker: Edee
nodes.words: I remember growing up in this city, when politicians were knocking on your door, it wasn't their proxies, it was the politician themselves. Can a politician knock on every door in the city of Boston? Well, you can if you want the vote. And that's just how I feel about it. As unrealistic as it may sound. There's something that you want from me that I can give to you, but my vote counts for what the next four years is going to look like for me as an individual. How do I pay off by you becoming the mayor? How am I going to benefit? I gave you my vote and I don't even know how I'm going to benefit in any way. The last couple of mayors, I haven't benefited in any way whatsoever.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: I'm here. I'm here. I don't see that I'm hearing... I'm hearing a lot of... how can you say, dissatisfaction? And that's always been the case, I think. I've never been in an era where people who have been politically satisfied, like that's always the... it's always the situation that everybody's dissatisfied or it's a high level of dissatisfaction. But I'm also hearing a lot of, I think a lot of emotion. So I'm hearing a lot of emotion and I'm hearing a lot of... I kind of just feel like that somebody... I was in a meeting at the day after the election, I was in a meeting. And it was a community meeting and everybody was upset about the results of the election. And everybody was saying basically that... not everybody, but the theme was that people of color in this city, don't have a big enough block to just propel a person of color into a position. They only have ability to... The going theme, the going theme that everybody believe, but they only have ability to swing an election. I mean, not make an election.

nodes.speaker: Armand
nodes.words: And yeah, so I don't know. I don't know. I'm hearing a lot, but I'm feeling a lot. I'm feeling as if there's a lot of people who not only being dissatisfied, but feeling they-

nodes.speaker: Zoe
nodes.words: Yeah, I can go. What I'm hearing is that we can all... we're all affected by each one of our questions and experiences in one in some way. So while we're experiencing this sort of disconnect, as Edee said, really, I guess there should... there is at the same time some unspoken connection. And I think that's the problem, that it's unspoken and not realized. And as a result, we feel further apart from each other than we should or than we actually are. And I pass it to Sydney.

nodes.speaker: Sydney
nodes.words: What I've been hearing is that I think there's just so much work that needs to be done within the city, whether that's kind of incorporating multiple... sorry. There's just a lot of work that needs to be done regarding people knowing more about certain things within the city and including different populations and multiple different aspects within the city, so yeah. And I'll pass it on to Caroline.

nodes.speaker: Caroline
nodes.words: Thank you. I think the thing that I heard most of was sense of alienation. And I believe that our experiences and this alienation that we feel is probably similar to the experiences of the majority of the people in Boston. And it's unfortunate that the majority of the people would feel alienated by a process that's meant to really serve everyone. And I think that a lot of it goes back to what Edee said about [inaudible] between politicians now. But I think that Zoe was also correct in saying that we hold the power and there is a connection in our shared experiences, that we all kind of need to unite and ask for what we want in a way... and I think that a lot of people do that, but in a way that will really get our point across and to the people who hear it the most. And I'm not sure what that would look like or what would be most effective, but I think that if everyone is feeling... or not everyone, but if a lot of people are feeling alienated by a process, then the process needs to change. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Thank you. That was great. Okay. So there was one thing that I missed, and we only have... I'm trying to stay on track, but there was one thing I missed. And it was, I believe... unless we did this, and again, this is part of my training, this is my last day of training. That's why Francesca's here as well, we really want to make sure that we get this done well. So any feedback you guys have, except for [inaudible] let me know.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: So it just says, if you wanted to say anything to anyone else about their experiences, it says to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you and then you could share a story from your life that connects you with that experience. And I feel like we kind of did that in the beginning, but I didn't know if anybody wanted to say something... We all did pick a personal, "Yeah, this person is..." and said we resonated with them. You know what I mean? So if anybody wanted to say anything further on that, I wanted to give them an opportunity.

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: And other than that, it is time for us to wrap up. So thank you all for sharing your questions and your experiences. So right now we're going to just quickly go around and share something that you'll be taking away with you and I'm inviting you all to share whatever you want. So do you have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share or other general reflections? Or do you have any questions for us?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Hold on one second. Just a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts you shared. These recordings will be transcribed, indexed, and shared with the Real Talk For Change team. You will receive an email from us when all the conversations are ready to review on the LVN platform. Okay. Edee, you had a question?

nodes.speaker: George
nodes.words: Oh, I'm sorry. I hope I didn't throw you off. So sorry. If you remember, please let us know. I mean, we can come back to it. Does anyone else have any questions? No? Okay. Well, before we leave this call, please stay for a couple of minutes and fill out our Zoom poll. You just need to include your name and email address so that we can send you a gift card. And as a reminder, that you will find in there a section with demographic information. Please fill in your neighborhood and any of the remaining you find comfortable sharing, it will help us a lot when servicing and uplifting the voices of diverse communities. All right-

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So we are already recording and we have to do consent for that. I wanted everyone to post it in the chat that they consent. I think that's how we doing it, but you could say yes. I'm going to read the [inaudible] agreements and do the recording script. So the purpose of this conversation is to create a new space across the city to facilitate constructive listening across the different divides while we focus on personal stories from lived experience. This conversation is being recorded. It's audio and your face won't be on the recording itself, just your voice and your name will be uploaded onto the Local Voices Network. So I'm going to read.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree and you could type into the chat and you can also voice it and say I agree. We really want everyone's voice to say I agree to being recorded.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome. So what I'll do now is we're going to use a conversation agreement. Fran, if you could type that into the chat, the conversation agreement, that'd be great. So speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Stay curious. Ask honest questions, pause, take time for reflection, listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible close unnecessary programs, applications and notifications and put your phone on silent or vibrate. If you need to take a moment, take a break, let the facilitators know in the chat. Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome. So we'll do a quick round of introductions, name, where you live or work in Boston and what neighborhood and then we'll do a PIES check-in and everyone would share how they're doing. I'll post that in the chat what PIES is. Let me see or Fran, can do it, that'd be great. I'm putting her to work, I'm so sorry.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So I'll check in first just to give us an idea of how check in goes. My name is Ziona and I lived in Boston. I still do some volunteer in Boston frequently and I grew up mostly in the Mattapan area. I'm a community organizer and volunteer with mostly the mental health and recovery community. My PIES check in, PIES stand for P is physically, your wellbeing physically. I is intellectually, how your wellbeing is intellectually. E is emotionally, how your wellbeing is emotionally and S is spiritually how your wellbeing is spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So you would pick one of the PIES to check in and say how you're doing. I'm going to go for intellectually, I'm very focused lately. I've been prioritizing everything that I need to do as far as groups that I have to facilitate and work that I need to be done. So I'm feeling well intellectually. And then what I'll do is for the entirety of the conversation, I will call on people in a random order to share and check in and speak and all of that. So mute is very important and unmuting is very important. So I'll start off with Cynthia, see if she would like to check in and do our PIES. Where do you live in Boston and just go from there.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: Okay. I'm Cynthia and I live in the Government Center area downtown and I'm a substance abuse clinician although I'm not working right now. I will select spiritually. I am developing my relationship with God and really working hard on being kind to everybody and being really quiet and really meditating on kindness.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you for sharing that Cynthia and welcome to the conversation. I believe we have a caller, I don't know iPad, I don't know if that's William.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. I just dropped in the chat what we're doing, William. So we're glad you're here. Ziona is facilitating, I'm her coach this evening so I'm off sounding camera but I just jumped in. I'm so glad you're here. William is a young artist and just an all around wonderful dude. I'm so glad you joined.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: All right, that's fine. Thank you for having me. I appreciate having a moment in order to discuss or even to be a part of this conversation, I very appreciate it and I'm here to listen. I'm also here to put in my own point of view so thank you for-

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So we're going around and doing check in. William, we'll come back around to you to do the check in point maybe while other people are going, you can get a gist of how we're doing the check in. Cynthia just checked in and I'm calling on people one by one to check in so I was going to go to Bruce next.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Hello everyone. Good evening. My name is Bruce Biggerstaff. I live in the Mission Hill area of Roxbury and it is still Roxbury. I've been in Boston since 1971 and been active throughout the communities of [inaudible] Roxbury and Dorchester. And I guess I will go to... Well, I've already said I'm physically okay, at least as far as I know. My sense is a combination of emotion and spiritual. I try to keep up as was just pointed out, keeping an emotional balance, because so many times people try to disturb or steal your peace by just setting you off with no rhyme or reason.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: And I try to, like you said, keep a good filter, keep my head up and eyes to the sky. Spiritually, I think it's like so many other folks, you again, try to maintain focus to whatever one would call that higher power and the basic tenets because that I think that spiritually, each and every cohort or discipline most speak to love and respect of fellow human beings. And if I can stay within those parameters and continue to ask from my higher power for grace and a bit of tranquility in turbulent times, I'm good. Period.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome. Thank you, Bruce. For that lovely introduction. I'm going to go next to Nancy, see if she wants to check in and do her PIES?

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: Hi, everyone. I'm Nancy. I use she, her pronouns. I've lived in Boston for about seven years. I've lived in the West End for six months and I lived in Roxbury before that, in Lower Roxbury. And I'm a part-time student in Roxbury Community College. And I also volunteer in the mental health community. And for PIES, I guess I'd say it's a cross between spiritual and intellectual. I'm trying to finish my classes this semester, so I'm trying to stay focused and stay organized and stay out of trouble and get all my work done and praying to God and asking for help to do all of that. So that's where my focus is. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: Hi, everyone. Good evening. Minnie. I also use she, her pronouns. I'm happy to be with you all. I live in Columbia Savin Hill area as of September 1st. I've been working in Roxbury and North Dorchester for about two and a half years and come from Cambridge. That's where I'm from. Yeah. Well, I'll start with the physically, tired because that just is the most accessible thing, which has a dulling effect on the spirit and the emotions. I think when I tap into the spirit and emotion a little bit it's I feel this positive fall energy, like that clock that was ingrained, really kicks in and I feel that new beginning fall vitality in general. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Turita
nodes.words: Hi everybody. I'm Turita. I am 27. I live in Dorchester. I lived in Boston, mostly my whole life. I've moved around bit to bit from Mattapan to Brockton and then I spent some time in [inaudible] for me to as well. Physically, I'm feeling all right. I feel like it was a beautiful day and it was nice to be outside, so that was good. Spiritually and emotionally, I am doing much better now. It's been a rough couple of weeks, but the last few days have been easier. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome, Turita. Thank you. And last but not least for this round, is William, would you like to check in and do the PIES? Do you understand how to do it?

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: I understand, mostly. So my name is William Ighalo. I'm a visual artist. I am a teacher. I've been able to be implemented into a lot of projects within the Boston region, especially Roxbury with the Black Lives Matter mural. And I've also, politically, no, I have not been too engaged into it, but I've also had the ability to meet mayors of both cities, both sizes like Cambridge, as well as Boston. I've also worked a lot with Cambridge city. So spiritually, how do I feel? I feel as a young artist, I feel that we need to connect ourselves with more of our surroundings. My fault, I'm a little nervous right now.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: Yeah. So spiritually, I could say that as artists or even people who were really trying to implement themselves within the community, we need to take advantage of our surroundings because our surroundings at the moment it's being taken over, especially with a lot of people coming in from the city, we're number one in the city when it comes down to business or even pharma and things of that nature.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So I definitely want to say the spiritual, I want utilize my city a lot more. And mentally I've been isolated because as an artist, as a creative, I've been able to just withhold or just stand in my own area. And I'm trying to create a brand where it's actually helping people, but at the same time, show the people or even get an inner perspective of what we are, especially as Boston natives. And I feel like that's something that we're missing in our city because people come to Boston regular, but we need to be natives. We need to show what it is.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yes, William. Thank you so much for sharing that and your perspective as an artist. I know, I do some art and there might be some other people in here that I definitely respect that. So with that, thank you everyone for checking in. I want to get into the bulk of the conversation because William got us going, we want to talk more about the major question and questions that we have. So I'm going to post the question for the question in the chat so everyone can look at it and let me look at the instructions.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So in this question, basically, we want you to take time to pose a question and reflect on that and you can write it down. I'll give everyone about two minutes to reflect and ponder on the question. So the question is, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? So you're coming up with a question, not an answer to the question. And it's also posted in the chat. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'll give us two minutes on the clock to ponder on that, write it down if you want and everyone will get a turn to share.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: (silence) Okay. So that was about two minutes. I hope everyone had some time to reflect and come up with a good question about the future of Boston. So I will go around randomly popcorn style and-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Ziona, excuse me. We don't want people to do the question yet, look in the chat. I sent you a direct message in the chat. Group messages, do you see them?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. Because you want people to state the question and the story, because we got started a little later and we want to move it, I'm going to drop the sequence of speakers in the chat and you can just unmute yourself after you're done and that way-

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. That's good. Okay. So the other question, that's part of that... I apologize you guys, this is why we're doing this so I can get better at it. The question is, give them minutes just to come up with a story. What experience in your life got you to this question is the other part to the question. So what personal experience in your life got you come up with the question that you're raising for the future of Boston. And then Fran is going to, put everyone's name in the chat in order so that we can all just... You see your name, who's next and go. Right, Fran? I get that right?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah. I made a mistake, but let's go with Bruce, Cynthia. This is how people signed on, Bruce, Cynthia, Nancy, Turita, and Minnie and William. And I'll put that in the chat now so that you don't have to keep remembering. It'll just be there.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Hold on. Did you get the second part to the question that I messed up, Bruce? Just that question two, that you're going to answer, but then it's also what experience in your life got you to this question? That's the other part to it.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Okay. Well, I oftentimes wonder why we cannot be more kind to one another. Most of the grief that we encounter is not around [inaudible]. I have seen examples and it may be poor and to some, but how Bostonian's pulled together in 911 or some tragic events such as the bombing on Boylston Street. And well, not so much because we've been forced to be separate, what is going on with COVID-19. It's a choice that each of us, as individuals make as to how we're going to interact with others.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Now, there's weighted factors who has resources, who doesn't, but because we all are here in the same way, we're born from our mothers, what go on between that time that we broached the womb and where we are in our particular life has lot to do with things in terms of how we're impressed to the world. But on the other side of it, is why can't we find it within ourselves to, like you said, just get along and be concerned about-

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Well, because I don't have a magic wand per se. I can't influence, I would love to be able to influence everybody just in a positive way. So I almost have to internalize this to say be The One, whoever The One is to make a world a community and there's concentric circles from one to even this group and others, people you don't know to try to be peaceful and resourceful and sharing and caring for the next person. And I don't know if that's a question or an... I hope it's an answer, but just to lending of thought.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: We really want it to be stated as a question, if it's possible. Is there a way we can work it into a question together?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: What you're saying is we need to be more initiative into kindness, within the community. And I think the question you're posing is how can we be more kind to each other and how can we be more resourceful of one of the other, I think I'm frozen.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Resourceful, caring, and as well as forgiving, I think some of these things have to because it's not me, we're always in the conundrum above. Well, why is this happening? Why is that happening? As opposed to trying to pick up that piece of paper or look in someone's face and smile and say something pleasant. And at times, even find a way tactfully and lovingly to correct. Maybe that's not the kind sounding word so that we can adjust each other's paths.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: Hi, my question is, is Boston becoming more dangerous? And this is my question because I was outside on a summer afternoon, it was about three o'clock. And I was chased by a man who was very scary looking. He chased me down Stanford Street, and before he chased me, he started yelling in a very loud voice, "Want to fight? Want to fight?" And I had no idea who this man was. I had never seen him before. I didn't know him, but he crossed the street and came after me. And I went running down Stanford Street, try to escape him. So that's how my question came to be feeling physically threatened and really, really scared about living in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: In terms of the second part of the question. I don't want to live in Boston anymore. I really had enough of Boston. I'm in my sixties now and I want to live in an area that's not polluted, where the air is not polluted, where it's very easy to park. And where the pace is slower. I want to live in peace and Boston is not the place for peace. It's very noisy.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yeah. Government Center. Thank you, Cynthia. Well, yes, you answered the question with a question and you, also stated your experience to why you came up with that question. So you hit the marks, Cynthia, just so you know and I'm sorry that happened to you.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: And I hope that you can figure something out that's more suitable for you, but thank you for joining the conversation anyway. So the next person we had on the list to share their question for the future of Boston and the experience was Nancy.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: For me, what's important to me. And I don't think any of the candidates really answered this well is how can we make housing more equitable for everyone in Boston? I've been homeless twice, due to domestic violence. Actually right when the Long Island shelter was closed, right before the hundred inches of snow that we got that winter and I'm grateful and privileged and blessed to have gotten housing after a few months of that.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: But I observed like when I go over to doctor's appointments over at BMC or being around methadone bile or mass and cast, as some people call it and the situation has gotten more out in the open and it makes me sad and just disappointed to see people not housed. I know that there's some small group that like to be outside because it's hard to be in a shelter, but I don't feel like the city is really doing enough. And I realized that it takes time to build housing, but I wish the city would make an even more stronger stance. And I don't mean just treatment, but having things like there's something called the housing first model where you don't put a ton of rules in front of someone and say, "You have to be six months sober or you have to stay in the shelter for three months before we'll fill out your verification of homelessness form."

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: All these things that just make it that much harder. It's harder to be sober when you're out on the streets. And so, I feel if we had a more listed... I mean, I can't have all the solutions, it's complicated and we could spend literally a whole day talking about just this topic. So for me, I'd like to see the homeless get more shelter and get housing and also to people who've lived here for decades and have been here, I don't like seeing people pushed out to the suburbs, to other states. So we should have housing for medium income levels too and low income and the elderly and disabled and all of that. So thank you. I won't go on and on.

nodes.speaker: Turita
nodes.words: Hi, everybody. I would say that my question would be with the recent elections, what does justice reform and police reform look like in this city, in the future? I didn't really follow the election so closely, so I don't really know what's going on with that. But, I asked that question because I have had... I grew up getting into fights and stuff in the community, but I've had several interactions with the police specifically, like the [inaudible] that it was extremely uncomfortable and borderline traumatic. So, I just wonder if that's something that is going to be worked on in the future, not just in the country, but specifically in this state and in the city.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: Yeah. I like this exercise. It's hard to come up with the questions, but it's cool to hear people. I guess, the question I'll say is, will this be a city in which people can be free to be rather than struggle to be? And, for me that touches on a lot of things. The thing at the forefront of my mind is housing and to people being able to be home and feel home and have security in their homes and have their neighborhoods be familiar. And a lot that comes from my history doing a little bit of organizing in Boston, just on a volunteer basis, over the last five or so years. And then more recently, my work is very focused on, housing and neighborhood planning work and know people's control of their own space.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: Yeah. I think struggle is... You can't eliminate struggle in the human experience and suffering, but struggle based on, to borrow from Bruce, because of how or where we were born into. Struggles as a result of all the things that divide us. What does a place look like where everybody can be? And by be, I don't mean like coexist without tension. I mean, where we can express ourselves fully and not be worried about getting food on the table and at whatever, whether you're fortunate enough to be, gainfully employed, have a career or wherever you are on the various spectrums of life, to feel whole and to have a rich spiritual and community life.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: So I don't know where those places are. I think those places exist in every place. I don't know if there's a city where people feel free to be. I think Boston, I think we have a long way to go to be... Yeah, I wouldn't go to Boston first if I had to make a list of those cities, even though one probably doesn't exist. All right. I will pause there. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So actually I had several questions. Is it all right that I go through all my questions because I felt like everybody set a certain point of each question. So the first question was, is there going to be affordable housing? And I believe that was Cynthia or Francesca, I don't remember which, but I think it was Cynthia notified that there is a lot of homelessness in their city. And I know that I live very close to methadone mile, which is technically my side. So there is a lot of homeless people-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: William, I love you. I'm interrupting because this part of the conversation is your question and your personal experience. And then the next part is to talk to somebody specifically about what question they had that connected to you and why. So you are always ahead of the agenda, my love. So I just want to stop you, also because you came on late, but Ziona is training and I'm helping her. So I wanted to just ask you to take a second, pick one of your questions and then your own personal experience. Share why you chose that question? You, William.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: My personal question is, are minorities set in higher class neighborhoods, especially coming from me. I'm 23 years old, but I lived in the city for so long and I've also been born and raised here within and New York. So I was raised here and I was also raised in the Bronx, but one thing I've understood is, not all minorities are accepted in every neighborhood. We used to go into Lower Allston or even Little Italy or even North End, and those kind of areas, you don't really see any of these operators or even businesses in that area. So to say, there is a restriction between Boston and Natives and then coming back to Bruce's ideal is why can't we not all live in peace, but for understanding is the reason why we can't leave in peace because we live under different tax brackets.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So as me, I'm a Roxbury native. I could go as far as South End and feel included because there's many Latinos living there. But as a Roxbury native, when I was working in Cambridge, I felt excluded. I felt like I wasn't a part of that neighborhood, even though that neighborhood is, it's two cities in one. So it's very difficult to say or to view that. Okay, I'm from Boston, I'm from the bean, I'm a Red Sox fan. I'm the official patriarch. There's things of that nature, where we are all implemented in, but at the same time, we can't just all cross each other's regions.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So my thing is when is it that it's going to be acceptable as me as a Roxbury native, that I'm accepted in Downtown Boston? Now it's very hard because I know the city has different on plans where they're putting in new housings, they're putting in new programs that doesn't really abide by Boston residential people. It only abides by people outside of the city or the ones that are coming in because Boston is technically known as the hub.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So being the hub, that means we're bringing in different businesses from all over the world. So being that means we're bringing in different businesses from all over the world. And a couple years ago, we was known as the number one city in the country. So my thing is, when is it that the people from our city are going to be accepted in our city? Because we're the ones who make Boston real. We're the ones who make it, the way it is, the persona of being a Bostonian, is not these out of state people. That's my difficulty of understanding. Are we really going to be fully accepted or are we not? And that's the end of mine.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you, William. So we're going to move on to the next part of the question. I'm going to drop in the chat. Oh, Fran's ahead of me. Thank you, Fran. And I posted the order of the names of which we should go in. So the second part of this conversation is, we need to find someone in the group whose question or experience resonates with our own life. Address that person and tell them why their experience resonated with you, and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience? What are you hearing in people's experiences? So find a commonality and connect with someone.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yeah, William just did that. He's always a foot ahead, which is not a bad thing, because he led us right into where we're going into next. So the order that we have is... Did everyone understand that part? Finding someone to resonate with their experience or their question? Okay. So the first person on the list would be Nancy, then it would be Bruce.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: All right. It's hard, because I feel I resonated with everyone's questions. But I have to say, while it's fresh in my mind, I would agree with William. There's the economic factors, but too, I think it's like, as I was saying earlier, when I was asking my question was how do we make sure that actual Bostonians who've lived here, don't get left out. So many people move in and do finance and biotech and all of that stuff. Is it possible that we could actually make... I wonder, is there a way that you could make a residency preference for people who have been born in Boston or lived in Boston so many years, like on the affordable housing. Some way to keep the people who've been here 40, 50 years is one aspect. Like I said, I can go on and on about this house stuff. It's close to my heart.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: Nancy, can you express yourself about the housing situation because I feel like at this point in time within our city, we are experiencing a heartbreak, because I even helped one of my friends to get into a shelter.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I hate to cut anyone off, but I want us to stay as structured as possible. So each person before talking we're going to just let them express and then we'll share, we're going order for everyone to share their piece, but I don't want it to cross questions because then we're going to be short for time, but thank you William, you have a lot of insight. But Nancy, you can continue unless you are finished. Go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: No, but I talked about that earlier. I was the one who was homeless twice. And I've been in the shelters, I've worked in the shelters. And as a white person, I have a lot of privilege, and so I can't see it through the lens of other people of color and cultures, but I can say that something does need to be done and it has to be equitable for people who've lived here a long time, and people have different socio-economic statuses. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you, Nancy. Bruce, you are next to share. So who you resonated with their stories and their experience through your own?

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Well, I resonate with everyone's position in some fashion or form, but Nancy, in particular. I am a Vietnam veteran. And I know that housing as an issue began somewhere in the 70s, with veterans returning and two things, war is hell. So many veterans come return home, male and female, with a lot of issues that there should be institutions there to help people resolve their issues of what's now known as PTSD. That wasn't even a channel to turn to, if you will. Over all of our wars as this country, there been no notifications and the name has changed to protect the innocent.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: But at same time, you did not see the numbers of homelessness that you do now. And again, it's started in a very different time. You also had a situation under I believe, maybe Ronald Reagan, if any youngins can remember that, where the deinstitutionalization of folks who had issues not necessarily war related, but had mental health issues, spiritual issues that were in an essence turned out into the streets. Because the theme at the time is, well, we can find a place for them to come and get their medication. And they can self medicate, and blah, blah, blah, which was absolute down to Coca Cola.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: Now you move to a time now, where the bottom is beginning to become thicker, because of our social economic situation, Nancy spoke to and please don't misunderstand. But her position as a white person in Boston, even with that, there were prevailing kinds of situations economically, socially, that have now thickened again, the bottom of people who otherwise would not have the same worries or concerns.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: And how do we take that super huge problem and crystallize it and stop the life out of it, if you will, to bring it to the larger body because the body of people who are falling under that social economic state is growing. And it's including everybody, people who maybe once thought that they were safe. When you think about homelessness and you think about people in this town, in this city, who are second generation homeless. I'm not talking about just falling off to a corner somewhere. But a homeless person, homeless family, has now raised children who are now homeless children and growing into adulthood and they don't have any perspective of shelter. I'm not talking about the great American Dream about buying a home. I'm talking about having a place that you have keys to and there's not a whole lot of leach.

nodes.speaker: Bruce
nodes.words: So it angers me, in one sense, because again, as we see Boston growing out, there's never been a problem about supply. Because from where I started, where many of us have started, the number of units of housing have increased, but the number of homeless has increased even more so. And where is the answer? And I'm sorry for running long. But this makes me very angry and I try to manage my anger, but at the same time, it's real. It's real to too many people. And there has to be accountability, whether it's in the fifth floor of City Hall or the State House or something else. We can't keep talking about, well, we're going to solve this problem and continue to cut off the supplies to create a situation for the Nancy, for ourselves. You know what I mean? But anyway, okay, I'll put my hammer down, I'll be polite.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you, Bruce. Well, this is a conversation. This is a conversation, we just want to keep it as compact and structured as possible for the sake of time and other things. The next person on the list was Turita. About, who do you resonate with, who story you resonate with through your own?

nodes.speaker: Turita
nodes.words: I definitely think that I would say I resonate with William the most, I feel like, there's definitely too Bostons. I've lived here the majority of my whole life and there's neighborhoods that I've never been to and I probably will never go to. I don't shop there, I don't go to eat there. I don't have any friends that live there. And I don't feel comfortable walking around in those neighborhoods. So it's just very much a city divided.

nodes.speaker: Turita
nodes.words: There's places where you can just feel the vibe as a person of color. Me and my friends aren't welcomed, going out there certain dress codes, they don't serve certain drinks or certain food. Where would I go with my friends late 20s, early 30s, if we want to just go out and have a good time, young professionals, students, it's like we go to Providence or we will leave the city because there's not very many places to just go and relax and be ourselves without constant judgment or being kicked out or stereotyped. So yeah, it's very much a divided city. So I felt that. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: All right. Hello, guys. I definitely want to say that I resonate with... Thank you Turita for understanding because we do live in a younger generation where the nightlife is a little bit different from what it is in the morning from Boston, and I want to resonate as well with Cynthia and Bruce, because the housing situation is very difficult, because I know that I just recently helped one of my friends get out of homelessness, and I understand that now. There's a lot more people on the streets than there is a lot more people within these houses.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: And being a born native within Roxbury, there's been a lot of changes, there's been new development, there's been people coming in from the suburbs and things like that, like Roxbury is changing. I live in one of the most hottest neighborhoods ever, was opium all pleasant. And I know that those neighborhoods are notorious if you look into Boston history, but as of right now, it's very gentrified and what we will call it watered down, basically, compared to what odds are, well, just nothing but neighborhoods where people defended themselves at a certain type of period. So to say that, I feel like Boston is pushing out us, us as natives and things of that nature and we're not being accommodated to our own spaces. So we're forced to move out in these places.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: I remember, there was a time when Obama was in office, a lot of people would leave in the hoods and they were going into suburbs, like on Providence, they were going into other neighborhoods, but they were gaining better houses. So I guess, that's the trick of it. I don't think it was fair, because I lost a lot of friends like that. A lot of my closest friends, they live in outside of town and they wish they were back. But I think regaining the city is what we need to do and it's a hard task because we have to go to many forces, many programs, even conversations like this helps a lot too, as well because them we as a people who live here and who understand what's going on, we're able to really fulfill what is needed.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: I feel like the city, there's a lot of things that's happening but it's not really necessary. I don't really agree with what Walsh, what Marty Walsh did, I don't agree with everything he did. I fully Menino was our best man. Now we were in office, the people voting for the new person office just because somebody is a minority maybe they don't... Depending on the plan or what we have to do, I feel it that's very necessary to know. And as us the people really going to suffer from their plans. I don't feel like it's fair upon ourselves. And we got one of the best cities in the world. Honestly, I can't say that more than... Well, I can say all day, but we've got one of the best hospitals, best schooling. We have one of the best on operational nonprofit organizations. We were able to actually move and co assists between ourselves.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So I definitely want to say that this city has a lot of potential but if we don't put our foot in the door then we're going to lose it and I don't want to lose it. No, I don't. So I want us to really think about it like what we're going to do after this? Because we really co-aside and we created valid points, everybody was right, everybody had the right notion, the right evidence, it's all facts.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So I definitely want to say, Bruce, shout out to Bruce. He's on top of... The homelessness in the city is crazy right now. And is sad. It makes me feel pitiful like wow, why do we really have these people outside in the streets instead of inside of a stable establishment? And I feel like we have many organizations who do help but they don't help enough. They don't want to get these people into these situations. I felt I could go on all day with the [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you for that William. The next person, last one. Does anybody see who's next. After William I think it was, I want to say it was Minnie.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: Yeah. Just taking in what you are saying, I resonated a lot with William and your comments, your question but from a very different position, a very different. I can walk around in those neighborhoods in some of those neighborhoods you mentioned and I think my other different questions I've drafted, really the question is who is the city for and what's the purpose? What is the purpose of this place? Is it because right now to me it feels like it's like a cash cow, it's like property, property, property, speculation, the housing market. The only way to have wealth in this country is to own a home.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: I'm sure, we all know how things look and a little bit about why they look the way they look when it comes to homeownership and wealth. So I just really appreciate you, Nancy referring to your whiteness and the privilege that comes with that and I have to do the same and I have great class privilege as well. But I think it's so right and evident to me how different the neighborhoods are and how... I guess, one of the things I've been thinking about recently is violence and aggression and different ways that those manifests.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: There's the cops assaulting people. That's very clear violence. And then there's also this push, there's just the violence, which is perhaps a more subtle force in a slower progression but pushing people out and pushing people away from each other. And I feel while I have a lot of love for people and humans in places, and I think there's so much connection. Our humanity ultimately can bring us together and whoever's on this call decided to be here, doesn't mean we're friends. But we've decided to be here, it's worth our time.

nodes.speaker: Minnie
nodes.words: But at the same time, I do feel deeply concerned and unwell in my body about who is the safe or what's it going to look like in 20 years? Is it just going to be the people who have lived here longest are just totally gone. And all the triple-deckers are condos now and every single neighbor is "Oh, I don't actually know this neighborhood." So I worry about that. So your comments resonated with me, William.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: Okay. I resonated with the Turita and with Nancy. And in terms of Turita, she had shared how she would not go into certain neighborhoods. And I feel the same way. There are neighborhoods that I won't go into that I am afraid to go into, like Mattapan, like Roxbury, even Dorchester. I don't feel safe in those neighborhoods. I'm a trauma survivor, and I don't even feel safe in my own neighborhood, on my own Street. I was chased down my own street. So that's how I resonated to what Turita said.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: And it also seems like Boston has lost a lot of its fun. We used to have in the '70s and '80s and '90s, we had dance clubs and people would go to the dance clubs and dance and it was fun. And the music was great. And we don't have those dance clubs anymore, a lot of them have closed. We're lucky if we have one dance club in Boston. I don't know of any at this point.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: And Nancy, I think shared about equitable housing. There's a building that just went up next to my building and it's a 44-storey building. And it's beautiful. And it has every single amenity including a firepit. And the studios run for $3,100 and the rents go up to 5,000. I can't afford a studio for 3,100. I could certainly not afford a one bedroom in that building. But a lot of the buildings that are going up are for people who have a lot of money and there aren't enough buildings going up for poor people. Boston is a very expensive city to live in. It's expensive to park your car. You have to have a parking space if you have a car and you have to pay for parking. And the parking rates are 300 a month, 400 a month, 500 a month. At some parts of Boston, the parking is 600 a month, by paying another rent.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: So that's the first question. Then it says, address that person, tell them why the question experience resonated with you and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. Well, what I mentioned about what Turita said, how she wouldn't go into certain neighborhoods. And I won't go into certain neighborhoods because I'm afraid of being chased or mugged. I was in East Boston and I got chased through the woods and beaten up. And they took my purse. And I was on the ground. So that's a story from my life that connects me with feeling afraid to go into certain neighborhoods.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: What am I hearing and people's experiences? I'm hearing a lot of disappointment, a lot of sadness. I hear a lot of sadness. And I feel disappointed and sad too. I feel disappointed in how the city has become the danger, the homelessness, the drugs, the violence. Selfishness in our society in Boston. People have become so selfish and self-centered.
