I don't see much caring anymore. I don't see much kindness at all. Everybody's in a rush. Everybody is disconnected. Everyone's on their cell phone, driving on their cell phone. High when driving.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: I'm a substance abuse clinician and I think it's really bad that they legalize marijuana and that they put these pot shops everywhere. People are going to work high as a kite. People aren't supposed to go to work that way. They're going home to their families high as a kite. They're not supposed to be living like that.

nodes.speaker: Cynthia
nodes.words: I'm worried about death. Self medication. How people treat each other when they use drugs, how they steal to buy drugs. I'm worried about the whole thing. I'm worried about people driving when they are high. They can kill somebody. This is not good.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: You're not wrong, Miss because there's a lot of people will live on our planet with a lot of baggage emotionally. I feel like emotions is what drives humans to-

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Only because this would be a good time to go on to the wrap up, we have final thoughts, can we keep them as brief as possible, because there's one more part of the wrap that we have to do and then we'll close out the conversation. So for the wrap up, the closing thoughts, everyone does not have to go. If you have anything brief that you wanted to add about the conversation or about what's going on, you can mention it, but try to keep it at least under 30 seconds if you can.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: This is the wrap up and then we'll close out soon. And then there's a form that everyone has to fill out, then the wrap up but thank you all for sharing everything that you have shared. And it was a very productive conversation. So anyone has any wrap up points, I know William was going into something.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: So my wrap up point is basically the city of Boston is very difficult, especially financially when it comes to people obtaining jobs or even withholding their own establishment. So you can own a house or retail space but taxes are very high only because there is a higher expand market within Boston. And I also want to say, to those who don't feel safe going into certain neighborhoods, you're not wrong for not feeling safe. But at the same time, you have to understand when you don't implement yourself into those certain businesses or even... If you don't make yourself known, you're more safer than anything. Because better not to be known to be known in any situation that you're in, really doesn't matter because also I've been in the ER and the ER, it's not any better than here, honestly.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: Especially with a lot of corruption, with police corruption and things of that nature. I would like to say that you're more safer than you think you are, but I know that your experience has been very traumatic. I'm sorry to hear that. I'm sorry but don't be fearful because if you're too fearful, then you're not going to be able to proceed in your own mission as you being in a person. And it's not fair. I've been in sticky situations myself, but I can definitely say I still love Roxbury. I was born there.

nodes.speaker: William
nodes.words: My final thoughts is all y'all were right. We have the great idea. I think we just need to sit down once more again and really finalize a plan. A plan that can actually motivate and cultivate a new Boston, because we all know Boston, you can't lie. I mean, even with the bad times, you always had the good times, especially with Boston. So I don't know, I feel like we got to sit down one more time. And I appreciate everybody for speaking. Thank you for listening to me. And let's do this again, honestly, let's keep this going.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: Okay. So with what I mentioned earlier about homelessness and housing equity. Ms Wu, you have great ideas. I feel you'd ever have solid plans on how to implement them and finance them. So I would like to see actual concrete follow through along with the great idea that you have. And for Ms. Annissa George, your husband is one who works in and actually builds housing in Boston. So with your experiences, my questions are one, how are you going to make sure that while you're Mayor, things will be equitable and there will be no nepotism or impartiality, things will be neutral? Because that's a lot of concern people have.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: And two, to piggyback on that, on the positive side, how can you with your experience and being around your husband, how would you implement housing equity? And again, a whole complete plan, not just great ideas, but I want to hear an actual plan. How to finance that. These are the kinds of things I want to hear. Great ideas are awesome, but you need to actually need the steps to get to the great idea. And that's all I wanted to say. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Nancy
nodes.words: I'm fine. But I'm thinking more about all the peeps over at methadone mile like actually having housing for people and housing, they can stay in, housing first model means they don't have to be 100% sober. The idea is they get into housing and then they can actually work on their recovery. That's my big thing. All right. Thank you, everyone.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome. Thank you everyone for sharing. I have left the link to the demographic survey that all participants of the conversations are required to fill out. This will definitely be getting your Amazon giftcard, via email and fill that out. Thank you for joining the conversation. If you can't see the chat, which I'm sure everyone here is Zoom savvy enough to see the chat. Can you see it? The link there? Okay.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Good. So fill that out. Fran, did you have anything else you wanted to add before we close out? Any tips?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Well, I did want to clarify that it isn't an Amazon giftcard, it's some other kind of gift card. And I will send out directions, although you probably will be able to use it, you can only use it online. And more importantly than the gift card, because I'm sure that's not what motivated you to be here is we will upload your contact. And then once the conversations are uploaded into Local Voices Network and the mechanism to share there'll be public. Everybody that participated can click on and find the conversation. And then we will have an opportunity for folks to use this information.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And Nancy, I just wanted to say, I hope we have your email, because there's a mayoral forum tomorrow night in Dorchester, that you may want to go and see if you can ask those questions yourself. There's no guarantee that your questions will be heard by the candidates. However, the whole goal of this is to have as many voices as possible, who weigh in around the future of Boston, your place in it and why it's important to you and then to talk to random strangers about what resonates. So thank you so much. I'm just going to see what Bruce's question is. And then I also want to encourage you to drive other people to our website to sign up for other conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: First of all, I just want to thank each of you for taking the time out and responding for a call for people to participate in what we're doing here. I want to start by just giving you a little overview of what this is all about, and then I will tell you a little bit about what you do with the recordings, and everything, and your permission around that. Then, we'll jump into the real conversation, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm not sure how all of you came to this. Some of you came because you knew Fran, or you found us on the web, or you knew Ron, or you knew [Zakkiyah]. There's a group of people out there organizing folks to participate in these conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What we're doing with Real Talk for Change is basically creating an opportunity for people to be in small, intimate conversations with other people from Boston, and in those conversations to really talk about the notion of the future of Boston, and where they see themselves in it, and also about their experiences in their life that got them to that vision of what Boston could or might not be. We're taking on these conversations, they're in small groups, and we have technology that allows us to do this, to connect them together, and index them all, and then actually present them back to the public, so the public can listen, and hear, and see what others in this community in Boston are saying.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're also using this around the mayoral's candidates to both give the candidates themselves to listen to these voices, because we're really focusing on who we consider under-heard voices, and also for people who are reports or people that are holding debates to use these to actually formulate the questions that really are coming out of people's lived experience. We're using the mayoral candidate as a [inaudible] continue to collect these stories and then use them as a vehicle to ... Basically, it's an accountability measure that as the mayor, the school superintendent, or police, whoever it may be, starts to suggest different policies and approaches to problems, we can go back and connect them to the experiences of the people really having around that thing, to say, "Are you doing something that really matters for how these people are living in Boston?"

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, this is a different way of doing a town hall, a different way of having public input into something, by continually connecting and collecting these stories and experience of what life is in Boston, and then having technology allows us to connect across. That's our goal. What happens is with, when we do this in Zoom or in person, we record the audio. On Zoom, what we'll end up doing is at the end of this call, is throwing away the video. We just keep the audio.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: That's uploaded into something we call the Local Voices Network, which is a system where we store all of these conversations. From there, we have a set of community fellows and some people at MIT who are working to help produce some of that, what we [inaudible] ... What are the things that are emerging, so on, and so forth, and then making that public.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: All of the data that comes out of here is we're building a data trust that's owned by community organizations. We're in the process of building that now, as we get this, but all this data will actually be owned by a collective of community-based organizations in Boston. We will serve to actually just store and hold that in trust for them.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, that's where we're going. That's where we're headed for with this. What I want to do is read some consent language to you that asks you if it's okay if I record. Then, from there, we'll jump into everything, okay? I have to read this, unfortunately.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with our mission. You understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection at the Local Voices Network whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico, that's the nonprofit that owns Local Voices Network, will collect, retain with Real Talk for Change, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: In addition, being part of Real Talk for Change mission is to present voices from the people of Boston. Therefore, portions of your conversation could be made public. One thing I didn't say, well, actually, let me just say that right now. If you understand and agree to this, could I hear each of you say I agree?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. With that, I'll keep the recording going. Now, a couple of things I can say about the recording, if you want to stay anonymous, you can. You can change your name to be something else. If you want to do that, then just go into the Zoom thing, and rename yourself, and we will refer to you by that name going forward. We won't refer to you. Then, we only use first names. Also, the other thing, just for everyone to remember when we're referring to someone, just use their first name, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I think the last thing I'm going to say to you is at the end of the conversation, when we're finished, I'm going to drop a little form in the ... As we get toward the end, a little form in the chat that I would like for you to fill out. It just allows us to collect a little demographic information, so that we can know who's been tracking these conversations, and we can make sure we're getting a good representation from across Boston. Cool.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Last thing I want to say is that, like all conversations, I know all of you have been in conversations before. In a small conversation, our goal is to listen to each other, to let people speak, give space for people to speak. We have a pretty structured ... Sorry. We have a structured framework for this conversation, and so, it's pretty easy. I'll give you some prompts and ask you to respond to those prompts in very particular ways.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: With that, why don't we begin? We're going to begin by checking in. We have a particular way that we like to check in with each other when we do these. The way we like to do it is something we call PIES. Anybody ever done PIES before? Okay.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: PIES is when we ask people to check in, and I'm going to drop this in the chat, on four things. One, how are you doing physically? How are you doing intellectually? How are you doing emotionally? And, how are you doing spiritually, okay? Those are four things.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So, when it comes around to you, what you're going to you is say your name, what part of Boston you feel affiliated with and connected to, and then check in on each of these four things, okay? Now, if you decide you don't want to check in on one or the other, that's okay, but we'd like you to do that. Then, after you check in, you say this. "With that, I am in," basically meaning, I'm present. I'm here. I've checked in. I've let you a little bit know what's going on with me, and I'm here, and present. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to model for you. Then, I will give you an order in which to go in. I'm Cesar McDowell. I actually don't live in Boston. I actually live in Brockton right now, so that's a little bit of something, but I guess if I was to say which part of Boston I'm really connected with, I've just spent a lot of time in Roxbury, and so for me, that's the part I feel connected to.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Physically, today, I am feeling really tired. I don't know why, I'm tight in my shoulders, and so I can ... I really don't know where it's coming from in my shoulders and neck, but that makes me lose energy in some sense, because I'm feeling like I'm using a lot of energy just to deal with that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Intellectually, I'm really charged, because I've been in some great conversations with people today. It's just got my head stirring, and I'm going. Emotionally, emotionally, I'm in a difficult space. Even as we're coming back together, I'm seeing people that are really excited, I haven't seen in a year and a half, that I work with. It's actually really pretty cool, but at the same time, I'm also hearing stories of their loss and what it's been like for them to go through this, so that's an emotional roller coaster.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Jalela. Physically, I feel a little tired, too. My day started early today. I usually get up around 5:30-ish, go to bed around 12:00. I don't know. My schedule is just bad like that.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Intellectually, I feel pretty on my toes. It was a lot of assessments that were needing to be done today, meeting with a lot of clients from my job, so just navigating a lot of tech stuff. So, I feel really on point right now, plus, I had coffee, so, you know ...

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Emotionally, I would say I feel confused, I would say. There's so much going on in a world as a whole. Then, me, myself, I'm trying my hardest to, I guess, show gratitude and be appreciative of my situation, while also putting myself in other people's shoes, and trying to see what I can do to be helpful to the different people around the world and the community. So, it's a little confusing space for me, I think, right now, that I'm still processing a lot of stuff.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Spiritually, I feel blessed. As always, I feel blessed. It's another day to be here, so I feel really good. With that, I am in, so yeah.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Hi, everybody. I'm Carmen. I use the pronouns she/her, [foreign language] in [foreign language]. I am in East Boston, and this is my area where I feel comfortable with, and where I connect with the city, mostly.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Physically, I'm a little tired, and I'm also struggling with a knee injury, so there's that. Intellectually, there's a lot going on at work, but I am excited about that, so I am pumped. Emotionally, I'm a little overwhelmed with everything that's happening in the news, especially with immigration topics, and just politics, and yeah, that type of thing. Spiritually, I am thankful for this conversation, and for you guys, and for the safe space that I am already comfortable with. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Hi. I'm Peter, and time, I guess, time for the PIE check-in. Physically, I'm tired, but ... I'm tired, and I think I am bouncing back, so a little bit of both. Emotionally, I think like a lot of people, I am exhausted [inaudible] exhausted, but, I guess, with [inaudible] ... Actually, just ties into the spiritual side, as well. Spiritual, I am very, very hopeful, and I am having faith that things can be better. I'm seeing enough glimpses to believe that that might actually come true, if not as quickly as any of us would like, but ...

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Intellectually, I am feeling recharged. I am just discovering all the great work that's been happening, too, in terms of real change, in terms of making our communities better. I'm actually getting a chance to read some of it, a little bit of it right now, to be honest, just a little bit of all that's out there. It's enough to be inspiring. Intellectually, I guess, I'm inspired. With that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. Thank you. It's really good for us all to be here. As I said before, we just like to do that as our opening, because sometimes we just step into meetings, and we don't allow ourselves to recognize that everybody's dealing with a lot. They come into spaces with an open heart, and being generous, but they're also carrying a lot with them. So, it's just a moment to acknowledge that and acknowledge our humanity.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Let's jump into this conversation. The conversation has two parts. Actually, it's three parts. This first part, actually, is in two sections.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: For the first one, you, if you would like to write a little bit, you can. You might want to take a little note or something. You don't have to. You can hold it in your head.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The first one I'm going to ask you, I'm going to ask you a prompt. I want you to think of the answer to that prompt. I don't want you to share it yet. I just want you to come up with your answer, but not share it, okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to drop this prompt into the chat after I say it. The prompt is this. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? Okay? Again, I'll drop it in ... Oops, sorry. I was on the wrong thing here.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Again, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'm going to give you a minute or two to just think about that and come up with your own response to that, your own question. I do want it in the form of a question. Okay? Is everybody clear? Okay. (silence)

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Only a little bit. I mean, you guys can go ahead. I mean, I'm probably within a half minute or so, I think I'll be able to jump in. I'm just, there's something I'm thinking about that is related to that question.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Good. Okay, so, given that you have this question, the next thing I want to ask you is, what is the experience in your life that got you to that question? Our belief is that questions don't come out of anywhere. They just don't. They actually come and are grounded in our experiences. Given that you have this question, what I want you to do is think about, what's an experience in your life that you know is part of why you have that question?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: When I ask you this, I want you to really make it about you, okay? Something you embody, that you actually experience, not something you heard about, read about somewhere else, but something that you actually experienced and embodied. I'm going to put this in the chat, just so you have it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You're going to tell us a story about that experience when we go around and share, okay? I'm going to give you a few minutes to think about it, because you may have multiple experiences, so you have to decide, what's the one that I really think is going to be the right one to convey to really get people to connect with why that particular is so important to me? Okay? (silence)

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: I'm actually wondering if it's okay to bend the rules a little bit and share two stories, because I think they're connected.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. Okay, so, here's what we're going to do. I'm going to put the order in the chat that I want you to talk. What I want you to do is first tell us your question. Then, tell us the story that got you there. Then, once you finish that, let's just take a pause, and then, whoever's next, you'll see your name in the chat. Then, you go, do the same thing, share your question and the story you got here. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Okay, so, my question is, is there a real pipeline for professional success and to achieve the American dream for new immigrants and people who have a strong accent in the city of Boston? My two experiences that I want to share with you guys today, I think that there are many, right? Because I'm a new immigrant to the city of Boston, and I have an accent. I'm from Venezuela, and I moved here as an adult, so I learned English as an adult, which is why I have an accent.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: One was a moment, I was in grad school, new to the city. I had a name tag, and it said my name. I didn't have an affiliation with an organization, but I was at this networking event. Someone was talking to me in the intro, hi, how are you? What's your name? Kind of thing.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Then, they were like, "You're new to Boston, you don't really know a lot of people," and this person just stopped having an interest in having a conversation with me, and just started looking for someone else to interact with, or at least that's my perception. Kind of like, I'm not going to network through you. I have no interest in having a conversation, so I'm going to move over to whomever is in this room that can connect me with a network, or give me some type of connection, or win something through that interaction.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: That didn't feel good, but it made me realize this ... Well, I guess that's the goal of a networking event, but also, as a new immigrant, all the things that you're missing, because you didn't grow up here, you don't know all the people. You don't know the systems. Like, "Yeah, my cousin works there, I can connect you," all those things in this big, but really small city, are reality.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: The other thing is, I remember one time, I was presenting to a client at work, and one of the people who came to the meeting, as soon as I started speaking, this person realized that I had an accent, or at least, again, that's my perception, and started to disregard my opinions. Like, the way that I felt is that they were assuming that I was less intelligent because I had an accent, or that my opinions weren't, that I didn't have a real understanding of the topic that I was talking about because of this, a little bit of like, what are you saying? What do you mean? And facial expressions that I don't think are okay in a professional setting or any setting, but that's something that has happened to me a few times in Boston, so I always connect those two ideas. That's why my question is what I asked. Thank you for listening.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: My question was, how would the future of Boston influence the communities and the young people? Like, what kind of spaces would be available for the young people? I asked this question because, growing up in Boston, I started my first job in community organizing. I was a youth organizer.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: I worked with a lot of young people that were my age, like 14, 15 years old, just being out in the community, whether I was trying to fundraise an event, have more cultural appreciation within our communities, potlucks just to get to know people in your communities, cleaning up streets, things like that that I was always a part of. I really like doing those things. I felt like my peers also liked it, because it gave us, at the time, for me, it gave me a feeling of like my opinion mattered, what I thought of my community mattered, and what I wanted my community to look like mattered.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: It was really good to have that new type of power within me, to know that my voice was important. I really hope that, moving forward with Boston, that they still value a lot of the young people's input. I feel like, now, there's not a lot of fundings that go on into young people's ... When it comes to jobs for people who are much younger, for summer programs, there's not a lot of funding in those areas, or sometimes that's the first spot where it's like, let's actually take some money away from them and put it towards something else, which I just feel like is wrong. When these are the people who are going to be the leaders of the future, you want to make sure they're on a good foot, so that's why I asked that question was my involvement in the community as a young person, and I still want young people to be involved.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: My turn? Okay. Yes. The question I have, which I guess is related to them, but not exactly the same, is how do we make sure that people who are basically the most stressed and the most marginalized, in many ways the [inaudible], how do we make sure that they have a voice, and a real voice, and a real ability to participate and contribute?

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: That would include youth. That would also include people who are homeless. That would include people who are maybe working multiple jobs or maybe have multiple family stresses. Having a job and family stresses are the least likely to be able to come to meetings or find time for the opportunities to participate.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I mean, besides me juggling multiple stresses of real life myself, just what came to me is that when I was collecting signatures for years ago, I ran, not particularly successfully, for city council locally in Boston. When I was collecting signatures, I saw that there was a place with a lot of people. I didn't realize that that particular place was a homeless shelter until I got there.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I got in right as people were lining up. I made a decision at that point that I would treat them like people, and collect them, and listen to them, even if I was totally unprepared, especially since part of what I wanted to do and part of the reason why I was running was addressing house instability and ultimately a path to ownership for everybody, including formerly homeless and low-income people. I mean, that was like, I would be a hypocrite if I didn't. There would be no reason to run if I didn't actually took time to listen, that kind of thing.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I was amazed. I mean, some were initially skeptical, but a lot of them were appreciative that I was willing to ask for the signature and take time to listen to them, even though, for a variety of reasons, including the fact that the addresses don't get updated in the city, a lot of the signatures probably wouldn't count, but I thought the right thing to do was to listen and do that kind of thing. That made me realize, you know, and it was apparent from conversations that a lot of people did not take the time and did not take time to engage people in that kind of situation that way. I was like, okay, maybe there should be a way to engage them when it's not in those kind of accidental, although not in a bad way, circumstances.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Wow. Thank you. The experiences we have are really rich. I just love these questions and the way they're really connected to the things that you live with and have lived with.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I treat these, and you should treat these, as really gifts that you're offering to each other, that have been offered to you. What I'd like to do now, and I'm not going to put an order in the chat. You can do it the way you feel moved. Having listened to the other two people in the conversation with you, if there's someone whose question you connected with, and/or something in their experience you connected with, then if you just turn to them, say their first name, and tell them what you connected to, and what's the experience in your life that makes that a connection for you, okay?

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Hi. Honestly, I connected with both Carmen and Peter. I feel like I could totally understand why Carmen asked that question. I think it's a very important question to ask. Where I work at now, I work in the program that helps a lot of people who are interested in learning English. I realize sometimes, there's sometimes a challenge when they come in, and I don't speak any other language, so usually, I use a lot of translating devices to communicate to them.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: I know a lot of times, a lot of people come in, and they will feel frustrated, or they will feel not heard. I always try my best to make sure that anyone who's coming in for these classes, they feel heard, and that they feel appreciated, and that they feel valued, because they are. Just because there's this communication barrier doesn't mean that we can't still relate with one another's stories or life paths, so I really appreciate you asking that question. It really reflects with me, with my work, and everything, and all the people I meet with different backgrounds.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: I also agree with Peter, as well. I think it's a great question you asked. My mom actually works with a lot of people who are in a housing situation or a shelter, and I meet a lot of people like that, too, at my work. It's a very multi-diverse agency, so it's a lot of different backgrounds that come in, and you're meeting a lot of different people. You just try to find what is the best way to help their situation, or help them grow past it, so I feel like it's just, both of you guys, very relatable to a lot of the things I'm exposed to at the moment.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Thank you for sharing that. I have to say, same here. I relate with both of your questions. I had other questions that were close to those, so, Jalela, is that how you say it? Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Thank you. You were talking about youth, right? In Venezuela, I was a dancer in a [inaudible] development program, so empowering youth through art, so I really ... You brought me back to my teen years, where I was lucky enough to be able to focus on art making and movement instead of, in a country like Venezuela, there's so many other pull and energies that could take you to, I'm just going to say wrong places.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: So, I don't know. You just brought me back to that, and realizing how having those experiences when you're young can help you become the adult that you want to be. So, youth empowerment with the angle of creative youth development, that was my connection.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Peter, what you were talking about really made me connect with, well, the realities of the electoral systems in the US, and this reality of how city hall looks, and how the makeup of the community is [inaudible] ... So, a question that I connected and relate with what you said is, is our city council, and our city hall, and Beacon Hill ever going to look like the communities that they represent, right? Is the power ever going to be in people that really look and are part of our communities?

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Me? Yes. Both of you, both of the other participants resonated with me, as well. Carmen, your experience resonated with me, as I'm the son of a mother who immigrated from China, who was first generation in this country and one of the early women scientists. I mean, the stories of exclusion and invisibility definitely struck.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: In term of, as an aspiring professional in Boston, a lot of the same invisibility, especially if you're not connected with organizations of prestige, or power, or even if you are, but not in a position, or not in a place that's respected [inaudible] ... I believe in saying names correctly, I'm just not sure how to ... Jalela?

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Jalela, okay. What you were saying in terms especially of inclusion of young people, that kind of thing, as not a young person not that long ago, well, as I aspirationally think, not that long ago, and as well as someone who's worked with youth, I mean, definitely the inclusion of the voice is important, and especially since I noticed that a lot of effective problem solvers are coming from newer generations, but those voices aren't often not being heard.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Even when there are important conversations around anti-racism spaces I've been to, a lot of the discussions, young people don't seem to be heard, or listened to, or quoted, or being publicized to the degree that they should be, and to the degree that they need to be for a solution to be. I volunteered with the Student Immigrant Movement and with the [inaudible] movement, so I've seen how important young people are to transforming social structures and that kind of thing, but at the same time, how they were not taken seriously by the rest of those movements, a lot of time to the detriment of those movements.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I mean, there's much more, but that's what's coming up right now. I'm sure as our discussion goes on, I'm sure, honestly, tonight, after the discussion, more is going to come to me from this.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you, Peter, Carmen, Jalela. What I'd like to do now is, we've been really grounded in experience and just, which is really important, but I'm going to ask you now just to take a step back, and just like, what are you hearing in all this conversation? What themes, what themes are emerging for you? What is it making you think about, now that you're hearing this? I'm moving you a little bit out of your own personal experience, connecting to someone else's experience, and asking you to lift up a little bit, and say, "Okay, here's what I'm hearing."

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: One thing that I see in the three of us is this need for change, right? Like, from different angles, we are getting to the point of the city of Boston needs to change in some significant areas. The other thing is people doing the work. These two, well, three, these individuals are inspiring me, so the two angles of the big, overarching realities of, okay, we do need change, and we have people who are working for it. Cesar, with you, with this initiative, Jalela and Peter with your questions and what you're doing out in the communities.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Yeah. Speaking of what you were just saying, Carmen, connect the dots, I feel just a huge sense of connection, overall. Even though we're coming from totally different points at the moment, I feel like it's all stemming from a source that there's these different needs that are all vital, and it's not one or the other. They're all equally important in all of our lives.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Like you're saying, we need to have a space where all these people who want the change, who are fighting for the change, to be in the support, to be in this community space where we are respecting one another's opinions, and values, and what can we do altogether as a whole with all these great energies we all have of wanting to make this change? We just need that space.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: Sorry, I'm spamming all different areas, but I just feel a lot of connection. I feel like there's a lot of connection in that, like you said, we need a space where we can all be together to support one another and uplift one another, so yeah.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I would definitely amplify and echo the points that both Carmen and Jalila made. I think it's definitely inspiring to see all, even if it's two or, well, three other people. Cesar, you're part of the change people. Yeah. I think it's inspiring to see all the change efforts and stuff.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: I think one of the questions is, how do we have structures or processes where we can amplify and build on each other? That's, I mean, those of you who have done the work for real know that there are times when there's togetherness. There's also a lot of times when you feel like you're doing this by yourself, or with your small group, or your network, and you know it needs to go much further. You're not sure how to move it further.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. When we schedule this out for 90 minutes, we design that time for you assuming we're going to have six or eight people, so we are fewer, so it'll be a little shorter time today. I hope that's okay.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: We're getting to the place where we're getting ready to wrap up. Again, I want to thank you both for sharing conversations and experiences. I want to remind you a little bit of what's going to happen. We're going to take these recordings. They're going to be up on the Local Voices Network.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You'll actually get communication from us when you can actually go back, and see the conversation, and hear it, and all indexed with keywords. You can see the conversations that other people who have been part of this, too. You can see all of the Real Talk conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Then, around the 15th of October, we're going to be announcing a public dashboard that actually has taken some of that information and put it into themes, and stuff, and really make it available for people to see the issues that are coming up in these conversations, and the interconnection among them. Like I said, your whole transcript can only be seen by people who also participated in the conversations, but segments of your conversation may be made public. This is the way we're doing it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Before we get to the end, I'm going to ask you ... I have three things I want to do. The first one is just to see if you have any clothing thoughts that you want to share, something that's just like, yeah, I wanted to get this out, or a final word. What I'm going to do is actually ... I did it again. Hold on a second. Hit the wrong button. I'm going to put your order in the chat, and we'll start with Peter, and Jalila, and then Carmen, just any closing comments you want to make. Then, I have a couple of other things to share with you.

nodes.speaker: Peter
nodes.words: Okay, yes. I guess my closing thought is that, I mean, I'm really glad that this is happening. I think this is a great start. I think that it would be a mistake if this is as far as it goes. I would, even beyond mid-October, I'd like this kind of conversation to continue. I'd like everyone who's been part of this, through this and other sessions, to be part of it. Boston needs this change for the better.

nodes.speaker: Jalela
nodes.words: I want to piggyback off of Peter. I feel really happy with our conversations. I feel hopeful. I have a lot of energy now. I feel pumped up. Yeah. I'm just really excited for the change that will be happening and for the growth our communities will be having, so I'm really excited.

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: Well, first I want to thank you three for this amazing hour that we've spent together, and the energy and love that I've received. I'm not tired anymore, so thanks. I'm pumped up. Echoing what you guys just said, let's not October be the end, but keep us engaged, and make ...

nodes.speaker: Carmen
nodes.words: We care about Boston. I think that's another thing. We had conversations about the city, and we acknowledge that there's some change that needs to be made, but I think it comes from a place of care. Instead of like, I'm just going to leave the city. It's too expensive, all the other things we know, we're here because we care. We want to see it thrive and become better, so I'm acknowledging that, too.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Nice, nice. Two more things. I just put in the chat ... No, I didn't. I'm supposed to put it in the chat. Let's see, let's see, there, a link. I'd like you to go to that link. It's a short demographic form we'd like you to fill out right now.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I want to explain something. It has your name in it, and it also asks for your email address. We need the email address in order to contact back to you to let you know when you can go look at all of the information, the transcript and everything, and also in case ... Yeah, so we can send contact with you around that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Some of the answers have red stars by them, meaning that they're required, we'd like to get them, and the rest of them are optional. We'd like you to fill it out, but you don't have to fill out [inaudible] ... Once you've all filled that out, then I'm going to do the next thing, so just let me know when you're done.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay, great, thank you. Thank you all for that. Okay, so, now, I'm going to ask a couple of other things. One, if you really liked this, and enjoyed it, and found it was of value, tell your friends. Find some other people. Have them sign up for one of the conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: If you go to our website now, there's a calendar there of when we have conversations, and you can just sign up for a conversation right on the website. If you want to gather three, or four, or five of your friends, and encourage them to be on at the same time, you can have them all sign up for the same time, and we'll be there to help with these conversations, because like I said, we're going to keep going, and going, and going.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: If at some point in time, you're saying and thinking, hey, I'd like to learn how to facilitate some of these conversations, then let us know. We will help you with that, also. We have a whole training program for facilitators.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What we do when you facilitate is say, there's like four steps. One, you have to know what the program is, so we give you an orientation. Two, you have to participate in a conversation. Well, you've done that. Three, you have to go through a training. The training is about an hour and a half long.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Then, the next one is you do a conversation where you observe. There's a coach there, and you do the conversation and observe. Then, we ask you to do two more conversations.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What we do is we pay you $200 to do the training and $100 for every conversation you do, so that's ... We know it's not a lot, but it's a little something to say thanks for helping me build this. In terms of appreciation, too, I'll just let you know, knowing we're all struggling in these days, we're trying to make a lot happen, and so, you will be receiving a little email with a little gift card just as a token of appreciation to say thank you for taking the time, and the energy, and helping us get some Real Talk in Boston. With that, I'm going to shut off the recorder.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So welcome. This is my first Real Talk for Change conversation, and thank you for responding to our invites and joining this network of voices and conversations that are happening across the city of Boston. We invite you to this gathering by asking you to think about one of the most pressing questions you have about the future of the city. Our goals today are to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experiences to this growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and be listened to, knowing that it will matter.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So the real question is, why are we having these conversations? So we really want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across diverse neighborhoods, like-

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: To this end, we're inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering a conversation with your position on the upcoming elections or specific candidates. We're doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that will improve our understanding of one another. Does that make sense?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Oh? Yeah. Okay. Following the meeting today, the audio recording will become part of a collection of the Real Talk for Change tool, and everybody could access it. So we'll send out a link and you could just click on the link, hear our conversation and others in specific themes that have come across during these conversations. Finally, I have to read the consent statement, all right? So bear with me. I have to read the consent statement and ask you if you are willing to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: As a participant in the conversation, you're providing consent to the Real Talk for Change to use and retained the recording in accordance with the mission. You also understand the conversation will be part of a protective collection on Cortico's Local Voice Network, whose mission is to understand and foster conversations in communities and in media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with the mission. In addition, part of the Real Talk for Change mission is to present voices from the people of Boston. Therefore, portions of your conversation can be made public. If you understand and agree with this, please say I agree. So let's start with Jennifer. Do you agree?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okie dokie. Thank you. Okay. So you had the option to use another name as part of this discussion if you wish. If you want to use a different name, let us know now. So if anyone doesn't want to use their real name, please let us know.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thirdly, at the end of the conversation, I'm going to ask you to help us capture some simple demographic information by completing the online form. We will do this before the end of the meeting. I will say more about that before I ask you to fill the form.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Lastly, I want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from each other in these conversations. And to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. Okay. So these are the guidelines. Speak for yourself and out of your own experience. Two, allow others to speak for themselves. Number three, share the time. Allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Number four, stay curious and ask honest questions. Number five is pause and take time for reflection.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: We have three more here. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs and applications, notifications and please put your phones on silent. And if you need to take a moment or take a break, please let me know in the chat. Now, is everybody on board with the guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Just to let you know before we start, my Verizon is on a very low stream. I don't know if you guys can tell. I can see people streaming in and out. That's my service. So if something streams out, I'll try to sign back on. My Verizon, it goes low. It's a low broadband.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Camera sometimes because sometimes when the thing is low, if you shut your camera off, if you just turn the camera off, it helps. So that's another thing that-

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Okay. Yeah, this is my first time on a Zoom, but I have such a ... I'm still on DSL here at East Boston.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Yeah. So it's been like that for years, probably two years now because there's no files here in this particular neighborhood. So I probably just was getting guys now, just in case.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay, so you can take yourself off of camera if that helps. So, right. To begin, I want to do a quick round of introductions and check in. Please share your first name, and where are you located right now, then let us know how you're using PIES check in. This means saying how you are choosing to check in using one of the following, okay? So I will model and then we'll do a quick round of introductions.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So my name is [Jacqueline] and right now, I'm calling from Revere in Massachusetts and work in Boston, and I how am I feeling today? So PIES means how do you feel physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. You only have to pick one of them. So I will talk about emotionally. Today, I actually did not go to my job because I woke up with a massive migraine and I just realized a little while ago that my best friend passed away two years ago today. So that might have been you know so you know. And then we will end with and with that, I am in and I'll pass it to Jennifer.

nodes.speaker: Jennifer
nodes.words: Sorry. It takes me a minute to get it to load because I'm on the phone. My name is Jennifer. I live in Dorchester, and today as far as emotionally, I'm a little drained. I took a really close friend to rehab today. So it was a stressful day.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Hi. I'm calling in from East Boston. And today, I guess I am doing well. And I'm sorry, but what else was it you needed?

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: I'm Sean Paul out of East Boston. I'm self employed as a landscaper, gardener, florist. Today, I feel better than yesterday, I guess. Is that physical? Yeah, but emotionally, overall, I'm probably more grateful, but a lot better than yesterday. But overall, grateful, usually optimistic on a daily basis, so that's good. And what was the last part? I heard people say all in which means what?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: And with that, I am in. So the whole idea was that is that we're sharing who we are, where we're coming from, and that we recognize that we're all human beings, and we do go through stuff physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually. And I believe that we're waiting for someone to come in. I'm I correct, Fran?

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Hi. Yeah. So I have a friend and he lives in Boston. And he said he is available to come into the meeting. He's just going to be a minute. He just got from home from work. Is that all right? Okay, thank you, Jackie.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: If people don't mind just pausing a second till your friend joins. That's great because we really needed four people, and yeah. The conversation will be richer. So we'll just need to repeat the consent. We'll just ask the person to say their name, and where they're calling in from, and to check in either physically, intellectually, spiritually, or emotionally.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Cool. If you know anybody else, send them my way because I want to schedule a whole bunch of these. So if everybody on this call is okay, we could pause for a few minutes. Is that okay with you, Sean and Jen?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We're just going to wait a minute instead of moving forward with the agenda. So did everyone check in and do their PIES?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. So then we're just going to wait till Ryan's friend joins and then Jackie will ask them do you agree to be recorded and then just ask that person to introduce themselves and say where they're calling in from and then we'll just pick up the rest of the conversation from there.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So this would be a good time to take a bio break, get some water, use the bathroom. Get some food, a pause for the class sort of thing.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So a couple of you near me, I made orange chicken. I made jasmine rice and I made some pinto beans because I want to eat a [inaudible] steak later, but the kids liked the orange chicken so. I guess nobody likes orange chicken.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Don't worry about it, Sean. It'll be easier if you just shut off the camera like stop video. So right, like giving a-

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Just stop the video, Sean, and that should get better. And Ryan, let's give your friend a couple more minutes. If not, we need to move on.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Yeah, I just checked in with him so I'm waiting for a reply. He just said [crosstalk] minute, but hopefully, it won't be terribly long. I'm so sorry.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: [inaudible]. All right, that's determination, Sean. All right. I'm going to put myself on mute. (silence). Okay, we lost Sean there. We know he's going to sign back in. All righty. So Fran, I understand people started at[inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I know, so I don't know what you want to do. Whether you just want to keep moving. Maybe text Sean and ask him to call in.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Do you have the phone number in front of you? Because I know sometimes, if he was on, [inaudible] yeah. He said he would call back in and I apologize, Jennifer and Ryan. I think that we should try and get Sean back in as soon as he comes in, move forward.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: And continue with Dan. Hi, Dan, welcome. So my name is Jackie Martinez and I will be facilitating this conversation. So we stopped just waiting for you to get on. And so I'm just going to go over and get consent.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So this conversation is being recorded, so we really want people's inputs on there and we really want people to talk from their own lived experience. And so unfortunately, ladies, I'm going to have to read this all over again.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: As part of this conversation, you're providing consent for The Real Talk for Change to use a retained recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection on Cortico's local voice network, whose mission is to understand and foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with the mission, in addition to be part of the Real Talk for Change mission, is to present voices from the people of Boston. Therefore, portions of this conversation can be made public. If you understand and agree, please say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you, Dan. So I have not heard from Sean. I have no [inaudible] from Sean, but I will continue. So everybody checked in already, Dan. So the way that we check in this particular conversation is that we want to do a quick round of introductions, and everybody already has. So when you check in, Dan, please share your first name, where are you located right now, and then let us know how you're using the PIES check in. This means that you're choosing one of the following to check in. You're going to tell us how you're feeling physically or intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. Then when you finish, you say and with that, I am in and I will model, and let me know if you understand.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So my name is Jackie Martinez. I'm calling from Revere. I work in Boston. I was born and raised in Boston. And I shared earlier that emotionally, I am pretty drained today. I didn't go to work because I woke up with a massive migraine, and I couldn't see. I couldn't drive or anything. And then I realized, a couple hours ago, that today's my best friend's ... Two years ago today, my best friend passed away. So it could be related, but with that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: All right. I think I got it. My name is Daniel Palomares. I live in Kenmore Square in Boston. Today has been a long day, but honestly, I woke up and still feel grateful to have a long day. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you. And just to let everybody know that Sean texted me and that he's trying to log back in. So let's move on. Okay. Now that we know who is here, let's get back to the core of this conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it is easy for us to lose focus and sight of what we have learned about inequality in America in Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. Keeping in mind, I'd like to invite you to think about a question about what's your question about the future Boston, and your place in that future? So if you need to write this down, please do so. I would like people to take a couple of minutes, and we'll get back if this is helpful. So again, what's your question about the future of Boston, and what's your place in that future? (silence).

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. So now, I'd like to invite you to think about what experiences in your life got you to this question. It is key to keep your experience personal. Is has to do to be something that you're experienced directly, an experience that can help us understand how you got to the questions you share with us. We'll go around a circle. Each person will share their question and then tell the story of an experience that got you to this question. How are we doing here? So Jen?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: I made a mistake. I'm sorry. I will model what to say so it was what's your question about the future of Boston in my place in it? And then thinking about an experience that has to do with that. So I'll bring it back to this conversation. So we're looking at my experience growing up in Boston is that there wasn't much research or conversations with the actual community, and I'm grateful that we're having these conversations.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'll model because you started telling a story, and you didn't frame your question. So we really would like you to think about our question. So my question is is there a place for working class elders in the future of Boston? And the reason I come up with that question is because I'm working class elder who can't afford $3,000 for a studio apartment and had to move 20 times in the last 30 years. I'm not a homeowner. So that's my question. Is there a future for working class elders in Boston, and it's related to my 20 times moving.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you so much, Fran. So it's my turn, I guess. So my question is would it be possible to work full time and pay for childcare in the next couple of years in Boston? And my experience around that is that the reason I moved to Revere was because I couldn't afford childcare in Boston. It was very difficult for me to maintain a full time job and go to school and be able to pay for daycare. How was that, Fran?

nodes.speaker: Jennifer
nodes.words: My question is is Boston ever going to sort out the housing crisis and benefits for people who are low income? My experience growing up, my mother was a single mother. She was super low income. I was raised like living in basements or sleeping in bathtubs, and she used to go into these offices looking for help. And it wasn't necessarily a hand up. It was more like, "Quit your job and do this and we can help you." She was making way below minimum wage and they basically just told her, "Well, we can't help you until you make below this."

nodes.speaker: Jennifer
nodes.words: And I just felt growing up that even myself, when I go in for assistance, as I sometimes I'm low income, you have to make so minimal to even just get a little bit of help that if there was some bracket that made it more efficient for people just looking for help, that there would be more funding for a vast variety of people.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Hi, Jackie. So my question is, is the City of Boston, the Boston Public Health Commission, the recovery services department, are they going to find a resolution for the opioid crisis down in the Mass and Cass area with the 200 plus times they have going on? And my personal experience with that is that I have steadily over this past summer since around June, July, when it started really popping up. I've seen that all grow in size as I've been down that area over the last couple of months. And I have a great deal of people close to me who I've lost due to drugs. And more recently, at least three people during COVID have passed away due to an overdose. I just want to see this have a resolution. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you. Okay, Fran has been nice enough to put the order of participants in the chat box. So we're just trying to save time here so.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: All right, thank you. And now I feel like copycat because my question was I've been very lucky, growing up in Boston my whole life, but in what way is Boston going to continue to grow without pricing me out completely? I came to this question because like I said, I have been lucky to grow up in Boston, whether it be in East Boston, Roxbury, Dorchester and now Kenmore Square. As a kid, we live in East Boston. My mom could barely make ends meet and was able to obtain section eight. But even having section eight made it difficult for her to be able to even work because while she was still working, she was raising three kids on her own. But they would tell her like "Oh, because you make X amount of money, you can put in for X amount of rent," but she has three growing kids. They tell her, "Oh, go on food stamps." Food stamps says she makes too much money.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: And now, as an adult myself, I can see real fast why she would have those problems. I do make above minimum wage, but even still, that isn't even enough to be in a ... I'm not looking for an apartment by myself, but even finding an apartment with roommates, it's making it harder to make ends meet just having a roof over my head with other people. And yeah, I guess that's it.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you so much, Dan. So now, what I want you to do next is think about each of the questions and experiences that we've just shared in our group. Find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you and share a story from your life that connects with that person's experience. So I'm going to give you a little bit of time. So a minute or two just to reflect. And then whoever is ready can start us off.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: All right. So I feel like Dan and Jen's are almost about the same, but they're coming from different places. Can I speak to both of them or just one, Jackie?

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Okay. I'm just going to go with Dan then, and I'm going to say I resonate with what you're saying because I feel like I have been in Boston for five years now and my rent in East Boston has gone up every single time I resign a lease. And I get told by my landlord that if I'm not interested in that place, he can find anybody else to take it because there's a billion and one people who would like to take that. And it just to me feels like you've run out of options for where you can go and then you get stuck having to take something that you maybe might not be able to afford exactly, but you have to make do because the options are limited around here these days, and it's not terrible so I might as well take it, I guess. I resonate with what you said, Dan.

nodes.speaker: Jennifer
nodes.words: So Ryan's story really resonated with me, I used to work on the mile in Southampton shelter. It's obviously not fairly recently, but at one point, down there, it wasn't to the level that it is now. And I noticed that a lot of things changed, and I feel like the city was really trying to help and I think they made the issue worse. Because when I was working down there, staff would go out and they would clear people and they had people going down there cleaning up needles, and there wasn't this tent where people could go into with ... Basically, when you go in the tent, you can bring whatever you want. There's no search, whereas all the other facilities down there typically had search and now, they have these safe injection sites out in the street and I don't know many people who typically go to the injection sites. They're just hanging around in those areas, and I feel like the city didn't do any of them a service really.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: All right. Let's see. They honestly both Jennifer and Ryan resonated with me. I would say Ryan resonated with me the most because I actually, earlier when you mentioned you lost a friend two years ago one of your best friends, next week is going to be the two-year anniversary. I lost one of my, I guess, online best friends, someone I never got to actually meet in person, but meant a lot to me. She had gone through a lot of pain in her life and took to heroin every so often. And the last time she took it, she overdosed because she didn't know it was laced with fentanyl.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: So ever since then, I'll watch the news, I'll even go down methadone mile because that's the route I take to visit my mother, and I'll look out and just see these people who are addicts who have done so much that to them, where they're at right now, what they're doing right now makes sense, or they think it's what's best for them, or whatever the case may be. And I just wish there was more we could do. But I'll be the first to say I don't have all the answers, and I wish there was something I could do to help them even if it's just getting them an Uber ride to somewhere that could help them.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Yes, apologies. Like I said, the low broadband in this particular part of the neighborhood, it's been like this for a long time. So if I go out again, I'll try to get back on. Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. So Sean, everybody on this call, you have not met Dan, but we have somebody new. His name's Dan but the question that we asked, so I'm going to give you a minute to think about, let me go back to my sheet here. So Sean, think about a question ... And I completely lost myself. What is your place in the future ... And Fran, thank you for putting it in the chat. Hold on a second. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future. So I just want you to think about that. Just think about it. Don't answer it. So what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? So just think about it, Sean. Tell me when you're ready-

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Okay. I think I wrote it down earlier. I think that's what we asked. It's along the lines of improving in the city, but personal?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Yep. All personal. So think about the question, and what's your place in the future Boston, your place in it, and then when you're ready, I would like you to share a story around what's the question and your story connected to that question.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Is the future of Boston, I know probably healthcare, I know they have health care, MassHealth and stuff like that. It does seem like a complex system. I'm sure a lot of people are missing out on it. So I guess my question would be for the healthcare system, the complexity of it. Maybe make it more simple, more available to others. I do know people that are less fortunate do qualify for programs, but there are some services that people will be missing out on. You would know more about that, Jen, but that would be my question, the stability of healthcare.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: [crosstalk]. Yeah, I remember the last speaker said something about maybe something along the lines of drug addiction and stuff like that. I'm not sure if healthcare covers all that kind of stuff. Healthcare is a wide range of things, so I would say that was my main concern. Yeah. Health.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: I remember, years ago, when I qualified for, I believe it was MassHealth. And I remember, there were certain time limits. There was a lot of things holding me back. It deterred me from being a part of that. I think it was counseling services, and I would join the counseling service, then I would be probably within a couple months, discouraged from attending again. But that was just personal counseling services, because I don't even think it fit under the umbrella of what they were allowing at that time. It could have changed, and all that. But this stuff like that psychological health, but again, sometimes, certain dental, eye. So overall, just the overall health care and understanding how it works, what's its cover, and the availability for everybody, I guess.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Well, like I said, it was discouraging, dropping out of maybe a counseling program when I was probably wanting to talk somebody or dealing with something personal. So it's almost like you're starting over or you got to deal with all those issues yourself. So maybe something expired, or I'd miss a counseling session because of it. So it was just basically felt like I was starting over constantly. So it built up a barrier, a wall to being a part of it. So I'm sure it probably discouraged me overall, but [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: It definitely resonated with me because those same experiences I've had over and over again since I was 16 basically. My mom had to get health insurance through MassHealth, and because we're children, we automatically qualify at the time, I believe. And I was seeing a counselor and then it felt like every year, they were saying, "Hey, they're no longer in your ..." What's the code? "In your plan, so you have to get someone else." So I also had to start over many times to the point that I just stopped going for a while.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: And looking back, those are the years I probably needed it the most. But I was also discouraged because I just got tired of every, I think it was every summer, having to be told like, "Oh, you need to get a new counselor or here or there." I know there were other points in time where I would get a counselor but they were leaving the practice. So it wasn't necessarily MassHealth's problem or fault per se, but it just happened so much that I just completely stopped going. I stopped going to see my doctor, my therapists or whomever that age. It's like, "All right, my health doesn't really matter right now."

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Sean? [inaudible] going once, going twice, Sean? Okay, so now let's talk a little bit about what we are hearing. What are you hearing and people's experiences? I'll give you a few seconds to think about that. So what are you hearing in this conversation about people's experiences? And whoever's ready can start us off.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: I'm hearing a lot of struggle. Is that what you're looking for, Jackie? You're looking for like what I'm hearing from people?

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: I also hear struggle but I also hear people having a hard time either trying to take care of themselves or family because they're going to those places that are saying, "Hey, if you need help, just reach out." You reach out but you're not getting what you need much less what you want.

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: And I will piggyback off that because as relevant is that is to accessing insurance services, housing services, social economic services of those types that you guys have mentioned, the people down on the Mass and Cass area who are trying to access services that are supposed to be centralized as well apparently, they're also having a struggle accessing the services they need as well. I've seen that in action when I've gone down the paths to help people. It's a struggle for them as well.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Would anybody else like to share? What are you hearing in this conversation or in other people's conversation? Or the people that have spoken, would you like to add anything else? And I'm not sure Jennifer's is [crosstalk] ... Okay. My mic isn't working. Okay, Jennifer, thank you. So would you like to add something in the chat?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: There we go. We got Sean back in the chat again. I'm hearing that we're all going through the same struggles in one way or another. Anything else? Jen? You could think about that, and if anyone else could think of anything, but if I have ... Let me see. Is Sean with us?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Yes, you are, Sean. So the question now is let's talk about what you're hearing from everybody else in this conversation. What did you hear? Anything stick out to you or resonates with you?

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: Yeah. Well, mostly I heard Dan, but I related to what he was saying, but I don't know what the right word is. Maybe, as far as what we were talking about with the health care, that part of the conversation, maybe discouragement, or I don't know. Maybe bureaucratic is the right word from that aspect of what we were talking about. It seems like it could be a complex system, I guess.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. All righty. So I just wanted to take a minute and thank you. If you have anything else, what are you hearing from people? Okay, that's the last one. That's the same question, but what are you all hearing in people's experiences? Just in case. And so if no one has anything else to add, let's do this right now.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: It's time for us to wrap up. Actually, we're here till 7:30 but if you don't have anything add, let's wrap this up. Thank you all for sharing your questions and your experiences. We will now quickly go around and share something you'll be taking away with you. Do you have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share or other general reflections? Do you have any questions for us?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Just a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts you share. These recordings will be transcribed, indexed and shared with you with The Real Talk for Change team, and you'll receive an email with the link to this conversation in the LVM platform. So does anyone have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share with us? Or any questions or reflections?

nodes.speaker: Ryan
nodes.words: Thank you for inviting us to this discussion. And then I hope that all future discussions go just as well because this is very important work you're doing.

nodes.speaker: Seanpaul11
nodes.words: I guess I'll add. This is actually my first time doing this. So I'm glad I did it and I would like to do it again. It seems like everybody here, the reason we come together like this shows we all care about our community and ourselves and we all want to make progress and it's good to do this together and share it with others.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: If you all know of anyone, send them my way. This was my first. I promise a second, third, and 100th one will be so much better. Practice makes perfect, right? We're close to it. Does anybody want to share any closing thoughts? Closing thoughts? Go ahead, Dan.

nodes.speaker: Dan
nodes.words: For me, this is also my first time and I did enjoy this only to hear from other people's perspective and other things that are issues for them and people they may know. When it comes to helping Boston, if I can help in any way, I'm always down to do something like this.

nodes.speaker: Fran
nodes.words: I'm going to begin by reading. As a participant in the conversation, you're providing consent to Real Talk for Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please unmute yourself and say, one at a time, I agree.

nodes.speaker: Fran
nodes.words: And I'm going to have Lauryn, Malcolm, Ji, Ashley, Ivy, Jaimy, Teresa and Charmaine. And I'll drop that in the chat and that will be how will go around. This is almost like a modified circle. And of course, once that man left, everything changed. So I forget who I said go first, so whoever I said go first. Okay. Thanks, Lauryn.

nodes.speaker: Fran
nodes.words: So now, let me just write your names in the chat and this will be how we go around. And we're going to start off with PIES. So I want you to take a second to think about which PIES you want to check in on. And again, the P represents physical, the I represents intellectual, the E represents emotional, and the S represents spiritual.

nodes.speaker: Fran
