nodes.words: The power structure will not move, unless they know that we're either going to kick them out of office, or we're going to be like, "We're going to start building our own alternative systems, we don't need yours anymore." Or, "We do technically need them, but we're going to reclaim it," because I think that people need to reclaim their power. I'm so inspired by y'all for, even showing up for this conversation, really matters. Because that indicates that, "I know there's other people that feel this way."

nodes.speaker: Alex
nodes.words: So thank you for you all being here. This has been... I've needed this. I've had a lot of hopeless, very long periods of hopelessness or unsuredness. Actually, when you think about the art of history, this is how all this shit happens. This is how we start shaking things up. And also, knowing that we live... We're part of a natural system, everything must be in balance. The empire is falling, literally right now.

nodes.speaker: Alex
nodes.words: People are pretending that it's not, it's literally falling. And it can't, not fall. What goes up, must come down. It might be a scary time, to be honest, because a lot of stuff is going to and unleashed by that, but at the same time, it opens up potential to say, "We don't have to live like this." It's only been, really the past few decades, with this particular type of structure, this particular form of White supremacy. There is a legacy that we're building on, including cultural technology such as food, which I'm so glad I was brought up here.

nodes.speaker: Alex
nodes.words: I've been telling people, food is one of the most advanced technologies. I respect food. I'm so excited for the day, that I can even throw out my laptop. I'm really done with it. The day's coming, so...

nodes.speaker: Mari
nodes.words: I think the main takeaway for me tonight, is that we can have and we should have this conversation, not only in the spaces, but also with the neighbors. I was thinking, what happens if I see someone like Angel or some like him, walking by. I feel that we're always kind of afraid. I don't know if you feel it, but the conversations are like, scripted. "How's the weather? How is this, how is that," instead of actually connecting with people. Sometimes you feel like you don't want to invade their space, but after having this conversation with you guys tonight, I feel more comfortable about bringing this subject up with other people who, maybe they're just not aware because they didn't experience it. And that's a consideration that we also have to have, because some people haven't lived it. You can not experience if you haven't lived it.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: I'll just double down on a few things that folks have already said, which is, I'm grateful for spaces like this. I think our ability to use Zoom, is maybe a silver lining of COVID. Folks like the Real Talk for Change folks who are creating these spaces, either online or in person. You just don't get the chance, right? When do you get the opportunity to meet people... I've never met any of you, except for Fran before, and I don't know that I would, out in real life. Especially with COVID. I wouldn't necessarily recognize you all with your masks up.

nodes.speaker: Kim
nodes.words: I'm thankful for this space, and I'm thankful for... There we go. Now we know. I'm thankful also, for the three of you; Angel, Alex and Mari, for being open enough to come to a space like this. I don't know about you, Fran sent around an email, we had a few texts about this, but I don't really know... You and look at the website. And so it is a scary thing, or maybe even vulnerable thing for some of these questions, and so I just appreciate you showing up and participating to the extent that you did. None of us has to, so I just appreciate all that you've given, especially on a Sunday evening. That's a nice thing.

nodes.speaker: Angel
nodes.words: ... And that is that, what also disheartens me is that, we've gotten so far away from basic respect. And until we get back to... We can agree to disagree, but we've got to love and respect one another. I think, especially this generation, respect is just... There's no respect in education, no respect in law enforcement, no respect in politics, no respect in church. We got to respect one another.

nodes.speaker: Angel
nodes.words: I think until we add that component back, with the human element, I think then we have a chance. But if we don't respect and we don't love... So peace out, Shalom.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Again, thank you all so much. I really, really appreciate taking the time. And Kim really summarized it well, none of you had to be here, and I'm glad that you were, and I'm glad that you brought your full selves into this space and was able to share your stories and make connections.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We do appreciate your time, and so, Dr. Voigt was able to get some resources so that we're able to give you an online gift card. There's a researcher in the room, so they'll understand, how important it is to understand demographics. So if you could click on the link and fill that out, and-

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I'm going to get started because it's 6:40 and I don't want to run out of time. But they really recommend that we have at least four people to start, but I'm assuming someone's going to roll in. But what we're going to do right now is just do the consent to record agreement. I've posted it in the chat and I'm going to also read it all off. Well, we already started recording. It's just the way this Zoom room is set up it, when soon as someone comes in, it's already recording. So usually we would hit the record button but this time, I'm just going to read off the consent and then you guys say agree, verbally in the chat, or [inaudible] in the chat and we'll go from there. All right.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So as a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, who's mission is to foster conversations in the communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yeah. So we're going to utilize the mute and unmute future a lot during this group. It's very useful for me so that I can make sure it's facilitated where everybody gets a chance to speak and be heard. So the conversation agreement is speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, allow others to speak for themselves, share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns, stay curious, ask honest questions, pause, take time for reflection, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact, when possible close unnecessary programs, applications and notifications, and put your phone on silent or vibrate. If you need to take a moment, take a break. Let the facilitators note in the chat. And then also... Oh, is everyone on board with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Awesome. So that's the comfort agreement. I was hoping somebody else would roll in. Let's see. Okay. I didn't get any call back or text back from the ones I contacted. So we're just going to go ahead. So what we'll do is go around for a quick introduction and check-in. I will model the introduction in check-in style, so you guys can have an idea. Also, what we usually do is we shuffle the names for people to go in a certain order and we randomize the order, but what I think we could do, which is very time effective is once we're done speaking, we can call on the next person. That sound good?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So then you just call on whoever you want. So I'll model the check-in in the introduction. We do something called pies. Let me put that in the group chat for us. But the check-in involves our name and where we live or work in Boston and what neighborhood, and also the pies, which is a check-in on how we're doing in one of the areas of physical health, intellectual health, emotional health, or spiritual health. I'm going to put in the chat. So usually we pick one pie, excuse me. We pick one pie to do with our check-in. Does everyone see that in the chat?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So my name is Ziona Rivera. I live in Brockton, South shore now, recently moved here. And I work per diem in Boston at Boston Medical Center. I grew up in Mattapan most of my life. I spent time pretty much all over Boston. My pies for today, I think I'm going to go with my emotional health. Lately, my emotional health has been well, I can say. I'm worried about some people in my family, so that kind of brings me down a bit but I'm doing everything I can to make sure I help out and do my part as far as getting them situated with whatever [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Oh, no, we couldn't hear you. And then also someone requested that you turn the TV down in the background, by any chance. It's a bit loud. I'll tell her to unmute when she gets back.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: Yeah. Ziona, the thing happened again where your audio, it wasn't muted but it just cut out. I don't know why.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Yeah. I'm getting that a lot. I don't know why my thing does that, and it was so fine when the tech support was here. Now, the tech support is gone, it's like,

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So Yvonne, we're still going to keep the mic on you. Go ahead and share your check-in and your pie.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: Okay. Well, first of all, my name is Yvonne Long, and I live in Roxbury. I grew up in the South End and I left Boston for numerous years, came back around my mid 20s. And I've been living in my townhouse now, here in Roxbury for 29 years. I've raised my family here. My mental, emotional and spiritual health is really good. I'm really a spiritual person. My physical health is coming along I guess because my mental, spiritual and emotional health has been really good.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: Those areas I've worked on and mentally, I was hurt two and a half years ago on the job. And I ended up having three hips surgeries, which didn't go well for me. So I went from realty to walker to role later. Now I'm quad can. And through it all, I've kept my spiritual. That's what's kept me. It kept me alive and kept me involved and not giving up on myself. So with that note, I can go on all night, but I can tell you the experiences that I've had through that all, but for the most part, I'm doing quite well.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: Thank you Yvonne. Hello Ziona. Hello Kristen. My name is Brandy Brooks. I am originally actually from South Carolina. I was born in South Carolina. Raised in Georgia. I came to Boston for school about 20 years ago and I decided to stay. I live in Roxbury in the Highland Park, Fort Hill area, and I'll go with physically. Today, I literally woke up feeling tired this morning. And so that's kind of stuck with me all day, is just like, I felt a step behind all day. I'm drinking tea. I'm doing everything but I've still felt just exhausted all day. But mentally, good. Spiritually, good. So yeah. Just feeling a little exhausted. And last but not least Kristen.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. Yeah, my name's Kristen Aldrich. I live in Dochester in Jones Hill. I grew up in Rhode Island. I came to Boston for college for undergrad and moved away and lived in different places, but I've been back in Boston and in this neighborhood, in this very apartment for the last five years or so. And I'll check-in on the sort of mental emotional side. I'm, yeah. Feeling pretty good, doing pretty well. I recently started a new job, so I'm still sort of settling into that and learning things and getting to know my team and stuff like that. And it's all work from home. So I'm just on Zoom with everybody all of the time, which is a lot of people. But yeah. I'm feeling good about it. It has so far not felt too overwhelming and all of that, so that's good. But yeah, I don't know. I'm feeling good about, yeah, the job stuff and creative outlets and different things going on. So that's it for me. I guess back to Ziona.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you everyone. With that, we're all checked in. That was wonderful introduction. So I'm going to just get into the hot topic for tonight. I'm going to copy and paste the arching questions of the conversation into the chat. Just in case anyone kind of forgets or gets lost, they can see the questions in the chat, but I'm also going to read them and kind of explain and maybe demonstrate a bit. Oh, here we go. Okay. So the first arching question is a two part question.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: The first question is, what's your question about the future of Boston in your place in that future? The second part to that question is what experience in your life got you to this question? So we're coming up with a question. For example, just to give you an idea, my question would be, what can we do about the housing crisis in the city of Boston?

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: And what brought me to that question in my experience is having to relocate, because I could no longer afford the price of living in Boston, just to give you guys an idea. So then we would discuss that furthermore as our turn comes along, but I'm going to give you guys about two minutes to kind of reflect on that, come up with a question that would work for you and think about your experience that you would like to share. And I'll give you two minutes. You could write it down, or you could just think and contemplate on it. And we'll come back.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Okay. So that was our two minute. I'm just going to sit back and let you guys really give the best of the conversation [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: Yeah, I don't know why. It just you're talking and we can see your lips moving. We just can't hear nothing.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: So yeah, the question is in the end. Remember this is a question you're asking, you're not coming up with the answer. You're asking a question to Boston. You can think like, what would you say to our mayoral and the city councils? What question would you ask them and express your experience behind that question? Excuse me. Kristen. Go right ahead.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: Okay. Yeah, well, so my question is actually how you're just framing it. I'm like, Ooh, I don't know if it's well posed for like this is how I would ask a mayoral candidate or something. But my question is... Or I don't know. How we can divest from police and put that money toward communities and into communities while upholding a feeling of safety for everyone. Yeah. And so my background in arriving at that question is I guess, my engagement in racial justice groups and more recently, organizations focused on prison abolition and de-carceration efforts, and more recently transformative justice work and just kind of thinking about alternatives to what is very harmful sort of police and prison reality that we are existing in. So yeah. I would be curious to hear I guess from one like mayor or something along those lines, what their response to that would be, and yeah. How we can be moving some funds from police departments into the community. Right, and I will pass it to Yvonne.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: Kristen, that's a very good question and that question, it becomes a very frustrated question. And I belong to a lot of different organizations on a weekly basis where I do Zoom meetings around certain issues and so forth in terms of our city. Safety is one of the number one priorities. I was at a conference on Saturday, and that was one of the questions that came up around policing and the funding the police and feeling that the whole policing thing needs to be reformed and they need to be reeducated and they need to allow other professions to come in and do their jobs around mental illness. And because right now our city is facing a crisis of addiction. So when we face a crisis of addiction,

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: Yes. My question is one of the main things, policing and incarceration for women of color being incarcerated, that was one of the topics. Are they being treated fairly? Are prisoners being treated fairly? Do we have any prison rights? Because there's been a lot of issues around that, and how do we approach this? How do we expose information? And let me just redirect to the point. South Bay, right up the street for me pretty much, 15 minute walk. Recently they've been protesting over there because there have been 14 deaths, serious. And it's just being exposed. There's a lot of things around that. 14 deaths and they want to shut down. People, family members are protesting every day because they're saying that their loved ones are not safe. And I could find out, but I don't know at this point how many were women, but I think the majority of them were women. And so, because of that, that really hits home. And who is responsible for this?

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: A governor is running this state of Massachusetts. And there's been nothing said in terms of, we're bringing it to his attention and he has commented on this situation. So that's one of my questions.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: How do we make our neighborhood safer? That's the other thing that comes to mind with me is, are we doing all that we can with our youth, because it's not just in one area, it's in the whole sector of the city. If you who listen to the reports over the Summer, with young crime at hand, and I've been in this city a long time ago and it has never been this high and it doesn't seem like it's changing. I haven't given up on our city and I don't think that anybody in higher position should give up either. We have got to do better.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: We have got to do more with our youth. I know we just went through a pandemic which is another whole issue, but as I looked, as I search, I just don't think there are enough programs for our youth. We don't have enough programs. We don't have enough involvement. And we don't have enough involvement in terms of policing. We don't have enough of them being able out in the community, in the schools talking so that people don't feel like policing is just about pulling you over, pulling out a gun, you know what I mean? Being afraid for your life. We're all very uncomfortable in this. It's how are we going to make it better? What do we need to do to make this better?

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: So after Yvonne, I actually have two questions, and they're semi-related for me. But the first question is, how do we truly address addiction humanely, and in a way that is more than just rhetoric. And I say that as someone who lives in Roxbury, not far from the, what's termed the mass and cast area, and it is appalling, how people are being treated and how we are treating residents of our city and our state down there. And I feel in some respects, it has become an almost out of sight out of mind, even though it's not out of sight because it is literally in the street. It is in the McDonald's bathroom folks shooting up. It is on the highway. It is on Southampton. It's on Topeka. You see the tents. And so that would definitely be my question, particularly for the future of our city, is how are we really going to address addiction issues in a humane way and in a more than rhetoric way.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: And then the second question that I would have have is, how do we truly address climate change and the changing climate in a way that does not just create additional problems? So we can not just say we're going to address climate change by having electric vehicles, because that does not solve the fundamental problem of how do we get away from our dependency upon cars and traffic density. So it's one of those things and particularly because we are a city at and below sea level, this is a real question, and it does become an environmental justice question too because different pockets and areas of our city environmentally are worse off now than other pockets. And some of that is related to class and race and other things. And so as a city, how are we going to really truly address climate change and get serious about it, and not just be rhetoric.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: It cannot just be play planting trees. And it cannot just be, oh, our trains and buses are now more fuel efficient. Okay. But that does not really get at solving the problem. So, yeah. I guess with any question for me, it's like, how do we get beyond rhetoric to really addressing some of the issues that our city encounters.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Do you have personal experiences in your life that brung up these questions for you, maybe in your work or your home life?

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: So with the question of addiction, yes. I have family members that have suffered with addiction, different kinds in different moments and periods in their lives. And for the last 20 years, I've worked in mental health. And so addiction and substance use and abuse is very much tied to mental health and stability and so in that respect, yes.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: From the environmental respect, I have lived with asthma my entire life. And so I understand that in certain times of the year, when I was younger, asthma would flare up, and I couldn't be in certain spaces because of that. And again, working in the field of public health, and you're looking at the map of Boston and you see certain pockets of the city that have higher asthma rates, and then you also know what it's next to, what it's not next to. And so for me, it's personal and professional. And then also as someone working in the mental health fields, when you see natural disasters, earthquakes, hurricanes and that type of thing, and I've been on some of those response teams to natural disasters months later, not aftermath because that's just too much. And you see the mental health and you see the impacts of mother nature and you're like, we got to do this. We got to fix this.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: When there was the... Was it a tornado that happened in Springfield, in Massachusetts? I think it was five of six years ago. One of the organizations that I worked with responded to that. And so you're like, a tornado in Springfield, what? So, yeah. I mean for me, it does not always have to be personal for me to know that we need to do something. For me it can be secondary or vicarious in some of these respects.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: Thank you all for sharing that. Sounds like we got some common themes. I work in the mental health recovery community as well, so I totally understand. So we're going to move on to the next part of the conversation. It's like a collective of questions really to get your brain working. So I'm going to post them in the chat but I'm also going to read them, but you're not really expected to answer one particular part of this section but mostly just to have the conversation kind of touch on these. So find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life, address that person and tell them why they're question experience resonated with you and share the story from your life that connect you with their experience. What are you hearing in people's experiences? So I'll shortly demonstrate.

nodes.speaker: Ziona
nodes.words: I relate and resonate with everyone, but in particular, Yvonne and Brandy were talking a lot about mental health and recovery and addiction and I resonate a lot with that, because in my experience, I am a person with lived experience with mental health and I'm in recovery for mental health. And I also volunteer and do a lot of work in the community to fight stigma. So that's a little bit about how that should go. The topic and the questions are also posted in the chat if you want to reflect. I'm going to sit back like I just did and let you guys kind of navigate the conversation, and I'm going to start the conversation off with Yvonne Long, and don't forget to pass the mic. And it'd be nice to really look at the person that you resonate in your experience with that you're connecting to and say their name, and let them know that you're talking about their experience or their question that they asked. Okay? So take it away, Yvonne.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: I've had personal experience growing up in the city all my life, and family members in and out of addiction. I have family members now that are in addiction. And that's why I have to keep a strong faithful platform in front of me when I hear about what they're doing, how they're doing until I can find a way. I even tried to get them sanctioned. And I was unable to do that the first time around. So I'm trying to get my strength up again, and this is very personal to me, to try to make it happen again before Winter hits. I talk with my loved ones on the phone, and I, myself too, have been certified in mental health. I've worked in the field. Something happened here. So it's very personal to me that [crosstalk],

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: Yeah. That whole thing over in [Malena cast] is a very personal issue. And I've asked questions, many at times, and I just feel like they're not doing enough, and everybody is just acting like it doesn't exist, but it does exist. And I feel like if we were doing something about it early on, it would never have gotten to this point. But it had as now and it really needs to be dealt with, with government. I mean, it's not just a state issue. It's not just a issue that needs to be sat down and worked out between the counselors. This is a higher federal situation which involves a class up step from the governor, the attorney general I think, and then you had some deaths. We've had a lot of deaths that haven't even been mentioned about, but some of them were severe enough to hit the news. We've had a lot of nonprofit organizations out there working their part to try to help which is very appreciative, but yeah.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: When you see people in such chaos, and I feel like when you see a loved one or anybody that really has an addiction problem, and if you know anything about addiction, they really can't help themself. And mental health plays a big hot pot in that. Is it our job to just step up and take over and say, okay, this person needs to be sanctioned, or do we let them just keep continue on and then watch them just die? So this is what I'm saying. It's our job as a city to step up, unless we want to, like at the conference I went to, this very question came up and people were saying, well, if we opened up Long Island again and we should have, but Long Island has been closed for a while now.

nodes.speaker: Vonnie
nodes.words: To me, I feel like Long Island was just the band aid. Right? Because it was a big space. And all that was doing was putting a band-aid. They did have a lot of services up there and a lot of people did take advantage of them services, but the ones that aren't able to help themselves, where do we step in and do the right thing on a humane issue in terms of, and this comes from the governor. I think we should step in and say, okay. This person needs to be sanctioned. Everybody deserves a chance. And to me, that would be the most insane humane thing to do, is to start having individuals sanctioned. So that they haven't chance because if they're not, then they just going to die. There's no other way. We have got to push this issue all the way to the top because to me, it's gotten to that point.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: Hmm. Yvonne, you sound very passionate about the issue of addiction and substance abuse and making sure we address it and how it connects with your life. I already kind of said my connection with substance abuse and addiction. So I'd like to say that I connected with Kristen's comment about police, less about the defunding or reallocation of funds and that to be thing, but more so on a personal note, as a Black woman, growing up in the south, and even now as a Black woman, the idea and the experiences of driving while Black, walking while Black, breathing while Black, just existing while Black are very real. And even to this day, when I am driving in the car or even in the car as a passenger, and I hear the woo, woo, woo, there is a tension that builds.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: And I may grip the steering wheel or I tense up, because I've been in experiences as a driver and as a passenger where police have pulled me over, and it has been because I am a person of color. I mean, you could be like, oh, I was speeding. No. Because I'm a person of color.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: [crosstalk]. many instances. There were two in particular that I remember. One was at two o'clock in the morning. I am in upstate New York, Ithaca, New York. I'm coming back from Syracuse, driving back to my campus and it's myself and my home girl, and we have two Black males in the backseat. It's 2:00 AM. We're going through a small town. It was 35 miles an hour. I think I was going 40. The cop trails us for an mile.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: And I knew he was behind me. I could see the outline of the car. So I'm slowing down, all this good stuff. He trails for a mile. After mile, he turns on his lights. Again, it's 2:00 AM, upstate New York. It's a very racial, hostile area. So I'm like, this is not going to be good. We got two Black men in the car. I mean, we're all Black. So he pulls us over, 2:00 AM. He says, "You were driving too fast." And of course I was already taught, given the talk, you show respect, you show difference. I'm like, sir, we were going 40. I clocked it, all that good stuff. And he's like, well, you're going 40 miles an hour. You could have hit a dog. You could have hit somebody. And I'm like, it's 2:00 AM. Right?

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: And I'm just like, this guy. And he's like, well, let me see your license. Let me see your registration. And then he starts to say, get out of the car. And I'm like, oh God, this is not going to go well. And I'm like, officer. So then I immediately say, because everybody in that are knows the school. I'm like, "Officer, we're just trying to get back to school. We're trying to get back to Cornell." And he's like, "Oh, you go to Cornell?"

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: Yes, sir. We all go to Cornell. We all didn't. But I was like, we got to get out of this incident. It's 2:00 AM. Nobody is out here. Getting out of the car is not going to be good. So those types of incidences and so for me, it becomes very real when people talk about issues with police and things like that.

nodes.speaker: Brandy
nodes.words: And I mean, we all saw the George Floyd incident. And even now to this day, I think about it and I get angry just thinking about it. And so it's very real. And so I hear it with the defunding, I connect to it. And at the same time, it creates, as a person, as an ally, I think that's important. But then there's also still that kind of in the back of your head, where you say, you will never understand, truly in the sense of that you will have to have the same conversations with your nieces and nephews or family members, that I have to have with mine. And so, it's like that. Yeah. It's that constant kind of thing. And so I definitely felt your experiences, your sharing of that and I appreciate that. And thank you for being an ally and just working in this space because it's needed.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you so much for sharing that. And that's absolutely true with that like, I am a CIS White woman. There are experiences that I just simply won't have in the same way because of the racist society that we live in and it's, yeah, really difficult. I mean, it's interesting, I don't know, if I feel like I'm about to go on a whole tangent. But yeah, I, yeah, very much appreciate hearing you share your story. And I actually recently have been reflecting on my personal experiences with police and the interactions that I've ever had with police and how I have always gotten off easy with any kind of interaction like that, getting pulled over for speeding or anything else, and like, I'm very aware of why that is the way that it is.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: And it's, I don't know. It's just awful. And I don't know what to do and I can to organize in ways that I can and work with people in ways that I can to try to move things in a different direction. And ideally, get other White people to understand that as well. Yeah, I mean, a few things, a lot of what you all said resonated with me, for sure. And I mean, certainly no people, myself, friends and family in my life who struggle with mental illness and substance abuse and that feels very personal. I mean, a lot of these topics are very universal or feel that way to me. I think it's hard to find somebody that really doesn't know anybody at all that struggles with some form of mental health or substance use or different things like that.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: But anyway, that is definitely one that resonates with me and thinking about how to address the people and really see the full humanity of folks that are struggling with whatever it is that they're struggling with. And yeah, the whole Mass and Cass thing. And how I hear politicians talking about it sometimes feels a little bit like... I mean, like what you're saying, Dr. Brooks previously, it's just rhetoric. Sometimes it's like, okay, well, that's maybe a nice thing to say but what's actually happening. Like Lots of substance of what is really changing or something like that or, yeah. So that definitely resonates with me too. And then there was something else.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: Oh, Yvonne, you were talking about I think women in the South Bay correctional facility, or prison in South Bay. But yeah, in terms of that kind of work that definitely resonates with me. And I was recently participating in an action to kind of promote decarceration of women and standing against, I guess the construction of the new women's prison that they want to build. And in Massachusetts, we have a very small population of incarcerated women. Anyway, so that also feels like, yeah, it's something that I've been thinking about a lot and yeah. And then the last thing I'll say, and then I'll shut up for now is the environmental justice piece that you brought up Dr. Brooks, and that also for me, is it interesting? So I studied environmental conservation education in graduate school, and that was a really important time in my life and thing for me to be kind of immersing myself in intellectually and led me kind of in different career paths and things like this.

nodes.speaker: Kristen
nodes.words: And that was all well and good, but it wasn't really, and it's like, I don't know, as I guess almost embarrassing to admit, but it wasn't until later that I sort of recognized how very White centric that realm of study is and how disappointing that felt to kind of like in so many layered ways. Like why did it take me so long to come to that realization, and why are certain people highlighted and certain people are absent from the studies that I experience and stuff like that. But certainly environmental issues are racial justice issues in my mind. And yeah, I think that's really real and it's really important to be recognizing that. nodes.speaker: Elvis

When you guys share these answers, we want to make sure that you guys give us as most possible details that you guys can just so we have as much information. So how bad is traffic when you leave to work? And then how bad is traffic when you come back to work? Walk us through your commute basically, that's what I'm asking you here.

nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: Well, a perfect example will be that before, let's say during the pandemic where everybody was not driving, it used to take me 20 to 25 minutes in order for me to commute from Boston until Lingfield. Now, it's taking me an hour and a half. So that is a huge change right there because now that everybody has started going back to work, going back to in-person school, the traffic it's being affected. Everybody has a car. They either have to stop selling car to people or find a way how to create different roads, something in order to deal with this problematic.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Thank you so much for that. Now that you guys gotten a little bit of feeling of what we're doing and now we had answer questions and the context of what is the purpose of what we're doing here tonight, are there any questions about this process? Okay. So with that I will continue our conversation tonight.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: So what I want you guys to do next is think back to each other's questions and experiences. This is why we hired you guys think about the questions that you were going to share with us and the experiences that got to arrive at that particular question. So within the group, that we just went around, we asked our questions, we shared our experience, find someone. I know that you guys cannot get up and go around. But when I say find someone is from the conversation, from the questions and experiences that you have heard today, I want you guys to think about one person's experiences and questions that resonates with you in your own life. Then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experiences resonated with you and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: No. So for example. Herschell spoke about how it was like, what was the educational system. Then Alejandro spoke about the educational system from a student's perspective that didn't get as much field trip, that felt that his school didn't get as much funding. And then you shared with us, your traffic and your commute and the fact that you've been looking for a house for over a year now. And there's just so many people moving into Boston and there's not enough constructions and new buildings coming up. So we want out of those three questions and experiences for you to pick one, either Alejandro's or Herschell's experience in question that resonates with you.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: And then we want you to take a moment and then reflect on those two things. And then whoever's ready to kick us off, can start us off with why somebody else question or experience resonates with you. And give us an example in how their experience and question has affected you in your life. How is that topic affecting you within your life? Do you understand now, Yomaira?

nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: Yes, I'm completely agree. Actually I think that I can answer to your questions right now. Which actually, I think it was Alejandro, the first one with the education gap. That's something that I resonate to myself because like example about it, I have a child of my own, which I decide to he was going to school here in Boston Public School and then I took him to the North Redding Public School System and they're difference on the education is huge. The funds that they receive versus the lack of funds that they have here in Boston, there is a huge difference.

nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: I don't know his name, the first one, was talking about that gap, where in their education that they received, it shouldn't happen. It shouldn't be that way. I think that everybody should be receiving the same type of education, because everybody have that right to receive. We all pay our taxes, we all here in our society, trying to do better trying to sustain, try to make a difference, just depending on what side of the city do you live in or is it if you have money or not.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Thank you. Just a follow-up to that, do you feel that... I know besides lack of funding, what else do you feel that BPS is lacking a school district that those are one of the reasons why you have now taken your son and brought him into the North Redding Public School system.

nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: It is also the education, it's not just the funds, it's also the education. It looks like they invest more time into the students, into the curriculum, they have more activities, they like to keep the students more busy during the day. And that extra homework that they provide to the student that, extra time, that extra effort, it makes a huge difference.

nodes.speaker: Herschell

I mean, we're coming from Indiana, the cost of living is not as bad home as it is here. But to even think that two thirds of everyone that lives in the Boston area, rent their house and they don't own it, that let you know that they just cost a lot of money. So it's like, I don't know if that could be fixed, but it will make a lot of people's life easier if it was.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Excuse me. Since you share that, one of the things that you resonate with is the whole housing. Do you feel that it is within the whole city of Boston where we're lacking, we don't have enough homes that we can sell to people? I really want to hear from your point of view, what is different from you, living in Indiana and then coming here, is there more houses there that you can buy? Do we have more houses here that you can... Give us a little bit more about that.

nodes.speaker: Herschell
nodes.words: I'll say, because when we initially moved here, we stayed in a graduate housing at Harvard, because that's where my wife is going to school. And the apartment that we were paying for, just so you can see what I mean, cost the same as our mortgage on a house, our two cars and our insurance back home in Indiana, just for a two bedroom apartment.

nodes.speaker: Alejandro
nodes.words: Yomaira, okay. So what Yomaira has said earlier about the traffic that I can touch on that because in EC where I live right now, they're building... Every month, it looks like they're just building something new. And the traffic here has gone up by a lot. A couple years ago, it might have been a little bit bad, but now it's pretty bad. Especially in the mornings, when a lot of people that bought all these new apartments here, they usually go work in the city. So the tunnels, it's crazy, man. It's jam packed in the morning. So I think they should figure out a way, I don't know, maybe make a new road or something to help the traffic in that area. So yeah, I feel that's a pretty big problem right now, at least in East Boston. I don't know about other parts of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: So you feel that if there's less construction, it would equal less traffic or how does that impact you? Are you a driver? Are you a commuter? How is traffic impacting you in your own personal day?

nodes.speaker: Alejandro

So it might have to do with that too. Because you always got people coming in and out, that are leaving the airport or going to the airport. But I've also noticed that the trains are now way more packed than what they used to be. And I feel like that's due to all the people that are moving in here.

nodes.speaker: Elvis

nodes.speaker: Elvis

nodes.words: Sorry that I went dark there. My camera, its whole problem. Trying to fix that. Okay. So now that we have taken the time to think about what we're hearing in the room I want us to share. nodes.speaker: Elvis

nodes.speaker: Alejandro
nodes.words: So, I'd like to touch on what Herschell had said about the rent, I feel like that is a big problem. And I feel like that probably has a lot to do with the fact that there's so many new buildings being built in Boston, East Boston, South Boston. When you have all these people moving in and you're pumping so much money into one space, the rent is bound to go up. And then that leads to usually, people of color and minorities getting pushed out due to all these people moving in because now they're not able to pay on rent anymore. They're used to paying X amount or something low and now the rent is increased and they can't afford it. They can't live like that.

nodes.speaker: Alejandro
nodes.words: I know a lot of my friends that do rent in East Boston, they say that it's really, really high. And usually they have to have roommates. It's not like they could just live by themselves. They need maybe two or three roommates. So I feel like it shouldn't be like that. So we could just find a way to fix that. And make sure that on people in our communities, people of color, minorities are not getting kicked out or we can at least give them some type of assistance to be able to pay the rent. I feel like that would help out a lot of people.

nodes.speaker: Herschell
nodes.words: I hear from everyone that education is important. And something needs to happen to make it better for the inner city kids, you know what I mean? They should have a fair shot to thrive and make a change. And it's hard to, like he said, be motivated to go to school, when you don't even have sometimes the simple things.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Herschel, I had this little question for you, I was going to ask it early, but then we moved on because you touch base about education and the fact that you're working in the educational space. I would want you to give us a specific story that you have experienced within the educational space that drove you to ask the question that you did and share the experience that you shared?

nodes.speaker: Herschell
nodes.words: I think it's a lot of factors that go into schooling. In Indiana, we had a saying, I worked at a high school in the front office in Indiana, they say, "They will be what they see." I'm sorry. So one thing I feel like, we need more people of color in the schools because especially the schools that dominantly people of color. I worked at a school in Cambridge, it's charter community school. So it's over 80% people of color. But there wasn't a lot of black males working there and there wasn't a lot of black females working there. And it's like, some of the teacher couldn't relate to. And so, I felt like there just needs to be a whole change in how can we motivate people of color don't want to work in the school. Does that make sense?

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Yes. Thank you so much for sharing that. I really do appreciate it. And I believe that our last person will be Yomaira.

nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: Yeah. I think that already shared my point of view, identify myself with the gap in the schools and what's going on the school system right now. Yeah, how identify myself with that situation.

nodes.speaker: Elvis
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you. Thank you so much for sharing. It is actually time for us to wrap up. I want to thank all of you for sharing your question and your experiences. nodes.speaker: Yomaira
nodes.words: I think that's a really good takeaway out of this amazing conversation, I first would like to thank you guys for making me part of it. Because I think it gives us an opportunity not just to express, but become a better idea and how we feel identify ourselves with everything that is going on, and be a little be empathetic with if somebody gets late to work or to school, understand that probably ran late on traffic. Thank you guys.

nodes.speaker: Elvis

But that could be a very good question for the next mayor that we're getting, in a couple of months. So very good question, Alejandro.

nodes.speaker: Alejandro

But it's good to see people especially like Herschell, someone who works in the school, in the school system, who knows how it actually is. It's nice to hear that we're on the same page.

nodes.speaker: Elvis

nodes.words: All right. So first of all, thank you, and welcome to this session. I really do appreciate you guys for coming here. And so, we invited you today to this gathering to ask what you think is the most pressing question you have living in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Our goal today is to share and elaborate on the questions that you have, and to engage in conversation with one another. And so, right now we will begin the recording. And before I do that, and before we do introductions, I would just like to give you a few important pieces of information about what the session's about. So first of all, you might be asking why are we holding these conversations? And if Randy or Brad, if you have not seen the little video that gives an overview of it, Fran, should you share it or would you be able to share it?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No, I think we won't take that 90 seconds, but can I send it to you and you can re-send it to them.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Okay, sounds good. I'll do that. So, why are we holding these conversations? We want to create a new space around the city to facilitate more constructive listening, across different divides, being neighborhood, political, cultural, and to provide improved visibility and accountability between the mayoral candidates, and the neighborhoods and people living in them across the city. And so to this end, we're inviting you to have a different type of conversation. So, this conversation is less focused on debates and who the candidates are, more so it's focused on sharing your personal stories and experiences living here.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: And so, we're doing this so we can help build connections with one another and foster conversations to help improve our understanding of one another, and the situations that we're in. So what will be happening in this recording? So after this meeting today, the recording will be split. Audio, video, video will be thrown out, audio will be kept, and it will be transcribed using their platform called LVN. And it's a web based tool used for accessing and exploring conversations, designed by the nonprofit organization called Cortico. And this system creates this transcript of each recorded conversations, which is uploaded along with audio recording, with this tool called Explorer.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: And the system will highlight keywords that will emerge across different conversations and allow people to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover different patterns. And note that the people who will have access to the full transcript will be just you guys, and the people who are working with Cortico. However, the main themes and the big snippets that will come out of that, that'll be available to the general public.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: And so, now I need to read this consent statement, and ask if you're willing to be recorded. And so first of all, do any of you have any questions? All right. Okay, sounds good. Okay. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection on Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations and communities, and in the media that will improve our understanding of one another. Cortical will collect, retain and analyze these conversations, in keeping with that mission. In addition, part of Real Talk for Change's mission, is to present voices from the people of Boston. Therefore, portions of your conversations can be made public. And so if you understand and agree to this, please say out loud and take yourself off mic, "I agree."

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Amazing, thank you guys very much. I just added the message in the chat. Okay, everybody good? Cool.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: All right, so now at the end of the conversation... Oh, finally, blah, blah, blah. At the end of the conversation, I'm going to ask if you can help us capture some simple demographic information, we'll be sending out a short survey, should only take about a minute long, that will ask questions such as, where do you live, where you are in ethnicity and things like that. And finally, there are just a few key rules that we will just go over before we begin the conversation. Is that all good? Okay, sounds good.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Okay. First, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Second, allow others to speak for themselves. Third, share the time. Allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Four, stay curious, ask honest questions. Fifth, pause and take time for reflection. Sixth, listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have impact. Seven, when possible close any unnecessary programs, applications or notifications, and put your phone on silent. The idea is just to be present here. And eighth, if you need a moment or need to take a break, let us know in the chat. Is everybody good, everybody understand? Thanks. All right, so-

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: Oh, sorry. Don't mean to interrupt, but I just want to say that I do need to drop in like 25 more minutes, if that's okay.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: In 25 minutes, okay. Let's try to keep it quick. All right, thank you so much. No worries, no worries. So the first thing that we're going to do is give a round of introductions and what we do, and also check in. So, the way how we do this, is we use a system called PIES. So that is, we first introduce ourselves, our name, where we're from and how we're doing either physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. And for example, how this could go is I could be like, "Hi, my name's Becky. I live in Brighton, and today, how am I doing intellectually? I feel like I'm doing great. And why? Because I feel like I am learning something new just about the city, just by being here." And then at the end, "You'd say with that, I'm in." Do all of you understand? All right. So, I'll write that in the chat. First of all, would anybody like to go first? Okay. Jason, can you go?

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: Hello, I'm Jason. I'm originally from Palestine, live in Boston. I live in Back Bay slash Fenway area, within the borders, I guess. And today, I guess physically I'm feeling well, because I went to the gym and also had some good food, so that's always good. And I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: I'm Haley. I live in Brighton. Today, I am feeling a little emotionally tired after a long day with my two year old. And I'm in?

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: Yeah, sure. Yeah, so my name is Randy. I am from Dominican Republic. Well, I grew up in Puerto Rico but that's where I'm from. I am, it's just a mix of things. I am tired physically, and in a few other ways. I really got stuff that I needed to get done, so I can rest for now. That's okay.

nodes.speaker: Brad
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Brad, I live in Brighton. And I am intellectually tired because I've been dealing with a lot of problems at work, but it's a good tired, it's a successful tired. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: All right, thanks guys. Okay. And now we know that everybody's here and we know who's here, now let's get to the core of our conversation. And so, as we start to emerge from the pandemic, it's easy for us to lose sight of what we've learned about what's going on, particularly the inequality that's in America and in Boston, and how our lived experiences have shaped our thinking. And so, keeping all of this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think. And if you need to, grab a pen and paper, or anything that will help you do that. And think of the question, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? I'll add that question to the chat, and please take two minutes or so just to reflect and think about it. And later on, I'll check back with you.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: All right, now do all of you have your question? You can just nod or give a thumbs up. Okay. All right, so now I'd like to invite you to think, and again, take a bit of time for this. What experience in your life got you to this question? But if you've read something, or just something that has affected you, that made you think about that question. I'd like for you to take some time to do that, then later on I'll check back in.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Okay. Is everybody ready? Yes, no? All right, so I'm going to post in the chat, the order of how we're going to share. And I know if you have something that you want to respond to right away, based on what somebody asks, please add that to the chat and we'll address that later on. So Randy, are you ready to share?

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: Sure. But I don't know if I took this question in the right direction. So as I share, you can probably just let me know, "This is not what we want. This is not what we mean, this is not what the conversation is about." So my question about the future of Boston is more related to me. Will I be here long term, will I be able to just, I don't know, settle here? Will I ever feel at home? I don't know, that kind of thing.

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: So what made me, I haven't answered that one, but just on the fly, what made me think about that question is just like, I don't know, houses are expensive. I don't know. I just, I really don't know.

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: Yeah. So my question was basically, will there be more events held between different neighborhoods? Could be focused for example, on volunteering, and basically more educational realm that would help, for example, underrepresented neighborhoods. And I guess the experience I had coming to Boston, for example for college, when I came in 2016 to Northeastern, I always heard about the different neighborhoods within the area. But everyone is just like, "Oh, go to this neighborhood, then go to that neighborhood." And I think people don't think like why different neighborhoods are different. And I one of the things we always noticed, is just differences in education, differences in support system within each community. And I think like all these things make me think of how each community, with more help or with more funding, can be helped more. And have, for example, more safety within Boston.

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: And I think a lot of people have concerns about going to different neighborhoods, just because of what they think that neighborhood is, or what each neighborhood could be like. And especially coming from abroad, everyone's tells you not to go to a certain neighborhood within Boston, or they just say, "Oh, all this neighborhood is just the same way." Which is definitely not true. So I think my experience is just, I believe although it should be within, I guess, the authority of the City of Boston in general to help. But it could also be people just volunteering and getting together from different neighborhoods, to actually build the community together and make a better Boston for themselves. Not just by just hoping that it'll become better somehow.

nodes.speaker: Brad
nodes.words: So, how I thought of this was related to housing. A little bit of what was mentioned earlier about affordability, but for me personally, being more trying to figure out what the best word would be, but I guess accessibility in essence. And in particular with young families. So you have the Lead laws for housing, and we were ghosted by realtor brokers and homeowners when we were looking for places to live here in Boston. Because we have a toddler, and we'll have another toddler in our home shortly. And they don't want to rent to us because of the Lead law compliance, which is not fair renting practices. So it makes it very difficult to think of a future here in Boston, when you're dealing with a housing situation on a lease by lease basis, and not sure if you'll even be allowed, from the sense of a realtor or a homeowner, to even begin to look for places here in Boston. Which I think would be very important, to have families here in Boston of all types.

nodes.speaker: Brad
nodes.words: Yeah. So the question on that is, if the desire of Boston as a whole is to have families here, and if that is the case, then how will Boston enable housing to be accessible to people with families like that?

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: No, that's okay. That's just been a really harsh experience we've had here in Boston several times, so it comes to our mind quickly. But a question that I have about the future of Boston is, will it be more accessible for children and people with disabilities? And I think especially children. So in particular, I guess this relates to my experience, I'm a stay-at-home mom with a two year old. We have another child who is missing his arms, and other disabilities, coming to our family through adoption. And we spend most of our day at the parks, and most of the parks we go to that are in walking distance, he can't reach most of the stuff because he has to climb ropes, or poles, or things that his body just isn't able to do.

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: And so, yeah, I guess that's my question. I think Boston has a lot of great, unique parks that for typically abled kids is really challenging and cool. But for children with disabilities, Boston can be a really hard place to be. The roads are tough, the buses are tough to access. A lot of the schools are really old, there's a lot of challenges if you do have handicaps in the city. So I guess for me, I wonder will our family be able to stay here long term, and meet the needs of our son?

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Thank you for sharing. All right, so now what I'd like for you to do next is think back about the questions that you might have thought of, or any thoughts that you might have had when people were sharing. And if you can, find somebody whose question or experience resonates with you. And feel free to go ahead, or else I'm going to call on one of you.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Yeah. Make a comment, ask a question, make a connection with somebody. Or if there's somebody that you resonated with, reach out to that or state that.

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: Randy, you mentioned part of your question was just wondering if, making Boston feel like home. Is part of that because you don't feel like you've been welcomed into a community here? Are there certain things, is it just home sickness from your culture, or are there other things that you wish the city would provide to make you feel more at home?

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: That is a great question. I guess I can't really pinpoint why. I don't know, I think in part is the culture, and I do feel homesick from time into time. But it's hard to give a straight answer, since I'm not myself entirely sure. When you're home, it just feels like home. But I wouldn't blame it on the community or, I wouldn't put it on that. I don't know, it's just different. Yeah, I don't know. But thank you.

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: I think I have a question for Haley. I was just wondering, I know most families just move to suburban areas. What do you think the benefits could be for having more families within the different Boston neighborhoods? Because obviously just most families, when people start a family, just move to the suburb. But what do you think could be done, or why do you think it's important to have families within the city itself?

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: That's a really good question. I think for one, diversity, diversity in thought, diversity in so many different aspects of the city. Because I think when you have families just flee, it creates a certain culture of the city that is I think more one dimensional. And I think, we obviously find children super valuable, that's why we have started a family. And I think there's no real community, no culture that has ever said we can thrive without children present. And so, I think even for cities to continue to grow and thrive, it's important to have children there.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: All right. Brad or Randy, do you have anything that stuck out to you? If not, that's okay. That's okay, I don't need to...

nodes.speaker: Brad
nodes.words: No. I just see a common theme here, of wanting to have multiple perspectives from different types of people living in the city.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Definitely. And on that note, do any of you see any other themes besides what Brad has pulled out from what you've been talking about?

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: I haven't had much experience with renting, for example, but I have a lot of friends who have had issues, finding a place, finding an affordable place, especially closer to the universities in the city, or even after. Because a lot of people have to move out, because for example, a lot of people have financial aid while they're in university, but then after that, no one wants to pay, I don't know, 1,800, 2,000 or more to live in an apartment, to be close to the city.

nodes.speaker: Jason
nodes.words: And definitely Back Bay is very overpriced, but they say it's location, but I don't know. It depends, obviously I like Back Bay and I think it's worth it in some cases. But now I've seen, I looked at the prices recently and they're insane. And I think landlords are trying to make back what they lost during COVID, so it's like the prices are really insane. The rent of the apartment I was in literally doubled. So, I think like maybe some sort of solution for that would definitely help as well.

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: Still thinking about Jason's questions, I was like, why should families stay in the city? And I'm having an identity crisis, why are we here?

nodes.speaker: Haley
nodes.words: But I think the flip side for families, cities house a lot of resources. For us, one of the major resources as a family with a child with special needs, is the hospitals. And many families have to come from all over the country, to somewhere like Boston, and pay a lot of money out of pocket to stay here, to get treatments. Where if you live here, you can drive down the road. And I think also, resources as far as education and things. I look at my sister who lives out in the country, and there's just not as many resources in the schools, and things like that. And so, I think letting families be in cities can also provide the next generation with resources they may not have.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: No, that's important. It's kind of like, the city is made up of so many different types of people, and there's a reason why we all gather here, especially in Boston. Universities, hospitals and everything else, work. So, thank you all for coming. I think it's time to wrap up. And so, now we'll quickly go around and share something that you'll take away with you. But before we do that, do you have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share, or general reflections, or any other questions for us?

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Is there an other? Well, here's the survey, it's right here. Actually, that's not right here, I will add it right here. There we go. I wonder if there's a question...

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: You could put yourself as other. It's tricky, because I've got, for example my coworker, he's Moroccan. That's North African, but he immigrated here to study at Northeastern. So it's kind of like, where do we put him?

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Here's not his home, but he's technically white-ish. But if you could please fill that out now, that would be great. And if you could particularly focus on the demographic information, that would be great. And the reason why we have the little question asking for your email address, is so that you'll have access to this conversation afterwards. And we also want to say thank you, and we'll be sending you a $40 gift card. It's just a visa gift card, and you can spend it anywhere as good as cash. And what else? Does anybody have any questions? All right. Randy, do you have something to say?

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: Oh no, I was just going to say that I'm going to drop. I need to prepare for some tutoring that I'm doing, that I will be taking. But it was super awesome, thank you for inviting me. Yeah, I'll be filling out that survey, [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Thank you so much. Wait, not related, but will your sister be at church this Sunday? I have her clothes in a bag. Should I bring them or should I not?

nodes.speaker: Randy
nodes.words: I honestly don't know. She's super busy with school. She goes to Berkeley, we also live around the Fenway area right away, so I might see you around, Jason. So, I don't know if she will be able to, hopefully she will. So yeah, if not, we'll be in touch. I'll try to reach out.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Thanks, Randy. Just FYI, his sister just came here from DR, and so she's looking for just clothes and coats, and that wasn't a thing back in DR. So, now she's just looking for a winter coat, hence why I've got clothes that I've been meaning to part ways with. All right, so I think we're all good. Are we, Fran? Do you think we're all set?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: And actually, I would think he would have the thing. So we're going to get started. So you guys, just to give you an overview of what this is about, this was started by a group at MIT. This whole process was the Center for Constructive Conversations is part of the media lab and Ron Bell and a few from Dunk the Vote and a couple of other community organizations. They brought it to the Center for Urban Studies at [inaudible] which was brought to people in the community, and the Dunk the Vote people work with us and a few other agencies and they said, we want to call this real talk for change. But the essential thing is that they collect conversations.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: And mostly what we're looking for is your own personal experiences about our basic question is your place in Boston. What do you think? What is a question you have about your future in Boston as it pertains to... Just as being a great place to live and things like that? And then we want you to think about that for a little while. And then the second part, I'll tell you in a minute.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Before we get started, I want to just everybody go around and say a little something. I think what we want to try to do is we want to make sure everybody's present. And some of you might have heard of this P.I.E.S check-in, is anybody familiar with that?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: No? All right. So basically it's, you sort of introduce yourself, and then just what is your sense of presence for this moment? Is it physical, spiritual, intellectual, or is an emotional? Basically you want to talk about how you here today. Almost like Lo was doing at the beginning, talk about his day and everything like that. Check-in in terms of, being present and ready to go. So anybody want to start? Or you want me to start?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Yeah. Yeah. What's your basis for sort of being present in this moment? What's your flow in terms of to get yourself to be ready to present at this moment.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: I think it's spiritual intellectual. Yeah. You know, I've been here and I like it here. I want to talk about it. I want more for it, enjoy it the way it is. I don't know if that answers it. I've done a lot. Been here a long time. [crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Lorena
nodes.words: I'm sorry to interrupt. I'm going to hop off it seems like everybody's all set. So have a great conversation, everyone. And Mike, please let me know if you need anything. You can just email me. I'll be on the lookout.

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: Yes, so I don't mind. Yes. My name is [inaudible] is my real name, but they call me [inaudible]. I'm in funny kind of spiritual and emotional mood here in Boston. And I've been growing up here in Black Boston. I'm really bothered by where we are in Boston right now. I feel that there's so much more that could be offered to Black people in this city. And I feel that the fact that we are such a large part of the city of Boston. And I look back and I look at how we participated especially in the election, and voting. I mean, it seems to me like a big joke. Because how is it that you get 4% of voters to come out, Black voters, when you have thousands of voters that are registered, just don't feel as necessary to come out to vote. I'm really bothered by that.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Yeah, no, I get it. So what's your question for your future here, and that you need to have answered that you think is an important question about-

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: What I think is important is the fact that how are we going to exist? Yeah. I wouldn't want to be a [inaudible] but I see us being pushed out of this community. I see us being moved out of here. So, where are we going to be in the next five to ten years?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: So, all right, beautiful. And now I just want to say though... We'll finish. We'll finish. You're next on my board Douglas, so we'll have you go next.

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: Douglas DuBoulay is my name. I live in the south end. I have been in Boston since 1976. I raised my family here. I came to this town by myself and as an 18 year old kid. And I have a family of seven now. And of course that's a spiritual thing in itself. Because I want the best for all my family and all people in their journey as well. I'm joining the conversation and putting a nice little spin on it and see where it goes. It sounds like [inaudible] thought. Where would I like to see the city go? I... Hey listen, maybe the politicians aren't playing the right game. Obviously there is a way to bring voters out. [inaudible] proved that. But they're not putting their feet to the ground. They say they're grass roots, but they're not really grass roots. And that's the consequence. [inaudible]. The vote always just splits in Boston. It always just split. Divide and conquer things seem to work in politics in this city. But it's unfortunate, you know?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: So the idea is you want to, what's your question about something that you want to see dealt with in a particular way. Or, what's your question about that?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: In this conversation we're talking about Boston. The script... In general, as Boston, certainly so go a lot of cities. And I'm sure there's a lot of similarities. One of the things about this process and this-

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: Oh I understand. Well, the number one thing, and obviously that affects all of us is this Mass Ave situation and how as a community [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Okay. So, from your own experience, something that... Okay. How this is supposed to go to is that they want you guys to answer, "What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? Okay? And then once you've done that, once that once everybody's done that-

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: ... then they want you to talk about what experience in your life got you to this question. All right. And we're particularly looking for things that you can talk about as part of your experience directly, about what was the catalyst for making this, for creating this as an important question for you.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: So basically, you're on the right track. I've just trying to... The question is what experiences in your life got you to this question? All right? Those two questions we want you guys to answer. Now, what I was doing was, I wanted to try to get everybody's question out first, and stuff like that. So you guys had some pretty good intros coming in. But we want to try to narrow it down so that you can talk about what's important to you and what got you to the place of this being important to you in some sort of resolution?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: All right. So your question is about doing something about, what's the type of things that are happening at Mass and Cass. That's what your focus is on as a question right now?

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: No, no, no, that was just something I felt that politicians, and us, and spiritually we all turn sort of a blind eye to it. You know?

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: It's the fact that I don't know what the numbers are today, but in the past it's been where very few of Boston [inaudible], Boston University, and the Massachusetts Universities.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Okay. So education and stuff. So, I want to get the young lady over here's question. And then we're going to go into... Then people are going to talk about what got them to that position. All right?

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: Good evening, everyone. My name is Beth Griffith and I'm a long time Boston resident. I live in Dedham. I have a home office in Dedham, but I do have a business office in Dorchester in the community. And I'm a community activist in the community. And what I can say on the local city level and the statewide level right now... And what I can truly say is I want a Boston where our leadership... My question is, why are we still putting up with the same transactional leaders instead of finding transformational leaders that are, uncorruptable like your dad, Michael. Mel King affectionately known as Papa Mel. And the only way for the Boston of color to actually benefit is to get people in office that will be transformational. And incorruptible, that's why like Brother Larry said you had a 4% turnout because everything's been transactional instead of transformational. So my question is who, what, where, when, why, and how can we achieve this? That's my whole thing.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Okay. That's that was seven questions, but I get it. I get it. Okay. So now what I want you to do is basically what some of you have started doing anyway. All right. Talk about what... not all of you actually... What experience in your life brings you to this arrived at this question. So what experiences in your life got you to this question? So you guys want to... Are you ready to think about that? Are you ready? Do you want a few minutes to think about it? Does anybody want to start?

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: You know, my question was education based as far as my children and my community, and how I see there's such a large gap in how [crosstalk] education between the ones who can afford to take their child to a private school, and one of those who go to public school. And the worst part, we're teaching our own kids. There's a feeling diverse [inaudible] that's in the Boston Public School system. But still, our kids are being left behind. And not to put any blame on any particular person, or the administration itself, but I think that the future of Boston lies in our children and on their education. And what brought me to that, my own experience with my own children, my own experience with children in my neighborhood who I know are smart, talented and went through public schools and did not achieve.
