But how just adds to my conflict.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: You know. We have a lot of people. I've been working in politics since I was 14 years old doing campaigns, running campaigns, managing, just a lot. But the thing is we have to pick our battles. We have a lot of people who talk a lot, have a lot of conversations, but they're not doing anything. You need to pick what you're serious about and do it. I mean, I've worked on a lot of different fronts, serve on boards that I am interested in for children, for housing. But you have to be serious and dedicated to them. It's not just chit chatting about it. We can all talk. Talk is cheap. If you have a candidate that you want to get in office, get out there. Stop talking and do something. We don't have enough dedicated people. And they will criticize other people who are doing it. But if you're serious stick with it and do it. No stop talking. Get out there. There's a lot of conversation going on just like this. But unless you apply yourself personally, like I do. I said, I'm bored, so I do a lot.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: Nothing gets done. Talk is cheap. I know nothing gets don't unless you apply yourself personally and get in it. I can sit and talk all day about stuff, but I have to go to meetings. I have to do things. I have to apply myself. I have to talk to people. Yes. But that's not where it ends. You have to get out there and do something.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: [crosstalk]. These people think other people are going to vote your candidate in without you getting there and doing something. You got to get serious. You look at people in other states look at Georgia and how Stacy... They are serious. Every day. They're not playing. We're fooling around. And see Larry and I were saying other people have had Black mayors and stuff way before we did. We were given one, and we couldn't even hold it. We're not serious.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: Show people that they can get from A to B, if they do this that and the other. We're not doing that.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Yeah. So you got to your question. I wanted to give Larry a chance to say how he got to his question.

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: Well, what contributed to me getting to my question is the expenses of living life here in Boston. And seeing, and I agree with my sister. That talk is one thing we as Black people, we allow politicians to be elected yet we don't hold them accountable. We vote them in and we don't hear from them, or see them, or call them, or speak to them until the next time they're getting ready to get back in the election.

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: They say the same things. They say the same things. There's nothing new that they're saying. They promise us all education, housing, jobs. I mean those are things that they present, but who's actually doing it? How can we vote these politicians back in? So to me, once again it goes back on us. If I'm working, if I have a decent job, then I'm okay. I ain't hungry, so I ain't so much worried about the next brother, the one that's breaking in your house, stealing your car. I ain't worried about him until he actually does something to me. Then I'm worried about him.

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: But we talk about being sick and tired, and being community, and coming together. But like my sister said, it's just talk. It's nothing new we're hearing under the sun. You know? So my thing is this, how are we going to hold these politicians accountable? And why is it so much that we have to go to the politicians that have them do what we should be able to do ourselves?

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Okay. So, all right. That was well put. I think I liked that question you ended with. And I think we should underscore that at least I'm going to underscore that for this process, that I'm working on. The idea... I probably should have showed everybody... Everybody hasn't seen the video? I'm doing this backwards and stuff. Right? They have a little video. Why don't I let... who hasn't gone? You haven't done your experiential thing Beth? Right? I think everybody else has. So do you want to do that, and then we'll show the video. And then I have one other sort of closing.

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: So it's kind of telling, I was actually reading an article about how Black people, and other people of color, and women were purposely discriminated against right now to this day, when it comes to joining unions and Boston, which is a shot at upward mobility. And as a person of color in the construction industry, you'll do better making money outside of a union and starting your own company, then you will being in a union and getting that union affiliation with your company. And then I want to go back to my childhood where I was excluded. I went to private school in West Roxbury when I was younger. And I remember getting chased home every day, being called the N word from my childhood. That's showing me, "You're not welcome here. You don't deserve to be here." And that's the same thing that's going on right now to this day at present time.

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: And the goal is to keep everything in Boston business as usual, white male dominated. And I am not afraid because of one of the positions I hold right now, I'm on the No against Prop 22 Massachusetts coalition. I'm not afraid to call out legislators and say, "I don't agree with this." Or my organization, which is representing Black, brown, 70% Black, brown, Muslim, immigrant marginalized workforce of drivers. I get pulled aside and told, "How dare I call a senator and voice the concerns of my constituents?" So even when you do try to speak up in this city and in this state, it's like, "Oh, how dare you? You're supposed to grovel to me."

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: Or what they do is they'll try to offer you compensation, offer you positions, so you can align yourself with an organization that's sponsoring a bill or things of that nature to see if you are corruptible.

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: And so it's really going to take a massive movement. And that's what I'm learning. We're still excluded. When we do try to stand up, we won't be bullied. We won't be corrupted. There's pushback, and not in a good way, when we do try to speak for our own people, when we try to speak for ourselves and fight for ourselves, like "How dare you?" You're treated as a token even to this day. So there are people like myself that aren't afraid to make [inaudible] to a senator, that aren't afraid to call senators out, that when I feel, and my group feels aren't doing the right thing for people of color. And it's like, "Oh, you can't do that." That's what you're told behind closed doors. "Oh no, no, no. It's a privilege to be in the presence of these people."

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: And we pay taxes. I have to pay money to my town. I have to pay money to this city for business certificates, parking fees, you have to pay excise tax, if you're a property owner, you have to pay property taxes. And all of that goes into the into the coffers to pay these politicians and to pay our civil servants as well. And so to respond to what you said, Brother Larry, well, why are we paying a tax? If we're expected to do everything's for ourselves, what are these taxes for? Give me my taxes that I pay you. Give me my fees that I'm giving to the city, since we're supposed to do everything ourselves. So we're getting doubly messed over because we're paying, and we're not getting services like others are.

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: You know, I agree with you, Beth. Well I write my people all the time, my senators, my reps. I write them all the time.

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: They won't even call you back. Or they call you, "Oh you're not a city resident." "Yeah but I have a business here though. I might not live in Boston, but I live right next door."

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: [crosstalk] elected people. And we don't get back to them, and we don't talk to them. And like I said, people need to understand the connection between A to B to elected. [crosstalk] like the other communities to. That's what we need to learn, that that actually [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Pat
nodes.words: Politically the connection, and the relationship between the constituents, and the elected person, whoever that is. You need to continue that relationship after the election day is over. You've got to talk to them. You've got to force them to do things, and understand that that works. It works in all the other communities and cultures, but we don't do that. We get them in... If we get them in there and then we leave them all alone. We can't do that.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: Well this actually is kind of, letting it go, because what this was supposed to be, this next part was supposed to be you guys talking about things that the other one is saying that you resonate with. And basically you guys are doing that right now. So go for it Brother Lo, go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: I have to say, because the Sister mentioned something that is so important to me. And I don't think you actually know this. And this is in reference to taxes. I want you to know that the state takes them $647 million in taxes for procurement dollars, which means services rendered to the city $664 million. [inaudible] One year gave less than a half a percent to Black people, less than half a percent. And look at this now. That was just one year. He's been mayor for almost seven, eight years, and I guarantee you not one time through those seven years, did we come to even close to one percent of the money procurement dollars. And it didn't go to white women, it didn't go to Asia, it didn't go to Latino, it went strictly to white males in the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: Brother Larry, I concur with that. I was on a webinar with the city because BECMA and Amplify, and LatinX is suing the city. I spoke with Tito about that. And he explained, "Oh, well, we're doing a feasibility study." And then when the study came out, and then I went to that webinar and I asked the people from the city multiple times, I said, "And what percentage of these contracts?"

nodes.speaker: Beth
nodes.words: Because what I noticed, I was walking down Humble Ave, and there's a condo development. The old multifamily was torn down. They put six condos up there and it was a picture of a white family. And it said minority owned business. I said, the white pastor owned 51% of this company, they would not say when they said the percentage went to minorities, how many of those companies were white women? Because the men put the businesses 51% in the wife's name because white women are considered a minority. And that's all they're saying, it's an MBE. And so they wouldn't say, I said, "No I want it broken down by sex. And I want it broken down by ethnicity, by demographic." They would not say, and by them not saying anything, they said a lot, Brother Larry.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: I just want to ask you guys. This conversation is very good. Douglas I think, had something to say and I want to try to get him in there. And if everybody can, I know people like to sort of give people reaction to what they're saying, but if everybody mutes while someone's talking, so what they're saying can get out. People are saying, "Yep, that's right. Or whatever." When you guys respond it's kind of sometimes steps on the audio a little bit. So if you guys can... This is primarily interested in the audio and not the video. This is a good time for me to jump in and just say that the project that we're working on here is a project where they're basically looking at all these voices from the communities of this place.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: They call it Local Voices Network. And like I said, people from Dunk the Vote in the Urban Studies and Planning at MIT, Ron Bell from Dunk the Vote and other community groups like, [inaudible] center, and a few other places we wanted to use this as a way to... We thought we were going to be able to focus... Well we still are trying to help focus some of the issues in the current campaign. But also how this tool can be used by congregating these voices and using data analytics, and machine learning, and stuff. We can come up with patterns and maybe see some different things that people might not have considered in other communities, maybe compared to other communities.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: We realize how much we're all the same in certain ways and things like that. But we were trying to get this you see if we can make ways to use the technology because I'm with you when you say... I mean, when they talked about doing this, I said, "Okay, well, what we ask asking questions and all we're doing is talking."

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: And so the next part for a lot of us is how do we use this to get better at communicating with each other about the issues and things that we need to work on and our society and our communities, and that's what it's supposed to be for. So if there's any other... Now it's supposed to be about 90 minutes, basically just a little over an hour. I mean, they say 90 minutes is max. Now did anybody... I think Doug had something to say I think. Did you get [crosstalk]-

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: Well, you know what you're saying is a little like we've got to beat the drum, but it's in a new way now. So we have to [inaudible] online group, or some way that people have concerns or issues that we can come behind each other and sort of put into the forefront and use our resources. It's all about networking. You never know who knows what, and has what experiences or what. The power comes in numbers. So you just want to reach out to people that's supposed to be pulling to make an effort towards our cause, or their cause, and get going in the right direction.

nodes.speaker: Douglas
nodes.words: But it was the same thing that is getting us to the point that we are today, coming together as a people, coming together as a community, and putting in force. But it all starts with the conversation, Mike. So I appreciate you bringing us together for this.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: All right. Yeah. I appreciate you guys participating. And I wanted to basically try to just ask about... So we've done surveys, anybody have anything else they want to add about the experiences people talk about? Are there any sort of things that you can see that are common to all these issues and things that people are bringing up?

nodes.speaker: Brother Lo
nodes.words: I just want to say that I'm sure that all of us have experienced this. Live in your house, headed for your job and you can't go in no direction, and I don't care what direction you going in without running into white males in your community, doing work on construction, whether it be the streets or the builders or whatever. But I think until we really put fire on City Hall to get what it is we think we deserve. Now they're not giving us nothing. This is what we deserve. We've had the highest rate of unemployment in Roxbury, Dorchester, and Mattapan. And that's been over the last 20 years. But I'm a believer of this, if you let me come in your house, put my feet up on your desk, reach in your refrigerator, and eat your food, and you don't stop me, that's your problem.

nodes.speaker: Mike
nodes.words: All right. So we have to... I've got just one... Let me see, Yeah. Everybody's not on. It looks like everybody is on a computer now. Are you on a computer, Doug? Doug?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My name is Fran Smith. I go Francesca. I live in Dorchester. I'm a community organizer. I got involved in this project through Dunk the Vote, and Ron Bell. I want to welcome you. I'm so glad that you came. All of you have been on Zoom before, so I don't have to go over any Zoom rules I'm sure, right? But we invited you to this gathering by asking you to think about the future of Boston and your place in it. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions, and engage in a conversation with each other. Thanks for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak, and be listened to, knowing that it will matter.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We are recording this conversation, and it is already recording, to make it easier for us facilitators, so that we don't forget that and lose the conversation. I'm going to read, for the purposes of this conversation we're trying to create a new space across the city to do some constructive listening across differences and divides. To this end, we're inviting you to have a different kind of conversation and the recordings will be stored, and you will have access to your recording. And you'll have access to all the other recordings. Cortico, and Live Local Voices Network, whose mission it is to foster conversations in communities, will store them.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I have to read an official statement to you, and then if you agree to be taped, just say I agree. So the statement is as a participant, and I just dropped it in the chat too. As a participant in this conversation you're providing consent to Real Talk Fr Change to use and retain a recording, in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities, and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations, in keeping with that mission.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: Yeah. I agree. And I have a question. Will these be used in a public area, let's say in TV ads and things like that?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I don't know about the TV ads, because I don't think we have a budget for something like that. But for example, Ron Bell, who's one of the project people, he does a radio show on Friday mornings. And he's played excerpts of the conversations. And I think WGBH did something on the radio, because somebody told me they heard my voice on the radio. And then somebody else said, "Oh my gosh. I was on the radio and I heard my voice." Someone that was part of the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And then you and all the other participants will have access to it. And they're also working on a... Something to put on the website. So say I'm a housing advocate, and I'm going to go to a public hearing on new development in Dorchester. I could go to this dashboard, that was the word, and click on it, and so far for example, 40% of the people that have done these conversations, housing has been an issue that has come up. So they have a team called Sense Making that's part of the project. And they're making sense of these conversations.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I talk about it as an organizer who's a 20th century old school organizer. It's a fusion of the 20th century kitchen conversations, stoop conversation that you'd have with your neighbors, and compadres, and allies who are working on different issues, but it's really powerful, because with the click of a link you can bring the 400 voices into the room with you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So that's what got me really excited about being a part of this. Especially since I used to do organizing around equity and excellence in the Boston Public Schools. And I literally would talk to lots and lots of parents who couldn't go and testify at the school committee hearing. But like you said, Edwin, how powerful it would be to have this tool in your community. So that as you mobilize and organize, you're building community. You're building power. And you're creating allies where they might not even know they exist.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So anyway, clearly I'm very excited about it. Lisa, I'm glad you're here. I want to make sure you understand we're being recorded, and that you heard the fact that this conversation is going to be recorded and stored. You'll have access to it, and so will others. I need you to unmute and say that you agree. And welcome. And our video will not be shown. So feel free to come off the video if you want. And if you want to use a different name when we do check-ins. Lisa, can you unmute yourself and say you agree or drop it in the chat? All right. Well, I don't know what's going on with you, Lisa, but-

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: So could you explain what your role is? Are you a paid facilitator? A consultant? An organizer who is using a different tool? What is your role?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm an organizer that's using a different tool. Juan reached out to me in July, and asked me if I wanted to be a facilitator for this project. And then as we get more into it, we realized that the facilitators needed some support, so then they asked me if I would be a lead trainer, and a supporter.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Oh thank you, Lisa. Welcome. So that's my role. And Edwin, did I meet you a long time ago when we did a conference in 2016 with National Race and Equity Initiative? Were you doing work in Four Corners, ever in Boston? Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: I did work there a little bit. I did work with Mimi Ramos in Dorchester, but I think I met you through the Question 2 campaign to stop the expansion of charter schools.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Oh yeah, probably that too. Yup. And I also was doing some work up in [inaudible]. But anyway, enough about me. My role is to get you all talking with each other. So glad you're here. Now, before we jump into it, I have a list of agreements. I'm going to drop them in the chat and go over them quickly.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: Okay, conversation agreement. Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Stay curious. Ask honest questions. Pause, take time to reflect. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications and put your phone on silent. If you need to take a moment, take a break, let the facilitators know in the chat. Is everyone on board with these guidelines? I am.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: All right, great. Thank you all so much, I see the nods of the heads. Okay, so now, the way we're going to proceed is almost like a circle. Jose will go first, Edwin, Ana, and then Lisa. I want people to do a quick round of check-ins, and we're complicated individuals and I'd love you to bring your full self into this conversation, so we like to do PIES. So you say your name, what section of the city you live or work in, and if you're a citywide person then say that. And then PIES represents physical, intellectual, emotional, and spiritual aspects of ourselves. So you can pick one or two and check in, it goes something like this.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Francesca, also know as Fran, I live in Fields Corner. I'm feeling really good physically, I made a decision to try and walk 7,000 miles. 7,000 miles, I wish. 7,000 steps a day. And I have almost reached it, but that's my new goal, and I've been doing between 3,000 and 6,500 steps since Monday, so I'm feeling good. And with that, I'm all in. So I would like Jose to unmute and introduce yourself and use one of the P, I, E, or S to check in and say where you're phoning from, or what part of Boston you're affiliated. Thanks.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: Yeah, thank you. There is always something to learn and this is new for me, but here we go. My name is Jose Palma, I actually live in Lynn, but I have been asked to help facilitate a conversation in Spanish with [inaudible] recipients from the city of Boston. I'm feeling great, I think I'm committed to do some exercise starting as soon as possible, and at least for right now, I think I'm going in the right direction. I'm here to learn and hear and 100% in it. Thanks.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: Hi everyone, I'm Edwin. I don't live in Boston. Although my connections with Boston have been through work in the past, in Boston, through Massachusetts Jobs with Justice and other groups. Currently working closely with the TPS Committee. Sometimes for the folks at [inaudible] economy, et cetera. But I'm curious about this process and this tool because I think that we need to be doing things differently in terms of organizing. I think all the stuff that we have learned is not working, I think that we need to find new tools and I would like to see [inaudible] for today to do something similar where I live and where we have very much similar problems, probably worse, in some aspects, than Boston.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: I'm currently in a wheelchair, my goals are very simple. To try to strengthen my body so I can hopefully someday walk again. And I just take it little by little, one day at a time.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: Well my name is Ana Maria, my story is a bit different. I just got to the Boston area a month ago, I lived in Bogota, Columbia, where I'm from, for most of my life. And I'm a student at MIT. I'm a research assistant for this project. We started a week ago. So I'm also here to see how the conversations go, what the questions are, get to know you guys. I'm very happy to get to see you virtually and hear what you have to say about Boston.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: I actually live on the other side of the river, I live in Cambridge. But I try to cross the river as much as I can. It's just much more exciting to be in the city, even, to be here. Physically, I'm feeling a bit tired. Grad school is a lot. Not a lot of sleeping going on, but I'm pretty tired, but it is Saturday, so I'm feeling good. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Ana Maria, now Lisa, can you unmute and say your name, where you're in and do a PIE check in? What part of the city you're calling from?

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Lisa [inaudible], I live in Dorchester, but I advocate throughout the city, greater city limits. Checking in, let's see, I feel great. One of my goals is to engage and to learn self care. I'm no good to the community that I serve if I'm not up and running healthy, so self care has been going well for me. As you can see, I'm at my regular job. I was called in as a facilitator to be a part of the real talk, and I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you all so much. Perfect. Okay, so now that we know who's here, let's get into the meat of the conversation. I would like you to just think for a minute about your relationship to the city of Boston, and I would like you to formulate a question about what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future. Can you guys mute yourself? There's some background noise when you're not speaking. Just because this is being recorded and I want to make sure that the voices are clear.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, thanks. And just take another minute or so and formulate a question. Boston, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Does everybody have their question already? Or do you need another few minutes? Few seconds? Once you have your question, I want you to think about an experience in your life that brought you to this question. Lisa, we'll reverse. We'll have Lisa, Ana Maria, Edwin, and then Jose. And what I'd like you to do is to share your question, but also, while you're sharing your question, share the story behind the question. What got you to ask that question? Remember, we want to hear from your own personal lived experiences. So Lisa, whenever you're ready you can unmute. Share your question first, please, and then tell us what got you to that experience. I mean, what experience has lead you to that question? Whenever you're ready.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Okay, my question is, "Is Boston ready for a new Boston?" As far as the change. And what let me to that question is because I've been in the city, I've advocated for so many years, and I think that there needs to be a change, the dynamics and the narratives need to change. Am I ready to be a part of that change? Absolutely, and that's why I do what I do.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Sure. As far as I'm across the board, whether it's housing, public safety, homelessness, substance abuse, domestic violence, trauma, all of the above.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: So my question for Boston is, "How is Boston going to provide housing?" Not just any housing, affordable housing. But also, dignified housing. Also, happy housing. A place where you can go home to the people of Boston who don't have access to it. Or who have to struggle and pay crazy rents that occupy even more than half their wages sometimes. How is Boston going to do that and how will that look in the future?

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: The reason I'm asking this question is, well, I come from a city that has a lot of complicated problems as well. It's a much bigger city than Boston, but it has similar problems. And one of our biggest issues is housing. Especially because we understand housing and affordable housing, and I'm going to say what people believe should be housing for poor folks is just a place where they can live, even if that's a tiny box. Even if there's no joy in there, even if there's no access to parks, recreation, and socializing. And I've seen that in my city and it worries me for my city, but it also worries me for here now that I'm here. How are we thinking of what home means to people, and how is the city going to provide that for people?

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: I've been starting to study housing and the history of housing in Boston in some of my classes, and I admire the struggles and the fight, and advocacy that Bostonians have done. It's very interesting history and I'm happy to be here and to learn more about it.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: My turn? Again, I don't live in Boston, but I think this equally applies to any community, whether it's a high density of people who are African Americans, who are Latinos, who are Asian, who are people of color in general. And I can't help but to think that the same problems that, more or less, the same problems that people were dealing with 20 years ago in our community, people are still faced with today. And that's kind of the genesis of the question, and that is, "Is there space for someone like me or my community in that future Boston, that future [inaudible], in that future whatever." Is there space and can we live there and feel like you can fully participate and be whomever we want to be.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Want to share a little bit more about your own lived experiences in Boston area that led to that question? I mean, you did preface some of it in the beginning, but is there anything else you'd like to share about your own experiences? And how do you question whether there's space for you?

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: Where do you start? If you look at the jobs, look at the industries that are growing and someone like me, someone from my community, does not have access to a biotech industry. Financial services industry. In the way that other communities that have influence, that have privilege, can access those industries. You go down the road [inaudible]. The charter industry's still around, they're still pushing in a ways to fight[inaudible] from public education. And I want to be clear, they're talking about the charter industry, and not charter schools. Because I think some of the charter schools do a decent job. But overall, the charter industry is trying to make a lot of money from public schools. Funding.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: Just who we are, a different immigrant experience, I'm a Latino immigrant from El Salvador, lived here for half of my life. And there's still a lot of places where we're not fully accepted. Whether it's the language, whether it's the way you look, whether your culture, et cetera, et cetera. We're confronted daily with microaggressions. I see it today, I seen it 20 years ago in East Boston. So to me, it's an existential question that I think we're responsible to provide and answer to. And I think just doing what we've always done is not going to cut it. We're going to have to try to find different tools to do it, and also actually try to learn more about each other. And try to truly an intention to work with each other.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you, Edwin, so much. I so appreciate you sharing. Jose, you ready? Your question and then the story behind it, you got to unmute.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: Yeah, my question is unrelated to what Boston is doing and planning to do to avoid the low income community in Boston, including the undocumented population are not priced out and forced to move out from the city. Housing, jobs opportunity, for low income and for undocumented people who have built families in Boston, and sometimes parents may be undocumented, but kids are U.S. citizens. And the story behind it is we're seeing, and I have seen, I don't live in Boston, but I work very closely with the Boston community throughout my professional job and also through my organizing with the temporary protective status community, is that in the last decade, people have been priced out and forced to move out even when they call Boston home and have been living in the Boston area for years. But now, jobs are not paying enough to pay the rents and the price to live in Boston. Because rent is one thing, but then there are so many other things that come to the game that eventually, salaries are not enough.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: Is Boston doing something to avoid displacing people who love Boston and have been dedicating their life to improve Boston, but now that the Boston is improved, are priced out and forced to move out again. That's the question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I really appreciate sharing your stories. Now that you've had a chance to hear each other's questions, I'd like you to take a minute and just reflect on each of the questions and the experiences that were just shared in our group. And find someone whose question and/or experiences really resonates with your own life that you felt some connection to. And then I want you to speak to that person and tell them why their question or experience really resonated with you, and maybe share a story from your own life that connects with their experience. And whenever you're ready, just unmute yourself and share.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: Okay, well I can start. So I very much appreciated listening to all of you, of course. But I very much enjoyed listening to Jose and just as a Latino person as well, I have a lot of friends who live in not only Boston, but other cities in the U.S., including other countries, undocumented. It's so difficult to see how people are a part of these cities and a part of our communities and so much that happens in the city happens because of undocumented people. We're working, we're putting in the hours, we're creating families, creating culture, creating value. And how bad the city treats them back. And I know that I'm a privileged Latino because I have a Visa here, so it makes me think of our privileges, it makes me think of how the city can actually give back to the people who have created it, and not the country, which is pricing them out. As we've seen time and time again. So yeah, thank you, and thank all of you for your questions.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Lisa, Edwin, Jose? Anything that anyone said resonated with you? Similar experiences, but not anything that you experienced and have questions about.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: I'm in between work. But I think everyone on the panel here, I'm just so impressed and honored to be here. I guess we all, meaning everyone here, we have our tangible issues that can be solved, and then the ultimate outcome is to make them sustainable. Housing is probably the number one priority, and adversity in every culture. Just having the tangible solution, I think Edwin spoke about employment, so that's stating these tangible things that are well needed, as well very much neglected in our city and that's part of the change that me, myself, I talk about as far as being a question and as far as my own life experiences. So it's just the tangible and sustaining them.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: Obviously, everything has been said [inaudible] for me. That's the reason why we're here. But what strikes me is that we did not name outright the question of race. And how this still is a very... It's real, it's been magnified by the last presidential administration. It's probably been exacerbated, it's pushing us even more to that. There's still seven million people who think that they're superior than maybe some of us that are here. Aspects of life. And that is something deep. Not only to think about, to deal with, but to better confront head on.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: Because when you think about housing, jobs, medication, the environment, all the tools that we need to live a decent life are and have been history, but now, I would say, in some ways, even more deepened by the environment, by the [inaudible] racial aspect of the way that society tries to function, or not. And I think it's something, things happen in history, you have ups and downs that are patterns et cetera, but the truth if the matter is that if the pandemic exposed something, it's that these things is still very much here. They're very much creating barriers for folks that look like all of us here.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: I wanted to name that. As something that, and that's why I said earlier that to me it's a very existential question. It's not just me, it's my children, your friends, your brothers, your sisters, et cetera. There is an effort to, again, keep things in a way that some people are able to succeed and some others are not able to access tools they need to succeed in life because of the systemic issue.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: No, I think it's similar to what Lisa was saying. One way or the other, we are connected and I think the issues that we have identify for sure resonate with me, the ones that were mentioned by Lisa and Edwin. And I think it does raise another question, is what is the city doing to unify the city as communities. Sometimes what is happening is Boston is not known in Dorchester or some other areas of Boston. Is the city interested in or doing something to everyone to think as one city and not those divisions that exist? I think it will be in the best for the city and the people that live in the city to be all unified and look forward together.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. I think that we touched on this but I'm just going to ask this question before we begin to wrap up. And I think Edwin actually, both Edwin and Jose already got to it, but what are you hearing in people's experiences? And Edwin recaptured that was he was hearing was the racism is still one of the major issues. So anything else that people are hearing in other's, in each of your experiences? Just feel free to unmute and share.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: I think what I mentioned at the end, the disconnection with the different neighborhood and the city for sure is something. I think it's also many communities, or at least the community I work closely with feels that they are not valuing the city. The leadership in Boston are more interested in bringing big companies and giving big house to big companies, but not willing to work hard to make sure the low income communities in the city of Boston are able to continue living in the neighborhoods where the kids have been born and growing up.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: One thing Edwin said that I think is very valuable is sometimes we are made to believe that advocacy and talking, representing our communities, is something that is very locally based. But I think what we're identifying here is that there are a lot of things that unify us. We have similar problems, depending on where we are and our background, there may be some differences, but I like the idea of thinking as a city. I think that's a very powerful idea. And I think it can unite a lot of people who are advocating and I'm sure that all of you are community leaders, have done community advocacy before.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: Sometimes you feel you're alone in the fight, and it gets tiring and it gets frustrating. But if people were to come together, and know that other people in the city, maybe in other neighborhoods, maybe it's not even next to your neighborhood, but it's the same fight, same struggle. And one issue that kind of relates to every issue, that is racism in the city and how it manifests in such different ways. So I think that's a very powerful idea.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: I just wanted to bring to the table the concept of filling the gaps. And by that, in my mind, as an organizer, I think about the generational gap. There are some of us that are veterans of some things, but it's no good that it stays in your head. How do you share some of the things that you learned along the way with people that are just starting to even begin to think about those questions.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: And vice versa, there's a ton of stuff that they're bringing to the table that we should be paying attention to. There's also this, although we're thinking about Boston, but there's something to be said about the way, systemically, these things play out. And if you even go deeper, it's usually the same politicians or the same characters that are funding something that is going to hurt us individually or as a community. But yet, we're only thinking Boston, I'm thinking about everywhere. But what if we thought about a regional approach. But that's what I mean by bridges and filling in the gaps. How do we claim those bridges so that we know what's happening in Dorchester. And vice versa, Dorchester's supposed to know what's happening in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: The developers are trying to build luxury condos in Dorchester. Some of them are the same developers that are trying to do the same thing here. Those developers are the same ones that totally transformed South Boston. And then some, more or less. And their lobbies and their lawyer firms, blah, blah, blah. So there's that, but there's also the history. We yet have not learned enough about each other's histories. I confess, lately I've been learning a lot about Afro-descendants in my own country. Because the education in my country did not teach me that in a formal way. There were laws created to deny the system of Afro-descendants. But now there are groups that are trying to assert their identity, their existence, their history, their rights, et cetera.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: And for us to ask ourselves, we are, we have some of that blood. But how does that relate to the history of Afro-descendants here in the U.S.? Here in our little, Dorchester Boston, Boston, et cetera. But our experiences, what can we learn from those experiences? And then take a look at the big picture and find. It's another to teach about each other, but there's, for instance, there's a lot of rich history around fighting for, ending slavery, civil rights, et cetera, et cetera. That we can learn a lot about. And that's what I mean by the bridges and the gaps. Could that be constructed in that new Boston, especially amongst ourselves?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks, Edwin. And that is one of the beauties of, and I'm not supposed to engage, so I'm just going to say this only thing. As somebody that's been in the trenches in the city for over four decades. I used to call myself an anti-racist activist until I became a parent, and then I had to think about, what am I working for? So I call myself a racial justice advocate.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: This tool, this Live Voices Network, allows us to begin to build community across difference through this strategy. And Live Voices Network, Edwin, you might want to go to their website, and I can send it to you, because they did a training for us, and they have a number of really interesting projects across the nation. And I'm part of SURJ, Showing Up for Racial Justice, which is a national network of white folks that are committed to anti-racist racial justice organizing, and I think that this will be a really powerful tool for us.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: But anyway, my bad, they're going to slap me upside my head, I am a social person and I love listening and talking with folks so I just wanted to give everybody a chance to make a closing comment before we sign off and I really want to appreciate the time that you took to be here. I'm excited that Jose and Edwin might be joining us to do some facilitation. I just rocked the demographic data. I don't know if you know that we give people a gift card if you'd like it, and once you fill out this Google form, which you can click on now and I can also email it to you if you're on your phone or whatever.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: But that way, we will also be able to upload your email and once these conversations are all uploaded, you'll get notified and then you can access them. So now that I've babbled on for way longer, is there any closing thoughts or comments? Before we sign off.

nodes.speaker: Jose
nodes.words: Let me just thank you, Fran, for the facilitation and the opportunity. It's nice to hear from others about these specific issues and I am really looking forward to see the material. I think it would be helpful as a community organizer, as a member of the community, it would be nice to see the different issues that people are identifying, and I'm really looking forward to more conversations on how to identify the issues, and then how to work together to find solution. Which is, I think, what we need anyway, at the end of the day.

nodes.speaker: Ana
nodes.words: Yeah, I just want to thank everyone for being here and for being the people you are to your families and to your communities and to your city. I'm super excited to be a part of this process as well, and to learn and to contribute in some way to the city for the time that I'm here. Because I do believe that even if you're going to be in a community for just a couple of years, you should try to contribute and give your best to the people around you. So thank you.

nodes.speaker: Edwin
nodes.words: I guess I can go. I appreciate the invitation to learn about the project. It piqued my curiosity. I think it's always useful and helpful when you're bouncing ideas off of each other. Especially if you don't know each other that well. But also, to continue reflecting on the [inaudible] questions and how to deal with them in a way that speaking to each one of us, but also to the people that are around us. And to me, that's how we build community, that's how we build with each other. And that is something useful. Especially in this environment. I feel like there's so much toxicity around any discourse of this nature. Everything is so polarized. But I'm glad there's still spaces where you can safely have this conversations with each other.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thanks, Edwin. And it's really nice to connect with you again after so many years. I'm glad to see you. Lisa, I don't know if you want to add anything? Please unmute yourself, I'd love to hear your closing comments. And then I'd also love for you all to, I'll send you the PSA, and I'll send you the calendar link, so if you do know folks in Boston, you can encourage them to attend. Also, we can do in person events if that would be helpful, too. And we can do it around people's schedule. Okay so yeah, Lisa, anything you want to say?

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Sorry about that. In closing, I'm once again grateful, thankful, meeting new folks and broadening the network. It's always great to see people on the same road and together we can conquer if we show up in numbers. It's just like I said earlier, each and every diverse background has the same adversities that we're facing. But I'm just so glad to be amongst so many that are just aiming, because it doesn't discriminate. We're all in this together. I really appreciate each and every one of you. I definitely would like to be put on the email, I can put my email in the chat, and I'm looking forward to great, great work. This great opportunity will bring such much needed great work collaboratively. And we can do this together.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah, if folks want to drop their, and then copy the chat before we sign off, if you want to drop your contact information into the chat so that you can contact each other directly, please do that. Expect an email in three to five days around the gift card and you can access.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: ... Conversations with people, about the future of Boston. Thank you so much for agreeing to be part of this conversation. My name is Fran, and I'll be facilitating a conversation with you. There's about four parts to the conversation. The first part, is to explain the purpose. We're trying to create a new space in Boston to have conversations about the future of Boston, so that we can hold our elected officials...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: ... Accountable. And to build community around the city, and for people to see what other people think about in different parts of the city. Different ethnic racial groups, different ages. So this is going to be recorded. And then it gets uploaded, and there will be a public dashboard where, for example, you all know, and this is how I was walking, and your mother said, "Fran, are you still doing stuff with schools?" I was like, "No, but I'm doing this." When we go to a school committee meeting, for example, and we want to say, "People in the community care about this." We can click on a link, and anything that was recorded about schools, we can play to them.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And our goal, as members of Real Talk For Real Change, is to help use our voices, to inform the next mayoral election. As well as, once the election happens in November, holding the elected accountable, for what we, residents who are often not included in the dialogue, really care about stuff. So I have to read this statement, and then if you agree, I already started the recording. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network. That's the nonprofit that was set up to hold the technology, and who created the technology. Whose mission is to foster conversations in communities, and in the media, that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations, in keeping with that mission. If you understand and you agree, please say, I agree.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Great. Any questions so far? Okay. Now we're going to do a quick introduction and a centering activity. We know that as human beings we're really complex. But for the next 45 minutes or so, I'd really like you to center, and bring your full selves into the conversation. I'd like you to state your name, where you live in the city of Boston, and then check-in with PIES. PIES represents, physical, intellectual, emotional, and spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: For example. I'll model. I'm Fran. I go by Francesca now that I've gone to Italy, and I love that name. I live in Dorchester, around the corner from this house. And I'm checking in spiritually. I think I need to go back to church, because I'm really struggling spiritually. And I've been away from a church community for a while. And since I know you through church, as well as other ways, I'm thinking it might be good to go back to church. With that, I'm all in. We going to have Brenda go first, then we'll have Lisa go. [Bakry].

nodes.speaker: Sandra
nodes.words: Well Fran, can I... This is really not a good time. I'm just trying to do my hair. I didn't know anything about it. Can we check in at another time? I just can't.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: All right. We're going to do the conversation with the three of us. It's too hard for her to be distant. All right, Brenda, your name?

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: My name is Brenda Thomas. I live at 16 Paisley Park. I know Fran from my [inaudible]. I go to Charles Street Church. And I'm a mother of four, and grandmother of six.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No. Say something a little more. Like I said, "I'm spiritually. I am in need of a home church. And so I'm suffering a little."

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: Spiritually we are all suffering with the home church, because we're doing the Zoom online. But now I felt a little better, because church has opened up to the parking lot. So we can actually go, and see someone in person, actually touch a person, and say, "Hi, how are you?" See a smiling face. So I'm fine.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: I'm Lisa Thomas-Parker. I live in Dorchester, and I'm checking in emotionally, because everyone around this time are dealing with emotional struggles.

nodes.speaker: Barry
nodes.words: Okay. Physically. I have a job now. So that's where I currently go walk up and down and see a friend, people. That's it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Great. Thanks. So now that we know who's in the room, I would like, to actually get to the purpose of the conversation. So I want you to think about a question, about the future of Boston and your place in it. Ms. Brenda.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. So I want you to think about... I want you to formulate a question. And I want you to, which is, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? Think for a minute, and then formulate a question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Wait one second. And then I want to, before you get into telling us your question, I want you to also think about, what experience in your life got you to that question? I want you to formulate a question, and then tell a story about why you chose that question. Go ahead, Ms. Brenda.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: Well, my question is about the young people that finishing school and colleges and then trying to buy a house, and can't buy a house because the rent is so expensive over there. My question too is, this is my granddaughter. She's getting married soon. She has a down payment for the house, but she can't afford the house, because the price of houses are so expensive. Even though you have a down payment, it will make a dent into nothing, because the house is just ridiculously out of control.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: What are they're going to do for these young people that are coming out of the college, and working, and trying to buy a house, and can't afford to buy a house.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: My question is, what are we going to do about who qualifies for certain things in Massachusetts? You can work somewhere, and they say you don't qualify for subsidized living. Or you don't qualify for any government assistance, because you're working, and you're making bare minimum. So if you don't qualify for those things, how will you be able to afford a house, or to afford rent? So that's my question.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: My personal experience is, I am 42 years old, and I still live with my parents because I can't afford rent. Because if I paid rent, I would only pay rent, and nothing else would be over my head. I wouldn't be able to afford food, or anything else.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Why is it so high to rent or buy [crosstalk] in Boston? Why is that your concern at this point? What experiences have you had with housing in Boston that would have you arrive at that?

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: I have one experience about housing. I have an experience about housing, and I guess the way they operate when it comes to inspection and the amount of days you would give a landlord to fix a problem. And then that problem not be fixed within that time that you give them, and you still turn around and give them the same amount of time. It continues. Versus, giving them less time, than you did the previous time.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Thanks. All right. Now that you have shared your questions, I want you to find someone whose question, or experiences resonates with your own life. And look at that person, and explain why their question resonated with you.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: I think Brenda's question resonates with me, because it's on housing, and how do we afford housing and homes, and purchasing as young adults or young people that want to possibly have something of your own, for your own kids, but you can't, because you don't get enough. The price of living is too expensive, but you barely make the price of living and the government saying, you make enough.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: And also, Lisa's question about when the inspection or service gives you time to fix, they give you two weeks, and if you come in two weeks, and it's not fixed, they give you another two weeks. Why can't they give them a fine, or something, or have something taken away from them? Because you give me two weeks to finish my homework, or you gave me a night to finish my homework, and if you're not finished, you give me another. Then if I'm not finished, then I get an F. So why are they keeping on just giving them a leeway, leeway. If your problem's not fixed the first time, you give them a second time. After the second time, they shouldn't get a third time. It's ridiculous.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: So you get nothing accomplished. And when Section 8 comes, you rent the place. Another thing about that too, also the landlord there. Because you rent the place, and the place is nice, and they come in and they take pictures, and the place is fine. And then when they get ready to leave, they tear up your place. When you have all these picture to show, this is how my property was when they get it. And then now they leave, and sometimes you don't get paid for the damages that they caused to their places. So it's also a two way street. Awesome.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: Telecom. I have a question for what she met up. She might have... I might get that to her. Because she say that she wanted to open a daycare, but she can't the same apartment [crosstalk] to buy the house. Then... I think we should just smack it up.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: There's lots of problem but no solution to this problem. They just keep on going on and on and over and over. Now somebody has to come up with some plan or something to support us to get us some kind of progress or some kind of something, because nothing's working out.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Your dad had to leave, so he wasn't able to join us. But when I ran into your mom on the street walking the other day, his question, he said, "Will there be a place in the city of Boston in the future for my grandkids?" So I just was throwing that in there. I don't know if you think about that.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Yeah. Because if I can't afford a house or have a house, then that means my future, my child won't be able to say, "Well, [crosstalk] I can possibly have it this or have something of my own brand." Other generations are able to pass down. They can pass down a tide. They can pass down a D. They can pass down some money that is saved as a big chunk where we don't get to have that opportunity to put forth that or to say because it's not available.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So we're in the middle of this conversation would love to ask you to join in. First, my name's Fran. I've known the family forever. I live around the corner. We're trying to ensure that voices of residents get listened to around the new mayoral election. And so we're having these conversations and we're recording them and we're having small conversations with different people all over the city. We're recording them and then they get saved. And then we create a dashboard where you can click on a link and see housing, education, prison, police, and see how many people formed a question around those different topics. So we would like you to join us by saying that you agreed to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And if you could say your name and where you live and tell us how you're doing either physically, intellectually, spiritually, or emotionally.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Thanks. And so what we've done all of this away quickly moving forward to catch you up. So the goal of this conversation is really to ask you to form a question about the future of Boston and your place in it. And also tell us a story about why you formulated that question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And Ms. Brenda, you want to just tell you, will you each just state your questions again so that, because the next part of it is having resonance with what other people said. So, Ms. Brenda,

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: My question is about the young people that's finishing college, have the job and working and can't afford to buy a house. Like for instance, my granddaughter Angelie. Because the price of houses are so expensive. They might have a down payment, but I don't make a dent into nothing when they selling a little building for a million dollars. So how can a poor person pay for a million dollars?

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: The building [crosstalk] a million dollars. She had her money, but she can't buy nothing with it. So what the point of having that money? Because you're not [crosstalk] going any place.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: My question was, how does a person who the government is making enough that they can't get any kind of assistance, afford a home for their self or their future generation or even right.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: What are they going to do about affordable housing in the city for families? I mean, I'm paraphrasing, but that's what I heard in your story. So now what is your question? And try not to be influenced by this.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: Oh, I'm not going to be influenced at all because I have a lot of issues. I used to live in Boston. I grew up here. I'm originally from the Virgin islands. I am a US citizen. I have to make that clear. Because sometimes when I really get into what is bothering me with Boston, you can hear my accent because when I get this, it comes out. Okay. So I try to keep it under wraps. But when I start talking about what I'm seeing happening in Boston, it's unbelievable. The rent...

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: My question is, well, I have a lot of questions. The first one I'm going to ask about is activities for the youth, especially like physical activities. I know we have parks and what have you, but why aren't there programs that are being run on a consistent basis where it's not just in the summertime, we have more than enough for the kids to do. Sports, get them involved in different sports and different activities where they can become physically active. Because if we're not noticing the games that you're sitting down playing are taking over.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: And so our children are becoming increasingly obese and they're having health issues because they're not getting enough physical activities. So why aren't there programs out there where parents can know about, learn, about to get their children more physically involved? Whether it's dance, it's gymnastics within the local confines of this area, the Dorchester area. I would like to see that for my daughter. So I'm wondering why we don't have enough of those because Lisa and I are always hunting for programs to put our kids in. So it becomes really tedious at times because we're trying to look out for their physical wellbeing as well as their mental and emotional wellbeing, because they're all linked. My second question. So the first question is why aren't there enough programs?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No. No. You're supposed to... I'm sorry. You're supposed to come up with [crosstalk] the question. And then what [crosstalk] made you come up with that question? Why did that question out of all the things that you talk about, what out of your own lived experiences led you to that question? I'm sorry. I was supposed to ask that first.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: I have a... She just made 13 year old. And when she lived in Ireland, because we only moved up here because of hurricane Irma. So when she was at home, she was in girl's guide, the girls brigade. She was in Scouts and swimming dance. But I had a schedule where she was constantly being active. It wasn't just about her academics. And I think the more exposure they get for them is better. So I came here and I'm thinking, "Okay, here should have a lot more to offer." I was wrong. It does not have a lot more to offer.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: So that bothered me. And then Lisa and I, we have kids. So we are always trying to transfer information to each other. And then I realized, oh, it's not me because I'm not familiar with the scene here now, it's a problem systemically. So then I was like, "Okay, something has to be done with this. This cannot be." And then leaving kids at home, the latchkey kids, kids just go home and watch TV. No. You know the hours their parents are working, you should have programs to accommodate those children. And they should not just be going home and watching TV or sitting there playing games all day, frying their little brains. And then you ask them a question and they can't answer you, because their brain is not getting any activity. So that's why I came up with that question.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Well, thank you so much. Now so everyone went around and did their one question until this story. And then we asked whether people had resonance or felt the connection between what anyone said. So I did want to give people a chance to see... Lorolie, Is that right?

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Yep. It resonates with me because Loralee is very close to the family and she has a teenage daughter like I do. And so we try to get the kids to do things. But it just seems like these activities are so much expensive. They could have discount rated for certain parents, for people that can't afford it. So our children can get the same benefits to all the same program that a white child basically would have the opportunity to do. And they don't.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: Yeah. Because I've seen them struggle and try to get places for them to go into the summertime, summer camp and this camp, or they can only get in for two sessions or one session. When someone said some of the program have four or five, six session. They need to make at least one session instead of a two weeks or one week. Make it a little longer. Maybe three weeks program that would be a little better on the parents. And they're so expensive also.

nodes.speaker: Brenda
nodes.words: Yes. [crosstalk]. I have to travel so far. So not only the program, you have to also spend money for gas. It's a go, pick them up, drop them off and pick them up. There has to be another way to do things.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Because for the summer I had the kids in gymnastics, karate and summer camp. We went to Randolph for karate. We went to Braintree for gymnastics. We're in Dorchester [crosstalk]. Even taking her to Weymouth for gymnastics. And those programs fill up so fast.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Andover for horseback riding. And she needed it for, because she was a kid that was in early intervention program. And that was the closest. It took us 45 minutes to get there just for her to ride like 30 minutes. I'll ride [crosstalk] the amount of time she was riding, that's 45 minutes there, 45 minutes back. And she was only writing 30 minutes. But as her parent, I knew she needed it, so I took her.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. So just so you know, because you know me, you don't... I'm not allowed to engage in conversation with you. So as soon as we're done with the recording, we can talk because I have some ideas. However, my role as facilitator, I'm asking you now to... What are you hearing in people's experiences was the other part. And folks had a chance to respond to that. So Loralee, what are you hearing in what people are saying? Anyone else can add.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: Okay. With regards to the housing, what I'm hearing is, no one can afford it. I've known this family since I've been here and I can honestly say, I consider them middle-class. But in the scheme of things in Massachusetts, just like we're paupers because everything is just ridiculous. Ridiculous when it comes to housing. And everyone's desire is to own a home. And when you're working your butt off, but you can't own a home, but you have to be paying rent. And sometimes you can't even afford the rent, that speaks volumes of the city. Because it makes you wonder who was in charge when these ridiculous decisions that are now being implemented? Who came up with them? Because how do we go back to making it someplace where people could live in and actually enjoy? Because you can't enjoy, because you're too busy trying to make money to pay your rent. So that's what I'm hearing.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: No, I said no. Not from what we already touched base on. So nothing from those things. Those things resonated in my mind.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So we're winding down and I want to thank you for coming and taking your time on a Sunday to engage in this conversation. Just before we sign out. Do you have any closing thoughts or anything else you'd like to have in our conversation? Library?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And you know what really stunk about that, which is why personally I hate referendum questions. I think there was only three or four cities in the state that had rent control. And everybody who lived in Massachusetts got to vote on it. And the real estate people went all out with advertisement. So yeah, since '94, the housing crisis is only gotten worse. So any other closing thoughts?

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Just thoughts about education and tuition when it comes to going to college. Also thoughts about why do... For instance, a METCO program get so many different learning experience that a Boston public school will never get? We should have the same kind of education and have the same kind of programs in a Boston public school.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: I like to piggyback on that because she's talking about this programs. I like to talk about the facilities. Why doesn't the school have cafeteria? When I was going to school, I went to the John Marshall. We had a cafe, we had a pool, we had facilities. I'm now watching my daughter in 2021, no cafeteria. She has to sit and eat in class. They have no gym. So they can only go outside when it's warm and ludicrous. And then [crosstalk] sorry. And then, like I said, this is Massachusetts. So I can't wrap my head around it because when I went to school here, I got the best. So now I'm trying to figure out I bring my daughter back, hindsight now. And I'm like, "What happened? You have no cafe." She told me she was eating in class. She was eating in her classroom, I thought she was joking.

nodes.speaker: Lorolie
nodes.words: They do not have a cafeteria at Lucy Stone. They do not have a gym at Lucy Stone. We had at John Marshall, we had a... What'd you call it? The astro room. The astro room you go in and you sit in the recliner chairs, and you look up and there's astrology surrounding. And you have to choose where the big dipper is and where this consulate is and that consulate it's all up in the ceiling. And you're just there in these chairs talking about the consulate. Hi, I'm trying to show them, "See the big dipper there. And the moon. When the moon goes this, the way it goes..." I'm trying to explain stuff to her, but she's like, "Mm-hmm (affirmative)." she's looking at me blank because she doesn't understand what I'm talking about. So I think I got so much more back then, where they didn't have more and now we have more, but she's getting less.

nodes.speaker: Lisa
nodes.words: Also the budget. We cry and we complain all the time, the school doesn't have a budget. But COVID hit, and there was a budget that came out of where. Because every kid had a laptop. Those same grants that might've donated at that moment, we could have been using a long time ago.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. I hate to be negative Nancy or Debbie Downer, but this is our reality. And that is why we are trying to bring more people into the conversation. I'm going to turn the recorder off.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Let me begin by saying, thank you all so much for coming. My name is Francesca, also known as Fran Smith. I'm participating with this project and Brother Ron brought me into it. I've known Ron [Bell], forever. And also,[Susan McDowell], from MIT, I actually know.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I started out attending one of these conversations. Thought it was a really cool fusion of 20th century, old-school community organizing and community building, with 21st century technology. I'm going to go over some of the... There's a script I'm going to use, and I'm going to stick to it because if you know me, I'm chatty.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My goal is to get you talking with each other, about the future of Boston. As you already know, this is being recorded. We invited you to this gathering because we wanted to hear what you think about the future of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on questions that you're going to come up with. The conversation is being recorded, and so I want to tell you why we're holding these conversations.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We really want to give people an opportunity to talk about, and listen to each other across differences. To this end, we're having a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing your own personal stories, bringing your full self into the conversation, not coming up with positions of trying to solve problems. What we're hoping to build is connections, and foster conversations, that will improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So as you know, this is being recorded, and I wanted to let you know that these conversations are being stored, in cyberspace, through LVN, which is a web-based platform, designed for accessing and exploring conversations, by the non-profit organization, Cortico. This system creates transcripts for each of these recorded conversations, and as you know, it's only our audio recording that will be uplifted, and that it highlights key words, and it has the ability to see what kind of patterns and issues are emerging from all the conversations. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with others who have participated in Real Talk for Change conversations, and members of our team.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Finally, I have to read this consent statement, and ask if you are willing to be recorded. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change, to use and obtain the recording, in accordance with our mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities, and in the media, that will improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations, in keeping with that mission.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: In addition, part of Real Talk for Change mission, is to present voices from the people of Boston, therefore, portions of your conversation will be public. So if you understand and agree to this, please unmic yourself and say out loud, "I agree."

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. And you're welcome to use a pseudonym when you speak, if you don't want people to know who you are. I doubt that will be an issue for this particular group of people, but feel free, when you introduce yourself, which is what we're going to do next... Actually, I just want to go over some, I call them ways of being guidelines, before I get into our check in. So I'm going to drop these in the chat, and then read them quickly. These are just a couple of things to keep in mind as we go through the conversation. And give me a second here, and I will read them aloud, once I drop them in the chat.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Fingers working. So, speak for yourself and out of your own personal experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, and allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Stay curious and ask questions. Ask honest questions. Pause and take time for reflection. Listen generally, and assume good intentions, while recognizing that our words have impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phone on silent. If you need to take a break, just let me know. Drop it in the chat.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Now, it seems like you all might know each other, so this will be very easy, but I'd like you to do a quick check in. Say your name, where in the city you live or are affiliated with, a particular part or neighborhood, and also, I want you to check in... We used PIES. Has anyone ever done PIES before? It stands for how you're doing either; physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually. So I'll model.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My name is Francesca, also known as Fran. I'm checking in from [inaudible] Corner, Dorchester, where I live, and I'm doing... I'm going to check in physically. I'm not doing as good as I was last week, because I'm trying to do my 7,000 steps, and I haven't been out there doing them, so I can tell my body is feeling a little stiff. Now that the sun's out, I'm going to try after this conversation, to get my 7,000 steps in. So with that, I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Any questions about the check in? And I'll drop that in the chat as well. And actually, I'd like us to go in this order, and I'll put that in the chat. I'd like to go with, the woman on the call, whose name just escaped me. So tell me your name again.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
