nodes.words: And then L. Rock. And then Eric. And we'll do that order, throughout the call. So we're asking you to say where you live, and a quick check in about the PIES, and I'll put them in there. Go ahead, Reverend Reyes.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: Okay. All right. I'll just jump right in. My name is Reverend Laura Reyes, I pastor United Baptist Church, located in Jamaica Plain, Mass. I'm a outreach pastor more so than in-house, but I do both. Physically, I'm a little sleepy because I worked the overnight shift at Rosie's, but other than that, I'm doing well. I have no complaints, physically, mentally. I'm just glad, every day, to be alive. And just excited about Real Talk. I'm a real person, I don't hold punches, I just kind of... Sometimes raw, but I look forward to what's going to come out in today's conversation.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: I am Franklin Hobbs. I am from Field's Corner, in Dorchester, at Global Ministries Christian Church, and representing healing our land, as well as Boston Praise [inaudible] Network. Physically, I am overall okay. A little tired, in my body, a little overwhelmed, just all that's going on, but in my spirit, I am well. So confident that this too will pass the challenges, and that I'm excited about, just where we are, quite candidly, as the church, and as an opportunity really just, to connect with MIT, that... To be able to build this infrastructure, really to serve the underserved and the marginalized.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: Good morning, again. Leon is the L, and Rock, I'm originally from Orchard Park, in Roxbury. Grew up in Boston, relocated, but still active in Boston. I work as a consultant. I've been doing work as a consultant for about 25 years, mainly in the Boston community. So I relocated to Washington, D.C., but I'm totally active in Boston, cause I have a commitment to the neighborhoods that I lived in.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I'm a fifth generation Bostonian, that's a long time. And physically, how am I doing? Tired. I just came into Boston at 7:00 this morning, well at 9:00 this morning, from Washington, D.C. So I'm just a tad bit tired, but because this is a up and down trip, doing consulting work again. But I'm glad to be in this conversation, because I got a bird's eye view, from outside looking in, at Boston, and its neighborhoods and its challenges. And I can speak regularly about it, because I have a program on Boston Black News, called, All Things Black Politics, so I'm just glad to be here, having a conversation with everyone today.

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: Again, my name's Eric Kennedy. I call Dorchester my home, even though I recently moved to the Hyde Park [inaudible] area. How am I doing? Intellectually, I'm doing well. I'm constantly reading and try to read at least two books a week, and try to just gain knowledge that way. And emotionally, I'm doing okay, all though I've been tasked with a project that I'm having trouble with. It seems like with the PUAs and the extra money be are getting, nobody wants to work, and I've been tasked to hire 100 people for a convention coming up in a few days, and I'm not having a good time doing it, even though the starting pay is very well. So emotionally, that's draining, because here it is, I'm trying to help people, and even rejoining citizens, and nobody wants to work. So it's emotionally draining.

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: Physically, I'm doing very well. I recently lost 75 pounds during COVID. Not because of COVID, but purposely. I purposely lost 75 pounds, and I did have some aches and pains in my knee. I had six surgeries in my knee from a shattered tib-fib, so when it gets cold, it bothers me. But other than that, health wise, I'm doing excellent.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Now that we all know who's here, let's get into the meat of the conversation. Keeping in mind that we're all complex individuals, and we all have had a host of experiences in our community, I'd like you to really think about a question, based on your own lived experiences, about the future of Boston and your place in it. I'll give you a minute to think, jot it down, if that's helpful.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I thought that I had hit enter, so that you could see it in the chat, but I hadn't. So there it is again. When you have your question, just let me know, because then there is another part of it that I want to say, before we begin sharing.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. So now, I want you to think about, what experience in your life brought you to that question. And then, give you another minute to think about that, and then we'll go in the same order as before. I'll ask you to share your question, and the story that brought you to that question, from your own experiences.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: Yes and no, but I'll give it a shot. What I didn't say earlier was, I'm a Boston native as well. So I grew up here, all my life, South End, Roxbury, Dorchester, and like I said, pastor at a church in Jamaica Plain.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: Experiences. I didn't say I was a former prison chaplain here as well, so I don't have... I could probably be here from now until tomorrow, with experiences, but future of Boston. I'm a little perplexed, because all my life, I hear about, "How can we bring the communities together? How can we make the communities unified". I'm 61 years old, and hasn't much been [inaudible] in the communities. Especially with our youth. They're being tossed in the shuffle, so to speak, like a deck of cards. And what collaboration with MIT or other organizations, can really help the youth?

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: When I was growing up, even when my sons were growing up, we had a lot of programs, organizations, that they could go to, as far as; after school work, just something to do on the weekends, basketball games, sports games. What can we do to bring that back? That's where I'm perplexed at. What are we really doing to help them? It seems like we're not doing as much as we could. My part in it, I'm a outreach pastor. Like I said, I've helped a lot of people that were in the prison system, helped them with their families and housing, distributing food, things like that, but I want to be able to do more. I don't know exactly if that makes sense, but I just want to do more, and how can I collaborate with people that actually want to do more and not just talk, but do more.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: Sure. My question is, how will we seize this moment in time, and I'm referring to the November 2nd election, to build a more equitable city for all, especially Black Bostonians. And my role in that, or part in that, is the ballot box initiative, and specifically building infrastructure for returning citizens, as our [inaudible] working with returning citizens. This is a huge population that is, as Pastor Reyes can say, just underserved and closed to the pain, and oftentimes, their voices aren't elevated to address the solutions that really need... For prevention, as well as intervention. So a movement really led by returning citizens, and so, really excited about the infrastructure at South Bay in [Nashua] County, for an aggressive...

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: And this to be in place by November 2nd, this ballot box initiative, that they'll be able to have to actually opt out, and then be much more aggressive with the infrastructure, and this be a pilot that can be replicated throughout the entire Commonwealth as, this is one of our... The most powerful things we have is our ability to be able to vote.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you for joining. I need to have you consent to be recorded out loud. We're a little bit into the conversation, and I would love for you to stay, but I just need you to say, "I consent to be recorded," and then I can catch you up on the rest of it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah, we can hear you now. This is being recorded, and then the transcript will go up, into cyberspace, with a bunch of other conversations. And I just need you to say that you consent to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Now, if it's all right with everybody else, I'll ask you to say your name, and where in the City of Boston you live or work, and then I'll repeat the question that we're talking on now. And then...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: You know what, this is hard, so I'm sorry that you can't hear me. I have a really loud voice. Can you write in the chat, where you're from? Does anyone know where he's from? I'm assuming he lives here, in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. And you know what else I'm going to do? I'm hoping he can see in the chat. I'm going to drop the two questions-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: ... Again, in the chat for him, because sometimes when you sign on afterwards, you can't see what's in the chat. And so, I'm going to just put those two questions in there, and then I'm going to ask everybody to use your outside voice, so that he can hear us. I'm assuming that you'll figure out what we're doing, by looking in the chat.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We're engaging in a conversation about the future of Boston and your place in it, and you'll be asked after everybody else, to share a question and the story behind the question. I'm going to ask L. Rock to go, and then Eric.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: Hi. In terms of the future of Boston, that's actually the question that I'm asking. Is, what is the big picture, future of Boston's historically Black neighborhoods or communities. The backdrop to that question, is actually related to my work over many years, in public housing and in the housing arena, both in the City of Boston, and nationally, and seeing that the numbers are beginning to dwindle, as gentrification is impacting Boston's historically Black citizens and community. And it doesn't seem as though there is a stop to it, it just keeps on growing.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: From South End to Roxbury, to Dorchester, to Mattapan, folks are being pushed out. Many are moving out of state, many are moving out of city, because it's not affordable. So the question is, what is the future of Boston's historically Black community?

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Did Eric have to leave? Did he say anything in the chat? Nope. Okay, Eric. If you can, unmute. It seems we lost Dayvon again, as well.

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: I said, the question is, with gentrification definitely happening, how do we move forward without the blame game of those moving in, and those who already existed here, and have that conversation that most people are scared to have, to talk about our differences and our alikes. Cause once we start having that conversation, I think we'll find that we're more alike than different, and my experience with that, growing up in the busing era and then traveling to different areas of Boston, Charleston, South Boston, and having negative comments thrown at me, and then to know that these people are now moving into predominantly Black areas, where before, they didn't want anything to do with it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Thank you so much. I really appreciate you all sharing your stories. Now what I'd like you to do is sit back and reflect on what you heard, and then this is not in sequence. This is just, unmute yourself. I would like you to share... Think about what you heard and look to the person and speak directly to the person, who's question really resonated with you, based on your experiences, and share why.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Just, think about what you heard, and unmute yourself, and speak directly to the person and explain why that question resonated with you.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: I'll go first, Reverend Reyes. Actually, Pastor Hobbs and Leon, and Eric, spoke about gentrification, and I've been seeing this since I was a little girl. The West End was predominantly African-American, when I grew up. The South End was practically African-American, Roxbury and Dorchester now, is becoming non... Because of the affordability, we can't live here, because the rents, the mortgages. It's been happening all across the United States, actually. So I don't know what the real solution would be, but that's what resonated with me, how do we have conversations with other Caucasians coming into the area, and other people coming in here, and not respecting what was already here. That irritates me, to be frank.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: We can't stop it, per se, but how can we have that conversation where they understand what's happened to us being pushed out. That's where I'm at with that.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: I'll jump and echo, Pastor Reyes sentiment. Everyone has said the same thing, under the larger umbrella of gentrification, and how do we stop that, as... And address particularly Black, unapologetically Black. Now there's this notion of communities of color. We know we're at a point where we've got two candidates who are running for mayor, that identify as women of color. Neither are people whom the Black community feels represent them, quite candidly. And so, our agenda has to be able to come... Either one of them is going to be the mayor, and so I think the whole thing around gentrification and how do we not just hold each other accountable and have the difficult conversation with individuals, but I would submit, also have the conversation with institutions like MIT. Like other institutions of higher learning, that have a lot of resources, that could help facilitate equity and infrastructure for underserved, for the marginalized, for the disenfranchised, for metrics and outcomes, that are really measurable and time sensitive.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: So, resonance? Anything that anyone said, resonated with you and connects to your own personal experiences? Just unmute yourself and share, please.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah, sorry. Find someone whose question or experiences, resonated with your own life. And then I want you to speak directly to that person, and tell them why their question or experiences resonated with you, and share that story from your life, that connects with their experience.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Let me just say, I heard a lot of general, like, "I've seen this," but I really want you to try and speak directly from your lived experience. So I'm sitting here wondering, have any of you been gentrified out. I didn't hear that, but that's what I wonder. So try to speak from your own personal lived experiences, as you do resonating. Thanks.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I think everyone here, without having a meeting, a meeting before the meeting, everyone talking about gentrification. So it's clear, it's a unified conversation that needs to be had, probably everybody on this call, but they can speak for themselves, has been impacted by gentrification.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I know that my grandfather, who came from Barbados, in the early 1900s, bought a house on [Stromard] Avenue, and was gentrified out, in the 1980s. After having a house, well, it was his daughter, my mother, who actually received the house after he passed away, but she was gentrified out because it became unaffordable for her to live there, because of taxes. Now it's a multimillion dollar home, on the corner of Stromard and Massachusetts Avenue. As I said, five generations of Rocks have lived over and impacted in that house, and unfortunately, it's gone now. That's the, I think, the collective experience of Black folks in Boston, being pushed out from one neighborhood to another.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: The impact is great, it's an emotional strain. In many ways, I'm not sure about this whole issue about a conversation. I think it's overstated, about conversations. Because we've been having conversations for years, about gentrification. In fact, Collins and Kevin White and others, already had a master plan for Boston, and that has been in the making for, now, close to 100 years.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: So when people say, "Let's have a conversation," have a conversation with who? There was a group back... And I know all of you all can relate to this, is that there was a group back in the day, called The Vault, and The Vault made the decisions, regarding what happened; politically, economically, socially, morally, and everything else, in the City of Boston. And The Vault still exists today.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: People are making decisions regarding Boston's future, and by the way, it's a done deal, what's going to happen to Boston's Black community. Period. It's not going to be affordable. Right now, with houses running between 700,000 and one to two million dollars, in Roxbury, Dorchester, and Mattapan, it's not affordable. I don't care what a particular mayor candidate will say, and say that they're going to put in more money for affordable housing, but the bottom line is, it's not affordable.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: If Roxbury residents, on average, are making $35,000 a year, they can't afford a house. It's unaffordable, so stop telling the big lie to the residents of Roxbury, Dorchester, and Mattapan, particularly historically Black... And I'm referencing this, Black, people. I'm not into the whole, people of color conversation. I'm talking about Black folks in Boston, so that's... You wanted it, you got it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you, Leon. I [inaudible] say anything. Anyone else, cause that resonated. I want to know who the 21st century vault is, but for another time.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And I wonder if they all look like me, or if they look like other people too. Just want to put that out there. Difference between 20th and 21st century stuff, in my opinion. But let me shut up, before I get fired.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I'll jump in there a little bit more now, seeing that everybody's quiet. There's another conversation that needs to be had, and this is the real conversation, and that's the conversation about educational equity, equality, and opportunity for all children in Boston. Why do I put that on the conversation, is because school desegregation happened in 1974, began in 1974, nothing has changed in Boston.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I just read, in the Boston Globe yesterday, that Black teachers hardly exist in Boston anymore. So all that work that Judge [Garrity] did, to actually call for a one on one hiring, and to bring up the level of Black teachers, to be at the same level of the population of students, which was at the time around 23, 24%, everything has changed and nothing has changed in Boston, in terms of educational opportunity for Black folks. And I'm going to put in people of color, and I'm going to talk about poor Whites too, that their parents jumped and ran and moved out, but some weren't able to move out, and they're still there, and the kids are getting the same lack of educational opportunities.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: So the real question for me, is housing and education. Those two things, along with health inequities, are the biggest challenge for Black folks in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Eric, you want to chime in? Did anybody's questions resonate, and did any of the other questions that just came up, resonate for you?

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: When I talk about this conversation, about gentrification not having a blame game, when I grew up in Roxbury, there was four other White families that still live in Roxbury, surrounding me. So I grew up in a mixed neighborhood, and it was a predominantly Black neighborhood. But my street, or my neighborhood, was mixed.

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: And I understand that the city government makes all these ordinances and stuff like that, but to place the blame on the people that are moving in, "You're taking this away from us," if they can afford it, then they can afford it. So how do we work with them, to get the government, to make the changes that we need to make, so that we can continue there, as they move in with us?

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: I'm glad that you're stating that, Eric, and your comments are resonating with me as well. How do we get the government to respond? Well, there's a big question, is, the government responds, based on voting. And if Black folks aren't coming out to vote, and if people that are running for election are not motivating folks to get out and vote, both in their conversations, speeches about what they plan to do, what plans they have, then the status quo is going to be the status quo.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: And the bottom line is, those that do vote, should actually coil all this together, and have those conversations with the body politicians, to essentially say, "Guess what? When a developer comes in and wants to develop on public land owned by the city, and they want federal or state, or city tax credits, you don't get them unless we come up with a plan to make sure that there's packages of housing, for one, two, three, four, five room housing." Because you know, Black families and Latino families are large. But they're making apartment buildings with one bedrooms and efficiencies, so that automatically forces people out, particularly those that can't afford that market rate housing. So if there's no strategy to make sure that the developers and the city, is requiring a certain number of properties made out for families... But there's not that conversation in the city, at all. None of the politicians are talking that language.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: To me, conversation just for pretty conversation, is nothing. We got to come up with real plans, and then have that conversation, based on saying to politicians, "Guess what? Call to action on this particular proposal."

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: If I can just sum it up, Leon Rock, I hear what you're saying and I feel what you're saying. I have to say though, I've been in several meetings, most recently, post the primary. State Representative Russell Holmes, he called a meeting at MorningStar that was really... A lot of people were in the room, and they were talking about a framework to be able... A Black agenda, unapologetically Black, not people of color, but a framework that had smart measures that were specific measurable, attainable, and had time sensitive markers.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: A report card with the NAACP, and they talked about... And subsequent to that, they got everybody's emails and phone numbers, and we broke up into break out groups, and we've been having conversations and even Senator Wilkerson, who does the Wakanda, who was instrumental in getting Rachael Rollins elected, and tried to endorse Janie, they have subsequently, or I think on today, are going to veer that framework that they came up with, that they are endorsing Wu. So I thought that different pockets or silos are starting to come together with a framework that is supposed to be a metrics for the Black agenda, regardless of who's going to be the mayor, and to hold them accountable.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: And specific things like, we talked about more housing, but it was specific. Like 2,000 Black home ownership, within a timeframe. I have been to a lot of these meetings that you're talking about, as well as Pastor Reyes talked about, and maybe I am naïve, but I do think that having different conversations... And State Representative Nika Elugardo, she was instrumental in really being able to help again, to create this framework that's not endorsing a candidate, but has an agenda and metrics, that is a Black agenda, that we will hold accountable to whomever that elected mayor is, in the City of Boston.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: In the mayoralty election, those folks that you just mentioned, couldn't pull off getting 35,000 voters out. Out of Roxbury, Dorchester, Mattapan, Hyde Park, Roslindale, Jamaica Plain, and other parts and neighborhoods of the city, so why would anyone expect them to be able to pull it off in the future? I'm just being real.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: When people don't know how to count the numbers... How many votes do I need? Fifty thousand, in order to be the mayor. How many votes do I need? Fifty thousand, in order to begin to have these conversations about what needs to be done, in the predominantly Black community of Boston, and they blow it.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: So guess what? Wakanda II, Wakanda I, all the other groups, NAACP, Urban League, all the rest of those groups couldn't come together and pull together 50,000 votes, to make decisions on the future of Boston, and now you come to me and tell me, "They're having another meeting." And I'm like, "Wait, they couldn't even pull together 35,000 votes from neighborhoods that they know, people that they know". I'm listening.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm going to ask us to just breathe for a minute. And so much of what everyone's saying is resonating with me, and I can feel my blood pressure rising, so I'm going to just take a pause, and actually invite Reverend Reyes and Mr. Eric, to comment. We've already got into the next part of this, and then we're going to wrap up in a few minutes, which is what are we hearing from people's experiences. So what are you hearing, Reverend Reyes? As you listen to these fine brothers talk about their experiences, what are you hearing?

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: I'm hearing the frustration of, again, conversation on top of conversation. But like you said, no one's been able to pull in, what needs to be pulled in, to serve our communities, the Black communities. This mayoral race is taking a toll on a lot of people, but the Black candidates that were running, did not put themselves out, as they should have. They would have gotten the vote if they had went to their communities and spoke to the people, and talked to them, and kind of relate to the way they were coming from. We would have...

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: Again, that's what I'm hearing. How do we stop having all these conversations, and have some solutions? As we bring all these different organizations, everybody wants to have a conversation again, but no one has a solution of what's going to be done. Education's brought up, my youngest son is a teacher at the Edward Brooke Charter School. He speaks about this frustration all the time, the lack of Black teachers. There's a lack of Black children seeing someone like them, and relating to them. What is going to be done about that?

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: It's over. The talk gets really redundant. It's tiresome. It's not a fact of giving up, but something needs to be done. What's going to be done? Questions on top of questions, but there's got to be solutions now. That's it. No more conversations, solutions.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you. Eric, do you want to say anything? What are you hearing, and then we'll do a round of takeaways. And then I'll drop something in the chat that I'd like you to fill out, if you can. So what are you hearing, and takeaways?

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: I'm still hearing frustration, as well. And the frustration is because lack of action. Me, personally, and I'm sure a lot of people are like me, I'm sick of having a meeting, about a meeting, about a meeting. When you have a meeting about an action plan, and then nothing is inserted, [inaudible] action, but yet you're having another meeting about more action plans, you didn't implement the action plans we had at the last meeting. And that causes frustration.

nodes.speaker: Orion
nodes.words: So I think once we come up, have that final conversation [inaudible] with a group, [inaudible] stuff up, in a meeting. And so, [inaudible] coming from and just that, all I can say is, [inaudible] we're going to [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Eric, I'm having trouble hearing your audio. So let me ask other people to just pause for a second and think about any closing comments, or if you want to share what you're hearing, it would be great.

nodes.speaker: Franklin
nodes.words: I would [inaudible]. I obviously do hear that frustration. I hear, quite candidly... I think that's just the best word that I can say, is that frustration that almost... And goes to a despair, and almost even a hopelessness, quite candidly, that is palpable. And what we have to do to be able to do our parts, individually, to try to change that, and that's the best way that we can do.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: When we talk about having real conversations, are we really willing what to hear, what realness means? Again, to really sit down and, again, release the frustration, someone to hear your frustration, act on the frustration, and stop having conversations. That's what I want to takeaway with that.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: I've been invited to a meeting on this coming Friday, with mayoral candidate Michelle Wu, and how the Black pastors have a vision of the Black community. I'm almost not tempted to go, because I'm going to go through the same frustrations that I feel right now, but I'm going to go, and to voice my opinion. And again, I really don't think that people really want to have real talk, because if they did, this solution would have come up to a point now, waiting 60 years, 70 years, of the same redundant questions that's going forth now. So hopefully and prayerfully, things will change, but again, we just got to shoot for that solution and stop conversating.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: Wow. I think, in many ways, all of us are saying the same thing, in different ways, but saying the same thing. There is frustration, it's there. The message about talk was important, and I'm glad that Eric bought it up, but talk in itself, is talk in itself. I'm more of an action person, so growing up in Roxbury, going to college there and high school, Dearborn, desegregation and the whole nine yards, I just get frustrated because I travel all around the country, and one of the things I do see is, many communities and neighborhoods doing the right thing, coming up with plans, and implementing them. Then I'm in my hometown of Boston, and I don't see the same action being taken.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: And actually, I see so many egos going on, in Boston. That's a big challenge as well, because egos get in the way, and action doesn't take place. And then everybody seems to be... Back in the day, we used to call them, "sellouts," or being bought out.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: And right now, in Boston, that's what I see. Lot of, a whole bunch of folks, just bought, for little or nothing.

nodes.speaker: L Rock
nodes.words: Little or nothing. And by the way, if you're going to have a conversation, let's have these. Let's have some clean hands, and then when we have clean hands, we can have serious conversations, as the pastor said. That's my opinion, and I could be wrong.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Any other thoughts? You don't know how much I was that I was a participant, and not a facilitator. But anyway, I just dropped in the chat, a link. We'd like you to fill out this demographic form for two reasons; one, we will send you, via email, a gift card that you can use online. And then we also, once the dashboard is done and the conversations are uploaded, we'll send you a link so that you can access your conversation and also access other conversations.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I too, have had a lot of conversations in my 40 plus years, as a anti-racist, racial justice activist, focused mostly on trying to improve the Boston Public Schools. I'm reminded that Judge Garrity found 408 violations, 408 ways that the government strategically kept Black kids out. So with that in mind, I am constantly reminded that we part of a river, of a liberation movement. And that all of us are doing our part, and I actually would like to end with a quick prayer from Reverend Reyes or Reverend Hobbs, just because our spirits need God.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: One of the elder Black women that I... I lived in a triple decker in Mattapan, for a long, long time. And it's amazing to me, because somebody who was a domestic worker could afford a triple decker. Not today. And so, Ms. Arlene gave me this thing, and it says... I have it in my bathroom, and it's right over where I brush my teeth, and it says, "Good morning, this is God. Hand me all your troubles, and have a blessed day." So I would love to just ask one of you to just say a prayer for us, as we close out, because-

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: Father our God, we come before you this afternoon, and we thank you for every opportunity to lift you up first, so God, we thank you for your presence in this meeting. Father, we hope that everything that was said here and done today, that we get some sense out of it, God. That we will not leave here, as frustrated as the conversation went forth, but father, we look to you, who is the author and [inaudible] of our faith, we look to you for wisdom and guidance, as all of us have strategic positions in our communities, the Black community. So father, I pray for our moderator today. I pray, God, for her persistence. I pray that she took something and will be feed off her own ignorance, that she didn't even know about the Black community, [inaudible] pray for all of us, in that sense of our own ignorance, that we still didn't know about our own people.

nodes.speaker: Laura
nodes.words: So I pray God, that this goes forth as something in the air, in the atmosphere, that we'll go forward with something constructive. And yes, we need clean hands, we need clean people to work for the Black community, [inaudible] move by your spirit, in us and forth, and us have a good day, because of who you are, not because of who we think we are. We bless you and we honor you, for this opportunity, and we pray that all this in this meeting, that their lives be richer for this day, for this conversation, but most of all, that we will go forth in your name, [inaudible] and solutions be made. We honor you and we thank you. In Jesus name. Amen.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you so much for adding your voices. And one thing I will say that gives me hope about this project, it gives us... I've been an advocate for racial justice in schools, and I would talk to parents and kids, and teachers, and then I would go to a school committee meeting, and I would say, "I talked to 100 people, and this is how they feel." Now I'll-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Now I'll be able to press a button and say, "Here. Here's what over 500 people, in the last few months, have said about what matters to us," and hopefully that will help each of us, in our own little areas, keep moving towards that unity, and unity of purpose, that we can all live in the city, and live with dignity. So thank you so much. I so appreciated your time. And if you think that this would be helpful for other folks you know, send them our way.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: All right. So let's get started. It is 6:05 and we're going to just kick it off. I want to just welcome you all to the call. Thank you so much for being here and welcome to one of the Real Talk for Change conversations. Again, thank you for responding to the invite for joining this network of voices and conversations that are happening across the city of Boston, which I'll tell you more about.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: We invited you to this gathering by asking you to think about one most pressing question you have about the future of the city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. So be nice to each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing Bostonians who would like to speak and to be listened and just really knowing that it all matters and that it will matter after this conversation.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: I will now begin recording this conversation and I will need to share four items of information with you before we even start doing the introductions. Did you guys hear that little ding on my computer? Did you guys hear it by any chance?

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: I think if you swipe with three fingers, you'll get to this side button where you can put do not disturb on your laptop.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. Thank you. Hopefully nobody reaches out to me right now. Okay. So before we start recording, I said it earlier, this actual recording, the visual of it, is not going to be used. So I think most of you who are on camera, for those of you that are not on camera, I encourage you to come on if you want to, but you don't have to.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: But I wanted to let you know that the visual will be dumped. So really important, why are we holding these conversations? This is the key. This is why I signed up for this process as a community leader. We want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive and listening across the divides.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So across the neighborhoods, the political, the culture and provide some improved visibility and accountability between all the candidates that we all know right now are running for mayor and for other seats throughout the city of Boston, and throughout our neighborhoods. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your position on the upcoming election or specific candidates. We're doing this to help build connection, foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So what will be happening with this recording and I kind of said that a little bit today, following our meeting today, the audio of the recording will become part of a collection of Real Talk for Change and it will be hosted in what they call the LVN platform. The LVN is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by the nonprofit organization called Cortico.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: LVN system creates a transcript of each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to the explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversation and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And if some of you have had the link to the Real Talk for Change video and if you didn't watch it before this meeting, I would definitely say watch it. This is of course MIT's engineering at its best. So I really encourage you to watch that. This conversation along with all other conversations that are taking place throughout the city will be shared with others who have participated in Real Talk for Change conversations and the members of the Real Talk for Change team.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So finally, I have to read this consent statement and ask if you're willing to be recorded. As a participant in this conversation, you're providing constant consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protective collection on Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversation in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. In addition, part of the Real Talk for Change's mission is to present voices from the people of Boston, which is all you all beautiful people and therefore portions of your conversations can be made public. So, kind of looking at everybody across the room to kind of acknowledge and I want to make sure if you understand and agree to this, please say all together, you could say, I agree.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. So now you have the option to use another name. This is the fun part of this conversation. You can use your stage name, your street name, your artist name, whatever you want to use as part of this discussion. If you want to use a different name now, let me know and also put it in your Zoom name. So my name is here, Nurys Camargo, well, I'm going to be myself for this conversation. Last week I was Sasha. So if you want to change your name, please do so, take a couple of minutes. And does anybody here, just so I know, want to change their name? Let's see.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Okay. All right. So Jesus. Perfect. Okay, so it sounds like we're good on that. Okay. And thirdly, at the end of the conversation, I'm going to ask you to help us capture some simple demographic information by completing an online form. It's very simple. It takes like two minutes. We will do this before we end the meeting and I will say more about this before I ask you to fill out the form.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation. And to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines from our conversation. I think I know everybody here and I think everyone was going to play it safe, but I'm going to read them anyways. Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking, take turns, stay curious, ask honest questions, pause and take time to reflect.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that words have an impact, it's one thing that I've learned, and when possible close unnecessary programs on your phone or your computer, applications, and if you need to take a break, let me know in the chat and that's all good. So is everybody on board with that? Can I get a kind of a head node, yes out loud?

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Okay. All right. And let me just say again. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you, for joining this. I know that everyone's had a long day. So we're going to get started. So we are going to have a centering activity. To begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check-in.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So very simple, share your first name, which means the name that you're using today and where you're located right now, then let us know how you're using the pies check-in, I'll tell you all what that is, and this means picking one and saying how you choose to check in using one of the following.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So the pies is physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. So, you can pick one of those four. Physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually. So as soon as you're done, sort of thinking and once you're done with your introduction, at the end you say, and with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So does that make sense? Okay. So for the ease of the virtual conversation, we're going to use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn. For this one, I'm going to just let people go in popcorn style. And then for the next one, I'm going to just tell you all who goes in what order. Does that make sense? Okay.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So I'll check in first if that's cool. Just a sort of model behavior. So I'm Nurys. I am in Mattapan. I am a community leader in Massachusetts. I do tons of civic engagement, which is why I'm here today and I am picking, I'm going to say spiritually, what is one of my pies to check in today because I'm in a very good spiritual place today, and it's very good to see you all. So I will let whoever wants to go next.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: I'll just go just to knock it out. My name is Ian. I'm also known as Uncle Loud. Community organizer. I know a lot of people and I just try to share the resources that we have. I would say spiritually, I'm in my gratitude. I'm in appreciation and that's what I want to share with everybody right now. I'm very thankful.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I'll give it a shot. This is the first time I'm doing this. So I don't understand what pies thing very well but Jesus, I'm in Hyde Park. I am a IT Manager. I'm also a small real estate investor in the Boston area and I am assuming physically. That's it.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: I'll go. Hi everyone, I'm Chantal. I'm in Roslindale right now. I'm a recent college graduate and I'm physically checking in. I feel great health-wise. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: Why me? Okay. Hi. I'm a multi-faceted individual. Cares about people, society, science, technology, just to make meaningful contributions of a better world. And I'm feeling great in every single aspect.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And I forgot to remind you all, I don't think I even did it myself, but then say, "With that, I'm in." So Hugo, you got to say it. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: Well, I'm Daphne. Actually, I'm in Cambridge but I'm originally from New York City, and I would say I'm S for spiritual. I am feeling pretty balanced today and grateful to be here. So, thank you.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Hi. Yeah. Carol Blair alias Multi Mode Mama. I'm a mother and grandmother, recovering engineer, retired transportation planner, bicycle rider, walker. I'm president of my neighborhood association. I live in Northampton Street in the space that people argue whether this is South End or Roxbury.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Of course now I understand we are both, so it's very important, well now that's going way beyond. How will I ground myself right now? I think physical because my brain goes much faster than I do. And I spend too much of my time on the computer in my brain, and I always need to ground myself physically. And my body loves it, but I forget to do that. So with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Naomie. I come from Mattapan. I guess right now I'm feeling more intellectual. I'm a social studies teacher. So, something that makes me go, is making sure that kids understand their identity and making sure that they know how they contribute to this world. So I feel intelectual and any way that I could learn some information to better myself and better my teacher practices to help kids is something that I always try to do. So I'm feeling a little intellectual and with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: All right. So I think everyone went. Yes. So I also just want to say that I didn't say earlier, but Daphne is here, also joining us in two capacities, one as a participant today but also she is part of a team of folks that are creating a documentary around the city of Boston's election right now.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And at some point, she will be sitting in one of these in her full capacity as someone who's working on a documentary, but today she's participating in here. So Daphne, thank you and would love to hear, maybe at the end, a little bit about your work and documentary and in communications and all that good stuff.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So thank you for joining us Daphne. Thank you. Thank you. Okay. So now that we know who's here, let's get to the core of our conversation. As we shed the restrictions of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequity in America and Boston and how our lived experiences shape that learning.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: So, keep this in mind. I like to invite you to think, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? Take two minutes to reflect on this and write it down somewhere, make a mental note or something, and I'm going to come back to you.It was like a minute and a half.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Now I like to invite you to think about what experiences in your life got you to this question. So you thought about for a minute, what's your question about the future of Boston? And I see Ian's baby girl here, so what's the future of Boston and what's your place in that future? And now I want you to think about what experience got you to that question.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: It's key to keep your experience personal. It has to be something that you experience directly and an experience that can help us understand how you got to the question [inaudible] I'm actually going to put in the chat here who goes when and if I've misspelled anybody, I'm sorry, but I tried to do it really quickly.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And what we'll do is, we'll go around and each person will share that question and then tell the story of an experience that led to your question. Goes with the order in the chat for you to go and you can always pass or tell us something back but everybody has to go. So Ian, you're the first one that I cut off.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: All right. I'm glad because my daughter is about to go in the bath, so this is a really good time for me... Yes Nayu, I am on camera. I'm the guy that everybody counted out to fail and lose and just didn't expect to succeed. And my success rate has been based on the mentors and the resources that I've had all my life that I've been able to pull on and grasp when I've needed them.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: So, an example of that from a very young age, and I'm speaking from about eight to 12, that really started to guide me into the best directions. Let me also give you a background. No father figure, no uncles, no older brothers. So no real great example of what a male should be and what males need to be doing.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: So, I would say, the first program was the Paul Robeson Institute and they were located where Ruggles is, so is T accessible. And I won't get in too deep in that. It was an awesome program. It was every Saturday, but you had mentorship and you had apprenticeship. So you could do shop, you could do fashion, you can do whatever it may be and you had an experience.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: You also walked away with the projects, so is a project based program and everybody in there, I still interact with on certain levels. Keith Motley was one of the head organizers. I think he was at UMass last, I don't know what's going on with brother Motley but that's what I'm saying. You still have brother Motley doing a lot of things throughout the city of Boston, and I can pick up the phone and call him.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: I have people like you from the Chica Project. We need more catalysts like that and that is the reason why I've been able to be successful, and I am currently the operations manager for Zuma Boston in the Four Seasons Dalton like you can't do that. Those opportunities doesn't happen for people like me where I'm from. And it's really because I'm a product of my environment that has encouraged me and enabled me to be the best that I am and give the best to the people around me. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: The question is, why am I not? Why can't I? How come me? How come not in my household? It's really an absence. It's really a physical displacement. I live in Dorchester. I'm from Dorchester. I was born in Jones Hill. I'm in my environment and I still don't feel included, but because I understand my surroundings, I know how to place myself. I don't feel invited and it's not just a black thing, it's just an education, it's a class thing. It's all the above. I don't feel welcomed.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you, Ian. And Sisno, I know you joined us. When it's your turn, I'm going to quickly give you an update of what it is so that you can participate. Okay. Chantal, you're next. So make sure you tell us the question first and then how you got there.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: Right. Okay. So the question was, what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? I think, for me, a little back story on me. I was born and raised in Roslindale, and I recently graduated from Syracuse University. So, coming back to Boston, I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do in the future and I think the pandemic enlightened me in a way that it made seem that what I went to college for wasn't exactly what I wanted to do. So now coming back home, looking for resources for college graduates and trying to figure out what my place is moving forward and how I can find that within Boston, I think is my biggest question. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: So question. What will it take for Boston to create communities that are desegregated by less socio-economic disparity, more Healthcare equity, and less divisive housing plans? What took me to that question is the following. I mean, Boston is a city that reproduces a national racial hierarchy and a racially structured society that surely limits access to resources and privileges on the basis of skin color.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: Example of the segregation? Well, based on my personal experience, that's kind of like, what you mentioned earlier. I've been very fortunate to be one of the very few black people that have been able to attend to the best university in the world, MIT and Harvard. And at every one of those scenarios, I've been always questioning, why am I the only one? Then I look at Roxbury and Dorchester, and I do see that there are black people there And just to give you some context, an Africa Latin American.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: So I was born in South America, but I've been in the US for many years and I've lived in different cities in the US. But then like I said, Boston reproduces these racial hierarchy to certain degree and extension. And then when you have a city that has like the top two universities in the world, and then you see that there are black people that actually helped build this country and they don't get to enjoy the benefit, is such a contradiction.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: And then you see people from all over the world coming to Harvard, MIT and then you see all these institutions talking about diversity and inclusion and they are talking about gender diversity, nationality diversity, but nobody really seems to care about racial diversity specifically, the absence of black people. So, that's what I'm talking about.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you for sharing that. And I kind of messed up the order a little bit. I put people in here twice, but it's okay. So Multi Mode Mama, why don't you go? Tell us the your question and then how you got there.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Very good. My question. So I do a lot of walking now since the pandemic, because I can't go to the YMCA without either wearing a mask, which is very hard when I'm exercising, or whatever. So, I haven't been back to the Y except for a very hot day swimming. So anyway, when I walk around, I see so much that we spend protecting ourselves from each other.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: That's all the fences, and grates, and the police, and cameras, and alarms and all the barriers that we use to protect ourselves and I'm wondering, how can we pull those resources that we currently spend protecting ourselves from each other, to help us all to thrive? I'm sure that when you put all those things together, there's enough to house everyone, educate everyone, provide the transportation we need and the medical care we need iff we can pull those protective resources. We could talk all night about how I got there.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Since I'm now 71 going on 72 and there's a lot of stories in me, although I'm not a good storyteller. But anyway, I grew up in Vermont where, in my high school, that was the first time I was in school with an African-American person in high school. And then there were three people of color in my whole high school and they were the same family. One of their name was Washington and they weren't in my class, of course, but I come from a long line of New England-

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Of Quakers, New England people. So clearly my philosophy, having come of age in the time of the civil rights like, oh, I didn't know that was a problem, but of course yeah, everybody's equal. I mean, I don't know any people who are different from me, but yeah that makes sense. So I didn't really have that real life experience.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: Of course, my ancestors are privileged and therefore, we know that they've benefited from slavery and all those things, but I didn't know anything about that, so you could call me innocent I suppose in the naive sense of the word. But now, of course, I've been here, I've been in Boston since 1972. That's a long time and I have a lot of experience. So this afternoon when I was out walking, I should say I live maybe a half mile from Nubian Square and so, I walked out bound toward Nubian Square through Nubian square, and then kept going.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: So, I did a big loop going down Blue Hill Avenue coming back on Warren Avenue, and I see lots of people and many of those people are averting their eyes when they get close. There's no good afternoon, and I kind of understand that's because of the racial difference and it's just very sad because I certainly would like to connect and yet I have to tune into a conversation like this to do that. That's probably enough for me, right?

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: That's good. Thank you so much for sharing. This is the first time I'm facilitating this conversation, so I was one of you all two weeks ago and I participated in the conversation and then decided to facilitate. So I'm going to apologize. But I want to go back just so that folks are going to keep going. The question that we had you think about what is, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Which everyone has pretty much answered. And then the part two of that is and what experience in your life got you to this question? This is so engineered. There's like a process in it. So and I think you guys have all answered it. But for those of you that are still out, I just want to reiterate that so that I don't mess anything up. So Jesus, you are up and then after Jesus, it's Daphne and then Naomie.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: All right. Came up with like a lot of different things. But especially as people were talking, you kind of think, oh, this other thing. I guess the one that gets me the most is about financial literacy. So why isn't Boston preparing the youth to be financial literate? That is a question that I've asked myself and I don't understand why today there's still nothing around that. I guess what led me to that is, I grew up in Boston. I came here from Puerto Rico when I was three years old and I didn't know. I didn't know how to balance a checkbook.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I didn't know what I didn't know, and no one showed me and I made a lot of mistakes financially. So now growing up, learning from my mistakes and a better place but right through a lot of bumps and hurdles, how do we teach our youth some of these things that other kids are taught from the beginning, so that they are in a better place to succeed.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: So when you talk about financial literacy, you're talking about balancing a checkbook, you're talking about your credit score, you're talking about saving money. All of these things that have an impact. You need these things in order to progress, in order to grow and in order to have some of these things that you want in life. So, what is Boston preparing? What are they going to do? So yeah, I think I answered it. I'm not sure. Good. Okay.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: There's no right or wrong answers here. We got to follow the prompts. So thank you Jesus. Thank you. Thank you. Okay, who is next? Daphne and then Naomie.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: Okay. So I'm not from Boston, but I'm here making a film as you mentioned earlier. Initially I came here to follow the mayoral candidates. I realized it's not even about the candidates anymore, it's about the people and the unheard voices. So what got me here? I'm a filmmaker. Been making documentaries for about 25 years.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: I initially approached this film more like, okay it's a political film, but my strength is making personal films. So now I'm looking at Boston personally, because, even though I'm from New York City, I feel like Boston is the city that can set an example for the rest of the United States. Racism is throughout the United States.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: I'm an advocate for education and it's a huge disappointment to come to Boston, which I feel is the city of education and across the river is Harvard and MIT and like a two or three stops on a train, you're in Boston and I'm hearing about children in schools that are crumbling are afraid to go to the restroom and then forget about the pandemic.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: So I don't want to go on about it because it just gets me so angry. But I am all about education and I'm really happy that this program is happening because we really need to listen and find the people that are afraid to speak because I believe those are the people that, maybe they're fearful, but I believe those are the people that have the answers and maybe they're not courageous or they're afraid to step forward, but I believe with programs like this, it might give them an opportunity to speak.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: And if any of these mayors or government officials are smart, they should start listening. From the middle school child up into the seniors that are also being ignored. So, that's my two cents. So I really hope Boston changes. Between the pandemic and the murder of George Floyd, these are big wake-up calls and from this point forward there's no excuse for us to make, not only Boston, but the rest of the United States, just a better place and set an example globally. So, hope I answered your question.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you Daphne. And I think we're so blessed to have you in this today because you're a filmmaker and this film was going to end up being through your eyes. So thank you for joining us today. Naomie.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: Good evening everybody. So the question is, what question do you have in terms of the future of Boston and what led you to this, I guess, experience. So the question I have is, why are our schools in Boston still segregated in terms of I guess race? In terms of that, I think that in Boston, there's like a very covert racism in terms of over racism in terms of other places in the US and it's like a cover-up in terms of like how things are running in Boston specifically in Massachusetts.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: Our prime example is the Boston Public School system. I teach in the BPS system. I've been teaching for seven years. I used to be a teacher at a charter school, and now I'm in the BPS system. And I see the big difference in terms of just how schools are run differently and given that BPS is the oldest institution within the United States and also, the biggest public school system within Massachusetts.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: I definitely see that resources are not being allocated to students and students are being greatly affected and that's not seen in different parts of Massachusetts. And then, when you look at the demographics within BPS and other school systems within Massachusetts, we see that BPS is predominantly students of color.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: So my question would be, why is this still happening in 2021? Racism is not something that has vanished, so I know why it's happening but also like why is it happening? But it's just I guess like a rhetorical question, like why is it happening and why aren't we fixing it as a city, as a community, to make sure that students in places that are far out Massachusetts are getting the same instructions, the same love, and the same attention, the same push in Boston that they're doing in Massachusetts?

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: I mean how I arrived to this question is just being an educator and just also being a product of the Boston Public School system, graduating and also teaching in the BPS system and teaching different systems and seeing the big difference in terms of like potential for students and how they could get to where they're supposed to be.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Naomie, do you have one experience that you can bring with this group from your question and how you got there? One experience, as in, put into play for us.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: So I've been teaching at BPS for a month, but I've been teaching overall for seven years. When I first was going to go into BPS, people were like, oh my goodness. Why are you going there? It's so bad. Oh, my goodness. How are you going to survive? And I'm like, no, I graduated from BPS system, I feel a little bit offended because I went to a BPS school and I turned out fine.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: And I feel like I'm a good contribution to the world. So I want other students to also feel that same thing once they graduate. I understand, not to say I definitely don't agree, but I understand where some of the stuff is coming from based off of just how BPS is run and how certain things, and I'm not trying to like downplay BPS like it's a bad organization, but we definitely have a lot of work to do and I just think that that was my experience of, why not be BPS.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: Why can't somebody from BPS go to Harvard. Don't downplay BPS, don't downplay the students in BPS. They have so much potential just like students that are in different parts of Massachusetts, whether they're in the suburbs, whether they're in the city, they definitely are capable of the same thing. So I guess that's something that has been playing in my mind over the last few months.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. And you all see me doing sort of thumbs up because I'm on you and part of this whole process is that our voices are being recorded, so I want to catch myself of not being mm-hmm, yes, yeah, amen, so I'm kind of doing this. All right. We have two more sections, and we're going to end on time.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: This is very fascinating. So now we're going to talk about connecting our experiences. We're going to take about a minute. What I want you to do next is think back to each of the questions and the experiences that were shared with this group. Find someone who's question or experience, resonates with your own life.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Then I want you to speak to that person here and tell them why their question or experience resonates with you and share the story from your life that connects with their experience. I'm going to repeat that. Think about some of the questions that we've talked about today, you all have talked about, find someone who's question or experience resonates with your own life.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And then I want you to speak to that person with their name and tell them why their question or experience resonates with you and share the story from your life, that connect to their experience. So let's give everyone about 30 seconds, maybe a minute to reflect. And then once that goes, were going to go popcorn style.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And then after that, we're going to have another quick little session and then we're going to keep moving. So I see Ian's hand is up. We're still going to give folks 20 seconds, but Ian, you'll go first. There's a lot said already, so want to make sure you guys have time to think about it a little bit. Thumbs up. Folks ready? Okay. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Ian.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: Yes. Shout out to her. I felt her. I don't know if she phrased it as a question, but more is how she had to come on Zoom to have an interaction with her neighbors and the people of our community. I completely agree. I'm a young 35 year old man. When I grew up, I knew everybody on the five blocks surrounding me, their last name, their brothers and their sister. I was raised when you make eye contact, you say hello to somebody, open the door for ladies and I understand not everybody has manners and was raised the way that I was raised.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: That's fine. But I completely agree with the disconnect and it's not even just race, just the disconnect that we have or that we don't have in our communities and its surroundings. It's very disheartening and it's frustrating. So I would love to see more of that and I feel you, I empathize. I'm right there with you.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: I really appreciate your sharing about the resources in the public schools. I can't imagine a good reason. There are lots of bad reasons. I know that they're lots bad reasons, but I grew up in a college town in Vermont and so I had an excellent education. And I came to Boston and I was committed to having my three sons go through the Boston Public School system, which they did.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: They graduated. They went all the way. But of course, they were smart white boys, and they were tracked well, so they probably got the best of the resources, but I know that. So I had an older son and then twin sons. The Twins were in 5th grade in an advance work program and because they were twins, they were placed in different classes, which is partly my hope that they wouldn't live as twins, that they would have their own lives.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: So they were placed in different classes and because of that, they had different teachers the year before they were supposed to go to where they would go to high school. I guess that was middle school. Sorry. That must have been fifth grade just before the sixth grade. And so, one of the twins went Boston Latin and the other one to Boston Latin Academy because of the teachers they had because the one who went to Boston Latin Academy had the really tough teacher who felt that she needed to treat all the kids as though they were in boot camp.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: And so she was really tough on them and the parents all complained the kids are getting ulcers, they are having nightmares and everything. Like it was really hard for the kids and because of that, one of my sons went to this school, one of my sons went to that school. I imagine their capabilities are comparable but I can see how it happens that because of a small difference, one goes this way and one goes that way.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: And certainly when there are much bigger differences, including the color of your skin and the way you speak and how much your parents were able to invest in your education, I mean, reading you stories when you were an infant or even in the womb or whatever. It's so important that the public school be the place where everybody gets what they need and I'm grateful that you're there.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I think I may just piggyback Ian and Naomie. I think you mentioned went BPS. Not a lot of people expected you to be the success you are today. And then Naomie going through the BPS system and then coming back to teach, I think that's incredible. I went through the BPS system here and I was that same guy.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I was in the graduating line. I went to Madison Park and I was the graduation line and they were like, you shouldn't be here. That they make a mistake sort of thing and stuff like that bothers at first, but then you use it as fuel to keep you going. As far as Naomi going through the system and giving back, I think of my kids growing up right now in Boston.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I was fortunate one of my older kids went to a private school. But now I have my younger kids, they're going to a charter School, the LA. So I'm seeing the differences especially when you compare private to BPS and charter, but even with charter and BPS, there's just a lot of differences with the education.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: It's tough for you want to give the best opportunity to all of your kids or nieces, nephews, everyone around you. Everyone deserves a shot and sometimes it's not fair how things just will happen the way it does and it's really out of your control. But those subtle differences, it has an impact and you just hope that they can do the best with what they have and still make it through.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: So, with graduating from Madison and I'm sorry, I just want to inquire, what were your final polls to get through that threshold because it wasn't graduation. It was the victory. It was the opportunity to do something after graduating. What pulled you through that threshold?

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I had enough drive to know, okay, once I'm finished, I want to go off to college. So I'm the youngest of four. So I think that had a lot of influence. Had I not had those older role models, maybe I just wouldn't have seen it. They paved the road, so I was able to see and say okay, now this is what I want to do.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: Obviously, when I was at Madison, I was not your A student, but I ended up going to Northeastern through it's a program called the Ujima Program. Not sure if it's around anymore. I was not prepared for that school. I didn't have the grades to go to that school. Financially, I couldn't afford it but through programs like that, they gave me the opportunity.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I had one year to prove to myself and to the professors that I could, that I belonged there and that was my stepping stone. And then after my first year and just saying okay, you know what I got this then I was able to continue. Definitely that resource made a huge difference as far as where I'm at today and then the older role models.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And I think this brings us into the next chapter of this of tonight. It's, let's talk a little bit about what you're all hearing. What are you hearing in people's experiences? I see the baby too. Hi, baby. Hi, Mommy. Hi, Mommy. So what are you all hearing? We have the future of Boston right in front of us. She's like six months. How old is she Ian?

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: 16 months. Get ready. So, the floor is open. Tell me a little bit about what you guys are hearing in people's experiences. And anyone can go. Whoever's ready, start off.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: Yeah, pretty much. How can we have more opportunities that I've had for my neighbors and the people around me and their children. And it was really why I asked, I completely forgot your name brother, why I asked you what brought you to the threshold because for me, I didn't have again male role models.

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: I had 15, 10 reasons like really straight up and I've seen these powerful women. So, I've seen women of color in positions that they weren't supposed to be in and open these doors and expose these resources. So for me, why aren't there these apprenticeship programs? You need more of those.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: I'm not sure it's a share, but I sure hope whoever the next mayor is will invite Naomie to sit at the table because that's the voice they need to hear.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: I appreciate it. I appreciate it. Thank you. I appreciate your words. Similar to, I believe his name is Ian, this program's for the youth in the community just because I believe a lot of youth within the urban community need that second push to get them to the next threshold in terms of success.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: I definitely had my fear of resources and mentors and people that were pushing me and that's one of the reasons why I'm an educator and I definitely want to give the next generation the same or similar resources so that they could get to the next threshold because all sometimes kids need or our youth need is just that one person to believe in them and that one person who will be like, you can do it, and that one person wil be like I understand what you're going through and you can get to this next level. So I definitely agree with what Ian said.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: Yeah, I was just going to say, I think from hearing everyone talk, it sounds like there's a gap and what can Boston do to make sure that it's not just one out of every 20 kids going to college and one out of five kids who are eventually going on to be like CEOs or have high-end jobs? Everyone should have that opportunity and what can Boston do to make sure that everyone has that equal opportunity and what resources are needed to provide better so that gap isn't there anymore and that's what I feel like I've gotten from the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: I majored in communications with minors in both Spanish and marketing. But I feel like for me, it's interesting because I had a different experience growing up in Boston. I was in BPS till like fifth grade, and then I did a program called Stepping Stone that pretty much helped me.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: The way I describe it to people is, it's pretty much a program that prepares you to take a test to then get to some type of private school outside of Boston. And that's what I did and I was able to get into a school in Chestnut Hill, Beaver Country Day School. And I spent six till 12 grade there. So my experiences are very different, but I know being one of five kids who went to that school, who were actually from Boston, that it's not easy.

nodes.speaker: Chantal
nodes.words: The experiences I had going to that school really molded me because it's kind of like I had an inside view into what private schools are like and what kids who have the resources from their parents and just their communities look at what they have to do versus us who have to pretty much prove ourselves constantly and fight for everything that we want to be able to stay within the conversation. So yeah.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: You mention a couple of programs of Stepping Stone as a program. So my oldest that went to private school, went through Stepping Stone. That's how he was able to get into private school in financial aid and everything else that brings. A lot of it is resources.
