But even within those resources and those programs that are available, they are limited. So from my three kids, the oldest got accepted, the other two didn't make it.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: So okay, you have to take a different path. One of my concerns now looking at colleges, so you have your UMass Boston Amherst etcetera. Before, those were safety schools. You didn't make it into one of those, you got into the one at UMass. Now, it's not a safety school anymore. It's difficult to get into any one of them.

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: So my question now is, what do they fall back on? It's difficult to get into some of the limited programs and if you don't get into those then what? But let's say you make it through the high school, okay, but if you're not in the Ivy League's and you don't get into those competitive school, then what? It just seems like there's always another roadblock and it seems to be affecting certain population and maybe less impacting others. So that's a concern that I see growing as we progress. I don't see that getting easier.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: I'm just going to take you to what people are saying. The lady in the middle I think that she'd sum it up very nicely. I think that the common thread here is like we got these opportunities. What's needed to happen for others to actually have some sort of similar opportunities and almost no one role and societous role to make it happen.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. So, any last thoughts on that part, in terms of what you're hearing? Anybody else want to add? I'll just quickly.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: I heard somebody say something about the next mayor and clearly what the next mayor does will have the potential to make a big difference. And I've been working hard to think about what message would help to turn out the vote from people who can really benefit the most. And so, one of the things that we in my neighborhood association have been doing is to try to turn out the vote.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: We did a little festival kind of thing outside the poolimg place last time and now we've got this kind of like a poster and I just put the text for the poster in the chat. And if any of you like that, like who is Boston, register by October 13th, vote November 2nd or vote by mail and then the website for figuring out how to do all that.

nodes.speaker: Multi Mode Mama
nodes.words: If any of you like that, make your own poster, post it on your office door or on your apartment door or give it to your I don't know what, put it on Facebook, whatever you can do to get it out there, so that people who might benefit from this election actually turn out to vote.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. That's key. That's so key. All right, so we're going to start wrapping up. I promise I was going get everybody out of here on time. Even though this is a really good conversation and I'm fired up and as a facilitator, it is very hard to facilitate and be fired up. So I just wanted to let you all know that I am both fired up but still facilitating because I think you all had some really amazing points today. Thank you for sharing your questions and your experiences. We will now quickly go around and everyone has to participate and share something you will be taking away with you.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And if you have any closing thoughts that you'd like to share or other general reflections, like Multi Mode Mama just did, please let us know. And just a reminder of what will happen with your thoughts you shared, these recordings will be transcribed and indexed and shared with a team of Real Talk for Change and you'll receive an email from them when all the conversations are ready to be reviewed in the LVN platform.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: And again, I'm going to encourage you all to look at that little, it's a minute and 35 seconds video on this and we'll talk a little bit more about that at the end but I want to just open it up to you all. Thoughts that you're bringing with you and anything you want to share and we'll go popcorn style. Jesus, why don't you start?

nodes.speaker: Jesus
nodes.words: I was going to set this one back. I was going to sit this one out. I'm not sure. I mean it was a lot of information that was shared but it's really about our work isn't done. There's still a lot left to do and thinking about how do we continue to make an impact? How do we continue to make a change and a positive change? Things are better but there's still a lot. I think for me that's really the takeaway is, what else can I do?

nodes.speaker: Ian Loud
nodes.words: I think my takeaways is it's just sometimes I feel like I'm the only one going through it, so it's really good to hear a lot of people from different places in my community express a lot of similar issues, even if their parents are not, so it was just really good to see that sometimes we just need to find the outlets that we can come together to amplify that that singular sound. So it was good to know that there is still a community.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: To piggyback on something that Ian mentioned that no one expected him to be successful and I try to think about that or lead with that in terms of when I think of teaching or when I think of a lot of stories within the urban community and I said, put a single story on people in the urban community, but I do think that the urban community that's not a light shed on the urban community.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: So just thinking of that, pushing people while pushing students and pushing youths and letting them know that they have so much potential to get wherever they want. And that's with resources and with the people in the right corner, just like a lot of us had mentors and a lot of us have resources, they could definitely get to wherever they want when they believe in themselves and they push themselves to get to wherever they want to go.

nodes.speaker: Naomie
nodes.words: I think for me what I got out of today, was just like how important it is to hear the voices of Boston because we are what make up our community and making sure that we have that space to be able to talk about what we go through. And through these conversations that you see how many things, I think someone else said it before, like you're not alone in your struggle and there's things that connect all of us and having that space to be able to talk about it and get out the frustrations or things we're scared about is important because that's how we make the difference and the change, is by first one acknowledging it, talking through it and figuring out steps from there. Like, what can we do to better ourselves and better our community?

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: And you and just knowing this platform exists, just fills my heart with joy because giving a space for people to speak shows that we are all connected for better or worse. So Kudos, and I have only good vibes and best wishes for this program to continue. Thanks for including me today.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: I was just wondering based on what many people shared, how can we actually become more effective at raising awareness of people's struggles and those multi-generational inequities that certain communities have come through so others can actually better understand why is it that there their equity in one way or another was built at the expense of building inequity for others.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: Actually there is a disconnect there and that's based on my experiences. People are being around with the different circles that have been, and the underlying concepts there is that when some people are forced to end up in unequal circumstances than many people, they blame them for making bad choices. Yeah, so we then read the inequality evidence of a broken system structure that produces inequality.

nodes.speaker: Hugo
nodes.words: But as the inability of those individuals to be as successful as the rest of us, so we put all the blame on them. That's because we don't have the ability to actually understand what struggles they actually went through and in some cases, well, they don't know better. But then if we do know better, how can we become more effective at helping them understand that those obstacles are real and that there should be mechanisms to actually break those barriers down.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: Thank you. Thank you. This is great. I just want to thank everybody. This has been a great conversation. I've taken a lot from it and I guess I'll just share myself. I've taken away that there's still community and there's a new way of community and this today continued to show me the new way of community, so thank you. I am going to drop a link in this chat and before we leave here, everybody needs to fill it out. It's a quick little survey.

nodes.speaker: Nurys
nodes.words: I'm going to drop it right now. And just a couple of minutes, fill it out and a reminder that you will find it in the section. It's a demographic quick survey, please fill in your neighborhood, which is very important and any other remaining information, you find comfortable with sharing. It will help us a lot when servicing and uplifting the voices of diverse communities. So we'll take a few minutes to do that. We're still on time. And let me know if anybody has any issues with it. And Daphne, you can just put on...

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So like I said, welcome to the Real Talk for Change. There's going to be a conversation, I'm going to read this off to y'all. The project scope and logistic. The purpose of this conversation is to create a new space across the city to facilitate constructive listening across divides, so we're talking about the city of Boston. We all know that the mayoral race is in October, I mean in November, and we have two candidates and we're living right in the heart of Boston and we want to see change. So, that's all we're really going to talk about. We're not going to talk about anything that you don't want to. I'm just going to go around, there are five participants, and with me, makes six.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: I'm going to be recording this conversation because this is going to be transcribed and it's completely confidential. So you could either use your real name or you could make up a name, doesn't matter. But in the order that I'm going to call on people will be... Who wants to go first? Like this, or like this? Doesn't matter? That way? Okay. So we'll start through the left. And first of all, I'm going to go around and have everybody consent to their being recorded and just say your name, whatever name you choose, you don't have to give your real name. Does that make sense?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. As a participant, this conversation you're providing consent for the Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the Real Talk for Change conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media to improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations and keep with the mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say "I agree." Conversation agreement, confirm with participants.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay, one thing that I want to tell you is that after this you'll get a... After this, in a couple days, you'll get access to this link that you can go back and hear this conversation, but you could also hear other people's conversations of what other people are saying across Boston, which is quite interesting. Okay so this is a centering activity so we are going to go around and this time we're going to start with Nelson. We're going to go around and we're going to do a PIES check in, and I'll explain, a PIES check-in, pies like a pie that you eat, is people...

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: We understand that people are social and emotional people, right? In human beings. So everybody's going to check in and I'm going to model how I want people to check in. It's either physical, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. And then when you're finished and when with... and when you're finished, you'll say "And with that, I am in." So you just going to have to check in with one of the four, if you're spiritually, intellectually, emotionally, or... Intellectually. So today I am spiritually... No, emotionally, I'm going to check in emotionally.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So my name is [Jackie], like I said earlier, and I had a situation that my feelings were kind of hurt yesterday, but I'm trying to deal with it, and he was here at work and I'm trying to like deal with it. So I'm not, we're not going to get into a story, just say what's going on for you right now. So, today I am very emotional about that because I really couldn't sleep because I needed to get this off my chest, but I'm glad to be here today and I'm glad that you guys are joining me. And with that, I am in.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: Well, a little bit uncomfortable. Like my muscles are not as flex, not as stretchy as I want them to be. I want my muscles to be really stretchy.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Can you tell me a little bit about why you chose spiritually? Or you could change, you could pick another one.

nodes.speaker: Verna
nodes.words: Yes, Jackie. Me is spiritually because I've been, before I was distanced from like not reading the Bible, not praying like I used to, but now I'm reading a book. Like I did read before, now I'm back with where I am with God, my relationship with God.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you so much. Thank you so much, everybody. So, this is an exercise that I just learned a few weeks ago and this is basically just to think that we're all human beings. We're all in that we are... Everybody's at a different place, right? Some of us are aggravated, some of us are emotional or physically going through stuff. So everybody's going through something, but at a different point [inaudible]. So that's just to help us remember and be mindful that everybody's at a different place, right?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. So my question is... So this is something that I just want you to think about. I want you to just think about this and that's it.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Oh because this conversation only needs to happen with this group. Okay so I want you to just think about a question. This is the question, I'm going to put out a question but I only want you to think about it. I don't want you to give me the response to it.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: And I'm going to give you a couple minutes to think about this okay? And then we'll come back. So the question is... We'll start with... We started with, or we'll start with Verna, but I just want you to think about a question. So the question is, what is your question about the future of Boston? What is your question about the future of Boston? Think about this to yourself and your place in it. Like really think about what is your place in the future of Boston and your place in it and I'll give you a couple of minutes to think about that. (silence)

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So just to be clear, you're going to think about a question. You're going to create a question in your own head of what's your place in the future of Boston, and your place in it. (silence)

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay? You thought about the question? Now, my next question with that is what experience in your life got you to this question? Does that make sense? So the question that you thought of, I don't want an answer or anything right now, for the question that you thought of, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? And then I want you to think about what experience in your life got you to this question and we could start with Miss Verna. What's a question and your experience with it?

nodes.speaker: Verna
nodes.words: I mean, I used to live in Cambridge and I went and come back and live in Boston. I hope Boston is great like when I first come in this country. I hope Boston is good place for affordable housing, a good place for people to live.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Thank you. What about you Miss Sarah? What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? And can you please tell me what's your experience? What experience in your life got you to this question?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Yeah I suppose. What's your question about Boston? Well, you can think about that and we could come back to you. Mr. Reggie, what's your question about Boston and your place in it?

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: I was wondering about the rail the past couple of days... For the last couple of years, has been problems with it.

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: The last couple years have been problems with the transportation, and I was wondering what it's going to take to fix that?

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: With the MBTA and I was just wondering what it's going to take to fix that and how much is it going to cost? That's what I was curious about. It's a serious thing.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? And the real question is, what's your experience? So you think about this question, about the future of Boston, but why do you think about that particular question? Your experience around it.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: Well, I've lived in Boston on again, off again for 20 years and I always enjoy the restaurants and shops. And I just wanted to see that they stay... the current restaurants and shops that are open, stay open. And some of the restaurants and shops that had closed over the years maybe come back, like Tower Records, Strawberries, Urban Outfitters, places like that come back.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: I don't know. I just thought it added to appeal to Boston. It was kind of mystical or those stores like... Well, the music scene kind of doesn't become just the radio. People have... Can buy albums and buy music for their homes and apartments.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: I thought you talking like you asking the mayor a question. If you asking the mayor a question, that's the way.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So I've heard of... Thank you. I've heard a few things in common, and now the next part to this is find someone whose questions and experience resonates with your own. Okay? Address that person and tell them why the question and the experience resonates with you, and share your story from your life that connects with that person experience. Does that make sense?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Oh, I forgot. Miss Sarah, you never had a question. What's your question about the future of Boston in your place in it? Okay. All right. One thing I want everybody to remember is remember where you're living at right now, and how that right this moment and how that affects you. Okay? Does that make sense? Okay. Now we had some people talk about transportation, some people talk about the other situations that they've been in. So please choose somebody and...

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: Because Cambridge request Boston to work with them, but Boston's refusing to do that. So the housing in Boston, like I agree with her. She said needs be changed.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: It effects because if I'm working the day before and I'm out there, I have to stand outside like all day. Even if you try to lay down take a nap, next thing you know you got the police or the security telling you "Wake up. You can't sleep over here." So the mayor of Boston should take over the shelters like Cambridge. The city of Cambridge controls the shelters.

nodes.speaker: Verna
nodes.words: I do not like it, but it is get me out of the bed and take a shower, go outside for a walk. But if they let me in, I would be sleeping all day and be depressed.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: Me, the only thing like I used to live in Cambridge like she did. I didn't go to jail, but I'm homeless in Boston like she is. She's concerned about housing, I'm concerned about housing.

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: Yeah. I just... just some days that you don't have any place to go. You don't want to stick around. You don't want to motor anywhere. You don't want to take it to the seriousness so that... So some of it, I think something should have to be done.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: But you got to have a referral and right now they [crosstalk] not taking a lot of people in because the Coronavirus, so whoever there already it's lucky, like you, but everybody else is not.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: So you have a place to go, but everybody else don't have a place to go. That's why I'm saying the shelter should change. You know that because... and I'm not, if I'm wrong, I'm wrong, but I was told that they get paid too for people to stay in that place. I don't know if the shelter gets paid or the people in [inaudible] actually charge money to the state. That's what I was being told so I don't know if it is wrong, I don't know if it's right, and I was told this by a state rep.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: You have nothing to apologize for. Could anybody else relate to what other people are saying? And if so, could you speak directly to them and share your experience?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So that's why I'm trying to get people to actually like communicate with each other. So what's going on with you and your experience in Boston? Miss Stephanie talked about transportation. We talked about homelessness. Miss Sarah?

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Yeah. So what about the police department? We talked about [crosstalk] we talked about discrimination. Can anybody relate to what Reggie's saying? Not Reggie, Nelson. Sorry.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: Yeah. I mean if they're going to have hours like that where you have to be out of the shelter, they should at least have some picnic tables or something outside. They do have a couple of tables there, but they have that locked up and then people are just sitting on the curb and [crosstalk]

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: But a lot of people don't smoke and that's a smoking area. So if you don't smoke, you are not going to go sit there. They should have a non-smoking area, smoking area, but they only have a smoking area which people are comfortable with.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: Okay. So what are you hearing from people's experiences as we're talking around here? What are you hearing? And I have to hear it from you before I say something. So what are you hearing for what this group is saying? Or not saying.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: Yeah. I think it's mostly about the shelter and the homeless and the housing. To me, it's not much transportation because I have a car, I have a motorcycle, so it doesn't really matter to me.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: So I know it's on the news about train derailing and all that and the guy got... was getting charged or something like that, so on the green line.

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: Problem with transportation, homelessness, how things are regulated, how shelters and stuff are regulated. Also, asking what the solution is, what the solutions are, and being a certain way, would it effect them every day by these things.

nodes.speaker: Verna
nodes.words: I'm hearing about transportation, housing, police, and stuff. Well, take it a day at a time. That's what I do. I don't let things bother me because I have major depression so I have to... and pray about things and be patient and stuff. Things could change because I don't have... Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: It's about everybody that's talking about the homeless, the police, the transportation. And then somebody's talking about exercising, about all the issues that's going around it. I guess the only... because the one with the exercise, she said that she had the issues stretching so she has a problem with that. I have a problem with the police department. She has a problem with the housing. He has a problem with transportation so we all have a problem with different things.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: And how it... So what I'm really trying to get to is like the connection, and the connection between all of this.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: The police treat homeless with a certain way, stereotype. Within the transportation too, if he complains too much, they going to call the cops on him and kick him out of the train station. The yoga, I don't know. I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Nelson
nodes.words: I guess the yoga, you can ease your mind about everything that's going around you. Right? So they all connected. I think.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: So what are your takeaways? Miss Sarah, you haven't said much in this conversation. What is your takeaway or any thoughts of what's been said here?

nodes.speaker: Reginald
nodes.words: That it was talked about when the subject came out, where if it wasn't like this, it wouldn't. So I think that's the first stop, is talking about it, being aware of what's happening. And you could find yourself for whatever's happening to go with it to the best of your ability [crosstalk] for success, for it to be successful. Meaning if it's going to be like that, all the rules are there now and try to be patient.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: Well, I just happened to think of religion too. Like going to church, saying prayers, seemed like it was a little bit more like that 10 years ago or so and people got so political.

nodes.speaker: Stephanie
nodes.words: Well like he was saying, the police are kind of brutally honest and... I don't know. I liked going to Catholic church. I usually go to Catholic church, but I'm not really near a Catholic church.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: All right. So we'll prompt to a conclusion and I really, really want to thank you for sharing your lived experiences and your faith takeaways and closing thoughts. So we talked about like homelessness and this was kind of the transportation disparities. We've talked about the discrimination and police force and how people are being treated. We've noticed that some people are like spiritual and still wanting some of that, and for that, we are blessed. And I just wanted to remind you that this whole conversation was being recorded, and I'm going to pass around the demographics sheets and if you need help filling them out, please is let me know. If you don't have an email address or you have a phone, or if you don't have a phone, you have an email address, or if you don't have either, just let me know so I can help you out with this.

nodes.speaker: Jackie
nodes.words: You should be receiving... Let me read this. Thank you for participating in the Real Talk for Change conversation and gratitude for the time you spent with us. We would like to give you a gift card. In order to receive this gift card, please provide us with, for name and email. And if we don't have that, do we... Huh? [inaudible] And by next week you shall... By next Saturday, y'all should have it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And I think, [Loren] has definitely broke it down to everybody. And so as we're recording, we really don't need to have pictures because we're going to be just keeping your voices and stuff like that. And so what I want to do start with, as a participant in this conversation, okay, you're providing consent to Real Talk For Change, to use or retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection on Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations and keep them with that mission. In addition, part of Real Talk For Change mission is to present voices from the people of Boston, therefore portions of your conversation can be made public. So if you guys understand... if you understand it, just say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Good. And I'm kind of... the script in front of me I'm kind of reading from, some of the things here. They say that you have an option to use another name as part of this discussion, if you want. So you can use a pseudo name if you want and just let us know how, or if you do, but you let us we know now and then all of you go through [inaudible]. So then at the end, I'm going to ask you for-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: No problem. All right, so at the end of the conversation, I'm going to ask you to help us capture some of the simple demographic information by completing an online form and we'll do this right before the end of the meeting. And well, I'll talk to you a little bit more about it when we get to that point. So before we get started, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation and to support those goals, we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. One, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, okay? Two, allow others to speak for themselves, okay? Three, share time, all right? Allow others to finish speaking and take turns.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So basically one at a time. Stay curious and basically ask honest questions and so I assume you all will and take time for reflections. And so we will have... we don't want to be feeling pressured that we have to respond right away or answer everything right away. Take a little time for reflection and then the best stuff will come up. All right. Any questions on any of that? Okay. All right, so just to get started, we kind of do like a centering activity, I'm going to cut my [inaudible] here now. We want to do a centering activity and so... the key thing is that we want to make sure that everybody is present for this conversation. And so we want if you guys to go around and do a quick introduction and check in, all right.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: And basically what we're doing, we're using the PIES check in. So I don't know if any guys... any of you are familiar with the PIES check in?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. So basically we want you to sort of say, like I had a... I don't know, I had a good day spiritually today, and I'm really feeling proud of the universe and stuff. So I'm going to check in spiritually, I'm here, I'm ready to go, I'm all in. That's kind of a check-in. We have basically the PIES check-ins are physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually. And so however you want you can put those together as some people do and stuff like that. So basically, we want you to reflect for a minute and say, as you're introducing yourself or after introducing yourself, or you introduce yourself and say on what level you're going to check in and be present and centered in this activity. All right. So, let's see how to start. I think, how about Becky, you want to start?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I mean, it looks like you're doing okay. I mean, I can see when you talk, to your square and I think just about everybody is got their video off.

nodes.speaker: Wayne
nodes.words: Yes. My name is Wayne. I have an excellent day. I woke up this morning, God is merciful and I'm looking forward tomorrow. Amen.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: All right. My name is Terrance Williams, from Mission Hill. And I'm checking in because I'm here. But thanks to All Mighty, and in him, hopefully I'm here tomorrow and brotherly love.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. Thank you. Thank you. Let's see, anybody else? Or is that everybody? One, two, three, four, five, we got one more. So, what do you think, Becky? You good to go?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I'm good to go. I'm checking in Becky Hope. I'm blessed and I'm glad to hear everybody is invited here and thanks brother for inviting me in.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. Good to have you here. Okay. You did a good job here. All right. So now... Who's here? And I don't know, have you guys been out since the pandemic supposedly ended and then got started again or something? How's everybody sort of getting through? Everybody getting through this, all right?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: There you go. Okay. This is up. So take a couple minutes and write this down somewhere, if that feels helpful, okay? But the first part of this is, think about Boston and your future in it. Think about the future of Boston and what do you think your future in it, in terms of where it's going, how it's flowing and what is a question that you have about that or have about where it's going, about your future in it, about where you're going, as far as Boston is concerned. Think of a question that you would want to have answered regarding your place in Boston and your future as far as Boston is concerned.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So just take a couple minutes and think about that. And I'd like you to write down the question, I think it's good to sort of center that. I mean, yeah. So I think it's helpful to write down, think of your question and write it down so that you can make sure you get it specifically. Sometimes if you don't write it down, you might change it a little bit and everything like that. Write it down. So I'm going to give you a minute or two to think about it. I don't know. When everybody is done, when you're done, just let me know, and then once everybody is done [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Okay. Yeah, just hold on one second. I want everybody to get their questions done and then we have one other part to it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: How you doing? Okay, Joe. Okay. So, Joe, you missed a little of the beginnings of it, but what I want you to do is think of the question that you want to have answered regarding the future of Boston and your place in it. What sort of thing you concerned about that you would like answered regarding just that. The future of Boston and your place as it pertains to you and who you are and who your family is, relationship with your creator or however you see that. What is the fundamental question you like to have answered? Take a couple of minutes to do that. And then everybody, I want to have you guys think of an experience, okay? That defines or that informs from where that question came from.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: In other words, why have you chose this question? What was the catalyst for choosing that particular question, okay? All right. So, and then-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So what we're going to do now is that I want you to say what your question is, all right, and then I want you to explain what is the experience that you've had that brings you to that question, that is the catalyst or that informs the reason why that's an important, serious question for you, all right? So, I think Wayne, you said you were ready to go?

nodes.speaker: Wayne
nodes.words: My question is where's going to be the affordable housing for our people? Because I can't afford a condo. I'm disability so I make so much money. I get so much money a month. So, and another thing, what are they going to do about Mass Ave, all that craziness going over there?

nodes.speaker: Wayne
nodes.words: Okay. My experience, when I used to go to Boston Medical and as you have a... I go there, and every time I go in the bathroom, I'm seeing somebody shooting drugs. So I had to change hospitals because that's disgusting. I came here, sit down at the bus stop, I'm a disability, so I hurt sometimes, I got to sit down. They took all the seats because before the guys used to sit there and shoot drugs and do everything else there. So, that's crazy. That's real talk.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. All right. So, let's go with Terrance, you want to tell us your question and then tell us your experience that brought you to that question? Terrance Williams? Hello, Terrance.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: Yeah. My question is when is black folks going to get out and really vote? And when are we going to stop killing each other?

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: What brought me to the issue of when we're going to get out to vote is, first, me, myself, when I ran for city council for District 4, we have over 75,000 registered voters in that district and less than 3% came out to vote. Here it is 2013 and even this election, we have black candidates running for mayor. We're never going to have a black mayor because we don't come out to vote. We think that presidential election is more important than the local election. The one that has 98% effect of your life and you stay home and you wonder why we're in predicament that we're in now. And why when we do have black candidates we don't support, we leave them out to dry. We can't just put them in office and then turn around and then leave them.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: No, if we put them in office, we have to stand by their side. If we want change, that's the only way things are going to get done, because if we go crying to them, ask them for change, and they go... before we start asking for change, but we're behind the wall saying, yeah, yeah, yeah, go, go, go. We know we're with you all the way, but we're too busy hiding from them then you know what I mean? We ain't going to have change.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: As far as us killing ourself, I mean, we can't keep saying the cops are killing us, when we're killing ourself. When we stand together and stop killing ourself, then the cops are going to stop killing us, because they're going to feel intimidated because we all going bond together and say, no, eye for an eye, tooth for tooth or life for a life. I mean, that's what we have to do. We have to come together as a people and say enough is enough. We're losing our generations. And our doctors, our lawyers, our technicians, those are our babies out there, that we're looting.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: And if they don't think that they have a chance because we're not showing them that they have a chance to survive, then we know we're crazy. I mean, Harriet Tubman said the best, "I freed a thousand slaves, we will free a thousand more only if they knew they were slaves."

nodes.speaker: Frank
nodes.words: No. Someone else can go next. Reason being is that both individual had great questions and just listening to them threw me off the minds. So give me a second.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. No problem. No problem. I mean, I think that I want to hope people... I mean, I think you have types of issues and stuff that whatever is close to you is what we want to hear, you know what I'm saying? I mean, I think it's important that we don't make assumptions about the questions that they ask that yours isn't important. I mean, I think, we have to make sure that we listen to everybody and allow everybody a voice. That's what part of this is. But let's see, Joe, I know you just got here, are you ready? Did you come up with a question and then why you came to that question? Are you ready or what do you think?

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Yeah, I think its real sad about the black on black crime and I'm really sick of it. Our people really need to stick together and stop acting foolish and come together. Think about what our aunt, sisters and everything went through in slavery and everything. You would think our race would be the main one that stick together out of everybody. But, we're not doing that though. We too busy, jealous, killing one another in everything, and I'm tired of it.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I think we need to have more businesses, come together man and let's put our heads together, man. Let's try to build, let's try to get some black businesses going, stick together most of all. We need to come together. And like I said, stop all the foolishness time out for all that. This is 2021, bad enough. The cops killed a lot of us just last year, come on. And then we doing it to one another too, come on. That don't make sense. That's all I got to say, man.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: This next thing is... I mean, I'm trying to see if Becky is ready. I was trying to see if she's ready to do her answer and her question.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Well, my questions is pretty much the same as all the other, was the violence and just not sticking together. It seems like it's just a different day and the same problems and we're not getting anywhere. So it can be depressing.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Give me example. Give total example on what makes you feel that it's getting worse and that it's kind of... I mean, yeah, give me an example, why you kind of feel like we're going in the wrong direction and it's not good or better or whatever?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I'm not sure if this because of the COVID it seems like we're on the standstill, not moving and I'm not sure I can give you example, just it's a lot of things, seems like we should be further along than we are.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: It just seems like we should be further along like things as to me, I mean it might be just me.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. So what's happening on a day to day basis, you know what I'm saying? Your experience that brings you to this? How is everyday in your day to day experience that makes you feel that we're not progressing and stuff?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Well, just looking around with all the work is going on, it's not us out there. It's more of other people doing the work that's within Boston and we're here. And it's not getting better. It's just all the contract, not us. It's not us out there and there's so much work is going on.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Oh, you're talking about the fact that all these contracts and all these money being paid to some business and to some contracts and we're not getting?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So I'm trying to get an idea from people's personal experiences, why these questions have become important for you to have answers. I mean your...

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Well, you see that in our community. I mean, if you can just drive around, you see that in our community. You all see a lot of construction work is going on and we're not being a part of it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. Okay. Well, what's your question and what has led you to this question? What is your experience according you to that question?

nodes.speaker: Frank
nodes.words: Well, my concern is the same as everyone else, in terms of working, personal experience, what's going on in my community, the violence. I personally think that... So a lot of that, I think is hopelessness. We see it so much, it just basically wears you out. This topic that we're having, we already had. Well, the things that everyone spoke about is something that I think we all has been dealing with for many years. So I think that I experiencing it for so long and not seeing it being resolved or get any better, I think that it makes us feel hopeless. I'm assuming you're Mel King son, right?

nodes.speaker: Frank
nodes.words: Yeah. Okay. So your father have been carrying on pretty good fight. Remember when he ran for mayor and you would think all the hard work he had put out things would be better. So you wouldn't be having this discussion, but here we are, I mean the same discussion. So my personal opinion is that I think you get to a point where it wears you down and makes you feel hopeless. I think what we probably need is some hope, a breath of fresh air. One of the things someone comment on, is the voting and everyone concentrate on the presidential vote. I think, I'm not speaking for him, but I think in my mind, when Obama was running, we were hopeful. "Wow, things are getting better." And I think that's what we need in our community right here in Boston. We don't see things are getting better. We're not feeling it. So, we're kind of in the dumps a little bit. So I think we need a rare hope.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. All right. So, at this point, this is kind part where we can sort of share each other's and talk about what resonate with something what other people said resonating. Some of that has happened already, but I want to go around again and say, what is it that resonated with you? That's one of your other people who's sharing this conversation they said. So anybody want to start with saying what has resonated-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: So basically at this juncture, what we do is we want you to talk about what maybe the other people have said, what is relating to you? What has struck a nerve with you that somebody else has spoke about? Say what that is and give us what that somebody else in here seems to live, because you guys are somewhat on track with each other. What is relatable to you that somebody else has talked about and just take it from there? Anybody on?

nodes.speaker: Frank
nodes.words: Yes. Everything, everything, everyone have hit the nail on the head and once again, like I said, I feel that we're in a hopeless situation and I feel that we just need a rare hope. We need to see good things happening. We need to probably see our next door neighbor doing good, so we know, "Oh, okay. Hi, wow." One thing about me is that if I'm accomplishing things and getting better, I want... in my business, if I'm making money, everyone else is making money with me, all my employees got to grow with me. So I don't have a problem bringing people along because I know where we're there's so much more we can actually do. And I know for fact, you can't run a business by yourself, so you have to bring people along. You're making money, they should make money. The more money your company make, the more money your employee should. It's better for everyone.

nodes.speaker: Frank
nodes.words: You just can't be on top of the hill by yourself. You need other people with you. You need people to share it with. So I think we need, like I said, back to my original, I think we just need a rare of hope. But I think, so what everyone said, definitely struck a nerve with me in terms of the violence, definitely. I hear it and it's sickening and I hate to say I got kids and I'm always concern of that about them, even though they're grown men and they're adults, but I am concerned. I would not want to experience what another parent is experiencing. So those, like I said, everyone is right on track and that's it.

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: Okay. I agree with Mr. Alfred said, we need hope. I think the violence need to stop. It'd be nice more jobs, more of us need to try to like I said, stick together. We just all need to try to unite, man and try to come together, man and try to build and try to get things going like Mr. Alfred was saying. A lot of us need trays under our belts and we just need to stop the violence, man. We shouldn't have to go out our doors being scared our kids, we have kids that is a concern and that's something you have to put into consideration because bullets don't know nobody, but most of all, we need hope like Mr. Alfred was saying.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Well, a second Terrance. Someone is on a bus, if you could, while you're not talking, you might that way whatever is around you. All right, Terrance, go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: Okay. So with Methadone Mile, Methadone Mile to me is a disaster that will never... well I'm not going to say never, well, won't be fixed for a long, long time. Because when you have the government giving people drugs and you expect them to come off of drugs, it's never going to happen. And that's why you got folks coming from other parts of the city into Boston, because the other parts of the city are not feeding them drugs, are not giving them that methadone, are not letting them just do what they want to do. Here we have other cities like [inaudible] and [inaudible] that said, "Listen, no, y'all, can't come over here with that. We're not helping." But some of those are their people. It's a shame that folks are like that, but they're like by choice.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: And we as residents of the city of Boston have to endure what's going on down here. We have to be careful when we walk down there to make sure that we don't step on needles. We have to make sure when we take our kids to the parks, they don't pick up a needle. And that's why I said, if black folks come together, together, we can get things done, because there is a way to clean up, we have to stop feeding them drugs. You know what? If one of us get caught selling drugs, we're going to jail. So why does the government give a pass?

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: We have to figure, "Okay, what's going on?" Because I tell people, any politician who's running for office tells you that they're going to clean up Methadone Mile, is lying to you. I'm just going to be real honest, they're lying to you because that's why they have the cop staying here at Southampton Street, because they can't do that unto them. That's why they build a camp, that's a public sidewalk, so they can be there freely. They're out there. And the thing about it is you have drug dealers who are amongst them selling their drugs. You have shops over there at South Bay that I don't understand how they're still in business when them junkies going over there rob them every single day. And security guards can't do nothing about it because of the police reform bill.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: And that's why I tell people, when you hear the police reform bill... that's why people should understand what the police reform bill is. Everybody thinks the police reform bill was set up in their mind to go in there and dismantle the police department so we just have a whole total reform. That's not what the police reform bill is. I tell people, you got to read it. The police reform bill going to hurt a whole lot of black security businesses. The police reform bill is something that was put there and they include everybody who has the power to detain, arrest, whatever it is of police power, because now you can't even touch somebody as a security guard because you can get sued.

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: So if a junkie is robbing the store on that, all of that you can say is, "You got to put that back. You got to put that back. You got to put that back." You can't even touch him. And that's why we have to really look. We know when we start asking for stuff, be careful what you ask for, be careful. And we have elected officials talking about defund the police. If you're talking about defunding the police and you're running for mayor, then you need to answer this one question, since you want to defund the police so bad, that means are you want to give up your detail security, which are police officers or your 24 hour security around your house to protect you and your family, are you going to give that up?

nodes.speaker: Terrance
nodes.words: Because what's going to happen, when you defund the security that some of us who are homeowners and we rely on, when we call that 911, the police isn't going to show up. It's not going to have that. Everybody has a scenario, oh no, this is what they should do with the defunding, blah, blah, blah. But that's not what they put into the bill. You have to be careful about what you're asking for and what you're signing on because just because you hear somebody else out there, wild roaring, roaring you better make sure you what they're roaring about because that can affect your life.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Well, Terrance say something important that I need to check in, in about defunding the police. That kind of hit me by surprise because we definitely have to get educated in the bills and the laws they're trying to pass. That kind of resonated with me, make me definitely need to do my homework because we get all into this roar, roar and not really fully informed. Well, I'm talking for myself. So we have to be really informed of what we're asking for and how it's going to affect us. So that really stopped me in my track.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Well, because most of the time we're busy running, running, running and doing... Well, I don't like to say we, and we get caught up in the middle of it trying to survive. And many things is going on that then we're not really educated, fully involved in the things that can affect us. So when he said that kind of taking me back, because... and that's not just that, well, a lot of things that we have to really get involved in what's going on and affect this locally and nationally. Hello.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: I'm Just trying to get... I'm hearing somebody is traveling on the bus while on this call. I was just trying to say all of us should, while we're not talking mute our mic, so that the sound from whatever you're doing or wherever you are doesn't fit into the audio when everybody is hearing, is on the call. That's one of the only thing about the system, is that you have to mute your own mic when you're not talking, all right. Well, that was pretty good. I mean, I liked what you said, Becky, I mean that was a good response. Anybody else have anything they want to share before we wrap up? I think everybody...

nodes.speaker: Joe
nodes.words: I just want to say I totally agree with Terrance was saying. I totally agree with that because he's absolutely right.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: All right. Just before you guys leave, I want to try one of the things that we want to be able to do, if you agree, and that is, so that we want to have good demographics. So we want to understand who's on these calls, some demographic information. Communities they got the script that they gave me to do this, and they say I'm supposed to give you this demographic forms. So let's see if I can find that and then let me see...

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And I just want to welcome everybody to our time together, the Real Talk For Change conversation. And I am doing this work for Real Talk For Change, and Real Talk For Change is a movement that will amplify voices of people in the city of Boston who aren't typically heard. And so this will be a space where you can speak about things that are on your mind, that you want to see something happen to and feel like one, you're being heard, understanding that a collective effort can make those things happen.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So without further ado, I'm going to be sort of reading some of this from a script, and then we will get into our time together. Okay. So again, welcome to the call and I can see everybody, this is a wonderful thing, and I'm just going to request that if you have other devices that are going to distract you to please sort of turn them off or whatever. And then we'll just go from there.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, we invited you to this gathering by asking you to think of one most pressing question you have about the future of the city of Boston. Our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in a conversation with each other. Thank you for agreeing to add your experience to the growing chorus of Bostonians who want to speak and listen, and be listened to, and knowing that it matters.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I am going to just let you know that this call is being recorded, so... the purpose of this conversation, we want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across the divides, and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates and the future mayor and the neighborhoods throughout the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your position on the upcoming election or... or your own perspective about it. Okay? We're doing this to help build connections and to foster conversations that will improve our understanding of each other. All right? So... that was like the first thing.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Secondly, I want to address what will happen with the recording of this conversation. Following our meeting today, the video recording of this will be discarded, and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. These conversations along with all other conversations across the city of Boston that are taking place will be shared with members of the Real Talk For Change team, and others who have participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network, which is LVN. So if I say "LVN," that's what it is. Local Voices Network.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: LVN is a Web-based tool that accesses and explores conversations designed by the nonprofit organization Cortico. LVN's system creates a transcript for each recorded and uploads both the transcripts and audio recording to the explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge from different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voice Network, which mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Perfect, perfect. Okay. Thirdly, before we wrap up this session, you... you will fill in a form with your name and email address so that we can send you your gift card. We have also included a section with demographic information, which is optional. This, the reason we are asking for this information is for us to be able to reflect and uplift the voices of diverse communities and different demographics.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Please only respond to the questions you are comfortable with. Hold on one second, someone's ringing my bell. Hm, hm. Hey [Yvie]!

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So [crosstalk]... all right. And so lastly I'm just going to give you some guidelines and some housekeeping rules for our time together on here, okay? So first... What happened to Carol? Carol?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Okay. Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, right? These are the guidelines for this conversation. Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. So no cutting nobody off or try to finish their sentence. Everybody has their own opinion, their own thoughts. That's it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Stay curious and ask honest questions. Five, pause, take time for reflection. And number six, we're going to listen generously, assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. Seven one possible clue, those unnecessary programs, applications, and notifications, and put your phone on silent. If you need to take a moment, take a break, let the facilitator know in the chat. Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yes? Okay, cool. All right. For the ease of the virtual conversation, we will begin to use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn. I will help transition us from one person to another. You can always pass or ask for us to come back to you. To begin, we want a quick round of introductions and check in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Please share your first name and where you are located right now. Then, let us know how you are using the PIES check-in. This means saying how you are choosing to check in using one of the following. So when you check in, you will check in either physically, you will check in intellectually, you can check in emotionally, or you can check in spiritually. And as soon as that's done, then just say, "And with that, I'm in," and then we can just pass it on. Okay? Does anybody have any questions about that process?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So I guess I will begin just to model how it's done. So PIES again is just the acronyms for our physically, intellectually, emotionally, and spiritually, and that's how we're checking in. So first thing is your name. So I am Marilyn Foreman and I am... I am located right now in my front room of the house. And I am checking in... I want to say emotionally today, because I feel like I got a whole lot of stuff going on, so I'm really trying to categorize my emotions.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So right now I have, I'm like in one place with it, but I feel like I'm also worrying about some other stuff that should be happening and I'm not sure that it's happening to my satisfaction. But anyway, and with that I am in. And I am going to pass it off to Carol.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Okay. I'm Carol and I'm in my living room. And I'm checking in... spiritually. I woke up this morning spiritually as always in a spiritually mood. As always, I check in with Him first.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: And that's how I start my day. So... that's the way I start off always, and so that's the way I am today.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Good morning, everyone. I'm Charlette checking in from Dorchester, my front porch. I'll check in spiritually. I am feeling rather calm today. And I meditated before we had this talk. I wasn't sure how it was going to go or if I was ready for it since just coming out of school forums and Zooms, but I took care of myself spiritually so I feel like I'm here and I'm present. So with that I'm here.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: Oh, hello. I'm Yvette. I'm calling from my living room, I guess I'm I'm spiritually also feeling good also, feeling good. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Perfect. Good. Now that we know who's here, let us get into the core of our conversation. So as we shared the restrictions of the pandemic, it would be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about inequality in America and Boston and how our lived experience have been shaped by that learning.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think, what is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? So take a few minutes to think about what I just said about that, what you're going to do next. Right? So... does everybody understand that? What is your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So reflecting back, like that pandemic that we just... we're really not out of it, but that pandemic and what has happened, and all of the things that rose to the top for you about what the city of Boston had to offer or didn't offer or what came out of it for you, and the question is, what is your question that you would want to ask about the future of Boston and then your place in it?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And this is reflecting on your own lived experience, not on somebody else's or what you saw, but for you. What is your question? So I'll give you about a minute or so to ponder that, and we'll look for those responses. Okay, so I will start with Miss Charlette.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Okay. So the question I have is for Boston is, are we going to finally take a look at mental health and what it's doing across the city? And for me just being a recent graduate for mental health counseling, I see myself in the community working with different organizations or agencies, trying to rid the stigma of having a mental health disorder or issues.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: I see that is a concern from the pandemic as well, where people were quarantined and people are usually on the go and commuting and the hustle and bustle and the connection with people in your office or wherever you went from day to day. So I see the present health concern of mental health and the stability of its Boston residents, that it should be brought to the forefront of the table, because if we can't start from within ourselves, how can we build community? How can we keep the neighborhoods together? How can we unify?

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: It's like they really have to take notice that this is something that has to be put on the agenda or the program, or however the candidates are leading to press Boston residents. This has to be up in the top five.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: Well, I can... I'm [crosstalk] also going to ask the same question about the mental health of the youth due to the pandemic, because I feel like... And not just the youth, but the young adults too, because they're kind of lost in transition. And I feel like nobody... I'm not, I won't say "nobody," but I feel like there's not enough guidance. And I feel like there's not enough support. And it's very hard to like navigate yourself through systems that are kind of shut down.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: And crime. Crime is going, getting out of control. People are just killing each other, robbing, stealing, and things are just out of control, the destruction of life that's going on in the city. They're just not even getting right. Really. That's why I, is how I start my day off spiritually for me, but just being in the city, they're not really even paying attention to, like I said, with the schools. So we've got to start out with the children first, which is where I'd like to start. Get that.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Take a look into that. I mean and the crime is just rising. It really has to be paid attention to, truly.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay, great. Thank you so much. Yvette. What is your question about the future in the city of Boston and your place in that future?

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: Wow. I don't know. I guess like after the pandemic, how do we get back to life altogether? Everything is all messed up. There's like, I mean, there's no resources available. You just feel lost. Throughout this whole pandemic and everything, being shut down and being isolated, mental health has gotten real. And that's why I had to take myself and get out, because I think that I would've been one of the people that really got crazy because of this. Because you just, you thought you knew a lot of things before the pandemic, and then everything was like, "I don't know. I don't know. I don't know." So how do you recover from all these "I don't knows"? You just feel lost.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Well, thank you for sharing your questions with us. Now, I'd like to invite you to think, what experience in your life got you to that question? And I know that in part of your responses, you kind of answered that, but just elaborate a little bit more just so that we can, you know, kind of categorize it. So again, what experience in your life got you to this question?

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: The experience that I feel got question pondering for me about the mental health is that it's always been a plague for black, brown, and even white counterparts to really, and truly, reveal that you do have a little slight... disorder. And for that, for myself, I've never been diagnosed with it, but I know firsthand just by looking all around that our people need help.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Even starting from within my own household, even starting from within the family, like I've noticed so much from doing all the readings and the research and all that. It's like, it's really there, but why was that always frowned upon that this is the buildup that's going to burst as to why nothing got done about it, or people didn't know how to speak to their physicians or just bring it out.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And that's not always a good way to rear children or young youth, because it's like, "All right, so what do I tell? What do I not? But I still need this help." So it's, I don't know, it's always been so confusing, but when it happened for my child, I made sure to do everything that I could. And even though I wasn't an advocate for mental health at that time, I knew that it was something that was real.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Even though I don't like the way that it was brought up from the school system, because sometimes people don't have of empathy for ways that they deliver messages. So it was kind of, you get on the defense first, before you really accept what was being said about your child or what they noticed.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: So that needs to be taken account of, like a revamp for those resources in the school to get them some kind of training as well when they deliver those kind of messages to parents about their observance of their student or that person's child. But yeah, so mental health is still really a big forefront because if you don't have sense of self, everything around you is going to always be in pieces.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: So you start in there to get those pieces together so that you can have the coping skills, you can have mechanisms that you can reach for and resources for people that you can reach out to. So, that's my main concern. And to piggyback off with Ms. Carol, the crime is really getting ridiculous. I sat here the other night, and I did hear that those 25 shots that that person got dumped in the other day up on Walk Hill.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And I could sit... I was sitting on the couch and I heard each shot and I said, "Oh my goodness." I didn't know where it came from, but to find out that it came from Walk Hill, that's still a distance from me. Like how did I hear that?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: So the experience that led me to that question, I would say specifically because of the pandemic, we were shut out and I feel like my child experienced, like, she missed the social interaction and became... she was always kind of lazy, but became super lazy. Like just a different child, like, "I don't even know who you are and you're here every day" type thing.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: And then also for me, also the social interaction, which I feel like I lost out on before the pandemic, because I had a baby and just stuff was changing. And not having access to specific resources to help myself move forward because people just go to work and go to work and just go to work.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: But when you're unhappy and you go to work, you don't want to go to work because I don't want to do that. That's not something that I want to do, so I don't want to go there. So then that was a depression, I fell into a very deep, dark depression because of that, because I knew that that's not what I want to do. You know? Like this is, "I don't want to do this. I don't want to go there. I don't want to talk to these people. I don't want to look at them. I don't want to see them," and I became very closed off.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: And then I'm trying to insert myself back into the regular world, and I see that it's not normal, it's not regular. People are just not the same. And it, to me, I don't think it ever will be. And I feel like the resources are very minimum, and... yeah.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Sure. What experience in your life got you to that question? The question that we started off with about the future of Boston. So what experience in your life did you have that kind of got you to that question?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Okay. Okay. Okay. So I'm going to go back to what Charlette was speaking on as well about the mental health. And it goes back to family with mental health. I raised a son with special needs. And during this pandemic, my son is now 27 years old. And the services that has not been provided for him through this pandemic is not in void. There has not been any services for him, and it is very shameful of the city of Boston that I'm just heartbroken right now that the city of Boston has neglected special needs, mental health.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: I'm just overwhelmed with the services that have not been provided. They are very slow and adamant about getting the services out for these people that have special needs, even the handicap special needs people. I'm overwhelmed with what they needed to be, what needs to be done with that. That's where I'm at with that. That's what needs to be done with that.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: So, yeah. But that's where I'm at with that. I don't even know where to go else with it, but the special needs, mental health issue, my family, families that are out there with the... that's where I'm going with that.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: I guess also the pandemic led me to the question because... just the fact of not knowing and not having the resources, not knowing what's next and how do you get there. Stuff like that, so.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you so much. It's key to keep experience personal. It has been something you experienced directly and experience that helped us understand how you got to the question that you shared. We will go around in a circle and each person will tell a story of an experience that led them to the question. Didn't we just do that? Yeah, I think we did.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, you sort of just shared those experiences that led you to the question, right? So I'm going to go... No, we can do that. We can still go into the circle and ask, because this is more on a personal thing. So you asked the question, so whatever experience you had, this is what we're going to focus on now to kind of share an experience and understand how you got to that question and share it with us.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay? So like what personal experience did you have? And I know it sounds like for the most part, Carol, you shared yours. Jamie, you shared yours. Charlette, you shared yours. And Yvette kind of pretty much shared hers too about the experience you had through the pandemic and the mental health issues and the school issues and so forth.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I'm going to move us into this next phase that what I want to do next is think back to each of the questions and experiences that we just shared in our group, find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life. Okay? So we're going to find someone who's question or experience resonates with our own life.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So, I mean, you heard what everybody had to say, so Charlotte, is there something that someone said that resonates with your own life? And then you can speak to that person and tell them why they question or experience resonates with you and share the story from your life that connects with their experience.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Right. So my connection to my question would be with Jamie. And I resonate with her question and her response, because that happened to my son as well. He was very social, and the pandemic really crumbled him down to almost just a shell. And where someone is just starting off their life at 18, it seems so sad that you would get to this point, but it was out of your control.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: So it's like, how do you help him? And even as myself as a mental health advocate and counselor, it was hard for me to work from within the home because I'm always working with clients outside of the home. So when it hit home that my son was depressed and like, he just didn't want to get up for school. Like he would roll to the bed and wake up, turn the laptop on and be in class in the bed and just not present at all.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: So it was so sad to watch that for, like, he struggled to get out of school. And the way the school system was set up, it was like they did everything to ease the kids so they could just get out. But to me, I still think that they weren't ready. The pandemic did push them back, but because of what was needed, like through policy or government, that they had to get these kids out of these seats for the next batch to come in.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And also with making them come back in this year, I don't know, to me it was like a force as well, because a lot of people are still getting sick. But just having that reflection of young people just going into a shell, it really resonated with me that that also occurred. And that was on the day of the shutdown where my son actually, he just went missing. He just kept walking around and hanging with friends. We had no idea where he was.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And that was the scariest time that I ever experienced something like that with one of my own children. I'd never saw that happening with him because he knows how we are and how we'll wrap our arms around him. So it was just so, like... I guess I was out of this world. Yeah. Because it was like, we couldn't find him, the pandemic happened, they sent the kids home, we don't know what's going on.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And it just was, yeah, bananas, pure chaos. But where I'm trying to work him back into society, so he's gotten a little job and he's moving through. But like I said, that if you don't have sense of self, you're not going to be able to stand when something like a pandemic happens.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative). Right. Thank you, thank you. Jamie, do you want to go next and kind of share with whose story resonates with your own life experience?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: Well, I mean, I think they all do, but more specifically, Charlette and also Ms. Carol, just because I feel like, again, the resources and some of the needs of people weren't met. And I feel like for me personally, like Charlette just mentioned, sense of self, because I don't feel like I was fully aware of myself and my potential and my child.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: And the things that she was mentally dealing with on her own, just being 12 and not wanting to get up and focus in class. We struggled a lot, and I wanted to be angry, but it was hard to be angry because it's kind of like, how do you expect a 12-year-old to get up and do things that college age kids don't want to do either?
