So I feel like, because I was trying to be hard on, "You got to get up and you got to do school," it was kind of breaking her down.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: Not able to see her friends, she's not able to do things that she normally does. I am also unable to do the things that I'm used to doing besides like going to the grocery store or visiting my sister or family and friends. I feel like I lost a lot of friendships just because I felt like I didn't... I wasn't aware of myself.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: And I wasn't aware of how I was communicating my emotions with others, because I was angry because my life was different. And I didn't know how to manage, like, how do I... how am I supposed to do this? What am I supposed to do? I don't know what I'm supposed to do. So even now when people ask me something, I'm like, "Well, I don't really know what to do, because I don't know how to start.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: So I just feel like it... I mean, I can resonate on it because I mean, I feel like we all are mentally and physically going through the same things, because when you're depressed and that wears on your body, you don't feel good about yourself, you don't want to get up, you don't want to be active. Like this was a good time for people to focus on selves, but it's hard to focus on yourself when you have to focus on your entire family and their mental ability and stuff like that.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yes. I may tap onto the crime issue. My son one is a client with Bay Cove, which is located in Methadone Mile. I'm-

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yeah. And they closed down Bay Cove, it's located near, in Methadone Mile over there near South Bay. And it is, it's very... And so he had no place to go during this pandemic. And see, that's just what I was trying to get at when I'm saying that people with special needs, the mental health issue, what is the city going to do for these residents, our residents with these mental health issues?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: During this pandemic, they were just... had nothing. They were just, we were just sitting home with our families with these health issues, mental health issues. My son was just out there. A lot of them, a lot of families, they turned to drugs, alcohol. They were just wandering the streets. I've seen it.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: And it was sad, not just my fam. Fortunately, my son didn't turn to drugs and alcohol. And I just wanted to touch on that because it hit a soft spot in me, and it goes back to the crime in the city with this pandemic. And then I know it touched a lot of families during this pandemic, a lot of families. And a lot of families have children's with mental health issues that have not been addressed during this pandemic, with mental health issues. And that's all I want to say.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Yvette, and I struggle with mental health myself. I decided to go back to work with mental health people, because if I could help somebody as I pass along, then maybe my living won't be in vain. And... I don't know, can't get no realer than that. That's just where I'm at with it. And if we would shut down any longer, I don't know where I would be.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: So it's hard to worry about everyone else when you know yourself is slithering away. So before I could let that happen, I had to get up and go to work so I could help somebody else so that anything that I'm dealing with kind of goes to the back. And it just makes life a little bit easier because you see so many other people dealing with so much other stuff, which it makes my life a little easier.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: That's it. So that's a little bit about what everyone said, you know? Just that mental health is really real, so.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I'm sorry. I wasn't laughing at you. I was laughing at what Charlette just had put in the chat. It was kind of funny. I'm like, that's why she was making that face. I was like, "Oh." Okay. Wow, this was really, really good. So let's give a moment or two to reflect, and then let's talk a little bit about what we're hearing, and what you're hearing in people's experience.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I think that there is a common thread and a theme here. And so I guess, Jamie, I'll start with you. What is the common thread or what is it that we're hearing in all of the conversations? What is it that we're hearing?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: We're hearing that there's a need that needs to be met amongst all of us and our families. I feel that, ... yeah. I mean, there's very much specific needs, specific needs to everyone. But I feel like a lot of people, they're worried, they're afraid of really asking for the help that they need. I think they're afraid to look less than themselves. I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: I think that more people should look into, and there should be more resources to and for therapy for people suffering from mental disorder or just whatever. And I feel like that's a major need that needs to be met.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So is that, that's what you heard through this entire conversation? Is that what sort of resonated with you or your outcome?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: I mean, yeah, because I feel like we can all use support. So yeah, I mean, we all need support and [inaudible] is my I support is obviously going to be different. It's going to vary, it's going to be different from you guys. But ultimately we need help because as a community everybody is suffering. And it's more internal. You know what I mean? And I feel like people need support just generally. And without it, you're kind of blowing in the wind.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Yeah, the city needs to really step up. The governor needs to step up. The state itself really needs to take an overall look in what it is providing for its citizens as a whole... of Massachusetts, basically, during this pandemic. I mean, I see they're trying, but they're not trying, so to speak. During this pandemic, I mean they're lacking in certain areas. When the governor went out and provided those troops to drive those children to school, I thought that was a brilliant idea. Brilliant, because it hadn't been done here.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: But there was some, there's still some other things that stick, that Methadone Mile really needs to be cleaned up. Truly. There's some things that can be done that should be done. That can be done. And it's really not even taking, being taken a look at, they're not even trying to access that place to get it cleaned up.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: And as part of being a mental health issue in the city of Boston that can really be effective in a whole, in the city.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm-hmm (affirmative)? Okay. And so Charlette, what are your thoughts? What are you hearing in the people's experiences through this whole conversation? Is there a thread here or what are you hearing?

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Yeah, so I feel like the correlation that we all have throughout this conversation is that we're looking for better resources, updated education resources as well. Economic factors, more stability within our people, the population of Boston. And I mean, just to even go into the question that Ms. Carol stated about having the National Guard come be bus drivers, it is a good idea, but then that still looks bad on us as a state.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Like where are the people? People need jobs. How come this couldn't have been done with people that needed jobs like right away?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: People need jobs, but people need qualifications. And they can't get qualified to do anything because everything, there's no resource for that. Like for people, for me to drive a school bus, I got to have a CDL. It costs me $10,000 to do that. If I don't got $10,000, how am I going to be licensed to drive a school bus? You know what I mean? I feel like I did during this pandemic.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Yes, I mean it just goes back to what you said, Jamie, that it costs to do these jobs. However, you're not investing in the people that are here to do those jobs. When did National Guard get CDLs? I don't believe they had those either, but they just wanted to... he wanted to show face that he was pulling in something to make something happen. That's what I think.

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: They're paying people peanuts to work in mental facilities that are battling their own mental situations and paying them nothing but expecting everything. It's just too much. It's way too much. And it's like I said, the needs are not met of these people. So people go to work and they're unhappy at work because I'm not even making no money. Why would I want to stand here and do this job? It means nothing to me. I'm not happy.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Breakdown is still a valid issue. And it's really been coming forefront within the community. So a lot of people are understanding the oppression and all of that stuff. Because I can say that I didn't really understand it community-wise or neighborhood-wise either until it really started to make sense, like why is all this stuff happening? Where are the people?

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Okay, I just went to go do something for two years so I could get a better job, and to have purpose with my work. Because it's just like going to work at one of the hospitals or going to work at one of the registries. You're just, like, it's burn 'em and turn 'em.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: ... action is the behavior that you're going to take. You can say that you want this, you want to do that, but if we don't have the person that is the right head at the time, it's not going to get done. We're just going to keep going around in a circle. Looking for different-

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: Yep. Basically that there's the same need to be met in everyone, the mental health and resources, and when and how everything's going to get back together.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. Well this is good, and... this is really good. And so Charlette, you'd made a statement about who's leading. And this is why voting is so important. And not just going out to vote, but understanding who it is that we're electing to lead us. But it should be based on what the community or those constituents in that particular area are looking for.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So if you find a candidate or someone who you think is going to respond to the needs of the people, based on what you think, and you've had discussion all of these forums and stuff, I wish I seen more people at them because here's an opportunity to question them about the things that you feel are lacking in the city of Boston. And that we need.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And when people don't show up, it's like a free ride for them. It's that dog chasing the tail, Right? They can just sit in that office and it's like you didn't... no one made a big enough stink so they do whatever, but it's so important not just to vote, but to really get involved in all of that.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. So the last piece of it is we just, if there are any closing thoughts or anything that you might want to share, I guess I just shared my closing thoughts, but if there are closing thoughts from any of you with regard to anything that was said or anything that wasn't said, or anything like that before we wrap up?

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: I'm just... I'm glad I had a chance to meet and express a few things with the mental health, the crime, the pandemic. Yeah. Because just to voice a few things about the methadone mile, the pandemic and the mental health issues in the city of Boston is so overwhelming, and not everyone can do that. And if it makes a difference somewhere along the line, I'm thankful. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Carol
nodes.words: Oh... that I'm just not alone in my plight, in this plight. There's a lot of residents here that have some worries and concerns about the city that are really concerning, yeah.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: So my takeaway would be that collectively we can all get something done. And I appreciate that this format is even in place because with the lack of resources and time, and things of that nature that people find as barriers or challenging, it was good that this forum came about to have this talk and to get this data out, and, that's what I take away from this in the conversation that us, collectively, as women and as black women, that we do see things.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: And if there's a way for us to insert ourselves to help the cause, that we are more willing and able to do so.

nodes.speaker: Charlette
nodes.words: Maybe she's saying "Skip me." Maybe that means "Skip me." If that's what that means, I'm a turn mine off too.

nodes.speaker: Yvette
nodes.words: I didn't know where the screen went. What I take with me, I guess, is that just like Ms. Carol said, I'm not alone. Everyone's feeling kind of the same, wondering about these resources and mental health, and how real it is. And again, like I said, I had to put myself out there and get back to work. It feel like if you can help someone else, it just makes life a little bit easier for yourself to deal with your own mental health.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Or you could have someone like Philip knock your head up against your head, boy, knock some sense into you. Jamie, what about you?

nodes.speaker: Jamie
nodes.words: I will say the same thing, everyone. We are not alone. We have the ability to make a change, whether that's a big one or a small one, change is change and change is good. And you know, mental disabilities are okay, they're cool. That makes me a little unique, me and you and everyone. That's okay. And I guess maybe we should more embrace each other to get through it together. Take this [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. All right. Great. So I think that this is our wrap-up. So just a reminder of what will happen with our thoughts we shared. These recordings [crosstalk] will be transcribed, indexed, and shared with Real Talk For Change, with the team. You will receive an email from us when all of the conversations are ready so that you can even review them.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: And this would be from the collection from across it's 100 voices across the city of Boston, so your voices will be included. No video of you, just the voices, and indexed in such a way where your topics were, you know, if it was mental health, if it was housing, if it was whatever, they will all be indexed . So you get to listen to those conversations. And these are from people that you don't... were not [Monica Tan], right? Or like, you don't hear her thoughts or whatever.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: But these are from people whose voices you never really get to hear, but have concerns and issues that they feel like people aren't listening or whatever. And maybe it's because it was never a platform to be heard. So, yes, I'm like you, Charlette, I'm so happy that this, that there is a platform, and that this will be shared with media, with officials, so that they know that here's what the residents, the people of the city of Boston are feeling about what needs to happen in the future.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So before we leave this call, please stay for a couple more minutes to complete a Google form and a reminder that you will find that section with demographic information, please fill it out... and then that's it. Let me see where that is, because-

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So our goal today is to share and elaborate on those questions and engage in conversation with each other. So thank you for being a part of the collective voices and this growing chorus of Dorchester who want to speak and be listened to, knowing that it matters. So I should also share with you that this conversation is being recorded and I'm just going to list out some instructions for you, and then we'll get more into the recording and your approval of it. So first the purpose of this conversation, we want to create a new space across this city to facilitate more constructive listening across the divides. The neighborhoods, political and cultural divide, and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates and the future mayor and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. Those conversations are focused on shared personal stories from your lived experience, rather than entering the conversation with your position on the upcoming election or specific candidates. We are doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve our understanding of each other.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Secondly, we want to address what will be happening with this recorded conversation. So following the meeting today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of a collection of conversations. The conversations along with all the other conversations that are taking place throughout the city will be shared with members of the Real Talk For Change team and others that have participated in conversations through the Local Voices Network. The Local Voices Network is a web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by a nonprofit organization called Cortico. The Local Voices Network system creates transcripts for each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and audio recording to an Explorer tool. The system highlights keywords that emerge across the different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets and discover patterns.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: What we want to accomplish today is to begin the process of weaving a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations, in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, "I agree." Shemeka?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Perfect. Thirdly, before we wrap up with this, I'll share with you a form to fill out. It's a section on the demographics. And the reason that we're asking for this information is to help us be able to reflect and uplift the voices of diverse community and different demographics.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Please only respond to the questions you are comfortable answering. And lastly, we want to make sure that everyone gets a chance to share and learn from others in this conversation. And to support these goals we will introduce a few guidelines for our conversation. So number one, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Number two, allow others to speak for themselves. Number three, share the time, allow others to finish speaking, and take turns. Number four, stay curious and then ask honest questions. Number five, pause and take a minute for reflection. Six, listen generously, assume good intentions, while recognizing that your words have an impact. Seven, when possible close unnecessary programs, applications and notifications and put your phone on silent. Is everyone on board with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Perfect. For these virtual conversations, we are going to use a modified circle, a process where each of us will take a turn and then I will transition us to the next person.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So to begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check-ins. Please share your first name and where you are located right now. Then, let us know how you are using the PIES check-in. This means saying how you are choosing to check in by using one of the following. You're checking in either physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. And as soon as we're done, please say, "And with that, I am in." You can then pass... Then I'll pass it on to someone else. Does anybody have any questions about this process?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: No problem. I could definitely do that. And I will definitely start just to model what's happening here. So the PIES check-in, is the acronym for checking in Physically, Intellectually, Emotionally, and Spiritually. And so my name is Marilyn Foreman and I am currently in Dorchester, sitting in my living room. And I'm checking in, I feel maybe intellectually today, because like I said when I came on, I felt like this morning being The Indigenous People Day... And that's rather new, but not so new. There's been little talk some years back, but never amplified to the point where it is today. And so listening to some of the radio cast today, it was interesting to me to discover how many people really didn't know history. Not so much about Indigenous People Day, but about Christopher Columbus Day and what he actually was known for.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So I thought, "Well everybody knows that Christopher Columbus sailed the Ocean Blue in 1892." I thought that. But apparently not, they just knew the name Christopher Columbus, and that it was a holiday. So I found that very interesting. So it made me do a little research this morning. So again, checking in intellectually and with that, I am in and I'm going to pass it off to Gail.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: All right, good morning, Gail and I live on Whitman street and I'm in my living room also. And I would say that [inaudible] want to... All of the above that you had mentioned. You know, it's a long haul, Marilyn, so I'm bringing it all to the table.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Okay. And then you can respond. "And with that, I'm in." If you didn't want to elaborate on any one or all, and...

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: I'd say at this point with everything, COVID, more spiritual than anything else's really. Because this has really hit my soul where we're at and where it seems that we're heading. So I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: Hi everyone. My name is David. I'm on Rosedale Street in Dorchester. And I'm currently in my bedroom. I feel like you guys came in with all these serious check-ins, but I'm going to just go with emotionally, and I'm a little down because I'm originally from New York and I'm a Jets fan and my team is terrible and we [crosstalk]. I'm struggling a little bit this morning, but hanging in there. And with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: Here we go. My name is Myra. I live in Rosendale on Cummins highway. I'm currently... Even though the background has a beach in the back, I'm currently in my bedroom. And I'll say emotionally. Well, I don't want to elaborate on that, but I am in, and I'm sorry, David, that they lost, but I'm happy on the other end. [crosstalk]. And I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: My name is Shemeka. I'm at home in my living room. I live in Dorchester on Merrill Street and I think it's more emotionally and spiritually, and I'm with them because a lot has happened. And I don't know where this is going and... But I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Hey, good morning everybody. I am Alveta. I live on Brinsley Street in Dochester. I am presently in my office and that is strategically so, because I'm taking tomorrow off and there's only two of us in here today, so it's awesome. It's a great day to be here. I listen to people and I think about where I am and I realize that spiritually, I am feeling particularly blessed because so many people... I've heard more about loneliness and separation and anxiety and what people have been experiencing over, through, around, about, and with COVID. And for me, that has not been my experience in my household with my husband and self, but my son and his fiance are also there. So it keeps things moving and quite frankly, I'd never really given that a thought until I started to hear the plight of others. So with all of that, I developed a new appreciation for the cat in the house, because I had never been a cat person.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: And my son and Danielle, it is such a joy to have them there and to always bring a whole other level of energy and joy to the house. So emotionally, all things considered, I think that I am in a good place physically. I have just been working to find some of that pre-COVID energy that I had, with regard to being willing to just physically get out and go and do things for myself. I've always been a person who enjoyed some level, some degree of physical activity. I miss that and got really comfortable when I had an excuse to not do it. And I have not been able to reclaim that yet. So I had to stop eating instead, or eat more sensibly.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Trust me, I'd rather be out walking. And I think that intellectually, we have no choice, but to be engaged because there's so much going on around us that we can no longer just sit on the sidelines. We can't do it. There is stuff happening right outside your front door, two doors down from you, across the street, across the city, and you can't hide. You can't be in a cocoon. So for as much as I thought I used to be engaged. I think that engagement has taken on a whole new level of consideration in my life.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Where am I now? I feel like I am too many places. I feel like I have a tendency to spread myself too thin and not know when to say when. I'm not a Marilyn, I'm not that bad. But, I think that's something to look at and to consider. I look at Marilyn and I just absolutely, positively marvel at her energy, her passion and her commitment, and I thank God for that. But at the same time, I think that it allows some of us to take half a step back and say, "Yeah, Marilyn's got this." So I want to be more of a support entity for her and for all that she's doing. And at the same time, I want to find some real balance in my own life. So yeah, I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Awesome. That was great. Thank you, everybody, for sharing. And so now that we know who is here, let us get to the core of our conversation. So here we go. As we shed the restriction of the pandemic, it will be easy for us to lose sight of what we have learned about the inequality in America and Boston and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. So keeping that in mind, I'd like to invite you to think, what is your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? So let's just pause for a minute or so, and think about that. And then someone, anyone, can go first and share that question, and then your future.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: I've been thinking about this quite a bit, Marilyn. As you know, you've been active for so long, Alveta. For years, we've worked towards building a healthy and green Boston. How do we balance those efforts with Boston becoming a luxury or an ultra-luxury city? Big real estate investments, wealthy individuals telling us that it'll create jobs, equity across the board, but trickle-down economics has not worked thus far. I'm very concerned about the issues of rezoning, and who are going to be the upcoming advocates for all that is green and healthy?

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Yeah, I guess I can. I'm making this up as I go. Gail, I love "ultra-luxury city." Had never thought of it in those terms, but that's exactly who I'm going to say, "They" are trying to create. And as always, it's at the expense of those people who are in their way in the communities, in those particular sections of the geography of the space that we're in. When folks decide, "Oh yeah, this is what we need. This is where we need to be." Then the question becomes, "Okay, so how do we rewrite the story and get these folks out of the way, so that we can have our ultra-luxury city?" You nailed it.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: And I think the thing that does bring some, I think joy and a bit of solace to me is the fact that I believe people learned a very valuable lesson from the South End and people being bought out and literally having property stole from under them, because the reality is, we don't see the blueprints, 40 years, 20 years, 10 years out. So we don't know where it's going. So, you think you're are getting a good deal when low and behold, it comes back and it becomes luxury property. So I am very thankful knowing that to some extent, I think that we've learned from that, to the extent that we can do something about it. It's a whole other story, but we've got young, progressive, savvy, young folks in our community now who are saying, "No, this is my home. I'm staying, and this is how I'm going to shore this up."

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: So it's important to me, I think looking at that and then figuring out my role in maintaining, sustaining, making certain that my young people are well equipped with, first and foremost, their history. They need to know what goes on, what happens, how things happen, how they transpire, and then I want to do my part to help to equip them and give them a head-start on protecting or creating. So that "generational wealth" is not a catchphrase that applies to other people. So I think that's where I am right now.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: Yeah. I can go [inaudible]. Well, first of all, thank you, both Gail and Alveta for sharing. I'm really learning so much. I mean, part of the reason I wanted to be a part of this conversation when Marilyn asked me is to hear from other members of the community. I'm newer to Boston. I moved to Dorchester in June. So, I don't have as much connection to the history or the different struggles you have faced in Boston. So I'm already super thankful that I get to be on this call and hear and learn about what's going on in the city. As for what I'm thinking about. So I've been in Dorchester context of working with young people so far, and some of that's really popped out to me, especially over the summer was, our young people trying to get access to mental health resources.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: We had a number of people come through the organization I work with, dealing with everything from anxiety to depression, self-harm, just a lot of different things that they've been wrestling with and often feeling that they don't have an outlet. A big theme that popped up for the teens I worked with this summer was dealing with family dynamics and oftentimes not feeling safe or heard in their own homes. And how can we provide resources for them to work through that? So for me, I'm really just thinking about, how can we create safe spaces for young people, teenagers, middle schoolers, high schoolers, to talk about what they're going through and then to get the help they need to deal with whatever it is that they're going through? And hopefully, I can play a part in that as well.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: I want to play off of that because I'm more looking at, what is it for the kids to do? There's nothing around. No community centers for that. So that there's a social worker, a tutor, or someone that knows how to play basketball or whatever. There's nothing around. When I was growing up, we had so many different centers where it was teaching us, keeping us off the street. We had different things that we could get into besides being on the streets. And there's no place for the kids to go to, to get any type of help. Like he said, "Mental health, having problems at home with their parents." You used to be able to go to another parent and talk to that parent about what their child was going through.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: Now, the kids don't trust anyone. So I think we need more of something for them to do and get into. There's no music centers, everybody wants to rap, or sing, or... There's nothing for them to do. So what's the future for them? Where are they going to go? Where's their outlet? How do they get help? And I have a daughter that's 20 years old. She doesn't walk, or talk, she has cerebral palsy and I'm always looking for things to do and bring her to, so that it's like, "Okay, I can put in my part, but then I'm also getting her out and doing something with her and showing the community that we do have all types of kids around."

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: I'm going to follow Shemeka as well. I've been in Four Corners since 1994, and I have advocated for a very long time, but I have not seen that happen yet for a community youth center. I was told, Marilyn, many years ago that there was going to be... You know where the Me Market is? When they remodeled that building, that place there was left. They said that they were going to turn that into a youth center. Because we always [inaudible]. So kids don't have anywhere to go after school. And it is like, I was at three 45 for 10 years. That was a convenience store. And for many years I saw the kids from Greater Four Corners, struggling because there was nothing to do. I remember the parent that used to live on the third floor from the store. She was always complaining, "My kids are at home alone. There's nothing to do around here."

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: [inaudible] home delivery. I don't know if you know this? That used to be... That was the only thing that they had around there. And after that was gone we have not seen anything for the kids. And that's one of the biggest problems that we have in Greater Four Corners right now.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. True. Well, thank you for sharing your questions. And now I'd like to invite you to think, "What experience in your life got you to that question?" So your question around the "what" and "when" and "why..." What experience in your life [crosstalk] question?

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: I had somewhere to go when I was young. There was a... It was called WODA, and that stood for Wiping Out Drug Abuse. They took us to different shows, movies. They had parties for us, Halloween parties indoors. It was safe. My mom knew that I was going somewhere that was safe. Was a tutor up there. It was, things that they knew that we needed, they would find. And just, next thing you know, it was there. So we had somewhere to go. I had somewhere to go up until 10 o'clock at night. And my mom knew I was safe. It was right in Carmen Square. It wasn't far from the house. It was right on the bus route. I had somewhere to go and I knew that it was going to be fun. And I was looking forward to going there after school. I was going to see my friends.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: They had drawing there. They had different things there for us to do. And it was all up to us to pick and choose what we wanted to do. I didn't do a lot of stuff, but I had somewhere to go and stay out of trouble and not be just standing outside or just sitting on my porch doing nothing. So that's what got me to that question.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: So I would love for these kids to... When I was growing up, it wasn't as much shooting and all of this stuff that's happening right now. And I feel like it's because they have nothing to do it. The guns are there now, and it's like, "Can't they figure something out to show these kids that, that's not safe?" I don't know, it's... Some type of training, if that's what they're into, then let's get them on the right path of using those things. Let's get them educated. Let's have classes or something. The generation has changed, so we have to change with the generation. But if you continue to use the old things with the new things, I think sometimes that works.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Marilyn, I'll give it a try. Everything that everyone has said is so true. And that's where it brought me to the equitable part of the conversation. One of the things... I'm not sure if anyone has heard of a new "docu" on Boston? It's called, This Ain't Normal. And it goes back to the nineties. It talks about the programs and things that we had initiated, such as Healthy Boston, [inaudible] Street. I don't know if you were around at that time? With Healthy Boston, a developed program that was called Ties that Bind. What the purpose of that was, was to bring an intergenerational component to children that were latchkey, what have you. And we did things like put together whale-watch trips, going to the theater. We got donations from the different museums and things of that nature.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Keep the children engaged, but also give them some guidance by participating in these different events with the older generation. But we've lost all those. Those were very successful programs. But I would say, if you want to see what was then back in the late eighties, early nineties and stuff, or what have you, This Ain't Normal would be a good show to watch. I know that they're streaming it on Showtime, YouTube, and other things. I don't know if anyone knows Dennis Wilson, but he's one of the [crosstalk]. And he is one of the co-producers of the show.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Yeah, and you're absolutely right. There's not enough, very constructive and engaging things for children to do. I see that with my own grandchildren. I have to make these things happen. And with everybody, and being in such a financial slump and stuff, it's very difficult. But especially at this time, we need to start to rebuild these children so that they can have some hope and joy.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Well, yes. Because the trauma and everything, and that they've experienced in the last year and a half... Seen a huge increase in the bullying, the meanness. So we have a lot of... Again, we have a lot of work to do. For me, this is like, excuse my expression, but, "It's like shoveling shit against the tide." We were there in the eighties and the nineties with the drugs and all of that sort of stuff. But I know that things can change because it did. We just got to keep our foot on the pedal and make sure these services are there, especially for the children coming behind us.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Okay. Well, I think that for me, my question would be, "Who's at the table?" So I am not a native Bostonian. I'm not a native New Englander. I am from Georgia. And I was born and grew up in the heart of the civil rights era. So I definitely have my own view and my own interpretation of things that I see and things that happen around me. And the one thing that my father was constantly working to drill and instill in us is to know and to understand who's at the table. And he was one of those people that, if there wasn't a table, he'd build one. And you don't leave people out. The best way to have a community conversation is to have everyone from the community. Those close by, even those folk who are far away, you include them in the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: And I look at where we are now on my street, on Brinsley street. We used to know everybody on our street. We used to know all of our neighbors. So when you talk about the kids having things to do and places to go, that wasn't so much an issue because all of our households had a hand in making that happen for kids. I can truthfully say to you now that I can't really walk out my front door and call anyone by name. My neighbor to my left has a lot of kids. And her kids call me neighbor, because I'll do stuff for them, I'll buy ice cream or treats or whatever, hand it to them. But they see me and they go, "Hi neighbor." That's our life now.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: It used to be that we knew them, they knew us. We knew about each other. We knew how to help each other. It was more than just a casual wave to someone, "Hey, how you're doing?" So, that's missing. So now I think that in our community conversations... I think much like this call, it needs to be intergenerational. It's got to have Gail on the call, and I should be on the call and Marilyn should be there. We need Shemeka and David to be there, to bring that perspective that oftentimes is beyond us because we are not thinking along that vein anymore. So we need to be cognizant of who's at the table, and then we need to make a concerted effort to make certain that if we're not there, we get them there. And if we need to, we need to build another table that's big enough to accommodate everybody so that we can all be a part of the conversation.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank, you for sharing, Alveta. That was some really powerful stuff. I think what led me to my question... I've been working in one regard, the other with young people for the last 10 years and just doing life with them, spending time with them, mentoring, hanging out, just seeing this consistent theme of young people, especially brown and black young people, not feeling like they have anywhere to go when stuff is going wrong around them. And when they're facing a trial or something, or trauma or whatever it may be. So many times it's either they turn to their peers or they're keeping it in, or unfortunately, turn into other things to try and fill that void. And so I spent a lot of time working with young people in the context of the church. And so, a lot of it is spiritual-based, but as I grew older, I just really felt this need of, "We can do more for these young people, than have them for two hours at a church service on a Friday night."

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: And so for me, it was just very looking for, "How do I find a holistic way to be of service to young people, to see them get access to more than just mental health resources, but healthier food, education?" And even this past summer, I encountered so many kids who just legitimately so intelligent, so smart. Even more than me, but [inaudible] for them, they don't want to go to school, they don't want to take classes, but it's so... Just tension of seeing the brilliance in them, that the things that they're passionate about, they're so gifted in, but then just having no desire to apply to the certain areas in school, or you even just like... Sometimes high school is just the end.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: They're like, "Let me just... I'll finish high school and then whatever happens, happens." And oftentimes there's not this... They don't often see that path or that way forward. And I think Shemeka, you mentioned something earlier about, or maybe I can't remember it was [inaudible], helping these kids finding that hope again. And so being able to say, "Hey, there is actually a path forward for me to success." And, yes, if that's[inaudible], but success doesn't have to be limited to getting a bachelor's. Especially in 2021, there are so many different ways that you can find success and make money and be happy and achieve all those goals. So it's really trying to find ways that these teens can actually envision a future. And it did surprise me this summer by hearing just how many of our teens didn't have that plan or even have that thought.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: And so hoping that in these conversations, and as we elevate more voices and elevate more youth voices, that we can start to bring back some of those things and some of those programs that show our kids and show our community in general, that there is a path forward, there is a way forward. And so that's just really where I'm at and how I've gotten here.

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: Well, I'll take you back on Shemeka as well. Growing up on Waldeck street, we had [inaudible] House, had a lot of programs that we used to use. And also I used those programs for my kids. I got them into swimming, but I was... What I had to get out, go outside of Dorchester to get them into music classes and also get them into baseball, softball.

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: I did my best just to keep them occupied in any activity that I found, even though they were outside of Dorchester, because it was hard to find anything nearby for them. So I just searched someplace else out of [inaudible] and that shouldn't be the case. In fact, we should have more resources for the kids, more activities for them to be able to go and attend. And I know it could be expensive, so we should have programs that are free for parents just to get these kids involved in getting them off the streets, because my [inaudible] kids off the street. And that's why I just went out of Dorchester to find other resources that I was not able to find in the area.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Mm, thank you. I think we got everyone? So, what we are going to do next is talk about connecting our experiences. And I think we did some of that just then, but think back to the questions and experiences that were shared in the group by everyone and find someone whose question, or whose experience resonates with your own life. (silence).

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: So I guess that, when you talk about somebody else's experience resonating with my own [crosstalk], that makes it ageist, I guess. So, that would make Gail and me partners.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: I know. But I think that just the fact that we are all in the same community, means that there is some interlocking and overlapping of our experiences. I think that just the fact that we are all on this call together, speaks to the fact that there is some overlapping and interlocking of our experience. I think listening to Shemeka moves me and moves my thinking out of one box, into another. I was not thinking actively about what's specifically out there for young kids in our area now, versus what may have been there a decade ago. I mean, I don't have any... I call them little people. I don't have any little people in my house, so that's not on the front of my brain.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: My son works in education and he is a tennis player and tennis instructor. And one of our commitments to the community has always been to be there and make ourselves available. And we've done that primarily through the tennis club because that was our family outlet. So if you would ask me, I would say, "Oh my goodness, yes, there's always stuff out there. There are things to do and places to be," because we literally had this sports facility incorporated into our life. And I wasn't necessarily forced to think broader than that, because beyond that, when David talked about the church, I was that youth fellowship director who had no problems throwing all the kids in the back of my truck and we'd all go to the movies.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: I took them all out to Worcester, to concerts or whatever. So those were the kinds of things that were happening, but you know what? As I listened, I realized that's what was going on in my little world. It wasn't universal. It wasn't the thing that was happening across the community. And I think that we got to think, or at least I do. I've got to think bigger, I've got to think broader. And I've got to think outside of things that touch me. And I think that I probably have not always been good at that at, so I need to readjust and shift and maybe do a better job at that. I think that, who was it that... Mya, Shemeka, David, somebody saying, "With all these kids now, everybody wants to be a rapper in music," all of that.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: My son is 37 years old and he has a degree in communication, but you know what? His heart, his passion is in this whole music thing. That's his love. And so, my thing with him is that, "Can it pay a bill? [crosstalk]. Then we need to take another look at communications, because that's where your energy..." So what he has done is figured out how to work with kids. To engage them, to encourage them, but to also talk to them about how they could apply some of those same skills, some of those innate abilities that David was talking about. How to recognize them, how to even point them out to them, because kids don't even... Man, they don't know how brilliant they are.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: And so he makes it a point to talk to them about that. So for me, I'm like, "Okay, so that's a good use of your passion for music by using that as a conduit, to connect with young people and to pay it forward a bit." But, I think that in the grand scheme of things, we all have to do a better job of understanding what the issues and the concerns are that are outside of our sphere. Being willing to look beyond that, because when you start to do that, that means that you may be required to do more, you may be required to do differently. And some of us... I would love to think that I'm exempt from all of that. I'd love to call it "dues paid" and move ahead. But that's just not the world that we're living in right now.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: Alveta, I related to so much that you shared just now. My parents [crosstalk]. My parents were those parents, they would just throw a bunch of kids in their minivan and we would go anywhere and everywhere. My dad would always take the family and at least three or four of my friends. And these are kids from the city, from Brooklyn, and take them camping, take them hiking, having those experiences that they never had. So I definitely feel you on that one. I feel like I'm always taking people, places in my car now. But something that I'm reminded of just being on this call is the wisdom of the elders. And I mean that in the most respectful way.[crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: No, just a few years. But no, just hearing all of you share and just the lives you've lived, the work that you've been involved in, the things that you're passionate about and that you care about just reminds me that there is work that we can all do together. That it really is a bridge. It really has to be intergenerational. I think it's so easy. Millennials, especially Gen Z, to just sometimes feel like quote-unquote, I'll use that lightly, "Y'all don't get it" or, "Y'all, don't relate," but I think that would be lazy on our part to just assume that, because you didn't grow up in the age of the internet or social media, whatever, that your thoughts and your ideas don't have credence anymore. I think Shemeka, you mentioned about the mission of the old and the new, and I think that's so important.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: And Gail, you talked about how in the eighties and nineties, you weathered the drug and gangs and change happened. And so the reason why you're still so passionate now is because you've seen the change happen before and that change can happen again. And I really believe that change is not going to be built without standing on the shoulders of those who came before us. So I think that, for this conversation to move forward, for the work to move forward, it's going to be so vital that we are leaning on everyone in this conversation. Those who have been through it and know what it takes to win the fight. And those after who are going to have those fresh ideas, those new ideas, the creative ways that problems are going to be solved. What worked in 94 may not work in 2021, but that doesn't mean the principles have changed.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: That doesn't mean that the things that are going to be required, the sacrifices that are going to be required have changed. And sorry, I feel like I've been a little bit all over the place on this stuff. I'm just thinking out loud, but for me, this past hour has just being a reminder of... This really has to be, who's at the table? All of us need to be at the table, pulling ideas and resources and vision and putting that all together to move forward. And I think if we can find ways to do that, that the future of Boston looks very bright.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Sounds like we need a bigger table. We need to go look for Alveta's father. Build that table. Who would like to go next? You can share an experience and share it with the person who spoke about it and how it resonates with your own experience.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: Alveta said something about neighboring. When I first moved around here, like she said, "Everybody knew everybody." We can go in each other's houses and everything. The kids would disappear off the street, but they knew we were safe. And now, I don't know. I don't understand why we can't do that now, still. We know people are not going to live forever, but when... It seems to be a bad thing, just to say "Hi" to someone. They are looking at you like, "What are you speaking to me about? Why are you saying hi to me?" But I think it starts there with just being friendly neighbors and knowing each other's names. And like you said, "Being there for each other." I was sick and Marilyn came and brought me some soup. She's like my second mom.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: At this point, because I lost my mom, but she's still always looking out for me. And like I said, I don't think I have another neighbor... I may have one other neighbor on the street that would do that for me. But it's nice to know that you have family on the outside of your house. That really stuck with me because it's not the same anymore. It's not the same.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: And our kids learn from us. So it would be nice for them to see us doing things together, getting along, working and all of the good things. And if they don't see that, then how are they going to learn how to do it? And then another thing, I think stuff needs to start in the schools. So, that's my whole thing. That's a whole nother subject.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: And I'm just blessed to be on this call because I like being around older people because I don't care if you're a year older than me, two years, you know something that I don't know. And I always like to grasp and learn more things because I don't know everything.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Oh, I'm at a loss. First, I want to thank David and Shemeka for their words. And I really appreciate the fact that they find value in what the elders have to say. [crosstalk]. Listen, I have a daughter that's going to be 52 next month, so[crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Yes. 52. And I have a son that's 32. So I've been through all of those phases. Let's see. I had an exchange with three young ladies the other day. I had my best girlfriend of 65 years, had passed away and she [inaudible] a clothes horse. So I've given many things away to women that I knew going back into the workplace and all of that. But I still had quite a few things leftover. So last Friday I said, "Well, let me just hang them outside on the fence and put a free sign up there." Well, these three young ladies... Oh, I'd say, one was probably about five years old, 10 years old. And one that was 12, 13. And when they stopped at the house, my husband was outside washing his car and, and they said, "Sir are these free." And he says, "Yeah, it's free, take whatever you want." So I heard them talking among themselves. And so I went outside and they said, "Ma'am, is that your husband?" I said, "Yes, he is." "He said, these were free."

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: I said, "Yes they are." And so they said "Free? Why aren't you selling it?" I said, "Well, because I know there are people in the community that could use it." I mean, there were a lot of clothes that still had the tags on them and everything. So they just said, "Oh my goodness, our grandmother would love these things." They were very deliberate and thoughtful in the things that they had picked out.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Then this one turned to me and said, "Miss, do you have any church hats?" "I'm sorry that I don't have." So got them a bag. They left here with so many things. The gratitude and the thoughtfulness of those three young ladies. So they said, "Well, grandma likes skirts. Do you have any skirts?" I said, "Oh, I have plenty of skirts." So I brought them down. So they even chose a couple of items that they said that they could use as night-shirts. [crosstalk] So the oldest said, "Are you going to be around tomorrow?" I said, "Yes, I will be." She says, "I'm going to try to get my grandma to come down so she can pick out things for herself." That little interaction with those little angels, it was like a rebirth for me. It just made my heart sing to see these three little girls, they were just out riding their bikes and they were on their little scooters and stuff, but they were so thoughtful about their grandmother.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: It just gave me hope that these sweet three little girls gave me a promise of tomorrow. And fortunately, that's how our street has always been. Most of the people on this street have been here for over 30 years. We know each other, we're there for each other. There's never any question. And I would like to see that type of community, that type of neighboring, throughout the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: But as I always used to tell people, especially when we were going through all the drug stuff during the late eighties, early nineties and stuff. People didn't understand what was missing. They would say, "Oh, these young children, they're throwaways. They're no good." And all that sort of stuff. "They don't know how to respect people." And my premise was always that, "You have to give respect to receive respect." [inaudible 01"00:03:37] what a lot of them just needed was to be respected or someone to just say, "Hello" to them, acknowledge them. And once we started doing that, it was received. Because I'll tell you, we have real tough bangers, especially on this street. And I'll tell you, once you started giving them the respect of being a human, someone of value, it changed. They still come to my home. So I know that change can happen. We just have to find a way to keep that momentum going.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: So many of the programs that we had were so successful, they were actually national models. But if things got good, everything went away. We got to make sure these things are sustainable.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you for sharing. Myra. She keeps getting kicked out, but she's back. So, I guess you got to talk real fast before it happens again. Myra, you're on mute. Myra? Well, maybe she froze because she did say she keeps freezing. But I'm going to move us along because we're running out of time, but we're also at the wrap-up. So I just wanted to ask really quickly. So, is there a connect? What are you hearing in the conversations and how they're weaving? I think Alveta spoke a little bit to that earlier, but is there a connection? What are you hearing through all of the conversations?

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: We all want the same thing. It's just trying to figure out how we're going to get there. We all want the same things, we all see the same things. It's just, how do we get to getting it better, making it better? And I mean, there's other things that were brought to my attention, that I don't think about, but I think we all want the same thing.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: So I'll tell you something that, that actually came to mind for me as a bit of clarity. Is that we all talked about community in one sense or another. And the thing about my community, my street, is that we went from families who had lived there for decades, to my street now being very transient. People coming and going, people moving in, moving out. No longer family homes, family dwellings from generation to the next. But I think as I was listening to Gail, the thing that comes to mind for me is that it's like not having an infrastructure. It's like not building an infrastructure, so that everybody who comes in, they come into something new. Imagine what it would be like if your community or your street is one that [inaudible] somebody new comes in, you realize they're new to the street.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: You welcome them for being new to the street, as opposed to looking at them and saying, "Okay, I wonder how long they going to be here. I wonder how many cars they have. I wonder how many parking spaces are they going to take up?" I mean, because that's just a reality now. But imagine that if we were in that time, when we actually made it a point to get to know people so that your street has an identity, your street has a culture. So that as people are coming in, it's not a chore to convince people to come to neighborhood association meetings, because the first time they see it or hear about it is not when you are shoving a notice in their mailbox, it's because you've actually had a conversation with them and you've mentioned it to them, you've told them about it.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: So that when it happens, you can say, "Oh, remember I told you about that meeting, would you like to come with me?" And I think that we have moved so far... I'm saying "move." Maybe we haven't grown or we have dissolved, I'm not even sure what it is, but I just know that we have moved away from that. And I'm just thinking that if we had something that even resembled that... Businesses and organizations survive when they have an infrastructure, right? When they have funds, when they have... So that there can be a transition from one, there's nothing worse than having a pastor leave a church, because the whole church falls apart if you don't have an infrastructure, you don't have something in place.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: When you don't have a transition team, you don't have a way to move from one thing to the next. And I think that as I'm just listening to everybody, I think we're missing that. I think that we don't transition. And maybe, when you start to talk about "getting back-to." Maybe that's one of those things that we need to get back to is, taking the time and the initiative to get to know, put a structure in place so that we can be more kind and more welcoming to the new people in our lives.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Thank you. Does anybody else want to share? Myra, are you back? She might still be frozen. Okay. No? Okay. So, it's about time for us to wrap up and thank you for sharing your questions and your experiences. And now we would just quickly go around and share something you will be taking away with you. And if you have any closing thoughts, you can also share them after you give us what you're taking away from this conversation. Gail?

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: Okay. I'll be quite honest with you. I've retired from working and I was going to retire myself from community work, but Alveta has shamed me [crosstalk] once again.

nodes.speaker: Gail
nodes.words: And the young man and woman has given me a sense of duty. Just the fact that they appreciate what we have to bring to the table, which hasn't always been. It's like a breath of fresh air. So yes, it's altered my future, this conversation. So, I want to thank everyone for that.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: T-hank you. Gail, I just wanted to ask you like really quickly. What did you refer to, the new housing? How did you phrase that again? I was trying to write it down, but I didn't.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: I'm also super thankful to be on this conversation. I didn't sleep super well last night, and so I was feeling tired and sluggish. Like, "All right, let me come on this call." Not necessarily knowing what to expect, but it's truly been just a pleasure to discuss with everyone. It's just, hear everybody's viewpoint. Something I'm taking away from it, I think is really a renewed sense of commitment to building community. Like I said, "It's so easy to just ignore those people that you might see on your street every single day or every [inaudible] you go to the grocery store, whatever, you always see these people and it's become so easy to just disregard that opportunity to build a relationship. And so I think just in the conversation, especially hearing the way communities used to be and just, you know if they're down the house at so and so, that they're down the black at so at so's house, everything's fine.

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: And I don't know if we'll ever get fully back to that, especially with COVID and those kinds of things. But I do believe that there are so many amazing people and resources already within our community and that we miss out on having those interactions and building those relationships when we're so closed off and just keep to ourself. So I'm really taking, just for me, just this idea of being more open to connections and not limiting it to... Obviously, I feel super comfortable with people my age, or obviously teenagers, because that's who I work with. But just being open to connections across all backgrounds, all ages, just really looking for that very just holistic connection with whoever comes into my life and whoever I interact with, in my community. So, that's really what I'm taking away from this conversation. And how we can all then off of building those relationships...

nodes.speaker: David
nodes.words: Sorry, last thought, how we can all then off of building those relationships, find ways to affect change in our community. I'm a firm believer that, if we can all come together and pull the different gifts, talents, resources, and bank accounts of everybody that we know, that there's a way forward and that there's definitely a future for our community. And so I'm just excited about that. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Myra
nodes.words: Well, first of all, I want to just thank you for inviting me to this conversation, even though I kept freezing and being kicked off. But I learned a lot and I really appreciate everybody's conversation and what I'm taking away is what, Shemeka? She mentioned the new and the old, for the young kids. I know we... Back in the days, there was different methods of bringing... Sharing with the kids. I know that things have changed nowadays. And I think that's a great idea to mix the old with the new, and just to start [inaudible] just get things rolling back again with the young kids to really get them involved and get them getting them off the streets.

nodes.speaker: Shemeka
nodes.words: Thank you for inviting me. And I'm grateful to be in this conversation. What I'm going to take from away from this is to know that there's hope, there's still ways of us working this out. And in the generation that I am, we're not alone. We don't really see it, but to know that there are conversations going on, and we can, if we just apply ourself to it, like David said, "Be more open and not..." I'm just grateful that I know that it's being... It's still talked about. It's not being ignored that things and changed have, did a big change. And I appreciate you guys, because if it wasn't for you guys, then we wouldn't know, or we wouldn't have the help... I'm assuming, and I feel like a lot of communities do not do this or reach out to each other and know anything about each other. Now if I see David on the street, I can say hi. If I see Gail on the street, I can say, hi. Myra on the street, I know Alveta. So it's just seeing each other's faces sometime and knowing, I don't know. But yeah.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. But getting to the heart of what everybody else feels and valuing their opinion and really being listened to. Because I think that those are the important things. Oftentimes we come together, but it's always on somebody else's agenda. Never really speaking about what's on your heart, how you feel, how you see things. So, I can appreciate being here too and listening and learning as well, because I think that's the beginning of change. Understanding and knowing each other first and what people care about and how we work together to really affect change. Alveta. I think you're the last one.

nodes.speaker: Alveta
nodes.words: Yeah. So quick and painless. I would just say, thank you. This was awesome. I appreciate the opportunity. It was so wonderful to be able to spend time this way. All of us being able to use this as an opportunity for a structured brain dump. So, I think that's a great idea. To Shemeka and David, let me just say to you, I am task-oriented. So don't expect me to just say, "Oh, I think I'm going to call Shemeka and see if she needs." Or, "Oh, let me check in with Dave and see." I am telling you, call me. If there's anything that I can do to help you in any way, call me. Because I'm that person who you can call and you can talk to, and I really appreciate it. Marilyn will tell you, because I am that person who is task-oriented. Give me a specific thing to do. Don't expect me to pull it out of the air, but just know that I am here for you. My household is here for you. I volunteer my family all the time and there's nothing that they can do about it.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. Thank you. So just a reminder that what will happen with the thought shared, these recordings are going to be transcribed, indexed and shared with Real Talk For Change team. You'll receive an email from us when all of the conversations are ready and then you can review them. So it won't be just this conversation, but be other conversations across the city. And you can hear the different themes and what people are saying and talking about. And this stuff is going to be also shared with some of the media, because this is stuff they don't hear that they need to hear. As well as the elected officials, we should be the ones informing their work, right. And oftentimes that's not what happens. "We voted for you because it was something we needed you to do," but it and happen like that. So, this will help to remind people, "This is why you're in office."

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Because this is what the people say, this is what's missing. This is what needs to happen. So help us get the resources to rebirth some of the stuff that doesn't exist and help us think of new ways to come together at these larger tables to have conversations for the new thing. So before we leave the call, I... Stay just another minute or two. I just put a Google form into the chat. And if you would kindly fill that out, it's just that demographic information that I talked about earlier and send that back...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Samantha. I already went over a lot of this detail with everyone before you can. My name is Fran Smith, also known as Francesca. Since all of you are meeting me for the first time I'd love if you see me again to call me Francesca. I'm with Real Talk For Change Boston. It's a fusion of 20th century kitchen conversation, neighbor-to-neighbor talking about issues that are important to us with partnership with MIT and local Voices Network where we record these conversations. After we record them, they get beamed into cyberspace, and then the team at MIT is able to develop patterns and share what other people are thinking across the city.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: The goal of doing this is we want to create a new space across the city to facilitate more constructive listening across differences, neighborhood, political, cultural, and provide improved visibility and accountability between the candidates, the future mayor, and neighborhoods throughout the city. To this end, we're inviting you to a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing your personal stories from your lived experience rather than entering the conversation with your positions on issues or candidates for the upcoming election.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: We're doing this to help build connections and foster conversations that improve our understanding of one another, and hopefully we'll be able to use the library in the future and hold the elections accountable. What will happen with the recording? Following our meeting today, the audio recording will become part of a collection of Real Talk For Change conversations posted on the LVN platform. LVN is a Web-based tool for accessing and exploring conversations designed by the nonprofit organization Cortico. LVN's system creates a transcript for each recorded conversation and uploads both the transcript and the audio recording to the Explorer tool. The system highlights key words and themes that emerge across different conversations and allows users to search conversations, listen to audio snippets, and discover patterns. This conversation along with all the other conversations that have taken place throughout the city will be shared with others who have participated in Real Talk For Change conversation. Members of Real Talk For Change team.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Finally, I have to read this consent statement, and I'd ask if you're willing to be recorded. As a participant in this conversation you are providing consent to Real Talk For Change to use and retain the recording and record this our mission. You also understand that the conversation we've had about protecting collection on Cortico's Local Voices Network whose mission is to foster conversations and communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. In addition, part of Real Talk For Change mission is to present voices from people of Boston. Therefore, portions of your conversation will be made public. If you understand and you agree to this, please say, "I agree," one at a time going to my left.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay, that's fine. And, if you want ... Okay. Before we start, I want to just talk about a few guidelines. Speak for yourself and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Allow others to finish speaking. Take turns. Stay curious. Ask honest questions. Pause, take time for reflection. Listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that our words have an impact. When possible, close unnecessary programs, applications, phones, put your phone on silent, et cetera. If you need to take a moment, just do it. The bathroom is through the kitchen and on the left hand side. The light is on the inside, or the outside? Okay.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: To begin, we want to do a quick round of introductions and check in. Please share your first name, where we're located right now, what part of the city you live in. Then let us know how you're using the P.I.E.S Check-in. P.I.E.S. represents how you're doing either physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. I'll model.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: My name is Francesca. I'm doing great physically because I was in a slump and I'm back and doing at least 7,000 steps a day for the last few days. With that, I'm all in, and that's how you do it. You pick one of them. It's physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. We'll go around like this. Do you want to go ... You'll go after because she's behind you.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I'm Claudette, and I'm in Dorchester. I live in Dorchester. Intellectually I am really interested in getting around a lot more people who are intellectually and mentally stimulating and launching the box to the think tank.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: Physically I feel a lot more energetic now that I'm starting to be ... I had about a year and a half off at work, so now I'm starting to get back more energy and into the flow of things.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: I'm Darneese. I live in Mattapan. Emotionally I'm dealing with grief. I'm sad quite often because I miss my mom and my sisters so much. So I'm dealing with that. My sister's been deceased for six years now next month. But life is good. I know life is for the living. I keep telling myself that. I'm trying to surround myself with beautiful people like I do, and that helps.

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: I'm Nina. I'm from Dorchester, but lived in the South Shore probably for the last 20 years or so. I would say that I am part of the P.I.E. would be probably physical and emotional. So I'm like what Darneese said dealing with grief. I lost my [inaudible] and a cousin that was like a brother. I think that I'm starting to get out more and do more, so I think as a part of that I'm starting to get back into my physical aspect because I really like to work out. I love to eat, but I like to work out, so strong [inaudible] with both, the physical part of it, but I just think with COVID and other things I have just shut down from doing a lot of things. I think the other question was surrounding yourself around ...

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Karen. I live in Dorchester born and raised all my life. Physically today is my birthday, so I ...

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: I feel a year older, a little more aches and pains now. Emotionally I just lost my grandmother about a month ago, so still deal with that. And with that I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: I'm Samantha. From Dorchester. I think physically and emotionally I'm drained, to be honest. Not having the right people in my circle and [inaudible] how I need, to be honest. On top of that I'm dealing with fibroids and a stomach virus that's making me lose more ... I don't want to lose weight, so between that and the other stuff it's draining. I guess on the flip side of that, I have a job that I love right now so that kind of helps me semi-balance, but it's roller coaster right now.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Thank you, Samantha. [crosstalk]. Does anybody want one of these? Because has anyone had[inaudible]? Local Voices, Inc. this is the part to give MIT, and I probably should've said that. Local Voices is the nonprofit they created, and our policy at MIT even though whether you're vaccinated or not is to be masked up when we're inside. Thank you. Okay.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Now that we all know who's here, thank you so much for sharing, the reason Claudette asked you to come is because we're really interested in having you think about now that we've shared most of the restrictions of the pandemic it's going to be easy for us to lose sight of what we've learned about inequality in America and in Boston and how our lived experiences have shaped that learning. So keeping this in mind, I'd like to invite you to think about, and if you need to jot it down or pull out your phones to write it down, I have some paper if you need it too.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Take two minutes to reflect on ... Oh, I forgot. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it? And I have some pens, if you need paper. This is something that I'm going to hand out anyway for people to complete at the end.
