So you can write on the back of it if you need to, and then ... So that you can access the conversation post conversation and so that you can also get your gift card I'll ask for those things back. I have plenty of pens. Oh, and I also have these if you want one. Don't let me forget. I have buttons. I'm a button collector.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I actually have buttons that says, "Black votes matter," but I don't have them. I've given them to Claudette so that you can get them to you. Okay. Now, everyone has paper and pen. You're formulating a question about the future of Boston and your place in it.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Think about it. Write it down. Once everyone has the question, now I'd like you to think what experience in your life got you to this question? It's key to keep your experience personal. I'd like it to be something that you've experienced directly, an experience that can help us understand how you got to the question you shared with us. Once everyone has a few ... I'll give you a few minutes to think about your question. We'll go around in a circle, and I think we'll start with Samantha this time and go ...

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. You can also pass. I'm going to stop talking. Question and then the story about what got you to the question.

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: My thought is that there's been a lot of changes in the area. There's been a lot of changes in the area, but I have not seen any service or door-to-door questioning in terms of what our input could be about the things that are happening in our area. They just kind of happen, and then we have to deal with them. So that comes from my experience of just watching things occur and not understanding why the community input was not given, and they'll say that it is, but we are the community and if the majority of us are saying that we had no idea then you really didn't reach out to us. So then how are we valuable here, and are they actually just not considering us, and is the goal to just remove us.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: My question is how can we get to more ... My question is how do we take advantage of all the opportunities that are supposed to be available to the City of Boston residents? I don't think that the opportunities that are put in front of us cannot be met by many of the black community business owners or people who are trying to do business because of the amount of information, one, that they ask for and the things that they require. Even though there's a lot of minorities running business in the City of Boston they're not really running their business correctly because we haven't really been taught how to run a business.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: We're probably going to be wearing more than one hat at one time when we're trying to run our business. We don't have the accountants, we don't have the bookkeepers. Maintaining the employees-

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: I am certified with the City of Boston, and that process is a process that not many people of color can qualify for. We need a hand up, not a handout more times than others or more than others do. It's just a lot for us to deal with. We need probably to structure it a little bit differently, the opportunities that are out there a little bit different for some of the minority business owners than just putting everybody in the same hat, you know what I'm saying, if that makes sense.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: Well, I've got a few questions. Mine is what does the climate control look like because there's a concern about the water levels rising, and what does that look like and who is in charge of that project that needs to be discussed with the homeowners and the business owners and the commuters and other people that can be affected. In addition to that if there was a situation, well there will be a situation. It's just a matter of time. They say what does that evacuation look like? Where is that discussion at because that's really important for people that live in the community that don't know?

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I know there were some evacuation signs, but I was told there really wasn't ... And the other thing is the tyranny that goes along with we voted for cannabis and consumption, and the stigmatization that went along with people who did smoke cannabis. And then you have these judges that lock up a lot of cannabis users. And now some of these judges, I wouldn't say all of them, but I wouldn't be surprised if they're not in the cannabis industry. Those judges that sent these young, and I say black and brown and Latino people to jail including my loved one. My family was incarcerated because they were an addict and they used drugs to provide for their addiction. What about crime? But they still did jail time unlike the addicts of today that they want to find them injection centers. They're not injection centers but there are places where they can go and indulge in the activity of their choice.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: They want to provide shelters for these addicts of today. They want to put them on Front Street in the prime areas where there's business owners. There's a black hotel down there. We won't even know that it's a black hotel. When it was open, we did very much go over there and have a great time, but now with the drug addiction people that are surrounding those areas who's helping those business owners to get back to the level where they deserve to get the revenue that they deserve. But because of the eyesore like where's that conversation at. And the consumerism, we can go into the cigar bars and you can go into the bars and you can do hookah, and you can do cigars. You can't do cannabis, but we voted for that, like you owe us that. There's tyranny there. And who's talking about that? It's not okay. It's just not okay.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: And then I know there's a whole 2030 Boston blueprint and what it's supposed to look like, the metropolis that they're building around us. We don't see that in the urban community unless you go down to City Hall and you're aware of ... We'll just go over all of it. If you're aware of the protocol that they have for that. And the last thing is Nathaniel Holland Fenway Park. Those parks are for the people, but the people can't use them. In other words, there was just a write-up in the Globe that Fenway had never had lined the Urban Act in the whole history of the Fenway Park. I have never, ever wanted to say, "Hey son, let's go to Fenway Park for an hour." Never, and I take my kids on a lot of outings.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: And the other thing is the youth center, when I played football and one of the things I always was very happy about in all the years that I played with my children is when we go to those games the people who support them always had a banner, so we knew who the business owners that support our children. In Northeast, I never had one. And I'll end it with that.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: I guess one of my questions is basically the rising cost of living and how are those rent prices formulated? Is a lot of it coming from how they're redeveloping the City of Boston versus you would have just because this house right here is say what's the word, remodeled, and they price it at a higher point than someone that lives next door to you or whatever or a landlord who would raise their prices just because that's what some of the other houses are doing, and their house is not up to par where you would say someone would pay $2,300 and then you're asking for $2,300 and you don't you know what I'm saying have ... The disparity of how the cost of living has gone up in the past five or six years.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And have you been impacted by that? Is that why that question came up? What's your story? Why did you choose?

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: Basically, with the whole crash that happened back from '06 to '08, '09 that was right around the time when I started getting into my 30s and I was thinking about buying a home, and the whole home market industry changed where someone like me on paper was just a red flag. And the credit score and everything was changing where I did have a decent credit score, but everything was changing. There was a lull for like two or three years where it didn't seem like anyone could buy anything. You know what I'm saying? With the whole watching ... Like I said, with watching housing change where there were housing being sold, three family homes, like I live in Dorchester. For instance, living here in Dorchester versus someone who may live in Roxbury where they started talking about the word regentrification.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: To be on this side of how everyone had to highlight on Roxbury, I'm one of the people who living here in this community would say that Dorchester is being regentrified, and no one was paying attention to that because like I said the three family homes were being sold, but they're being sold and they're being turned into condos, and how do you turn a three family home and all of a sudden start saying that these are condo floors, and each floor now costs $360,000 versus a home, that whole home would run you $500,000. You know what I'm saying? I personally witnessed that. That's where my question comes from with the formula in pricing based of ...

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: Where I think the housing crash happened, it took away, I think, the American dream of a hard working person owning a home and being able to own a home and say possibly use one of their floors to be their small business or like I said a second income. That's what I've seen with the what happened to housing since 2008, and the way that is continuing. That's a part of the whole plan of where she says the whole plan of before was what was Boston going to look like in 2020, and now the whole vision is 2030, and just that part like where is rent going to go from here if an average three bedroom apartment if you can get it to say apartment and not condo is running like $2,200, $2,300 and more.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: There's something a lot of people who have decent jobs that work for the T, that work for the police, I work for the city, one of the city department divisions, and that's astronomical to be asking somebody to spend $2,000 a month. I've been fortunate to be in a situation where my family does own properties, and realistically for what has gone on like I said with the whole housing situation, I don't even seen my three family home being something that I want to stay. You see different changes in your neighborhood as far as one is a condo, one is a home owner, one is absentee landlord. Some of the communities really have a different wave of who may live from house to house, and it becomes a little uncomfortable. Sometimes you don't know who your neighbors are because the turnaround on renting is like this person's out of here in the morning.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: My question is the racism in the police force. I grew up in East Boston in Maverick projects. There were 12 families in the Maverick projects at the time in the late '60s and '70s when I moved there. As a child when the white boys, white girls busting our windows out I'm looking out the window peeking. And we'd call the cops. They'd come, do nothing, absolutely nothing. So as a little girl watching this, my mom walking around the house with a football helmet because bricks was coming through the windows. It got so back the Black Panthers actually came to Maverick projects to help us, to assist us because the cops never ever did anything for us. So my whole life I've endured this kind of racism on the police force, as a parent living in the projects in South Street watching my son and his friends being harassed constantly by the police. And there's never ever, in my opinion, my own experiences, there's never ever been anything but racism that I've seen.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: And then I think about the black cops. When are you going to show up for us? You're sitting in the cruisers with these folks. I was arrested for trying to defend my son in my home. Called them to my home. I'm in the back of a cruiser, and the white boy, because that's what they are to me, says to me, "What do you do for a living?" As he's transporting me to the jail, and I said, "None of your business." And his response to that was, "Probably nothing. You're just like the rest of them collecting a check."

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: That's what we endure. And at this age, 61 years old still enduring that kind of racism in the police force, so what is going to be done? Who's going to help us? We need some assistance with these folks that are supposed to protect and serve. I think it's just generational racism. Who are they now? The white boys that were busting my windows out, who are they now? Where are they now? Are they teaching my grandchildren with that racist spirit? Is this why our kids can't learn because you talk about generational wealth, what about generational racism? That's what I've endured. That's my question, when is there going to be some police reform and something has to be done about this racism on the force. When are they going to see us as people and human like the rest of them? When are they going to recognize that we need to be protected and served as well? Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: Thank you. Okay, everybody had some really good ones. Mine is totally about healthcare and really just figuring it out. I've been in healthcare for over 35 years and really just trying to figure out when or how do we either remove or reduce the gap of I would say good healthcare versus medical care for minorities because I think that more can be done for the community for people to get more preventative healthcare or more awareness. There's a lot of walks and different things for breast cancer and different things like that, but there's no things that minorities know about or feel comfortable participating in. And I think that if there was more preventative healthcare minorities would probably live longer because there's a lot of health issues that are hereditary things that are killing black men and women, but also I think that it's hard to get good healthcare in Boston if you don't have the right health insurance. So I would really like to see how to change that disparity.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Actually, the next part of this conversation is what did you hear from people that connect to your own concerns or issues, so you're right on cue, Samantha. Residents, look at the person whose question or story really connected to your concern, and then anybody can raise their hand and go.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: The two was Dionne and Nina, and I guess even if you have good healthcare they still ignore you. For example, my doctor knew that I had fibroids and didn't say anything to me, so I started complaining again. They could've been prevented [inaudible] or I could've done things to help shrink them or make a decision sooner, and now I have a worse situation than I did nine months ago.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: And then the other thing with what Dionne said is even though I'm from Dorchester I had to leave. I've always had a good job. I've always had a great salary, and my salary can't even afford to stay in Boston. That's a problem because now I have to transport back and forth, and my child is in school here. It's like I have a great job, but I still can't afford to live here. Those are the two things that resonated for me.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: I think you bring up a very good point because I have worked in healthcare for a long time. I have fibroids. I think that most black women do or had them. It depends on ... I always contribute it sometimes they're going faster because of weight, and people don't know that. But I think the issue really is that probably people that we see in the community don't know enough about it, so they're not educated enough about it. And I think I feel like I got good healthcare because of where I was, but I know so many other friends and family that I had to either advocate for them or tell them how to advocate for themselves. And I think after a couple surgeries I just decided to have a hysterectomy on my own because they kept growing back, but they really don't tell you all of the options like shrinking them or having ablation and doing a lot of things because they really don't know.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: They just kind of sweep it under the rug until you really have a medical issue where people are really hemorrhaging or people are forced to have a hysterectomy because your fibroids are so large. It does contribute, too, for women that have fibroids with infertility because basically that's what the fibroids do. It's blocking your uterus so that you can't carry. I've seen that happen to a lot of friends and family, and people feel shunned about it so people don't talk up about it, and when you talk up about it then you can get more educated by it.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: Yeah, I've had to just search groups online. Literally there's a large group online, but I had to look myself because the doctors just wouldn't say anything. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: I have a piggyback on what she said that's really important, and I'm guilty of this. I had hysterectomy and I had fibroids. And when I was hospitalized it was supposed to be a day treatment and I wind up in ICU after the procedure. And it wasn't because of what my doctor did for me. It was because of the workers that worked at the hospital. After the doctor does the procedure you go to the-

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: Yeah, like the staff. And those people there are people who they might want to be a nurse, didn't make the nurse or whatever. One of the guys happened to use drugs, and I accused him of taking my drugs. But the long story is after I got out of that hospital, which was a nightmare, and I had to fight literally and tell them, "Do not send any residents in my room anymore. Only send medical doctors. And do not come in here and tell me what you're going to do for me," because they were going to send me home with an oxygen tank. They was about to run it up. Because I was advocating for myself I knew that I had to get off the drugs and I had to see the medical doctor and not their little resident.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: But I didn't complain after I was discharged. I should've called the chaplain. I should've put in a written complaint so that nobody had to endure what I endured. And that's the thing that I was saying because the preventive is good, but then when we go through these experiments and these excruciating changes due to the doctor may be having an overload or just not educated, whatever it is, but then we don't write it down and complain so they can't fix the problem. So it's kind of like a two-fold. When we go through these things it's so important to go back and write that complaint because they have people on staff that only do that, and they want that information from us. We're guilty of that as a whole collectively. We can't get better preventive treatment if we're not playing into the system or partaking into the information.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: Yes, I have to piggyback off that. I agree because I had my gallbladder removed, and I was told that a blood vessel was cut during the surgery. It was supposed to be day surgery. I stayed three days in the hospital. I wake up violent, it's documented, and I hit a nurse, and she hit me back. So I was crying for my sister. And finally when my sister came in the back it had been on three hours. I laid there crying for my sister, and when Valerie finally came back there I was crying like, "What took you ... The nurse hit me." And she's like, "What?" I said, "Where have you been?" And she said, "I've been in the waiting room waiting for you." Three hours.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: A lot goes on. I had a really bad mean streak. God worked on that. But I wanted to fight. Literally like fight the nurse, I wanted to fight the doctor. It doesn't mean like you said advocating for myself, writing all this down, documenting all this and taking it through the protocol. I threatened the doctor. I was waiting for her. It's like I was just crazy in my head because they just treated me so bad, and I should've known better and I didn't at the time, so you're right. I agree with you 100% on that.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: I'll piggyback on her story on the real estate. If you could afford to pay $2,200, $2,300, $2,400 you should definitely be in your own property. There are some resources out there that are available, but they don't really make it public, so you've really got to go and search for it like Bank of America right now has, which I don't really like Bank of America, they have a really nice program right now for first time home buyers where they're giving like $15,000 for [inaudible] and closing costs. That's huge, but they're really not putting that out there where people can really get the information. That's one thing I think that if they make those resources known I think we'd be doing better because like I said if you're paying that kind of money or can afford to pay that kind of money you should be paying for yourself.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: I might just close on her with her business idea. The think about business is that a lot of people don't understand how business operates. They don't understand. They go around and say they're in business because they have an idea in their head, and that's not the way you do business. And people don't understand the importance of having a business registered. Even if it's just a hobby for your business, but having it registered as an LLC or corporation or whatever, DBA, whatever you decide is so intricate at this time because I believe that there's a movement going on where they want justice for the blacks, for the slavery, for what they put us through. And the SBA is one of the organizations that gives business owners the capital and the startup money when you have your business in order. And they're giving these grants. And these grants don't have to be paid back.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: But we as a people we don't have business. We don't understand how to open up a business. What does it mean to open an LLC? what does it mean to pay the registration fee? what does it mean to get your website? What does it mean? We simply don't understand that, and it's so important now especially where corporate America has really, really cut their numbers down. I work downtown, and I can't tell you how empty it is. I'm one of the few people that go to work every day. Now they're starting to come back, but like the Dunkin' Donuts isn't open. A lot of stores that you just assumed were there are closed, just closed, and they're still not open. And there's big businesses the lights are on but there's no movement. There's no people.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: But at the same token there's other businesses that are coming in and they're building. There's no people downtown. They're building these big skyscrapers and they're putting all these elaborate storefronts up, and the next thing like who's going to ... It's not making no sense. So I say get your business in order. Mind your own business is not negative. People think when somebody says mind your business ... That's the best advice somebody can give you, literally.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: We as people we think it's better to have a business and not pay taxes, find a way how to get around that, and that's why we're not surviving as business because you think you're saving a dollar by not paying your share of taxes. So we try to work under the table or do other things just so that you're invisible really, but you cannot grow a business that way. You really have to know your steps, know what you really need to do to be actually qualified as a business. And then they wonder why they're unable to grow because they have a business or they have a business name, but they're not registered as a business. The City of Boston or whoever the government cannot find you as a business, and you can't take advantage of the SBAs and all the other stuff that's out there to grow your business. But then they want to blame the white man for holding them down.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: I'll play devil's advocate because at the end of the day you have to take the initiative to look for information that is literally out there. When other people say you don't know how to run a business I see information in my face every day, free information about how to start your business, what to do, how to get business credit. The information is there, so if people really want it they can find it.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: [inaudible] right about all the businesses that are closed down, so when I have a break I'm a Duck Tour driver, so I'm downtown Boston every day. I have three locations so I can be either at the aquarium, the Museum of Science, or Prudential. And if I have a break, which is usually two hours, I'm just amazed at all the businesses that didn't survive. Like you said it's [inaudible], but yet the construction is astronomical down there. It's like you're on detours all the time because they're tearing this down, they're tearing that out, and the skyscrapers are steady going up. And yet people are like, "There's no jobs. There's no this." It's out there. You're right.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: But those people were in business. The people that are building are the people that had their business in order, and they are available to take advantage of the ... They get the grants too. You might be a small business owner getting a $5,000 grant. But if you're a big business owner you could get a ... You're hearing about these business having to pay back millions of dollars because they [inaudible] multi-million dollar company they know that money's out there, they're writing the proposal to get that money. Then it comes back. It's business. People build a skyscraper and people [inaudible] business.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Okay. Two things as we wind down. First of all, does anybody else want to share whether something resonated or not? And then if not, what are you hearing from people's experiences?

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: That there's a lot of changes that need to be made in our city for us. And some of it has to be by us as well. The voices have to be heard at the right table, and if not we've got to create our own table and make sure that the word is out.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: I'm a homeowner, and I agree with you about if you can spend $2,200, $2,300 a month like a friend of mine is renting his house out $2,800 a month. If you can spend $2,800, three grand a month because you're not getting utilities with that, then you're definitely right. I know credit score plays a big part. When I was working for the NBTA a lot of the black folks that worked for the NBTA and I'm still in the credit union couldn't get a loan. Can't get a loan. One of my friends she actually worked upstairs in that department, and they let her go because the racism was just blatant. You know what I mean? So that plays a great part as well.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: People can sugar coat it all day long, but it's black and white. I'm having diversity training on my job because I called the boss at Duck Tours out on their racist antics. I had enough. So now next year we're having diversity training, and they want me front and center. But yet they put out an unconscious bias video that everybody, all the employees had to look at, and they're making a mockery of it. It's ridiculous. So black and white is an issue, period.

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: I think that there needs to be some education around how we elect our local offices because they play a major role in these things that are happening around us, and if we don't [inaudible] really quick everyone is ... If we have anything being pushed to the wayside. I feel like if more people were educated on how the local officials are elected and how can we actually make them accountable to the platform that they say they're running on that we could possibly get more change. But I think it would be electing people we think are the best fit to help us progress. I would just love to see more people educated and more involved and participating in elections.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: No, that's great. I just want to say that I'm not allowed to comment on anything you say, and it's killing me. My job is just to listen and to keep the-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Claudette knows me, how hard this is for me. I have opinions and thoughts about everything you said, but that's not my role here today. So closing thoughts.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I'd like to hold their feet to the fire too, the elected officials. I think they say what we want to hear, and then once they are elected then it's a different story. We need to just make sure they want to come into this community because the black vote is what's going to really probably get them in office now, so they need our vote more than ever. So they're saying the right things, but we need to make sure that they do the right thing once they get there.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And how do we hold them accountable because we can say that this is what we need, this is what we want from you and everything is going to be yes, yes, yes to get that vote? How do we as the people hold them accountable?

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: That's the thing. They're just saying yes, but they're not giving the how and why, and we never question them about that.

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: We just hear them say yes and then that's it. And I think we just need to be a little bit more firm with them and have them really answer the deeper questions instead of it just being a flat yes.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: The way you do that is you have to put your money where your mouth is. Black people do not donate to politicians, so they have no reason to serve you. The reason why they serve the other communities, they pay into the politicians' pots, and that's just how it goes.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: They serve the interests that serve them. I didn't write the rules, but I [inaudible], and that's how it goes. The other thing is there's three things I want to close on. One of the things I want to start talking about was human rights versus civil rights. They say civil rights and the civil acts is such a big deal. To me it's not because the civil rights didn't make a big difference on the human rights. It's our human rights that they're violating. It ain't our civil rights. And that's the thing that we have to start collectively changing our mindset.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: I understand what it means to be disregarded with your human status. They play the word games on us a lot, and we buy into it. We think that we marched for civil rights. No, we want to march for human rights. You put our people in jail for marijuana and solitary confinement. That's human rights.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: And the other thing is immigration. They want us to wear our masks, and they want us to be protected, but the immigrants can come here untested, some of them undocumented, and some of them getting the benefits that are made for Americans that are in line waiting for benefits as we speak. That's not opinion. Those are facts because that's just the way our system works. And I don't have a problem with immigrations getting handouts or health when they need it, but don't give it on the health of the people that are in line that's waiting for their dime.

nodes.speaker: Darneese
nodes.words: Everything happens when we talk about reparations, the American Americans and descendants of slaves. You put anything LGBT and you will have an agenda. Anybody will have their agenda at the same time when we're supposed to be at the table. There was a case just recently that's historical that they had to give one of the African Americans or black Americans their land back in California worth $70 million. She's not the only one with that story. And the reason why I think that's happening because California has started to look at reparations and what that really looks like.

nodes.speaker: Dionne
nodes.words: There was somebody in Long Island too. A family got property in Long Islands along The Hamptons or somewhere in that area.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: Yeah, that's going to happen because whenever California it's kind of like a trickle down effect. And the thing is we're in the age of revelations. Anything is revealed to us. Donald Trump was one of the presidents that revealed his own men, his own white supremacist. He revealed it for the world. He revealed the fact that you can go and start as many businesses as you want, bankrupt them, liquidate them, and go back into business. That's what he is known for. That's why they can't touch us because he is a business man. He is a builder. When you're a builder they like to call you a mason, but when you're a builder no matter if you're a mason or a builder they earn a respect. They couldn't do nothing with him because he's a builder. Because I was wondering why can't they throw him out. He's a master builder. He develops.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: And the other thing is the American status. We must change our mode of thinking African American or this and that. We're Americans. Americans are going to get the benefits. Nobody else but Americans. This is the land of the free of America. We have to change our mindset to say we're American and get the benefits that we deserve as Americans. That's it.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I see what's in my face, but I think it's beyond that. This is probably going to be a longer conversation that I will get into, but I don't think it's that black and white. I think with generations before us [inaudible] certain things, and now we've gotten wiser and we're like, "Hey, this doesn't make sense." And I think that's really what it is as opposed to someone just saying we don't know our identity. And America is a melting pot, and so many people have contributed to the greatness of this country.

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: Then we need to hold them accountable and ask them these question so that we understand what the actual platform is because their platform is never very clear. When they did, they are really not doing what they said that they were going to do. The major thing is that no one focuses on us. They win, and then no one contacts [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: I guess that was my point but like how do you hold them accountable because I think that like you said they're all their saying the right thing or like they have the time. I sometimes correlate it to I hire people, so when we're interviewing people for a job they know what to say. They know what to do for the job. But when they come on board some people are surprised. Oh, you have a 90-day probationary period. We have people who will do very well, and then the minute the 91 days come then they're the employee from Hell or vice versa and it's the same thing. I have an opportunity, you could do corrective action, but you have an opportunity to let people go if they're not doing what they're doing, but when someone is elected if [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Samantha
nodes.words: If you're making these promises and people are voting for you and they you're not doing. You're not going to do everything that you say to make everyone happy. You'll always have that 80/20, but if the 80/20 is the opposite and it's 20/80, how do you hold those people accountable [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I think [inaudible] accountable is that we have to participate more. I personally don't think that we're participating enough. And to [inaudible] point, I don't think if we gave money anything would change, to be honest. I think they would still screw us because they're screwing us in other ways as well. I don't think money-

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: When she started talking about that because when I used to drive for the bus, right? So I drove for the MBTA, and I'll tell you something. When I was working out at Forest Hills upstairs and all the Caucasian folks were up there tapping their cards going to sit down and read their paper I'm taking [inaudible], that fare box, I learned how to count the money in the fare box, y'all, okay? And there's plenty of money in that fare box. And then I go downstairs and I drive the 31 route, the 21 route, and they're getting on saying he got it, she got it, he got it and they're walking all by me. And in the wintertime my folks are all[inaudible] freezing their behinds off and guess why, because they didn't pay that fare box.

nodes.speaker: Karen
nodes.words: So I started educating my folks. I told them, I said, "Listen, you're hurting yourself. It's 13 degrees out here, and you've been waiting for me to pull up for 14, 15, 20 minutes. Buses upstairs are running six, seven, eight minutes. They're running. You've got to feed the fare box." So maybe we've got to feed the politicians. [inaudible] got a point.

nodes.speaker: Nina
nodes.words: Well I think that ... In fact, I already started off that then people really have to get out and people really have to vote because you showed how it came all down to one vote. I think people think, [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Claudette
nodes.words: I think it's a combination of voting and actually supporting the politician because I know for a fact that the ones who are giving the politicians some money they do look out for that person or that organization. And the ones who do vote actually need to do more than just vote. After the election is over we need to call these politicians if we don't like something that they're doing or we feel that they're not doing enough for our community we need to call them because they have local offices within our community, and we don't go sit down with them or whatever and make ourself known to them.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yes. Any other closing comments, and do you mind if I take a picture? I just would love to take a picture of you all because we have been doing most of these remotely. [crosstalk]. Let me see. Yeah, okay. Let me get you together.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: All right. Power to the people. Let's have those raised fists. All right. Thank you. [crosstalk]. Oh, and let me shut this off.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yo soy un participante en esta conversación y mucho gusto, bienvenidos. Como participantes en esta conversación, está dando su consentimiento a Real Talk for Change para que utilice la grabación de acuerdo con su misión. También comprende que la conversación será parte de una colección de la Red de Voces Locales, Local Voices Network de Cortico, y su misión de promover conversaciones que mejoren nuestra comprensión mutua en las comunidades y los medios de comunicación. Cortico recopilará, retendrá y analizará estas conversaciones de acuerdo con esa misión. Si comprende y está de acuerdo con esto, diga "estoy de acuerdo". Y me gustaría, María, diga su nombre y entonces "estoy de acuerdo". ¿Está bien?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Muchas gracias. Y ahora me gustaría otra vez dice su nombre y cómo te sientes ahora. Una palabra solamente, cómo te sientes.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Y Michael Jacoby Brown. Estoy en gratitud y muchas gracias a Denise y todos los demás. La primera pregunta es-- me gustaría pedirle cuál es su pregunta sobre el futuro de Boston y su lugar en ese futuro. Otra vez. ¿Cuál es su pregunta sobre el futuro de Boston y su lugar en ese futuro? Y toma un minuto o dos minutos para pensar en esto. ¿Comprendes? ¿Entiendes? ¿Está bien?

nodes.speaker: Nidia
nodes.words: Mi nombre es Miriam Mejía. ¿Al futuro? Una comunidad más tranquila, más servicio en la calle, más policías, security, más buildings para la gente mayor.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Bueno, algo que a uno le preocupa es tanto tiroteo que hay por todas partes. Incluso aquí hubo tiroteos en estos buildings. Eso es algo muy preocupante.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Eso. A ver qué se puede hacer, ¿verdad? O, no sé, más cámaras o más cosas. Porque muchas veces están los tiroteos y no se sabe quién hizo los tiroteos y todo eso.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: No personal, pero aquí donde yo vivo, en el building, hubo un tiroteo que rompieron persianas y todo. Por eso es que me preocupo, imagínate.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Porque a veces hay personas mayores que están buscando lugares buenos, tranquilos, callados, que no haya tanto revolú de tiroteos, como dice ella, para vivir tranquilos, por lo menos, ya que uno llegó a cierta edad, uno quiere tener paz y tranquilidad.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Bueno, no conmigo directamente, pero con unas clientas mías sí. Estábamos en una cita médica y cuando nos regresamos la guagua del programa donde ella asiste, cuando fue a llevarla frente al building, había un muchacho queriendo tirotear a otro muchacho. O sea, que esto--

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Pero ahí no había cámaras en esos lados ni nada. Y cuando el chofer quiso llamar a la policía, él se fue, pero como no había cámaras. Entonces, es peligroso cuando hay algo así uno grabarlo, porque entonces pueden cogerla con uno. Pero si hay cámaras, van al building y procuran las cámaras, tienen pruebas. Pero si no, no hay.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Eso es, una bala perdida. Y la señora estaba nerviosa. La señora, cuando subió a la casa, subió a acostarse, mal.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Bueno, yo voy en la misma línea que Herminia. Yo creo que sobre todo mucha seguridad, mayormente donde hay personas de la tercera edad que viven, hay que darle más seguridad y darles más beneficios en cuanto a la salud, porque uno en un tiempo se va a ver en ese mismo estado que ellos. Que tengan viviendas que se sientan seguras donde viven, que tengan más beneficios, que muchas veces no los tienen, no se los dan. Igualmente con los niños. Uno tiene a los niños en la escuela. Cuando se desmontan del bus que a veces hay muchos delincuentes, hay balaceras, hay muchas personas también que no saben conducir, hay muchos accidentes también, que deberían también tomar medidas sobre eso también en un futuro. Inmediato también, porque se ve a diario.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Bueno, en el entorno, aquí, mayormente se ve mucho en verano, se ven muchos accidentes, personas que no viven de estos lados, muchachos jóvenes que pelean o tirotean que, cuando uno viene a darse cuenta, tiene que meterse a donde uno encuentre. ¿Me entiende? Y uno a veces no se siente seguro, ni los hijos de uno.

nodes.speaker: Adela
nodes.words: Sí. Antes era terrible, ahora ya tenemos más tranquilidad, porque Dorchester Bay hizo una seguridad, tenemos una seguridad que cuida estos buildings. Eso es la policía, cuida.

nodes.speaker: Adela
nodes.words: Yo he visto cuando ellos se tirotean, unos están [inaudible], otros se quedan en el piso, viene la policía, los recoge, los mandan a la ambulancia, otros que se esconden. La policía no se va, hasta que los encuentran. Y hay un hecho específico y yo siempre se los he dicho a ella, que es muy importante. Me encontré una vez que una madre-- ellos corrieron a esconderse. Eran como cuatro: uno huyó, el otro quedó herido en otra cuadra y tres se escondieron en los buildings. Entonces, cuando vino la policía, la policía estuvo aquí más o menos como unas casi seis horas, buscando de building en building con los perros policía, todo.

nodes.speaker: Adela
nodes.words: ¿Qué sucedió? Que de repente yo salí, porque es mi comunidad y yo soy el líder comunitario. Entonces, yo salí y de repente una mamá de ellos, que uno de ellos vivía en la esquina, y bajó la señora y me dice: "Adelita, ¿qué cree usted que yo debo hacer?". Y yo le digo: "Usted tiene que hacer lo que debe hacer. No se pregunte dos veces. Haga lo que debe hacer". Entonces, ella vino y me ha dijo: "¿Usted ha visto dónde--?" Porque, usted sabe, viene la policía y viene un detective. Entonces, ella me dice: "¿A quién tengo que dirigirme? ¿A un detective o a un policía?". Le digo: "Al primero que encontremos en el camino". Entonces, viene un detective, y yo le digo: "A mí me parece que es, porque tiene el arma guardada". Entonces, ella le dice: "Señor, por favor, suba. Arriba está mi hijo. Está escondido en el baño, en el tercer piso". El policía subió. Ella entregó a su hijo. Me parece que es lo mejor que hizo esa madre. Algo de aplaudir. De ahí sé otros casos más, pero quiero que los demás residentes también hablen. Señorita Elda.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: ¿Tiene usted una pregunta sobre--? Queremos oír cuál es su pregunta sobre el futuro de Boston y su lugar en ese futuro, y qué experiencia en tu vida, una experiencia personal, te llevó a esta pregunta. ¿Tiene una pregunta o algo?

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Yo tengo una observación. La pregunta sería de que si el nuevo alcalde electo puede trabajar más en conjunto con la policía, o no sé con qué entidad, para que haya mayor control sobre las drogas. ¿Por qué? Si bien es cierto, el consumo de ciertos gramos de marihuana es permitido por la ley. Esto no quiere decir que la gente tenga más restricción en su consumo. En la calle, usted lo huele en todas las esquinas. Inclusive en las zonas periféricas de donde uno vive. Y personalmente me ha tocado ver cómo venden, o sea, uno en el carro le da el paquetito, el otro le da el dinero y uno tiene que quedarse-- uno se asusta en primer lugar, porque uno no está acostumbrado a eso. Y obviamente ya uno vive atemorizado, porque si esas personas que venden drogas se dan cuenta que usted ve, ya usted se gana un enemigo. Entonces, eso ya genera en uno como personas que viven en este sector de andar con miedo a las calles, de no querer ni salir, no querer ni abrir las ventanas, porque el olor de la marihuana entra a las casas y eso genera molestias en las personas que no consumimos. Entonces, eso sería mi apreciación.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Yo viví a lo mejor casi lo mismo, de la seguridad, de los buildings, porque hay demasiado delincuencia. Por lo menos que haya más seguridad con-- que llaman para cualquier cosa, que vengan de una vez, porque uno no está-- en el building ahí donde yo vivo también tiraron una bala, que si la señora no hubiese estado acostada, la matan, porque pasó así de la cama. Una señora que vive ahí.

nodes.speaker: Candita
nodes.words: Sí. Bueno, yo no sé si sería como tal una pregunta, pero sí sería como decirle, por ejemplo, que en los próximos futuros, el que sea, por ejemplo, como dijo ella, que sea la gobernadora de aquí, que haya más fondos para estos policías que vienen a los edificios, para que hayan más policías donde-- por ejemplo, en el building que haya un policía, en el building de ella que haya otro policía. No policía, sino-- ¿cómo--?

nodes.speaker: Candita
nodes.words: Seguridad. Para seguridad. Sí. Porque a veces no tenemos-- tal vez no tienen tantos fondos para la seguridad, ¿usted ve? Pero, por ejemplo, el buidling de ellos, de aquí al lado, pueda que vaya la policía, pero al de nosotros no va, los guardianes no van. O sea, yo nunca he visto un guardián en mi building a venir. O sea, okay, es tranquilo, gracias a Dios, vivimos como familia ahí, pero sería muy bueno que un día entre un guardián y suba allá arriba y baje y dé una vuelta por atrás y mire, porque eso le da más tranquilidad a uno, más seguridad. Entonces, ¿cómo se logra eso? Con fondos. Que se consigan fondos para esa institución. Sí. ¿Qué podemos nosotros hacer? Si yo tengo que votar por fulana, porque ella va a lograr con fondos para eso, yo voto por esa persona, un ejemplo. Para que haya fondos para lograr eso. Porque ahora ahora estamos un poquito bien, pero cuando llegan esos veranos es bien difícil. Entonces, cada tiempo se ve muchos casos de personas que-- una bala perdida. De niños, gentes mayores, uno en su propia casa. Yo, por ejemplo, tengo un sofá frente a una ventana. Pero yo no me siento en esa ventana hasta en la hora que yo sé que hay mucha gente en la calle. Yo mejor me siento más para allá.

nodes.speaker: Candita
nodes.words: Porque yo no sé cómo puede venir una bala perdida de un pronto. Y ellos, hay cámaras ahí. Allá hay cámaras y hay hasta algo que si echase tiroteo, avisa la policía. Yo creo que hay ahí. Por lo que yo creo. Pero es como le digo, no se siente uno como tan seguro, tan tranquilo. ¿Usted ve?

nodes.speaker: Candita
nodes.words: Esa es mi cosa, que me vino así, estaba pensando, con más ayuda para esas personas, para que haya más seguridad.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Yo pienso y hago esta pregunta. En el futuro, ¿qué pasará en la calle, los carros que andan con velocidad y atropellan a niños? Precisamente no hace ni dos meses, atropellaron a un niño cerca de aquí.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Por la velocidad. Que pongan [inaudible] a los conductores. Saben que la velocidad en el suburbio son de 30 millas. 30 millas, ¿no es?

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: 30 millas. Pero ellos andan más. A cada rato hay accidentes aquí en la Columbia Road. Y en muchas partes de Dorchester.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: So she wants to know about-- she said that there's a lot of speeding, like not too long ago a car hit a kid, and it was a hit and run. So she wants to know, in the future, is this speeding going to continue, is the speed limit going to be the same, are they going to put the--

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Y cuando tú cruzas la calle, eso es personal. Cuando tú cruzas-- she lives right on Columbia Road. So you know Columbia Road?

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Yeah. So when she's going to cross the street, she's afraid to cross the street because she don't know, cars come out of nowhere. You could be like, "Wow, there's no car."

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Sí. A mí me pasó-- yo antes cruzaba la calle así normal, pero ya no, ya yo me voy a mi línea, le doy a mi botón, espero mi tiempo, espero hasta que pongan el muñequito y todo para cruzar la calle. Yo hago todo eso. ¿Pero qué pasa?

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Yo antes no lo hacía. Pero ahora digo: "Hay que hacerlo". ¿Qué pasa? Yo estoy ya cruzando mi calle, en el mismo medio así. Cuando yo hago así, viene Jeepeta así, yo le digo: "Hey".

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: En el medio de la calle. Pero yo estaba allá, yo había cruzado en rojo. O sea, estaba bien. Yo estaba bien. Pero salió esa Jeepeta así de esa calle, de ahí. Y yo le-- "Hey".

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: So, like I expressed before, my concern is, I drive every day, so the streets are getting worse and worse, like they do a patch here, they do a patch there, there's holes eveywhere.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: So I want to know like, in the future are they going to fix these streets or are they going to keep it the way it is, or they're going to make it worse? Because it keeps getting worse. So I want to know like what is the plan, is it even in the plan that they're going to pave the street better?

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Sí. So yo le estaba diciendo que yo manejo todos los días y las calles están peor y peor. Hacen roto por dondequiera.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Entonces, encuentra a alguien cuya pregunta o experiencia resuene con su propia vida y dirígete a esa persona, dile por qué su pregunta o experiencia le resonó y comparte la historia de tu vida que te conecta con su experiencia. ¿Entiende?

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Debe de hacer revisión, qué se yo, de vez en cuando, en las esquinas, los carros, la ciudad debe de encargarse de eso, porque todo el mundo armado así. O por lo menos que sean con permiso, algo. Pero mucha gente tiene las armas sin tener ningún--

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: So she's saying that a lot of people carry guns illegally, and she would like at least like police that do traffic stops or be in the neighborhood, the police be more involved in the neighborhood, so they can actually catch people, because it's getting worse and worse with people carrying illegal guns.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: ¿Hay alguien que tú conoces que tenga una historia personal sobre alguien que tenga una pistola o que ha disparado o algo?

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: El comentario que yo hice, sobre lo de la marihuana. No lo iba a decir, pero es importante acotarlo. Donde yo vivo, mi dormitorio, la ventana da a un patio, un lugar común. En las tardes, llegando ya casi la noche, el olor a la marihuana es insoportable.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: En dos ocasiones tuve que abrir la cortina y ver qué es lo que pasaba, quién era, qué era. Y en las dos ocasiones eran teenagers, muchachos que salen de su escuela, de su colegio, y se reúnen, como esas zonas son oscuras y escondidas, y se ponen a fumar. Y no se iban y ya habían cogido de hueco, de guarida ese lugar. Entonces, un día me armé de valor y les golpeé al vidrio y les dije que si no se iban iba a llamar a la policía. Nunca más volvieron.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Entonces, si hubiera un poquito más de vigilancia a partir de la tarde, que salen los chicos del high school. Como dice Elda, los inspectores o los de seguridad--

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Las mismas personas delincuentes o muchachos que hagan estas cosas ya no van a ir a ese lugar, porque van a saber "ahí está un supervisor, un policía que va a dar la vuelta, mejor vamos a otro lugar". Sería una de las pocas soluciones que se podría dar a ese asunto, porque el consumo es un poco que se sale de las manos. Pero tratar de que sea menos, lo menos posible en nuestra comunidad, sí se puede lograr.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Sí. Pero son muchas veces menores de edad. El consumo autorizado por la ley es para los adultos que tienen problemas de salud y que se autoriza ciertos gramos, pero eso es como que dice viva la fiesta, todo el mundo quiere andar con su droga en la calle. Antes lo hacían más recatadamente, pero ahora es de frente, en la calle, no le importa si al de al lado le molesta o le hace daño el olor. O sea, es como una cosa bien incómoda y preocupante.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Pero lo pusieron aquí, en el driveway. Tenían que ponerla ahí adelante, donde ellos se sientan a beber y a fumar. Y en el ascensor yo no creo que haya cámara, porque [inaudible] ahí adentro se sientan con el frío y hacen de todo ahí.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: A mí me entran bajo a cigarrillo, de cosas ahí que va-- yo tengo que irme para el cuarto, porque yo soy asmática, yo me cae una tos que quedo--

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Pero ya eso es cuestión del building, eso no es cuestión de la ciudad. Esto es los dueños del building. [crosstalk] más seguridad.

nodes.speaker: Nidia
nodes.words: Dice ella que en el basement se van a fumar marihuana. Y eso es cuestiones de las managers, que reúna a los residentes. Cuando se den cuenta que abran-- tienen cámara escondida. Cuando ven que abren el basement y lo dejen abierto, entonces ellos van a tener una reunión [inaudible] del building.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Hablamos después, luego. No, she's talking about like building issues where people are going in to smoke, and she's saying that the management should have a meeting with the residents and stuff like that.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: ¿No tienen preguntas como que "oh, yo quiero saber si en el futuro Boston se va a ver igual o Boston se va a ver como Nueva York"? Porque eso es lo que yo también-- se va a ver como Nueva York, están haciendo building encima de building encima de building.

nodes.speaker: Jacqueline
nodes.words: Yo veo en el futuro que se va a poner [inaudible] peor que Nueva York. Porque en todos los lugares que yo he pasado están haciendo muchos buildings, en cada esquinita, están sobrepoblando la ciudad. En un futuro no muy lejano tú no vas a hallar ni por donde tú andar, porque está demasiado [crosstalk].

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: She's saying that in the future's going-- actually not too far from now it's going to get worse than New York because they're doing way too many buildings, and the population of Boston is getting way out of hand.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: She said it could be progress and bad at the same time, because they're making more apartments and stuff, but it can also be bad.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Progreso en el sentido dependiendo de las personas que vayan a vivir, el uso que se le vaya a dar también, todo eso influye.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Yeah. She's saying that it also includes that it could be affordable apartments and apartments that people can actually utilize and that can bring resources to the residents there.

nodes.speaker: Nidia
nodes.words: Yo veo a Boston en el futuro una ciudad bonita, limpia. Porque Boston es limpio comparando con otras ciudades. Boston es bonito.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: So she said that in the future she sees Boston to be very clean, because compared to a lot of other cities and stuff, Boston is actually the cleanest.

nodes.speaker: Herminia
nodes.words: Lo mismo. Esa gente que cuando le van a dar un apartamento a una gente deben de averiguar bien quién es y que sea una gente seria. Si es una gente de edad, okay, si ya coge su retiro o lo que sea, pero una gente jovencitos que lo que andan es en eso y se lo dan a cualquiera.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Okay. Entonces, ¿usted cree que en ese futuro de Boston que se ven casas de bajo ingresos para las personas, que las puedan comprar, que sean accesibles? Porque ya en Boston no se puede comprar una casa.

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Yo vivo aquí, en esos apartamentos, pero por ejemplo tal vez yo no quiero comprar una casa, pero mi hija quiere comprar una casa. Entonces, cada tiempo está más difícil. No es accesible a nosotros comprar una casa en Boston. ¿Usted ve en ese tiempo más-- que Boston tenga casas accesibles para las personas que quieran comprar casa de bajos ingresos?

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: She wants to know do you see in the future that Boston will have-- first-time homebuyers available like-- first-time homebuyer houses available for people that are kind of like-- that are in the low income brackets?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: No, that's an important question. Es una pregunta muy importante y no sé el futuro, no estoy seguro qué pasará. Pero está importante que ustedes votan. ¿Entiende?

nodes.speaker: María
nodes.words: Una de las candidatas, yo he escuchado en la televisión que una de sus propuestas de campaña es controlar los altos arriendos de las casas, las rentas, regularizar las rentas. Entonces, si va por ese lado, quién quita que en el futuro también puedan incluir las viviendas a más bajo costo, para que sean accesibles, ¿no?

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Yeah. So she was saying that maybe in the future after that is controlled, maybe they'll have the low-income housing-- first-time homebuyers.

nodes.speaker: Ester
nodes.words: Lo que pasa es que todo el mundo debe de ir a votar. Hay gente que no van. Se quedan acostados y no van.

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Es que también algunas veces ellos prometen, prometen y prometen, y al final, cuando ganan, no hacen. Eso es otro problema también. I said that there's another problem, that a lot of city councils, governors, mayors, they promise so much to Boston, promise, promise, promise, and once they win the election and they get their position, they don't do what they say that they were originally going todo. So that's the problem too, that we could vote and we'll vote for them, but what makes us sure that they're actually going to do what they say they are going to do?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah, I can't say this well in Spanish, but you need to follow up and build an organization, construir una organización de mucha gente, que tiene como un sindicato que tiene fuerte-- ¿entiende?

nodes.speaker: Anaya
nodes.words: Yeah. So yo le dije a él lo que les dije a ustedes, que muchas veces nosotros votamos, votamos y votamos y ganan, entonces cuando están en el puesto de ellos no hacen nada. Entonces, él dice que si eso pasa ustedes que reúnan muchas personas, hagan una organización de ustedes juntos, que así puedan ir a State House y hablar con ellos y, tú sabes--

nodes.speaker: Nidia
nodes.words: Yo tengo-- perdón, no vive aquí. Yo tengo a mi cuñada que vive en Búfalo, New York. Su casa ella la compró con un programa así, de bajo income. La esposa de David.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Entonces, muchas gracias por sus preguntas y sus historias y experiencias. Y gracias, entonces, para-- hay muchos alimentos, pizza, agua.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Just so you know, you see it's orange there, that's how you know it's worth more. There's orange around there, so if it changes to some other color, hola. First of all, I want to thank you all for being here tonight. We set up these conversations around the city of Boston, for what we're calling Real Talk for Change, Boston. The idea here was to create an opportunity for people throughout Boston to actually have their voices heard. We targeted mostly what we call under heard voices. The people who in the midst of an election or other efforts in the city, don't necessarily get listened to, or don't have a platform that's really comfortable for them for saying what they want to say. Aren't, even if they do have [inaudible], there's no way to kind of get it in front of other people and people who should be listening to it. So what we're trying to do in this effort, is actually change that.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The way we do it, is by having small conversations throughout the city. We have a mechanism for taking those conversations and uploading them online and making them available for anyone to see. Then with a team of people from our lab and a couple of key fellows, going through all those conversations and really finding the different things and highlights, that have come across in the conversations, and the patterns that are existing. Then pushing those back out to the public, to news media and others to actually try to elevate and give lift to those voices. Tonight, we're going to be recording. I want to say a couple things about the recording. This is an audio recording only. When we finish, this will actually... I'll take this back and upload it on the web. Then we'll let you know when it's actually there and available, so that you can actually see the conversation. I'm going to do a quick round of introductions in a minute.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: But before we do that, I had to take care of some of the administrative parts of this. Everything has that in it in this world. As I said to you, we are doing these recordings. These recordings are actually going live on a platform that's run by a non-profit that we support called Cortico, and they've become part of what's called Local Voices Network. We say living, shouldn't do that, but they are living on local network. We're doing Real Talk as our conversations, there are hundreds of other conversations going around the country in different formats and different things, we can all reside in the same place together. It's like the platform. In some sense, you could think of it, as our Zoom space. It's something that we use that actually connects all these different conversations. Our conversation is private, so it's held on our own collection.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Right now, the only people who can see that collection and people who participate in conversations. Where in particular parts of those conversations are going to be made public, and there's a process we have checking back with some of our community partners, who for right now have entrusted Ron and I have to make a decision about which cuts can actually go public or not. That's the process we're in right now, and we can send you more information at the end of this conversation. Now a little bit about the technical part. We are recording this and so I need to have your permission to record. The way we're going to do that, I want to read a statement to you. Then I need you, each go around and say basically if you agree with that, okay? Let me do that, and then we get us started and I have to actually read it. As a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent to Real Talk for Change, to use and retain the recording in accordance with it's mission.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You also understand that the Real Talk for Change conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. We will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand this and agree that you will participate in the recording, can I hear you each say yes.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yes. Uh-huh (affirmative), I have to participate too. With that, let's get into the beginning of this conversation. The first thing is, let's center ourselves and find a way to just kind of set ourselves and get into the room. The way I want to do that, is I'm going to have you each go around and introduce yourselves to each other. What I want you to do is say your name, say what part of the city you're from, and then I'm going to give you some prompts. There's four prompts I'm going to ask you to check in on, okay? But before I say that, one thing you can do in this, if you decide... Now is the time, you can decide. You can use a different name by now, you don't have to use your real name. If you're feeling like, I may say some things and I want to be free, if you want to use a pseudo name, let me know. The way you let me know is when you introduce yourself, whatever name you use, that's the name we're going to use throughout the rest of the conversation, okay? Cool.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I'm going to go round, I'm going to pick a person. They're going to start out, when they finish, the person on their right is going to go next. That's the pattern we're going to use. Here's what I want you to do. I want you to say your name, what part of the city and I want you to check in on four things. We call this pies. How you're doing physically, how you're doing intellectually, how you're doing emotionally and how you're doing spiritually. I want you checking all four. But today you may feel like I only want to use three, or two, or one or none. That certainly is up to you., but we're doing this as a way to just let you bring a whole part of who you are into the room with us today. With that Tibi, I'm going to start with you.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Tibi. I live in East Boston and physically, I feel good, healthy. Mentally, I've been feeling a little bit anxious. I'm waiting for medical result from an exam, that my mom just took a few days ago, so I've been a little bit anxious about that. But other than that, I'm feeling good.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Good evening. My name is Zakiya Alake. I live on the Roxbury-Dorchester line actually. Checking in physically, everyday my back is a little bit better than it's been in the last 18 months and that's a big deal for me, because I have to do a lot of walking and talking in my life. Intellectually, oh man, I'm really busy right now reading about food systems. From the point of view of Black farmers down south. I do a fair amount of food security volunteer work here in Boston, so that's exciting to me. It's exciting that one of my nieces in college found the book and knew about my interest in it, and gave it to me when she was finished. Emotionally, I'm excited, I'm feeling passionate, I guess would be the word about the different opportunities I have to do good in my community. Spiritually, there's a old Buddhist expression, to poison into medicine and that's what I'm working with right now, turning bad situations into things that I grow from, and with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: The other thing is I forgot the one part of this, if it's the same after you've finished, your prize. You're supposed to say, "With that, I'm in."

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: Hi, everyone. My name is Sarah. I live in South Boston, not far from the Broadway T stop. Physically, I'm feeling a little bit stressed recently. I'm applying to graduate school and I am planning a wedding at the same time, which is a lot to take on.

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: Thank you. All good things, but definitely feeling a little bit of stress at the moment. Intellectually, I'm feeling curious. I think that I'm really excited about the work that I've been doing recently and how that might tie into my future plans, and I think it all feels really like there's a lot of opportunities coming up which I'm excited about. Emotionally, I'm feeling light. I think that I have spoken with many of you many times, but I've not been able to sit in the same room with many of you and it's just a really wonderful feeling to be surrounded by this group of people. Spiritually, I'm feeling thankful. This time of year as the weather turns colder, I always am reminded about how fortunate I am, and just reminded how important it is to be giving back to others. With that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I'm Francesca, I live in Fields Corner, which is a neighborhood of Dorchester. Oh, sorry, and I have a big voice, I'm sure you could hear it through my mask. Physically, I'm doing really good. I actually had a physical for the first time in two years on Friday night and I'm a diabetic, and all of my test results were stellar.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: And I've actually turned some of my pre-existing dangerous things as a diabetic. my eyes were not good, and now my eyes are better and all my test results were stellar. I heard this study from researchers at university, that if you work 7000 steps a day, you can live forever, so that's my goal. I'm more like 4500, but I'm getting there. I did 8800, it took me two hours, so I guess working class people, that's why we're fat, because we don't have two hours to walk. Anyway... Then I just want to skip to spiritually. I feel super good, especially in the space. I want to welcome you all on behalf of Freedom House, which is like a spiritual space for us in the Black community. It's a 70 year old legacy organization. I've been working with them off and on for decades and they're part of Real Talk for Change, and all of their staff participating. So it feels really nice that we're doing this here in this space, especially since thank the votes started, originally was housed at Freedom House, so with that I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Hi, my name is Becky. I live in Brighton. Basically, I'm doing all right. I mean, I'm pretty tired, it's been a full day. I've just been making a lot of site visits of my organization and I think that ties into intellectually. I would say, like Sarah, I'm also curious. I do a lot of community work, just to my regular job. But I also see that there are a lot of things in the neighborhood that still need to be addressed that I don't think the organizations here are already addressing, or this one but in general, physically, intellectually. Emotionally, I'm feeling... I would say I'm feeling good. I would say that I feel like I'm learning and that's always a good thing. I think spiritually, I feel fantastic. I had a great conversation with a work colleague about faith and just seeing like how all this ties into what we're doing, ties into groups that we're in. With that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Hi my... Excuse me. My name is Ron Bell. I'm from Mission Hill, which is a part of Roxbury and actually I've lived in about five different neighborhoods in the city of Boston. Growing up here, going to school and working here. Physically, I'm in the best shape my life. I mean, I know you was talking about 8000 steps, I've been up to 15,000. That's part of my work, crisscrossing the city, [inaudible] city of Boston and I feel great. I had a physical the other day and my doctor said I was in the best shape of my life. I was like, "Wow." So that makes me feel good.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Intellectually, I've been working on a lot of final reports and trying to figure out what's next for our community? What's next for this project? What's next for Dump The Boat and so forth. Emotionally, it's been actually good. Saturday, we celebrated the Melvin King Square, which was exciting. He's a mentor to many of us. That was like a lifting of my spirit, my morale to see people from every sector in Boston come together. Of course, this project was in his honor when we first started, when we did the launch, and I was really touched by that. But spiritually, I'm grounded in my faith in everything I do, so I'm solid in that, so I'm all in.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Good evening, everyone. My name is Marilyn Foreman and I am from Dorchester not too far from here. I do so many miles a day in my car. Laugh it out.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah. I really want to just check in physically and say that I feel pretty good. My back was hurting for a couple of days, but I have a granddaughter and a half a second floor unit that I decided to rent to her and her new husband and they're early 20s, and I'm like, "This is probably the biggest mistake of my life." I'm going to... That'll probably be in one of my other checked in points when I get to that one. But, intellectually, I think that maybe I've made the right choice. Because sometimes I feel like our young people do need good role models.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I think that my husband and I have the best relationship on this planet and so we will be good mentors to that new union. Emotionally, I feel overwhelmed. Because there's just so much going on. You want to try and be supportive to all of those things, you see the need of people and I think to whom much is given, much is required, right? I feel like I need to always give back, and I'm always trying to figure out ways to do that, and so it's overwhelming. Because it's like, "I'm one person, I can't do all that, but I need to do it." So yeah, which one was that? Emotionally, right?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Spiritually, yes I too am grounded, and that's what keeps me going. My faith, because when I feel like I can't, God said yes you can, I got you. So I just keep on keeping on and with that I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: Hello, everyone. I'm Elden [Villafane]. I live in Jamaica Plain. Right now, emotionally, I am going through good emotions and personal challenges. When I'm working on learning to work with my friends and talk to my friends and build relationships and rebuild relationships since I've been gone for years outside of my town of Boston. Now that I returned, it's not too long ago, so I'm rekindling and revisiting my relationship so that's helped me emotionally. Physically, I just want to mention. I've been in better shape than I've been in a long while. Actually got a personal trainer, actually started exercising. It has helped me with my emotional-

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: And helped me to work my stress. Because at the same time on my personal career and business, that's been keeping me busy and so that's been good, that's been picking up. Then we have spiritually. I too, am grounded in my faith and that has kept me level headed and centered. Then I think with that, I'm in.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So nice to actually come together. Start out by just listening to the other dimensions of people's lives and really coming short. I appreciate all of you taking that step and that risk, to share it with each other here. I want to move us into the kind of heart of this conversation, and it has two parts to this... Let me put it over here. There are three sections to the conversation. The first section has two parts. So let me give you the instructions. What I want you to do is think about this a lot. The first part, and the first question I want you to respond to is this problem.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: It goes, what's your question about the future of Boston, and your place in that future? Let me just say it again. I'll say it again. My question of question about the future of Boston and your place in our future. What I want you to do, not to answer that. I want you to think about what that question is for you. I'm sure you have many, but the one that you want to share today. I'll give you a few minutes just to think about it. (silence) How are people doing? (silence) How about this one saying that once you're done just put one or two hands on the table and then that way, I'll know you're done.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Everyone have their question? Here's the second part of this. Our questions don't just come out of thin air, they come from somewhere and they can come from lots of different things. It could be something you read in the paper, or that you look at it and question, it is something you saw on the street, or something you heard on the radio. But what I want to do is, kind of get a deeper understanding of your questions. Because I believe when we look at these questions about the future and how we see ourselves in the future, a lot of what generates that question is some experience we had. What I want you to think about is, what's the experience behind the question you're asking? What's the experience you personally have had that has informed that question?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: When I say experience, I don't mean, what did you hear about what somebody else did? I don't want you to something outside, something that's an embodied experience that you actually had. What I want you to do is think about that experience, and then think about how to tell us about it as a story. What I'm going to do is have each person go around and tell us that question, and tell us the experience. [inaudible] that question. I'll give you a minute to just kind of think about what experience you want to add, and then we can just start out. (silence) Now, I'm going to use the same process we did before. I'm going to call on someone, we're just going to go around clockwise in order from there. I think I'm going to start with her.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I just want to... No, let's keep it on. Just to remind everyone, first you say your question very clearly and then tell us the story of your experience.

nodes.speaker: Becky
