nodes.words: I think my question about the city of Boston is what is it being developed for? What I mean by that is that, there are many buildings going up. What I mean by that are, apartment buildings, condos and the like in different neighborhoods. I think in my own, like Allston, Brighton. They're beautiful. They're also taking over many of the old houses that are in the area, and they're very expensive. A family of three might spend like $3,000 to live in a luxury condo, and these luxury condos don't even have a living room. Traditionally, this neighborhood has been very... It has been working class young people of different color. But it seems like this in my experience with that is, it doesn't seem like these people are the ones being considered for these condos. Many people are being pushed out, and I hear that they are out of the city.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: What did you say was your [crosstalk]. And true on your perspective? But I was hearing an analysis, I wasn't hearing your own body, your experience. What happened to you in your live that makes our question so-

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Oh, what's going... Okay, what's happening for real. The real question is like... Personally, would I be able to live in the city that I love? I moved here two years ago, and I think the only reason why I can afford to live in the place that I live is because, I'm renting from my aunt's best friend and we live in a shared house, me and my roommates. We're paying much less than $1000 each person. I could live through my means and I'm fine. But it's like, I also know that it's important to buy home, especially if friends are going to continue to grow up. Looking in this neighborhood that has traditionally been working class, houses are starting at $600,000.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I guess that's might be affordable to some people, but not me and not a lot of people who live here. Talking to a lot of my neighbors, were just thinking, what are we going to do? This is why there's community meetings, and it seems like the PDA allows enough space just to tell the residents during these community meetings, this is our project, this is what we're going to do, what do you want? With that, we can move forward with it, and there's maybe space for two or three people to ask questions, then they get cut off and then the process is just... How do I say? It doesn't seem like a real process, it seems like a sham in some ways.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I was just around here near Savin Hill, doing site visits for my work. You go to one corner of Dorchester and it's very different in terms of ethnicity, in terms of peace and rhythm. Then I just see all these cranes in this area, and yes there's a nice grocery store. Yes, there are these beautiful buildings. They look really out of place, which is I guess... I don't know. It's about they're not, but you just wonder, "Who are these being built for?" I mean, "Who's actually living in them?" Because I know a lot of people and one development in Brighton, not going to give the name. Because of COVID, there was a big discount on rent to them, students were able to like move in. This site was originally meant to provide affordable housing to the neighborhood and then it's like, if you're starting out a studio apartment at two or three grand, how affordable is that? Great you know?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: My question is, will the city of Boston continue to mistreat Black men and Black boys. I say that, from my personal experience growing up in Mission Hill, at the age of nine years old, coming home, going to Cub Scout, being spit on by white boys. Then going Cub Scout singing, My country tis of Thee, sweet land of liberty, but I didn't feel very free. I could still smell the spit. Liquor in spit does not have a good smell. From my experience as the Director of the Community Center, watching Black men being savagely violated, to civil rights doing the Steward case, I still see that. Every time there's a act of racism, I feel it. I feel it, I see it. During this pandemic, we've seen... I've personally known 20 Black men who died during the pandemic. It seems as if Boston does not care. That's my question. Will the city of Boston continue to mistreat, ignore and disrespect Black men and Black boys?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Well, I think what I want to say about the question for the future of Boston is, what are the electeds going to do to try and make our neighborhoods safe and have young people grow in a healthy way? Just their whole physical, emotional, intellectual and spiritual beings. I think that what I see is not right, and I think that a lot of what's happening around them is why it's like that. I say that out of experience I had growing up in the same area. I own the house that I grew up in, and so I've been here for... I'm 60 years old, so I've been here for a very long time. I remember sitting on the steps of the house, it'd be 20 of us, all young people. We would walk from where I live, to Grove Hall, to [inaudible] ice cream place that you see ice cream place over here-

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: We would walk in a bunch, but we would laugh and we'd have so much fun. Then there were the older teens, would teach us about things. In fact, we were able to have a basketball court in our neighborhood, because we complained about not being able to have something like that in our neighborhood. Because of some guy who came and took one of the brownfield's empty lot because there was a big disinvestment in the area and he used it to make money for himself. He used to chip bricks and pack them and sell them. We played basketball on a telephone pole with a cut out milk crate and what have you. These older teens, probably I was young but the older teens 15, 16 talked about creating this petition. They taught us what that meant, because like petition, that's a big word. What does that mean?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: They taught us about what that meant, so it was a wonderful thing to walk through the neighborhood not fearing anything, but just knocking on doors and telling the people about us having to use these milk crates to play basketball and the number of these cars coming up the street while we're trying to play. I almost got a three pointer, but this car came and stopped me. I had to stop and get on side. They signed off for us, and we must have collected 200 signatures. Then we went down to City Hall on the train. I'd never been on the train, that was my first experience with the older kids. We went to City Hall and the mayor at that time was Mayor Kevin White. We went to talk to him about what was going on, and he told us... He laughed. First, they were like, "Why are all these little Black kids in City Hall demanding to see the mayor."

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: But I think they found some humor in it as well. He came out, he talked to us and told us that he was going to come to our neighborhood. Three weeks later, he did and he listened to story. Again, he saw exactly what we were talking about and then probably three weeks after that, there was a big sign that went up and said that... It said, "The future site of the [inaudible] Street Basketball Court." The basketball court is still there to this day. However, I feel like the kids nowadays are being robbed of this childhood that I can reflect back on and remember it like verbatim, everything that happened. They don't have that. They have nothing to compare it to, so for them, the violence and everything is normal to them. They hear gunshots, "Oh, somebody just got shot." Like, "What?" But it's normal. My question is, how are we going to change this mindset?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: How are we going to get kids to live like these lives that are fulfilling and healthy, they're developing these relationships, and they're learning, and they're growing and they're giving back to the community. I think that's why I am today, and why I give back, because of what happened in my life. But I don't see it for them, so I'm concerned about the future of our young people. I think that a lot of them just don't have a spiritual grounding, but emotionally, it's like they're dead. They don't have feelings for people, and so I worry about that. I wonder who and where? How do we get back to a place of what I call normal?

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: My question for Boston is... It's interesting, because it kind of ties into some of what has been shared. For me as someone who grew up in Boston, I went to Boston public schools, elementary, middle and high school. I left to go to law school in New York and enjoyed New York, because as a Latino man, I got to see a lot of similar situated Latinos like myself, who are professionals. I was inspired by their stories of how they became lawyers and judges, professionals. I felt comfortable in that environment. My question to Boston is, how do you make a city that I grew up in? A hospitable place for a Latino man? Who are now as two daughters, an 18 and 14 year old, who would love to have them stay and say Boston is my home. Beyond affordable for me, but beyond the issue of affordability, we need affordable health.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: Beyond careers and jobs which has always been a challenge here for me and not so much in New York, I felt more accepting in New York in terms of who I was as a Latino with a law degree. But also, most so is the afterlife, the home. We work and live here, but I'm interested. Boston, how do you make this a place that I can enjoy playing, meaning going out, enjoying the place to go and have fun with families and others and friends? That's what I enjoyed in New York and sometimes I'm torn about moving back or moving elsewhere from a city that I grew up in. That to me is home, parents still live here. They're aging and I think I'm here because they're still here. But I'd swiped their parts, they'd miss New York City. For me, don't call me here in Boston very similarly. I'm looking for a place in Boston that's going to be something that I can enjoy, and I had the opportunity... Not until I think it was interesting and I'll share it.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: But it felt like I have to walk in the shadows in the dead of night to go see where the activity is in the city of Boston. I was having breakfast at South Street Diner at 2:00 in the morning, on a Friday night with some individual... It was probably now, but I'd go with a group of folks. We were there, and it was lively. I saw a lot of young people, professional Black, Brown at the South Street Diner. Nice music, and it was just a group of us men, women and friends. We were hanging out, having breakfast and at that moment I felt, "Wow, this reminds me of New York city." I shouldn't have to say that, I should say this just great, I'm in Boston. But it was at 2:00 in the morning at a diner, on a Friday night in the city of Boston that I had felt some kind of interesting connections, so that's been in my mind. Again Boston, how can you make this city a very hospitable place that I can enjoy to live?

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: My question about Boston is, is there a place for immigrants whose native language is not English to professionally advance and have access to the same economic opportunities that other people have? I ask that question, because it seems to me like for people with accents, it's hard to get off, let alone succeed no matter how educated you are, or if you have a lot of experience. Sometimes I feel there is some bias against people who don't speak English fluently, or made some grammatical errors and people might think that they are less intelligent. Yeah, my experience is that for a long time, I was interested in doing broadcast journalism. I know that was a big challenge for me, because I learned English here eight years ago, when I moved from Venezuela. I consider myself an educated person, and I worked hard to learn the language and really advanced on it.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: I knew it was going to be hard, but I thought it was possible and I was able to confirm that for a person like me, it's just impossible to write the news in an English media, because I tried hard several times. I wonder, why? Because if I see someone like me doing that job, I feel inspired. I feel like, "Okay, I can do. Because someone else is there, so I can do it too." But I haven't found that here in this city, and I wonder if we can... Maybe the City Hall... I know there is an office for immigrant advancement, and I know they do a great job supporting community organizations and distributing food, especially during the pandemic. But I think we also need a serious plan for workforce development for English that goes beyond just learning basic English, so I would like to see that. That's my question, I would say. Oh, sorry.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Oh, I was just taking in what she was saying, that's a long talk for another time. My question is, will Boston ever read really welcome civic engagement from all residents all the time? That comes from my experience of working 365 days of the year to get people civically engaged. What does that mean? It's not just about voting. It's about knowing how you go downtown and fight for a basketball court. It's about knowing that we have public community cable access stations where you can have your own damn TV show, and attract your own audience. It's about knowing that you can start a Black men and boys commission that can be heard, because you put the grassroots efforts into it such that it got traction from elected officials.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: It's about knowing that we have to fight our own elected and appointed officials on the Boston Planning and Development Agency which many of us call the Black People's displacement agency. We have to fight them to be heard at public meetings on development in our community. I belong to the Roxbury Neighborhood Council, we put on our own damn hearings and don't invite them, but we make the developers come.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Yeah, every day there's civic engagement work to do. This new mayor has the opportunity to fill something like 400 seats on various commissions and boards. How many of us are ready with names and resumes to say, Mayor Wu, this person would be great for the Election Commission Board. This one would be good for the Boston Employment Commission. That's my lived experience with that, and with that, I pass.

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: It felt to me like there was a lot of energy this summer with the election coming up, and I guess my question maybe related to Zakiya's here. Is how do we translate energy into voting, while recognizing that voting isn't all of what civic engagement is? When I moved to the city a couple of years ago, I had a voting location right down the street from where I live and so I signed up to work as an election official and I have every election since I moved and I love it. It's a long day, but I love it. I just remember, the hardest election that I worked at was the presidential election. So many people which was fantastic, but a lot of people who don't vote regularly. I just remember coming out of the presidential election, in my neighborhood, leaving the polling location and thinking to myself, "Wow, the next election is a municipal election and I just want to feel this energy at the municipal election."

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: I got there and I was like, I wanted lines and I wanted lunch rushes and I wanted dinner rushes. No, I have worked at municipal elections before, but I felt like this was a change election. All I wanted, and it was really disappointing. There were a lot of familiar faces, which I loved seeing, but I wanted to see a lot of new faces at the polls as well. I feel the energy in my neighborhood and in Boston and this feels like a moment of change and I wonder how we actually translate that into casting votes. And I think... One more thing. I know, this is not all sort of city controlled. But the amount of frustration I feel projected at me when somebody comes in and can't vote or there's a registration issue, or can't drop off their mail in ballot at the location, have to go to City Hall, it just... I feel the frustration and I feel like I'm on the receiving end of the frustration and I totally understand it. But I think we also need to push our elected officials to make it easier for people to engage in that way.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: (silence) I'm having a really hard time articulating this question, so I'm going to... I've been scratching and trying to write it. In the 20th century, I was schooled by a lot of Black activist about the Vault. What I understood was, that was the white power structure that went behind some curtain like the Wizard of Oz and made everything happen bad for working class people, especially Black, Latino, immigrants, women, people who live in public housing and depend on the safety network from a federal government that has shrunk considerably in the 21st century. I guess my question for Boston is, what will it take to love Black people, the way rich White people love themselves? My experience as somebody that's been racialized White in this city, is that 450 years of White supremacy, bullshit lies, and the academy, and the fact that Judge Garrity in 1973, ordered 408 remedies for the school district to fix stuff for Black and Latino kids.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: I came through the school district when Judge Garrity was around, and I had friends that looked like people around this room and we all were excited about what we could get. because we knew that except for that tracking system of the advanced work and exam schools, working class White people weren't getting should either, the few that were left that didn't abandon the district. Because their children weren't better than Black children, and so until we face that reality I think, and I have not seen anything really since Malkin, Chapter and [inaudible] 20th century electeds, who had the analysis and operated from a place of love. They had a shared agenda of empowering all of us, so that we could all live in a beautiful city. So that our kids... You look at Boston Latin, and you see what Boston Latin has produced, and then you go to Boston Latin, and all those White frigging men upon the thing, and the Black kids that are just as brilliant as those White men, have systematically been denied opportunity.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: So my question is, what is it going to take for the electeds and each one of us to destroy White supremacy, so that we can have honest dialogue with resolutions about 450 years of exploitation and White supremacist lies. I have a Black child and she doesn't want to stay here. A lot of young Black people that I know, it reminds me.... They flee to places where they can be Black and Latino and have a social life and they serve Hennessy, and they can wear hoodies and no one's going to think they're a thug. So anyway, those are my experiences as a White woman who's racialized White, in a city who has totally bought into White supremacy. When in fact, race is a social construct.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: This is some powerful stories we've heard from each other, I want to thank all you for really just opening up and sharing. I think we should look at these, these are gifts that each of you have offered to each other. What I'm going to ask you to do now, and I'm not going to call on anyone in any particular order. My only rule is if you speak once, wait till everyone else speaks before you speak again, that's my only rule. What I'd like you to do is just, remember all that, what you've just heard from everyone. If there's someone whose question or experience really connected with you, for you, I want you to just turn to that person, talk to them and say, "Hey X your question is really, right. Let me tell you experience in my life that resonate for me." Or, "Your experience, this is what you said your experience was, so I have something similar. Let me tell you what it was, and how it worked for me." This is the time for you just to cross pollinate, connect with each other and who ever feels like starting can start.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I'll start. Actually, a lot of folks, what folks said resonated with me. But I'm going to pick on you Sarah, 365 days a year to engage people. This has been an emotional rollercoaster as relates to civic engagement. When the pandemic started, you had the Black Lives Movement, or moment, Black Lives Matter moment and I just knew this year was going to be... everyone was going to go to the polls. For the last 23 years, we Dunked the Vote. We've been registering people, getting people out to vote.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: This year especially, we had an opportunity to have a Black mayor, and for someone who's been here, pounding the pavement, organizing and mobilizing, it was such a disappointment not to have one which was an alum of Boston with me. For me, it was just like suck the energy out of me. But I still had hope, because of the Black Lives Matter Movement, where all these false protested and I kept saying to myself, I hope that this protests will be done to the polls, but it did not happen. I share that same disappointment as far as turnout, but I am optimistic when I see faces like this.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: These he Black, and Brown, and Latino faces and Asian faces. It's inspiring to me, because when we started, I worked with Dunk the Vote. Not many Black people were running, not many Latinos were running, so there is some improvement, and we need to keep pushing.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Yes, we know. I didn't absolutely vote for you, I don't know who should I trust, can I just [inaudible] one person at a time, or how does this all work?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: At a personal level, Zakiya I really resonate with you. Because I think outside of my work, I'm really deeply involved with what's going in the local community, both have been on some writing, but also with the city and its itself and different organizations. Like unique capital to Boston, or a gym out of people's public government network things with the city. All that is really just to get a pulse to see what does it look like to look through the lens of these neighbors, their ethnicity? What do they celebrate? What are their needs? What are their strategies? What are the underlying factors under the hood that make them tick? I think taking a step back, everybody wants the same things. Everybody wants safety, they want a home that they can call their own, neighbors. They want a home, but different people have different strategies and use it like what that would look like, or how that should be carried out.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: The way things been carried out has not been done in a way that is effective. Like he said, you don't see kids going to City Hall protesting or basketball court and it's not... I mean, you might look at it... It might look silly, but it's just kind of a note in the series that people can do. It's like, how do we... I think my question is, how do we get the voices of those who are not only crying out, or not being heard. But even those that just gave up, because those are the fighters that are still here. There's some people that just say, "I don't have a place here." Unlike their [inaudible], I'm not going to do these things, I'll try to cultivate this myself. Kind of, you're on or shouldn't we?

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: Yes. I had a great conversation with a good friend of mine and he's in Boston. He told me that what is so important is seeing spaces not just where the immigrant community can be served in different ways and be given resources, but to be able to integrate. Well, he comes from a long heritage dating back in Spain. He's Colombian, so he has a background in aristocracy and all of that. At the same time, he also lives in a community where it's very mixed in terms of income, in terms of exposure to different things. He's been exposed to one world, and he's been exposed to the other world and he sees that many people, especially in the immigrant community are not taught about all the power that they have, for living in a democracy.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: That being able to not just learn basic English, but Business English, invited to the spaces that would allow them to grow and thrive. Even just being told the value of their home, like no. The developer comes to you and says, "Your home is worth $500... I mean 500 grand." And it's dilapidated. Actually, to look back and have resources be offered to them, for them to get to know and be like, "No." Is actually worth $5 million, it just needs to be fixed up. If people knew that, and what is the push of the city to have people be access, to be integrated, to be able to thrive here? Anyway, thanks.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: I'll go next. Yeah, I really connected with many people here. But I want to pick you because you were talking about housing and I think that's a major issue in this city. Probably the number one issue, and I'm sure many of us have experienced some housing insecurity at some points.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Oh, yeah. Yeah, I think there has to be a plan to address that issue. We need a solution now. We can't wait, because we're losing population. If you look at the data from the census, for example the Black population has decreased and it's because of that problem. We can't allow that to continue to happen in the city. In the past four years, I've moved four times because of the same problem. They raise the rent, and then you have to move somewhere else and now I'm living in East Boston, I love East Boston. But I don't know if I'm going to be able to stay in East Boston beyond next year, in two years. I don't know what's going to happen. Yeah, I think I connected what you said about gentrification [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: I see a lot of... I mean, obviously we've got intersections here in the topics and it brings me back to this city of Boston in its entirety and how it's a home to especially Black and Brown residents as a Latino here who went to school in the 1970 through, and I went through busing, and went through my share schools around here. Just from your foundation of what you started and halfway of what is coming from. One of the things that I had two experience as my entrance into the school system here, was that everyone always questioned my abilities. Up to a point, I can give one example. When I was a senior in high school, I went to Copley Square high School, so shouting it out now. It's now Snowden, but I had some good teachers. I enjoyed actually theater there of all subjects, but I had my English thesis.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: I did a thesis on John Steinbeck and had so many hours in that Boston Public Library, which is the main one right across from [inaudible] South street, because our school is on Newbury Street, so I'm writing this and I remember the hours that I have all the writing memory in all hand of my notes. I went there, I submitted it and the teacher brought me into the principal's office and said, "We don't accept plagiarism or anything. [crosstalk] accept everything." My father, who I guess they didn't know. He was a professor of theology, Dr. B.U. He had to come over there and was very offended, and then they went just say, "Well, did you write it for him?" I had to produce all my notes and they realized that they were wrong. It kind of gave me a lot of example there. That was an illustration of how Boston itself, and it starts with a young man. I can only... That's one of my stories.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: I can only imagine how many other stories by fellow students that grew up in the '70s and '80s. Went to school, had to feel and if it starts in school, that's something that has carried on to me. For me anywhere going outside was going to be exciting. I wanted to be out and it was not just about race, for me it was also about... I was taking this about class. Although we were considered middle class, I just saw the difference. The class and I read about the bolt and the common ground, then I knew people and I'd bump into folks that come and visit your school and talk to you about working in the bank or working here, but God forbid you ever get a chance to work in the bank yourself. For me going back to this issue about how the city has been hospitable to certain residents, and for me has a lot during growing up, it was something that... For me, I knew New York City wasn't perfect.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: I mean there's obviously racism strikes and there. There's always racial tensions in a lot of these cities, but it just felt like at least I can go to a city where I can see a fellow professional, Latino lawyer, judge, or doctor or something and it was just common to walk around and not have to defend yourself that you are actually as intelligent as you thought you'd be. You could feel you can get that reception, so Boston was to me that parochial. Every time I walked around, I mentioned a share to my fellow professionals or whoever I'm working with in New York.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: They would say, "Oh, you live in that racist town?" I had to listen and to hear this. I wanted to shed that kind of... That reputation of Boston so, I wanted to come back eventually and said, I'm going to come back and I want to be at least a part of the problem, so a way to be a solution. Every day, I try to think about how I can, but your sharing that friend kind of brought me from that upbringing in the city of Boston. My experience started with the Boston Public Schools.

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: Marilyn you've painted this beautiful picture of kids organizing and going and getting a basketball hoop. I didn't live in Boston growing up, but I had a very similar experience where we raised some money and then petitioned to the local sporting goods store to the donate the rest, and we worked so hard and it was so fun. Yeah, I sort of wonder too about what it's like for kids growing up, and I love living in Boston. I don't know if I can afford having kids in Boston, I would love to, and it's something that keeps me up at night. To both Becky and Tibi's points as well, that just the affordability is really hard and the experience with kids and growing up in Boston right now. Your experience brought me back to that magical place of waking up every morning thinking about how we get that basketball move and just hoping that there is a place for young families in Boston and a place for kids to grow and have fun and play, get basketball hoops.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: So much has changed, but I can definitely resonate with so many voices around the table. I grew up in an immigrant household. My parents are from the Caribbean island of Monterrey. My mother is... Her father was White, and her mother was Black, and so growing up she was in the islands, especially it was tough because her dad was White. Coming here to America was different. She didn't go to... She didn't further her education, but she was white. But the only job that she could get was domestic work, so she worked in Christian Science reading room, and she cleaned the toilets and all of that. But she worked hard, do the hard work and so she was able to buy her first home. My dad was a cop and he was a tradesman. I was born in England, they moved to England, he worked there. It was good until coming here and trying to have kids and everyone thinking that because they were from the islands, the American... This is Black and White, that it was just difficult.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: They really had to fight... My oldest brother in the late '60s, '70s, he went to Boston Technical High School and that was one of the exam schools Boston Public School. I think he with Charles [inaudible] as a matter of fact. After graduating, it was tough for him. I think one of the saving graces for him was that he played football. He was a foot... The athlete. I think there's something about being... Well no, because Jackie Robinson had trouble too. But he... You're laughing and you're athlete. You get a little bit, they treat you a little bit better.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: He went away to college. When he went away to college, he did really good. He had a really good friend, this White Jewish guy and my brother fought really hard for racial equality and his friends saw it and he saw the injustice against my brother. He saw because they used to say all kinds of things, go back to the banana boat. They say all kinds of things. But he didn't give up, he was still empowered, he never gave up. So much so that even after graduating, he went back to Union College in Schenectady, New York and served on the Board of Trustees for a number of years. Had Charlie Baker son, but now they just build this building and named after my brother at the college. But it was because he did not give up. He was an immigrant and they made they wanted him to believe that he couldn't succeed and he couldn't get, but he kept going and going.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: When I hear you talk about your aspirations and your dreams, I'm like, "Don't give up and don't settle for what they think you can have." You can have whatever you want in this big wide world, you can. We did it as kids, we got a basketball court so don't give up and the power is yours. I think that build in power is amazing, and it doesn't take a whole army, just a few good people and that's it, right on your side. Then build your power going out like that, it does start small, so never give up and be proud of your heritage, in who you are and bring that to the table. That's what accentuates this whole thing. And the whole housing piece, I'm so happy that my mother with her toilet cleaning self and my dad, he was a carpenter, so he did pretty good. But, she bought a house. He bought the triple decker... Well they bought the triple decker, but we own it now. When they bought the triple decker, they bought it for $9,000.

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: I bought it for $500,000. But now my house is worth a million dollars. I understand, I see what's happening in the city of Boston. When we had our house appraised a couple of maybe about... I don't know. A few months ago back in February, and I found out what it was worth, the appraiser when they asked how much rents were and I told them, he just looked at me and he says, "Why are you giving your apartments away?" Because he knows. It was important to me to feel like I had a good tenant. It was a single mom, with two boys and she was just a good tenant and I'm not trying to be greedy. I just want to live and I want to see everybody else live, and so she's like family. Again like I said, we just let my granddaughter. She's 22, she's in her senior year at La Salle University, but we let her move in. She's paying $1,000, who does that?

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: But I understand, and so all we need to do is find a few good people and it can't be about greed. It has to be... I want people to live, I want to live and I know how I want to live, so it's the golden rule. You do unto others as you would have them do unto you, so I feel for... I'm happy for your situation though, that you all have.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: My situation is your situation because my landlord is like, "I don't care. I know, I can make much more money, but it's like, I just wanted people."

nodes.speaker: Marilyn
nodes.words: Yeah, like just spreading... Like having these small conversations, and seeing and hearing where people are at and figuring out a way to build power together is I think the key. We see the wrongs, how do we make them right? We don't need a whole lot of folks to do it, to start anyway, but it has to start somewhere. I think little forums like this is the right place and the right way to go, so thank you Ceasar for it, and Ron for pulling us together and having the conversation so that we can continue to inspire other people to have conversations. Then let's Co-Op some stuff so that we can own it.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: When Becky talked about seeing all the different developments in different neighborhoods, one that she lives in Boston, Brighton and others that she works in, I know and some of the people around this table know that a lot of those parcels are public land. You have people like me that are saying, "Well wait a minute." The city is holding on to this land and are supposed to be in our best interest, and when we look around and look at the census tracts, we're sitting in a census track right now with a median income... I haven't looked in the last two years, but I bet it's no more than 38,000.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Now what you do on private land, no. But public land, that big empty lot over there, that's public land. I want that housing, if there's going to be housing there to benefit the people who need it the most. The most vulnerable in the neighborhood, and that's when we go to those those public meetings of our city government and have to fight to get that set. That's a big problem, and being able to convince people from every neighborhood, you have got to pay attention and come to these community meetings. Before you do that, we've got to educate you on what the zoning rules say, and what the Boston Public Development and... What is it? BPDA, Boston Planning and Development Agency is supposed to be doing, and what the Department Neighborhood Development is supposed to be doing. It's challenging because, it's so much to learn. It's not just about 32nd sound bites of defund the police and [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Not that that's a bad thing, but you can't... What's bad is that you can't say everything you're trying to say in a 32nd sound bite, so it's a lot for people to grasp, come to a meeting and have to... My father used to say, it was like playing whist against three people. In other words, you don't have a partner. The city of Boston is supposed to be your partner, but instead, we have to go to these community meetings ready to do battle with our own bureaucrats that are getting paid by us. Then I look at a brother all the way across the table talking about, "I want to be somewhere... " We used to say this in meetings all the time. We want legal, affordable, adult nightlife. We want family life, that's what we want in our neighborhoods.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: But yeah, I want that in the neighborhood. I mean, I forget where I was. Oh, I was in Boston, Brighton two Saturdays ago. I took a Lyft from Uphams Corner area where I live over to there, and I was getting so angry as the Lyft ride went through the different neighborhoods. Because I have to walk 20 minutes or so to get to anything that I really want or if I just want some non-dairy creamer for my coffee, I can't count on it being in the CVS at Uphams Corner, I got to go to the Stop & Shop in South Bay, or over here.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: But if I were living in Austin Brighton area, is just place after place after place that I can go to, where I can get all these different things that I want. I was becoming so frustrated and then I had to change my mindset, because that's not going to help me get those things in my neighborhood. How do we get gentrification without displacement? Gentrification, if you look the word of it, just means to improve something. It doesn't mean, we're going to steal your land from you. But anyway, gentrification without displacement-

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: I just wanted to say, it resonate a lot what a friend had mentioned, and it brought back a lot of memories. As I mentioned, we had an event from Mel King celebrated it on Saturday. But yet I also celebrate this place, 1949, 70 years civic organization, Black community. 2000, Dunk the Vote moved in here. I probably resonate with you, so we could re-work together for the last 30 years, so lot of stuff that Fran was saying, a lot of things she was saying. It's so true, but I am optimistic. I am very optimistic, I'm really glad to be a part of this conversation. Be a part of real talk for change, because I believe we're making change right here in Freedom House. Everything happens for a reason I believe this time is has been ordained, so thank you all for being a part of this. This is really good. We have a lot of work to do. 22 neighborhoods in the city of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: As I like to say, when an old person dies, the village can lose a library. But with Real Talk for Change, we're creating libraries everyday.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Yeah, I just wanted to say that, what popped into my mind Marilyn, when you were talking about your story was, I've done organizing since I was a teenager to get the Boston Public Schools to do the right thing for our children. And I was working with the people, students and we went to visit Mel King. He was a state senator. I think it was more money for summer jobs, for youth jobs or whatever. We went up to the statehouse, and Mel listened to what we had to say and then he said, "Okay, give me a minute." Then he said, "Okay, come on let's go." He had called the... I get goosebumps just thinking about this, and I was young. I was a college intern working for the summer something, and he threw us all in the back of the truck and drove us over to The Herald to meet with the editorial staff and then there was... We co-created with the editor, a piece that ran in The Herald that day.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: For each of what people were saying resonated, I just want to say that. Then the immigration thing, just this morning I was reading in the Boston Globe that Roger hat... the multicultural education project that's been around since Judge Garrity's case, just cited the district. There's 6000 English language learners to speak to ratios that have not been even tested to find out where they place to get the right instruction. When you come as an immigrant, if you had any formal education, you can't even determine... The issue of accent goes straight to White supremacy in this notion, that perfect English and formal education... Yeah, it all resonated with me and I guess, education is probably one of the most disappointing. I don't have any hope like you all, about... I think of Sweet Honey in a Rock, and the song by Bernice, about the lives of Black... Ella's song. Until the lives of Black... We who believe in freedom cannot rest. Yeah, that's my song. Then until the life of Black boys matters much as White boys-

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I think that one of the biggest challenges in our city as I sit around the table, is that we do not have inter-generational spaces, the way we did when we were coming out.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Because I would be on the porch, or around the [inaudible], and Mr. Richardson would be there, or Miss King would be there and there would be like... Just like there was this plethora of folks that schooled us.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: That's just... and I feel like I see lots of different things happening in Black and Brown communities, but we're not speaking to each other and we're not building power and I think we have to learn how to check egos at the door.

nodes.speaker: Becky
nodes.words: [inaudible] I have to take a [inaudible] brake, I'm sorry. I needed to do this for a really long time, so-

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I wanted to, we're going have these conversations all over the city and the way we put these conversations together, it's usually a set of people who have some relationship to each other and know each other how it's happened. I want us to just take a minute to bring in the voice of someone who was in a different conversation, just so you can hear what somebody else who's been one of these Real Talk conversations actually had to say. I want to play their question and experience, just to understand here so we can understand another perspective of how someone sees this city. Give me a second, [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Speaker 10
nodes.words: I guess what is Boston going to do to address the health disparities amongst the Black and Brown people and most marginalized people in this community?

nodes.speaker: Speaker 10
nodes.words: Yes, absolutely. Yeah, so it's blatant. they treated my mom in particular, like she was somebody who wanted to get a fix from the street, because I guess the neighborhood or whatever. I'm like, this is my mom's hospital. She's been here, check our records, never had any drug issues. Treat my mom, her pain is real. It's like that and it's historical actually. I don't know how Boston would address that, but I've been championing, been working behind the scenes. Encourage people, speak up, I'm going to say that Black personally, my mom and myself. A lot of Black folks we're strong and we have a high pain tolerance too, and don't often report it. But if you're in pain, don't not share it. Share it, you know what I mean? Because it's bad enough that healthcare professionals don't think that you experienced that pain, but it's real and that's what I'm championing on, addressing those healthcare disparities.

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: Sounds too familiar. What immediately came to my mind when I... I had a heart attack, and when I was in the hospital, I see the way Black people were being treated. It was so bad and the reason why I got special treatment, not because I'm Black, I got treated because I worked in the governor's office. And the organizer that I am, I was in the hospital fighting for folks. But Black people do get treated as if we're drug addicts, criminals when you go into the hospital, and then you wonder why Black men don't go to the hospital. They go to the hospital, they get mistreated. They think that, yeah they had to get a fix, get some drugs, so the story is true for me.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: If it can happen to Serena and Venus Williams, it can happen to any of us. I forget which one of them was mistreated during her prenatal care and put to die. But Boston is funny. Here we are the medical Mecca and the disparities in health care, treatment or health outcomes for Black, Brown and low income Whites is... We're the laughingstock of the developed world, really. White women have the worst outcome from maternal health in this country than any of the developed nations and we of course, that's even worse. Yet, we have the Boston Public Health Commission, which a lot of people have the opportunity in Marilyn knows, to take part in neighborhood meetings where you can go over the data and give your lived experience and learn about things you can do to increase the good outcomes for child and maternal health for example. Again, getting people to come to the table and stay at the table.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I know we're close to time. I don't want to keep people over. The what I'd like to do is actually give you each just a moment, a minute to kind of lift up, now what's the takeaway for you, tonight. What are you walk away with that could be just your own reflection of something or something you want to lift up that someone else said. I'll give you a second just to... 30 seconds to sit with yourself, and then we'll go around. I call on someone in and then we'll go around.

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: (silence) I see a lot of revolutionaries, even just in this room, and just in this room is Boston, Dorchester [inaudible]. This is just a small group of people. Yes, we are very selected small group and we within one demographic, but just think how many people in this city? I don't know how many people are in this city. Multiplied, it's like everybody had their voice heard in some way and then compiled together, what a force that is. How do we leverage it and bring that? How do we activate that voice?

nodes.speaker: Ron
nodes.words: We have work to do. I am optimistic but I know that change can be painful. It can take time. But with this group as you mentioned, we can multiply. We can continue to uplift the voices of those that typically don't get hurt in our communities. This past election was very... It brought me back, because sometimes you can get far removed when you're not on the ground, when you're in the office spaces and so forth. But to see the level of lack of constituency services in the Black community, it is pathetic compared to White countries like West Roxbury, South Boston, Charlestown. My takeaway from this is that we have work to do, I want to see this work continue, Real Talk for Change. As you mentioned, how powerful that would be to have them fire all of these voices. This is my [inaudible].

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: Wow, it's all really deep. When I think of power, and where we're going with Real Talk for Change, change is good and conversation is good, but it can't just stay conversation. When I think metaphorically about the mustard seed, and thinking about what happens with that. Thinking about my fate, and thinking about all that I learned about having that faith, just that much and moving mountains, just imagine all of those conversations compounded on top of each other, that's a lot of power. We can crush racism. Sorry, I banged on it too hard.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: [inaudible]. But we get crushed racism, we can crush all of the disparities, I mean we have power to do it. So yeah, these collective voices, it's not just conversation. That's power in there, let's activate it. For real, let's make something happen. Real Talk for Change is about making it happen.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: Since I actually started involved involved in different ways, with Real Talk for Change, this exercise that reminds me of the exercise. [inaudible] when he was working with Reverend Michael Haynes, at Twelfth Baptist Church and working one of the few kind of Black and Brown, Black, Latino kind of efforts to help educate Black and Latino ministers who didn't have the education, but they had the church, but they needed the qualification and the funding from their national, district church affiliations. It helps you get educated, to have some of the degrees and so he'd work together to build that in the community of these storefront churches. A common thing to my father was, in his mind he said, you have to come from an organizing perspective and really be contextual, because where the voices are, he would say. I grew up with this drill in me, where the voices are on the streets.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: Voices are the people you're not hearing, they're not in the power structure. The real power is there, it's dormant. People don't know it, but it's there. When you hear the voices, and you hear the collective spirit of wanting to do something, but when you gather together... And so one of his push of course was that the church is one entity that does that. But there are many of other entities that do that, but the commonality of all this is that each one of us, we're a powerhouse and we can make these things happen, so the voice has to translate to action. In his case here, he'd always preached and wrote about the fact that the church has to go from preaching to acting, and the acting is an important part. The organizing and being political involved is very important. But my takeaway from all this experience, and I commend Ceasar's work and Ron's [inaudible] work.

nodes.speaker: Eldin
nodes.words: Is that, there is a real feeling and just from listening to the portal or getting on appointments or conversations, [inaudible] Talking about, there is a common thing about people wanting to stay in the city. They want the city of Boston to be better. They want this to be their home, as I have wanted this to be my home since I went through the school system, and I left and now I'm back. I think to me, that's the takeaway in all these conversations. Is that everybody wants the city of Boston to be their home and we'll do everything to try to survive and afford to live in here, to have a career life and to be able to play and enjoy life here in the city of Boston. I think there's a real need in this case now, just to get those voices elevated and to make some real change.

nodes.speaker: Tibi
nodes.words: Yeah, Elden I couldn't agree more with you, even though I grew up in another country, I feel Boston is home and I love Boston. When you talk to other people, and you have this conversation, some people express frustrations and concerns, and you feel connected because you feel I'm not the only one, and I'm free to speak about this, because you also find that both Boston is as you said. A place where we can all live and I have hope. And the fact that we are involved with this project exists, it's hopeful and my take away is that we've already started and we have to continue.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: My takeaway is that just like there were eight people around this table who are willing to pitch in and do the work, that's why I got to keep knocking on doors and talking to people because people really do want to invest in making Boston better.

nodes.speaker: Sarah
nodes.words: Marilyn said it earlier, that it just takes a few good people. Something I heard in almost everybody's experience here was evidence of a few good people in every single question and experience, and so I'm just reminded of a candle. That a candle can light up a room and what happens when you bring a bunch of candles together, there's a lot of light. It's such a good reminder that all you need is a few good people.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: I guess my takeaways from this conversation is that there is intersectionality and that there is a lot of helpfulness and a lot of questions about how do we... I'm leaving with questions about the action piece and how do we turn... Well, let me just say one thing. What was beautiful about the conversation and my take away was how we were authentic and speaking from our lived experiences and you could feel it. I think that the power of this project is in building community across difference, and the power of the portal will be for folks who get access to it will be hearing their story someplace else and not feeling alone.

nodes.speaker: Francesca
nodes.words: In the real world, we've done these conversations and some of us have been in lots of them. I think that has been... That wasn't something that I thought would be an outcome, but that people feel really heard and listened to there's power in that and there's power in having that conversation with random strangers, and finding resonance. I guess I have to end on a hopeful note because, if building community focused on hearing voices and from a place of love, there is no stopping us.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you all so much. I know we're a little bit over, but this has been wonderful and I'm going to stop the recording now, and-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay, well start. It's 6:22. Well, welcome. I'm glad you could come. This conversation is called Real Talk for Change. We invited you to think about the pressing questions that you face, and we all face, but really you face here in Boston. Our goal today is to look at those questions and add your experience to, probably now, 300 other people who've had little conversations like this. We actually had two of these at Dorchester Bay. Elias was one of them. I'm going to begin recording, and I want to share a little information about why we're doing this. We're trying to create a new dialogue across the whole city of Boston, so people can really listen to each other. A lot of times people don't listen as well as they talk. We're going to mostly listen, and also we want to have a different type of conversation.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We're not going to ask you to make a speech or just tell us all the things that are wrong, but ask a question and tell us your personal lived experience, your experience, not someone else or not we all or not what everybody thinks, but your personal experience. Not what's your position on housing or this issue, but your experience. And with doing this, because I think when we talk about our personal experience, it builds more of a connection, and also, when people in authority, whether it's the mayor or the governor or the head of a hospital, I think they're more likely to listen if they actually hear your voice, as opposed to-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah, as opposed to reading something. They actually hear your voice, because there's more emotion in our voice, in my voice and your voice, than there is just when you read something. We're going to record this conversation and I just want to let you know what's going to happen. It's just an audio recording, no video, obviously, and it's going to be part of this Real Talk for Change conversation. I don't know if you've seen the website. We have a website called Real Talk for Change.org. Have you seen a it, Kay?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: You have? Okay, cool. It's hosted on this thing called LVN, which stands for Local Voices Network, and that's a web-based tool that's used all over the country, and they have a nonprofit that's called Cortico. I don't know what the name means, and there's a way in which, after it's recorded, the system uploads certain key phrases, things you say, and you can hear on the website what people are actually saying. This conversation, along with all the other conversations that have taken place and will take place, from East Boston to Dorchester, Roxbury, all over the place, Hyde Park, will be shared with others so you can hear what others are saying. Right now, you can go to Real Talk for Change.org and listen to different conversations and hear real people, including some people from Dorchester Bay. I've got to read the statement to ask you if you're willing to be recorded, okay?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a protected collection on Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. In addition, part of Real Talk's mission is to present voices from the people of Boston, therefore portions of your conversation can be made public. If you understand and agree to this, just go around and say your name. And you can use a pseudonym, a fake name if you want, and just say, "My name is Michelle and I agree."

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay, great, thanks. Well, one of the things I want you to is speak for yourself. Not what someone else says, speak from your own experience and allow other people to speak for them and share the time. Luckily, we don't have a huge group, so you'll have plenty of time. Stay curious, ask honest questions, take time for reflection. If somebody says something, listen generously, assume good intentions, even recognizing that the impact that someone says can be not what they intended. If you can, unless it's an emergency, close your phone and all that kind of stuff, so we don't have the phone ringing so we can pay attention. Is that okay?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Let's start. I know you know each other from the leadership, but just say your name and just say one quick word of how you're feeling either physically or intellectually or emotionally how you're feeling, or spiritually, just-

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: My name is Kay and I'm feeling a little stressfully, because my daughter, she had a baby and she doesn't have... I don't know if that's... Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: She had been... I don't know, some kind of just like, "I don't want to hold the baby. You take the baby." And I'm like, "I didn't have a baby."

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. And my name's Michael and I'm feeling feeling grateful just to be here and be with you and... Yeah, and grateful that I have friends like Elias and that you're willing to do this. Okay, let's think about... What I'd like you to think about as we're here today is what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? And you can just take a couple minutes to think about it. What's your question? A question starts with what, where, how, why, when, how, et cetera. Just take a couple of minutes, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that. And then just, we got time to think about this, and then reflect on what experience in your life, what story, personal experience led you to that question? Do you know what I mean?

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: But that's the only thing that's bugging me. That's the only question I would have, because that's the only thing that is different for me.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: The way the job market is right now, it's just so weird to even know where you fit anymore, basically. I'm trying to figure out where I fit.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I can do customer service. I don't want to do retail anymore. I really am sick of working with food, stuff like that, because people are just so rude right now. I don't know what it is, but it seems like this world is angry and people are just taking it out on everyone, especially when you work in that type of field and I just don't want to be in it. So many people are getting hurt, not just their feelings, but physically hurt, because of that.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I've had people... No, because I'm kind of outspoken, so when people step up to me, I know how to step back. I kind of get them away from me before they can get to that point, so I rarely have had that, but because I'm small, a lot of times they think they can, until I open my mouth. They expect me not to protect myself, but you have to. You have to. Some of the strongest women I know are smaller than I am, so yes, I have to.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: No, it's just that I'm 60 years old and I don't know where my next chapter is in the work field. To me, that's important, because that's what I'm going to be doing. I haven't figured it out.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: And for me it's housing. For the future, I'm hoping they make more one bedrooms for single people that would like to live alone, like myself, and make it affordable. That's my future and my thoughts right now are... I'm either always making too much money for the one bedroom, or to even enter the building and stuff like that. I'm looking for the future to change that, definitely for the future.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: To make more affordable housing, especially for single people, like one bedrooms. I never want to look at a two-bedroom, but they're like, "Oh, that's all we have. Plus you make too much money for a one bedroom." I'm not understanding why I make too much money for a one bedroom and I'm just one person. But he didn't... I don't know, but that's my story. And in the future, I hope they start to think about stuff like that. We have single people that works hard that like to just live alone in some kind of affordable housing. And we do need rent control. That's the future here. We really do need rent control. We need a lot of rent control for everyone, everywhere, to prevent homelessness.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Well, right now I have a personal experience where I want a one bedroom. I went to this office, talked with these people like, "I just want a one bedroom. I have a job. I don't see why I can't move into a one bedroom."

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: And they're like, "Oh, well it's levels." And it's income levels that they face. I can't just, at my income, go into a one bedroom. I will only be eligible or a two bedroom, but it's just me. What do I want a two bedroom for?

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: I don't know. I don't want a roommate. Right now I'm in a two bedroom, but I'd rather be in a a single one bedroom by myself. Once I turned 40, it was like I started getting into the alone zone and that's where I want to be. If I want to be bothered, I'll come outside. Otherwise, leave me alone. I'm just surprised everywhere I fill out application and it's like, "Oh, with your income, you have to get a two bedroom." I don't want no two bedroom. Why can't I just have a one bedroom? It's just me, but I don't know how that works out. I hope the future changes that. Single people should be able to have low income apartments or something like that.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: They were trying to raise the rent here, making me spend $1,300 a month, almost $1,300 a month from 850 to up there, and I had lost my job right around the same time. They stopped them, but yeah, I hear you. How many people you know can do a one bedroom for $1,300? For real.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: I can't even sleep, because I get up at 5:00 and then I can hear, "Boom, boom, boom." I'm like who's outside partying? It's okay, you can party, but why I got to be here for it? I can't even sleep. Who do you call? Nobody, because that security company never answers. And it takes about almost a whole year to get [Jamila] on the phone.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Well, last meeting we had, she said that they were trying to hire new security and they were going through three different companies that they were trying to decide from. We don't have no security over here right now, just so you know.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: And then they took that white picket fence and they took that down and put that wire fence up so they can't hide over there, because they were charging people money to go over there. Girls would be dressing up and acting like they were going to a party. My living room's right across from it, so I'm like, what in the world? Music was blasting.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: For me, I will say my question is when we will feel safe in Boston? And the reason that is my question is because as a mother of two daughters, and seeing all this guns violence and missing kids around Boston, it makes me concerned. And my experience, real experience, is being every day when my oldest daughter goes to school and the time that she returns, I feel like something's going to happen. I feel panic all the time. I have to be constant calling to see where she is at the moment, if she's on the bus, if she's walking, and now that it's kind of dark, it makes me feel much more concerned and worried. She's 16, I still being like sometimes in the morning I have to bring her to the bus stop, stay there, seeing that she's taking the public transportation. But on the time that she returns back, sometimes I'm at work, I do not have that access to be there. It makes me feel like we are not safety here.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: It's something that I question about it. When can we feel peaceful? They can walk in the street, nothing's going to happen. No one is going to just take your kid. No one is going to get hurt, because everywhere that you go around Boston, especially in Dorchester, you feel like it's not safe. And that's my question. When we will feel safe in Boston? I want to see myself in the future, because when I came here Boston was my first place, especially Dorchester, because [inaudible] community is in Dorchester, and seeing Dorchester as my home since I came, and I will like to see and feel safe here and keep my kids here around Boston.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Good example, because I feel your daughter has to go to the bus stop and you have to worry, she could be waiting for the bus and these fools start shooting and then something happens.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I was walking to work, because I wasn't comfortable on the buses. I understand what you're saying. Especially depending on what area you're in, when you go up by the Boston Medical Center, some of the people that get on up around there, they be very ew.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Just, men will either try to speak to you and if you say, "I'm not interested," they start disrespecting you and calling you all kinds of names and getting loud, and, "You biracial B." I don't even know you. I don't understand this.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: And I said, "Because it's easier to say, 'I got to go home to my man,' than, 'oh, I'm not interested.' They're not as rude." And I'm 60 years old. You would think I wouldn't have to deal with that anymore, but all women, we still dealing with it, no matter what age we are. It's funny and it's sad at the same time. It's a compliment, but then again, it's not. Because a lot of women don't get noticed, but I don't want to get noticed because you think I'm cute. What about this? Can you have a conversation?

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Well, my experience with that when my kids was... They was going to the Burke High School, but they would fight every day. Every day. And nobody... I'd go, break up the fight, "What are you fighting for?" Nobody knows why they're fighting, because this one, he say, she say, but now it's a little worse for her situation, because back then I was just driving them to school and picking them up, because I didn't want to deal with fighting in the middle of the streets and stuff like that. But now it's worser, because then when my kids were more respectful to the adults. I'd say, "Stop it! Break it up! Everybody go home!" That's fine. Now I can get shot.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: It's a big difference. My son is 33. He's 33 and yeah, they was respectful then, but as my daughter now, she's 20 and when she was going to school, I would be like, "Just get in a car, just get in the car." I never said nothing to nobody's kid, because I'm not good at being disrespected, so I'd be, "Just get in the car." But now, I hear the kids talk to the teachers, oh my goodness! I couldn't be a teacher. I understand what she's saying. We need a big jump in the future in the school system.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Yeah, a big jump. Because my granddaughter, she's only nine years old, she fights every day, because she doesn't have what other kids have. Now, some people raise their kids like, "You have to have jewelry on, you have to have brand name sneakers, this, That." My daughter's not doing all that, so they feels like she's a little bum, so they want to pick on her and then it's a fight.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: For me right now in the school, what I see the most is I don't know if it's the reason is all the kids were remotely, learning remotely at home with all this, the COVID pandemic, being at home, and they're going back to school with all this and getting violent. Because there's a lot of fights and probably there's a mental issue with the kids. They're being violent at school, even with the teachers. We had recently a school that a principal was beat up by a student. I think all this is something that they have to look at right now, because we have to see some improvement on these cases at school.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: Recently in our high school, I think one kid just bought a soft gun. I don't know what is that, because I don't know what is that? I never saw what is soft gun?

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: It's a gun that they can put together, it's apart, so it's under... They can't identify it, so if you use it, it's like a ghost gun. It's like a ghost gun.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Yeah, these kids are so smart today, they order stuff off the internet and they can do things that we couldn't even think about.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: ... I was worried about it and we had a meeting that they did explain it, the kid already being suspended, and also there is an investigation about it, but it's not just her school. It's being a lot of schools that is, if you look at the news, it's a lot of schools that are being with a lot of concerns and problem with students being fighting, bringing arms to the school.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: When my kids was growing up, it started out starting like, "I'm from Humboldt. I'm from Blue hill. I'm from Castlegate."

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: I tell my kids, "Mm-mm (negative), we're not from nowhere." But it started from there, so now it had built up to the point where we got the different gang of kids going to school, and through the courts, we lost respect from our kids, because if I go to the school and smack the heck out of my kid, the teachers are mad at me, but how am I supposed to get control of the kid? Because the kid is being disrespectful to you, me, himself. It's crazy. That's when I say we take a big jump, because when it was my kids, I can go into school and say, "What did you do?"

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: "No Mommy, Mommy, I'm sorry, I'm sorry. Ms. Brown, I'm sorry, I'm sorry." But now they cuss the parent out, the teacher out, the principal.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I think a lot of these kids that were stuck home were stuck home with abusive people in the house. And now, when they coming back to school-

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: That's why all the fighting is coming up, because they spent over a year locked in with abusive people. If you got a brother and sister that's beating your ass every day and you can't do nothing about it, because you live in that house, my relatives, oh my God, I don't speak to any of them for a good reason, but if I had to, I would understand how these kids feel. I'd be angry too. I'd be fighting. I'd be something, because it's not natural. But a lot of these kids are being abused terrible at home by their own siblings.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: But I don't care. I have four kids and my son is the oldest, but he just watched TV. But the girls, they will fight each other. I say, "Okay, that's what y'all want to do? Spank, spank, spank, spank." I make everybody feel, this is not what we're doing. But if you just whooping, spank, spank one, and let the other one get away, then yeah, you do have a house of drama. You do have a house-

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: My brother's [inaudible]. My mother had three kids in four years, so me and my sister and brother, we were like... I'm the middle child out of them, oldest daughter.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: That's another big change that should happen. They have Chinese New Year. We don't know nothing about that, but if I go in a restaurant and they say it's Chinese New Years, I just say, "Happy New Years!" But I can't celebrate Chinese New Years, because I have no idea where to begin. But maybe if my coworker could explain to me what's Chinese New Years, I might can join in. I don't know, but the job don't give you that opportunity.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Yes, not being safe, not being safe, because when I was 16, they were stabbing each other. That was a long time ago, because I'm 50, but they would stab each other in a fist fight. I witnessed people getting stabbed in the lungs and the heart.

nodes.speaker: Alda
nodes.words: From there until now, used to seeing that we are not done or we still have concern about safety. It's something that they really need to look into it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah. Is there anything else you want to share? We can wrap up now, unless there's other questions you have, or-

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Well, I do want to say this, because now, she make a good point about being safe, because these people will fight the police. We used to be scared of the police, but now these people will fight the police. Yeah, I don't know. That's a good example out here, because I don't feel safe with the police or anything. I'd be ready to protect myself.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Well, not only that, they know for killing people of color. Why would we call them? If somebody in my family got killed because I called the cops, I would have to deal with that for the rest of my life. No, thank you. I'd rather deal with my family.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: I had a experience with that, because my uncle worked for Boston Police. He still does, but now he just sit at the desk, but when he was out, I guess they call it out-

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: ... on the streets, the lady called and she said she's hiding in the bathroom. Her boyfriend is abusing her. He happened to be the first person on site and when he got there, she came out and she's like, "He's upstairs." Because he's talking to her, whispering, "Where is he? Where is he?" He goes up the stairs, he pulls out his gun and he's like, "Listen, I'm going to put you under arrest until I get to the story."

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: He's like, "I have to put you under arrest, sir, until I get the story. Right now you're being dangerous." He jumps on my uncle and they fall down the stairs and guess what she does? She started kicking and punching my uncle. That's [inaudible] call the police.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I was the victim of a violent crime and the police made me feel like I deserved it, like I was asking for it, so I wouldn't deal with them. It wasn't in Boston, but still-

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I was the victim of a violent crime. Some guy broke into my house and kicked me in my face and beat me up and raped me and stabbed me 10 times.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: No, no, this wasn't in New York. This was in Oklahoma. Nothing never happened to me in New York. I got too much relatives out there.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: No, I'm talking about out in the West, where they hate Black people, especially mixed Black people. They treat you really bad. I had a chest tube coming out of me and they cut me open without any pain medication, because I was mixed. My mother was so upset. I never seen her so freaked out in my life. For real, I don't trust doctors. I got to really have a good relationship with them, but I don't trust cops at all. And they tried to make it sound like someone else did it. They wouldn't take into consideration what actually happened. They tried to make me feel like I was lying about it. Yeah, no, when something like that happens to you and you're fighting for your life and people are trying to push you back, you know not to trust them. Yeah, I came back on the plane with a tube in my chest. I could have died coming home, but I was getting the hell out of there. I really was.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: And that's the first time I ever really dealt with racism too. I've dealt with it here, but not like there. And it's worse there now, because of all this Republican bullshit, and them doing these women like that with the abortions and everything else, so I wouldn't go out there if you paid me.
