My boyfriend's brother wants to move to Texas, because he's in love with some girl from there, some Mexican girl that just moved back there, and he's trying to tell him not to go, because he is afraid something could happen to him because he's Black.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: This happened because a young, white boy wanted to do something to me. I never saw this person, so I don't know why he did what he did. All I know, it was some young, white boy, but the cops refused to blame it on him and tried to put it on my boyfriend. The boyfriend was the one that found me, and I bled for almost seven hours before I was found. To put him through all that was wrong, because he saved my life, but they tried to put it on him. You laying in a hospital bed and they're trying to force religion on you and everything else, and trying to make you say that it was someone that it wasn't, it just doesn't make sense. It's hard to be honest when everybody's telling you not to be. And the funny thing is I don't lie about shit. I am so honest. Everybody's like, "Michelle, you should-" No, that's that's the way it is. But yeah, I've always been an honest person, but they made me question that.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I'm okay. I'm 60 years old. He didn't kill me. He tried. He just took away my ability to have kids, that's all.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Well, that's why I have a little dog, because if you come to my door, she going to let me know. If I'm going to live by myself, I got to have a little alarm, and that's my alarm.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: I lived at 225 Blue Hill Ave and I don't know how many people in that building, but it's at least 300. People would say, "You live here?"

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: [crosstalk], there's those millions apartments. So what? You got a million neighbors. You don't have to know them. They just live there.

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: "Yes. Right now I don't want to talk to y'all, I just want to be by..." I'm a self person. I just want to be by myself. You can make one little friend and that friend will give you so much trouble, I learned growing up, so I don't need friends.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: I don't think about it as being horrible. I just think of it as what makes you who you are. I wouldn't be who I am if I didn't go through what I went through. I'm not going to be mad about it.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay, well I just want to see if anybody has anything else they want to say; any other questions you have, or experiences?

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: Yeah, I never got help in Boston, so I never know. This is my first time dealing with this apartment type stuff and everything like that.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: When I moved here, I went to Cambridge and Everett and Malden. I didn't live in Boston. I didn't move over into Boston until I was almost 30, because my ex-boyfriend is 6'9", I had to get away from the North Shore, because I couldn't go anywhere. Everyone knew him. Everywhere I went, it was like, "Oh please, I need to get away from him." I moved to Boston, because I know he's scared of these people over here, and he left me alone. See?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Well I just want to thank you, and do you have any questions for us about anything? What's going to happen with this recording or-

nodes.speaker: Kay
nodes.words: Well, who will listen to it? Is it someone that can help us without... That will listen to it, that can go forward for our future, like my granddaughter growing up, to help her be safe, and her children?

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Yeah, that's part of what the leadership class, I think, will be dealing with. We're going to record it and then we're going to have... The current mayor, Michelle Wu, has already listened to this on Boston Neighborhood News, and we have to follow up. That's part of what the leadership class, and we're doing followup all across the city with Dunk the Vote and an organization that does leadership training for people everywhere, so we can make sure people-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: We're doing this all over the city. We have. We've already had over 50 conversations like this with over, I don't know, 350 people have... In small groups like this.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: In Boston. In Boston. We may be doing it in other cities. Some friends of mine in Everett that are interested, but right now this is just Boston. Although we're also listening to people who've grown up in Boston who had to move away, like Elias, who has lived in Dorchester, and a lot of people have moved to Brockton, Fall River, because they can't afford-

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Dorchester has become more expensive than Brockton, Fall River, so there's a lot of people who grew in Roxbury, Dorchester, Mattapan that can't afford to live there anymore. A lot of them have moved, so we're also want to find and listen to those people, because what's happened when things become so crazy expensive, like you were saying one bedroom, $1,300? We're trying to listen to, first, people in Boston, but if you know people who've had to move out, like Elias has had, not happy about it. He doesn't like commuting so far every day, so much traffic especially.

nodes.speaker: Michelle
nodes.words: And they'll be sending you a gift card. Actually, if one of you wants to, I have an extra one from our last thing, because one person wasn't there. If one of you would rather get it in person, rather than over email.

nodes.speaker: Michael
nodes.words: Okay. Then why don't you, Kay, why don't you write on the bottom of this, "Received gift card."? I'll just write it.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Great. Okay. It's recording. And this recording is just the only people who are going to be able to use this is this class because you're going to show you what's recorded. We're going to put it on the system and you'll be able to play with it and figure out things. And so you'll have your own access to this conversation, okay? So don't worry about it going anywhere 20 years from now.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So as I said, the purpose of this conversation is really to give you a brief experience of what it's like to be in one of the Real Talk conversations. Bourne, you've been in one before, so you have a sense of that. So a little bit about the recording. The recording will be kept and transcribed, and then it's going to be uploaded to our system, which is called the Listening System or the Local Voices Network.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: And there what we'll be able to do is allow you access to it, to highlight thing in the transcript, and we'll be able to teach you the process of sense linking and how that works. But you'll be working off your own data material, but then we will add other data for you to try. So in order to record, I have to read this and then I need your agreement to it. As a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent for the Real Talk for Change to use and retain the recording.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You also understand that Real Talk for Change conversations will be part of our collection of our Local Voices Network. The mission of Los Local Voices Network is to foster conversations in communities. And they will kind of collect, retain, and you'll be able to analyze these conversations. But they will be stored on that network. And that organization, local Voices Network is part of our center part of the work that we do. And so if you understand and agree with this, I just need each of you to say I agree.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Perfect. Okay, so we're going to do a quick check-in round the check-in identification. And I know we've done this earlier today, but we're going to do it so you just get a sense what the whole conversation piece is. So what I'd like you to do is each of you to check in as following, give us your name and then I want you to check-in in one of our [inaudible], how you are feeling physically, intellectually, emotionally or spiritually.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: However, the other thing I want to say as part of this conversation, if you would actually not like to use your real name and use a pseudonym, you could ask this group to call you by a different name. So if you saying like, "I don't want to be known as Bourne on this recording, I want to be known as Born-again." That's good. That wasn't good? And then our responsibility is to refer to them by that name going forward. Okay? So we're going to go around again, check in, your name and on one of the pies, how you're feeling physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually. Okay.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: Cool. I'm Allie and I think emotionally feeling a bit like if I were in a dryer or a washer tumbling around between good, the highs, and then circling to the lows. So it's been a lot of good emotions, but a lot of unpacking recently. So that's how I'm feeling.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Marietta and physically I am feeling tired, but also a bit energized. I went to my first spinning class yesterday and I felt it was a very utopian experience. I'm not going to go into details, but if you are interested I can tell you about my experience. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: I'm Diane. Emotionally, I think I can relate to you. I think was my birthday this week. So it's a good celebration. But also it brought some memories of the... It's been for my family, so it's brought that to the surface, so a little bit that way

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: I'm Daphne. And intellectually, I think I feel with a lot of things to do here, I'm also in my country. And emotionally, a bit nervous maybe because it's my first experience, something like that. But I am okay.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Okay, great. Thank you all for checking in like that. So the way we're going to do this, I'm going to give you a couple of prompts and then you have to kind of think about something. And this is the one place where if you feel like I want to write it first before I say anything about it, you can do that. Normally, when we do this, everyone's from exactly the same place, but we're not all exactly from the same place. So what we're going to, I'm change the question a little bit. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: So the form of the response is I'm going to ask you the following. What's your question about the future of the country you identify with and your place in that future? Okay? I'm going to say that again. What's your question about the future of the country you identify with and your place in that future? So I want you to think about it. I don't want you to share it, think about it, you want to write it down, you can do that. I'll give you a couple of minutes. And sometimes it's hard to generate a question, so it's going to be very hard to say, "Ugh, question." Okay. Anybody have a question again? Got a question? Don't share it. You got a question?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah. Okay. So as I said, the first thing I asked you to do was really come up with this question about the future of the country that you identify with and then your place in that future. But our questions don't just come out of nowhere. They actually are tied to lots of different things. And one thing they're tied to is an experience that you had, something you've experienced yourself. So what I want you to do is think about an experience in your life that you know has informed why you have that question. And then I want you to think about how you're going to tell us the story of that experience. Okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: You already got that? So you have a question? Something you experienced in your life has actually informed that question, and you're going to tell us the story of that experience. And here's a couple rules, it can't be someone else's experience. It can't be an opinion or a political rant about it. It has to be, I always like to say this way, "One day I was walking down the street and I came upon..." And so it has to be about something you actually experience. Okay? So I'll give you some time to think about what story that's going to be for you. Everybody have a story in mind?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Story? Okay. So here's how we're going to do it. We're going to go around and each questions are going to tell us their story. They're going to tell us first, "This is my question," and then you're going to say, "And here's the experience that I have that's connected to that question." Now, Daphne, you asked the question about language before, right? Because I think you are feeling like you'll be much more eloquent if you could just speak it in your own language, and that's fine. But can I ask you to give us your question, say it in your own language, and then just try to say it to us in English and then tell us your story in your own language and then give us the short version in English. Would that be okay?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Yeah. So first your question and how you see yourself in that? So it's just a question. You just want to give us a question and then you're going to tell us an experience. And if you start in your own language.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: Okay. My question is how we can make real change in the education in my country, in the public education in my country. And I see myself in my role as a educator to make some change. This is my hope. And then my story is about when I was a child, I realized at the early age in my life that I didn't like the place where I live. I didn't like the neighborhood, I didn't like almost anything about this place. What I did was my place.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: And after that, when I was in my maybe high school, also I realized that I have to do something to change this reality in this moment. And it's maybe depends only of myself, not the other people, not my family, not the other person. And then, I don't know, but in this moment I thought in the education, in my grades, in how I can have a position in some public university and all those things.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: For this reason, I really believe in the education, also in my country because we have really difference between the people who has some education and people who doesn't have. And the second there are the majority in my country because it's not a value to have an education maybe. Because maybe you have another funds to make money, not it's the education way. It's maybe the most difficult. In my language?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. I just appreciate the difference. Just means so much. So thank you for sharing. And we're just going to go in a circle process. So you'll be next and we'll just go around that way. So give a little breathing room in between each response, and then when you're ready, go.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: Okay. My question is how to think about and turn grief and frustration over the state of our country and just the vast inequality, and especially with impending climate change disasters and how that is going to disproportionately impact communities in this country. And for me personally, how to turn that grief into something actionable, and how to be part of making change. Yes. So my experience mostly thinking from a climate or climate justice environmental justice lens was a while ago when I was relatively newer to Boston.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: I had lived in Cambridge and Back Bay, which is very different Boston then other parts of the city. And I did this environmental justice tour of East Boston, and that was really a visual culmination of all of these compounding factors of redlining, segregation, inequality at large, just like putting an airport and the region's gas tanks and a new substation just over and over impacting this community with the things that the wealthy white communities don't want.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: So I think one of my earlier introductions into environmental justice and I found it so frustrating and often feeling powerless of how to do something about that, especially feeling from a privilege outsider background, and what is my place in that.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: My question is very similar to your question, just with a bit of change. So recently, I thought a lot about what is my role in the future of my country, and do I have a role in it? And the reason why I have this question, because my program is ending soon, so I have to think about what's going to happen when we are moving back to our countries. And the experience that informed this, which is... I don't know, I was probably very influenced by the video that you showed. So I couldn't think of any other experience.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: So my background, originally I wanted to be a journalist. And I worked on a lot of freedom of speech topics. When I was young I worked for a very big media news outlets. So it was traditional paper-based journalism. I was an intern there, and I don't remember if it was like 2006, 2008, something like that. My editor sent me to cover a meeting of people who are international people and who are bloggers.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: And then this whole network was founded by someone who worked here in the media lab. And when I went there, so I was thinking, "Oh, my thing is journalism and I'm interested in that." And then I met this community of people who were, basically, what they were doing is that they were reading the internet in their own language and writing kind of summaries of social media conversations.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: It's called Global Voices online. They are still existing, but I don't think they are as active anymore. Although to be fair, I'm not following what's going on there. So this was Hungary after the '90s has become like, "This very hopeful country where democracy and market-based..." All those things. It's going to be so nice. And I grew up with that hopefulness, and this was still the time when it was very hopeful.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: And I think thinking back just now, I also feel like even having that conference, there was a sign that this hopefulness is here, this country is stable, there is free speech, there is media diversity, there's something that's happening here just to mention some famous names. I know now it's not a good thing to talk about, but at the time you remember WikiLeaks was a big thing. And Julian Assange was there. So some of the most famous people who were internet freedom talkers.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: And I was there and I was listening to these talks, people from Madagascar sharing how bad it is for them to upload videos to the internet because it's so slow. But they do want to share. And I was so impressed that I can be a part of this. I later joined this community and I worked there, like volunteered there for nine years.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: And then a couple of years ago, there were a lot of political changes, a lot of closing, a lot of things that have gone bad with politics anywhere, it happened in Hungary just maybe 10 times worse. And they did close the news outlet that I used to intern for. So most of the things that I like have disappeared. That's the story.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: My question is how are the stories of people who have not been documented, people who have been part of the underclass of America, the BIPOC communities, how will their stories be told? Where will their stories live? And if those stories aren't told, how well we have a complete history of America without those stories being told?

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: My experience is I grew up in a time where I had a lot of people fighting for freedom, I had a lot of people fighting for democracy, a lot of people fighting for their children to have education and opportunity and access to opportunity. And in the work that I do now, one of the organizations I work for did a lot of work on stopping a highway from coming through the middle of a community.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: Another group did a lot of work on making sure that there would be space where we could have farmland and grow food, and use it as a way of commerce to change the economic reality we were living in. And those organizations both are suffering from organizational memory loss, their stories, the stories of the people who built those organizations and the work that they did is for the most part missing. And even though it's been donated to places for it to be archived, it's sitting in boxes.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: And so how do we make sure that those stories are told and that people understand that everyone's story is important, and that everyone needs to be able to tell their story? And how do those stories change? How will they change the reality of America moving towards 2043 in a time where we know that whites will no longer be the majority race? How do we get to a place where we can be at a table and listen to each other, and respect each other, and hear each other in totality of those stories being heard in every way?

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: So my question about my country is what will it be like? Will there be physical and economic security in the future? And will I be able to live well there? So I think the reason why those are my questions is because I'm being broke. So I think for the last few years I've been doing work that I find meaningful, but isn't necessarily profitable, you can't really live well with the kind of work, it's community-based. And it's not consistent and there's no... You know how you grow in a career, and at the end of the year you have a annual review, you get a better salary. So I haven't had that for a while.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: So I think also, politically in my country, we have a new government that's very corrupt, I guess, is the word. So there's a lot of stealing from government funds already. They haven't even been a year, but funds are already been misappropriated. And this is in the middle of the global economic conditions, and we've been declining economically for a while. We have a lot of debts with nothing being produced, new growth.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: So things are tense. At home, people don't have money. And when people don't have money, people are angry. And they can't take care of themselves, and they can't take care of their families. There's a lot of frustration, there's a lot of disappointment. Just wondering what kind of future we'll have even 10 years from now, even five years from now. And, of course, will I able to live there?

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Thank you. So just what I'd like you to do now, you've listened to each other. We'll tell some experience, the life that you're connected to, and some of these touched you in different ways. So we're going to create a space for each of you to turn to any one person here and say, "Hey, your story resonated with me for this reason. And I actually have a story that's connected to it that I want to share with you." And I'm not monitoring this, so when you feel free and ready to do it, you just turn to that person and say their name and go ahead.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: Daphne, your story is very beautiful, I'm very proud of you. You've come along, so I'm incredibly impressed by your story and the things you've been able to accomplish. It reminds me of a lot of people in my family and my parents, actually. And they had to do a lot of work to get to be able to allow me the life that I live and the comfort. So really, really, I see you and I appreciate you completely.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: I might as well just say everyone's name. I could just go around. First, your story touch me in a way that I would say that I always feel like technology is passing by the communities that I've grown up in. I always feel like it's introduced in Massachusetts, it's here in Boston, in the city, and then it's just gone, it passes by Roxbury, Dorchester, Mattapan, a lot of the urban areas.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: Your story touched me in the sense that I worry about relationships between people because people's stories aren't being shared. And when they are shared, I don't know if they're actually being they're being plumbed, like all the richest of the information is being shared and worked through and developed. Your story was amazing because I grew up in a place where... I remember even though I lived at the top of this hill in a really big house, which my parents bought, which sat dilapidated for a long time, that when I was a kid I would always smell the smoke from the buildings that were burning on Blue Hill Ave.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: And buildings that were being burned in devastation, and other buildings that were being set on fire by people who were leaving the neighborhood, and they needed the money from their house being burned so that they could take it and go and start a new life outside of the community. And your story because it seems like people of the community, BIPOC people are always continuing to move wherever they're being told that they need to move.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: And interestingly enough, that's how I first found out about World Talk for Change because I was asked a question about, "Do you see a place for you to be able to live in Boston with everything that's happening?" And so this idea of displacement of will be we be able to afford it. And so Roxbury, this place that I grew up in where no one wanted to stay and everyone wanted to leave, you couldn't leave Roxboro, you're told, "Stay. You can't move to Roslindale, you can't afford to live there." And now it's like, "You need to move out of Roxbury," but you can now move to Roslindale and these other suburbs that you could never move to. Very interesting. So thank you all for sharing.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: I was very moved by your story because recently I started my internship at the Summerville City Hall, and I discovered that everything that we do has to be translated into seven different languages, which was not a thing in the municipal government where I worked in Budapest, which is a 2 million people city with a lot of foreigners from everywhere. And immigration is becoming very important because in Europe, aging population, so no one really wants to work, all those things.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: So it's very shocking that a capital of a country would decide not to include people who don't speak Hungarian properly. Hungarian is not even related to any of the neighboring language, not even related to English. So it's not like it's an easy language to learn. And I find it very unfair. And I was so impressed. And I know with all the things, I know enough this is just a surface of something.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: In my city, we even started touching that surface of translating the most important messaging into the most spoken languages in the city because it's not being done. And because that way, no one can really connect and we are not going to hear those stories. If the city government doesn't hire someone full-time who speaks, I don't know, Chinese would do all the languages that are around there.

nodes.speaker: Marietta
nodes.words: It's shocking. So there are things in America that exaggerate, so I can give a lot of criticism. But this one thing, I was like, "This small city hall, we have to do everything in seven languages," and I think that's great.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: Born, your story reminded me of just in capturing and really hearing people's voices. I think the richness of recordings and videos or whatever technology was available at the time. I went to Holocaust Museum a few years ago and they were thousands of... They projected a person sitting there telling their story about the Holocaust. It's really emotional when you can hear someone recount their own story. And it was an interesting intersection of using technology to even recreate things, which I have very mixed feelings about, but how to think about that to really bring a live stories that otherwise might be lost.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: For me, I think before this experience, I never think about the importance to keep the memories as the war as she mentioned. Because recently I went to this museum with my son and it was really emotional for me. My son was happy because he love this history. And how we can keep all these memories from the future, also, I never think about this, but the importance because also for me, I live in at all this change from... When I was in the university, we didn't have internet, for example. And then I leave all these things, I am not like at all. But yes, it's important for the future and I never thinking that until now.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Any others connections, sharing you want to do? So this is open part of the conversation. Just like what are you hearing, what are you taking away, what are you hearing from what is in these conversations? So it doesn't have to be necessarily in your experience, but it could be making you think about bigger issues or whatever. But what are you hearing in people's experiences?

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: I think the thing that I hear most is the fact that we really have more similarities than we do differences. And so that when you can sit and talk with people, you understand that there's a lot more in common than there is that... I just said the same thing again in two sentences. But that thought is that as you explore that and as you converse, and you look at history, and you look at culture, there's all these different ways that we're kind of bound together where, "Oh, we have a pancake in our culture too. We use it this. It's mooshy over here." "Well, this tortilla from where I come from." Or, "Over here, it's a wrap, but we call it different and this is how we say it, and we make it with this thing."

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: And so that there's these connections that we have that are things that bind us. And if we look, we can see that poverty is an issue everywhere. And if we look, we can see that communication is a problem everywhere. And if we look, we can see that inequality is an issue everywhere. And so that we start to look at shared misfortune or shared goals around changing our lives, we all need the advancement of technology, but will the technology actually help us to revitalize our lives?

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: Or will technology actually mean that civilization is advanced, as opposed to technology just being something that comes along and we're still in the same place that we were? How do we use that technology in a different way? And I'm trying to think of an example that I think it's like we can get metrics. And metrics are wonderful for telling us stories, but metrics don't deal with people.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: How do we deal with people? How do we get someone to make the metrics human? And how do we deal with people in a way that the metrics become something that are personable, human, valuable, that does change all of the quality of our lives? And so I think that's the thing that I noticed through whatever we were talking about, very different approaches to coming at the same thing, but it's all about humanity.

nodes.speaker: Allie
nodes.words: Yeah, I appreciate that, everything you just said and I share a lot of those same questions. I guess pivoting, I feel very aware of all the pain and maybe fear and sadness in everything everyone shared, which is interesting because the question had nothing to do with something maybe bad and how will that change in the future. But I think where a lot of us went to. So I think just thinking about how people's lived experiences and the pain drives people is so embedded in what they want and want to change. But then on the flip side, also thinking where is the joy and optimism, and things? And how to weave... I don't know. I'm not as coherent, but weaving those together.

nodes.speaker: Daphne
nodes.words: Okay. For me, as I recognize the importance to make these kind of questions because maybe it's not because I don't like this question, but maybe I don't like the answer or there are not a real answer. I am used to have almost always an answer for my questions because it's like abstract. I don't know how to say in English. It's like a objective and not subjective. And then it's different, I feel something different because I am not used to make me these questions without answer, or to think about the future. I don't know what is important.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: That's real. That's very true. It's very uncomfortable to have that ambiguity. But again, just taking off from where you started, I think it's interesting that pain or the trials that we go through, it's interesting that everyone's response was to make things better. Like it's not to, "We suffered, so everyone else will suffer." So that's the interesting thing, that's the beautiful thing that we don't want people to go through the same things that we've gone through, I guess. So that's what I'm taking away from this.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: And their future can be better. Somewhere embedded in the answers is that in the answers, that there's a hope that something can change. There's a lot of fear, there's a lot of questions, but there's hope that there's potential for transformation. And maybe our questioning of what our role is in that is how can we feel alone in this fight sometimes that you think you're the one who's changing things. But maybe there are other people that are also looking to change things. And maybe if we found each other, then that'll make things a lot easier to transform.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I should say at this point too. It doesn't have to be around, you can riff off of each other at any point in time. Loosen up a little bit.

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: Can we flip the question? Can we flip the question? Can we play with the question? Okay. When we talked about our future is it was more like the fear, but what are the things that they're hopeful for? What do we hope? What's a good thing that if things work out, what can we imagine it would look like?

nodes.speaker: Dianne
nodes.words: A change of heart. So hopefully, the trial that we're going through in my country invigorates people to think critically about how politics shapes their lives and how to be less disengaged. And to think of it less about we have complicated politics, and sometimes it's very, what we call tribal and very ethnicity-based. And maybe to detach ourselves from those identities and to think of ourselves in terms of what's good for me and what's good for my people, my people being my fellow Kenyans and my fellow human beings, what's the best thing for us? And maybe that can happen in five years and we'll have a great president, and we'll have great transformation.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: I love this question. Why don't we go around, everybody respond to that and that's how we'll close out? And whatever language you want.

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: Yeah, I like that thought. It's basically saying what if we were all really looking at each other as a human family on the planet as opposed to groups?

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: When you were talking about Kenya, if we put down, "I'm this group, I'm this group, I'm Igbo, I'm this, I'm that," that we're just the people, right?

nodes.speaker: Born
nodes.words: So if in a more perfect world, I dream of a place where we're all one human family, and that we look at each other like a human family, and so that we treat each other different cause we're family. Because you're going to do it differently if it's your mom, your dad, your nephew, your niece, it's different. And so I think the world that we would have in that place or in that space, in that time would be a really good place because we wouldn't be concerned with flags, or borders, or anything. We'd just be family.

nodes.speaker: Ceasar
nodes.words: Others? Okay. This is where we close out. I want to remind you that we did record this. We will upload the recording. You'll get a link so you can go look at the transcript. Actually, for the rest of the class, Dmitri will actually talk me through what that looks like and you'll see it. And I just want to thank you. And with that, we will officially stop. We'll probably debrief in there, but if there's anything you want to offer up about the conversation and experience, please feel free to.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Great, so welcome everyone. The purpose of our conversation today is create a new space across the city to invite people to join small group facilitated conversations. Share their hopes and concerns about living in the city, and create a new space for listening across differences, across experiences and divides. Our goal is to focus on personal stories drawn out of your own lived experiences. It's not about sharing opinion statements or facts, it's not about finding points of agreement or deciding who's right or wrong, but it's a space for us to share our own personal stories and experiences. The conversations are going to be recorded. They will be kept and transcribed so that we are able to review together how the platform works and how do we engage in making sense of these conversations as they're happening in scale. I need to read to you a consent text before we start and I'd like you all to review and say if you agree to be recorded.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: So as a participant in this conversation, you're providing consent to Real Talk in Boston to use and retain the recording in according to its mission. You also understand that the realtor conversation will be part of a collection of local voices whose mission is to foster conversations in communities that improve our understanding of one another. And the Center for Constructive Communication will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with admission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, "I agree."

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Okay, great. Thank you. So before we start, we always introduce a set of conversation guidelines that will be our agreements for this dialogue going forward. So I'd like to invite you to speak out of your own experience. Use I statements instead of we statements. Listen generously, assuming good intentions while also recognizing that your words can have an impact. Share the time, take turns, allow others to speak and be heard. And stay curious, asking honest questions. So is everyone on board with these guidelines?

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Okay, thank you. So now that we know what our goal is today, I'd like us to do a quick round of introductions and we're going to do a check-in using the PIES framework. And if you remember, we did that in some of our earlier classes and PIES stands for physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually. And I'd like to invite you to choose one of those two to check in. So please share your name, which place you call home, and then check in with one of the four elements physically, intellectually, emotionally and spiritually. And whoever is ready can start us off.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: So physically, I am feeling good, feeling rested and well-fed this morning, which is great. Intellectually, I'm feeling also good, engaged and interested in all this stuff going on right now. So feeling grateful for that. Emotionally, I'm feeling very distracted because my best friend's husband, his cancer just came back stage four.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: Which is really, really scary and I have no idea what the survival rate is for stage four colon cancer. So we've all been texting to try to figure out how to support her and that's been very distracting this morning. And so spiritually, that's also weighing on me though, otherwise things are good. And I feel like I've had some grounding conversations in the last few days that have made me feel good until this news came up, so. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: Hi, I'm Karma and I'm from Bhutan. Physically I'm good. I went for long walk yesterday, the weather was nice. Intellectually, I feel I've like absorbed a lot and I've reached my goal, which I've set before coming here for this fellowship. And now because the program ends, it's due to end towards the first week of June, I mean May.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: So yeah, so I'm feeling good, but I think that it's... I feel like I just came here yesterday. And emotionally, I'm in a good state. I'm in a good state because I'll be seeing my daughter soon. And spiritually, I'm in a good place too. Yeah. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: Hi everyone. My name is Rukan. I come from China. Physically, I feel a little bit sleepy because I didn't sleep quite well yesterday night. Intellectually, I feel a little bit overwhelmed because recently, I have been checking with flight tickets between China and the United States. Emotionally, a little bit nervous, I would say, because yesterday I bought two tickets, but from travel agency, but I pay the order. But they told me since the price of the fly fluctuates, they cannot accept my order and they are give me a refund.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: Yeah, yeah. No, because China reopened just this year. So there is a lot of Chinese who plan to travel between China and the United States. That's why the price of the flights can be a [inaudible], can cost me like $3,000-

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: ... which is probably a little high. And spiritually, I think I'm slowly working on that and hopefully my family can visit me in the late April. Because during the time, means China Federal holiday. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: Hi everyone. I'm Valinda. Physically, I feel okay. A little tired as well. Just lots of running around and stuff on the past few days between my regular routine and then preparing for this air quality summit that we're having later tonight. So it's a lot of last minute logistics and stuff. So then I think intellectually, emotionally, spiritually, all related because then I'm just feeling all over the place and trying to make sure that we have all the details sorted and corralling everybody to make sure that we have everything covered. So that's how I'm feeling. And then, I think I'm also super relieved knowing that tomorrow's Friday so that I could take a little bit easier after this.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: It's exciting. Nice. Thank you all for checking in. Usually these conversations, we ground those in people who live in the city of Boston. But I understand that this group is diverse and not everyone has experienced living in the city of Boston. So I'm going to tweak the question a little bit. So I'd like to invite you to think what is your question about the future of your local community? Whatever you understand under this can be your local community here or your local community back home, and your place in that future. So I'd like to invite you to take a few moments, think about it. You can take a few notes if that's helpful, and formulate a hope, or a concern or a challenge into a question. So I'm going to repeat the question again. What is your question about the future of your local community and your place in that future? And as soon as anyone is ready, feel free to start us off.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: Yeah, I can go first. I come to the United States last August and first question that Boston gave me is it is modern city, but I would say, is public transportation is not as good as I expected. I mean, the environment of the subway is sometimes not clean. And also this is 100 years ago, their facilities can be outdated. There is no fence which can protect the passengers from falling to the subway, which I find is quite scary. Because inside China actually, the subway is always on time and also there are fence, double fence between, it's between doing different subways so that it can keep, even though sometimes can be crowded, that passengers cannot accidentally fall into the subway. I mean, fall into the slots which I find quite scary.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Great. Thank you, Rukan. I couldn't agree more about public transportation. Who would like to go next. Liz, you seen ready to go?

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: So I would say my local community is Boston, more specifically East Boston. But for Boston General I would say how can we protect everyone in Boston from the environmental issues and have it be as fair as possible?

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: So one thing that's on my mind is on air pollution because of, in East Boston, the way East Boston is situated geographically, really close... Well, the airport is our neighbor, so there's emissions from cars coming in and out of Logan airports, emissions from the planes. There are truck routes all around through East Boston. And also, a lot of trucks go through East Boston to different neighborhood areas like Chelsea Revere because of industrial reasons and purposes. So all those emissions, higher exposure to extreme pollution is associated with higher rates of COPD, asthma, cancer, heart disease, there's a whole list, lower IQ, lower school performance.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: But it's very different comparing that part of Boston to maybe another part of Boston that has more trees or doesn't have as much traffic or doesn't have an airport in its backyard. So that's one thing with air pollution and other things too. Now we're going to have a substation in East Boston, which helps with generating electricity too, and delivering that as a source of energy. But it's situated in a very dangerous part because it's right near a school playground, right near jet fuel. And in other areas where our substations are, there's always that risk of explosions. So it's not really fair to have all these things concentrated in particular areas.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: Well, I was thinking this and wondering, and I especially was thinking about it during lockdown in the beginning of the pandemic, which is how can we get to know our neighbors better? How can I get to know my neighbors better? I think living in the city, I find that I frequently just accept that I don't know who I'm living closest to and in a disaster, that suddenly feels like a big problem. So thinking about how could we get to know our neighbors better to improve our resilience in the face of emergencies or whether that's climate issues or social issues.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: My question is it's because I work at the land agency, I'm always thinking about land, land, land, land. So I've been always thinking about how can reuse land to generate revenue to fund the community or the urban developments taking place in Bhutan. Let's say just one, maybe I'll take one region, one district. So what I've realized after coming here was that I think land-based financing is largely absent in Bhutan. So I feel it's time we wake up that sleeping giant and then see how we can use land.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: Because we are formulating land policy, the first level land policy in Bhutan and Bhutan is currently in a very bad state economically. I think most of the civil servants in Bhutan are now leaving their jobs and then going to Australia. So I don't think we are in a very good situation. So I was like, "Now, what can I do in my place to at least contribute in a very small way towards this urban redevelopment in Bhutan?" And which can actually maybe help address these issues in Bhutan. Because what I feel is one reason why they're going is because it's prominent in other developing countries as well. The income for the public servants are very low. And I think the entire GDP of Bhutan is less than $3 billion. It's very low. So more than affordable... I've always come up with this issue of rental housing and homeownership.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: You may give these civil servants rental housing, affordable rental housing, but then what they need is a generation wealth that they can at least give it to their children. So what they are looking for is homeownership. So maybe now I'm trying to come up with interventions and strategies where we, as a civil servants, we can use state land and see and come up with innovative strategies. I'm now doing, my professional affiliation at Habitat for Humanity, I love their work, what their game is so good. But mine will be focused towards the civil servants and see the interventions towards coming up with homeownership for the civil servants.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Thank you all for sharing your questions. And I would like for the next question to just have the opportunity to understand why you came up with these questions. What is an experience in your life that led you to that question? So maybe you can focus on the moment on the story, something that can help us understand why this question and this topic is important to you. So again, take a moment to reflect and as soon as you're ready you can share your own experience. And Liz, you seem so ready.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: Yes, if you want to go back in order. Well, it's what I've alluded to, I think in the pandemic during lockdown, realizing I lived in a four-storey walk-up in Back Bay on the fourth floor. And so, there was a store on the ground floor. And so there were six units, I guess, in total. So I had five neighbors and I had interacted maybe once briefly with one of them. And that just suddenly felt scary to realize how few people I knew nearby. All my friends live in Cambridge and Summerville. And so, distance just felt very different during lockdown. All of a sudden this idea of... I was biking around, especially as the weather got better. But all of a sudden close proximity just had a very different feel to it.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: And I think especially in the Trump presidency, as things got scarier and scarier at various moments, especially once during the movement for Black Lives in Boston and the state started rolling out tanks on Newberry Street outside my house. And I was like, "Wow, I mean am totally on my own." I lived alone. None of that. But I don't even like my neighbors. I mean, once I did interact with them, I was like, "You are not who I need in a disaster." So just thinking about this, how can I be in more community with people in close proximity in a way that makes me feel like we have a shared investment in each other if something goes down? Honestly.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: Well, I sometimes heard news saying that maybe the subway in New York is now safe. Sometimes they are gun gunshot, sometimes they're like middle-aged women being pushed to the slot of the subways. So I know this is the rare case that happened, but it's giving me impression that maybe subways not a place which is safe enough. And also during the winter break I visited Los Angeles, I would say the transportation of Los Angeles is much worse compared with Boston. A lot of the homeless people just live inside the subway because it can provide them with a shelter from the sun, from the rain. So I mean, every time I went into the subway I see homeless people. I feel awful and also scared. I'm afraid that they come to me and be rude. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: Okay, I can go next. Actually, it's because I really like this. I don't think I'll say I like this, but the reason why I took this initiative of... I mean, this initiative was because it's through my own experience as well. Help me articulate it. I can see how my friends are doing, my colleagues are doing actually all because they're public servants too, and the challenges that they are facing. I live with my parents. I don't have to pay my rent my. I'm a single mom, but I have my parents and because she's only the grandchild in the family, they can help me with the expenses of the child. But what I've seen my friends going through is they need to pay the rent, they have to pay the loan for their cars, they have to pay for their kids educational, they have to have education too.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: So the expenses are really high and I can see they're... More than 60 to 70% of the income is... They don't have savings. So yeah, I think that is one reason why they are now leaving the job and then going to Australia. And when going to Australia, doesn't mean they get a good job there. They go there because of the value of the money here and the jobs that they do there... I'm not looking down at the jobs, but I'm just trying to see what if we as... If the policy makers can come up with great interventions and try to come up with retention policies.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: And then I was thinking, "Yeah, why didn't the government do that?" But the government doesn't have money. In terms of funding for the infrastructure or the urban developments in the country also, we are, I think, largely dependent on external aid. So that is why I thought or maybe let's see how we can try from... Through land-based financing maybe I think this could help. So that's why I'm trying to see how I can, in my very small ways, intervene from this approach here. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: Yes. What got me to this question? Well, when I was pregnant with my second child, my prenatal anxiety was really bad. And then, I would spend every day waking up thinking about, "Oh, it's so hot right now, can I open the windows?" But then the air quality today isn't so good because of how the temperature is and [inaudible] the direction of the wind and where it was blowing. And then, it was also during when I was working from home, so I was only really home and not really going to the office to be exposed to other things and stuff. So the areas I would go to were very limited and I would take my oldest out to the playground as well because he couldn't go to daycare. And then, I would be looking at Google Maps and researching all these things and reading these studies about how ultrasound particles can be detected, the utero and all these different health issues.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: So I would say that what got me to this question is through my experience of those nine months of pregnancy and worrying every day and how it affected something where if I could open a window, it just felt so ridiculous that I had to think about that. And then we were also thinking about moving outside of East Boston, but then it was also really impossible to figure out housing and all that. So it was definitely a combination of feeling like I was trapped and I couldn't really go anywhere and I couldn't really do anything, and I didn't really know how else to get my mind off of it.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: The reason I ask you to save this for later, because for this round, I'd like to invite you to find someone whose question or experience resonates with your own life. And then address that person and share what part of their question or the experience resonated with your own life. And then you can also ask that person a question. So Liz, you can go if you're ready.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: I would love to know more about all of your experiences in these things. I was going to ask you because I feel your passion for this civil service and I share that interest. And so I'm curious, I was going to ask you what drew you to working in the civil service? What makes you so passionate about working for the public?

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: I think that's just the... Okay, so I'll be very thin. So right after you grad your graduation, we have to set for the civil service examination. So I think there will be around 3000 students, I think, hopefully. And only 30 seats, will be the first 30 will then be taken into the civil service.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: Yeah. So I was within the 30 and I got into the National Land Commission. I think the main reason my... I think what really intrigued or what really made me really passionate about this work is because our agency is directly... We are an autonomous agency and we have to report it directly to his majesty, the king. So having this opportunity and the privilege of working under his majesty is... I think working on this majesty's guidance, we were really, I think, I'd say lucky because I've seen how much he would really put himself in the forefront of everything. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: So we don't have any landless people in Bhutan. So if you don't have a land, you can just appeal and then you'll granted a land. But the tenure ownership of land in Bhutan is you have private land as well as state land. So the state land is under, as per the constitution of Bhutan, it's under... Since the head majesty is the head of the state, so the whole governance and administration is under him. But we look after all the governance and administration. So because now I know how the state land governance is in Bhutan and the means of allocating and... Basically, I know the whole governance system of state land in Bhutan, I can see there's no possibility of addressing this housing issue through this state land.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Not everyone has to go for this round, but if you find someone who's question or experience has resonated with your own, feel free to address that person and ask anything. Yeah.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I want to talk with Belinda because I think air pollution is also serious issue. When I was back in China, I remember when I was young, especially during winter, we rely on burning coal to generate heat. So every time during winter we can barely see it blue sky. And also back that time, maybe a decade ago, the government didn't put much emphasis on the air quality. They only want to develop their economist to generate some interest. It was not until recently when Beijing, especially big cities, they're trying to move their factories to the rural area all moving to the nearby countries. I don't think it's a good idea. China is moving their countries to the nearby South Asian countries sometimes [inaudible], Malaysia.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I think government should figure out a better way to deal with the air pollution problem because it's going... I think it's going to take a step by step approach maybe several years before they can prove such air quality before we can resee the blue sky. And also when I was young, I remember during winter, I constantly cough and it was not until that I moved to the south of China, a city in the Hunan province because it rains a lot during winter, no matter it's winter of summer. But I suddenly realized, "Oh, it's not the problem of my health is the problem of the air polluting in the north." Yeah, yeah.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: Yeah, yeah, it's really interesting hearing about that experience because you're actually... Sometimes it's for some people they can't... There's this disconnect because they're like, "Oh, well, I don't see anything." Or they do see some signs where they're like the air's little darker or grayer, but it's hard for them to see, "Oh, well, how does this affect me if I'm not coughing?" Or unless they know somebody. But then it's hard to prove it or know, "Hey, this is the cause and this is the effect." So that's really-

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I think it's a good... Yeah, I think the good news is there's less this kind of wind through the peer were developing their second industries. And they are moving their second industries to other developing countries. I mean, there used to be his in the sky actually [inaudible]. And people by that time, especially in China, in Beijing, people are used to wear mask even before the COVID because they want to protect themselves from air pollution.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I also think maybe developing countries can learn from developed countries, gain some experience that how to develop and economy while new simultaneously protect the environment.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: Yeah, yeah. And how do we give people and companies incentives or make it so that they understand the importance or how to do that kind of work. Yeah. Thank you for sharing and asking. Anyone else wanting to address someone and yes, ask a follow-up question?

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: Well, I have been curious about, because in Back Bay, I'm always curious like, "Oh, I wonder if neighbors know each other and stuff." Whereas on my block it's like I know everybody's names, and kids, and how old they are and if they're going on a trip. So it seems like a very different kind of community. So I was curious-

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: More about the neighbors and more about things that you were like, "Oh, okay, now I know who you are. I don't really want to interact with you or interact with you as much."

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: Yeah, totally. And I think being downtown is... So I can't speak for other parts of that. I was on Newbury Street, which was is cost wise, more available to me than other parts of Back Bay. And so I can't speak for where maybe there's a lot more homeownership in Back Bay. But people, I felt, in my building were very insular and very clearly independent. So you could immediately tell that they were not of a collective mindset. So if we engage in conversation, it was very cut short, very much so. I mean, I don't know what their political leadings were, but I would get the sense that they didn't necessarily share mine. And the person below me, I once... I mean, it was the pandemic. I got an electric drum set, which is electric, but it still makes sounds when you're hitting the base pedal. And I didn't properly put padding underneath it, and the guy below me came upstairs, it was like 8:30 PM it was late, it could be 9:00 PM, not so late.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: But I get that he wanted to go to bed early, but he banged on my door and then just screamed at me and walked away. And I was like, "Dude, we are neighbors." It was a few weeks into lockdown and I was like, "This is not a good sign." So it was just the way that we interacted. And then, I remember during the biggest protest for the movement for Black Lives, when people were protesting downtown and then moved down Newbury Street. There was a number of... I saw the Zara window get smashed from my window and the guy next to me on my floor, and he knocked on my door and he was like, "They're coming, are you going to be okay?" I was like, "Yes." I' like, "What?"

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: And I was like, "Oh my God, who are these people?" So it was like we were just so not on the same page. And I was like, "We are not going to be in solidarity with each other." And I mean, yeah, I don't live in Back Bay anymore, but I was like... I'm sure that's not true for every building in Back Bay, but it felt like people there were looking for a certain kind of consumerist independent lifestyle and I didn't share that view. So, yeah.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: We heard from everyone, so many different stories, so many different experiences. And I wonder what are you hearing in people's experience? Anything that is coming up for you in terms of maybe commonalities, or differences or just surprising things that you learn from each other Today?

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I'm amazed by people have a different experience. I make sure that I maybe have never thought of it, like how to use the land property. Maybe I am not maybe old enough or not experienced enough at the stage, but they actually put up with a very important issue for parents, for mothers who have kids. It is also they have to concern lot of things.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: I also haven't thought about this topic either and the work that you do. So that was really cool, hearing more about it and why it's important to you.

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: I think it was really interesting to hear about your perspective on the public transportation here through your eyes. And my understanding is that in China... And I've been to Seoul most recently and it's beautiful there just such good public transportation. So seeing it through your eyes and understanding how you perceive it, I think I get used to it and I feel like hearing you talk about it makes me want to demand more for our public transportation. And so, I appreciate that reminder to have higher expectations.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: I can understand and I can also feel the culture shock because I remember once I time I talk with my one of my American friends, he told me, "United States is a country which is built on autos, that's why the taxpayer are relaxing to spend their money on the transportation because only the poor people who would use public transportation more frequently."

nodes.speaker: Liz
nodes.words: But I think it was interesting just to say I feel like, especially with your story, and I feel it's such a powerful personal story. I could feel your anxiety and it's so genuine and so well warranted. And I feel like a lot of all of you have... It's coming from a real and personal place that whatever those concerns are, it's good to always... Really powerful to hear just the real concerns that people bring into these issues.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: And I think these concerns are... I think the experiences everybody shared on stable is not just limited to within your own, I think community, but it transcends to beyond national boundaries, then internationally. I think it's a problem that... It's a global problem. Air quality, housing issues, transportation, everything, I think, that's what I've realized. You're bringing everything, it's a shared problem. That's all I've realized. Because I've experienced what you guys are experiencing too.

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: It's almost time for us to wrap up the conversation. And before we do, I'd like to go around and each of you can maybe share a takeaway or a thought that you'll be caring with you for the rest of the day or maybe the week. And you don't have to talk about any specific experience, but something maybe like a feeling, or something that you learned or something that you realized. Maybe one closing thought from everyone before we wrap up.

nodes.speaker: Karma
nodes.words: I think because I'm a very positive person, and when I talked about this problem of housing, homeownership back home and Liz, everyone was like... Y'all were very, I think, asking questions and showing... That means you had interest in my topic and which again, gives me this boost to again, do more and drive more I think into this. Thank you.

nodes.speaker: Rukun
nodes.words: And this conversation makes me realize communication is very important. When government officials may trying to make a decision, they really... They need to, and highly recommend to listen to people's ideas because different people have diverse background and have different opinion on issues. So if they want to make a plan to make people's life better, I think they should listen to their people.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: We're looking into it. Because I really am very interested. I got an air quality sensor for my indoor air quality and started obsessing over it a little bit. So yeah, I just want to look more into that.

nodes.speaker: Valinda
nodes.words: I love that. One thing that's on my mind after this conversation is how do we have these conversations like this outside of a structure like that? Because I don't think I would've heard these questions and the things that you all shared if we weren't prompted and-

nodes.speaker: Dimitra
nodes.words: It's great that I learned so much from each one of you. So what we will do is I'm going to stop recording now and... Oh.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Okay, I confirm that all the participants said they confirmed the consent to record this conversation. So a quick round of introductions and check-ins. I've already told you who I am, so let's start with you.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: We're going to check in, excuse me. We call it PIES, physically, intellectually, and emotionally. Choose one. Or spiritually. Or, I like to say for those of us who don't talk about spirituality, consciousness.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: My name's Rebecca. I would say emotionally, I've been all over the place, but trying to ground myself by just doing some basic self-care things that I have been needing to do for a while. I went to a doctor's appointment, so things like that.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Well, we have a choice of checking in physically, intellectually, emotionally, spiritually, or people who don't use the word spiritual, they might want to say con consciousness wise.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you. We ask that when we go into the official Real Talk for Change conversation, speak for yourself and out of your own lived experience. Allow others to speak for themselves, share the time and allow others to finish speaking, we take turns. I say we, but I will not be a part of this, I'm just a facilitator. State curious, ask honest questions. Pause, take time for reflections. Six, listen generously. Assume good intentions while recognizing that your words have an impact. So the centering activity, we've done the pies, and I forgot that I was supposed to model a brief response. So physically, I'm tired as hell. I've been up since 4:30. I had to get on the road by 5:00 to get here. My daughter-in-law dropped me in Kendall Square at Tateis at quarter of eight. And then I decided I could walk over here because it said 19 minutes on Google Maps and I forget the Google Maps and I are not good friends.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: So I found myself going in circles, and I asked all these people who looked like students to me, what way to go. And it was like The Wizard of Oz where the scarecrow does this and Dorothy's like... And then I saw this man who was delivering water from Spring water company, whatever it is, and he said, "Girl, just go down here and take a left at the stop sign. That's building nine right there." I was like, "Damn, I've been looking around and he was here all the time." Okay, so sharing questions and lived experiences. Now this generally takes 15 to 20 minutes, even with four people.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: And even if you don't live in Boston, pretend that you do for this please. What's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? And you don't have to go in any particular order, whoever's ready first. Again, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in that future? There's going to be a follow-up question that I'll ask, and that is, what experience in your life got you to this question? So what's your question? A question, not a comment, about the future of Boston and your place in it and what experience in your life got you to this question.

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: Yeah. Just to know where to go. But the future of Boston is confusing for me. I feel like it's going in the right path, but as an urban planner, so I'm seeing it from that lens. So Boston is getting so congested.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Then let me push you as a facilitator. What is your question about the future of Boston? Even in that context, of the congestion.

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: Yeah, my question is, is Boston doing the right thing of bringing all people to the center, other than [inaudible] Boston?

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: Yeah. We're talking about making opportunity accessible to everyone. So we focus in... We're trying to make that happen, just the way we saying it, it's making opportunity accessible to all people. So we are making a lot of transit and lot of transit plan and lot of way to make it easy for people to reach Boston, downtown for example. But sometimes I feel it's the opposite. It's maybe taking the opportunities to people rather than making them coming to Boston every day. So yeah, and this is why my question coming from, why I'm seeing this tone of people coming every day to Boston, even for doing grocery. So why not to take some, I don't know. For example, if you're saying Kendall is a hub of technology and bio trucks and so on, we can create another one in, let's say [inaudible] I don't know. Or in East Boston, or I'm going to just say, near the airport, let's create an aerospace, something related, or I'm just saying. So this is the way I'm seeing it, and this is why I'm asking this question.

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: Because, is Boston going to going to grasp all these responsibilities of all this people needs? And the infrastructure is going down.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I can talk some. I think my question for Boston is, as a city, how will it capitalize on the energy of young people and...?

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I forgot. I guess my place in that future is doing what work I can to help educate through action, like how young and transient people can be involved in the development of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: Yeah. As I'm repeating it, I realize that's less of the important piece for me. And I say that, my experience that's led me to that is, as a transient person and someone who meets a lot of people who are coming here from college, from outside of Boston, and as someone who just traveled a decent amount, seeing some of the ways that Boston wants to develop and some of the gaps in it, a lot of times seem to be from stagnant and regulated because of its history of segregation. And it's a little bit of...

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: It's not as bad here as it is in other places, but there's a lot of restriction, again, based in the historical context of Boston being very puritan and the high cost of housing and availability for people to dig in. And so, I ask that question because I see a lot of young people who feel like they are here to get their education and then leave, or they're here to buy, as far as doing what they need to to survive and then move on to somewhere else. And it doesn't seem, in some of my previous experiences, that the city wants young people to stay and build in the city in the way that I think it could.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I don't think there's one experience, I think it's a collection of observations, specifically during 2020, of seeing a lot of the things that young people value being defunded when it comes to art and creative spaces, when it comes to just a lot of backlash and outcry about housing, when it comes to feeling like... Having conversations with people about cost of living and their adjustment to that, and knowing and seeing a lot of people who wanted to be in Boston for school or to learn or whatever, and then basically as soon as they had an opportunity, the pandemic to stop and reflect on what they were doing, went back home because it was easier for them to feel invested in. And some of that's a familiarity thing, and I can live with my parents or whatever it is. But making choices to not be here.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you. Ismael, can we go back to you? I'm not sure if I explicitly heard what your place in the future of Boston, what's your question about the future of Boston and your place in it?

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: My place in future of Boston maybe will be through academia, maybe continue doing research and learning from other cities experience. And especially I feel like, urban planners, we've been learning and doing a lot of techniques, like technical, not things. So we forgot about the social part. So maybe through academia and through my way of seeing Boston maybe outside of what I am now can help in the future.

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: My place in it. Are people in Boston going to be okay in the context of climate change? Is there hope? Where is there hope? And what is my place in trying to make it more okay? Does that cover the parts?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: I believe it does. The second part of that question or the follow-up is, what experience in your life got you to that question?

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: I think I'm very scared of what could happen in terms of climate getting worse. I think I'm more aware of it because I grew up in Cambridge, not in Boston, but the neighborhood I grew up in floods a lot, especially in rainstorms, not from the coast. But one result of that is that my basement got pretty moldy, and that made me really sick. This was more recent, but that made it really personal, kind of the health impacts. Mold from flooding, I know heat has so many health things, and I know those aren't felt equally. My neighborhood floods from the water from Belmont, which is wealthier and whiter. And so, it feels like a really real issue, and that it, I don't know, the fear of it also just getting worse because of climate change. I think sometimes, I feel like there's no hope and I'm not really sure where to find hope for that, just because it feels so big and vocal with factors that control it.

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: And then, when I think about my place in it, I think something I am wondering is, I have been affected by some of these things, but I also grew up in relative privilege from some groups. And so I wonder, is it my responsibility to be working for a city because I can access those spaces as somebody who's getting a master's degree right now? But then sometimes, I feel like... I had an internship with the city of Boston over the summer and I felt like it was just so slow. I really felt like there was not that much I could really do. And so now I'm kind of like, where should I be? Where do I have the right to be? Yeah. Sorry, I don't know.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Okay. My name is Rebecca and my question about the future of Boston in my place in it is, how will large institutions like MIT shape the economic and physical development of Boston, and what can I do to ensure that this process will be equitable as a student here? And the second question is...

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: Okay. So I live on campus, and the main thing that strikes me is how much construction there is going on all the time. So these multi-million dollar projects. We're getting a new music building, there's the College of Computing, there's a new architecture building, there's a new grad house. It's insane. And I just think about all that money and how exactly that's just, specifically changing Cambridge. Where Kendall Square and MIT are just a really large economic center, and anything that happens here has a large impact on anything that the residents of Cambridge and the economic landscape of it as well. And then I think just in general, I feel like I notice a lot of big plans going around in Boston, because it's kind of a biotech hub.
