Today I saw this enormous construction project and I was like, "Oh, what's going in the construction project?"

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: And the person I was talking to was like, oh, it's going to be more pharmaceutical and biotechnology businesses. And I guess, just in general, these are the things that I notice and are very much... I'm kind of in the MIT bubble, so these are the things that stand out to me the most. And I know with that comes a lot of concerns from residents, but this is land that has been used in the community. It's not necessarily supposed to just be for MIT's profit or something like that or MIT's development. So I guess, those are just my general concerns because I don't know what to do about that. As a student, I know I have a voice, but it's more like, how am I as a student going to say, hey, there are other ways that this development can be done that is not as, I guess, as much of a gentrifying force, and is including the citizens of Cambridge.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: So I don't know. It's something I worry about because, I feel like I'm part of the system even though I don't make these large scale decisions. But if I don't do anything about it or if I don't even think about it, that it's something that I should be thinking about because it's directly part of the landscape that I live in.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you, Rebecca. We're going to transition to our next phase of Real Talk for Change, and that is called Connecting our Experiences. So what I'm going to ask that each of you do is find someone whose question or experience that you just heard of the four of you, resonates with you and connects with your own experience with your own life, and address that person and tell them why their question or experience resonated with you and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience. So let's take a couple of minutes to think about that one. I may have exaggerated on a couple of minutes. Let's take 60 seconds, mostly because I can't sit still.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: All right, that's a full minute. Didn't it feel like an hour? Anybody is welcome to jump in. Ismael? You can wait. Somebody else may...

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I can, I can. Actually, it was about you and your experience on, your reflection on congestion. Do I have to answer this one a question too or...?

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Let's see. Address that person and tell them why their question or experience, and/or experience resonated with you, and share the story from your life that connects you with their experience.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: So when you talk about congestion or you ask about congestion, and specifically channeling, it feels like a lot of the congestion comes because Boston channels a lot of its traffic into downtown. So I moved to Boston four years ago, and I moved into Austin Brighton because that's where the internet said to move to and I forgot the internet is white. And a lot of the Black neighborhoods in Boston, they weren't even that far from me, but because Brookline juts in through Boston, there's very little transportation that goes through Brookline to get between where I live in Austin, Brighton to Dorchester and Mattapan and Roxbury and other Black communities in Boston. And so, to get there, I always have to travel into Boston, because this is before I was biking heavily, I have to travel into Boston and then out of Boston.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I also had a friend from college. We went to school in New York five years ago, he was one of the few people that I knew living here, and he lived in Quincy for a while, and then he lived near the Wollaston T station, which, it's like South Dorchester. And again, for me to get to him, even though it's not that far distance-wise, was an hour 75 minute, sometimes 90 minute trip taking the trains. Which is, that's not even me taking the bus. And he lives close to the train station and I live literally across the street from the train station. And so, since that time, I've gotten very into biking and it makes it a lot easier for me to take direct routes, and I can cut through Brooklyn now that I know the roads, and I can cut through Dorchester a little bit. But the roads there aren't really designed to bike well.

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: And in my work on community building outside of that, a lot of my experience has been trying to figure out how to set up hubs and set up engagement in specific neighborhoods of which, being in Boston, I feel like doesn't get highlighted. People talk about Boston having a dead night life and not having activities or not having things going on, and partially that's because the train shut down early, but also it's because it does feel like the city only recognizes the activities that are happening in the downtown area. The businesses that are happening in the downtown area, and the different neighborhoods that exist in the city of Boston don't necessarily get reflection or promotion or credit from the city of Boston unless it's outstanding to a different level. Yeah, I think that some of that is structural in how the trains and buses and things move always, like you said, funneling towards the center. But some of it also is marketing and space giving, where they're only highlighting the things that happen there, which is why everyone's attraction and attention goes there when they could diversify and split where they show.

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: I connected, Gray, with your experiences talking about both people here who are here just for college and their role in community, and then also related to COVID. I was doing some organizing work prior to COVID and some during it, but it felt really, very highly during COVID where people left to go home a lot. And because a lot of the young people in this organizing group, it wasn't just for students, but a lot of people were students, and it felt like discontinuous, kind of disjointed as people leave. And it's not really conducive to building long relationships, especially with people or groups who are based in Boston with people who've lived in Boston for a very long time and will continue to. And so it felt like, where is our place and can we really form partnerships with groups if the people in this organization are just going to keep cycling out every two or four years from school?

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: And I think, I hadn't really reflected on it this way until now, but I think part of the reason I paused doing stuff during COVID was, both because other stuff is happening in my life and its overwhelming, but also, I didn't really feel connected and then I didn't feel this ties of connection were strong enough to keep me doing that because of this kind of turnover. So that resonates and makes me also curious about your question that you said.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: I think I definitely connected with your concerns around climate change and how that impacts Boston specifically. I feel like a lot of the messaging that I see, I guess, right here, building nine, it's in a dangerous area anyways, and I feel like if there's any sea level rise, anywhere that's filled in is going to be some of the first places to go. So I guess I'm just concerned about, in terms of why this resonated with me, I feel like I don't really hear about it from, specifically MIT in terms of climate resiliency. I never really hear about anything that it's trying to do or how it's collaborating with the city of Cambridge or anything like that. I really only hear about that from student groups and activists, but I never hear about it from the people who have the funds and the actual institutional power to provide resiliency.

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: And I think that really stresses me out, honestly, because also I think MIT, in terms of their climate goals, I think they like to be carbon-neutral by 2050, which is still, in terms of goals, isn't the most audacious, especially for a research university that is doing so much technology work. So I think, I don't know. It stresses me out because it feels like there's nothing... I know so many people that are very invested in this at the school, and also hear about it from groups in Cambridge, but in terms of the people who can do things about it and have the power to set these large scale policies, I feel like I don't really hear about it, and it worries me. Yeah. So I'm sorry to hear that your house has mold also.

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: Yeah. Also, because of my background, so I see the flooding is an issue. Yesterday, I was watching a video of my country, the risk of my country into flooding. And I was surprised, it's a desert, but if the sea going to rise, there is lot of places that will just disappear. And the thing that, why I agree with you, like I said people, put themselves first. So if you go all over the world, the Maldives is the first place to go. And so people, they waiting for the first sign. Let's see what's going to happen in Maldives. I'm talking about sea, the horizon. But the flooding is another issue. And here in Boston, when I first started, I wanted to know the history of the city and I was surprised of MIT being like, reclaiming those land and a lot of other places and how the Boston reshaped over time.

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: And the thing that I was surprised also is, MIT is doing nothing about it. They did a study where they're trying to find out what are the most vulnerable places, and the basement that are having some issues, but I was just a study, nothing [inaudible] So yeah, I think I agree with this. Cambridge and Boston especially, and what's happening in the seaport, and invest a lot of money, and it's the most risky place to build. But when we coming to explain it as, we're getting money out of this, it's okay, because the developers were saying, we don't care. It's like, we're going to invest $2 million, and I'm going to get that $10 million in three years? I don't care. So we're valuing this crisis by money. And this is the thing that really, yeah.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Oh, that's right. That's right. You responded to Ismael, yes. Now, for everybody drawing connections, what are you hearing in people's experiences? It can seem like that's redundant, but now, this question is more, in some, if you can, are you hearing something? Any threads?

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: I feel a little bit of... Powerlessness seems too overwhelming. But there are big issues that we feel we don't have control over. And I think to some extent, all of us are doing what we perceive or what we feel is our part to work on and address those issues. But they seem very big, as an understatement, and a lot of our question about the city of Boston is for the entities or institutions that we exist in much bigger than us, how come we don't hear more from them in addressing these issues that are closer to their scale?

nodes.speaker: Gr3y
nodes.words: The organizations and institutions in the run. So City of Boston, MIT, city of Cambridge, developers. All these organizations have power in a much bigger way than any individual, and yet, so.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you. So again, what are you hearing from the experiences of the four of you? What are you hearing in those experiences?

nodes.speaker: Rebecca
nodes.words: I guess another thing, the thread that you guys [inaudible] connected about the people that are engaging and how to ensure that people stay inspired when they're trying to advocate for themselves and advocate for others in their community. I guess, I really liked the question that you posed at the beginning because I feel like our questions around institutions within your question was about the individuals, how can individuals be inspired? And that was a really good thread, I feel like I haven't thought about that too much. How to actually ensure that people can engage in advocacy in a way that feels meaningful and productive, is a really good question. So I really like that thread.

nodes.speaker: Anisha
nodes.words: I don't quite have all the words for this, but I think there's also a thread about being new to an area or being not, I don't know, not living our whole lives in Boston and still being in those same places where we grew up, I don't know. Something about different perspectives or experiencing the future of Boston differently through that. I'm thinking kind of in contrast with a lot of the stories is was listening to in the Real Talk for Change portal, where people have lived in their neighborhood for decades. I don't know, I'm not really sure where that's going, but that's something. That sort of thing.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: Thank you. And if you have more to add to it, let us know before we... Because the last thing is takeaway and closing thoughts. So for me, the takeaway is that these are important conversations that residents all over are having thanks to Real Talk for Change all over Boston, but it will expand to other areas. But this is a very good experience, I believe, for you as students here at MIT, some of whom live in Boston or visit Boston, and have serious concerns about Cambridge, where you are at the moment.

nodes.speaker: Zakiya
nodes.words: The next step for this is, we'll stop the recording, but I need to say that the reminder is that, it was recorded and it will be uploaded into Real Talk for Change cortico's local voice network. And students from MIT will key word it so that, if somebody goes on to the Real Talk for Change portal and looks at climate change, congestion, traffic, these conversations that you all had, this conversation among the four of you will come up. And that's exciting to me. And that's not hyperbole, I really think it's important that there could be a young person, younger than you all that says, "I want to talk about climate change but nobody else is." And then they somehow stumble into Real Talk for Change and find out, "Well my near peers, college students are talking about it. So maybe there is a way for me to enter this." And that's it for me. Is there any other thoughts about, before we close this out, what you might have been hearing or did hear in other people's experiences as you entered into this conversation?

nodes.speaker: Ismael
nodes.words: I think we share the same thing, which is a failure of humankind on managing the planet. So we all share the same way of thinking. And I feel it's, yes, I believe that it been before, different broadcasts and different audios and books that we read of some classes that happened back in time, but I don't think that we're learning. I'm not pessimistic, but the reality of, we have to start or at least stop thinking of saving ourself alone on this planet going to be the key. Because you hear some people trying to move from place to another to save their lives, from Cambridge on Northern Park to run from flooding.
